course_title: Black Art and the Refounding of America: Art, Race, and U.S. Law 001
best_comment: The night after our first class session for AAAS 112, I wrote in my journal that I think Professor Lewis is going to be one of the best professors I've ever had at this school. Her wisdom, and more importantly, the breathtaking vulnerability and sincerity she gifted us that day, made me profoundly admire her and want to be like her as a professor and as a human. Class after class, my admiration for her only continued to grow! She brilliantly designed this class to take us on a historical journey across the United States and its use of race for discrimination and oppression, empowering us to tackle hard discussions as a group while opening up space for everyone to feel comfortable sharing their experiences and ideas. Doing this through the lens of art, one of the strongest tools constructing the social narratives all around us that uphold such negative societal structures, was mind opening. I greatly looked forward to our discussions every Wednesday morning, where we would engage in deep close readings of paintings or photographs, discuss the conclusions and implications of our readings, and saw each other grow in the depth and quality of our work. I feel extremely fortunate to have had this experience with Professor Lewis! She is one of the most dedicated, passionate and kind professors I've had at this school!

TAKE IT!!! This class is an absolute gem! The workload is not bad at all. The professor and TF were so kind and passionate about the topic, which makes the class even more enjoyable. I've never read this many African writers, and I genuinely enjoyed it!
subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: Africa in the Twentieth Century: Culture, Representation, and New Diasporas SEM
best_comment: Professor Ogene is fantastic, and the course really gives you a firm grounding for further engagement with African thought and culture by exposing you to many different items throughout the semester. Additionally, the course material is very interesting and classes, though in a small group setting, are not stressful at all. This is the ideal type of class for someone that is interested in a humanities course but is scared of the small group setting. Readings for the week take 2–3 hours at most, and Professor Ogene is always willing to work with you to further develop your own interests. Definitely take this course if you’re interested in the subject – you will not regret it!!!
subject: African & African Amer Studies
course_title_2024: Africa in the Twentieth Century: Culture, Representation, and New Diasporas

best_comment: If you are at all interested in African American Studies from a humanistic perspective, take this course. Like you may expect, this course will exercise your chops as a student of literature and history as you dive through a canon of Black American plays dating back to the antebellum era. Via this Black lens as well, you will gain a special appreciation for these works and the theater medium, more broadly. Moreover, you will also be given invaluable experience working with theater critically, an opportunity which is often missing from academic spaces.

If you are at all interested in African American Studies from a humanistic perspective, take this course. Like you may expect, this course will exercise your chops as a student of literature and history as you dive through a canon of Black American plays dating back to the antebellum era. Via this Black lens as well, you will gain a special appreciation for these works and the theater medium, more broadly. Moreover, you will also be given invaluable experience working with theater critically, an opportunity which is often missing from academic spaces.

This class had a lot of potential which made the disappointment stronger. I think there is hope and the course could be much better structured. But what I experienced was subpar. Having a class on this subject is incredibly important, which is why getting it right is important. There were few guided discussion questions and the conversations often led nowhere, stifling engagement with the text. The same people (overwhelmingly graduate students), spoke over and over again, and said few things of substance. The professor did not engage enough with the discussion to encourage critical thinking. Breakout sessions were not effective and wasted time, they had even less direction and would end quickly with students having nothing to say. There was no other structure to the course besides unguided discussion for three hours straight. This kind of experience turns people away from theory and academia and makes it seem like it has no purpose.The course assignments were very unclear. Because few to no requirements nor guidance was given, success in an assignment was nebulous, hard to understand, and hard to achieve. Additionally, because there were only two assignments, it was hard for students to learn from mistakes and improve. We had to  figure out for ourselves what a good paper looked like and what the staff was looking for. By the time we got our first feedback, 40% of our grade was finalized because there was only one other assignment left. Even after going to office hours, how to succeed in the next assignment was unclear. I'm not sure if this is how graduate level courses are intended to be, but since this course included first–years, the assignments did not feel appropriate for learning. Because there were few to none concrete guidelines given for assignments, grades were not assigned based on concrete mistakes or meeting the guidelines given. Even after soliciting more feedback in office hours, the course staff gave no concrete ways to improve in future work. I would encourage students to take other classes in race and gender studies, because they can be incredibly powerful and useful. If this course improves, I would encourage students to take it.

course_title: A Black History of Electronic Dance Music 001
best_comment: On top of its rich and engaging content focus, this course has an invigorating pedagogical approach that centers the voices of those in underground spaces who create electronic dance music and its surrounding culture. The readings inform and invite great class discussions!

I loved this course, but I must say it was the hardest class I've taken at Harvard. Professor Eatmon is one of the smartest minds a student at Harvard could have access too and I highly recommend anyone who loves history and Black history to take it. The only way to enjoy the course is to lock in and actually do the readings, so if you're having one of those semesters where you won't read, this class will become your worst nightmare. You should always come to class because professor takes very intense role call and you lose slight points for being late. She can be tough, but when you are in the class itself it feels very peaceful and leave feeling stronger as a historian.
Take this course! Super interesting and interdisciplinary. Dr. Williams is a legend in this field and a wealth of knowledge. Not very labor intensive assignment wise which is a huge bonus.
best_gem_comment: I feel like this is a very basic, introductory class to the social determinants of health. The professor spends the entire 2.5 hours lecturing, so if you want a class where you can be super involved, I do not recommend. Otherwise, the course material is interesting and the assignments are really easy, so if you want a GEM,  I would recommend this for sure.
subject: African & African Amer Studies

best_comment: It is an interesting class, and a nice opportunity to get familiar with some topics related to African studies.

This is a fantastic course! Be prepared for a lot of reading but the materials you'll encounter will make it well worth it. Dr. McCarthy is an amazing instructor who will prompt engaging discussion and make astounding connections between the texts.

This class is amazing. The small community in the class really makes it strong. You learn a lot while having a great time.  Adriaan is amazing! Really caring and helps you improve from day one.  Great class.
subject: Afrikaans

best_comment: There's definitely more of an emphasis on writing than speaking. If you're a true beginner, you're going to need to put work in outside of class. Other than that, this class is easy and rewarding.
worse_comment: It's hard to learn the language from this course because it has a lot of relevant information presented to you every week and it's hard to remember it all. Additionally, only one week is spent on learning the alphabet so if you don't take the time to learn it yourself outside of class and assignments, you won't learn it.
subject: Amharic

best_comment: This is certainly a Beginner course. Sometimes the pace can be quite slow. On the other hand, the workload is very manageable and you do slowly but surely make progress. If you are keen on learning one of the major Caribbean languages, then you should definitely make the most of the provision that the ALP offers.
subject: Haitian

best_comment: Have some patience with the professor. She comes from a job to teach the class, but shes a great, funny woman and is passionate about spreading the Igbo language. It's a harder language if you've never heard Igbo before, but I had never heard it and I was okay.
worse_comment: this was a TERRIBLE CLASS because professor Inky was such a bad and inconsistent teacher who would never take the blame for the mistakes she made. She would blame us for not getting assignments or projects in even though we didn't know we had them. she was just always harsh when it came to giving people time to understand the language. she was just a terrible teacher and you won't learn anything from her. we didn't even speak in igbo which is the whole point of the course. the tests were random as well. just don't take this class with her.
subject: Igbo

best_comment: If you are interested in Jamaica and the culture, take the course. It is best to learn with an intent of actually learning it. Kara–Sue is awesome and such a humble person, and has so many fun stories and ways of helping you learn the language and culture. Do not be scared of taking the class just because you do not have a relation to Jamaica. It is open to everyone and Kara–Sue makes it a welcoming environment.
subject: Jamaican

best_comment: I loved this class, and Professor Degaga has been fantastic in and out of the classroom. I strongly recommend enrolling in this class and investing time in learning the language and culture of the Oromo. For Oromo and non–Oromo alike, this language and culture is so meaningful and should be engaged with intentionally.
subject: Oromo

best_comment: Take this class!! It is very fascinating to learn about pidgin, and the way the course is taught ensures that you can learn the language well during the course sessions. Taiwo is also an amazing and knowledgeable instructor who wants his students to succeed.
subject: West African Pidgin

best_comment: Yoruba is a very fun and low–stress class, where you can definitely get back as much as you put in.
subject: Yoruba

best_comment: As an athlete who took this class because it met only twice a week, I got so much more out of it than I anticipated. My teacher Ntuli was incredible and cares so much about her students. It's just a fun class and great to a great place to bond with other students as well.
best_gem_comment: Ntuli is a gem and makes this class worthwhile.
subject: Zulu

best_comment: This course was a wonderful experience! Damina clearly put much time and energy into reading selection and assignment curation, and each step that we took towards our Junior Essay and/or future Senior Thesis felt purposeful. With a variety of assignment types, lecture topics, and guest speakers, this course definitely gave everyone something meaningful to take away, regardless of their interests/future career plans.
subject: Anthropology

best_comment: Take this class, it is hands down the BEST class I have taken at Harvard so far. The course isn't particularly intensive, it's a three–hour lab once a week, so if you are efficient in class, you can complete the majority of your work within class each week. (If you don't do the assignments in class, expect to spend 2–3 hours a week outside of class working). In terms of the assignments, they were all labs with associated lab write–ups. I have never had more fun learning about topics than I have in this class. If you're interested in anthropology or archeology, and you'd like to get some hands–on experience doing the work that field professionals do, I would highly recommend this course. Sarah is an excellent teacher who has a fantastic way of teaching without lecturing, and she was always available and ready to help with any difficulties. 10/10.

This is an amazing course.  This class affords the incredible opportunity to excavate on campus and develop archaeological skills needed for excavating, record–keeping, identifying artifacts, and understanding them through the lens of historical archaeology. You learn to engage more meaningfully with Harvard's history, and have the chance to actively contribute to our understanding of it via our findings. We also share our conclusions with the public thanks to public archaeology initiatives. Don't worry that this is a two–semester course; I am so excited to come back next semester to analyze and interpret what we have found. Trish (Dr. Capone) and Diana (Dr. Loren) and our TF Veronica are all incredible instructors, and are so passionate and understanding.

This is an amazing class! It was my first anthropology class at Harvard, so I would recommend it to everyone who are interested in anthropology and would like to learn more about the field. The readings are definitely not short, but they are all super interesting and are chosen very wisely so that you can build on the knowledge you learn earlier in the semester. There are a lot of full circle moments in the class, and if you put enough effort and time (going to class, lectures, section, and be on top of the readings), I definitely believe that it is one of the classes that change one’s perspective about the world, human life, and meaning. Also, Dr. Fierman is the best. She is very supportive and approachable, and I would recommend to go to her office hours!! Ashwin is a great TF and very supportive. I only have good things to say about this class, and please take it!!!
subject: Anthropology

best_comment: This is a really interesting course! Professor Bernstein is certainly a really brilliant person, though definitely quiet and a bit hard to reach via email, especially if you are an undergraduate :(. If you are looking for an intro anthropology course, or simply are fascinated by death the various roles it plays across the world and time, this is a perfect class for that. I found the students in my class to be incredibly motivated, and many had experience in the field, so it was great hearing them discuss. It's definitely a pretty easy class –– it is possible to get by the class by skimming the readings and vaguely participating in the conversations. There are two papers, but the topics are closely aligned to what we do in class, so they are not challenging if you keep up. With that being said, you get out of the course what you put in it, as with many other gems. The readings are super interesting, I found it to be philosophically and existentially satisfying in many ways, so definitely take this class if that's what you are looking for!
worse_comment: The topics of this class is great, but the execution of it was poor. Professor Bernstein appeared stressed the entire semester and since she let student led discussion take up most of the class, I did not feel that she contributed much at all to the experience. Most of my learning came from the readings and student led discussion, however these learnings were minimal. As someone who has taken many classes in religion/ the humanities, this might be been the most poorly executed humanities class I have taken.
subject: Anthropology

course_title: What Is Latin America? Politics, Culture, Identity 001
best_comment: It's great for people from a variety of backgrounds and Julia's a fantastic lecturer.
subject: Anthropology
course_title_2024: What Is Latin America? Politics, Culture, Identity

best_comment: pros:– great variety of topics in religion and a focus in the beginning especially on theoretical frameworks to understand religions– many readings that allowed me to branch off in interests– professor Bernstein + our TF Majid Dohan are great people to talk to one–on–one with interests on the course. cons:– week to week, readings sometimes felt a little dense and tough until they were broken down later in the class.– lectures sometimes left me still unsure of some of the main points of core theorists, especially towards the beginning half of the course. Secularization in particular was a bit confusing, and required me to re–read and re–engage with the material a couple times before I could confidently apply it in the later parts of the course and in my essays.– while I appreciated the open–endedness of the assignment prompts for the final research paper, I wished we had more guidance on example prompts or even just the type of paper and scope of argumentation that was desired from the first two smaller papers. – while this may not be a fault of the course heads themselves, encouraging student participation and motivation during discussion–related aspects of the course was tough. It was unclear to me whether this was out of lack of understanding the material, lack of comfort in the discussion space, or lack of piqued interest.
I would highly recommend this course to future students. The readings are interesting and will help them to better understand the theory.
I would highly recommend this course to future students. The readings are interesting and will help them to better understand the theory.

course_title: The Past Matters: Cultural Policies, Heritage Education, and Community Engagement. 001
best_comment: The class is great, but it is very discussion based. You really need to read the readings (and there are a bunch) to participate effectively every week. But readings aside, Sol is wonderful and fosters a great learning environment. The guest speakers were always a highlight and we often had snacks in class!

course_title: Theory and Practice of Social Medicine 001
best_comment: This is one of the best med anthro classes you'll ever take (or even more generally if you're interested in medical humanities/social sciences at all you should take this class)!! The faculty are INCREDIBLE and are so personable and accessible and make this class so fun. It is a lot of reading so be prepared for that but it is so worth it as everything was incredibly interesting and we had the coolest discussions all semester.

The good things: by far one of the most useful classes to take at Harvard. Independent of programming level, I feel like you learn SO MANY SKILLS that are simply so useful regardless of whether you want to do SWE or not. If any of your work remotely involves computers/coding/collaboration, it's so helpful to take this to learn git, learn how to systematize your files, it's been so helpful for research. Also the content is genuinely super interesting and I felt like the labs kind of forced you to engage with every part of the syllabus, so you genuinely become a much better coder.The bad things: this class is the biggest mess I've ever seen at Harvard. I didn't even know courses got to this level of disorganization, and I feel like that becomes even more painful in a class where your work *actually* counts a lot for your grade. Little to no feedback on HWs, it took like 2 months to have some type of schedule defined, project was completely chaotic and we got no feedback up to the final milestone. Very different to 109a/b for example, where it's much more structured. I think the staff is aware and I can imagine they make this better in future years, and I really hope they do, because the class is great and Ignacio is an amazing professor!
worse_comment: Materials but only materials are good. Other than materials, everything is messed up:1.A lot of important materials covered in previous years are not covered this year;2.So much confusion about deadlines, grading, submission, etc. It's very messy. There was once a student requested to fix the autograder, and then what the Professor/Head TA did was remove the autograder instead of fixing it. I was completely shocked by how they do things in this class.3.Everything the instructor added to the class is completely unreasonable. I spent 90% time trying to understand astronomy and only 10% time understanding the 107 concepts.4.The head TA doesn't respect anonymous posting on ED. If I post something there, they will reply to my post with my name in this. 5.Going to class is meaningless. The lecture is very boring.6.Please choose a good professor if you decide to take this class. I wasted 1/4 of my tuition on this class.
subject: Applied Computation

course_title: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science 001
best_comment: lots of work, but very fulfilling. if you have an interest in data science/analytics, this class is really great! it definitely helps if you already know how to code in python, but it's not too hard to learn as you go. lectures: pavlos and kevin are great lecturers imo and the slides are super good. sometimes they'll spend a while answering questions, but lectures are overall efficient and effectiveassignments: psets were mostly biweekly, but super long... be prepared to spend lots of hours finishing the psets. final project: LOVE THAT WE HAD A FINAL PROJECT INSTEAD OF FINAL EXAM! just make sure to work with people you know will get their work done or else you're left with a lott of work to do. milestones are nicely spaced out and definitely help with getting the project done early:)exam: midterm had in–class mcq portion and take–home coding portion. take–home portion was easier than the mcq by far. mcq was open note and internet, but was super hard lol make sure to study
worse_comment: AVOID THIS COURSE AT ALL COST. If you are interested in learning data science methods, I would suggest taking some combination of Stat 139/149 and MIT 6.3900, which will  be much more comprehensive and, more importantly, far less annoying as a course. This course assigned a lot of busywork, and it could feel like the staff did not have much respect for students' time (especially when they assigned a major project milestone to be due on the Monday after Thanksgiving break, and a homework due two days after that). It also often felt like the staff put in much less effort than it asked of students, and held itself to a much lower standard than it did the students. The assignments — and even the exams — were riddled with typos, coding errors, and other mistakes, and they were often very unclear in the way they were written. When asking questions, the teaching staff always led with a condescending tone, and were extremely unwilling to admit they had done something wrong — they would even gang up on students on Ed when one suggested that there was a mistake in an assignment. I and all of the other students I talked to were extremely frustrated with the course by the time December came around. I would not even wish this course on my worst enemy.
best_gem_comment: FGLI FYRE CERTIFIED undegrad RESPONSE: If you are interested data science, environmental science & engineering,  EPS, or any other concentration that requires some sort of research or handling of data, YOU NEED to take this course. I am a cs concentrator and THIS COURSE GOT ME MY FIRST DATA SCIENCE INTERNSHIP. It literally taught me everything i needed to know and i was so surprised at how vocational this course really is. This course is super organized on ed, slides are very pretty, lectures mostly easy to follow (not when kevin lectures im sorry). But i don't think i was ever taught anything that didn't matter you know? It all seemed important and very useful and helped me do really well in data science interviews. Problem sets were super easy for me im not going to lie. If you KNOW how to code this class is kind of breeze most times because you can get away with knowing the main idea behind stuff and the coding parts are very plug and chug and I wouldn't say I did any serious thinking. Final project is a little different because you don't have your hand held, but it was very manageable. Cs50 is DEFINITELY 100% ENOUGH. and if you only took an r course (like stat 100) you are 100 % okay you can do this and you will not regret it. I procrastinated on every pset. THey can take a fat minute to finish which is the hard part, and theres no clever solution or something that will save you time ya know? late days are a blessing too </3. I would say the first psets are difficult the rest was a breeze. I think the hard part comes when you have to interpret things or make decisions about the direction you take your models. THats where the true data science knowledge is applied I would say. ANyway, i took cs107, cs61, and this course at the same time with a gem! Extremely doable ladies trust me you got this.
subject: Applied Computation

course_title_2024: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science

best_comment: This was my favorite course I've ever taken at any institution. Please take it if you have ANY interest in machine learning, software deployment methods, or any of those tools you see on industry job descriptions (like Docker and Kubernetes). I will describe some specifics of why this course was so good:– The project specification was extremely clear. For a course with a semester–long project, this is critical. Pavlos, Shivas, and the team put a lot of effort into designing a reasonable project roadmap and thinking through all the steps and deliverables. We were never at a loss for what we needed to be working on for any given assignment. Also, the project deliverables were evenly spaced throughout the semester, and the project was designed such that students can use it for their professional portfolio.– The in–class lectures and demos showed a TON of hard work and preparation on the part of the teaching staff. I found the demos (and associated Github repos) to be incredibly valuable teaching tools. Pavlos always made sure the demo would work before class, sometimes testing it multiple times. – The content of the course is SUPER relevant to essentially any career or project in machine learning, and many other areas outside machine learning. I have looked for a course for years that would teach me Docker, Kubernetes, cloud platforms, Weights and Biases, etc. Many courses assume you know this material, and MANY companies require skills in these areas, but no other course actually teaches it. Pavlos saw that gap and created the perfect course to fill it. – The strategy of assigning each group to one TF was very effective, because it allowed each group to work with their TF to explain the unique features of their project, and not suffer from inconsistencies in grading between TFs.In summary, don't hesitate to take this course! Find a good group and establish good communication. I recommend a smaller group otherwise it can be hard to coordinate with everyone. Choose a relatively simple project with a less complicated model–– you will still have a very impressive project by the end of the semester.
worse_comment: This is a great course, but it is very disorganized. It is unclear where to find the code from class, as it is in GitHub repos that have to be accessed from the slides. The assignment requirements are unclear and are released only a couple of days before the due date.
subject: Applied Computation

course_title: Computational Science and Engineering Capstone Project 001
best_comment: The capstone course this semester showed some room for improvement in its organization. There were moments when our group's project seemed to lean more towards academic research rather than the anticipated industry–focused capstone experience. Progress initially felt sluggish, with the first three weeks dedicated exclusively to literature review. However, the course became increasingly engaging towards the end, especially when we delved into actual coding. This is somewhat expected when the project veers towards academic research. Nevertheless, I had hoped for a greater involvement of industry partners in contrast to the academic research groups.
subject: Applied Computation
course_title_2024: Computational Science and Engineering Capstone Project

best_comment: A unique class of sharing views, ideas, and how to improve the diversity and inclusion within the technology industry and beyond.
subject: Applied Computation

course_title: Computing with Python for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: I took so much away from this class and would recommend it with enthusiasm to anyone, especially those looking for a good intro to CS. I came in with zero prior coding experience, and left with a firm grasp of everything that was taught. It is pretty math heavy, and understanding the math is key to having a good time doing the coding on the psets. Luckily, the readings are REALLY well put together, and a close reading of them before the week's material is done in class is so helpful to making everything run smoothly. This class doesn't pull any tricks, you can really get a lot out of it if you put a lot in. I would hold off on taking this class if you aren't at least in math 21A concurrently – there is quite a bit of multivariable calculus. The teaching staff are lovely, I cannot say enough good things about them. Also, attendance is worth like 30% of your grade. This class really rewards showing up and doing your best work.
worse_comment: Entered with no coding experience and learned a ton. This class is more about coding to understand and demonstrate  mathematical concepts as opposed to programming.
subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2024: Computing with Python for Scientists and Engineers

course_title: Computing with Python for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: I took so much away from this class and would recommend it with enthusiasm to anyone, especially those looking for a good intro to CS. I came in with zero prior coding experience, and left with a firm grasp of everything that was taught. It is pretty math heavy, and understanding the math is key to having a good time doing the coding on the psets. subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2024: Computing with Python for Scientists and Engineers

best_comment: Take this class. It is amazing and you will learn so much. You need to be very focused and attentive in class and follow everything from the beginning. Always revise after and before the class and try to study during the workweek and understand the concepts really really well before starting the pset. The sets are not hard if you understand the concepts. Otherwise they seem very hard. The MATLAB part is the part you want to focus on the most because it gives you an understanding of the methods and applications of Linear algebra. Understanding those few problems is fundamental. When it comes to Shalom, the professor, he might not always be amazing in explaining and helping you get the intuition and visualize what is happening. Definitely use Gilbert Strang's lectures if you feel you need another perspective for understanding some topics. Getting some linear algebra or multivariate calculus books on GitHub for free could be veryy useful as well. Ali, the TA, is amazing and he will help you understand the topics very well and he is very patient when you are stuck. He will point out what you need to revise and learn. Definitely, go to oh even when you don't have psets to understand the topics better or learn more.
worse_comment: I find the class was poorly taught(i.e. it felt designed for students who had previously taken multivariable calculus and linear algebra and needed to fulfill the requirement). The office hours were excellent when run by Shlomo, but the TFs often either did not know the material or were unable to explain it. For the assignments it was not easy to do it based off of just attending class, and sometimes class was slow, and other times it moved way too fast. Frequently students (myself included) were utterly lost. If you are looking for what is allegedely a "better" class than 22A or 21B, I don't think this is the one (unless you don't want to show up to class and still get through Linear algebra).
subject: Applied Mathematics

course_title: Complex and Fourier Analysis with Applications to Art, Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: This course will be interesting and fun if you put in the effort and hours to really understand what is going on. The math is not very difficult, but you need to spend time understanding the reasoning and the theorems. It ended up having really cool applications to noise and filtering which I thought was interesting. The psets do take a while, but going to office hours really helps. The midterm was not hard and the final was take home so nothing horrible.
worse_comment: This is a good class, with a fair midterm (however, the midterm has very few points, so you could be penalized for small errors). The assessment structure is logical. The problem sets really vary in difficulty, with usually one very hard problem and the rest straightforward. Possibly highlighting the challenge problem in each problem set would be a way for this course to improve.
subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2024: Complex and Fourier Analysis with Applications to Art, Science and Engineering

best_comment: The course staff was the best course staff I've had at Harvard. Office hours were fantastic.I learned some cool stuff about computers as well, and Dr. Iams' problems are EXCELLENT.  I learned a lot of math. I became quite a bit more comfortable coding with NumPy and got a lot better with indexing in Python. The class is small, and everyone really likes math. So taking APMTH 111 is a great way to make friends. Some advice:1. Take the pre–class assignments seriously. You'll clear up some confusion you have even as you articulate your question, or at the very least, your posts will inform the course staff that you're confused about specific material.2. GO TO LAB. 3. Be on top of the project. Make sure you're understanding the basics of what you're studying.4. If you don't end up taking this class, PLEASE take another class of Dr. Iams'.
worse_comment: This is an interesting course, but not my favorite AM course. I would take if necessary.

course_title: Introduction to Optimization: Models and Methods 001
best_comment: Good, easy course. I wouldn't expect to learn very much, but some of the assignments are fun. I think the best thing I've come away with is an appreciation for thinking about real–world situations or other academic interests in terms of optimization. Margo is extremely nice and approachable. Lots of athletes in this class. The group projects are quite easy.
worse_comment: This class is structured in the flipped classroom model, which means that you are expected to teach yourself the material for the upcoming class and then work on problems with your peers during class. I'm sure this worked well for some students, but it was not so helpful for me. Much of the time, Margo would see that many students were confused about the same topic in the pre–class discussions, and go over the material at the beginning of the class. She would also walk through the in–class problems at the end of class; I found these explanations from Margo magnitudes more helpful than going through readings and problems on my own. So, just be aware the way this class is structured and be sure that the flipped classroom won't be an issue. Other than that, excellent course, and Margo is amazing!
subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Optimization: Models and Methods

best_comment: The class will teach you how approximations behave. This course changed the way that I look at so many systems, a perfect example is looking at dominant balance between terms in a PDE. It's a concept that seems so simple but I am surprised I had never seen before; it is the ideal introduction to applied mathematics for an advanced undergrad. The psets are pretty tractable with office hours, and there is a lot of time to do each one. Section materials are incredibly useful for solving problems in the class.
worse_comment: Take this class if you want to get an intro about approximations. Bare in mind that it may not be the best structured course you have taken though.

best_comment: The lectures are wonderfully engaging, be present and enjoy seeing a master at work! On a logistical note, make sure to do the homeworks well, because you'll get many more points from the homeworks than the quizzes.
worse_comment: This class is just a collection of buzzwords where dozens of topics are mentioned in a fly–by manner in lecture and nothing is taught in–depth and you don’t engage with 90% of the material in any context. Homework assignments have little useful applications of the material covered and the vast majority of the content is never touched upon in the homework. The professor is passionate and enthusiastic about the material but his pace of lectures is completely disconnected from the pace of students’ comprehension. I found lectures absolutely pointless for learning because nothing was explained in depth. We covered a million different topics in the span of mere weeks, some of which the other classes take the whole semester to build up to. This class was taught with the assumption that we’re already familiar with most of the material covered. The midterm exams tested our understanding of tricky topics from basic linear algebra instead of the actual algorithms discussed in class. Overall this was one of the worst classes I’ve taken at Harvard and a complete waste of credits in my senior fall. Unfortunately, it’s a required class for the concurrent SM degree in CSE so I had no choice but to take it. If you’re a practically–minded person looking to learn and engage with real useful applications of math, avoid this class.
subject: Applied Mathematics

course_title: Advanced Scientific Computing: Stochastic Methods for Data Analysis, Inference and Optimization 001
best_comment: Petros is a great lecturer! I think this class looks pretty daunting with all of the prerequisites it demands, but the main two that are non–negotiable seem to be statistics and Python. I have a decent background in both, so this class was never too confusing, but both skills are certainly tested throughout the course. Overall, I was scared to take this class as an undergrad, but in hindsight I would say this course was my favorite of the semester. It is certainly not easy, but the course support is great and my computational skills have genuinely improved.
worse_comment: There are probably better courses that cover the same material. The professor is very disorganised. However he is nice and wants you to learn and so does the teaching staff. Before taking this course I heard a lot of discouragement that the course is difficult. I wouldn’t let that scare you away. The actually material is actually not difficult especially if you’ve taken a couple statics related courses. What is difficult is understanding what the material is, what you’re supposed to know, and where the relevant information to learn it is.
subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2024: Advanced Scientific Computing: Stochastic Methods for Data Analysis, Inference and Optimization

best_comment: I cannot recommend this class enough, it was my favorite class of the semester and one of my favorite classes I've taken overall!!! Anna is so fantastic as an instructor and she's a total expert (and in some cases THE expert) on the course material, which functions as an overview of her research. The class seems like 40/60 undergrads/grad students and most sessions are whiteboard lectures, though there's the occasional group presentation day. The class only has 4 psets and a final project and tbh the workload is somewhat low (~5 hours a week but that's inflated from the project) but it's definitely what you put in scaling with what you get out, seems pretty appropriate for a grad theory class. Basically if the syllabus is interesting to you I would jump up and down to recommend the class. I want to reiterate how awesome Anna is and like how after week 3 she knew everyone (~40 students?) by face and name and she's so approachable and nice in office hours too!!
worse_comment: Siegal is a phenomenal lecturer, the course was slightly disorganized in the first year (outsourcing note taking to students made sense, perhaps this will change next year). Problem sets were very relevant to the material and helped to reinforce the main concepts, although the computational parts can be confusing to set up.

course_title: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part I 001
best_comment: This is a class that grows on you and has aspects to it that can either be really enjoyable or annoying, a lot of it has to do with the mindset you go into it with. The workload is indeed 10 hours of work per week that gets repetitive and annoying but over time you learn how to get it done quicker, which comes at the expense of your learning. I really love how clearly the course tells you the expectation and allows you to monitor and improve your performance over time. They truly give you almost unlimited chances to make up work and work towards improvement which I valued. In terms of physics learning, you can leave the course learning almost nothing but you do learn passively just due to the sheer quantity and variety of work you must complete, inside and outside of class. If you are choosing between this and PS2, you wont go wrong, especially if you want to learn physics in more of a fun, group format.
worse_comment: The class isn't too challenging for the most part but you really have to be putting in a lot of time to complete all the assignments. The content is manageable, although the "challenge problems" (not called problem sets) can be very difficult and time–intensive, although they do not grade you on correctness for those types of assignments. Every assignment is basically pass/fail and you need to pass every assignment to get an A in the class (with a few stipulations), but they really make you work for that pass on some of them. Having all group projects with no assessments or final exams is a total lifesaver and my peers in other physics classes regretted not taking this class over their other choices for that reason alone.
subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2024: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part I

course_title: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part I 001
best_comment: This is a class that grows on you and has aspects to it that can either be really enjoyable or annoying, a lot of it has to do with the mindset you go into it with.
