subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2024: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part I

best_comment: This class is an absolute gem, not because it's no work and super easy, but because Prof Mundy has found the perfect balance between challenging coursework and a stress–free learning experience. I have learned so much from this class because of it. The topic is interesting and relevant, and Mundy's lectures make everything accessible and exciting. The problem sets are adequate and the tests are totally doable. As long as you go to class, which is easy because its great, and do the psets, the tests truly feel like an opportunity to demonstrate what you have learned.
worse_comment: I found this course to be very unsatisfying in terms of the physics covered. The pacing is very slow, and the course focuses on applying different models of solid–state interactions while brushing past most of the interesting quantum mechanics behind it all. Lectures were clear but slow–paced and repetitive, making it hard to pay attention at times. Midterms were fair, but it was hard to prepare for them given the lack of practice materials. It's a decent light–workload class if you're not overly concerned with rigor, though.
subject: Applied Physics

course_title: Chemistry in Materials Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: Great class for SEAS PhD students. Gives you a large breadth of knowledge, chemistry confidence, and good intuition that you can bring into your own research.
subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2024: Chemistry in Materials Science and Engineering

best_comment: If you are looking for an easy class to fulfill SEAS technical requirements, this is a winner. I did not learn much – entirely my fault because of the lack of time I invested – but if you need to check the box and focus on your research this is one of the best. Max is a great professor and very engaged with students, and I would love to learn about a subject I have more research interest in from him.
subject: Applied Physics

best_comment: To clarify (e.g. for future waiver applications): at least in 2023, the part of the syllabus referring to 'phase transitions and critical points' included the renormalisation group and the epsilon expansion.Vinny is a fantastic lecturer who not only explains course content clearly and engagingly, but who also tends to teach as much of the broader motivation and historical context as possible. You'll come out of the course with a deep understanding of what entropy is (spoiler: it's not disorder) and how to resolve associated apparent paradoxes, and also with an idea as to the diversity of applications of statistical mechanics in current research. I'll prewarn that the final section of the course gets a bit pacy, and from certain conversations, I've heard it's important to choose final projects carefully.
subject: Applied Physics

course_title: Inference, Information Theory, Learning and Statistical Mechanics 001
best_comment: Given the very broad range of topics that this class covers, it actually does a remarkably good job giving intuition into each topic and connecting them to one another. But definitely don't expect to come out of the class with a rigorous understanding of any one of them –– this is very much a survey–type class. The first 1/3 of the class (information theory) is definitely the best organized and taught part of the  course. The second 1/3 is statistics (a subset of stat 111 covering MLE and Bayesian stat). Idk, maybe it was just me, but after taking a real stat course, their way of doing things looked pretty sloppy and confusing. The last 1/3 is ML, which was interesting and although it had a fair amount of overlap with cs 181, I still learned a lot of new things and gained some intuition.I did take this class after stat 111 and cs 181, which I wouldn't necessarily recommend since it was a bit repetitive. However, Sharad is an excellent lecturerer and the way he motivated everything using information theory and the perspective of a physicist/biologist was still quite new and interesting to me. I think it says something about the class that I still learned from it even coming in with a decent background.The problem sets for this class were decent, but you kind of had no idea what you were going to get. Sometimes they were super easy, sometimes super hard/fancy coding, and sometimes incredibly tedious algebra. MULTIPLE TIMES they would have these problems that were worded in an incredibly confusing way that nobody could figure out (eg has a paragraph of incomprehensible text and then asks about some variables that aren't even defined in the text). Then, when you went to ask the professor or the TFs they seemed to have no idea what the problem was trying to ask either or would give conflicting / self –contradictory explanations of the question. Like ??? The course staff is super chill, so it's ok. It was just a bit weird LOL.
worse_comment: This was one of my favorite, perhaps the favorite class, I've taken at Harvard. Despite being familiar with some of the material, I was excited to go to lecture and see how Sharad thought about it. We spent ~2 weeks in CS 181 on the expectation maximization algorithm, and Sharad presented it more clearly in 45 minutes. He is an incredibly engaging lecturer and it really feels like he has a deep, intuitive understanding of what he is talking about. The course moves quickly over topics sometimes, but I it is intended to be a survey course, and I think it is an excellent survey course. The one downside I'd say is that it was a bit unclear how to complete some of the problem set questions sometimes, but that was more of minor irritant than a major problem with the course.

best_comment: Excellent lectures, reasonable workload, and interesting topics –– please take it!

4 This course is not for everyone as it teaches art from a process over result perspective, focusing less on purpose or symbolic meaning but more on experimenting with materials, and tends to be pretty unstructured at times, not following topics on the syllabus. It takes more of a [d]uck around and find out approach for teaching that can be self–centered and fun at times, but also frustrating, especially when a lot of time is spent on projects which make me question "what is art." This course has some pro's: I learned a lot about process art and experimenting with materials, as well as getting out of the perfectionist mindset and instead appreciating "mistakes" and "destruction" as avenues for art to grow and explore. It also helped me to get a better feel for how AFVS exhibits work, how to install artwork in general, and the different resources the carpenter center offers. That being said, there are better courses in the AFVS department. With so much making and breaking, I too had a couple of breakdowns over this class.

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! This was my first course in the AFVS department and it made me decide I really want to do a concentration or secondary in AFVS. The class is so much fun, and screenprinting is such a versatile and amazing medium to learn. The class consists of just 3 art projects/installations and they grant you a lot of creative freedom in terms of your pieces. Annette and Kate are amazing and their feedback really helped me grow as an artist. 100% RECOMMEND!

This class is super fun. You should take it. It challenges you to think outside the box to make appealing comics, but in a good way. If you try your best on your assignments you will be happy with the collection you have created in the end. It only takes about 3–4 hours outside of class to do your weekly assignment. Take it.
worse_comment: I am sure this course is really incredible for students who are extremely skilled at illustrating and have taken a lot of art courses. I would warn that as someone who was taking this as an intro art course (and have never taken an art course) that this is not entirely an intro class. Although it's an intro to comics, I believe it is not an intro to art course and a lack of illustrative experience will make this course miserable.

best_comment: Take this class! I learned so much and it was the perfect introduction to oil painting. Kianja and Kathryn were so patient and encouraging and really wanted to see all the students grow. I enjoyed all the time I spent in the studio as a release from my other stressful classes, and I made good friends in the smaller studio class as well. Overall, this class was a wonderful experience and I'm incredibly happy I took it.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: Oh man. I feel like this course fundamentally changed how I view myself. I used to think that I'm not really an artsy/creative person. I took photos for fun or for memories, but I didn't really share them nor did I see myself as someone with creative outlets or artistic vision. Certainly the technical aspects of learning photography helped me feel differently, but ultimately, I feel like this course was also a class on life, how to live life, how art is an expression of life, and how we all can make art ourselves. I think about photography so differently now –– photos as revealing something intimate about the photographer, their relation to the environment and the photographed, spelled out in the framing/composition/technical details of the photo itself. This class has fundamentally changed how I see the world with beauty, wonder, and complexity –– the patterns and geometries and intimacies that are already present, which this class has helped train me to look at and appreciate and photograph. This is without a doubt my favorite and most impactful class I have taken at Harvard. Patrice has such a unique pedagogy, and the class truly embodies their vision of what education at Harvard could be: classes that help us grow, feel, live, explore, think as fellow human beings. I have never felt so connected with my classmates (truly we were in it together during our critiques), and much of that is a product of how Patrice fosters a dynamic and CARING class environment: the music that we listened to together in class before critiques, the compliment notes that we passed to each other for feedback, the class photobook, the guest speakers/critics, the films and movies we watched, the tea and snacks on the shelf... they are all testaments to how this course was set up for us to succeed and grow as artists and as people. I'm coming out of this course with a way of looking, loving, and photographing the world around me, not to mention many beautiful prints for friends and family (along with invaluable room decor)!
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: Beyond the time and effort it requires, which in themselves are often signifiers of some positive outcome by the end, this course was a failure for me. I learned relatively little about the craft of photography, as someone who came in with everything to learn, with little prior experience.I would say I come away with this course confident in: 1) managing aperture, shutter speed, and ISO 2) how to use flash and white balance 3) file and hard drive management and conversion4) printing prints of diverse sizes the proper way While those are great and substantive skills, they are vastly less than what should have been learned in a semester of this class, which had nearly 6 hours of class time a week, on top of a 2 hour lab. We never learned composition –– as just one example, the "rule of thirds" was something I heard about only through a friend in a different intro to photography class. Color theory and editing were nominally explained, but the instruction was primarily a demonstration that, if you wanted to, you could choose to adjust, say, exposure or highlights. I never understood how to look at a photograph with a discerning eye and make those edits productively; to the very end of this class, I was merely pushing a slider on the screen to see what number made the photograph look nicest, frustrated that we had never meaningfully learned to technically analyze and edit a photograph. In class, there was minimal instruction, and time was spent meandering between watching miscellaneous videos the Prof liked, taking extended breaks, or spending extensive time discussing general life lessons. Patrice Helmar is a professor of genuine wisdom who shared many thoughtful and moving things, but the difficult fact that those things were essentially all I got in regard to learning anything about photography from them –– besides periodic instruction in the lab from our TF –– made it hard to appreciate them as a teacher. The primary advice given by them when asked questions like how to improve the visual appeal of a given photograph, or decide whether to print it in color or black and white, were responses like "sing the song that only you know," and "show us your world." They were positive and empowering sentiments for a teacher to say, but those ideas can’t work when they're replacing real, concrete instruction that we needed to get better.I left this class feeling defeated and a bit embarrassed that I had so little to show for so much time spent in class, time that could have been spent doing a million other things. ALL THIS SAID: this course seemed to work wonderfully for people who were already trained in photography; it gave them an opportunity to practice, experiment, and get a bit of feedback on their work, and engage with people who were true experts in the field. Those kids in my class very demonstrably improved by the end and I imagine will have positive things to say about this course. If you do not know photography, do not take this course to learn it.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: Sharon is absolutely wonderful!!!! One of the greatest professors I've ever had both in her teaching and how she treats her students! I would recommend any class she's teaching so highly. She cares so much about her students and does such a great job meeting every individual where they are. She does a great job telling you her honest expert opinion on your work but will also listen to what you care about and are interested in and give really helpful feedback accordingly! She really goes above and beyond to help everyone succeed and she really cares about fostering a good class community. Claude is an awesome TF and will always bring your spirits up. He also did such a great job trying to foster a good class community. Our class was always laughing and helping one another even in our 9am exhaustion and Sharon and Claude always made sure class felt worth our while. For the work, you get out of this class what you put in! Take tons of pictures and carry your camera everywhere and it'll be easy to stay on top of assignments and you'll have a great experience.

This is my favorite course that I have taken at this school thus far and likely will be until I graduate. The professor is amazing. The TF is amazing. Your fellow students are amazing. You develop a bond that can only be made by spending hours and hours sharing blood, sweat, and tears with these people in the basement of sever.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: take it! this is a brilliant class if you want to dive into filmmaking and documentary projects. Professor Guzzetti and Kristen are both very friendly and helpful. They make you feel valued in the class.
worse_comment: Don’t underestimate how much time the final project will take you in editing.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This is an incredible class! If you have any interest in anything artistic, this class is a great way to fuel that excitement. The assignments take a while because animation is a long process, but if you love the work you're doing, then you'll have so much fun making everything and will feel really proud of yourself in the end. Ruth is hilarious and gives great advice. The TFs are also really engaged and thoughtful in the work we do.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: Alfred is amazing and the course is amazing but make sure you are passionate about image capturing and fine tuning your skills as this course is designed to get into nitty gritty details of image capturing.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

course_title: Approaching Narrative: Introduction to Fiction Filmmaking 001
best_comment: Don't go into this course expecting to learn to write a script. Or to direct. Or even to hold a camera. Come ready with an idea for a short film and be ready to mostly figure out how to produce it on your own. However, you will have immense support from your teaching staff for this course IF (and only if) you push yourself to ask for it.
worse_comment: Be cautious of taking this course if this is the visiting professor's first year. Lack of experience in teaching can lead to a course with little to no clarity that teaches you very little.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies
course_title_2024: Approaching Narrative: Introduction to Fiction Filmmaking

best_comment: Take this course if you're interested in learning what art can be!! You will learn to push yourself in so many ways, step outside of your comfort zone, build a fun community, and discover forms of art that you may not have previously imagined possible. If you mostly care about a perfect end product, this might not be your cup of tea. At it's core, this class is all about process and what you can find through that process. Coming in with an open mind is crucial for this class and you will get so much more out of it that way! Loved the teaching style as well and felt very comfortable throughout even though I didn't have previous experience
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: Katarina is chill and gives useful feedback! We are allowed to explore very freely with very limited constraints. The class atmosphere is supportive, encouraging, and I learned a lot from my classmates. I enjoyed the class as an opportunity to create and meditate outside of my other major courses.

course_title: Thinking With Your Hand: Intermediate Painting 001
best_comment: The thing about any art class is you have to be prepared for the time commitment. You can't cut corners with paintings – you'll succeed in this class if you put in the time consistently over the semester. The class was a good cheerful environment and good community, Judith and Scott are both great artists who do genuinely want to support you in your learning. I enjoyed the creative freedom we had as the class went on, and I'd say take advantage of these types of classes where materials are provided (it's such an amazing opportunity).
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies
course_title_2024: Thinking With Your Hand: Intermediate Painting

course_title: Sleight of Hand Sleight of Mind: Creative Process and Photography 1
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS !!! so so amazing. claude and sharon are wonderful. so many cool ways to explore your own creativity in a way that is very low stakes and encourages exploration. so amazing. not an afvs person but took this class because it looked interesting and DONT REGRET AT ALL. so amazing
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies
course_title_2024: Sleight of Hand Sleight of Mind: Creative Process and Photography

best_comment: Take this class! Patrick and Alain are awesome and it’s such a unique opportunity to get to spend a year making your own film
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: what you get out of this class is really what you put in — both in terms of editing, but more importantly, summer preparation. if you come in having put in a lot of energy and thought over the summer, the editing process will be more productive and rewarding!
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: I absolutely loved this class and I think any creative people could take away a lot from learning animation. It challenges your previous idea of animation and gets you trying new things
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

course_title: The Frankfurt School on Film and Mass Culture 001
best_comment: Take this with a grain of salt, but definitely try to learn skills in philosophy/theory reading. Frankfurt School can be a bit confusing, and the class is very fast–paced, making it hard to learn these skills during the semester (at least if you do not want this class to take up your entire week). That being said, I think everyone would benefit from learning this content. Definitely do the required readings, discussions would be hard without it. The class will take up a good amount of time, so try to balance your schedule. The projects are great though, and allow you to explore the Frankfurt School in your own life. Rentschler is a great professor, will guide you and provide you great feedback on your work

As a non–AFVS concentrator, it was amazing to meet students from this department that I would have otherwise likely not met. The teaching staff is very supportive and I learned a lot through their feedback. I also loved learning about other people's work when they held presentations. I definitely challenged myself with the project I took on for the class and I am very happy with the result.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This class is like a miniature arts conference/retreat in your semester. You enter a small community of curious and adventurous people, and by the end of it you're best friends and you appreciate one another's work deeply.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: I would tell them –  no questions asked – take this course. This is the most interesting and fun class that I have ever had the privilege of taking at Harvard. Every lecture is packed with enthusiasm and demos, and there wasn't a day that I hadn't enjoyed my time in this class. The homework assignments are rather thought–provoking, and you are best served going through them with a friend. They too are rather fun, but they can be a bit math–heavy (as one should expect). The math is not terribly difficult (no calculus required, physics knowledge is helpful), but I would recommend taking notes and jotting down the formulas presented in lecture. You will be seeing them again. Above all else, enjoy your time with Professor Charbonneau. He is a radiant and infinitely–insightful professor, and he is genuinely fascinated by the material. Ask him any and all questions you may have, and listen as he guides you to a new understanding of a topic you hadn't previously considered. Never before have I encountered a professor that can spend 75 minutes highlighting how miniscule we are in the grand scheme of things, and still make us feel so important. Take this class.
worse_comment: do not take this class unless you want to suffer –– an FGLI non–STEM concentrator.

best_comment: This class is a great introduction to astronomy, little preparation needed, great as an elective. Professor and TF are both extremely helpful if you take the initiative to approach them and ask them questions. Three–hour lab at night might throw some people off but it's mostly really fun and useful. You get to practice a lot of hands–on things like plotting, using sextants, etc. Mid–semester p–sets get much more time–consuming: expect maybe four to six hours but the beginning and end of the semester are pretty light. Highly recommend the class as long as you're willing to put in the work and learn. Everything's cumulative so if you fall behind on material, the midterm and final aren't going to be fun. Also a tip: get good data in your journal early before things pile up. You really only need two or three weeks' worth of good data, predictions, and models to get a high score on it.
worse_comment: Only take this class if you have the time in your schedule to commit to it. IT IS NOT A GEM BY ANY MEANS! The content isn't exceptionally difficult, but it is time consuming and often super confusing especially since none of the assignments or tests or anything are actually proofread so there are errors and contradictions everywhere that take forever to iron out. The grading is horrendous and completely biased and often just wrong, which you wont realize until you ask for a regrade and they will just be like "oh oops my bad". I also was told that I would not get credit on a question back because it wouldn't make a huge difference in my final grade, even though the points that were taken off were completely illegitimate (CA also backed me on this but professors are stubborn about grading and didnt listen).  Anyways, I was super excited about this course and it was a let down and after the midterm I genuinely never wanted to return to the classroom because I felt I got cheated and was back in 5th grade. Something I will say is that the second half of the course (post midterm) is significantly better than the second half, so I guess if you can hold out then go for it.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: As an astrophysics concentrator, I really appreciated all that this course had to offer. I think that prospective astrophysics concentrators would gain valuable exposure to the fields of galactic and extragalactic astronomy and also cosmology as promised (i.e. the universe at large scales), but would moreover come out with somewhat of an appreciation for how modern optical astrophysics research surveys are conducted, which is valuable exposure to gain! Furthermore, Professor Eisenstein is just incredibly knowledgeable and very supportive and invested in answering questions and making himself available to students. He has led or been involved with several impressive astrophysics missions / instruments /surveys, ranging from SDSS to DESI to the James Webb Space Telescope; Prof. Eisenstein is very interested in instrumentation, and so you learn about the instruments themselves, too. I appreciated the effort this class makes in giving you the chance to actually work with real survey and spectroscopic data, and think about the instruments that gathered them, not just absorb (cool) astrophysics theories and knowledge. Definitely a good class to take to learn about modern astrophysics and the universe at large scales, especially if you are interested in astronomy!
worse_comment: Only take if this is a requirement. If you are interested in Astro, this will give a rather myopic view into the field. Would instead recommend taking more specialized higher level astro or physics classes. This class is doable but kind of takes away the sparkle of astrophysics. Focuses too much on instrumentation and observational astronomy (loves spectra). Lacking in the "physics" of astrophysics and often just describes the phenomena without really discussing the implications and what everything really means. Unless you put in the extra effort, you just have to take everything as given. If this sounds less appealing to you, would just recommend taking as much physics as possible until you can take Astron 130 or Physics 212. If you're an astrophysics concentrator, you have to take this course but as a concentrator myself lowkey regret taking the 16/17 intro sequence and would have preferred to have concentrated in physics and just take higher level astro classes further down the line.  Modules were somehow long yet not super informative. There was just sooooo much material yet so little substance to it all. It's incredibly doable but just rather disheartening. Theory could have been probed so much deeper yet it wasn't.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: This is a good course, but you definitely get out what you put in. Finding a good research mentor early on is key, and staying on top of this very fast paced class. Prof. Chen is great, and it's very cool to hear from a new scientist every week.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: Take this class!!! The material is very hard, but it is so interesting. You will have to work hard in this class, but you will be rewarded with great insights into the universe. This has been my favorite class in all of Harvard. It might even be the best physics class here. The midterms are hard and the midterm was very hard too. The final was take–home and super interesting. I actually really enjoyed doing the final. It felt like a long pset, but the topics were so interesting that it never felt like I was doing a test. Xingang is a great professor and explains the material well. Catherine is the greatest; she is an incredible TF and really made the course. I learned a lot in this class and would recommend anyone to take it.
worse_comment: Take this class if you want to get an intuition about GR but do not want to get lost in grad version of it.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: Focus on enjoying the material as well as learning it. Finding ways to apply the topics being discussed in class to my research allowed me to engage in the course at a deeper level.
worse_comment: Pros:Course material was comprehensive and in–depth, thoroughly explained a lot of different really important concepts in astrophysics at a very detailed level. Section was consistently very helpful, Misha even offered tips/hints on how to solve the homework problems (without giving up the answer, of course). Problem sets force you to understand the course material really well. They are really hard, but this is fair for a course covering this sort of materialCons / stuff that this course needs to improve:1. WAY more office hours. There was just one set of office hours per week, which I could never make because I had a class at that time. It would be really nice to have multiple sets of office hours, especially because the problem sets are so difficult. (Section is not really the same as OH, because section is more like a recap of lecture)2. Slower paced lectures , or more pauses in lectures so we can ask questions – sometimes I would get confused on a concept 15 or 20 minutes into lecture, and if Prof Narayan just progresses straight to the next concept, I don't really get a chance to ask questions.  Since later lecture material builds on earlier lecture material, I would remain confused for the later parts of the lecture.3. Practice problems for the final exam. Since we didn't have practice problems, I went into the final exam not really knowing what to expect. I am particularly frustrated that there were no practice problems because Ay 200's was the only final exam I've ever taken where practice problems were not given to students.4. Problem sets are extremely inconsistent in their difficulty. For instance, Problem Set 6 was very hard and took me a very long time to finish, while Problem Set 7 was extremely easy (to the point where it didn't really help me understand the material better) and took me only around 30 minutes to finish. It would be really nice to have just had two regular–difficulty problem sets.I would rather off myself than take this class again. Just do something else. Hear me now or believe me later.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: definitely take this class if you want to understand astronomy at a high level. prof john johnson is an excellent professor. he always asked what we wanted to learn about in the course, was very helpful at office hours, and had 5min breaks in lecture so we could get up, walk around etc. he is also one of the most successful people in his field. the material is super interesting and johnson explains it in a way that is detailed, yet not too hard to comprehend. this course isn't really that hard, if you pay attention in lecture you will be ok. but, johnson does NOT do lecture notes so you MUST come to class. a lot of the learning in this class is done in a group setting, it's very discussion–based. this is nice because sometimes one person in your group will understand the material better than others, and can teach the other students (and vice versa). also helps for forming friendships so you can collab on psets

This course is very dense in its subject matter, but if you want to learn about physiology or are required to, this is the class to do it in. Dr. Sieber is an excellent professor who really clearly cares about the material and study learning. You will be challenged in your ways of thinking about health processes and occurrences, for the better. In terms of coursework, there are three long homework assignments across the semester and three exams (timed, open–note). The weeks of the assignments and exams were challenging, but the course is on the large enjoyable.
subject: Biological Sci in Public Hlth

best_comment: The class will make you more confident about your ability to communicate your scientific work, and feel better equipped to apply to fellowships and grants later in your academic career.
subject: Biological Sci in Public Hlth

course_title: Topics in Immunology and Infectious Diseases 001
best_comment: This course will help you become a better scientist more entrenched in the literature, with a better understanding of how to continue learning from newly published articles.
subject: Biological Sci in Public Hlth
course_title_2024: Topics in Immunology and Infectious Diseases

course_title: Topics in Immunology and Infectious Diseases 001
best_comment: This course will help you become a better scientist more entrenched in the literature, with a better understanding of how to continue learning from newly published articles.
subject: Biological Sci in Public Hlth
course_title_2024: Topics in Immunology and Infectious Diseases

best_comment: I'm sure many people heard of the horrors of BE110 as I once did. But standing on the other side of this class, it's not that bad :,)––– haha we'll see once the final grades are released. Though it was a hugeee trauma–bonding class, I think we can all confidently say we all became easily became friends because we were spending so much time with each other. Establishing a solid Pset group from the very beginning is essential... or do what we did and make a class group chat :p!For a bioengineer, a solid understanding of systems and signals is essential. And as you start to learn more through this class you will understand what I mean. This class made me more confident as a bioengineer concentrator because for once, I feel as though I was able to hone and master something special to my field of study that I can contribute in a group setting. Moreover, it made me feel very confident in my Matlabs skills which is a great thing to feel confident in looking forward to thesising and applying it in other classes in scenarios that require rigorous calculations. Though Maurice can be all over the place at times, he is really funny which makes the class more palatable. On the other hand, I think the material is pretty streamlined and very well organized. This has to be the most challenging but fulfilling class I have taken so far at this school. Good luck future BE110ers!
worse_comment: Anybody reading this likely has to take this course in order to graduate with a Biomedical Engineering or Bioengineering degree. However, if the time ever comes that BE110 can be replaced with another course (like ES157), avoid this class at all costs. Maurice is actually fine as a person, contrary to many previous reports. However, the issue is that he's totally disorganized. Expectations are totally unclear (for pset answers, exam answers, conceptual understanding, etc), and you never know where you stand grade–wise. Also, test conditions are awful. For our first midterm, Maurice showed up 20 minutes late and projected a PDF of the exam onto the projector and handed us blank printer paper to write our answers on. He also left the room for 20 minutes at a time, during which the projector would turn off, leaving us with no exam questions. He wrote question #7 on the chalkboard spontaneously—we had about 10 minutes left in the exam when he decided to do that.
subject: Biomedical Engineering

course_title: Biomechanics of Movement and Assistive Robotics 001
best_comment: Course was extremely interesting and the lectures were amazing. I learned a lot from the class, but in its first year, definitely did leave a lot to be desired. If you are just at all interested in learning how the body moves and how assistive devices are made, then this class is made for you. However, you must have a relatively strong physics background to succeed in the course. Class was great, and with this year's feedback, can only get better.

This is a lovely class and I would highly recommend it. Prof Liu splits "neuroengineering" into a few categories: observing the brain, probing the brain, and integrated approaches combining these technologies. You can expect to spend about 1/3 of the semester on each one of these. Prof Liu is a very effective lecture –– it feels like he's put a lot of thought into what he is going to present and teaches in a very clear and understandable manner. He is always happy to stop for questions anytime. The lab is super interesting. This year it was tissue clearing of mouse brain sections and then laser confocal microscopy to perform 3D connectivity mapping (basically 3D imaging and reconstruction of the neural structure of the mouse brain). Very cool experience, which was a highlight of the course.Assignments were short prelab/postlab reports, and then 'journal club' midterm presentations where you will present with a group on one of about seven papers provided by Prof Liu. He emphasized time and time again that if you wanted to get anything out of the course, it is vital to read the papers. It is through this exercise that you come to truly understand where the field is now. It is quite easy to just read your own paper and present on it, but I would stand with the professor on this account –– make the extra effort to read as many papers as you can. Your grade does not depend on this, but your understanding will definitely deepen. I found the presentations to be good assignments, however because everyone must present on their papers, it did end up taking up a significant portion of class time, which was a little unfortunate. Also, *do not go over the time limit in your presentations*. Prof Liu is very strict about them and likes to keep class on time. Final projects were fun, I liked the idea of having us write NIH–style grant proposals for novel research. Talk to Prof Liu about your project ideas –– he is a wonderful resource and was very helpful and thoughtful. Prof Liu really is a leader in this field, and knows his stuff quite well. This class was a pleasure, and I'd highly recommend it!
worse_comment: Take it, it is amazing and not a huge time commitment (apart from the labs). Make sure to pay attention in lectures though, as you are not required to but then you are not gaining anything from the class.
subject: Biomedical Engineering

best_comment: Jeff is a fantastic instructor for probability. Jeff pays great attention to the presentation of the material to make sure it's clear and presented as straightforwardly as possible. He has a great sense of how the material relates to a variety of topics in STEM which makes the examples and connections he's able to draw in class engaging. He truly impressed me by his ability to answer what I thought were hard questions on the spot, and I felt more importantly than being impressed, I always learned from what he had to say. Jeff is also very nice and fair as an instructor.  He was clear with us that he wanted to make sure the content did challenge us, but wasn't too hard. He often asked us for feedback, asking "how was the exam?" after a midterm, and seemed to genuinely hear us. This is a great class!  Take it if you think you'll ever need to engage with probability in a substantive way (e.g., to work with probability distributions, to invoke the central limit theorem or laws of large numbers rigorously, etc.). It's a great stepping stone to more advanced material, but it would also be great for someone who will go on to do more data science/analysis.
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: I would say that if you're the type of person who wants to be that colleague to others who can rigorously defend their statistical methodological choices, this is a great course for you, especially if you want to be that colleague in a public health, epidemiological, or biostatistical (/medicine) setting. This course probably requires a fair bit of motivation to keep at it — which isn't a bad thing if you have it!  If you feel like the above describes you, and you can keep that in view while going through the class, I think you'll see why the material is important and how you will benefit from it.I would say students should come into this class already motivated to learn the material, rather than looking to get motivation out of the class. My view is that this course is all about simultaneously showing students the statistical software practices necessary to do rigorous statistics alongside its theoretical justification. That said, it leans pretty heavily towards the theory (that's most of what you see in class). So I wouldn't say you learn a ton of R programming from the class — just how to do what you need to, which is mostly fitting models, performing hypothesis tests, and not all the data cleaning/management that surrounds that.  It would be helpful to make sure you've brushed up on your R programming before going into this class.  I would say this course expects that you should at least be able to write functions in R without stressing about it. It's a good class!  It's just more advanced than most people who are just interested in "statistics" or "data science" typically need.  But if you want to see the theoretical justifications for the paradigms we've used in applied statistics for the last ~100 years, it's a fun whirlwind through the ideas.
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: This class ia a great coverage of a diversity of topics relevant in modern statistics (concentration inequalities, penalized/sparse regression, optimization,). It is not a "Methods 2" for Biostatistics PhD students per se, but covers topics both "recently established" (~90's–2010's) and more modern/cutting edge statistical/machine learning applications. A very useful overview if you are all interested in a breadth of topics, such as high–dimensional statistics, more learning/ML focused work, graphical modelling, Also very useful for any students with less of a computer science/optimization background for its review of optimization methods, both in implementation and in proofs of convergence for convex optimization.
subject: Biostatistics

course_title: Analysis of Multivariate and Longitudinal Data 001
best_comment: The course is challenging but worth taking. You will learn skills and develop intuition that will be invaluable for future endeavors. Dr. Chen is very thorough and challenges students with hard assignments and exams, but very gracious in grading and providing great feedback. Best course I've taken at Harvard.
subject: Biostatistics
course_title_2024: Analysis of Multivariate and Longitudinal Data

best_comment: **, attedance is marked but also super useful to get opinions on topics, the syllabus is not very organized so make sure you follow along. also, you really have to do the readings to complete the assignments, which is both good for the student and good to know that you can't just half–effort the final and midterm. luckily, the midterm and final are the only assignments (no weekly psets), which makes this class a good one if you're looking for a non pset class. didn't know what to expect from this course but am glad i took it.
best_gem_comment: This is a great course! I would call it a Gem if you're ok with some light reading that is actually really fun and interesting. Nagy and Rachel are also both really nice and helpful.

course_title: Transatlantic Celts: Narratives of Loss and Belonging 001
best_comment: I loved this course. It was super interesting. Would recommend.

course_title: Quantum, Statistical, and Computational Foundations of Chemistry 001
best_comment: THIS WAS AN AMAZING CHEMISTRY CLASS. TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU CAN. Adam Cohen is an AMAZING lecturer. The content is incredibly informative and rigorous. If you're curious about the mathematical models that all of chemistry derives from, or you feel like you're just not convinced about how chemistry works yet, you should take this class. It's intimidating at the start, but it's very, very rewarding by the end. I had very little chemistry background, below the level of AP chem and AP physics, before enrolling; now I feel like I can hold my own in a discussion with chem concentrators. After taking it, I feel prepared to take orgo (Chem 20) as well as both quantum mechanics (Phys 143/Chem 160) and statistical mechanics (Phys 181/Chem 161/MCB 199). If I had a few words to describe this class, it would be "difficult, but you're prepared." It was definitely out of my comfort zone, but it was never unmanageable or overwhelming. It is going to be intimidating at the start. The first section and first pset will be a challenge. Don't be scared – it gets much more manageable the longer you spend. Do go to office hours and don't be afraid of asking questions in lecture. It is absolutely encouraged, even expected, to ask questions – it's not seen as disruptive at all, and there are no stupid questions.The course staff are amazing and very supportive (Lu, the chem department preceptor, is really nice!) and since the student population ended up being pretty small this year, we formed an actual community by the end. The teaching staff really got to know us and always took the time to answer our questions; they devoted so much extra time to this course, including one who designed and 3D printed a spectrometer for us to assemble(!!) You should definitely go to office hours even if you don't have a specific question – Adam is an awesome professor, hearing other people's questions can also be very informative, and you can always chat about research or about life in general. Reasons you shouldn't take this class: you haven't taken calculus yet, you hate math, you have a really heavy workload outside of this class, or you don't want to put a lot of effort into physical chemistry for some reason or another.Reasons you should take this class: you're curious and you want an amazing physical chem experience!
subject: Chemistry
course_title_2024: Quantum, Statistical, and Computational Foundations of Chemistry

subject: Chemistry
course_title_2024: Quantum, Statistical, and Computational Foundations of Chemistry

best_comment: Organic chemistry is a tough subject, but this year's teaching staff really did a great job at making the course accessible and understandable. I genuinely enjoyed the course and the content. It was challenging and I spent a ton of time on it, but it was such a rewarding course. Go to office hours to complete PSETs as the PSLs and TFs are super helpful and answer a lot of questions. The PSETs can be very long so get a head start on them so that they aren't as daunting at the end of the week. Sirinya is an AMAZING lecturer and I thought she did a great job of keeping things interesting despite organic chem being a dry subject at times. I really loved the course (which I know is crazy to say about organic chem) but I was very impressed with how it was run this year and how much I genuinely feel like I learned.
worse_comment: This class has bias grading. Prefers suck ups, and does not help students who have had no previous exposure. Honestly teaching staff, especially Tori and Emma are not helpful or useful to students who do not know what they are doing. THEY are awful and unsupportive teaching staff to go to. As far as TFs go, they are horrible. Besides lecture, this class is basically self taught. Section teaches you nothing and is a waste of time. Tfs are unsupportive, and do this job as a resume boost. CHEM 17 needs to rethink their hiring process, because it makes it even more difficult on its students.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Chem 30 is a wonderful class! I personally enjoyed it even more than chem 20, mostly because of the greater emphasis on synthesis. You definitely learn a lot of material very quickly in 30, but it feels easier than chem 20 because you've gotten over the activation energy of learning orgo, so the speak. If you felt comfortable with chem 20, you have nothing to worry about going into this class, especially if you enjoyed the synthesis aspects. Some of the mechanisms can feel a little complicated at first, but Meyers does a great job explaining the underlying chemistry beneath every reaction, and I found that it was really difficult to get confused. Teaching staff is also great, though significantly less available than the chem 20 teaching staff. I didn't find that a problem, though, since we definitely got enough support throughout the class. All in all, a great continuation of chem 20, and it certainly made me love orgo even more.
worse_comment: This class will be difficult if you do not have people to work with, or an ability to go to office hours. I had to work, thus I was rarely able to ask anyon efor help on anything and that severely impacted my performance in this course.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Honestly, I really enjoyed Chem 100r! I was very intimated by the 10 hours/week in lab at first, but it's actually not as bad as it seems. And you do really cool research with potential real–life applications which was very cool! The teachings staff is awesome and super supportive too. The DC trip is definitely a highlight! This course really helped me gain a deeper appreciation of organic synthesis and as someone who had never worked in a lab before, I actually feel like I now have real research skills and experience which is awesome.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: If you like organic chemistry and are open to a challenge, take this class!! I am a pre–med, non–chem concentrator who took Chem 17 and 27, but found that I really enjoyed those classes and wanted to learn more about organic chemistry. I was intimidated by this course because there are a lot of chem concentrators and graduate students, but I felt motivated to put in the work because it truly is so interesting and rewarding when you find that you are able to understand things. I can say with absolute certainty that this is my favorite course I have taken at Harvard, and I found every lecture genuinely so fascinating. You can definitely take this course if Chem 17/27 is your only chem background, you just need to be willing to put in the work. Professor Jacobsen cares very deeply about his students and wants everyone to succeed, so take advantage of his office hours and the TF office hours to aid your understanding. This class has a reputation for being very challenging, and it definitely is, but it is so worth it if it's a topic you are interested in.
subject: Chemistry

course_title: The Chemistry and Biology of Therapeutics 01
best_comment: Great class! I loved talking to friends about this class all semester, and I’m a new chem concentrator (used to only be a neuro concentrator, doubling now) so that’s pretty surprising. Section is also so chill. You’ll have to put in the work with problem sets and the final project, but overall, super worth the time and effort! I will say if you’re an undergrad, get ready for grad students to know about all sorts of lab techniques and stuff already. But don’t worry, because the grad students are mostly just G1s so they aren’t that far ahead of you. You might even end up pulling the weight for your whole group yourself for the group project… it’ll be a fun surprise! Also be ready to see slides from Chem27 if you took it already, because a lot of topics come back here and it’s super cool to see!
worse_comment: This course is what you make of it. If you're a die–hard chem person, then you might enjoy it a lot. But the class isn't always fun, especially for non–chem concentrations. I did not like how they graded some things and felt like they were being a bit strict. Nevertheless, I did learn a lot about drugs and therapeutics, and the class as a whole was relatively low–stress.
subject: Chemistry
course_title_2024: The Chemistry and Biology of Therapeutics

best_comment: Probably the best chemistry class I've taken here. Dilek is so supportive of her students and the TFs Nejc and Jane really helped make this such a great learning environment. Even though I didn't have any practical chemistry skills, this class starts training the practical component from the ground up and I always felt like I was learning something new.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Take this course (after you take Chem 40 or have taken some beginning inorganic equivalent though)! A lot of great topics in materials chemistry are covered, ranging from solid–state synthesis, electronic structure of solid–state materials, magnetism (lot of this, which was great!!), nanomaterials, optical treatment of solid–state materials (i.e. photovoltaics, etc.), and extended materials (like MOF's and Zeolites). None of the other inorganic classes at Harvard really cover any of these topics, so it was really nice to learn new stuff while still applying background knowledge from previous inorganic classes. (But seriously @ the person considering taking this without taking Chem 40 or a beginning inorganic class DON'T DO IT! If you do, well, can't say nobody warned you! :) )There were 7 PSET's  total, 2 exams, and a final presentation / written proposal. While the last two weeks were a little bit annoying b/c PSET + exam + presentation + written proposal, it wasn't so much work the whole way through, and the exam content was 100% fair! As a grad student who is finally done taking classes and has taken too many classes by this point (ranging from awful to great btw), I can confirm this is definitely one of the good ones! Joy was a fantastic TF who knows the material incredibly well, graded super quickly, and was overall very on top of it! Jarad was an awesome lecturer as well, and I learned a lot in the class that will be super helpful going forward I'm sure! As a side note, I didn't crack open a single textbook or recommended reading, only studied based off the lecture notes and did perfectly fine in the class. So uhh go to lecture if you take this class; it's def worth it!
worse_comment: Professor Mason is an excellent lecturer with a deep knowledge of the field, but doesn't hold students to a rigorous standard, for better or for worse.

best_comment: Khaled is a wonderful professor. This class made learning such a difficult and complex topic a joyful experience. I don't like physics, I don't like calculus, but I enjoyed this class.  If you show up to lecture and section and pay attention, you will be okay. The structure of this course was great!! I didn't stress about exams and was just working on the psets and quizzes (pset every other week and quiz the weeks between the psets) and learning the material. The grace and kindness shown to students by the course staff like offering extensions and extra support if needed was really wonderful. That is how all classes, especially STEM classes, should function. This class wasn't a weed out class and classes like Chem 17 or Chem 20 that actively try to discourage students from being successful, should take notes. My experience in this course was a good one and I actually felt like I got to learn the material instead of scrambling to study for exams and remember formulas. The concepts are interesting and again, if you pay attention in lecture and review the material in section, you will be fine. Really great class in the Chemistry Department and I hope other professors choose to follow a similar structure that prioritizes student learning as opposed to prioritizing making students feel awful and actively hate the class.
subject: Chemistry

course_title: The Chemistry, Biology, and Societal Implications of Genome Editing 001
best_comment: Overall, a great class. David is SERIOUSLY talented as a scientist, mentor, and lecturer –– I have no idea how he hasn't won a Nobel prize yet. He's extremely knowledgable about all things gene editing, but also an entertaining lecturer. The class dives into a *lot* of different aspects of gene editing –– mechanisms, pharmaceutical development, policy, ethics, etc. I honestly didn't think it would be able to cover everything, but we went in depth on basically everything they mentioned in the syllabus! It's totally focused on the science elements though, so I'd recommend a different class (SCRB 120?) if you're interested in the ethical debates of gene editing. It's tough to make a 3 hour class on Friday  evening entertaining, but David does a pretty good job. If you're not used to long classes, though, the lecture can be really brutal. As engaging as David is as a lecturer, the class isn't very interactive (it's 2 hours of content–based lecture, and 45 minutes of student presentations on individual papers related to that week's topic). The final projects were really fun, and we had a lot of creative liberty. The TFs are also a shining part of this course experience. Nick and Colin are AMAZING. Absolutely phenomenal!!! They can break down the most complex papers into picture books! They are really great teachers, and very knowledgable about their fields.
subject: Chemistry
course_title_2024: The Chemistry, Biology, and Societal Implications of Genome Editing

course_title: Quantum Mechanics for Physical Chemistry LEC
best_comment: Very fun course. The 5–minute presentations really help you learn a lot about a specific topic in quantum mechanics. A lot of different, interesting topics in quantum mechanics are covered.
subject: Chemistry

course_title: Advanced Statistical Mechanics: Frontiers in Research 001
best_comment: Prof. Shakhnovich is an excellent lecturer, he begins the class with lectures that allow every student to be on the same level when it comes to the course material. The assignments are very relevant and you get to learn a lot about protein folding and phase separation.
subject: Chemistry
course_title_2024: Advanced Statistical Mechanics: Frontiers in Research

best_comment: This course really helped me gauge how I am as an instructor and how I can improve to be a more effective teacher in the future.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: This course really helped me gauge how I am as an instructor and how I can improve to be a more effective teacher in the future.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Overview:If you have any reason to take this course, take it (especially since it is only offered in the fall)! I had little experience going in – 9th grade biology and COVID 10th grade chemistry – but I did just fine (at least I think, I haven't seen my final grade yet). My first piece of advice is to get sleep. Basic, I know, but if you are not following the lectures and getting behind on understanding the topics, a large part of the reason may be because you were not well rested enough before lecture to comprehend the material. I say this because after going back and thoroughly studying the lectures before exams, they actually made sense with all of my focus and energy on them. Tucci is an excellent lecturer, very engaging, and encourages asking questions. Enjoy the time you have with him during the chemistry component, when it switches to biology only then will you understand how superb he truly was. PROTIP: not necessary for this course since it includes a course calendar, but please put all of your class times, office hours, exam dates, assignment due dates, etc. on your google calendar before classes start (during orientation). It will save you lots of stress because you will not have time to do this during the year.Schedule:Lectures 3 times a week (hard to wake up but recorded – I have never missed a lecture though). Lab once a week for two and a half hours – you need safety goggles ($12 on amazon, $20 at the Coop). In the lab you can only have a pencil out. Sit at the front where the Lab TF is if you want to actually know what’s going on.Section – TF very much determines how useful these are for you. Mine was a gem.Structure:A course google calendar is provided and is extremely helpful because it includes all assignment due dates, class times, and office hours. The Canvas is very organized and everything you need is in one place. I have never once spent more than five seconds looking for a material (except for maybe the beginning when getting used to everything).Lecture handouts are provided for each lecturer, but make sure to write down additional explanations, more than what they write on the notes.The Canvas also recommends reading the textbook chapters and pre–readings, but these are also not necessary as I have never read one. Even Tucci said the textbook chapters are not needed.Assignments:1 P–Set a week. Chemistry p–sets were easier to follow but checking with friends and in help room is a must during the biology portion; grading is often very picky. I spent 3–6 hours on these.Pre lab due before lab section. Often hard to understand and complete when just seeing the lab on paper, especially since they expect you to be able to devise your own instructions to follow and already know how to complete the calculations for what you are testing. Can be done in 1–2 hours in help room.Lab Report due after the lab that is usually more writing and calculations. Can also be done in 1–2 hours in help room.Optional practice problems. Not necessary to complete. I have never done a practice problem.Midterms:Looking back, the first exam (chemistry) is EXTREMELY easy. Please study. Do the practice exams. This is non–negotiable. I scored pretty low (for over–achiever standards) because I did not study enough, and without the first exam score I would have easily gotten an A in this course. The second exam (chemistry) went the best for me, and the last exam was shaky because it was biology and poorly taught, but oh well. Final Exam:Start in advance. Just do it. Even if you look at your notes for an hour a day starting reading period, or do one problem a day, I promise it makes all the difference. For reference this final was on the last day of the examination period (Wednesday) and I started the weekend before (Saturday) but did not take it seriously until Monday which resulted in me not being able to take both practice tests and losing out on sleep as I packed my suitcase and studied the night before. Another tip, I know you want to leave, but if you are not proactive and tend to procrastinate, I do not recommend flying out right after the exam because the extra stress is not worth it (though it is a sweet, sweet victory).Conclusion:Overall, it is a great course that does what it’s supposed to; I definitely have a strong foundation in chemistry and biology. You can definitely get an A if you work like you are supposed to and since this class is only offered in the fall semester, if you are even considering it just take it. For reference I am a potential physics concentrator but postponed physics in favor of this course. I hope I didn’t forget anything, and if you read all this, I hope it helped! I tried to include everything I wanted to know going in.
worse_comment: Study!!! So many students started from a disadvantage because they didn't do enough active practice before exams (me included). You will do well when you put in the work.

best_comment: I LOVED LPSA! As someone who was debating between LPSA and LS1A (especially because I had taken AP Biology but not AP Chem in high school), I am so glad that I stuck with LPSA. There is so much more support in LPSA, and you don't have annoying weekly PIEs like LS1A does. There is a decent amount of work in LPSA and you are in class more, but I feel like it is equivalent to the amount of work you have to do in LS1A (because of their learning pods). Especially as someone who had a roommate in LS1A who did not enjoy the class, I'm super grateful for LPSA and the immense support that they give. My best piece of advice would be to ask for help EARLY! I felt low–key embarrassed to ask for help at first, until I realized that I really needed it and requested a peer tutor through the ARC. Best decision ever. My tutor, Akua, was amazing and really helped quell my worries and review major topics coming up in exams.  Topics in LPSA are not so difficult where you need a tutor, but it was super helpful to make sure that I was reviewing content regularly outside of class, since that is really important for success in this class. Be sure you understand the material and are paying attention in class. Even though it's early at 9 AM, it really does make a difference in your coursework + saves time overall! Professor Tucci is great with large lectures, so it won't be too hard :)Section was super helpful for reinforcing content and applying it to practice problems. My TF, Ada, was amazing! She did a great job going over topics and would explain them in an easy–to–understand way while going through questions. I'm very grateful for LPSA. Even though it is considered to be the "easier" course as compared to LS1A, I learned a lot and was far less stressed than the LS1A students. Especially as a freshman who was still adjusting to college life, LS1A was the best decision to transition from high school to college learning.
worse_comment: Study!!! So many students started from a disadvantage because they didn't do enough active practice before exams (me included). You will do well when you put in the work.
