Another tip, I know you want to leave, but if you are not proactive and tend to procrastinate, I do not recommend flying out right after the exam because the extra stress is not worth it (though it is a sweet, sweet victory).Conclusion:Overall, it is a great course that does what it’s supposed to; I definitely have a strong foundation in chemistry and biology. You can definitely get an A if you work like you are supposed to and since this class is only offered in the fall semester, if you are even considering it just take it. For reference I am a potential physics concentrator but postponed physics in favor of this course. I hope I didn’t forget anything, and if you read all this, I hope it helped! I tried to include everything I wanted to know going in.
worse_comment: Study!!! So many students started from a disadvantage because they didn't do enough active practice before exams (me included). You will do well when you put in the work.

course_title: Introduction to the Ancient Greek World 001
best_comment: (Personal context: I'm a History & Classics joint, who has done well in the class so far)OVERALL: 7.5/10TEACHING STAFF (8.5/10): Dr. Kosmin's lectures are very engaging and super fun. He gives a very comprehensive history of Greece and its very intentional about going against the grain when it comes to accounting for things like foreign influences, which was refreshing. He also makes it all the way through lecture the vast majority of the time, so you never feel like you're missing out. He is very willing to pause lecture and provide further explanations for things or go down rabbit holes if you have a question. Very good with audience participation and is good at soliciting many different voices every lecture. Eli is a very good TF. His feedback on assignments always makes sense and he is very willing to meet with you during office hours to explain anything you don't understand. I once had to miss a lecture and Eli gave me my own personalized lecture during office hours, which made me feel like I missed basically nothing. He also offered to lend me his copy of our textbook more than once. He seems genuinely interested in making sure everyone succeeds in the class. He's great at leading section. My one criticism would be that he is longwinded, so if you're in office hours with somewhere to be, try not to ask too many questions.WORKLOAD (5/10): Readings are assigned per lecture instead of per week, which really annoyed me. My whole Sunday and Tuesday were taken up just doing the readings for this class. Most of the readings aren't mentioned in lecture or section, and frankly can be skimmed or skipped if you have other work to do. When readings are mentioned in lecture, Dr. Kosmin summarizes whatever is most important about them anyway (either their thesis or how they changed classical scholarship). The textbook we had this semester is very comprehensive, but everything discussed in the textbook will be reiterated in a more comprehensive, synthesized, engaging, and sensical manner in lecture. We are also only ever quizzed/tested on information from lectures, not the readings, which make them feel especially extraneous. There are weekly quizzes on information from lecture, but every lecture is accompanied by a silly little handout from Eli that literally tells you every thing you need to learn from that lecture that you'll be quizzed on, so you just need to pay enough attention in lecture to note what's important about each item. Literally the most painless weekly quizzes I've ever had. We also have weekly discussion posts that are graded on completion, and Eli makes really fun prompts that always get you thinking harder about the history or scholarship. MIDTERM & FINAL (9/10): Since there are weekly quizzes, you know exactly what to expect on the midterm and final. There's also a final project/paper, and the project option is really cool. You get to do stuff with items from the Harvard Art Museums.
subject: Classical Studies
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Ancient Greek World

best_comment: This class is awesome! Ancient Greek warfare is fascinating, and the professor and the TFs did an excellent job bringing the material to life. This course made learning about history fun and accessible, and the work load was manageable. I highly recommend this class!
worse_comment: I am rather frustrated that I spent one of my valuable elective slots on this class. The class is marketed as focusing on the nature of ancient Greek warfare. Instead, we spent about two–thirds of the class looking at vases. That is not to say that nothing about warfare can be learned from pottery, but if you come in expecting detailed analyses of particular battles and military strategies, you will probably be disappointed. You will likely learn more about any single battle by reading its Wikipedia page than you will by taking this class. Additionally, lectures were often disorganized, forcing the TFs to do remedial work in section explaining what we were supposed to have learned that week. Despite the fact that this course had an extremely low workload, I would still not recommend it to friends –– I would rather have simply done the work for a more meaningful class. The professor also attempted to change the final project from a Powerpoint presentation to a substantial paper after the add–drop period had closed. Assignments were frequently posted to Canvas without any announcement and were given short deadlines. I should note in the interest of fairness that the course exposes you to a number of ancient Greek artifacts from the Harvard Art Museum's collection, which was a cool experience.
best_gem_comment: This is a huge gem

best_comment: This is a great survey course on the main themes and thinkers in ancient medicine. Prof. Schiefsky has a wide scope of knowledge and is a very enthusiastic instructor who takes the time to meet and engage with each student. If you have any interest in the history of medicine, this course is worth taking.
worse_comment: I came in wanting to foster my interest in medicine and classics, but did not feel fully satisfied.

best_comment: Great class, highly recommend taking this if you have any interest in Classics or even Ancient Greece and want to take an easy language class
subject: Greek

best_comment: If you're on this page you're either a classicist or someone who, trying to fulfil their language requirement, has stumbled on Ancient Greek. Interesting choice! Look, like a lot of intro language classes at H it's entirely run by the TF and the "professor" never appears. Ever. So it's dependent on the TF. If you get someone awesome then you'll love the class. I had a terrible TF for Greek 2 but an absolutely amazing one for Greek 3, so it's really down to chance.
subject: Greek

best_comment: Professor Rau is amazing and incredibly knowledgeable about pretty much everything –– you will learn a lot of linguistics whether you like it or not, but you should like it! Take this class also because Herodotus is AMAZING!

course_title: Dionysus and Greek Tragedy: Euripides' Bacchae 001
best_comment: The class is very good for a first class reading a piece of Greek literature, as so much support is given on grammar and reading. If one is looking for a class that expects one to have read well on one’s own and that consists mostly of discussion, this is probably not the best class to take.

if you struggle to pronounce (to my learning disabilities girlies) or language, in general, is painful, you should take this course. I have a learning disability that impairs language learning greatly. I have also taken three intro language courses at Harvard two romances and one Asian. the teachers will actually explain a grammar concept in several different ways to each person. That is real teaching right there. Not just saying the same thing over and over and be like why don't you get it – ugh that happens so often. the teacher and tf both have mastery over Latin and can offer several examples until you understand. HW was not busy work it all was exactly how the midterm and final were. no surprises. I loved that. you must do homework on time or your homework grade will suffer – so stay on top of it! The homework assignments are not hard or unnecessarily long it always felt like the right amount for three times a week I had no complaints The teachers were not mean about absences but actually nice!you find latin everywhere carved into random statues around campus this is not a dead unuseful language! and the most painless way to complete language requirements. take this course!!
subject: Latin

best_comment: This is a great class, but definitely challenging! Having an intermediate grasp on Spanish carried me through some of the toughest parts. Because there is no spoken/auditory component, you cover a lot of vocabulary and grammar. The course is pretty fast–paced, so be sure that you're willing to dedicate time outside of class to actually become familiar with the language, beyond just doing whatever you need to complete the homework assignments.
subject: Latin

best_comment: Please take this class if you like Latin. Made me feel more confident about my latin skills. It is unfortunate that Alex will not be teaching this class next semester but you should definitely take any class he teaches. He is wonderful and really goes above and beyond to make class fun.
subject: Latin

best_comment: It is hard but so so worth it. The assignments became easier each week, and I saw my own improvement every day.
subject: Latin

best_comment: I absolutely loved this course and cannot recommend it enough if you are taking Latin. The course content was super interesting and Professor Philbrick was incredibly engaging and accessible. I would definitely say that this course is a step up in terms of expectations and difficulty from the intermediate Latin courses, so there is a bit of a learning curve over the first couple weeks, but it is super rewarding to work with the course content at a higher level because of it. Office hours will absolutely be your friend. Make sure to start studying for the midterms well in advance (over a week) and to really review all the content before it because they will expect a lot in terms of ability to translate. Every word counts, so make sure to thoroughly review vocabulary and start building a list of new words at the beginning of the semester.

This class is a great but intensive overview of important Latin texts, and it is definitely not an easy course, no matter how experienced at Latin you might be. Most students this year agreed that the readings and assessments can take up a lot of time — much more than previous Latin classes I've taken here. I did appreciate how all students were treated as if we were experts on the material and had important contributions even if I was sometimes very lost in our discussions. If you're required as a languages and literatures track Classics concentrator to take this course, or if you're looking to improve your translation and sight–reading abilities quickly, then this is the course for you, but if you want something less time–consuming and are not feeling prepared for this course, take it the next time it is offered. I'm really glad I took the course when I did and had a good experience with it, but it's good to keep your other commitments and workload in mind.

I have a very love hate relationship with this class. It is an amazing course. Prof. Coleman is an amazing teacher who really cared about her students and is really good at making you learn all the material. But it is also a very time consuming class and probably the most difficult Classics Department course I have taken so far (ps. I have not taken 112s). Epigraphy is very nitty–gritty, and there are a lot of memorization in this class: abbreviations, epigraphic conventions, dates, historic context, so many things. And Prof. Coleman is not particularly a nice grader. Your quiz grade can easily go from A in the previous one to C or D in the next one, because so much of it depends on whether you are attentive enough to figure out everything on the stone. We have a lot of reading in English that are pretty overwhelming to get through but are never discussed in class. Not a lot of Latin reading for homework, but what we read in class is HARD. Most inscriptions or graffiti we translate are legalese (with tons of clauses), or have archaic spelling, or misspelling, or just poor grammar that hardly makes sense. You really have to think outside of the box and know your original forms and charts. There could be a million way to translate habere and facere in a legalese context. And you also have to learn so much weird vocab, anything ranges from "tunnel" to a kind of gladiator. The final project is pretty cool, but since so much scholarship on epigraphy in general is written in Italian or German or French, it was a pain to google translate every single article that is mildly relevant or to channel all the Latin you know to try to read Italian... I enjoyed writing my final paper and felt really accomplished afterward. But I do not miss the process of researching. I do not regret taking this class at all. It is really cool and refreshing to learn and read the regular Roman Latin, to laugh at their jokes, to emphasize with parents who lost their child. It also made my Latin grammar improve a lot, since I have to think in reverse on what ending should this abbreviated word has. Again, Prof. Coleman is a great and concise teacher on the basics. And I would definitely love to take more epigraphy classes in the future if there are any chances. But it was a challenging and time consuming class, and you should consider it at your own discretion.

Absolutely amazing professor! Great examples and enthusiasm for the language. I love how we barely did the same learning drills twice it was always a new learning experience, always very fun and unique learning experiences. I have never seen a professor have as much of a passion, care and enthusiasm for teaching as prof. DourouIt’s hard to describe the strengths of this course because of how many strengths there were. This course was an amazing experience. I absolutely grew as a student, and i’m so happy that my language requirement got to have such a positive impact on me by taking modern greek. What i would take away from this course is how beautiful it is when a group of people all love and appreciate a different language and culture so much. I feel that we were really immersed through food, body wash, commercials, shows, songs, and little amazing things like learning “Greek hospitality” through learning the word for offering someone something and saying thank you, “ ευχαριστώ” as the first thing we learn by passing food around to each otherTake modern greek! It’s the absolute best way to finish your required language. .
best_gem_comment: I would tell future students that this class is a gem! There is no pressure to master Greek, you just have to do your best and have fun in the class. It isn't your typical lecture style class, everything is very interactive which makes it more enjoyable to learn the language.
subject: Modern Greek

best_comment: THIS IS YOUR SIGN TO TAKE THIS CLASS!!! I'm confident that this class will likely be one of my favorites of my whole time here, as it was overall such a great experience and I learned so much from it. The syllabus was what initially drew me into signing up for this class, and after reading all the books I still stand by that fact, as I read intriguing novels that were often not what I was used to reading. Professor Damrosch really dissected each novel for us and I'm still amazed that he could pack that much analysis in a 2–hour class and completely redefine what I initially thought of each book, in some cases! He's an incredibly enthusiastic, engaging, and entertaining professor, who is also very supportive of his students and readily makes himself available to meet for office hours. Workload–wise, this class was light other than reading novels each week and a final paper at the end, which I loved because this allowed me to really focus on being able to dive into each novel without worrying about juggling other assignments simultaneously for the class, and I honestly think I learned and retained much more that way instead of having multiple assignments to do during the semester! Professor Damrosch also allowed us to get feedback on a draft of our final paper, which I feel like is rare for professors to do, which shows how much he is willing to help his students and really eased a lot of the stress in writing a final paper. He was also super receptive of student feedback on the readings for this course and is making some changes to the syllabus based on it, so I'm sure next semester will be even better in terms of the content! This was my first–ever CompLit class and it certainly won't be the last (seeing as this class helped solidify my decision to declare CompLit as my concentration), and I strongly recommend this class to anyone who is interested in learning more about literature!
worse_comment: If you love literature and if you are open to reading a novel every week, this class is for you. You would need to be able to balance your time throughout the week to be able to finish your readings. If you're not so good with making a schedule, you might have a hard time completing the readings every week and come prepared for class. I personally am a slow reader and not the best at scheduling, so I had a tough time finishing the readings on time.

course_title: The Arab American Experience in Fiction, Film, and Popular Culture SEM
best_comment: Everything in this course is amazing. I loved how interactive and immersive it was. The conversations spoken in class were extremely insightful and enlightening. As an Arab, the class felt like a great way to grasp Middle Eastern literature and other art mediums and discover new perspectives from authors I have not thought of. The course was my favorite of the semester and it felt like a privilege to attend class weekly. While the readings do take up time, sometimes ranging from 6–7 hours a week, I found them very enjoyable. Professor Naddaff is an amazing professor who is incredibly understanding, engaging, and enthusiastic about the course topics. I would highly recommend this course to everyone.

course_title: Comparative Literatures of the Indian Ocean LEC
best_comment: Take this class! Professor Lienau is one of the true gems at Harvard: she is genuinely invested in her students and in curating an incredibly rewarding seminar experience. She is incredibly prepared for class and oozes competence and expertise — she truly generates enthusiasm for her subject matter!
worse_comment: I would tell future students that if you don't read the books, you are setting yourself up for failure. It is crucial to contribute to the discussions and the class is extremely small. Also, it's important to read every page that is asked of you to read because they will move through everything quickly and analyze every aspect.

course_title: Beyond Subtitles: A Media Theory of Foreignness LEC
best_comment: Such a great course! Subject matter is really really interesting and is approached from so many different angles. The range of films shown in class is great and there is flexibility for the class to suggest additions. An interesting range of assignments including a translation project.

Really enjoyable course, would really recommend doing all of the readings, I don't think I would have read some of these novels otherwise, and I am so grateful that I did—especially with the context from the philosophy and the support of the discussions to help interpret the texts
worse_comment: I loved this class, but if you do not enjoy heavy readings and highly theoretical discussions, you probably will not.

course_title: Comparative Literature in Theory and Practice 001
best_comment: This course is a fantastic way to encounter comparative literature. It opens far more questions than it answers, so its best function is as starting point for further research in other contexts.
Take it! It's informative and chill. Prof. Thomas is enthusiastic and knowledgeable. It's a very rewarding course!

course_title: Incentives in the Wild: from Tanking in Sports to Mining Cryptocurrencies 001
best_comment: This was one of the cooler and chiller classes I have taken. It introduces you to a new way of thinking, and the material you go over is actually very interesting. The only thing I will say is that some of the lectures can be a little boring as it can get into pretty dense math, but you really don't truly need to understand the complex math and its proofs. As long as you understand the major conceptual takeaways you will be fine. Definitely not much work outside of class as there were only 3 psets all year (1 per month), each  of which was based on completion. Each one took 3 hours max, and that was because I cared about actually getting the answers right, and being pretty thorough. Additionally, every student has to take notes for one lecture and then write a page about your takeaways, and my only qualm is that this was pretty harshly graded given that they give us almost no info on what they expected. Thus, I would really make sure you write these in depth. Finally, most of your grade (75%) will depend on the final project which is also not much work as they do a good job of spreading out the milestones. It is a group project which is nice too, so doing it with your friends is really chill and you get full ownership over choosing your topic. If you choose a fun topic, it will actually be enjoyable. I have yet to receive my grade back for this final project, but seeing everyone present their project was really cool and low stress as the presentation wasn't graded. Overall, I definitely recommend this class as Yannai is a great person and professor.
worse_comment: This class is a little weird – big on the project–based learning, but you get NO feedback until the final paper which is 75% of your grade, which is frustrating.
best_gem_comment: Yannai is an absolute gem, as well as the rest of the teaching staff. It is interesting to frame incentives and how they impact decisions and it was so cool to see how it plays out using math. The paper was easy as long as you have a good group that works well together. I had a blast working on every part of this class and am so sad that it's over. TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!

best_comment: I took CS50 with AP Java background, and I felt like this made for a really nice transition. The first couple weeks were familiar, but I learned so much more than what was covered in AP Java. I'm so glad I took this course – it was great to be exposed to so many different languages, even if we didn't go super deep into any of them. I think this course lays a strong foundation to continue your computer science education. That being said, the course is very fast paced, which is why I suggested some background in computer science before enrolling. I know people that didn't have a background previously, and they had to put in significantly more work to catch up, but it's doable. The course definitely felt like a production at times with the high–tech lectures and all of the events, but it was really cool. I enjoyed the lunch at Changsho and the CS50 Hackathon. The final project was a really great way to apply the skills you learned to whatever you want. Highly recommend doing the final project with one or two group members. This made the project much more fun and enjoyable and productive. Overall, I really recommend CS50!
worse_comment: Take if you want a surface level overview of various languages and computer science concepts. While some of the concepts and p–sets do go in–depth, they are not routinely enforced since there are no tests. If you want a strong computer science foundation moving forward (conceptually), this course is not the best because you learn by doing once but the course moves so fast you are not consistently developing your skills and knowledge. It is definitely overhyped, and lectures are generally a waste of time especially if you have taken computer science courses before (most learning happens by actually doing the problem sets on your own). Don't take this course if you are just band–wagoning, you can find another (computer science or other) course worth your time. However, because it is pass / fail anyone can take this course without a problem. The problem sets are necessarily hard, just time consuming, so don't take this course letter graded if you aren't willing to put in the time. Assignments are graded arbitrarily and even subjectively, so that is another factor to consider.
subject: Computer Science

subject: Computer Science

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS AND SAVOR YOUR TIME IN IT!!! I can go on forever just raving about this class, and I truly mean that I stand by all the positive reviews of this course. CS 61 never failed to make my day; I always looked forward to attending lectures on Mondays and Wednesdays, and on the days that we didn't have lectures or sections, namely on Fridays, I would feel a little sad. Any day with CS 61 is a good day. And Professor Mickens is one of, if not the top, reason that makes this class so worth taking. He is an absolutely BRILLIANT professor and an even more inspiring systems expert. Coming in with some experience with systems and embedded security,  I found myself growing increasingly fascinated by the topics and concepts discussed in class. Although comprehending the materials wasn't always an initial 100% direct osmosis transfer of ideas and genius as Mickens intended, this course really gives you the time and opportunity to marinate and ask questions to fully grasp the granular details throughout the week. Mickens is a phenomenal lecturer in the way that he understands the subject so well that each lecture almost transforms into storytelling –– he is engaging, coherent (like a buffer cache), and thoughtful and detailed when responding to students' questions. Not to mention the terrific slides that are constantly interspersed with hilarious memes and jokes that never fail to crack the class up. Time truly flies in this class, because I never notice that an hour and fifteen minutes have passed until Mickens announces the end of a lecture. I left 1.321 every Monday and Wednesday wishing for even a little more time going down rabbit holes and exploring topics beyond the level taught in the course. It is so easy to become completely immersed and engrossed in the granular details when you're in this class. Heck, I even nearly got to meet former president Obama thanks to this class and Professor Mickens! He, along with the rest of the teaching staff, is so available, approachable, and supportive. After every lecture (and I do mean every single one), Professor Mickens would spend 1.5 – 2 hours of extended office hours to answer our questions, explore concepts (unveiling all the "gore" that truly goes on behind the scenes of some concepts we abstract away for the sake of the class) beyond the depth at which they're presented in the course, and share some of his seemingly endless number of life stories. This class has given me such an invaluable introduction to CS at Harvard and it has been a wonderfully transformative experience overall. Additionally, the course is easily one of the most well–structured and reasonably paced CS class I have ever taken –– the pset schedule is manageable, and there is a plethora of OHs throughout the week to help clarify concepts you may be confused about at first. The psets are very interesting and the extra credit opportunities are super cool! If you are on the fence about taking it (especially as a freshman), take it!! Start psets early, find your group, engage in the Ed forum, and enjoy the course!!! I have found so many friends and mentors through CS 61, and I would recommend this course in a heartbeat to anyone who is interested in systems programming or would just like to learn more about it.
worse_comment: As hard as Mickens tries, there’s only so much you can do to make systems interesting. He’s a top lecturer in Harvard’s CS department but I ended up skipping lecture a lot this semester because systems is just so boring. Psets aren’t as scary as they seem although youre kinda screwed if you don’t do extra credit.
subject: Computer Science

subject: Computer Science

best_comment: I loved this class!!! It is an awesome opportunity to combine art and code into one medium. The class meets twice a week with one lecture and one critique class, so the schedule is pretty chill. Usually each week there is a creative assignment which can take time depending on your experience level. Personally, I am more on the art–side and only took CS50 (two years ago), so the assignments were challenging and time–consuming. Some assignments I spent 10+ hours, but I really enjoyed the work in designing visualizations. More CS experience would be super helpful and would make the workload lighter. You will love this class as long as you love art/visualizing data or have CS experience
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Design of Useful and Usable Interactive Systems 001
best_comment: This was a great course, extremely well–structured and interactive. As with any project–based course, your experience will be highly dependent on the teams you end up working with, but the course materials are fantastic and the teaching staff is very supportive. You learn a lot about product design by doing it, especially with Figma, which is super useful. This course also interweaved ethics content really well. Definitely recommend as a different kind of CS course than the usual, although it is certainly not easy, especially during pitch weeks.
worse_comment: Take this class if you want to work collaboratively in groups to learn more about design principles! It will be a great experience if you work in good groups for each project, but a bad group with slacking team members could ruin it for you. The best part is no psets and no exams!!

best_comment: This class is incredibly interesting!  I have learned so much––from different issues in privacy that I hadn't really thought about before to how to discuss open–ended issues with those around me.  This is because this course is a survey on different topics in privacy, in which you get to learn about fascinating technologies and their uses.  And the course is super interactive:   you are frequently encouraged to discuss with your peers during class.   The readings were very interesting, though do take quite a bit of time.  Some of the initial papers are stressful and nobody does well as you have to write in a new writing style, but that's okay!  Professor Waldo is super encouraging and tells you not to worry about it!  I had such a wonderful time getting to learn from him, as he's hilarious and really cares about his students.
worse_comment: This course is unique among CS classes in the way that you have to do no coding at all if you so choose, but the assignments can definitely drag. They open on Friday and are due on Sunday (weekly), and frequently are 4–page essays or equivalent. I wouldn't say it's too bad, but know that that's what you're signing up for if you're a CS student who much prefers problem sets over essays.
best_gem_comment: This is a good class, and it shows some really cool parts of the privacy side of the course. Definitely a good one for those getting a secondary. Waldo is a gem, literally the best ever.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: The good things: by far one of the most useful classes to take at Harvard. Independent of programming level, I feel like you learn SO MANY SKILLS that are simply so useful regardless of whether you want to do SWE or not. If any of your work remotely involves computers/coding/collaboration, it's so helpful to take this to learn git, learn how to systematize your files, it's been so helpful for research. Also the content is genuinely super interesting and I felt like the labs kind of forced you to engage with every part of the syllabus, so you genuinely become a much better coder.The bad things: this class is the biggest mess I've ever seen at Harvard. I didn't even know courses got to this level of disorganization, and I feel like that becomes even more painful in a class where your work *actually* counts a lot for your grade. Little to no feedback on HWs, it took like 2 months to have some type of schedule defined, project was completely chaotic and we got no feedback up to the final milestone. Very different to 109a/b for example, where it's much more structured. I think the staff is aware and I can imagine they make this better in future years, and I really hope they do, because the class is great and Ignacio is an amazing professor!
worse_comment: Materials but only materials are good. Other than materials, everything is messed up:1.A lot of important materials covered in previous years are not covered this year;2.So much confusion about deadlines, grading, submission, etc. It's very messy. There was once a student requested to fix the autograder, and then what the Professor/Head TA did was remove the autograder instead of fixing it. I was completely shocked by how they do things in this class.3.Everything the instructor added to the class is completely unreasonable. I spent 90% time trying to understand astronomy and only 10% time understanding the 107 concepts.4.The head TA doesn't respect anonymous posting on ED. If I post something there, they will reply to my post with my name in this. 5.Going to class is meaningless. The lecture is very boring.6.Please choose a good professor if you decide to take this class. I wasted 1/4 of my tuition on this class.

course_title: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science 001
best_comment: lots of work, but very fulfilling. if you have an interest in data science/analytics, this class is really great! it definitely helps if you already know how to code in python, but it's not too hard to learn as you go. lectures: pavlos and kevin are great lecturers imo and the slides are super good. sometimes they'll spend a while answering questions, but lectures are overall efficient and effectiveassignments: psets were mostly biweekly, but super long... be prepared to spend lots of hours finishing the psets. final project: LOVE THAT WE HAD A FINAL PROJECT INSTEAD OF FINAL EXAM! just make sure to work with people you know will get their work done or else you're left with a lott of work to do. milestones are nicely spaced out and definitely help with getting the project done early:)exam: midterm had in–class mcq portion and take–home coding portion. take–home portion was easier than the mcq by far. mcq was open note and internet, but was super hard lol make sure to study
worse_comment: AVOID THIS COURSE AT ALL COST. If you are interested in learning data science methods, I would suggest taking some combination of Stat 139/149 and MIT 6.3900, which will  be much more comprehensive and, more importantly, far less annoying as a course. This course assigned a lot of busywork, and it could feel like the staff did not have much respect for students' time (especially when they assigned a major project milestone to be due on the Monday after Thanksgiving break, and a homework due two days after that). It also often felt like the staff put in much less effort than it asked of students, and held itself to a much lower standard than it did the students. The assignments — and even the exams — were riddled with typos, coding errors, and other mistakes, and they were often very unclear in the way they were written. When asking questions, the teaching staff always led with a condescending tone, and were extremely unwilling to admit they had done something wrong — they would even gang up on students on Ed when one suggested that there was a mistake in an assignment. I and all of the other students I talked to were extremely frustrated with the course by the time December came around. I would not even wish this course on my worst enemy.
best_gem_comment: FGLI FYRE CERTIFIED undegrad RESPONSE: If you are interested data science, environmental science & engineering,  EPS, or any other concentration that requires some sort of research or handling of data, YOU NEED to take this course. I am a cs concentrator and THIS COURSE GOT ME MY FIRST DATA SCIENCE INTERNSHIP. It literally taught me everything i needed to know and i was so surprised at how vocational this course really is. This course is super organized on ed, slides are very pretty, lectures mostly easy to follow (not when kevin lectures im sorry). But i don't think i was ever taught anything that didn't matter you know? It all seemed important and very useful and helped me do really well in data science interviews. Problem sets were super easy for me im not going to lie. If you KNOW how to code this class is kind of breeze most times because you can get away with knowing the main idea behind stuff and the coding parts are very plug and chug and I wouldn't say I did any serious thinking. Final project is a little different because you don't have your hand held, but it was very manageable. Cs50 is DEFINITELY 100% ENOUGH. and if you only took an r course (like stat 100) you are 100 % okay you can do this and you will not regret it. I procrastinated on every pset. THey can take a fat minute to finish which is the hard part, and theres no clever solution or something that will save you time ya know? late days are a blessing too </3. I would say the first psets are difficult the rest was a breeze. I think the hard part comes when you have to interpret things or make decisions about the direction you take your models. THats where the true data science knowledge is applied I would say. ANyway, i took cs107, cs61, and this course at the same time with a gem! Extremely doable ladies trust me you got this.

course_title: Introduction to Algorithms and their Limitations 001
best_comment: A lot to learn in this course. I really liked it (maybe not in the moment at times, but now that it's over, I feel like it was rewarding!) Don't be scared of it! It's hard in the beginning but it'll get easier, I promise. Get help if you need it, please. If there's a Patel Fellow, I highly recommend reaching out for help. I was lucky enough to have an amazing Patel Fellow, Noa Kligfeld, guide me throughout the entire course. Couldn't have done it without her if I'm being honest. But overall, this course made me much more interested in CS and the ways to problem–solve in CS. I really liked it and I recommend it. I think it could've been taught better at times, but the material is super interesting and the lecture notes are great. So, although lectures aren't the most exciting, if you're willing and able to take yourself through the course too (and with extra guidance from other resources) then it's worth it!
worse_comment: I had a lot of trouble understanding some of the lectures, and the midterm was a lot more difficult than previous years so a lot of people were underprepared for it.  The problem sets were doable, but I think my general criticism is that I never really had time to fully think about/grasp the concepts of this course because it would already be time to start the next problem set.  Otherwise, it was very doable with STAT110, which is a very common thing to do. It is also a good class to take after taking CS 20 in the previous spring semester.

course_title: Introduction to Algorithms and their Limitations 001

Otherwise, it was very doable with STAT110, which is a very common thing to do. It is also a good class to take after taking CS 20 in the previous spring semester.

best_comment: This class is like a visit to the doctor's office. The doctor is lovely, they're clearly skilled at what they do and they can get their point across to you very well. It is also healthy that you go, because you cannot go further in life without the insight the doctor's visit will give you. However, your visit may sting a bit. (Also Boaz won't be teaching this next year so take the following with a grain of salt)TL;DR: This is a great class, but the grading is a bit annoying, the textbook isn't the best, and Boaz doesn't show up to his own final, which feels somehow symbolic.Let me explain.Boaz is great: he speaks a bit slowly, but his lecture style is very strong, clear, and gets at the important bits of the material while cutting out as much of the faff as possible. The material is also wonderful: it really is bedrock–level stuff for understanding CS and the class really gives you an overview of the entire field of CS theory, so while you may not be able to read current research right after it, you at least know where to start and can recognize the ideas and link them back to what you know. There is also a great deal of pop–CS that you learn here: P vs NP, Turing Machines, Uncomputability, Godel's Theorem, as well as trendy stuff like ML theory and quantum computing.The homework is fine: it's a significant amount of work but it's not killer (I think 10–12h a week is fair), plus there are reflections available on the psets to regain some credit, and usually some bonus on top of that (PSET 3 is the hardest, hang in there!). The flip side: everyone gets 100% on the pset component of the class, meaning your grade is entirely determined by the exams.So, how are these exams? They're not *too* bad: all the material this year I feel was quite fair, but you should definitely read the textbook, since some questions were lifted straight from solved textbook examples. The final was also very very fair and there was plenty of practice material (plus PSET 10's solutions were quite useful).Ok, so how is the textbook? Not great. It's very verbose at times, there are mistakes/typos here and there (which increase exponentially in the second half of the course) which make it hard to read and a bit boring, so I recommend watching the relevant lecture first to discriminate what the important bits of information from a particular chapter are, to then deepen those with the textbook, not the other way around. Boaz also has his own definitions of things, separate from the standard, which are debatable; they are definitely more intuitive and modern, but I don't know if proofs over them are as simple as they would be with Sipser's definitions, for instance.The section component is great, and a lot of my understanding came from the CAs, who were all excellent. Attendance being required and Perusall comments / Ed questions being tracked are a bit annoying, but they're not a great hassle.
worse_comment: This class was very difficult and made me reconsider my concentration in computer science. Don't take it as a senior.

course_title: Fairness and Privacy: Perspectives from Law and Probability 001
best_comment: Found this course because it satisfies a lot of CS requirements, and was pleasantly surprised with the course material. This is probably some of the most interesting applied mathematics in computer science. As a bonus, Prof. Dwork is part of a hotbed at Harvard for the study of Differential Privacy, and it was satisfying to have questions answered directly whenever. That is also a small downside, though, as finding additional explanations online only yields scientific papers. Definitely take this if you are interested in secure secret sharing mechanisms, cryptography, and privacy as a whole. It is theory–based PSETS due every two weeks that shouldn't take more than 10 hours each.
worse_comment: This is a highly relevant class given the recent advances in AI, and the joint sessions with law students offers a chance for inter–disciplinary discussion! However, the CS–only classes are often overly technical with difficult problem sets to follow, so be prepared to do the work!
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2024: Fairness and Privacy: Perspectives from Law and Probability

best_comment: David Parkes is the best professor at Harvard. That being said he probably won't be teaching the class going forward, so I'll try to focus on other reasons on why you should take this class. 1) Reinforce core material in interesting contexts. This class utilizes bits and pieces from CS 124 / STAT 110 but does it in an interesting context that had me a lot more motivated to understand everything thoroughly than, for example, the highly  abstract treatment that STAT 110 often gave.  2) The final project and lack of final exam. The scope of topics you can write about is very large and you can have a lot of fun with this if you want, or you can play it safe and write a survey paper. 3) Rewire your brain to think about incentive properties. Unlike an algorithms class where you are often assumed to have some input and then you study how to transform it into a desired output, CS 136 flips this idea on its head and teaches you to consider how the "algorithm" itself might influence the input you receive. For example, google "The Boston Mechanism" for an interesting case study that is covered in the course. 4) The textbook. It has some typos here and there, but other than that it's just about as good as the STAT 110 textbook, i.e. it's very good. 5) The students. I found that the level of excitement for the course by other students was noticeably higher than it has typically been in other classes. Probably some sort of strong self–selection bias. 6) Applicability. It is true that this class can be a lot of work at times but it never really feels like it since everything is so well–motivated. If you're in CS and even remotely curious about economics do yourself a favor and take 136.
worse_comment: David is a fantastic professor, but unfortunately he will no longer teach the course in the future.

best_comment: Honestly, looking back I'm realizing that actually this class was really well run, I was just far less organized than in other semesters (generally scrambling on other CS work, thanks CS165). I think Stephen Chong (Prof Chong, Steve? What does one use on the QGuide?) is really a solid instructor and both is clearly interested in the course and in you (I didn't do this much, but he just seems super nice to chat to. If you're reading this, thanks :). My friend who took 152 told me before I took the class 'he gives the definition of a CS lecture', and that's exactly how I would put it. There's no Eddie emacs wizardry, there's no Mickens meme pyrotechnics, but nor is there a Hesterberg black board derivation that causes abject misery in 80% of those unfortunate enough to be actually trying to pay attention in 124 lecture (for context, I really like Adam too and actually enjoy his lectures, but I can understand why some don't) etc. Rather, you get the content delivered at a reasonable pace, at generally very clearly. If you were paying attention, it will make sense, and you will walk out feeling like you learned something in basically every lecture.  While sometimes I miss that thrill of the CS (or other) class where you have no idea what the heck is going to go down each day, it is nice knowing that if you pay attention in lecture, you should basically know everything you need to know (no section which rocks, and lecture is clear enough that I don't think anybody will say they want section here). PSET0 is not a real comparison to the main PSETs, I maybe wish they made it slightly harder or introduced a few other things that will be helpful to know in OCaml that appears in the starter code and you then have to google, or if you're like me, ignore until PSET4 and just shrug and say 'it's in the handout, it works somehow' and then discover what '@@'  does and why actually it kinda rocks in the ocaml world. The PSETs are decently hefty, but totally doable and fine if you start at reasonable times (again, 165 meant sometimes I was starting like 1–2 days before deadlines, and having to dip into late days. This can be done, but it was pretty stressful as someone who hates doing work last minute, and one PSET I made a bad design decision that I couldn't really recover from and took the hit knowing that I was gonna fail like half the student tests. Student tests are generally like 5% of a PSET grade though, so it cost like 2%, no biggie).Final is totally fair, PSET late days are pretty generous and office hours were overall good. In summary, just a really solid CS course – you'll learn a good amount, you shouldn't lose too much hair (it's an important metric to me okay) and you'll have a reasonably good time doing it.

Having just submitted, it's hard to know what to say here. This was brutal, as expected. I feel like I learned a lot, as I expected. I don't think I walked away with a huge amount of insane knowledge about how data systems work. Yes I understand batching, indexing and joins far better than I did coming in (but you could learn about a B–tree and it would make sense from a 20min youtube video, and hash joins is mostly just... use a good hash table). I am also not a perf or gdb god, or suddenly converted to neovim and ascended to a higher level of CS entity within the CS community (maybe that will be after 161 next sem, don't ask why I'm doing this to myself in my senior year, and perhaps use this to caveat all opinions shared here). However, I without a doubt feel that I became a better systems programmer. It's rare here you need to actually think about how to organize a project. My final code, just including .c files that I wrote, is 5500–6000 lines of C. Honestly that doesn't feel like that much now, but after re–writing functions, changing how things fitted together, the amount of code I've deleted, changing or refactored, I reckon I actually wrote 2–3x that this semester. Thinking about how you organize a project of that size was super valuable to me. What functions should be accessible in other files. What should be defined in shared header files, what should be unique to each header file. Maybe you want to use extern. Maybe you want to consider what should be global, what should be specific to a client context.  I actually genuinely considered cache effects – I changed my load function at some point (much later than I should've), and watched my load performance improve by a factor of like 50 (yes, if you're reading this in the class, make your load faster earlier and save yourself pain later. Or don't and get the learning experience). I experimented with the worst nested loop join, then the cache page at a time nested loop join, and crazy, it makes a HUGE difference. Just some examples. I didn't really ever think about the TLB and never really needed to it felt like.Lectures were overall pretty good, I have no idea where an attendance grade came from at the midterm so please be careful about that and ask about attendance points. The first midterm was psycho hard, the second one was in my opinion, extremely doable (I got a 70 on the first one, admittedly I got the takehome deadline wrong, but I still think I would get <90 (/100 but with like 40 bonus points I think), second one I got 130/130). I would recommend watching a few of the sections and going to lab in the first few weeks to get setup, maybe I just can't read but setting up the testing locally etc was a bit of a headache initially.The testing set up this year felt a bit all over the place, the tests literally were being changed up until the last week and had a major change at the end of Novemeber. I hope this is a one time pain point and not a problem for future years, as it was pretty confusing/caused some stress, unsure if tests were failing because I can't code or because the tests were broken, changed or whatever. Labs also didn't run every day as promised on the website, I barely used them (probably a mistake) but I think it's worth saying, I think the course needs one or two extra staff for future iterations.My brain power is running out, I submitted the report like 5 hours ago and am completely spent, but just to end on some practical tips that maybe will be useful if you do decide to take the course:–> Do milestone 0, it takes very little time and you'll thank your previous self a HUGE amount when you're fighting the deadline at the end like most of us. I was able to do naive hash joins in a few hours since I had the hash table from m0 ready to go (please don't bank on this though).–> Write some unit tests. I had one void function like test_batch() in most of my header files, so that I didn't have to add functions to the header file that shouldn't be accessible outside the function (other option is two versions of the header file, and use different include paths, I started going this route initially but it was just a bit of a hassle). This really helped me at times, especially for index creation – writing unit tests to check my sorting stuff was working correctly meant I knew that my cache conscious mergesort worked correctly, so it must be how I was calling it that was wrong, helped me spot a dumb mistake very fast that otherwise I might've been trying to debug my sort algo forever. Just one example.–> Write a better load function than just stream inserts. Just do it, it'll take you like three–four hours and make your life better.–> Think about how you're going to break up db_manager.c almost instantly :)–> Use doubles for averages. I quite literally replaced every occurence of the word float with double (matching case) and it fixed my printing for averages lmao.–> You're going to need to print in chunks. Sorry, it's inevitable.There's probably a bucnh more but I can't stay awake any longer. I think if I did the project again, I would make 5x better decisions with what I've learned, and that knowledge will help me in the future, I'm almost certain. If you choose to hop on board, good luck :)
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This class is like taking a walk on a sunny day in a beautiful garden full of flowers after being in a hurricane for so long. This class is a breath of fresh air in the CS department. It reminded me why I love coding and I am so happy I took it. You get real coding experience and learn about such an important topic. This class is low stress but you genuinely learn!! Also, being in a class with a lot of grad students gets rid of the toxic CS culture that is sometimes present at Harvard. I love the professors so much they have genuinely been my favorite STEM professors here. They care about the topic with such a strong passion.You could take this class with the level of CS50. At first, they help a lot with the assignments and then they let go of your hand eventually. You really have to know which office hours are good as some of them will try to dismiss you, which is really the only flaw of the course.  the final project is also really rewarding and it is nice to have for a resume.
worse_comment: This is an incredibly time–consuming and difficult class. It teaches you so much about how to design and implement data visualizations, but the pace is so fast that some learning is lost in favor of blind survival. The labs are deceptively time–consuming, and having labs, problem sets, quizzes, and in–class activities all due on the same day at the same time is difficult to manage at times.
best_gem_comment: gem cs course as content isn't hard, it just requires time (they tell you ~10hrs per week). if you are familiar with js, html/css then you'll do fine. course staff is very helpful during OH, not so much on Ed. staff are very passionate about visualizations which makes the class more fun

best_comment: – I think there's a lot of variance in TF quality (this year), as I sometimes got help that led me in the wrong direction, which really sucked because I just sunk hours into problems that I could have figured out faster on my own. But also, TF section notes were really really good, and probably the only way I was able to learn stuff– I get the feeling the professors were pretty detached from TFs (/the course in general) and there weren’t really standards for how much the TFs should do, so it was a little chaotic.– lectures are sometimes really bad. I had taken some ML + algo courses before, which is what made the lectures doable/semi–understandable, since I already knew most of MDPs, DP, etc. By the way, the lingo is so different from what I’m familiar with, but this is mostly doable once you take the time to relearn definitions and reason through why they’re equivalent (or subtly diff). Attendance was required, so I mostly sat in class listening until I realized it was a filler episode or that I was so utterly confused that I’d be better off doing other work.– Very early on we were told textbook was optional, so naturally I did not read the textbook before class. There’s a lot of extra stuff in it, so I actually still wouldn’t recommend reading it before class. That being said, you might be less confused during lectures if you do read it? But also they sometimes didn’t post the relevant readings until a a couple weeks later.– Psets are fun, very very doable just from looking at slides/section notes/textbook, and fairly satisfying. No complaints here (just that the Ed could be a bit slow if you did happen to get confused). For these, I would sit down for a really long time, read the textbook and section notes, and work through the pset, which is the only way I actually learned anything from this class. So basically I learned the content in like 4 spurts, cuz there are 4 psets.– The midterm was so different from the practice ones, it was literally written in google docs or something and the physical formatting made it so difficult to actually fill out (i.e. diagrams on previous pages and then like 1/8–height cells to fill out in a table on the next page). It was like 2–3x longer than any practice exams given. Genuinely, have never taken such a poorly thought–out exam. It was like the professors realized they had to write an exam at 1am the night before and just slapped some stuff onto a random document, no proofreading or nice formatting or whatever.– When we asked for clarification on grading/curves after the midterm, a TF tried to give a nice estimate of what would happen with curves, but no discrete answer. I assume this is because the professors were detached and didn’t really care about this class, so I'm still not sure how the grading works in this class. I assume not too terrible though, idk. – Overall really disappointed, since I do feel like the material in this class (psets, content, past exams, section notes) have been meticulously organized and are superb. Just think that some course staff/maybe professors did a poor job in making this a class that I actually cared about or liked, since it felt like they just didn’t care either (with the exception of 1–2 outstanding TFs).
worse_comment: Don't take this course unless it is required. The professors are very knowledgeable in their respective domains but do not do a good job teaching at all. They are also very lazy with the course material –– there are typos all over the lecture slides, they don't bother with clean notations (e.g. subscripting, etc.), and problem set questions are worded terribly.

best_comment: This course gives a very good overview of popular reinforcement learning algorithms. You get to cover the shiny exciting realm of deep RL, but also some classic algorithms that turn out to be surprisingly useful. Although this class does go over the statistical justifications behind most of the algorithms, I wouldn't let that scare you. The course does a very good job of giving intuitive explanations for each algorithm and why they might do as well as they do, and I found that understanding these explanations could carry me quite far. Problem sets are pretty chill since they're across multiple weeks, so as long as you don't leave them for the last minute they are very doable. They also give you a lot of freedom for your final project, and it turned out to be the least stressful part of my finals period. Overall if you are interested in machine learning and want to see what reinforcement learning is about, I think this class does a great job of showing what is being used in practice today.
