course_title: Introduction to Computational Linguistics and Natural-language Processing 001
best_comment: Content wise?  This is a great course.  You learn a ton about classic NLP and if you've done everything right, you'll leave the course with a pretty cool final project that really does cumulatively build upon everything you study.  That being said, you are pretty much entirely self taught in this course.  The lectures are few and far between (maybe six the entire semester?) and fairly useless and redundant if you've done the readings.  Make sure you read the textbook and go to office hours if you're stuck on labs, but don't expect much in the way of guided instruction/feedback.  Honestly I would still recommend this class because the material is just so so interesting, but if you're on the fence or concerned about the time commitment just download the textbook online for free and read it cover to cover––you'll receive 75% of the same education.  Also, don't come into this class expecting to spend a ton of time on the ultra contemporary developments in the field.  If you're someone who has AI on the brain after playing with ChatGPT and wants to learn everything about LLMs, this is not the class for you (we only cover transformers/attention in the last segment of the course).
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. I am so disappointed to write this, because I've been wanting to take this class since I was a freshman (I'm a senior). It was unfortunately a truly terrible experience. I've never taken a class this poorly run. I never leave Q reviews like this, but this class was a logistical nightmare. We didn't get any grades back until the last week of the semester, and even then (as of the last day before Q reviews are due) we have not received feedback on any of the major assignments, including the first one which was due in the first week of OCTOBER. This made it impossible for me to learn/grow/improve –– I have no idea how I'm doing in this class. Staff did not answer questions on Ed, even though this was the way that we were told to get in touch with course staff –– important Ed questions would get 20+ likes and go completely ignored. Labs and assignments were confusing and there was barely any help offered, with office hours for the entire 100+ course only offered during a 2–hour window on Thursday and a 3–hour window on Fridays. This meant that if you had class during these times, there was no way to get help, and office hours were mobbed and panicked. Additionally, from Friday afternoon to Thursday night, there was no way to get help. TFs would consistently show up 30+ minutes late to office hours, and sometimes would not show up at all, instead posting on Ed after the fact. Staff was not at all responsive to student concerns and really didn't seem to care. The grading that we did receive was confusing and we were not able to see or understand why we got points off. The labs varied wildly in length, and were often far too long to complete in class, which was incredibly stressful as there was no help offered outside of class. They were often confusing/tedious/stressful. By the end of the class, I had lost hope that I would actually understand the material, and was just doing my best to solve the problems and get by. I don't feel like I learned anything or like I actually understand NLP.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2024: Introduction to Computational Linguistics and Natural-language Processing

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! TAKE THIS CLASS!! I cannot recommend it highly enough. If you are interested in theory, if you interested in machine learning at all, then this is the class for you. In my honest opinion, this class explores one of the most exciting research fields in math, computer science, and statistics. There is an abundance of empirical phenomena in machine learning/deep learning that are not well–understood, and the nascent theory to try to explain them is flourishing (most of the papers Prof. Chen discusses are less than 10 years old.)   If you are curious about this extremely new area of theory, then this class gives you the right mental framework, the mathematical tools, the background to think about these problems.  In that regard, this class was a formative experience for me and inspired me to go to graduate school.  Prerequisites: In terms of concrete requirements you should know theoretical linear algebra (Axler suffices) and real analysis. The research field does not use sophisticated techniques beyond this, and Prof. Chen introduces the background knowledge when necessary. The main requirement is strong problem solving skills.  Lectures: The lectures are very fast, as Prof. Chen basically goes through a paper or two every lecture. It is not easy to follow the lectures, but I thought they were extremely fun, challenging, and engaging. Prof. Chen also does a great job at emphasizing the important ideas of a paper and appropriately splits time between derivations and big concepts. Moreover, Prof. Chen does an amazing job connecting the ideas in the class together and forming cohesive themes throughout the semester. You get the sense that this course is building to some larger goals.Problem sets: I really enjoyed working on the problem sets.  They were a highlight of my semester, challenging but not unmanageable. I would definitely recommend collaborating with a friend.
worse_comment: You get out of this class what you put in. If you pay attention in lecture, ask questions about the material, and complete all of the supplemental readings, you will gain a ton from this course and learn a lot of state of the art theoretical results about machine learning. However, if you have difficulty pushing yourself to do more than the minimum, you may not get too much out of this course. The problem sets, though mathematically rigorous, do not require you to have too much of a conceptual understanding of the material. The class is not too much work.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Topics in Theoretical Computer Science: Essential Coding Theory 001
best_comment: This course is excellent, very fair and the instructor (Madhu Sudan) was amazing. Madhu is so enthusiastic about the content that it rubs off on you and he is always willing to make time for you and help you. He truly cares about his students and makes the course adaptable to students currently taking. The topic is also very interesting and relevant across many areas of research and you will find the history of the field to be very interesting. I strongly recommend to take this class or any class by Madhu. I really enjoyed the experience!

course_title: Topics at the Interface between Computer Science and Economics 001
best_comment: You get however much you put into it. This class is so chill but you won't learn anything if you don't go through the papers, but if you really take time to work through the papers it could take a long time. This class would inspire research ideas, and take it only if you are interested in the niche research topics. Make the most out of the class by going Yiling OH and make friends w ppl in the class bc they're all awesome.

This class is great! Kung isn't the most animated lecturer (you should probably sit in the first few rows) but his passion for the material is clear. This class offers the opportunity to learn about many exciting cutting edge ML models. On top of that, you have the freedom to explore if something piques your interest. The weekly workload is fairly low, especially relative to most CS classes. However, the final project can be quite time consuming so be cognizant of that when constructing your schedule.
worse_comment: I have mixed feelings on CS 242. I clearly have learned a lot from this class and I now feel knowledgable on current advancements in machine learning. But I also don't think what I learned from this class was worth the stress I have been through this semester. HT has very high expectations for the final project and I would say I was pushed to my limits working on that project. I was not happy with the quizzes, as they accounted for 25 percent of our grade and were usually very hard.  HT cares about his students and the teaching staff is also very well–versed on the material. If you want to challenege yourself, take it.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: If the project portion is good, this course can be a pleasant experience. If you read the papers in detail, you can learn a lot. Minlan and the TFs are absolute goats on ML networks/systems and can offer very good research guidance. Reading the papers was really good; they were good papers in ML systems and I wouldn't have read them in my free time. I think working on the research project is challenging and very time–consuming so definitely start early, and even then it's tons of work. It's definitely, definitely, definitely (and I repeat: DEFINITELY) necessary to continuously communicate with the Prof. and TFs about the project direction so there are no surprises on the day of submission for unexpected feedback. Please find group members that you work well with so again, there are no surprises.
worse_comment: Do NOT take this course under ANY circumstances.The project for this course was extremely difficult, and the expectations were incredibly vague. For this reason, I would strongly advise anyone against taking this course. I will also discuss some other glaring issues with the logistics and course organization. The project assignment for this course is very open–ended. There is no coding content to the course, so you can theoretically be at any level for the project. That’s how the course is advertised. But in reality, you cannot succeed unless you have in–depth systems and networks coding ability at PhD level or above. Even then, you might not meet Prof. Yu’s extremely high expectations.Prof. Yu constantly encouraged my group to work on ideas of enormous scope. Every time we met with her, she stated that we weren’t doing enough and that our project lacked novelty. It is patently ridiculous to expect students to make a large, novel contribution to the entire field of networks and systems, within the span of about 2 months, in a course which has no coding guidance and has several other assignments in addition to the project. Every time we asked Prof. Yu exactly how to actually implement her suggestions, she was very vague and said “just write the code” or similar. It seems like she doesn’t really understand that coding and complex systems implementation are not inherent skills that every person is born with. We are actually here at Harvard to learn these skills, not to be told to “just do it.”I am not exaggerating when I say that Prof. Yu’s project suggestions were 10 times larger than a reasonable scope for a course project. Some of her suggestions would not have been out of place for a PhD dissertation. My group left every single meeting with her feeling deeply stressed and inadequate. We worked constantly on our project throughout the semester and had multiple sleepless nights. Yet without exception, we were met with lukewarm or negative feedback from Prof. Yu at every possible juncture. Prof. Yu would grill us on obscure details related to our project so that we felt clueless and ashamed of our work, even after weeks of effort for every project milestone. The teaching fellows made the course experience even worse. In theory, the teaching fellows were supposed to be available to help students with their projects. However, most students I talked to in the class said that any meetings they scheduled with the teaching fellows were vastly unhelpful. The TFs don’t really know what you’re supposed to do for the project, because Prof. Yu is the only one who grades the projects, so meeting with the TFs for help is pretty unproductive.Additionally, the course had a weird system where you are supposed to send your slides for your in–class paper presentation to one of the TFs. What is the point of this system?  This TF didn’t actually attend class to watch the presentations, so what exactly is he doing with our slides? Is he grading them purely based on textual content? My group ended up having 3x as much text on our slides as we needed, because we had to assume that the TF is somehow grading the presentation without watching it. What about uploading the slides to Canvas? No, this was never discussed. Both Prof. Yu and the TFs refused to use Canvas. The aversion to Canvas extended to grades, which were posted late (a few assignments) or not at all (most assignments). As a result, no one has any idea how they are doing in the course basically at any time. This has remained true throughout the semester. I will also touch on the very frustrating structure of in–class presentations. In theory, students have one class period (75 min) to make their presentation. However, on the first day of student presentations, Prof. Yu insisted on giving a weird half–class lecture which completely disrupted the presentation schedule for the rest of the semester. Every single group except the last few ended up having their presentation cut off in the middle and having to present the second half of it in the next class. This was literally only because of Prof. Yu’s lecture on the first day, which messed up the timing for everyone. Presentations were not only much harder to follow in this format, but stressful for the presenters. Also, students were encouraged to participate in class, but many times when someone would participate, Prof. Yu would follow up and interrogate them on their point, often asking really hard questions. This made it really difficult to participate because I felt like I had to know the topic inside out before speaking up.This course completely ruined my semester, full stop. I am appalled at the incredibly unrealistic expectations Prof. Yu has for students and the very poor logistical organization of the course itself. I would advise that this course should be discontinued because Prof. Yu is not capable of guiding students through their project in a constructive manner, or running a course in line with Harvard’s organizational standards. For future prospective students, please take my advice and stay FAR AWAY from this course.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Definitely apply for this class! It is very manageable and worthwhile. Professor Janapa Reddi is a great instructor who is passionate about the subject matter. The teaching staff are very accessible and care a lot about making sure everyone is having a good learning experience.  I cannot underscore enough, this class is so fairly graded – the work isn't too heavy, so if you put in the effort you will reap the rewards. The project ends up being a bit rushed but the teaching staff are supportive. There can be a bit of busy work at times between paper reading, chapter contributions (this year we helped Professor Janapa Reddi compile a textbook – not sure how it will look next year), chapter peer reviews, homework assignments, and then the final project – but generally it's manageable. It's a unique lens into a cutting edge field. There isn't much programming to be honest which can be good or bad – good for making workload easier, but a bit unfortunate for depriving us of the opportunity to learn some of the technical fundamentals underneath the black box of Edge Impulse. Overall, highly recommend!
worse_comment: Though well–intentioned, this class was poorly organized and unnecessarily time–consuming, with unclear expectations and inconsistent communication from the teaching team. I would only recommend this class if you already care deeply about TinyML or if you're trying to fulfill a Computer Science systems requirement without writing tons of code. Also, I'd want future students to know that the 2023 version of the class sprung a lot of unexpected disturbing content on us (such as showing hateful, sexual or violent images produced by generative AI models without any content warning).

best_comment: Note that the topic changes each year, but this year's (Fall 2023) was Program Synthesis. Normally you need CS 152 to take this class, but we were able to get through this year without it. Each class is a student presentation of a paper to read for that class. So, a lot of the learning will be done by discussing with and listening to your peers rather than a traditional lecture format. Nada is truly a gem and is very knowledgeable about the field of PL (programming languages) in general. A great component is the final project which I think is a great venue to get a good practical experience. Highly recommend this course, it's a great elective
best_gem_comment: Note that the topic changes each year, but this year's (Fall 2023) was Program Synthesis. Normally you need CS 152 to take this class, but we were able to get through this year without it. Each class is a student presentation of a paper to read for that class. So, a lot of the learning will be done by discussing with and listening to your peers rather than a traditional lecture format. Nada is truly a gem and is very knowledgeable about the field of PL (programming languages) in general. A great component is the final project which I think is a great venue to get a good practical experience. Highly recommend this course, it's a great elective

best_comment: Take any class Elena Glassman ever teaches.  Period.  End of discussion.  Not only is she the undeniable GOAT of HCI, but most importantly she treats her students as colleagues and encourages ideas and preconceptions to be challenged and questioned while keeping an open mind.  If you're someone who has a strong background in AI/ML, UI/UX, and HCI (which includes experience reading conference papers), there is absolutely not a single reason to not take this class.  If you're an undergrad, the final project is going to give you a lot more freedom than you're likely used to, and you're expected to manage your progress completely outside of class over the course of the semester, but as long as you've got a solid project group you'll be all set.  I know everyone says this about every class, but you'll honestly get out of this course what you put into it.  Do the readings every night, and be active on Perusall.  Participate in class discussions (at least within breakout groups if you're not comfortable sharing your thoughts in front of a class), and you will find yourself gleaning so many more insights from the papers than otherwise possible.  I don't know what else to say––Elena is awesome, Catherine is the best TF––just take this class!

course_title: Topics in Machine Learning: Inverse Problems in Reinforcement Learning-with healthcare applications 001
best_comment: The papers are all on a very specific topic, which at times can feel repetitive but truly give you a great understanding on the different methods for IRL. The project can be long and difficult at times depending on what topic you choose, but Finale makes sure to check in with you and provides feedback at every checkpoint assignment, which is useful for generally staying on track. Please start early!

I would really recommend taking this course! Todd is an absolutely terrific professor, and you can really see his passion for the material and for helping his students learn—particularly if you attend his weekly office hours, which I really recommend.  The work is decently middle–loaded—the PSETs will get harder after the add / drop deadline, but the last few are shorter than the middle ones. Be ready to do a ton of debugging (most of the PSETs is usually programming in Numpy), but you'll get a ton out of the lectures and the overall content. Plus, it's so cool to finish a PSET and create your own optical illusions (and actually understand how they work)! This course is a fair amount of work, but I think that the work is definitely worth it!One important thing to note is that this class is more of a applied math class than a computer science class. There's a ton of programming on each PSET, but most of the programming is using Numpy to model mathematical equations. The final (which is in mid–to–late November) is pretty much entirely applied math–oriented, so be ready for that.

course_title: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: Useful and interesting class!

course_title: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: Useful and interesting class!

course_title: A Brief History of the Earth 001
best_comment: Take this class! The teaching staff are the kindest in the world, and the lectures are always fun and interesting, with a lot of hands on components. The teaching staff are really good at explaining concepts very clearly even for people new to EPS. I took this as my science requirement and I'm really glad that I did. Above all, the sections also make this class totally worth it –– I got to see a lot of cool resources, museums and visualizer labs, at Harvard that I'd never been to before even as a senior, and they were always a lot of fun. I learned about a lot of rock names but more importantly, it was just heartwarming to be around the teaching staff's joy for geology and it made me feel more connected to this Earth we live on. Even if I don't remember all the rock names, it gave me a renewed appreciation for the Earth from a scientist's perspective, Overall, this is a really fun class with very little stress and really cool people and content! Highly recommend.
best_gem_comment: This course is a really easy introduction to earth and planetary sciences. I'm a CS concentrator and I took this class as an elective with a friend, and it was a GEM. Only 4 labs throughout the semester that are all pretty easy, and a midterm + final that you will be more than well–prepared for, even if you can't make it to class often.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences
course_title_2024: A Brief History of the Earth

course_title: The Fluid Earth: Oceans, Atmosphere, Climate, and Environment 001
best_comment: This class is made solely by your TF; if you have a good TF you will have a great experience, but if you do not have a good TF you will probably not find this class very rewarding.
worse_comment: Overall the course – specifically the psets and midterms – was more difficult than expected

best_comment: Take this course this is the one. Take it even if only to get to spend 2.5 hours /week with Jerry Mitrovica. You will learn in this course regardless of whatever math/physics backgroud  think you don't have enough of to suceed because Jerry will help you learn it. I took this as an elective as a humanities major and have no regrets, i think it is priobably the best elective course I could have chosen because although the topic is rather specific, it gives a really good understanding and appreciation of how subtle and sensitive the Earth is to climate related changes. Problem sets are actually interesting and not super stressful or too much. Also, again, Jerry Mitrovica might be the most goated professor at this school. He genuinely cares about his students, geophysics, and teaching equally and wants everyone to learn. He is also just super hilarious and interesting to talk to about anything. Take it take it take it take it please for the love of it just take it please.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

course_title: Data Analysis and Statistical Inference in the Earth and Environmental Sciences 001
best_comment: This class is hands down one of the best classes that I have taken at Harvard. I am very interested in Environmental Science and Data Science so this class was a perfect mix of the two. I learned so so many useful tools for statistical inference that I will continue to use in my lab's research, future class projects, and all other data analysis that I do in the future. Roger is so so nice and really loves the topics covered in class. The class is full of environmental and stats kids which is a great, welcoming combo. I would 100% recommend this class to anyone for the tools that it gives you to analyze any kind of data to understand the world around you. Very applied and useful. I have coded a lot before this class which was very very helpful in the psets, BCAs, and projects. I would recommend that you come into this class with some coding background to get the most out of it. If not, be prepared to learn a lot about coding and put in the time to do so. You will have a lot of help from friends and the TFs.
worse_comment: Low stress intro class to statistics. Only 3 psets and midterm and final are group projects. Content can get difficult though and not a lot of resources outside of lecture to help you. Not knowing coding in python will hurt you.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences
course_title_2024: Data Analysis and Statistical Inference in the Earth and Environmental Sciences

course_title: Introduction to Planetary Materials and Earth Resources 001
best_comment: Class is fun, the people are cool,
worse_comment: That there's a field trip to Norway (we didn't get to go this year, sadly )
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences
course_title_2024: Introduction to Planetary Materials and Earth Resources

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN!!! By far the most fun class I've taken at Harvard (Elsie told us on the first day that her teaching philosophy centers around fun).  This class gave me a really thorough sense of what it is like to conduct scientific research in this field. I absolutely loved how this course was structured to give students an opportunity to learn about how to come up with a research project, how to conduct field work, how to conduct lab work, how to analyze data, and how to give a scientific presentation. I felt like I really got a sense of what doing research was like and it was super fun! Although this class is super chill and doesn't have a lot of work, I still got so much out of it.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences
course_title_2024: Field and Lab-Based Seminar on Local Pollution Issues

best_comment: I absolutely loved this course! Professor Jacob is a wonderful lecturer, and the course covers many important and cutting–edge topics in atmospheric/climate science. The problem sets are very reasonable and interesting, and the course material is very accessible for undergraduate and graduate students. An added bonus is that there are no exams – instead there are midterm and final presentations where you have a lot of freedom to apply the concepts from this course to a topic of your interest.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

best_comment: If you have any interest in learning Chinese, take this class! The teachers are amazing and they make it so easy to learn. The classes are so fun and are always the highlight of my day. I highly highly recommend to anyone looking to try their hand at a new language!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: The Chinese faculty at Harvard are really the strongest language instructors at our university, and I do not believe this to be an exaggeration. Their care in organizing course materials, with dedicated time to speaking, listening, and reading, was absolutely phenomenal. While the expectations are very high (e.g., learning 20 new vocab words for each dictation), we knew exactly what would be tested, and assessments never strayed from the target vocabulary and grammar structures. The objective–oriented learning meant we drilled the set vocabulary and sentence structures in great depth, with *daily* interaction with our teachers and our classmates. After taking this elementary class, I have already been able to start conversing spontaneously with native Chinese speakers, such was the strength of the teaching in this class. I really have to commend ALL the teachers/instructors –they are among the most kind and enthusiastic teachers you will find at Harvard.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!! I'M BEGGINGGGGG YOU TO TAKE THIS CLASS!!! The Mandarin department is a well–oiled MACHINE with crazy good pedagogy! I learned so much every week, and the teachers were so so capable, welcoming, funny, and helpful. At first I dreaded having to go to class every day, but each session ended up being so fun. I've been intimidated by Mandarin my whole life and I thought I'd never get around to learning it. But I did learn it— I learned so much, all in 1 semester. This class takes hard work, but ultimately it provides so many avenues for you to seek help and/or earn extra credit. The hard work was so worth it. AND I LOVEEEEED ALL THE TEACHERS IN CHINESE BA. They are THE BEST!!! It's clear that they are all truly educators by training (and not random people who happen to have PhDs...) They all go out of their way to help students, and they're just so so fun and lovely. I really really appreciated all my laoshi. XIEXIE LAOSHI!!!!!!! Chinese BA changed my life!
worse_comment: Study Hard
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Just a great class, but as with any language, it will require time and discipline. Highlight is the teaching staff (they're angels) and the worst part is the knowledge gap between students when they enter the class. Some students come in with way too much prior knowledge, which detracts from the learning experience of the rest of the class. Ultimately, though, effort will prevail, so given enough time spent studying, you should do fine. Plenty of opportunities for extra credit as well
subject: Chinese

best_comment: One of my favorite classes I've taken at Harvard, if not my very favorite! You learn a lot of material, but sections are also lots of fun, and the small class environment (about 10–15 students per classroom) allows you to ask the teachers a lot and get a much more engaging experience. Would definitely recommend!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Course staff are really great, always do their best to be lenient and helpful throughout what is a rather intensive course. Course material is largely organised logically and each week builds upon the last ensuring that you recall and practice structures continuously throughout the semester. More frequent review sessions could be useful to group closely related grammar structures. Assessment is very frequent, which isn't a bad thing, but can get confusing at times. Individual sessions are honestly not very useful. Course materials are abundant and useful; the more you engage with them the faster your Chinese will improve. Feedback is great and the lecture/drill combo is one I think works well. No background in Chinese is necessary, but obviously the more you have the easier the class becomes. A good course to take if you’re genuinely interested in speaking the language; grading isn’t harsh and there are plenty of ways to earn extra marks but it isn’t a gem of a language course.
worse_comment: This class is a lot of work and can be very intimidating if you don't already speak Chinese. Most students in my class already took Chinese in high school or spoke it at home. However, you will learn A LOT
best_gem_comment: Course staff are really great, always do their best to be lenient and helpful throughout what is a rather intensive course. Course material is largely organised logically and each week builds upon the last ensuring that you recall and practice structures continuously throughout the semester. More frequent review sessions could be useful to group closely related grammar structures. Assessment is very frequent, which isn't a bad thing, but can get confusing at times. Individual sessions are honestly not very useful. Course materials are abundant and useful; the more you engage with them the faster your Chinese will improve. A good course to take if you’re genuinely interested in speaking the language; grading isn’t harsh and there are plenty of ways to earn extra marks but it isn’t a gem of a language course.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: If you are looking to fulfill your language requirement: TAKE THIS CLASS! There is a reason why everyone says that the Chinese Department is one of the best departments at Harvard. All the instructors are so fun and enthusiastic which make the class so fun to take (will gladly wake up early and walk to Vanserg for this class). If you want to improve your Chinese, this is the class to take.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: This class is difficult, but completely manageable! Du Laoshi and the other three laoshi are absolutely amazing. They're funny and engaging and I looked forward to class every day. You would also likely get very close with your section since it's such a small class. I love the community and I'm very glad I decided to take this class. A lot of Chinese heritage students decide to take Chinese BA for an 'easy' class that satisfies the foreign language requirement, but I strongly recommend you to take BX if you have a solid speaking background! We learn how to read/write so many Chinese characters and go twice the speed as BA. I would recommend that you have some prior intuition for the grammar. Grammar came relatively easily to me since I spoke Chinese at home, so I spent much of my time learning how to read/write the new characters with Quizlet. Had I not been as familiar with the grammar, I would've really struggled with this class.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Great class!! 5 days/week which is time–consuming, but the workload outside of class is not bad (<10 hours/week). Teachers are very nice and make class fun, and my Chinese has definitely gotten a lot better!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: First of all, Dr. Sena is a great instructor. He does not do the hand–holding a lot of professors do, which was honestly great. This course made me feel a little like Sisyphus at times, but in our case we actually make it to the top! And it feels great! This class is very difficult and takes time, but it was one of the most rewarding experiences I have ever had. We really had a community across ages and interests in our little class!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Difficult but very rewarding. The teaching staff clearly care about each student and want everyone to succeed. There are extra credit options and attendance drops that give students some wiggle room, but you definitely need to study and work for this course. I think my Chinese has really improved over the course of one semester, especially because of the biweekly individual sessions with Taiwanese teachers to help students improve fluency and confidence in actually speaking the language.I did not take Ba/Bb and came straight from high school Chinese after taking the placement test, which was a very steep learning curve to get acclimated to college level language courses. But I am definitely glad I stuck with it, even after a stressful first couple of weeks! I think either taking Ba/Bb or having AP Chinese under your belt would be sufficient preparation. (My high school Chinese education was pretty sporadic and I didn't even attempt to take the AP exam, so even that much background was enough for this course!)
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Absolutely take this class! The instructors are seriously some of the kindest people ever. I'd really recommend making flashcards (Anki or Quizlet!) and sticking to a good routine of looking over the grammar in the textbook so you don't have to cram as a test approaches. That said, it's a super rewarding class with incredible teachers and classmates whom you'll grow close to, and you won't regret taking it!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Chinese never fails to be a highlight of every semester. Yes, it still meets 5 days a week, with weekly quizzes, but it is worth it for an amazing teaching staff and actually learning the language. The class is definitely more difficult than BA/BB, but still manageable, and still really fun. If you are thinking at all about taking 120 and seeing if it is worth it, I will undoubtedly say 100%, take the class.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Though this class is a lot of work, I truly enjoyed each week, as each week was a new topic. Learning about China's food security was something that I only briefly touched on in the past, and it was exciting to finally hear about it from a Chinese lens rather than an outside perspective. My favorite part about 130A was definitely the calligraphy sessions we had, they were all just nice breaks throughout the course and in my weekly schedule that I always looked forward to.  If you put in the work for this class, you'll definitely enjoy the benefits of taking the course. Plus the teaching staff (Yang Laoshi, Wang Laoshi, and Jiao Laoshi) are all extremely understanding and really want you to learn Chinese in a fun way.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Take Chinese!! Yes it is a large time commitment, but Chinese is taught incredibly well here and you will actually learn. there are plenty of bonus opportunities, so the grade should not be a large concern as long as you are willing to put the time in. Keep in mind the teachers change from year to year, but overall the Chinese teachers are wonderful!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Chinese 130a focused on social issues within China and was meant to use these topics to teach us how to speak and write Chinese more professionally. I feel that the course taught me many interesting things about society within China, and used readings and online material that drew upon the standard Chinese experience to teach us these topics. That being said, I believe that the pace of the class is too fast. With 2–3 quizzes a week and 1–2 long homework assignments it feels like I am always learning new material, however, the speed at which we move through new topics leaves me without any opportunity to digest the words and grammar structures we are learning and incorporate them into my language use. Additionally, I feel like I teach myself all the material at home to prepare for quizzes, making class time sometimes feel like a waste of time. I wish we had less material to learn so we could truly practice and keep up with what we are learning. I honestly felt like my Chinese level has not risen very much in the past semester.
subject: Chinese

course_title: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 001
best_comment: Yang Laoshi and Jiao Laoshi (both of whom taught this class) make this class amazing. So approachable with questions and to chat about life in and outside of class. Truly amazing class in which you feel like your Chinese (especially formal verbal) has improved a lot by the end of the semester. I do hope this comment can be published on the q guide – just because I don't think the Chinese department gets enough credit for the sheer amount of work teachers put in to help their students learn.
subject: Chinese
course_title_2024: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners

course_title: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 002
best_comment: Please consider taking the class. My Chinese improved by leaps and bounds like never before ( and I've three semesters of Chinese prior to this). I thoroughly enjoyed coming to class everyday. My peers were phenomenal and kind people and our professors were always warm and encouraging. I learned SO MUCH about China and its current social issues. A lot of what I learned I would've never learned if not for this class.
subject: Chinese
course_title_2024: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners

best_comment: If you're thinking about taking 140a, you definitely already know what's up with the Chinese department. He Lao Shi and Chen Lao Shi are both awesome and amazing teachers for this course. Definitely rigorous, but your Chinese will improve a lot, this was the first semester where I really felt like looking at news articles I could start understanding enough to fill in the rest of what I didn't know with context – pretty cool feeling. I'm planning to take 140b next semester but I know a lot of people pivot into other classes like 142a or 163, etc. so definitely recommend 140a regardless of what your overall goals are with Chinese.
subject: Chinese

course_title: Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 001
best_comment: It's great! It's definitely a step–up from previous classes with the level of difficulty increases for grammar and vocab, however, it is still doable. Moreover, the teachers are super sweet and supportive, always willing to help out!
subject: Chinese
course_title_2024: Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners

course_title: Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 002
best_comment: As someone who mainly self–studied Chinese before taking this course as my first Chinese class, I would say it is very accessible, the teachers Yu Laoshi and Xiong Laoshi are very nice, and I certainly improved a lot on speaking and listening (which was what I was aiming for since I self–studied mainly through reading, but there are also improvements in writing/reading for sure). If you are considering taking 140x or 140 and you have some background in Chinese or Chinese dialect speaking I would recommend 140x. The community is great, and I made good friends in this class. Yu and Xiong Laoshi also really cares about the students, and we have fun lots of fun activities like playing games or watching popular/funny videos in class. Other than my complaint below, the instructors and community are absolutely fantastic and I would highly RECOMMEND you to take the class!!One important complain I have for this class is not about the instructors but more about some aspects of the textbook, and just keep it in mind if you are taking the class (or I hope they fix the textbook):I am not a fan of oversensitivity to racial or cultural topics,  but somehow the textbook extols western values or culture at an excessive level which is kinda sad for a Chinese class. For example, when learning some adjectives, good adjectives will be associated with western parenting and bad adjectives associated with asian or chinese parenting, which is quite ridiculous and which uses lots of stereotypes. I personally do not care what a textbook writer thinks of my parents or their parenting (or my future parenting for that matter) but I think some people might find it quite offensive and I think it is just inappropriate in general to treat Chinese culture or Chinese parents in such an unfair and biased way. The textbook also gives the vibe of trying to criticize Chinese culture or the Chinese government whenever there is a chance, which I guess is not surprising because it's America but even as someone who is not the biggest fan of the Chinese government and fully aware of its problems, I still think it is a bit excessive and unnecessary since it is a Chinese class after all, and I find it hard to imagine an English class textbook with criticisms of British/American culture or the American government whenever possible.
subject: Chinese
course_title_2024: Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners

course_title: Research Methods in Late Imperial Chinese History I: Seminar 01
best_comment: This course will prepare students to read, interpret, and use a wide variety of Qing–era primary documents – from palace memorials and state–compiled annalistic histories to local records and even sources from unexpected corners, like scripts for dramatic performance. The regimen is intense but rewarding, gratifying.

Definitely take this course if you are a fan of "Dream of the Red Chamber" or want to explore Chinese literature. Course assignments are manageable and the though reading can get a bit overwhelming sometimes because the novel itself is long, it is truly worth it at the end and you'll likely become so absorbed by the book that you won't even care. Professor Li is also such an approachable and nice teacher and creates a very casual environment for open discussions. Could not recommend more to those who want to learn about arguably the greatest Chinese novel of all time!!

course_title: Modern Chinese Literature: Theory and Practice: Seminar 01
best_comment: This is the best class I have ever taken in EALC! Prof. Wang is the only professor who would provide each student with feedback on a weekly basis, and the quality of the lecture&discussion is also extremely high!

course_title: The Literary Life of Things in China 01
best_comment: I strongly recommend this class, as it deals with a range of fascinating texts (and objects) while giving a great overview of issues relating to materiality in Chinese literature, and literature more broadly. It also gives students a lot of room to explore areas of interest related to their own research, and encourages cross–disciplinary approaches, so it isn't limited to students of Chinese literature. Professor Kelly is always helpful, engaging, and approachable, which fosters a great class atmosphere.

course_title: From Late Tang Poetry and Poetics into the Song Dynasty 01
best_comment: Professor Owen is extremely knowledgeable and one of the most renowned professors in his field. I felt like I learned so much in this class and improved my literary chinese reading skills. Definitely take a class with him if you have the chance!

This is a great course for anyone interested in learning more about documentary, filmmaking, or Chinese media/culture. The assigned films were all interesting and the readings were not extensive, which made for a greatly balanced workload. The instructors are also very engaged and always willing to help the students succeed. Overall, a great experience.

course_title: Rip and Tear--The Body as Moving and Moved Image in Japanese Film: Seminar 01
best_comment: This is an amazing course, and I would highly recommend it. I took this course as an undergraduate student with some background in Visual Studies but limited knowledge of Japanese History. The graduate students I met and the professor were incredibly inspiring and encouraging. A background in Visual Studies and Japanese History is essential, as these will be prominent topics discussed in the course.

The course is **good**!. It is a government elective but there is a lot of economics involved, not in terms of required knowledge. But I felt like the first part of the class was all made of trade policy, foreign investments, and related readings, which was surely interesting but I was expecting something else. However, we gained a lot of knowledge on other topics later on and the class became a little more interesting. The interview assignments were good, but be very careful in who you choose, as they emphasize that a lot and thus grade very harshly. However, the policy memo and the final projects, combined with the weekly discussion posts, were very fun assignments and very manageable. The class discussion can sometimes be a little uneventful, as many people tend not to be responsive to in–class questions posed by the professors, but other than that it is very obvious that Professor Koss is very passionate about what he does and the topics covered in the course. I would recommend it to anyone!

Fantastic class!! Prof Kuriyama is just the most wonderful prof/human being. He has (relative to the conservative nature of academia) radical ideas about how people should think about, write, and present research, which takes some getting used to but I think he is very much onto something. It is a very practical class! For instance, we literally whip out Photoshop and PPT in class and go through ways to make our presentations more engaging. This makes it very different to any other classes you are likely to take at Harvard. This is a graduate class, which means it is training you to be an effective academic, hence the practicality. All this means that you should ideally come in with a big and clear research project in mind that you want to workshop throughout the class – ideally at the level of senior/MA/PhD thesis. It is also helpful but not necessary to have some background in cultural/social history and/or literature/humanities. Similarly, it is helpful but not necessary to have background in East Asia and East Asian languages. tldr if you have a research project in mind already, this is a radical and awesome class that will shape how you think about your research with skills that you can apply for the rest of academia / other parts of life – HIGHLY REC!!
subject: East Asian Studies

best_comment: This class is time–consuming, and the numerous assignments mean that you really have to be on your A–game every week to avoid falling behind on the new vocab, grammar, and Kanji, but it is by far the most rewarding course I've taken at Harvard so far. It's easy to see your progress week by week, and given how small the department is, it's really easy to meet a lot of new, amazing people. I loved the professors, and there were quite a few fun Japanese events to attend outside of class. Also, the projects we completed for the course were actually a lot of fun.  If you don't come in with any Japanese language experience (or Chinese language experience for the Kanji), it will be pretty hard at first to balance the coursework with other courses, but it gets easier with time. Would 10/10 recommend!
subject: Japanese

best_comment: The teaching staff (Sakomura, Higurashi, and Hirzane) are all amazing people. They truly care about your learning and are so kind and accommodating. They truly make learning so much fun and although it is a lot of work because you are learning a new language, it's honestly fun work. You learn so much so quickly and you don't even realize it too. Definitely recommend this class
subject: Japanese

best_comment: The instructors for this course are great! They are very enthusiastic and do an excellent job making sure that students understand the information. That being said, it meets for one hour every single day of the week (yes, five days each week), which is SUPER inconvenient and a big time and scheduling commitment.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: If you want to read Classical Japanese, take this class! It is tedious sometimes, the exams are hard, but overall it's just so valuable to be able to read traditional poetry etc.! Though you shouldn't expect to be able to read it fluently, we always worked with a dictionary/vocab list and grammar annotations. Danica is such a kind instructor and made classes really enjoyable. Work load wasn't bad, but you'll have to study a lot for the tests.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: This class is pretty much a continuation of the intro Japanese classes. The workload is about the same, and Takehara sensei does a great job making sure everyone is learning at their own pace.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! If you are currently like me, you are still deciding whether to take this course because the daily class time commitment seems to tedious. While I won't lie and say it is easy, I did find going to class one of the highlights of my day (I enjoyed going to class) and it was great for me to have that structure throughout the semester. The professors are super nice and understanding (even when you accidentally miss class or are super late) but it is definitely on you to bring that energy to class and to your homework (so that you actually learn Japanese). As long as you keep up the work and dedicate some time to this class, it will be worth it (especially for my STEM ppl!! this was a great opportunity for me to interact with non–STEM ppl)
subject: Japanese

best_comment: 1. A solid Japanese foundation is needed. 2. Most of the homework is interesting and has direct ties to events/issues relating to Japan. 3. Units are well progressed and thought–out. 4. The more you get out of your comfort zone and speak in class the more you will get out of it (confidence, practice, discussions, etc). 4. SUPER FUN class overall!! (I would say its right around JLPT n2 level of Japanese)
worse_comment: Please consider taking a language class, even if not this particular class. If there's anything I learned from taking this class, it's that language classes are genuinely very special (this was something I did not at all get from my high school Chinese class experience). They are perhaps the only avenue to act stupid without being judged. Pretty much every lesson, every single person in my class makes at least one mistake, with some people, myself included, making mistake after mistake sometimes in things like reading from the text or responding to Yagi–sensei's discussion questions. I will say that though it is a very humbling, that kind of feeling—that everyone is dumb sometimes—is special and, in my opinion, really important to have.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: Japanese 140 will allow you to improve so much! Compared to previous Japanese classes, it's less busywork and allows you to focus on actually knowing the grammar and readings. As always, the workload is a lot, but definitely better than the previous classes. Also as always, the senseis are incredibly kind and the classroom environment is very enjoyable. You'll also get so much helpful knowledge about language in context, e.g., how to write a formal email. In conclusion, I would highly recommend Japanese 140!
subject: Japanese

course_title: Readings and Discussion in Japanese Social Sciences 001
best_comment: This course is great for those planning on using Japanese to conduct research in the social sciences.
subject: Japanese
course_title_2024: Readings and Discussion in Japanese Social Sciences

course_title: Reading Scholarly Japanese for Students of Chinese and Korean 001
best_comment: This is a course that is very closely focused on grammatical structure, which I've found extremely helpful, and definitely helps with reading the nuances of academic Japanese more accurately (even if you can "get by" already).
worse_comment: Students can expect rigorous training in Japanese here, and within just a few months you'll find yourself reading academic Japanese at a level previously thought impossible! Classroom activities focus on grammar and reading line– by–line, allowing students to atomically dissect and take apart individual sentences.
subject: Japanese
course_title_2024: Reading Scholarly Japanese for Students of Chinese and Korean

course_title: Traditional Japanese Literature: From Mythology to (Early) Modernity 01
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! If this class is ever offered again, do not hesitate to take it. Even if you are a STEM concentrator or have never been interested in literature, you'll have a good time in this class. It's a fairly easy class with interesting readings, fun class discussions, and a nice atmosphere. The readings can occasionally be dense, but they aren't long. The readings were always interesting since we got to learn more about Japan's history through poems and fictional stories. I loved how the class covered a wide range of genres to dissect traditional Japanese literature (e.g. plays, short stories, poems, novels, etc.). There were simple weekly Slack assignments, three papers, and one final exam. The papers were fun to complete since you get to dive further into the texts from class, and the assignments are really easy and fun to complete. The professor, David Atherton, was so funny and enthusiastic during lectures. Even if you're having a rough day, he will make you laugh and know to check in on you. If this class isn't offered, you should at least do a class with him. He is so much fun; he provides snacks during class sometimes; he's always cracking jokes; and he makes everyone in class become friends. The lectures in his class are always engaging since he let's us talk to our peers about the readings. He'll encourage people to speak, but he never cold calls or forces participation. It's a chill, fun atmosphere. I had Kassandra Diaz as my TF, and she was the best!! She always gave me inspiration for my papers. She was great facilitating discussions during sections, and she made me see the stories/poems in a different way since she has a deep knowledge  of Japanese history. She's also a fun person since she sometimes held a picnic–style section with class outside while providing snacks!

I would highly recommend! Any course with Prof. Atherton is wonderful, and medieval literature and poetics are particularly interesting. Would especially encourage if you have interest in the shapings of Japanese Buddhism.

The class is very engaging and fun. It honestly feels like a family. At first thinking of having class everyday felt very daunting, but after taking the class it is understandable. We are learning a lot of content and being able to review it and continue learning daily was helpful/needed. The class is fast–paced, which was difficult in the beginning for me, as I knew no Korean prior, but I was able to get the hang of it a few weeks in. We have 2 quizzes a week and then every few weeks have 3 assessments (2 quizzes and a lesson test). This was also something new to get used to, but similarly overtime it becomes a routine. It gets easier, as you know what to expect and you learn how you need to prepare and study to do well in this situation. Having different types of quizzes was helpful as there are vocabulary quizzes, dictation (listening), dialogue (speaking with a partner), and speaking quizzes with the section teacher. Though it also feels like a lot of quizzes, it definitely helps you improve in your Korean.
worse_comment: It is a rewarding course, but it can be stressful and it does require a lot of efforts throughout the whole semester.
subject: Korean

best_comment: My parents are Korean and speak Korean at home, so I had decent listening skills and some speaking skills coming into the course but no formal knowledge of grammar. I was debating between taking this or Korean Bx and decided on this to have a slower introduction to Korean. If you're in a similar situation, it depends on what you want to get out of Korean, but note that Bx goes twice as fast as Ba, and I found Ba to be slightly overwhelming at times. I don't regret taking Ba over Bx but Bx would have improved my skills quicker if I had taken it. Most of the class has no experience in Korean, so if you're in a similar situation as I was this will be an easier course for you.It is a lot of effort if you don't know the language at all, as there are quizzes every week, weeks of only tests and quizzes, class every day with attendance taken, and projects. The teachers were great and made lessons fun. Take this course if you want to learn a relatively easy East Asian language but be prepared to put in a lot of effort if you have no experience beforehand. Overall, highly recommend – my Korean has improved a lot through this course.
subject: Korean

best_comment: This is a super, super intense course, and you will do a ton of work, but you will also learn a ton. Throughout this semester it was my most demanding course, with several quizzes weekly in addition to constant homeworks and frequent exams. As a result, however, I look back and am surprised that I have been able to learn so much in a difficult language in such a short amount of time. Also, the teachers for this course are phenomenal. Both my lecture and section teachers were super kind and good instructors, who wanted me to succeed. Additionally, some of the assignments are pretty fun, like the final project which was to make a film, or the Korean cultural event participation requirement. I would recommend this course for people who want to learn Korean. One side note: I am not Korean and have no prior Korean experience, but there will be a decent amount of people in the class who have grown up in Korean–speaking homes and will naturally come in knowing more than you. At times this would frustrate me, as they would finish exams first etc., but I also learned so much that it didn’t end up bothering me.
subject: Korean

best_comment: Be prepared to dedicate a decent amount of time to this class!! While not exactly to the extent of a P–Set class, Korean 120A does have many assignments and will take up a good chunk of time. However, if you're interested in and are truly dedicated to learning Korean, this class will help you improve SO SO MUCH. Noh 선생님 is an amazing instructor and also very understanding when it comes to individual circumstances. This is one of the few classes I've taken where I feel like I can adequately measure my progress and what I've learned! Highly recommend!!
worse_comment: You will be degraded in section for your ignorance be prepared (but still take this class it's fine don't worry bro)
subject: Korean

best_comment: This class is a lot of fun, but assignments really stack up near the end of the year. The rest of the class is manageable, and as long as you complete all of the assignments it should be easy enough to keep up. Section is much harder than regular lecture, but definitely rewarding! Grading is reasonable.
worse_comment: Great instructors but the course structure wasn't great
subject: Korean

best_comment: Professor Koo is absolutely fantastic. This course is the most comprehensive and efficient Korean history class I've been exposed to. It was even interesting and engaging for graduate students who had grown up in Korea.

Whether you have experience in Viet (but you can't write/read/speak), TAKE THIS CLASS. Cô Hoa is so so welcoming and makes sure to take any feedback that we have like something we need to review or focus on. Even though it's four times a day (which is typical for an intro to a language class), as someone who had very limited vocabulary and some prior speaking/pronunciation skills, I've learned so so much over the past semester to the point where I can speak to my mom in only Vietnamese.  She's very lenient with the grading and gives you many opportunities to get extra credit which you can get extra credit through participating in Vietnamese events and activities, which allows you to learn more about Vietnamese culture, make friends, and eat good food/candy. And for people who are nervous about the cultural presentation, you get comfortable with the class (because everyone is struggling and trying to learn), and you can choose the topic you want to talk about. The Vietnamese community at Harvard is very tight–knit, so no matter if you're Viet or not, you will meet a very kind group of people who will make you comfortable and teach you about Vietnamese culture and the language.
subject: Vietnamese

best_comment: The strengths of this course is you immerse yourself into the Vietnamese language although unfortunately there are no external excursions. You will need to be able to know Vietnamese sufficiently enough to listen and converse in it for 2 hours, 2 times a week. Co Hoa is great and is very nice! Pay attention in class and go the assignments, and you will learn a lot.
subject: Vietnamese

best_comment: I was nervous to start this course because I had never taken an economics course before. But Ec10a is for anyone– regardless of their prior knowledge! I genuinely loved this course and I felt like I learned so much. Both lecturers are amazing and are experts in their fields, the guest lectures are great, and the community is also something to look forward to. I think every freshman should take Ec10– not only do you learn so much, but you also have a bond with around 700 of your peers. Is it easy? Not exactly. But there are so many resources for it: office hours, pset collabs, Slack channels. Do the readings in advance to get a good grasp of things, use the resources available, talk to peers, and you'll be good.*****IMPORTANT: DAVID MARTIN IS THE HEAD SECTION LEADER FOR EC10 AND HE IS THE MOST AMAZING FACULTY MEMBER AT THIS COLLEGE. HE MAKES ECONOMICS TRULY UNDERSTANDABLE AND WORTH STUDYING. HE IS ONE OF THE KINDEST AND MOST CONSIDERATE PEOPLE HERE. HE GENUINELY CARES ABOUT ALL EC10 STUDENTS AND HAS NEVER MADE ME FEEL ANYTHING LESS THAN VALUED AND APPRECIATED. HE HOLDS OFFICE HOURS FOR PSETS– GO TO THEM! NOT ONLY FOR PSET/ECON HELP, BUT JUST TO MEET HIM AND TALK! HE IS TRULY SO AMAZING!!!*****
worse_comment: ec10a is NOT an easy class. it's a great class – super comprehensive overview of econ and fascinating material. i think it's one of the better designed classes i took in my first semester at harvard. exams are hard!! take the midterm seriously and overprepare!! also keep in mind that practice exams they give you are easier than the actual exam. prepping for the midterm/final was a grind for sure but it was a fun class, minus the frustration of exams.my one thing with this class that was a turn off was the guest lecture done by roland fryer. i am completely shocked that the ec10a teaching team would bring in someone previously suspended by harvard for SEVEN title ix violations to guest lecture one of the biggest intro classes at harvard, with an audience of mostly all first years – the most impressionable group of students at the college. what is even MORE appalling to me is 1. the lack of disclosure of this troubling background and 2. that we were mandated to attend this lecture and later tested on the content matter. i hope the ec10a team learns from this semester and deeply reconsiders bringing roland fryer back in future semesters. if i google someone trying to find out more about their economic theories about education inequity and instead the first thing that pops up is a new york times article about their 7 title ix violations, maybe there should be some thought given to whether you want that person giving a lecture. overall ec10a was a great experience, minus this one incredibly shortsighted, inconsiderate decision by the teaching team.
best_gem_comment: It's honestly a gem if you have good computational thinking skills and want to learn a bit more about how the world works through the lens of economic models! There are so many people in class, so you'll definitely have friends you can talk to and work with. There's definitely a mix of levels of interest in econ in this class –– from concentrators to people taking it for fun –– but you will find your psetters and learn a lot along the way!
subject: Economics

best_comment: I was nervous to start this course because I had never taken an economics course before. But Ec10a is for anyone– regardless of their prior knowledge! I genuinely loved this course and I felt like I learned so much. Both lecturers are amazing and are experts in their fields, the guest lectures are great, and the community is also something to look forward to. I think every freshman should take Ec10– not only do you learn so much, but you also have a bond with around 700 of your peers. Is it easy? Not exactly. NOT ONLY FOR PSET/ECON HELP, BUT JUST TO MEET HIM AND TALK! HE IS TRULY SO AMAZING!!!*****

There's definitely a mix of levels of interest in econ in this class –– from concentrators to people taking it for fun –– but you will find your psetters and learn a lot along the way!
subject: Economics

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Of course you have to study and it's not a gem, but you can definitely get an A if you work hard, go to office hours and get help as needed. The work you will put into this class is absolutely worth it. I am not an econ major, I am pre–med and will never touch a finance/consulting career in my life, and I really enjoyed this class. I feel like what I learned has made me a more informed citizen. I found the content really interesting and relevant to my life and the class really helped me understand how our world works. Dr. Maggi also gives an optional personal finance lecture before Thanksgiving break, which I really enjoyed because he literally tells you exactly how to make money through investment, which is the most relevant thing you could possibly learn!I specifically recommend taking Ec10b off cycle because Dr. Maggi is really the highlight of the class, and the smaller class size will give you an opportunity to get to know him. He's the kindest instructor I've ever had. He really cares about his students and literally memorizes everyone's Canvas picture or something, because he knows everybody's name. His lectures are very clear and straightforward, and even though I normally take notes on an iPad, I am a big fan of his no–electronics rule. If you need help in the class or feel yourself falling behind, literally go talk to him. I was never great at social science/humanities subjects so I did struggle a little bit with exams but I felt that they were fair. An A is definitely within reach if you put in the work. 10/10 would recommend.
worse_comment: I took Ec10a on–cycle with Laibson and Furman and didn't like the huge lecture style. I would much rather recommend taking Ec10 series off–cycle! I've learned a lot more material and actually understand the concepts. I feel like I can better approach the teaching staff whenever I am confused. However, lectures may feel long at times due to other students asking various questions in the middle of the lectures, and most other students are not paying attention and zoning off.
subject: Economics

course_title: Personal Finance: Making Better Decisions and Building a Better Financial System 001
best_comment: EVERYONE at harvard should take this class. Probably the only class I've taken here where I didn't have an answer to the "what can be improved" question on the Q guide: it's about as perfect as it could be. The weekly psets are extremely easy, especially if you're a STEM concentrator but even if you're not, and don't take more than 2–3 hours a week (you also get 2 drops). You don't need any background besides early high–school level math (logarithms for example). Think stuff like using the compound interest formula, applying that formula in Excel to generate some graphs, some basic probability (you don't need to know this, it's introduced from scratch). Exams are also pretty easy. And yet, I learned SO many useful things about personal finance that I've already started using (think budgeting, opening new bank accounts/credit card accounts that make me money, understanding how stocks/bonds/ETFs/mutual funds work, figuring out a good investment portfolio, actually investing money). I'm so glad I took this as a senior before graduating.
worse_comment: Class is ok, will teach basic information, but not exciting material that still falls under the personal finance umbrella
subject: Economics
course_title_2024: Personal Finance: Making Better Decisions and Building a Better Financial System

best_comment: I think picking a section with a topic that genuinely interests you is really important for this course. All of your readings and a lot of the adjacent work will be related to the topic you choose. I personally found my section really interesting and relevant which made readings and discussion engaging. I also had a great TF/preceptor which definitely made a difference. At points it does feel like there are a lot of assignments to keep track of and they're all coming from different places, so it's important to be organized and time manage.
worse_comment: Worst econ class at Harvard. you better prepare yourself mentally

best_comment: I learned a lot about housing and homelessness that I otherwise would not have gotten the opportunity to learn at my time at Harvard – I am very appreciative of the subject matter and found it very interesting. The grading for this class is difficult and confusing and its hard to know where you stand in the class
worse_comment: This course is somewhat misleading. While there are roughly 4 written assignments dispersed throughout the semester, there will be much more work entailed since you are expected to continually revise your assignments throughout the semester. On top of that, there are regular problem sets that are run through the general Ec 970 class, and you will probably need to attend Office Hours to complete those. The final paper is also looming over your head, but there is little preparation until the semester's end. Just keep in mind that there are a lot of moving parts to this course that you need to be on top of.

subject: Economics

subject: Economics

best_comment: This course is as good as the courses get at Harvard. Professor Ken Felter is the star and crown jewel of the tutorial program, by my definition, for a number of reasons. First of all, he's a retired partner at a law firm, so he has a bunch of industry experience. He is extremely dedicated to the course and helping his students. He is extremely accessible for office hours and answering a bunch of questions. But beyond that, what is really super outstanding about the course is the content, which is so interesting for anyone interested at all in how the law is made or what the law is at all (like literally everyone has had to have wondered about jaywalking at some point), and also the way in which he engages everyone in the classroom. Each class is like a session where we ask a bunch of questions and collectively learn about the law with Prof Felter. The big elephant in the room is the time commitment for the course. Admittedly, the course has a good deal of reading and assignments, and it's hard to spend less than 6 hours a week on average, even at a minimum, on the course. I think most people will find it worthwhile (evidenced by the other reviews). It is just such an enriching course that even though one might have doubts about joining at the beginning, this is the course to take. Prof Felter also has so many stories up his sleeve from his decades of experience, it is a delight to be in the class. Just be someone who's ready to commit some time and participate in the class. Prof Felter is nice, caring, and an upright person, and he will inspire you in ways, and perhaps convince you that the law (or law school) is something interesting to think about.
subject: Economics

He does an outstanding job of teaching the course in an interesting way, and connecting with students. He’s also super reasonable and understanding if you ever need help or an extension. We had readings, and they were always super interesting. The weekly response papers are super reasonable, and honestly made the weekly readings a lot more meaningful. By far my favorite class this semester, even though it was pretty late in the day! Definitely take the digitization ec970 with Cirrus if you get the chance :)

best_comment: Take this class with Dr. Basilico if you can! This was hands down the most thought provoking, interesting, and enjoyable economics class I have taken at Harvard so far. The readings are curated very well as they give you an opportunity to see how we can apply very common economics concepts and models to mental health and health policy in general, which is something not usually thought in other econ classes. Dr. Basilico himself is very kind, flexible and definitely cares a lot about his students and, specifically, their well–being. His feedback was really helpful for improving my writing skills, and his way of viewing economics/psychopathology gave me a new perspective in the field as well. Just a fantastic section!

best_comment: You probably have to take this class as a concentration or secondary requirement. Everything was manageable, the psets are quite annoying but there are only four of them. Personally, this was one of my favorite classes I've taken, but your experience will truly depend on your section and professor. Topics on Information and Technology with Omar Olivarez, which I took, was an extremely good section. Omar was an incredibly caring, thoughtful, and organized teacher. He was always clear about what was expected of us for each assignment. Every class I felt like I took away something useful (either learning about an econometric method or a new technology case). He was always available for questions and gave very thorough feedback. It was clear he cared about the class structure and all of his students. Other friends who were in this class but had a different section/professor had a very opposite experience from what they have told me. TLDR make you sure read the syllabus and Qguide of each section carefully (look at number/length of assignments, participation requirement, grade weight etc.) when choosing what to rank in the lottery because your section/professor completely dictates your experience in this class.

best_comment: Would absolutely recommend (especially if Ed is a TF again!). If you have any sort of interest in industrial organization or health policy, both Professor Pakes and Ed are incredibly knowledgable on the topic and are great in making sure you learn a lot about healthcare economics as well. The class is presentation heavy (a student presents on one of the papers that was assigned for that week), and then you write a paper on what you read for your presentation – these don't have to be super high–stress though, as Ed will guide you through your presentations and papers if you ask. Both Professor Pakes and Ed are amazing, the support you get from Ed throughout the semester is unmatchable :).

course_title: Economics of Work and Family : Junior Seminar 001
best_comment: This class is amazing. Professor Goldin knows so much and is probably the best professor I've had at Harvard. You probably know about how influential and important her work has been, but she's also hilarious, cares so much about her students, welcomes discussion and sharing your thoughts and questions, and is amazing at making complex material she has developed over the course of her career easily understandable to undergraduates. Can't recommend the class enough, she and the teaching staff really help guide you through the research paper, which is the only intimidating part of the class, and you'll end up producing a body of literature you can be proud of.  I left class everyday thinking meeting two hours, once a week wasn't close to enough, which is crazy because I've never wished a course had more class time. Amazing course with one of the best professors you can ask for
subject: Economics
course_title_2024: Economics of Work and Family : Junior Seminar

best_comment: Ec 985 is a incredible way to get started with your thesis and it's also a great experience to meet new friends/learn from others in the Econ department! When taking 985, think of it as a full course commitment––as it doesn't meet every week, it may be tempting to think it's okay to think of it as not very time consuming, but know that you will make your life a lot easier by prioritizing the course as a class itself, rather than just thinking of the thesis as a side project. Doing research takes time, this class will make your spring much easier by forcing you to get started early, but don't take it for granted!Finally, if you can, try to get into Kiran's seminar––we couldn't have been more lucky this semester! Kiran is an amazing human, incredibly supportive and knowledgeable about the thesis writing process. Class didn't feel like class, but rather a meeting with friends to talk about cool research projects, and in individual meetings she also always made us even more excited about our topics.
