best_comment: You MUST go to section! It will make your life 1000x easier. The textbook isn't necessary, but I REALLY recommend going to every lecture and reviewing the week's lecture slides before starting the corresponding pset—they're so well–made and contain everything you need. Also, try not to enter with a negative attitude. People like to hate on required theory type of classes, but a lot of it is unnecessary. It is NOT overly challenging unless you let yourself fall behind. So long as you keep with the course schedule, you will be more than fine. And try to enjoy it! A lot of it is genuinely quite interesting and will really help you understand your elective coursework better. Also, Professor Boycko is truly the most adorable man in the world. He made me smile so much every lecture, and it's really touching how much he cares about us. The teaching team, too, is wonderful and brilliant. Good luck and keep up!!
worse_comment: It's a shame that this course is practically required for an ec degree. It is simply a worse, more confusing, and disorganized version of the EC10 series (which I am a big fan of and learned a lot in). Lectures are impossible to follow along (not because of content, but because of unengaging presentations, long and dreadfully painful tangents that go on for a while, and an overall lack of diversity of content in material or format). The exams are way different from the very very limited practice exams we are given, and overall the main challenge in this course isn't the material as much as it is just dealing with the course.
subject: Economics

best_comment: textbook used for the course is very well written, very useful for studying for exams. psets are also relatively straightforward, helpful to form study groups, office hours also helpful. lectures are very wordy and stuff tons of information, some arguably unnecessary (like long derivations). would be helpful to condense or at least summarize key takeaways from each lecture, use more visualizations to explain concepts. also really not a fan of the exams being all multiple choice and making up 75% of the grade. makes somewhat more sense in the 10a/b series since there's so many students, but the off cycle 1010b class has like only 100 students, that should be manageable to grade with help of TFs without having to make everything be multiple choice. I don't think multiple choice is the best way to exanimate here since it doesn't give students opportunity to demonstrate their knowledge through work, and it gives zero forgiveness for situations like when student gets initial calculation wrong but does all following calculations wrong (except based on the first initial calculation, so in MP exam they'd get no credit even though they used correct methods). with that said, at least it's better than 1010b in the spring (I think multiple choice exams make up like 90% of grade for spring version of 1010b), and the professor for off–cycle 1010b goes above and beyond for his students. He's extremely responsive to questions from students and is generally a kind person
worse_comment: I came into this class very excited because I loved macro and thought it would be a great building of theory on top of the foundations I learned in EC10B. However, as I began the course, there were so many opportunities to get lost and become confused with the course material. My first issue with the course is that lectures are not recorded. I understand that some professors do this because it is a hassle and/or they want students to attend class in person, but I found it literally impossible to keep up with lectures in person. Usually when I do the readings for a class, the lectures make a ton of sense. However, there was so much disconnect between readings to lecture slides to what the professor was actually teaching. Lecture slides were often extremely confusing and unclear and there were several times that the professor would go off on random tangents deriving random equations on the board and it was really difficult to follow along. In classes, it sometimes felt like he was talking to himself because no one was understanding what he was saying. I’m not sure if lecture recording would have helped much, but I think they definitely would have been a useful tool to look back on since there were so many additional details in lecture. Next up is section. I would go to section every week, and every week my TF would start the class saying that he was super tired and didn’t want to be there. I get it, I am tired too, and I don’t particularly want to be here either, but sometimes we just have to push through. It is evident that my TF put effort into preparing for section, but again, maybe because of how section was structured, I didn’t get much out of it. It was difficult to follow along and it felt like a lot of bouncing all over the place. My biggest issue with the class is how it is graded. As an Econ concentrator, I am used to exams being weighted very heavily on the final grade. It sucks, but it is how it is. However, almost every component of this class is based on multiple choice/ fill in numbers??? That means if you mess up one little equation, you get the entire answer wrong and there is no opportunity for partial credit. Going with this, questions often built on top of each other. So if you got one multiple choice answer wrong, there is a good shot you would get some of the subsequent ones wrong as well. On the midterm and the final, I found these exams extremely difficult for no reason. Usually for Econ courses, understanding the “big picture” ideas is the most important part of the course and you should be able to figure out most other things if you understand those overarching concepts. However, this was not the case in this course. Thomas pulled out random graphs that he has maybe showed once in class and put them on the exam. He would ask questions about authors from readings we barely talked about. Numeric questions all built off of each other, so if you got one question wrong because of a silly calculation error, you likely got several in a row wrong. This type of model makes it seem like the course is testing your ability to do perfect math and memorize silly little details instead of actually gaining a solid understanding of macroeconomic theory, which I feel like defeats the entire purpose of the course. That being said, exams were extremely difficult and no matter how much I studied, I still didn’t feel prepared. I hate writing bad reviews for courses but I really had an unpleasant experience in this course. I know that the 1010s are hard, but this was unnecessarily difficult for what it was. I thought 1010A was hard, but exams and grading were fair if you understood the course material well. I did not feel the same way about this course and don’t think I’m getting much out of it which is a shame. Thomas and the teaching staff are wonderful people, but I think the course definitely needs some restructuring.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Take this class, even if your concentration has nothing to do with economics. First of all, Ed Glaeser is amazing. The policy discussions he starts every lecture with are very interesting and valuable — not only does he motivate that day's lecture, but he also references so many things that only he could, from his many (famous) friends and his own fascinating research/policy experiences to personal anecdotes. Hearing from him and reading about him, this guy deserves a Nobel in the next few decades. The economics of cities (Ed's area of study) sounds boring, but trust me — it's fascinating when you apply 1011a concepts to it. Have fun! Ed successfully inspired me to at least consider econ grad school.Some argue he lectures too fast — but all you need to get from lecture are the key concepts. He moves quickly through math on the board for a reason — it's not important that you follow along, since you no doubt already have the ability to easily replicate the derivative–bashing yourself. He moves quickly through the unimportant stuff and emphasizes the right things. Trust him.Most importantly, get to know Ed. You're at Harvard to build relationships, and this is a great one to have — more important than a grade will ever be. (Speaking of, don't stress about the grade — getting an A is hard, but an A– is easy if you are competent enough.) This class, more than anything, taught me how to *think* like an economist (and believe me, I thought I already knew how to do that!). Ed genuinely made me a smarter person, and what more could I ask for?By far the worst part of this class is the ugly algebra and calculus, but just power through it, especially on the problem sets. Don't spend too much time on the psets because they are completion based — you'll only not get a 100 (the possibilities are 100, 50, and 0) if you attempt so little of it so poorly that you couldn't argue for a 100 with a straight face. Just put in enough effort to derive the pedagogical value from the psets.The modeling projects should be fun, but it really depends on the TF who writes them. The exams are very, very hard, but they are fair. Just remember that they are heavily curved. In fact, the exams being long helps you — you can answer the questions you know, and let the curve take care of the questions you leave blank. And economic intuition always scores points, even if you don't have time for the math the question really calls for.In summary, this class is very, very hard. I'll be honest — I stressed more about this class than about Math 55. But don't let that dissuade you. It's worth it. Your grade will be fun — the curve is generous. Seemingly Ed's sole purpose in life now that he has done so much impactful research is to attract talent to the field of economics — to show talented math and physics students that econ is more than just the "silly" graphs from Ec 10. If you have any trace of that talent and analytical brain, you will take away a lot from this course. You'll see how economics really is a STEM subject, and no matter how far down the pure math rabbit hole you are, trust me — you'll enjoy all of the mathematical modeling.
worse_comment: This course is very poorly organized, and its purpose is not to teach students the material, but to intimidate them, The problem sets are doable but since there is no quantifiable feedback on them, you are not prepared for exams and projects which have too high expectations and are very harshly graded with medians of 50%. The midterm (due in 1h 15 min) was longer than a pset (due in a week), so I really don't see its purpose: it doesn't test your knowledge, but only how to get as many points as possible in a short time. Also there are no deadline extensions so beware of that: you can't be sick in this class. Get ready to pull all nighters when you have a problem set and a modeling project in the same week. This class is just harsh for no reason. I really love the material and i learned a lot in the class, but I feel like the stress and disappointment of getting low grades and sleepless nights because there are no extensions are just unnecessary.
subject: Economics

course_title: A Libertarian Perspective on Economic and Social Policy 001
best_comment: This is probably one of the best courses that I have ever taken. It did not make me a libertarian, but it has empowered me to think critically about things that I previously accepted at face value. Jeff is a phenomenal professor and Harvard Economics is super lucky to have him. He is approachable, extremely intelligent, and very respectful when engaging in debate with students. The fact that the course is light in terms of workload only made it more enjoyable, and allowed me to have a positive relationship with the course. The exams are challenging, but you should be fine as long as you study. I also really enjoyed the section component. So much so, that I would like to be a TF if undergrads will be allowed to be next fall. I highly recommend this course.
worse_comment: This class is a gem! You'll walk away from some lectures, thinking, 'How the hell does Miron figure that?' but even if you regret taking the class, it's no big deal! No assignments, quick sections. And you'll learn some new perspectives on economics and political issues.
best_gem_comment: This class is very manageable and actually thought–provoking. Miron's goal isn't to brainwash you but rather show you how Libertatrian's approach policy and you can agree or disagree with whichever take you like. Entire grade is based on midterm/final so caution with that, but overall definitely a gem and worth taking.
subject: Economics
course_title_2024: A Libertarian Perspective on Economic and Social Policy

course_title: Using Markets to Solve Social Problems 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE. it is so low work commitment but you actually learn so much from the professor. He is so funny but honestly so interesting and knowledgable. It is such a chill class but you get out a lot from it. The two assignments are all group work so it is manageble and lowkey still fun.

course_title: Game Theory with Applications to Social Behavior 001
best_comment: Grading for this course was Prompts, Problem Sets and Exams. Prompts: very enjoyable, a lot of the answers were in the book hidden game, some of the prompts though I didn't understand their purpose, like the American Revolution one. Expect to skim about 4–6 papers a week, this only takes a few hours though. Problem sets: These fluctuated a lot. Some very easy, some crazily difficult. Inconsistency was difficult. TF Ivan's office hours were great though!! But he is only one man, and the course should have had 2 Ivan's in my opinion. Exams: super–duper chill, very fair, just covering basic knowledge. I would bet almost everyone got above a 90. So in conclusion, this course is a fair amount of work during the semester, but chill coming up to exams! Also, you can do all of the prompts and psets in pairs of 2 and submit the same thing which is nice! take the class with a buddy! (or meet one!) Final comment is that lectures were sometimes disorienting, but Prof Hoffman was very happy to explain things after class.Also class basically had unlimited extensions. This flexibility was extremely helpful. Very grateful!
worse_comment: Ok. Here’s the deal. The psets really weren’t that bad, and the material is interesting, but this course was just not taught well. Also, I found it very difficult to prepare for the final; the provided study materials were littered with errors, and the grading is unpredictable.
subject: Economics
course_title_2024: Game Theory with Applications to Social Behavior

course_title: Incentives in the Wild: from Tanking in Sports to Mining Cryptocurrencies 001
best_comment: This was one of the cooler and chiller classes I have taken. It introduces you to a new way of thinking, and the material you go over is actually very interesting. The only thing I will say is that some of the lectures can be a little boring as it can get into pretty dense math, but you really don't truly need to understand the complex math and its proofs. As long as you understand the major conceptual takeaways you will be fine. Definitely not much work outside of class as there were only 3 psets all year (1 per month), each  of which was based on completion. Each one took 3 hours max, and that was because I cared about actually getting the answers right, and being pretty thorough. Additionally, every student has to take notes for one lecture and then write a page about your takeaways, and my only qualm is that this was pretty harshly graded given that they give us almost no info on what they expected. Thus, I would really make sure you write these in depth. Finally, most of your grade (75%) will depend on the final project which is also not much work as they do a good job of spreading out the milestones. It is a group project which is nice too, so doing it with your friends is really chill and you get full ownership over choosing your topic. If you choose a fun topic, it will actually be enjoyable. I have yet to receive my grade back for this final project, but seeing everyone present their project was really cool and low stress as the presentation wasn't graded. Overall, I definitely recommend this class as Yannai is a great person and professor.
worse_comment: This class is a little weird – big on the project–based learning, but you get NO feedback until the final paper which is 75% of your grade, which is frustrating.
best_gem_comment: Yannai is an absolute gem, as well as the rest of the teaching staff. It is interesting to frame incentives and how they impact decisions and it was so cool to see how it plays out using math. The paper was easy as long as you have a good group that works well together. I had a blast working on every part of this class and am so sad that it's over. TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!

best_comment: This is a cool class! I was nervous coming in as an undergrad when it's mostly grad students and I didn't have a super solid background in econometrics (just AP stats really), but Dr. Carlana explains everything very clearly and as long as you're comfortable with linear regressions the background part shouldn't be too much of an issue. I took this class because I was thinking about an ed secondary, though the class focuses much less on substantive education issues than it does on (more broadly) how education/econometric research works and how to interpret it. Which is also a cool skill to have!The workload is not too bad – there are 3 psets in the first half (not too hard), then a midterm (hard, but not graded too harshly), then a research memo (2 pages summarizing 6 papers but you do it with a group), and a final project which is a decent amount of work. The material can feel a bit dry at times, I think it depends a lot on how much you are interested both in the statistics/econometrics and the education aspect of the course.

Please just take this course!!!! It is absolutely incredible and you will learn so much. Emily Breza is one of the kindest and most caring professors who cares about your learning as well as your professional growth in the future, and Oluchi is also so kind and always willing to help students. This course will fundamentally change the way you think about finance in the best way possible, and I couldn't recommend it enough!
subject: Economics

best_comment: Definitely take this with Pettenuzzo in the fall, he's amazing! econometrics covers a TON of information and can seem daunting but his lectures are great, especially the notes he takes aside from the slides. you definitely need some familiarity with  stats (stat 100, stat 104 etc) and its great bedcause the first half of the class will feel very familiar. Read the textbook (it's more helpful than you think and will pay off for the multiple choice portion of exams). Midterm and final were super fair, very reasonable and straightforward. He doesn't try to confuse you or catch you off guard as they are very similar to the PSETs. PSETs were due every other week and not crazy long/hard (~3 questions + a STATA question). Find a good group to pset with and you're good to go. Office hours and section (go to section!) were extremely helpful (shoutout Karen!) The teaching team is easily accessible and so willing to answer your questions/break information down. The 2nd half of the class definitely ramped up in difficulty but it wasn't hard to catch up (lectures are recorded!) Overall, this class definitely seems daunting but coming out of it I actually really enjoyed both the content and the structure. Nowhere near as stressful as I thought, very manageable. Definitely one of the better econ requirements i've taken!
worse_comment: Only take this course if your concentration requires it – material is very boring and repetitive. I'm an Econ concentrator and wouldn't have taken this otherwise.
subject: Economics

best_comment: ECON 1126 is an intense class – it blazes through material with so many derivations that have questionable use at the end of the day (in the assignment/exam context). It's most likely that you're looking at this class because you have no choice as an applied maths concentrator, but I would definitely recommend taking another class if you have the option. It's useful in the sense that you get to learn the theory behind many of the ideas economists use for their regressions and statistical methods, but it is very theoretical so that it will not prepare you to write a thesis for instance. If I had the choice, I would rather have taken STAT 139 or other statistics class that probably would be better taught/more applicable.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE unless you really have to. This is the most disorganized course I have ever taken at this college. If you are AM/Ec, I would just take Stat 111 than this storm of a class. With 1126, notation gets out of control fast, and only skilled professors are able to dispel confusion around a topic by improving the language of the notes. Unfortunately, this class struggles to find ground with the lecture notes and easily sends students rethinking their place in the course. The lectures themselves were not of much help either given the vague language. Regarding homework, rarely did the questions in the problem sets align smoothly with what was taught in lecture. Most problem sets contained questions that could only be figured out if you went to office hours and discovered an obscure math trick. Thank GOD the CAs were real ones. The tests were much worse. This is less so for the midterm, but there were very few materials posted to help prepare for the final exam. The only hint provided was during section on what the final exam could possibly cover. There were no practice exams, no meaningful practice questions for the main topics that were actually on the final, and the answer solutions for the minimal practice questions provided were only tentative solutions with little explanation. Also, the average for the midterm was a 40%, even lower than the 1011a midterm average, how is that even possible?! I just don't understand why this school cannot teach econometrics well. This course proves that world–famous education does not equal world–class education.
subject: Economics

course_title: Closed Borders and Crowded Buses: The Economics of Human Mobility 001
best_comment: If you are thinking about taking an econ elective, I would highly recommend this course. Before this class, I had never really thought much about the potential gains from migration but Professor Kreindler did a great job of motivating the subject matter and generating enthusiasm for it. The lectures are always very interesting and engaging and the readings are very reasonable as well. Kartik is also a wonderful TF who really takes the time and patience to answer our questions and make sure we are understanding the concepts taught in lecture. This is one of few classes where I feel like I learned a lot and enjoyed the material. Additionally, the psets and exams also feel very fair and reasonable given what we have been taught. Again, I strongly recommend this to future students thinking about the course.
worse_comment: I took this course because the Q guide had stellar reviews of the class and professor, and the topic of the class seemed interesting. I had high expectations and was severely let down. The class is difficult and has high–level economics concepts. My request to pass/fail the course was rejected after the last day I could have dropped the class. The psets are difficult and go into nitty gritty econometrics/math concepts. They didn't tell us what was going to be on the exams or any practice problems.
subject: Economics
course_title_2024: Closed Borders and Crowded Buses: The Economics of Human Mobility

best_comment: This is a great course. It is extremely easy and at the same times it's great to have an opportunity to learn from Summers and Liebman. Make the best use of it and make sure to meet with the professors outside of the class, because they can give you a lot of valuable advice and support. Some of the stories the professors tell in class about their experience in the government are incredible, and the joint lectures are very entertaining. I would say that the material can be sometimes boring if you are not a hardcore Econ bro (turns out I am not) and the course being so easy adds to it, but it still really solidified my understanding of real–world macro policies even if it came with the realization that Econ doesn't actually excite me much. The TFs very really helpful and easy to approach. Overall, great course, and I really enjoyed taking it.
worse_comment: If you are going to take this class, you need to do the readings. It features lots of debates on complex economic topics, and if you don't do the readings, you will be lost. The sections feel a bit detached from the actual content, too, since they focus on how to do economic textbook practice problems but don't recap lecture effectively.

best_comment: i loved this class but that's because I'm really into history/macro. i know it seems like a gem, but the assignments are actually pretty hard. like kotz does a really good job of making you think about counterarguments and both him and Sebastian are always super available to help. despite being a 9 am, i loved going to class bc it just felt like listening to a podcast. the grading isn't the easiest but it's super fair. overall, highly recommend!
best_gem_comment: i loved this class but that's because I'm really into history/macro. i know it seems like a gem, but the assignments are actually pretty hard. like kotz does a really good job of making you think about counterarguments and both him and Sebastian are always super available to help. despite being a 9 am, i loved going to class bc it just felt like listening to a podcast. the grading isn't the easiest but it's super fair. overall, highly recommend!
subject: Economics

best_comment: I highly recommend this course for students interested in a survey of economic literature in the vein of behavioral economics. As someone who was interested in exploring behavioral economics beyond the often discussed topic of nudging, this course provided a great overview of the work that exists at the intersection of morality/psychology and economics. While there were certainly references to money and spending, the thrust of this course really emphasized the view that economics is a way of studying incentives and behavior.  It also required a fairly low time commitment –– much less than Ec1010a –– and had an amazingly dedicated teaching staff. While the insights from this course often left me fascinated and are certainly applicable to a number of academic fields (and even to real life), I would not recommend this course to someone who is not interested in a survey–type course –– most of the lectures are focused on describing economic papers. While this is a consequence of this research being so relatively new compared to many other topics discussed in econ, I could see the course feeling very theoretical to some.
worse_comment: The problem sets are deceivingly more difficult than they look, so it is important to double check your work on them
best_gem_comment: Not the best course, not the worst. The intuition/ overarching concepts of this course are pretty interesting— why people vote the way they do, looking at why certain demographics vote one way or another. Ben is a great professor and tries to get people excited. That being said, lectures can feel pretty dry. The typical lecture consists of stating an interesting hypothesis (eg religious people tend to vote against national redistribution) and then going through ~ 2 studies (in a bit of excruciating detail) that prove the hypothesis. Because of this, it often feels like the bulk of what you need to learn is stated in the first 15 minutes of class (but it's a very interesting first 15 minutes). Week to week, the course is pretty minimal work (1 pset every 2 weeks) and no readings. Because of this, it's easy to call this class a "gem," but don't be entirely fooled— the final was worth 50% of the grade, and it consisted of fairly confusing multiple choice questions (you could pick from A, B, A or C, all of the above, none of the above). With only 29 questions, it's easy to see how someone could do poorly on the exam and tank their grade (each question was worth over 1.5% of your overall grade, after all). That being said, there is HUGE inflation, so if you pay attention to the overall takeaways from lectures and study, you should be okay.

best_comment: Take the course; beyond Professor Summers being a true titan of macroeconomics, he is truly an amazing teacher beyond his incredible resume. Very pedagogical, engaging, and, most of all, kind. He clearly loves teaching and his students and wants us to succeed. I can say the exact same of Professor Tucker. Their back and forth was both hilarious and illuminating.

Take the course; beyond Professor Summers being a true titan of macroeconomics, he is truly an amazing teacher beyond his incredible resume. Very pedagogical, engaging, and, most of all, kind. He clearly loves teaching and his students and wants us to succeed. I can say the exact same of Professor Tucker. Their back and forth was both hilarious and illuminating.

This class is a great way to learn about trade if you care about international economics, public welfare, multinational firms, etc.; it's also a great option if you want to knock out a theory requirement. The lectures are interesting, section is helpful, PSets/exams are fair, and workload is not that heavy. You'll learn how to structure your economic thinking and analysis and how to evaluate the economic arguments of others.
worse_comment: The courses material is very organized and presented in a coherent manner. It makes good connections to the real world, and it gives a good understanding of trade from both the firm–level and the policy–level with careful consideration towards individual and societal welfare.The professor and the teaching staff were all very nice and articulate in their explanations. I learned a lot!The grading scheme for this course is completely opaque. By the time of the final, we had gotten back only 1/4 problem sets graded.This ordinarily may not be a problem, however this class expects you to answer exam questions in a certain style. Furthermore the solutions presented for past exams and for the problem sets are extremely terse, and would not themselves get any marks.  Many solutions simply say "good reasoning will get you points" but no actual reasoning is provided, even though the exam questions expect very specific reasoning.It is even more unclear what to expect on exams, because the professor and the teaching staff didn't seem to communicate that much, which was especially troublesome when the exam's expected very specific wording/reasoning/assumptions...
subject: Economics

best_comment: Take this class!! Many students dropped the class at the start of the semester because it can appear very math–heavy at first. However, the problem sets are completion–based, and the exams are quite fair when it comes to the math. The second half of the course is definitely more geared towards policy too. I came in wanting to improve my intuition in macroeconomics and learn about macro beyond the closed–economy scenarios from my intermediate macro classes, and I definitely did that through this class. The papers were particularly interesting. It might initially feel daunting to write the group papers, but Prof. Rogoff meets with each group outside of class and provides sufficient guidance and support to write a strong paper. Prof. Rogoff also invited us to his house, which I thought was nice – he's an interesting guy! Both Jieying and Anhua (the TFs) were great too.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This is an interesting class–definitely not the hardest econ elective out there, but you will have to work hard to memorize a lot of different formulas and be comfortable with terms whose names can sometimes be confused. Bergstresser is an awesome professor and always tries to make the 3 hour lectures engaging, but naturally it can sometimes be hard to pay attention to content for three straight hours, especially when important concepts are taught through a screen–shared Excel spreadsheet. The midterm in our year was definitely harder than the practice tests, but the final was fair IMO. Also really appreciated the walkthrough videos going over midterm/practice final questions that Bergstresser shared. Overall, mixed feelings about this class but don't hesitate to take it if you're interested!!
worse_comment: The course is easy, but pay attention during lectures to avoid learning the whole course the day before the exam.
best_gem_comment: If you are interested in banking, take this. Super easy way to understand a lot of the work you will do in banking at a very high–level. Should be very easy to anyone interested in finance. Definite gem.
subject: Economics

best_comment: He has good intentions with the course and I hope it improves in the coming years to be more friendly for undergrads (it's pretty complex and hard to follow). He’s extremely intelligent and his passion for teaching his findings from his book is exciting. The course felt a little more like a graduate level course since it lacked support in many ways. Also, 2 hour lectures without any breaks is challenging to follow. Everyone doses off pretty quickly and sometimes people fall asleep...
best_gem_comment: This course completely transformed the way I view my economics education at Harvard. I learned how think freely, challenge mainstream economic doctrine I previously held as gospel, and for lack of of better way of explaining it, I feel like a real economist now. Professor Marglin is an absolute gem of a human being and very well may be the best professor at this school. Enjoy his hand–picked apples and go raise some Cain!
subject: Economics

best_comment: Ed goes super super super fast in the first quarter. I still learned some stuff through lecture, but it's impossible to understand everything. Eric Maskin explains things very clearly and at a good pace in the second quarter.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Ed goes super super super fast in the first quarter. I still learned some stuff through lecture, but it's impossible to understand everything. Eric Maskin explains things very clearly and at a good pace in the second quarter.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Laibson is a great instructor and explains things super well in the first quarter. But you should check who is teaching the second quarter before deciding whether or not to take the course.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Laibson is a great instructor and explains things super well in the first quarter. But you should check who is teaching the second quarter before deciding whether or not to take the course.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This course covers microeconomic theory well and it is a hard class. I strongly recommend having intermediate economics coursework under your belt before taking this one. With that said, it will give you a great overview and teach you valuable things about micro theory.
worse_comment: The lecture and teaching is not greatIt is important to find a study groups because the problem sets are very hard
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is certainly quirky. It is poorly organized. The professors changed the topics mid–class, they would never finish what they had planned to talk about, and there were no assignments over the course of the year except for the final paper (worth 100% of the grade). Prof. Sen is 90 years old––he has interesting things to say and he really cares, but he's definitely a bit past his prime. The only assignment in this class is a 25 page final paper for all students (including undergrads), which is difficult. Office hours were good, readings were interesting, but that's on YOU to actually do (since there is 0 accountability for students beyond the final paper). The teaching team offers support if you ask for it. Honestly, it's a crazy class but probably not worth taking unless you want to take a class with Sen specifically.

Amazing course, with lots to learn. The classes are long though, so be prepared for that. Though there are few psets, they are quite involved and challenging.

ECON 2040 is a great field course that will expose you to some of the most advanced work in the field of experimental economics. Professor Enke is an effective lecturer who knows so much both through his own work and his close connections with many of the researchers in the field, and I learned a lot through class discussions of papers. The problem sets and final project are also great ways to apply learning to potential projects of our own, which is a rewarding experience. Professor Enke is genuinely invested in his students' success, and always interested in giving you constructive feedback!
subject: Economics

best_comment: Professor Greg Bruich is one of the best professors to meet and take your first–year PhD classes with. Not only is the class designed to help you succeed and learn about so many topics you may have heard about but never really understood but he also will help you navigate and orient your interests and research applications to the coursework. Plus, it's great coding practice!
subject: Economics

best_comment: My understanding is that often time we need to estimate something for something. Thus, we can come up with all kind of estimators. We can then impose assumptions (write a model) to prove some properties of the estimators we came up with. Then, there are certain properties that we like and certain assumptions that we don't like, so there is a trade–off. Finally, it appears that vector space optimization techniques are very useful in all this business. Indeed, "everything is an orthogonal projection".
worse_comment: The visiting professor frequently made mistakes while teaching the course material in lecture, would sometimes disparage students or make comments that seemed off–beat and disheartening about the class, and decided to veer into material completely beyond the scope of what should be taught for a first–year econometrics course. By the end of the semester, over half of the cohort completely stopped attending lectures because of the pedagogical approach in lecture. The visiting professor taught the course in a way with a design that almost seemed to gleefully mock students when they would not understand the material, which is antithetical to teaching. Many students have talked about suffering because of the almost hostile, mocking tone that the visiting professor would take on at times when speaking to them. This course notably damaged the cohort experience and dynamic, and I would not recommend this visiting professor. Elie, who usually teaches this course, I've heard is a much better professor, so for future students, do not worry if Phillip Heiler is not teaching this course again.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is challenging but extremely applicable and interesting. In my opinion, you need to be comfortable with statistics above the level of Stat 110/111. My only statistics background was Stat 110 and CS 181, and I struggled to keep up with the theory in lectures (even though Neil is a pretty entertaining and informative lecturer). I think Stat 210 would help, since we referenced results and ideas from that class pretty frequently. You don't need any economics to understand what's going on, but a lot of the application questions Neil gave on psets were macro–related. Assignments had 2 theory questions and 2 applied questions each, which I thought was a pretty good balance. They helped solidify why we use certain models and why certain properties and assumptions matter. There were only five psets, and we were able to drop 2 of them and use extensions on 2 others. There were no midterms, but there was a final that had an applied section that we did at home and a theory section that we took in person during the scheduled final exam time. The final seemed fair to me, even though I didn't do very well (lack of understanding and preparation on my part). If you keep up with homework, attend lecture and office hours, and really understand what assumptions are carried by each time series model, then you should be fine.The class is fair and the content is useful. Take it! It's tough but worth it.
worse_comment: Just read the book and skip lectures (because they are kinda bad and confusing). Also it was very frustrating that half of the final was on a chapter that was taught in the last 2 weeks and we had no practice problems on that topic in particular.
subject: Economics

course_title: Spatial Mobility and Development: Evidence and Quantitative Models 001
best_comment: This is an excellent course that marries (1) a survey of the latest spatial econ work, and (2) building practical skills for spatial econ work, in particular modelling and estimation with GMM. Gabriel is a passionate lecturer who knows a lot about this field, he gives clear lectures, and is one of the most down–to–earth, accessible and helpful professors when it comes to consulting for my own research. Diego (TF) was super responsive to all my concerns and questions about the psets, and he conducted great sections too.
worse_comment: This is a great course to learn quantitative methods relevant to many areas of economics. The problem sets are difficult, but not impossible.
subject: Economics
course_title_2024: Spatial Mobility and Development: Evidence and Quantitative Models

best_comment: Take this class! It was a really great survey of key topics in the political economy literature, and I left feeling like I had a better grasp of basic concepts in the field,  as well as key techniques and models used in papers. Both David and Aakaash were very accessible and willing to provide detailed feedback. My favorite class of the semester!
subject: Economics

course_title: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy I 001
best_comment: If you're at all interested in optimal taxation or public economics, this course is a must! You should be comfortable with microeconomics and calculus, but section 1 will provide a very useful recap and sufficiently thorough if you feel rusty. Classes with Stefanie are amazing with ample mix between theory and empirics to both be interesting and challenging. You'll come out of the class with a thorough overview of everything related to public economics and be more than adequately prepared to engage in academic  debate and early stage research. Beware, PSet 1 is useful for making sure you understand the derivations from class in detail, but can be a bit tedious and is not directly applicable to the exam.
subject: Economics
course_title_2024: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy I

best_comment: The classes and reading list felt disconnected at times, so make sure you thoroughly understand the readings and ask the professor if in doubt. He is happy to help, but you'll be on your own if you don't as slides were not sufficiently detailed to help with some questions. I think the class could really benefit from slides being made available in advance, since the calendar seemed to not line up with the reading list, so it was difficult to prepare sufficiently for class. Interesting material covered, but I didn't always feel as though the class supported my learning.
subject: Economics

best_comment: I valued the professor's flexibility with the final assignment. If you possess a solid grasp of econ and a keen interest in cutting–edge research in international finance, this course is worth tackling, even if you're not a PhD student.

I totally recommend this class. Since it is strongly focused on methods, it is useful for many fields in economics. It provides a strong training for structural estimation as well as applications of IO techniques  to many fields.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is a must–take for anyone seriously interested in finance. It has a very steep learning curve, so you should have a somewhat comfortable background in finance and capital market logic, but you will be able to catch up on some important concepts in the start of the course. The course moves fast, however, so make sure you're not too far behind at the start. Begin PSets early, they're very long and somewhat involved, but they'll help you think about the topics discussed in class in more detail. John is a world–class teacher with an amazing knowledge of asset pricing (and finance in general) from his long career in academia. You will come out of it feeling like you've ran a marathon (and perhaps got lost on the way), but once it's all said and done, you'll be thankful you took it and had your logic sharpened and your intuition strengthened at its core.
subject: Economics

best_comment: For undergrads, this is a great class to take if you're interested in corporate finance, enjoy theory, and are considering getting a PhD in Economics. The problem sets can take a lot of time though, so make sure you find people to pset with or budget your time accordingly. Definitely also ensure that you have a solid understanding of econometrics before taking the course, or the referee reports will be challenging
subject: Economics

best_comment: For undergrads, this is a great class to take if you're interested in corporate finance, enjoy theory, and are considering getting a PhD in Economics. The problem sets can take a lot of time though, so make sure you find people to pset with or budget your time accordingly. Definitely also ensure that you have a solid understanding of econometrics before taking the course, or the referee reports will be challenging

best_comment: The class was amazing. Professor Katz teaches with enthusiasm and has developed a very interesting course, especially for those interested in labor markets. The course interestingly covers good breadth and depth. I thoroughly enjoyed being part of this.

course_title: Early Stage Research and Discussions on Deep Learning and Big Data in Economics 001
best_comment: This class is a fantastic way to increase your exposure to a multitude of research topics under the big data and deep learning umbrella, also providing you the opportunity to get experience presenting your research. The class is structured in a presentation–heavy format with little to no formal teaching, which can be a positive or negative depending on your interests. Professor Dell is also great and incredibly insightful in her recommendations and opinions. Overall I highly recommend Econ 2924.

best_comment: This is a fantastic class for meeting a broad selection of faculty in health economics. I left the class feeling supported with a foundation for new research ideas and a better understanding of modern research in health economics.  Professor Shepard is a great instructor and helped the classroom environment feel comfortable through the variety of lecturers and topics. It's a light work load if you need it to be but you can also delve into the readings and topics that interest you! Very flexible and overall worthwhile.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This course is great! The topics are interesting, the class discussions are fun, and it is very little work. Honestly if you just attend class, you'll get a good understanding of all the concepts without doing the readings. The readings are interesting though and contribute to your understanding. I think this is a better option for developmental psychology than the undergraduate course just because there is a wider range of topics covered and it is much more chill
subject: Education Studies

best_comment: I took this course to satisfy the divisional requirement. The workload is pretty easy. You have a bit of reading, maybe 2 hours maximum per week if you are really reading everything (most weeks <1hr of reading) and a 200–300 word response essentially graded on completion. You also have to teach one of the sections, but this doesn't really count for any part of your grade from what I see. As for the midterm paper, only 1500 words, but beware that they typically give out bad grades on it. Seems like they should provide more guidance rather than just giving people a bad grade. The final paper was pretty grueling to write as the topics didn't seem to me to be super interesting. Overall, the course was pretty interesting. You get a pretty diverse set of perspectives from the readings and the lectures are pretty enjoyable. By the end of the semester though, it seems like we are talking about the same things over and over, which gets boring. As for the assignments, just beware that your grade is essentially made up of only 2 papers, so if you do poorly there is not a lot of opportunity to improve.
subject: Education Studies

course_title: The Politics of Education in the Developing World 001
best_comment: This is a decent course, definitely a gem. You will get out of it what you put in. Teaching staff is super helpful and section was enjoyable. The class culminates in writing an Op Ed, which is a pretty enjoyable process that I grew a lot as a writer from. I think my overall feedback is that there's not a ton of structure to lecture, which can make it pretty dry at times, and leave you feeling like you didn't learn too much that day that you couldn't have gotten out of the readings. However, the professor is a cool person, and the "ungrading" policy makes the class feel a lot more relaxed.
best_gem_comment: This is a decent course, definitely a gem. You will get out of it what you put in. Teaching staff is super helpful and section was enjoyable. course_title: What Education Should Be: Purposes, Dilemmas, and Future Directions 001
best_comment: Please, please, PLEASE take EDST 132!!!!!! If you're thinking about becoming a teacher or going to education school, THIS CLASS IS A MUST–TAKE. IT WAS HANDS DOWN THE BEST CLASS I TOOK THIS SEMESTER. I COULDN'T STOP THINKING ABOUT IT.  In fact, it's one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard, if not the best one.Dr. Cheng is more on top of things than any professor I've had here. She plans lessons so beautifully and is phenomenal at leading in–class discussions. Homework was very reasonable, and I learned a lot from it. The readings were amazing and eye–opening. The essays were an absolute joy to write.Also, I must say this in these exact terms: DR. CHENG IS AWESOME. Please take one of her classes.
worse_comment: The course is very much a survey course in education, so it is very similar to a GENED you could take on the topic of education. The course is not very demanding, but the in–class activities are pretty repetitive. There were one or two speaker panels, but all other class sessions had the same activities that only differed in the topic of the week. I would take this course if you want an introduction to education without too many assignments to worry about.
subject: Education Studies
course_title_2024: What Education Should Be: Purposes, Dilemmas, and Future Directions

best_comment: Great class would highly recommend!! Kelly is awesome and the class is a welcome distraction from every other class.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Take it especially if you love hands–on machining and tinkering––if so, you'll find comfort in the makerspace. EdDiscussion is so helpful, for everything from Psets to CADding because Professor Seymur responds insanely quickly. Lab and lecture feel like 2 different classes so ES51 did sometimes feel like the coursework for 2 classes, where the labs felt like they were worth 1.5 classes and lecture seemed like half a class. Also, Psets and classwork and CAD at the beginning will feel very overwhelming but all of those of the lecture part of ES51 calms down pretty quickly so just stick around. Overall though, if you do love manufacturing, the excitement from that will get you through the class. Best professor, CAs, and classmates!
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Quantitative Physiology as a Basis for Bioengineering 001
best_comment: Please do MATLAB Bootcamp before you start the course. It won't make the course easy, but it will make the first lab MUCH easier. And you'll just generally feel more confident going in. It's not obligatory; it just saves you a good amount of pain. Linsey is a good professor––not tyrannical like I hear some other engineering professor are. She's open and considerate, so definitely talk to her if there's anything you wanna discuss. Overall, the class is kinda hard. But if you put in the time, you should be able to do well on everything, including the exams. But that also means this course is pretty time–consuming, especially if you wanna do well. My advice for success? After each lecture, really read through, take notes, and make sure you understand what is going on. Because when the exams come around, you might need to digest all of the lectures at once. That was the situation I was in. Digest the content week–by–week.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Even if you are not bioengineering necessarily, but are looking for another class to complete your biology prerequisites for medical school, this class is by far one of the best STEM intro classes at Harvard. You will not only gain a solid conceptual understanding of physiological systems including the nervous, cardiac, skeletal, and renal systems but will also apply your understanding with mathematical and computational tools. You will also get lots of exposure to MATLAB!

best_comment: I met some of my best friends at Harvard through this course, and I don't think that was a coincidence. If you are an entrepreneur, the best thing you can do by being at Harvard is to meet other people on campus building cool ventures, and this class is one of the best ways to do that. I really appreciated the time it gave me to work on my startup and cherish the connections I have made with others. Being in the Slack is something that continues beyond the class and is valuable on its own, too.
worse_comment: If you have a startup you want to take seriously this semester, take this course. It's very very light on the courseload side –– basically only one small assignment the whole year + a weekly Slack post –– and you will get accountability and feedback as you build your startup.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 001
best_comment: Since we got to work on a technical project this semester, I actually loved this class. As a bioengineer we don't get a lot of hands–on experiences in classes, so this was a great change. As with all group projects you can imagine some of the issues we ran into, but overall this was a great class and I hope students in the future get to work on more technical solutions! Kyle and Shawn were also the best TFs to work with.

best_comment: You're always doing extremely rewarding and practical work in the class, but the course could be structured a bit better. I wouldn't go into it expecting the course to be extremely easy. Despite being a half–credit course, it's taken up just as much time as my other classes, and isn't given that much grace in terms of grading either. While the project leads and instructors are very helpful in–person, I haven't found them super easy–to–approach and feedback on assignments has often felt a bit abrasive. Course content however is still overall fulfilling for those looking for engineering real–world experience.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: OVERVIEW:★★★★★ (5/5) | OVERALL RATING★★★★★ (5/5) | PROFESSOR★★★★☆ (4/5) | LECTURE★★★★☆ (4/5) | SECTION★★★★★ (5/5) | HOMEWORK★★★☆☆ (3/5) | EXAMS★★★☆☆ (3/5) | LABS★★★★☆ (4/5) | PROJECTOVERALL: (5/5)★★★★☆ (4/5) | DIFFICULTY (HARD)★★★★☆ (4/5) | TIME EXPECTATION (LONG)★★★★★ (5/5) | WORTHWHILENESSHard class that takes determination to do well in, but it's worth it because mechanical systems are essential for any engineer and this class is a great primer for diving into that. Very analytically heavy with some computational components, but material is presented sufficiently well with a good support staff. This class is (quite literally but also compliment–wise) a must–take for any prospective engineer.PROFESSOR: (5/5)★★★★★ (5/5) | PERSONALITY★★★★★ (5/5) | KNOWLEDGEABILITY★★★★★ (5/5) | COMMUNICATIONBoris is an extremely personable and engaging professor. In a field of study where it is common for professors to 1) present topics in a dull and boring way, disparate from real–world application; 2) lack the ability to put concepts into digestible, layman terms; and 3) hand–wave a lot of concepts away when they lack current understanding, Boris stands as a pillar for mechanical engineers everywhere, which is appreciated tenfold considering the fact that Mechanical Systems is REQUIRED for prospective mechanical engineers. He is humorous, demonstrates great expertise on the course material, and is highly communicative and accommodating on Slack.LECTURE: (4/5)★★★☆☆ (3/5) | ENGAGEMENT★★★★★ (5/5) | CONTENTOf course, being fully lecture style means that there is not a lot of hands–on or personal engagement required from you. The lectures are definitely worth attending as they're very comprehensive and understanding tends to work better when in an environment where you're surrounded by others trying to understand the same material. All slides are posted on Canvas and lectures can be attended on Zoom, but don't make the mistake of skipping class because you will learn much better in person.SECTION: (4/5)★★★★☆ (4/5) | USEFULNESSWhen I say "section", I refer to office hours. These are HIGHLY important for anyone taking this class; unfortunately, everyone also realizes this and nearly everyone goes to office hours, which means it can sometimes be difficult to get help on your own because the TAs have a lot of people to help (though this will be solved if you attend multiple office hours!).HOMEWORK: (5/5)★★★★☆ (4/5) | DIFFICULTY (HARD)★★★★☆ (4/5) | TIME EXPECTATION (LONG)★★★★☆ (4/5) | LECTURE PREPARATION★★★★★ (5/5) | FEEDBACKMany difficult problems that are built on concepts learned and practiced in class, with some details added on top for critical thinking and problem–solving. The problem sets are manageable if you go to office hours, but I HIGHLY recommend you form a PSet group to tackle problems, because sometimes these problems are a doozy. Progression of difficulty is steady but towards the end, can be exhausting (prepare to show A LOT of work). TAs give incredible feedback on Gradescope that helps you understand why and where you went wrong in your work.EXAMS: (3/5)★★★★★ (5/5) | DIFFICULTY (VERY HARD)★★★★☆ (4/5) | LENIENCY★★★★★ (5/5) | FEEDBACKExams are too long to be done in time for most and aren't curved, although they will be graded with a lot of leniency to give credit wherever possible. I personally felt underprepared for both exams and I wished there were either less problems on the tests or extended time on the tests.LABS: (3/5)★★★★☆ (4/5) | DIFFICULTY (VERY HARD)★★★★☆ (4/5) | ENGAGEMENT★★★★☆ (4/5) | COURSE RELEVANCELabs had interesting physical, hands–on components and set–ups, but the problem this year was that Steve left (he abandoned us for MIT) and a lot of the underlying code that enabled the labs were hard to troubleshoot or didn't work. We were able to make due but in general the labs were very finicky. They did reflect course content pretty well when they did work, however.PROJECT: (4/5)★★☆☆☆ (2/5) | DIFFICULTY (EASY)★★★★★ (5/5) | ENGAGEMENT ★★★★★ (5/5) | COURSE RELEVANCEFun final project that is essentially for completion— designing a suspension system to soften the landing of a falling carriage containing an egg, and presenting it at the end of the semester. I had a lot of fun designing and building my project, and watching other people drop their projects. Don't sweat this project and have a lot of fun with it!
worse_comment: it is hard, a lot of content is covered
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Innovation in Science and Engineering: Conference Course 001
best_comment: This will be one of my most memorable courses during my time at Harvard. Yes, it does have a reputation for being easy, but really you get out of it what you put in. The speakers have great variety, where you learn a lot from most of them, very few were boring, and even the boring ones you could tell were great experts in their field. I really appreciated the flexibility of this course, you can really tell that the professor is passionate about inspiring and supporting students.
worse_comment: This class was actually the bane of my existence. They completely restructured it from last year and what was most frustrating was the grading change. So now, even if you follow the rubric to a T, the max score you could get was a 90%. The remaining 10% were awarded if they considered your submission to be "exceptional". It was so incredibly irritating as it made all the assignments more confusing than they had to be as you were trying to reach this subjective "exceptional" standard without having any idea of what exactly was considered exceptional. Would not recommend this class at all.
best_gem_comment: Super chill class if you're looking for a gem or to fulfill the SEAS divisional distribution. The course administration was a bit disorganized at times though.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2024: Innovation in Science and Engineering: Conference Course

best_comment: To begin with, to all the EE concentrators, you have probably heard of this course and/or the iconic Gage Hills, and I assure you the hype is real. Of all the courses in EE I have taken, none has been as effective as ES152 in instilling an intrinsic curiosity and desire to truly understand how things work. This course is very challenging. Be aware that this class is called ES152: Circuits, Devices, and Transduction, which Gage will point out should probably be three separate courses. That means that material which should be covered in three semesters (or more) will be covered in one. It's a big ask, and Gage being as dedicated and passionate about the material as he is, will not skimp or shy away from unturning as many stones as possible in this one semester. Don't be afraid though. It is one hell of a ride. The lectures are always focused on establishing intuition and Gage has an incredible ability and level of patience to explain concepts in a step–by–step way, building on your understanding and connecting sub–concepts into full topics.  The lectures are so entertaining and useful that this is a class where you would never want to miss a lecture. They are very engaging (pun intended) and Gage even spends hours outside of class making MATLAB simulations of MOSFETS and electron orbitals just to help us have a better visual. Homework was split into analyticals and labs. They come as a set, intended to be given once a week/two weeks. Fair warning, each homework is very long, ranging from 20–30hrs on average. However, the homework is full of excellent explanations and guidance, and although you may go pale seeing subparts a–t for a single question, know that by the end of it, you will be amazed by how deeply you understand the concept that question was targeting. Labs were excellent. They covered a good variety of material like audio amplifiers, DACs, and semiconductor devices. Georgios, who I hope will still be a TF for the course, did an incredible job redesigning these labs last year with Gage. Georgios is a gem for the course and has some of the best advice, understanding, and explanations for course material. If he's available in lab or outside of class, he is a wonderful asset to the course and is a great person to discuss questions and concepts with. Speaking of teaching staff, the TFs were truly a dream team. I have never witnessed a course where all the TFs were as all–around excellent as in ES152. Georgios, TomHenry, and Jalil were the Holy Trinity. TomHenry was a wizard at section. I was amazed at how succinct and intuitively he could explain concepts. Interesting to note is that TomHenry has a more traditional background in how he understands the material, meaning his equations match the textbooks. This was a nice juxtaposition to the less traditional way Gage explained material in lecture. Both approaches have their benefits so getting to hear different angles, one in lecture and one in section, really was a powerful combo. Jalil did a great job leading lab and helping us with debugging any issues. Overall, all the TFs were incredibly enthusiastic, capable, and generous with offering time to help us whenever needed.Lastly, as you have probably come to realize in this long response, Gage is an extraordinary professor. I doubt you could find a student who would describe Gage as anything less than exceptional. No matter if it was the beginning of the course, the weekend, some weekday at 3am, in class, after class, whenever and wherever, Gage is always full of energy and passion for teaching. His dedication toward his students is unparalleled, allowing us to slack him any time we had questions (he responds fast) even late at night, and making it easy to schedule one–on–one time with him if we needed help or just wanted to discuss something. The lectures, homework, and even the final exam were custom catered toward the class. I think Gage takes pride in making the homework questions unique yet comprehensive. For example. the final exam took us step by step in creating a display monitor which was so cool, and it was an amazing moment having Gage guide us in proving to ourselves that with the knowledge gained in this course, we could do things that seemed impossible at our level, like designing circuits to make our computer or phone screens. Gage is an excellent teacher but his dedication to getting to know the class and helping us with problems big or small and doing it with such joy made him the best professor I've ever had. Sometimes, we forget that like any professor, he's probably juggling research, meetings, conferences, and his personal life alongside this class, but it was undeniable how much he prioritized this class and every student in the class. This wasn't something he had to do, but he does it because of the person he is and because he understands that teaching and learning is not just about giving lectures and doing the bare minimum. Every student learns at a different pace and in a different way, and Gage made sure we never felt short of having the right support and help however and whenever we needed it. ES152 will be challenging but so fulfilling. Be excited. This class will probably convince you of why you love EE. And finally, just know that you're in excellent hands.
worse_comment: Things will be confusing. Ask questions and make it a habit to get those questions answered at office hours. Gage is more than willing to help you, but it is up to you to tell him that you are confused.
