subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: For an introduction to control theory course, ES155 does an excellent job covering the essentials. Lina's lectures get straight to the point, and she distills the information necessary to intuitively understand problems and concepts as well as the best guidelines for solving problems. The textbook by Astrom and Murray follows the class material faithfully, especially in the first half of the course. I would definitely recommend doing the textbook readings before the lectures so that Lina's teaching will reinforce material you've already been exposed to and have pondered on.In terms of assignments, there are roughly 8 psets, once each week or every two weeks, and they are fairly written, covering the material according to the lectures. Most of the time, the psets will have MATLAB integrated, so it would be helpful to at least cover a crash course into MATLAB and gain some familiarity with the control toolbox before or at the start of the course. There will be sections that will help provide this on–ramp, but it's honestly easier and more effective to take care of it yourself beforehand. If anything, you can do the training earlier and ask any lingering questions in section the first couple weeks.Besides the psets, there are two short labs (very guided, don't require more than 30min to conduct the lab and roughly 1–2hrs to do the lab report) in each half of the semester. The other assignment is the course project. This is done in about ~4 stages, called milestones, throughout the semester. The teams are picked by Lina, but you do get to send her your preferences for partners. The project objectively is time–consuming and difficult since it requires the knowledge acquired in just the last couple weeks to be applied to a control problem you study with your group. Now, depending on the commitment and work distribution of your team, the difficulty can range from challenging but manageable to extremely time consuming (i.e. expect a few all–nighters). Lina is very understanding and will provide a lot of help and guidance throughout the project, so please don't feel intimidated. By the end, you will feel that the project is probably your proudest accomplishment in the course. The project truly does provide a healthy challenge and is going to greatly help your understanding and confidence in the material you learn, but like anything you study, it will take time to digest and there will be a lot of mistakes along the way. Try to stay optimistic and know that all groups end up doing very well by the culmination of the project!Lastly, there is one midterm and a final. I think the format of it changes from year to year, but in this past year the midterm was done in class with a handwritten cheat sheet. The final was a 3hr take home exam. Both were very reasonable. Be sure to look at the practice exam Lina will send because they represent the exams very well. For a few last notes, the class definitely will feel like a math course at times, but the math is based on a few key linear algebra topics like rank and finding eigenvalues. It's nothing extensive, so even if you don't have the best math background coming in, these are concepts you can still pick up. Plus, if you are an engineering concentrator, having concrete examples and applications will greatly help in your understanding, in ways pure math classes were lacking. For EE concentrators, this class pairs excellently with ES152. Truly, I cannot think of a better class pairing in the same semester as ES155 and ES152. The concepts overlap so nicely and the knowledge you gain in one class will help reinforce what you learn in the other. The best benefit is getting to learn bode plots and transfer functions in ES152 just before they are covered in ES155. Overall, ES155 is a very solid course and if the appropriate time is taken to understand the material, you will most likely have a great appreciation and fascination with controls that stays with you beyond the class.
worse_comment: Overall: Controlling systems via feedback, i.e., taking mathematical models of physical/biological/mechanical/economic systems and using feedback of the output to create inputs that allow us to control the output. Useful for a range of concentrations where stability/feedback are important. The first half is modern control theory with the state space model and lin alg; the second half is classical control theory with the Laplace transform and frequency domain analysis. Also teaches some basic MATLAB, Simulink, and MATLAB ControlSystemDesigner. Professor: Lina is a wonderful teacher. The lecture notes are extremely well written and are great references both inside and outside class. Textbooks: Not critical but very useful for understanding. Should be online: https colon slash slash web dot archive dot org slash web slash 20230327000000 asterisk slash http colon slash slash www dot cds dot caltech dot edu colon 80 slash tilde murray slash amwiki slash index dot php slash Second underscore Edition1) Astrom and Murray, Feedback Systems: An Introduction for Scientists and Engineers. Second Edition. Topics covered: State space model, difference equations (discrete); equilibrium points, phase portraits, stability, linearization, LTI systems; matrix exponentials; stability and Eigenvalues; state feedback control, reachability theorem, reference tracking, placing Eigenvalues, controllers; observability, Luenberger estimator; impulse/step/frequency response; Laplace transform, transfer functions, block diagrams; Bode plots (<3), zeros and poles; Nyquist plots, Nyquist criterion; tracking/steady state error, phase/gain margin; PID, lead/lag control, sensitivity functions, performance limits, robustness.Course structure notes: Pset due on Fridays mostly. Group design project with project milestone assignments (replaces pset that week) and final report writeup, actually quite fun and extremely educational. Two short lab data collections with short writeups. Two midterms.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Extremely interesting and engaging, and the topics are relevant and applicable.  Professor Ba is an amazing professor––very thoughtful and knowledgable, takes all questions seriously even when they go beyond the scope of the class, and genuinely cares about his students and the course material.  Take advantage of his office hours, not necessarily to go over psets and other assignments but rather just to have conversations with him about the material and your final project, because he knows so much about the topics and is sincerely very interested.  This course teaches a lot of useful data analysis skills and provides great background into timely issues such as AI and neural networks.  However, it can feel dense and confusing, especially if you don't have much background with probability and statistics (as I did not).  Try not to get too bogged down in the details during lectures; it's more important to pay attention and absorb the high level stuff, and you will get a lot out of this class.
worse_comment: Professor Demba might seem slightly hard to read, but he's a phenomenal human being, go to his office hours!

course_title: Introduction to Optimal Control and Estimation 001
best_comment: Hank is so great! I enjoyed his lectures and his office hours. He is new so I was unsure about his teaching before taking the class, but he is so approachable and a good guy. I found myself super interested in the material. I think this class is much better at teaching controls than ES155. I remember Hank gave one exceptionally good lecture on stability that made it click for me even though I had taken ES155 a year prior.

OVERVIEW:★★★★★ (5/5) | OVERALL RATING★★★★★ (5/5) | PROFESSOR★★★★☆ (4/5) | LECTURE★★★★★ (5/5) | HOMEWORK★★★★☆ (4/5) | EXAMS★★★★★ (5/5) | LABSOVERALL: (5/5)★★★★☆ (4/5) | DIFFICULTY (HARD)★★★★☆ (4/5) | TIME EXPECTATION (LONG)★★★★★ (5/5) | WORTHWHILENESSCome into this course recognizing that this is a mathematical, conceptual class more than a building robots class. There are 5 really fun but challenging labs where you work with a 6–joint robot, which feels amazing to do because it's like you've spent all this time learning about these concepts without application and now you're doing it, and when you're doing it, it actually works! Professor is great, homework is challenging but worthwhile, and labs are fulfilling. Support is great.PROFESSOR: (5/5)★★★★★ (5/5) | PERSONALITY★★★★★ (5/5) | KNOWLEDGEABILITY★★★★★ (5/5) | COMMUNICATIONProf. Werfel is personable, easy to talk to, and understanding. I haven't had a bad experience with him. Pretty humorous, especially about his derivations.LECTURE: (4/5)★★★☆☆ (3/5) | ENGAGEMENT★★★★★ (5/5) | CONTENTI missed a few of my other classes, but I always made sure to never miss this class's lecture. Lectures have always been interesting and worth coming to. They are NOT recorded, but they can be supplemented by online videos, so it's not a huge issue, especially because lectures tend to have an emphasis on derivation. Engagement is 3/5 because it's a lecture style, there's not gonna be a lot of back and forth, but the content of the lecture is interesting enough to keep you focused for an hour and a half— I know it kept my attention that long the entire semester. Wish there could've been more demonstration tools; it's very chalkboard heavy.HOMEWORK: (5/5)★★★★☆ (4/5) | DIFFICULTY (HARD)★★★★☆ (4/5) | TIME EXPECTATION (LONG)★★★★☆ (4/5) | LECTURE PREPARATION★★★★★ (5/5) | FEEDBACKFour to five difficult problems per problem set but are both conceptually relevant and interesting. I am a big fan of the questions because they're interesting to think about spatially. It is worthwhile to have a PSet group or go to office hours. EXAMS: (4/5)★★★★★ (5/5) | DIFFICULTY (VERY HARD)★★☆☆☆ (2/5) | LENIENCY★★★★★ (5/5) | FEEDBACKExams have the right amount of difficulty. Professor himself stated he's very strict on exam grading. You have a note sheet, and with a reasonable amount of studying you can do pretty well on the exams. LABS: (5/5)★★★★☆ (4/5) | DIFFICULTY (VERY HARD)★★★★★ (5/5) | ENGAGEMENT★★★★★ (5/5) | COURSE RELEVANCEOMG. I feel like a robot master. It's like everything I've learned in class, I actually got to use. In the future, this will come in handy. You start out playing around with the robot virtually and in person, then you get to moving the arm to a position by adjusting its angles, then you get to moving the arm to a position by adjusting its velocities, then you get the arm to trace out a path through a maze, and then you get to make the arm pick up a block and place it on a platform using image processing. This class FEELS cool.
worse_comment: This class was very very interesting! Only issue was that i found the final exam to be very unfair given the level of difficult for the midterms.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Introduction to Electronic and Photonic Devices 001
best_comment: This is a really great course! It will not overload you with work but will allow you to learn about semiconductors, p&n junctions, solar cells, and more in a relaxed, informative, engaging environment. Evelyn is such a great, inspiring professor :)
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2024: Introduction to Electronic and Photonic Devices

best_comment: I thought this was going to be a super hard course but it wasn't that bad. I think Professor Coughlin made it easier.  I really enjoyed the material. Taking PS11 before this would help, there is some crossover.
worse_comment: If you are chem/phys and deciding between this, Phys 181 and Chem 161 – take either the chem or the phys versions. This class talks a lot about mechanical systems (piston cylinders and engines) and is very limited to engineering – there is pretty much no stat mech and very little reach beyond mech e.Lectures were dry, slow, and sleep inducing. The only way I could stay awake was to do something else and re–read the lecture slides later. Maybe Mark will get better? This was his first year lecturing here. The textbook is really dense and difficult to use as a resource (I normally rely heavily on textbooks, so this is saying something). Most of how I learned was through trial and error with the psets and exams. Psets are not hard if you go to section. Labs were fun but the lab write–ups were awful! They were graded leniently though. In hindsight this class was *fine,* but I did not enjoy any part of it while I was taking it.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: I thought this was going to be a super hard course but it wasn't that bad. I think Professor Coughlin made it easier.  I really enjoyed the material. Taking PS11 before this would help, there is some crossover.

subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: The lectures for this course are not very technical, but they are genuinely interesting and fun. The problem sets are infrequent, but be prepared to reference the textbook for the problem sets and midterm as there will be some calculations and concepts that are more challenging, especially without experience from courses like ES120 or ES128. The course capstone project is a great opportunity to do something that you care about and if you budget your time well throughout the semester, you will easily find the time to do everything needed for the scope of the project. Overall, I would highly recommend the class as it is fun and not a lot of work.
worse_comment: low hour engineering requirement
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: If you've taken a physics undergrad QM course, please take physics251a/b instead of this course. I found this course to no more rigorous––in fact, even easier––than the QM courses I took in undergrad. This course basically covers scattered topics in Griffiths but at a pretty shallow level. It teaches some applications like band structure, rotating wave approximation, quantum info, etc., but I found those to be rather pointless since many people plan to take solid–state, AMO, and QI anyways, which cover those topics more thoroughly. By taking this course instead of a more rigorous grad QM course, I felt underprepared for the other course I took this semester and future physics courses. PSETs and exams are easy but often algebraically tedious, which made them just busywork. The grading also made me feel like I had gone back to high school after graduating undergrad––it's been a hot sec since I've seen points being taken off for not showing enough work even though my answer was correct and I understood what I was doing. But to be fair, the course assignments/sections are very pedagogical and probably useful if you don't have a solid undergrad QM background. And the easier, biweekly PSETs allow for more time spent on research (unlike physics251a where PSETs are weekly).You're required to take this course if you're in QSE, but I would suggest stalling until your later years or until this requirement is relaxed (probably unlikely though).
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: If you are interested in the topic of neurotech, this is a very good class to take. It provides a great overview of different topics and because of the assignments and readings you can walk away with solid understanding. Prof. Srinivasan is awesome and makes the lecture very engaging, and accessible to different educational backgrounds.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Biomechanics of Movement and Assistive Robotics 001
best_comment: Course was extremely interesting and the lectures were amazing. I learned a lot from the class, but in its first year, definitely did leave a lot to be desired. If you are just at all interested in learning how the body moves and how assistive devices are made, then this class is made for you. However, you must have a relatively strong physics background to succeed in the course. Class was great, and with this year's feedback, can only get better.

This is a lovely class and I would highly recommend it. Prof Liu splits "neuroengineering" into a few categories: observing the brain, probing the brain, and integrated approaches combining these technologies. You can expect to spend about 1/3 of the semester on each one of these. Prof Liu is a very effective lecture –– it feels like he's put a lot of thought into what he is going to present and teaches in a very clear and understandable manner. He is always happy to stop for questions anytime. The lab is super interesting. This year it was tissue clearing of mouse brain sections and then laser confocal microscopy to perform 3D connectivity mapping (basically 3D imaging and reconstruction of the neural structure of the mouse brain). Very cool experience, which was a highlight of the course.Assignments were short prelab/postlab reports, and then 'journal club' midterm presentations where you will present with a group on one of about seven papers provided by Prof Liu. He emphasized time and time again that if you wanted to get anything out of the course, it is vital to read the papers. It is through this exercise that you come to truly understand where the field is now. It is quite easy to just read your own paper and present on it, but I would stand with the professor on this account –– make the extra effort to read as many papers as you can. Your grade does not depend on this, but your understanding will definitely deepen. I found the presentations to be good assignments, however because everyone must present on their papers, it did end up taking up a significant portion of class time, which was a little unfortunate. Also, *do not go over the time limit in your presentations*. Prof Liu is very strict about them and likes to keep class on time. Final projects were fun, I liked the idea of having us write NIH–style grant proposals for novel research. Talk to Prof Liu about your project ideas –– he is a wonderful resource and was very helpful and thoughtful. Prof Liu really is a leader in this field, and knows his stuff quite well. This class was a pleasure, and I'd highly recommend it!
worse_comment: Take it, it is amazing and not a huge time commitment (apart from the labs). Make sure to pay attention in lectures though, as you are not required to but then you are not gaining anything from the class.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Xin Li is very passionate about batteries and is so knowledgable in the topic because his lab focuses on solid state batteries. I learned a lot in this class about batteries, their common problems, comparisons between different types of batteries, their varying applications, why patents are important, etc. I found it very very interesting as someone who is interested in energy and engineering. It is a cool introductory class to a large industry and is approachable to undergrads.
worse_comment: Take this class! Prof. Li is an excellent professor, and this course is very accessible for undergraduates who are interested in energy and energy materials but have a difficult time finding udnergrad–level courses suitable for the subject matter. Nothing is too difficult, but a lot of the theoretical bases of battery systems are covered in the course.

subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Gu is an absolute joy. def more of an ML class this semester but a good time.

Dr.Habbal is a very nice man, he cares about people learning. I feel like the lectures didn't feel directly connected to what we were doing in CNS sometimes and I also think we could have started our project earlier. However, I do think this class is useful especially if you don't have much CNS experience. Even if you do, it's nice exposure to other skills you might not have already developed.

This year DTV was optional, but in the end the vast majority of us took it because it let us maintain have one part of the EC fall designed uniquely for the MS/MBAs (both academically and socially). That alone makes the course worthwhile. Tom and Rob are very open to feedback and have a clear interest in making the course valuable to the cohort, so it is worth making time to connect with them outside of class and share your learning goals. The MS part of the class needs to be reworked, and I suspect they'll act on the feedback. Otherwise it is very easy, in line with a typical HBS class with case readings and some exercises. The final project is a cool opportunity to partner with a startup, but could be integrated into the class a bit more consistently.Overall, all MS/MBAs should take it since it's a great opportunity to get time with and learn from your MS/MBA peers like you did in DTP, EDIM, and TVI.
subject: Engineering Sciences

subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Nano Micro Macro: Adaptive Material Laboratory 001
best_comment: I love the vision of this course–– uniting engineers and designers to make better materials at every length scale. While the vision of this course is inspiring, for engineers (especially graduate students) it isn't super rigorous. This is partially due to the mixed students in the class–– design students will not be able to keep up with graduate level engineering and engineers are limited in design. In all honesty, I am not sure how this will be solved in the future, but I would love to see this course succeed. I do not think the night–time demo sessions were necessary or helpful. Instructors are absolutely passionate and want you to succeed. I think Jonathan and Joanna put their hearts into this class and I can't wait to see how it continues to grow. I would recommend it, but more as a fun class where you are learning about productization.

course_title: Nano Micro Macro: Adaptive Material Laboratory 001
best_comment: I love the vision of this course–– uniting engineers and designers to make better materials at every length scale. While the vision of this course is inspiring, for engineers (especially graduate students) it isn't super rigorous. This is partially due to the mixed students in the class–– design students will not be able to keep up with graduate level engineering and engineers are limited in design. I would recommend it, but more as a fun class where you are learning about productization.

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: This course was EXTREMELY helpful for me this semester while I was working on a scientific paper. I found that the structure and content of the course was very applicable to my writing, and I was able to make enormous progress on my writing over the course of the semester. I am very grateful for the feedback and insight Suzanne provided, as well as for the peer–review part of the course. It is most helpful if you are working on some sort of writing over the course of the semester. The coursework was not difficult but since most of the assignments are related to a final deliverable of a paper/statement/proposal it is a situation where you entirely get out what you put it. I think this course would be very helpful for any scientist who wants to communicate effectively or who wants to lessen the intimidation of writing some work up.I even found that the process of writing the paper as laid out in the course was helpful for me to plan future research efforts and streamline my day–to–day work as a graduate student.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2024: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers

best_comment: Fantastic experience! If you're interested in writing about art in any form, this is the course for you. Maggie was fantastic, the syllabus was very well structured, the workload was manageable, and the readings were super interesting. I grew a lot as a writer from this course.
worse_comment: I would recommend students to keep an open mind about their final longform criticism, since what I ended up with was not what I thought I was going to write when I entered the class.
subject: English

best_comment: It's a great course and I loved the pieces we read and the discussions we had. Professor Yoon is super friendly and passionate about what he does, but first and foremost he is so enthusiastic about his students and writing in general, which really just made me excited for class each week. I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to receive feedback on their pieces, and also find a really fantastic and safe environment for their ideas and questions.

well this is a workshop and if you take it you should like writing poems. if this is the kind of thing you enjoy taking seriously, you will love it. personally it was probably my favorite class this semester.
subject: English

best_comment: Prof Smith is so inspiring as a discussion leader and will completely shape your thoughts on what poetry is, how it works, why it's important. She speaks so beautifully about poetry, and the class is worth it just to hear from her and be in dialogue with her. The syllabus is wonderful too. Having a pre–existing creative practice in another medium might enrich your experience in the class, particularly for assignments which encourage you to break form, but it's not necessary.

This is an amazing course! Working with Tracy Smith is an absolute honor–––her breadth of knowledge and experience alone is invaluable. Her feedback is always thorough and thoughtful, and her syllabus is full of other incredible poets. Beyond that, she is truly an incredible and kind human being. Since so much of the course is peer–focused, the experience will of course vary depending on the makeup of the class, but you can expect your peers will impact you for the better! Each of my classmates brought something really unique to the table and my view of poetry and art/writing has been changed forever. Definitely worth applying for!!

There was a discussion at the beginning of this course on the ethics of autofiction. Of course, we were talking about our writing, but we were really doing much more than that, addressing a profound ethical issue with which many of us were about to be confronted. I came away from our discussion with a better understanding of myself, my peers, and the literary landscape we inhabit together. Professor McCarthy handled the discussion brilliantly, making it clear that we were free to submit whatever we wanted to him while still hearing our arguments for and against writing about the self in a collegiate setting. This is unlike any other creative writing seminar at this college in terms of the amazing feedback you will get, the wonderful community you will create, and the writing you will eventually produce.

course_title: Fiction Workshop: The Art of the Short Story 001
best_comment: If you are interested in starting your creative writing journey, this is a great class to take. The professor is very flexible and understanding, the assignments are not too overwhelming, and you can enjoy and express yourself. Your assignments are effort–based, and the feedback can really help you develop your style. Definitely recommend for beginners.
subject: English
course_title_2024: Fiction Workshop: The Art of the Short Story

course_title: Interiority & Experience: Writing Character-Driven Fiction: Workshop 001
best_comment: Claire is amazing! She is such a sweetheart who brings snacks to every workshop and gives little kernels of life advice throughout. More importantly for your benefit, she is an amazing writer who gives incredibly detailed feedback. I've taken workshops before at Harvard, but was blown away at the amount of thought that Claire puts into her feedback — she will push you so much as a writer. If you get into any workshop of hers, you will not regret taking it! With all creative writing workshops, you get what you put in, so make sure that you have enough time in your schedule to put time into writing and workshopping other people's pieces in order for maximum impact.

course_title: Genre Fiction Workshop: Sci-Fi, Speculative Fiction, Horror, The Ghost Story, The New Weird 001
best_comment: Take this seminar if you're interested in science fiction/magical realism/any exploration of the un–real!! You will read really cool texts and produce your own. Neel is great and class was always a great time.
Take this course if you can! It's a laid back atmosphere, but the poets who come are serious about their craft and committed to growing together. Really a bright spot in a courseload.
subject: English

course_title: Getting the Words Right: The Art of Revision 001
best_comment: This course was fantastic. Writing workshops aren't always offered again, but I really hope that this one is. The course is well–structured and organized, the readings are useful without feeling overwhelming, and the two rounds of revision with feedback are super helpful. The first third of the course (before workshops start) has a very light workload. Reading your classmates' work/writing critique letters and doing revision exercises on your own work makes up most of the time spent on this class. Once workshops start, be prepared to spend some real time and energy. There's some flexibility with deadlines for everything except your own workshop if you need it.

CLLW is amazing!! Take the class if you can!! I learned so much: reading about lives, writing about lives, and just enjoying reading and writing as a craft. Louisa is great at facilitating discussions, and she is always so supportive with student writing. Class itself is really chill but also so informative. Every week, we read one or two articles along with two workshop drafts, and we have an open discussion about the works. It has just been truly amazing to see how much I, along with the rest of my classmates, have grown as readers and writers throughout the course of the semester. I cannot emphasize how much I love this course and Louisa, I have truly become a better reader and writer through CLLW.
subject: English

best_comment: i really really loved this class. musa is such a great professor and the class was a wonderful introduction into screenwriting as someone who hasn't formally studied and worked in the field
subject: English

best_comment: Melissa is so kind, funny, and thoughtful. The feedback that she provides is insightful and encouraging. Apply if you can! You only need enthusiasm and a willingness to participate. An encouraging (and stellar) class community also made this SUCH an enjoyable course. We read Melissa Febos' Body Work, Hanif Abdurraqib's They Can't Kill Us Until They Kill Us, among others. It was great. I think I learned more from reading & giving feedback to peers' writing, which was more than half of the course time–wise. I learned about strategies to employ to craft a moving piece: jumps in time, what it looks like to weave introspection with narrative, different writing styles. I loved that this course gave me the permission to think about writing and write freely in an unstructured way. I had a really lovely time, and would recommend the class to anyone who is interested.

I loved this class! It was an amazing experience to read these pieces every week and then practice writing through the weekly assignments. In the workshopping section of the course, it was super fun to read and work alongside the class as we were helping each other on our pieces. This class definitely instilled in me a love for writing, and it's allowed me to take on a new confidence when I write. If you're at all interested in reading/writing nonfiction, I would definitely recommend.

TAKE. THIS. COURSE. I know you read that under every Q guide for a class that isn't awful, but I mean it so so genuinely –– this is definitely one of the most impactful experiences I've had at Harvard. I love reading/literature, and I had absolutely zero experience with creative writing before this course, but you don't need any. There was a decent mix of STEM/humanities people in the class, so don't think that you can't take it because you're an outsider to the English department or whatever. Paul is an incredible writer and thoughtful teacher, and you get to read these amazing and genuinely fascinating stories that are somehow written by your peers??? It's the kind of course where you can put in the amount of effort that you want to, but putting in more work/time will obviously make you get the most out of the class. All you have to do is read two of your classmates stories every week (which is such a nice change of pace if you're used to doing psets every night) and write a peer critique letter to them, and then write your story for your week. And you leave the semester with a completed short story of your very own, which is a cool achievement! TAKE A WRITING WORKSHOP WHILE YOU HAVE THE CHANCE –– you won't regret it!
subject: English

course_title: The Surrounds: Writing Interiority and Outsiderness 001
best_comment: This class is one of the three best classes I've taken at Harvard, and any course with Rachel will be a privilege. Under Rachel's support and her ability to stretch her students' minds and encourage us to reimagine the world and the place we all hold in it, I learned so much more about myself and produced such rich writing that reflected the beauty of the intellectual journey this course takes you through. I've come out of this class with such a stronger sense of myself and my passions in this world –– I cannot say enough good things about this course or Rachel!

course_title: Art of Listening. The Politics and Aesthetics of Sound 001
best_comment: The premise of this class is tough to explain, but just trust it. Valeria is a wonderful professor, and the course is interdisciplinary in the best way: we read academic articles, essays, fiction, and poetry from all over the world, listened to audio, watched documentaries, and thought about sound from all kinds of different perspectives. The atmosphere of the class was friendly and collaborative, and it drew a fascinating group of students from around the university. If you're interested in a course that will stretch your mind in addition to giving you the chance to express yourself creatively, this is a great choice.

i liked this course! it can be a bit disorganized at times, but the stuff we read is really fun, the assignments are pretty cool (most of them are creative), the course staff is really kind, and lectures are still really wonderful to listen to. it does get pretty theory–heavy, which, in the beginning, was kinda cool, but it eventually didn't feel super applicable. i think it would have been nice to change things up and do close readings every once in awhile rather than strictly focusing on theory, but oh well. still a good course! and required for english concentrators. lol.
worse_comment: If you want to take an English class where you really delve into and discuss the texts, this isn't the class for you. It's mostly just a lecture where the professors tell you how they interpreted the book, and then you move on. That's not to say that their insight isn't interesting, but it can be a bit boring to sit there week after week.
subject: English

best_comment: i liked this course! it can be a bit disorganized at times, but the stuff we read is really fun, the assignments are pretty cool (most of them are creative), the course staff is really kind, and lectures are still really wonderful to listen to. it does get pretty theory–heavy, which, in the beginning, was kinda cool, but it eventually didn't feel super applicable. i think it would have been nice to change things up and do close readings every once in awhile rather than strictly focusing on theory, but oh well. still a good course! and required for english concentrators. lol.
worse_comment: If you want to take an English class where you really delve into and discuss the texts, this isn't the class for you. It's mostly just a lecture where the professors tell you how they interpreted the book, and then you move on. That's not to say that their insight isn't interesting, but it can be a bit boring to sit there week after week.
subject: English

best_comment: this class is AWESOME. stephanie is the best. eunice (the teaching fellow) is so wonderful. the people are SUPER COOL. the material is really fun to read (for the most part). i read reviews for this course from recent years about how some people found it difficult to take a class with stephanie since then discussion is all over the place, and i can see that, but i think that's because stephanie is the smartest person probably ever, and so though it might feel a bit all over the place, the connections are all there and really fun to tease apart. if given the chance, i would not stop talking about how amazing stephanie and eunice are. please take this course.
worse_comment: English 20 is a core class for any concentrators/secondary pursuers, so you just have to take it if you're one of those two. It however is a class that is very much varied and dependent on the professor teaching it. In this iteration, Stephanie is a great professor and is obviously very knowledgeable about the content. However, class can be a little disorganized due to her teaching style, which works for some people but personally did not work the best for me. She is also a very prominent professor of poetry, so a lot of the course was centered around poetry. Again, didn't work the best for me because I'm not the biggest fan of poetry, but it was still a good time nonetheless. All in all, take the class if you need to and go into it with an open mind — you really do learn a lot.
subject: English

best_comment: I took this class as a senior CS student and loved it. I'm someone who loves to read (but doesn't always make time for it) and this class forces you to read something each week. The weekly discussion posts allow you to think a little more deeply about the text if you're not a talker. The assignments besides those are quite manageable: 2 essays, an imitation assignment (where you write two poems on the same subject in different forms and reflect on it) and an in class final. The in class final was honestly really fun as weird as that is to say. The time crunch forces you to run with whatever ideas pop into your head first and ~1.5 hrs later you've written 3 full essays. As someone who hasn't always been convinced by substantiating claims about literature with super close reading (e.g., the alliteration here conveys the overwhelming sadness of the author, or the consonance here proves blah), this class helped convince me otherwise.Downsides are its a decent amount of reading with a particular focus on the kind of British classical corpus (jane austen, medieval poems, beowulf), so you're getting what feels like a lot of a certain type of literature. Also, the class is broken down into lecture and subsequent discussion, and occasionally professor watson's lectures take up the vast majority of class, leaving you either to check out or no time to discuss things that excite you. His slides are occasionally very hard to read.
worse_comment: I found the selection of texts seemed a little random. Also the focus of the course just did not sit right with me. It was supposedly on forms but then it was unclear in lecture etc how exactly that was tied in and that gave it an unfocused feel. I also felt the class was badly run. it was not clear what weeks we had a discussion post and what weeks we did not which made me do a lot more work than I needed to.  Would not recommend unless you have to take it.
subject: English

best_comment: Just an amazing course. I took it as an English elective, and I never knew I was interested in theater—I couldn't even really name an "Asian–American play" before this class—but it introduced me to so many great works, and I truly looked forward to class every week. The weekly discussions on Canvas were always so interesting already, and continuing them in person with Ju Yon's lecture to guide us really forced me to think deeply about art and identity. She's an amazing professor, she was always happy to meet and discuss, and she gave such helpful feedback on all the assignments. You get such a great mix of students of different backgrounds, both culturally and artistically speaking. It was so fun to step out of my comfort zone and act and dance alongside such talented people during scene presentations—and you couldn't have caught me dead participating in any sort of performance before this class. Take it!

course_title: The Rhetoric of Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. TAKE PROFESSOR STAUFFER. DO NOT MISS THIS OPPORTUNITY. Professor Stauffer is such an amazing and accomplished man, and this topic is so damn interesting. You will gain an appreciation of two of America's most talented orators while having fun with the openness of all of the writing assignments. DO THE READING EVERY WEEK. You of course won't be penalized in any way if you don't, but do it because the speeches are so good and have so much to teach you. Also class is more interesting when you do the readings. This was my first non–Expos/non–Gen–Ed writing class at Harvard (I'm a Chem/Math concentrator with Music secondary) and now I want to take more in the English dept. I was not disappointed.
worse_comment: Take this! Professor Stauffer is incredibly knowledgeable and passionate about the civil war, and teaches the material exceptionally.
subject: English
course_title_2024: The Rhetoric of Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln

course_title: Indigenous Sci Fi, Horror, Fantasy, and Futurisms 001
best_comment: If this course is offered next year, take it!! The assignments are very chill and the readings are fantastic. I learned a lot about Indigenous literature, which I hadn't experienced much of before. Professor Pexa is super knowledgeable, encouraging, enthusiastic, and always open to meeting with students.
worse_comment: If you don’t have any experience with Indigenous literature and/or history, take this class. If you do, take this class. This class is vital to a complete and deep education as a citizen and as a Harvard student who will, by nature of attending this elite institution, amass power. If we do not discuss Indigenous Futurisms and their literatures, our society will become the very thing they warn us against. Your education is incomplete if you do not take a class like this one.

best_comment: If you are interested in Shakespeare and theater productions of Shakespeare, you should take the course. You will meet the 5 or so people at Harvard that are HUGE Shakespeare fans. Be prepared for lots of reading, but it will be fine if you're into Shakespeare.Professor Whittington is a fantastic teacher with lots of insight into Shakespeare. It will definitely help you understand art in general better if you put in the work.
worse_comment: This is an engaging, rigorous, demanding course that will make you experience the full range of Shakespearean emotions. See Othello act one scene three line 160

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS TAKE THIS CLASS TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!! One of the best classes I've taken at Harvard (as a senior STEM concentrator essay–hater). Professor Miller is so special –– it was a privilege to be able to learn from him this semester. I loved the entire structure of the course. It was designed so thoughtfully and intentionally. It was wonderful to read plays and be able to talk/write about them, while also discussing the meta–question about how lists of plays are created in the first place. Assignments were the perfect (and rare!) balance of not being stressful while actually helping me learn and push my understanding further –– they were honestly fun to do and I got a lot out of them. I'm not an English concentrator, and was worried about taking an English class, and Professor Miller does an amazing job of focusing on the content of what we say, without expecting us to conform to specific departmental norms. Professor Miller's feedback is so kind and specific –– he would leave overall comments in addition to over a dozen in–line comments on detailed points. When reading his feedback, I could tell that he was actually reading my work and thinking about it –– I felt encouraged and also pushed to improve. I've rarely received feedback like this in college classes. I looked forward to class every week and am really sad that it's over. An amazing experience.

course_title: Metaphysical Poetry: The Seventeenth-Century Lyric and Beyond 001
best_comment: Super interesting class with a super low workload. Professor Teskey is great, and you can tell he's genuinely very knowledgable and very passionate about the subject he's teaching. The whole class is participation and completion–based except for the final project/paper which really isn't too bad if you know what you want to do it on early on. I had a great time in this class, as someone who's usually in STEM classes, and would definitely recommend it.
subject: English
course_title_2024: Metaphysical Poetry: The Seventeenth-Century Lyric and Beyond

course_title: Race in the Age of Artificial Intelligence 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Great prof, great syllabus, actually fun and interesting assignments + really good feedback. I literally never leave course feedback but I'm doing the people a favor here. If you feel like you haven't written a paper since high school and don't want to take an English class with a bunch of people who write them all the time, don't worry because the lit kids are going to be in the same boat as you in this class–the syllabus is super unusual for Harvard's English department with a huge range of mixed media (graphic novels, movies, music videos, websites, art installations, short stories, magazine articles) and the assignments are way more accessible/unusual/open–ended for English:  one close reading paper, which you rewrite with AI and examine the differences; one creative writing assignment (imagine waking up in hundred years–what does AI look like in this world? the best one in my opinion) and then illustrate your story with image generation AI and then examine how the AI interpreted your story; final project is either traditional research paper about AI and social justice issues or designing an AI prototype in pretty much any form (almost everyone did the second one). Professor Dikcis is so good. I loved this class, it was honestly the highlight of my semester. Even for classes I really like the readings can be such a drag sometimes but because every week there were so many different media forms, this class provided such a nice break from endless reading.

I have very mixed feelings about this course. On the one hand, the syllabus is very well crafted and the whole notion of "reading politically" is one that has interested me for a while. Many of our discussions in class were fascinating and probing. And the class was just a lot of fun, partially a result of having a lot of great students in the seminar.However, the course suffered from two main issues in my year:(1) We didn't get any grades back until the last day of class. This is partially a function of there just not being many assignments, but likely this can be rectified in the future.(2) More importantly though, while Professor Menon is awesome, super cool and smart, I don't think she's amazing at facilitating discussion. In nearly every class, significant proportion of discussion would come down to us discussing her opinions on the secondary sources / novels. In some cases, this was fine because it felt like there was some back–and–forth. But in some situations it felt she was sort of forcing her own perspective onto the class. I don't have a problem with professors expressing their views per se, but I think in certain cases here it came at the detriment to open, productive discussion. This is all to say that I think this class should just be taught as a lecture where Prof. Menon delivers arguments on the text. You could either do that where you spend the first 45 mins of seminar with her giving the argument and the rest in discussion, or just as a full–blown lecture class. That version of the course would be fantastic, I think, because Prof. Menon has clearly thought deeply about all of these issues and she could give the full version of these arguments instead of haphazardly presenting them in seminar. So if it's taught as a lecture, I'd definitely take it. If a seminar, it's still a really interesting class with good readings but it might prove a bit frustrating.
worse_comment: Take this class if you want to tackle hard questions and use literature as a portal into understanding how information and media is consumed today–it is a class so painfully relevant to the world today. It will alter the way you read and watch everything because you will understand that there is no thing apolitical in this world.
best_gem_comment: Professor Menon is one of the best faculty members at Harvard, a true gem: she is funny and thoughtful, kind and intelligent, assertive and enthusiastic. You cannot go wrong by taking a class taught by Professor Menon. She is an expert on the 19th century British novel, and she is adept at making any student, irrespective of major, enthusiastic about the subject matter.

best_comment: This was hands down my favorite class of all time. If you love medieval literature, discussing fascinating ideas with interesting people, and perhaps learning a bit of Old English, this is the class for you! Professor Donoghue is a classic academic and truly delightful to talk to. The readings are dense, difficult, and WONDERFUL. I never would have found many of these books on my own. It's a difficult class with a lot of readings, but it will be worth it. HIGHLY recommend.
worse_comment: Unless this class has changed considerably, the fact of the matter is that you should not take it if you are looking for something about Tolkien. If JRR Tolkien is the primary reason you want to take this course, it's not for you. He's not involved. Other than that, there is a bit of a Hum 10 vibe with a book, or several readings, a week. Professor Donoghue is really sweet. I learned a lot, but my primary goal of nerding about Tolkien was frustrated entirely by the complete lack of Tolkien in the classroom.

best_comment: Whether you have knowledge of Sherlock Holmes or not, the stories are so fun and interesting to read. Anna Wilson is such an engaging lecturer and so incredibly smart that coming to class has been a joy every time. She even makes time for super fun activities like a romance novel paratext workshop, and has built in flexibility for attendance in the semester. My favorite class this semester; arguably the best sophomore tutorial!
subject: English

course_title: Literature, Science, and the Body in 18th-Century Britain 001
best_comment: This class was a lot of fun! It was my first time studying the 18th century, but I've been persuaded it's a really interesting period. I was honestly a bit apprehensive at first, but thinking about science, in general, turns out to shed some very interesting light on how artists were thinking about how/what they were creating. The assignments were very flexible and fair. Reading could be a lot at times (looking at you Roderick Random) but for the most part, it was pretty enjoyable.

Tara is an incredible lecturer. I usually actively avoid 9am classes and can never stay awake for them, but I never once felt tired coming to this class because the lectures were that fascinating and engaging. As a stem concentrator, this was my first english class and I could not recommend it more as an introduction to the english department / a way to integrate reading into your schedule in a fun way. There are no analytical papers, only creative assignments, which definitely made the class more approachable for people who don't typically write a ton. Some weeks have really heavy reading, and you can definitely get away without reading everything in the course. However, the texts are very thoughtfully chosen and I felt like I got a lot out of doing the readings! Also we were assigned films during some weeks, which I found to be really fun to watch and good breaks throughout the semester. Sections were also fun and Lara facilitated great conversations and provided a ton of helpful resources & support on the 4 assignments. Highly, highly encourage anyone to take this!!
worse_comment: Take this course!! Even if you're not an English major. All the best parts of studying English (getting lost in novels, analyzing films, discovering new criticism and critical lenses) are on display here.

best_comment: If you are thinking of taking this class, you should absolutely take it! Prof Dimick is incredible –– she is so kind, supportive, and a great teacher. Her lectures are always interesting and engaging, and she is constantly open to student feedback. The readings of this course are great –– even if you don't love every single one, the conversations about the readings will make it worthwhile. The class environment is also very supporting and welcoming, which just makes the class even better. At a school where there aren't very many environmental humanities classes, this course is a gift. I wish I could take it again.

course_title: Thinking Through Writing: Science Themes | 2023: The Time Things Take 001
best_comment: I recommend this course with the highest enthusiasm! This has been my favorite course I have taken at Harvard (I am a senior). I have wanted to take a course about writing about science and this course was everything I hoped it would be, and so much more. Prof. Messud and Prof. Franklin's lectures are incredible; I learned so much from both of them and I appreciated their complementary approaches. I also really enjoyed the guest lectures they arranged for the course: it was so cool to hear from the authors whose work we were reading! I learned a lot from the course readings and appreciated the variety of styles we encountered. The course readings are also really fun and engaging; we read poetry, fiction, essays, science journalism, history of science articles, and much more. I also really appreciated the teaching staff who were very knowledgable, helpful, and dedicated. I regularly attended the professors' office hours as well as the teaching fellows' office hours and I found these sessions to be extremely helpful. I learned so much about how to creatively communicate about science and how to use forms of creative writing to think through scientific ideas and develop my understanding of these. If you are interested in science, creative writing, and/or how these connect take this amazing class!
worse_comment: It's too bad because the concept for this class is so cool, but the execution was just not it. The lectures were very disjointed and disorganized, and the two professors often seemed to be in conflict with each other to the point where it was uncomfortable to be in class. Melissa (the physics professor) also seemed to be disinterested in, or have disdain for, both literature and the students in the class. There was a weird assumption that kept being brought up throughout the course by both professors that English concentrators don't understand anything about physics or vice versa, which I think 1) goes against the purpose of the class and 2) made me a bit annoyed as an English concentrator who hasn't taken a physics class since tenth grade and yet understood the vast majority of the physics concepts that were being introduced in this class. The readings were also heavily white and male, way more than I would have expected from any class taught in 2023? Unless the course improves, I wouldn't recommend it.
subject: English

course_title: Thinking Through Writing: Science Themes | 2023: The Time Things Take 001
best_comment: I recommend this course with the highest enthusiasm! This has been my favorite course I have taken at Harvard (I am a senior). I have wanted to take a course about writing about science and this course was everything I hoped it would be, and so much more. Prof. Messud and Prof. Franklin's lectures are incredible; I learned so much from both of them and I appreciated their complementary approaches. I also really enjoyed the guest lectures they arranged for the course: it was so cool to hear from the authors whose work we were reading! I learned a lot from the course readings and appreciated the variety of styles we encountered. The course readings are also really fun and engaging; we read poetry, fiction, essays, science journalism, history of science articles, and much more. I also really appreciated the teaching staff who were very knowledgable, helpful, and dedicated. I regularly attended the professors' office hours as well as the teaching fellows' office hours and I found these sessions to be extremely helpful. I learned so much about how to creatively communicate about science and how to use forms of creative writing to think through scientific ideas and develop my understanding of these. If you are interested in science, creative writing, and/or how these connect take this amazing class!
worse_comment: It's too bad because the concept for this class is so cool, but the execution was just not it. The lectures were very disjointed and disorganized, and the two professors often seemed to be in conflict with each other to the point where it was uncomfortable to be in class. Melissa (the physics professor) also seemed to be disinterested in, or have disdain for, both literature and the students in the class. There was a weird assumption that kept being brought up throughout the course by both professors that English concentrators don't understand anything about physics or vice versa, which I think 1) goes against the purpose of the class and 2) made me a bit annoyed as an English concentrator who hasn't taken a physics class since tenth grade and yet understood the vast majority of the physics concepts that were being introduced in this class. The readings were also heavily white and male, way more than I would have expected from any class taught in 2023? Unless the course improves, I wouldn't recommend it.
subject: English

best_comment: This class is such a needed treasure within the English department — its syllabus covers works diverse in time, place, topic, and style, and it was a pleasure to dive into each one with Professor Rich’s guidance. She’s wonderfully encouraging of our ideas, challenged us to think critically, and was also just so kind! I highly recommend doing the readings, since I was so inspired by the prose and the themes we covered. I’ve definitely found some new favorite reads in this course, and the papers also allowed me to deepen my excitement and understanding of elements of the text!
Do the readings and do them with care! They are genuinely interesting, and this is the only way you'll get much out of this seminar
subject: English

best_comment: Lectures were fantastic and really well done, and assignments were great as well! Honestly a really interesting class and liked Prof Wilson––would recommend taking. One thing that frustrated me was grading of assignments (and the sections themselves) felt pretty openly political at times (I say this as someone with generally the same political leanings, but it was quite extreme), so worth thinking about. But overall, I thought that class was designed well, feedback was given on assignments promptly, the professor was super accessible outside of class time, and it's a good choice as an elective.
worse_comment: thought the class would be a gem, it's a decent class just not a complete gem. grading can be a bit harsh and sometimes it feels random  (I didn't score well on the assignment that I put in a lot effort but did well on those that I hardly tried) (there's no rubric or set expectations so grades can be a bit of a gamble)
best_gem_comment: i really enjoyed this class and prof wilson is such a gem! she is so kind and helpful during office hours. we got to watch 10 things I Hate About You and Arrival, among other films. The course content is interesting and the discussions are engaging. Would recommend for anyone who is interested in taking an English class with no background in English courses!
subject: English

best_comment: This is a great class! The syllabus is fantastic, and covers some of the greatest hits of Renaissance literature. Stephen and Joseph are fantastic teachers: eager to help graduate students work across disciplinary boundaries and keen to think with the entire class about what counts as an "ego–document." I'd highly recommend this seminar.

This is a great class! The syllabus is fantastic, and covers some of the greatest hits of Renaissance literature. Stephen and Joseph are fantastic teachers: eager to help graduate students work across disciplinary boundaries and keen to think with the entire class about what counts as an "ego–document." I'd highly recommend this seminar.

course_title: Sensation and Moral Action in Thomas Hardy 001
best_comment: – This class takes you on a tour of all of Hardy's major works which is an incredible, once–in–a–lifetime experience. If you're not ready for such a journey, then it's perhaps best to be realistic because most weeks you really are trying to finish a 350+ page novel, but if you do have the time, you will find the class more than worth it. Also, the readings are novels, good novels, so it's not like reading through Kant's Pure Reason (as good as that is).– You would be greatly remiss to pass over a chance to study under Professor Scarry; I can not write enough good things in her praise. Everything she says is so articulate and insightful and intelligent and relevant that I'm often in disbelief that what's she's saying is extemporaneous. She pulls from a wealth of knowledge from history and philosophy and of course literature, having read, it seems, every great book in the english language. Most importantly, she is kind, and very willing to meet outside of class. I am really sad that this class is over, which is probably the best testament I can give to the seminar's worth.
If you have ideas you think are valuable, and worth sharing with the public, this course will be a very helpful guide in how to get them out there and get people to pay attention to them.
worse_comment: It won't feel much like a "workshop"; I'd say it's more akin to a speaker series.

course_title: The Fluid Earth: Oceans, Atmosphere, Climate, and Environment 001
best_comment: This class is made solely by your TF; if you have a good TF you will have a great experience, but if you do not have a good TF you will probably not find this class very rewarding.
worse_comment: Overall the course – specifically the psets and midterms – was more difficult than expected

course_title: Data Analysis and Statistical Inference in the Earth and Environmental Sciences 001
best_comment: This class is hands down one of the best classes that I have taken at Harvard. I am very interested in Environmental Science and Data Science so this class was a perfect mix of the two. I learned so so many useful tools for statistical inference that I will continue to use in my lab's research, future class projects, and all other data analysis that I do in the future. Roger is so so nice and really loves the topics covered in class. The class is full of environmental and stats kids which is a great, welcoming combo. I would 100% recommend this class to anyone for the tools that it gives you to analyze any kind of data to understand the world around you. Very applied and useful. I have coded a lot before this class which was very very helpful in the psets, BCAs, and projects. I would recommend that you come into this class with some coding background to get the most out of it. If not, be prepared to learn a lot about coding and put in the time to do so. You will have a lot of help from friends and the TFs.
worse_comment: Low stress intro class to statistics. Only 3 psets and midterm and final are group projects. Content can get difficult though and not a lot of resources outside of lecture to help you. Not knowing coding in python will hurt you.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering
course_title_2024: Data Analysis and Statistical Inference in the Earth and Environmental Sciences

course_title: Ecosystem Patterns and Processes: Parallels in Natural and Built Environments 001
best_comment: Honestly, this class was great and I would highly recommend taking it.  The content is interesting and incredibly broad in its scope – even if it doesn't have the time to go extremely deep into certain more tangential areas as a result, there is truly something for everyone to gain here regardless of if you're more policy–focused, engineering–focused, or somewhere in between (e.g., don't take this course expecting to become an expert on fluid dynamics or hydrology or public policy or anything, but you will be very well–versed on the core cycles/flows/processes underpinning the natural world by the time you're done; take this course to gain a strong fundamental sense of how the environment works overall and how to approach and model the science/cause–and–effect relationships of key issues).  Labs are particularly fun (and you'll get to use some awesome equipment along the way, expect to look forward to this for sure!), and Prof. Yoon does a great job lecturing and putting together the HW.  The workload isn't too bad either, provided you start early on those lab reports.

course_title: Space Science and Engineering: Theory and Applications 001
best_comment: Take this class! It's flipped classroom—if that's really not your vibe maybe avoid it—and they do it very well. The class time is group work, and the homework is online lectures. The material is super interesting, and Robin is an awesome professor that really generates enthusiasm for all of it.

The only context in which I would recommend this course is if you really want to learn environmental chemistry and you feel that this is the only way to accomplish that goal. Even then, I might advise you to find a different, more applied class and dive into it from that side of things. I found it to be a pretty dry and pretty frustrating class. I am the kind of student who likes to read a good textbook; the assigned textbook for this course stinks. (The majority of the class agreed on this point, though one previous student reportedly "loved it and read the whole thing"). You have to engage with the textbook in regular discussion posts. There's no lab component of the course, which is disappointing for a class on environmental chemistry. Lecture attendance is mandatory; lectures alternated between boring and confusing.A large portion of class energy and time is spent on student presentations, which are generally more interesting and informative than the lectures themselves. Still, student presentations are variable in quality and subject as they are on "topics from the textbook;" i.e. whatever that student decided they wanted to focus on for 5 minutes. I prefer not to have the most interesting part of the course feel up to chance and the good knowledge of my peers. There is little to no feedback on student presentations throughout the semester.The final semester project was meh. It was a group project and the groups were too large, so the typical mess of scheduling and priority conflict led to less–than–effective collaboration and less–than–equitable distribution of work. There's a final presentation as well as a final report; the report is 20+ pages (with figures), 1.2 space font. Who assigns 1.2 space font? The assignment was to take an element and relate it to environmental chemistry. Pretty open prompt. Not a lot of helpful feedback in professor consultation sessions or on our presentation. As you might expect, the project had variable outcomes of questionable quality.The best part about the course was the section, which always shed light on the confounding lecture material and provided examples relevant to the homework. Sadly, the TF that taught it this semester will not be doing so in the future, so all bets are off.The course feels like it's being taught 20 years ago. I suspect the professor of believing that the world and students have changed too much in recent decades and that students should learn the good old–fashioned way with a textbook and lectures.I think I learned some environmental chemistry concepts that will apply to my future concentration and studies. I wish I could've learned them in a different class. Take a class with a lab or with more engaging material even if it's more time–consuming; save yourself the headache.
worse_comment: Take this class. It is low stress, well organized, a nice small environment, and you learn a lot about the subject matter. Weekly pset thats pretty low stress and short question pertaining to the reading before every class.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN!!! By far the most fun class I've taken at Harvard (Elsie told us on the first day that her teaching philosophy centers around fun).  This class gave me a really thorough sense of what it is like to conduct scientific research in this field. I absolutely loved how this course was structured to give students an opportunity to learn about how to come up with a research project, how to conduct field work, how to conduct lab work, how to analyze data, and how to give a scientific presentation. I felt like I really got a sense of what doing research was like and it was super fun! Although this class is super chill and doesn't have a lot of work, I still got so much out of it.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering
course_title_2024: Field and Lab-Based Seminar on Local Pollution Issues

best_comment: Wow. This class is fabulous. I feel like it has given me the language to express a lot of criticisms of "tech fixes" of climate change — and the frameworks to more rigorously analyze them in. It's not an easy course conceptually and is unlike anything else I've taken, but it has been a really enriching experience and I would recommend it to anyone! Not quite to like hte "this changed my life experience and the way I view myself and others" but like the closest I've gotten to that point in recent history. Fantastic. And Prof. Jasanoff is quite the figure –– one of the smartest professors I have ever had, and with iconic stories too boot.
worse_comment: I really dreaded attending these classes. Professor Jasanoff lectures continuously, often straying from course materials into little mini stories or rants. The course theories and lenses just aren’t very compelling or necessary, i thought, even after the full semester; I don’t need a field of study to tell me that technology is informed by politics. Overall the course was pretty boring. I am surprised that taking a course with Prof. Jasanoff is an ESPP requirement. I do not feel like this course will help me as an ESPP concentrator.

course_title: The Law and Policy of Climate Change: Influencing Decision Makers 001
best_comment: This class is a lot of work, but it is a rewarding experience. Being exposed to concepts of law and litigation as it pertains to climate change was incredibly intellectually stimulating. Learning about torts, takings, standing, and many other kinds of legal concepts was awesome and solidified my desire to go to law school. Even if that is not your intent, it may be helpful to know about the legal side of climate change.
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol
course_title_2024: The Law and Policy of Climate Change: Influencing Decision Makers

course_title: Addressing the Global Climate Crisis: Challenges for Both Developed and Developing Economies 001
best_comment: Take it! Prof Mcelroy is super nice and approachable and the topics covered are super timely and important. You don't need any background in economics or natural sciences, just be interested in the material.
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol
course_title_2024: Addressing the Global Climate Crisis: Challenges for Both Developed and Developing Economies

best_comment: This is a great course if you want to learn about what climate responsibilities of different people are. Professor Frumhoff is genuinely amazing, and  (at least while I was taking this course) the students tend to be engaged and excited as well, which makes it a great environment. The only issue is that, if you are new to this topic, and if you think you might have a hard time immediately contributing to the conversation, I must say that the participation grade is slightly harsh and not super understanding. Regardless, know they will be realistic and literal about how much you participate or how many times you speak. Other than acknowledging this, I truly recommend the course!  It was life–changing for me and made me realize I might want to consider a career path relating to environmental policy. Great class!
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol

course_title: Global Wetlands: Boundary-spanning ecosystems for science, social justice, and public policy 001
best_comment: This is a great class to take! If you're interested in wetlands or even water more broadly, Professor Matthes does a great job introducing you to wetlands and water policy more broadly. The readings are great and relatively chill, while the discussion is usually good and sparks interesting thoughts. The guest lectures were also interesting and provided a different perspective on water policy from people working in the field. Take this class!
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol
course_title_2024: Global Wetlands: Boundary-spanning ecosystems for science, social justice, and public policy

course_title: Power, Knowledge, Identity: Critical Approaches to Race and Ethnicity 001
best_comment: This is a great class! Professor Craig and Maya and awesome instructors who really care about students and are very responsive to feedback and to the classroom environment. This class moves at a different pace from other classes at Harvard, which some may find frustrating but can be really cool to lean into if you choose. All of the assignments were super interesting and intentional, as were the readings, and none of it was an overwhelming amount of work. Good theories and methods for Social Studies concentrators who are interested in race/Ethnic Studies, but know that you won't receive a handbook of exactly how to do x method for your thesis... you'll get a much more broad and critical understanding of methods!

course_title: Quechua, Indigenous language revitalization and Global Indigeneity 001
best_comment: Américo is a great professor with a passion for this topic. Being able to really engage with the content and broaden my understanding of Indigenous issues about not just Andean communities but efforts globally was a big takeaway of mine. The class isn’t too time consuming and is consistent on assignments and expectations. Make sure to participate (not just once a class, really communicate your thoughts); it matters so much more than you think. Use OH to your advantage as they really provide insight about how you can make the most of the class. I would’ve liked to learn more Quechua through the language–learning component, but I am more than satisfied with what we were able to practice

The course was incredibly engaging and thought–provoking. The way it delved into the subject of orientalism, especially in the context of technology and futurism, was both unique and enlightening. I really appreciated the educational environment of the course. It felt like a space where everyone's opinions and insights were valued, which made the learning experience even more meaningful.Professor Fernandez is a standout. His depth of knowledge in the subject is remarkable, and his ability to convey complex ideas in an understandable way is commendable.What stood out most was his supportiveness and active listening skills. He genuinely values student participation and makes sure everyone feels heard and respected in discussions. His dedication to fostering an engaging and inclusive classroom atmosphere really enhanced my learning experience.I'd highly recommend this course to any student interested in exploring the nuances of orientalism, especially through the lens of Asian literature and technology.It's not just about the content; it's about how the course makes you think critically and consider perspectives that you might not have encountered before. This course is a real eye–opener and a great addition to anyone's academic journey.
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights

course_title: Land, Labor, and the Color Line: New Perspectives on Black and Indigenous Histories 1
best_comment: Take this class!! Professor Izadi is intelligent, attentive, and passionate about the subject. You will learn so much, whether it is about Black history, Native history, or the discipline of history more broadly. Professor Izadi also does her best to make the course engaging, from taking us on Indigenous walking tours to seeing a movie in theatres to bringing in speakers. You will enjoy the readings, discussions, and new perspectives you are exposed to. You will also grow in your skills as a writer because of Professor Izadi's EXTREMELY extensive feedback (more feedback than I have ever received in a course, which I really really appreciated). It is very obvious how much Professor Izadi cares about the subject, the course, and her students, and this care makes this course so valuable.
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights
course_title_2024: Land, Labor, Legacies: New Perspectives on Black and Indigenous Histories

best_comment: THIS CLASS IS GREAT! Harvard doesn't have an Ethnic Studies department, but I've been on a mission to take interesting ethnic studies courses throughout my time here; EMR 159 certainly did not disappoint. Dr. Fernandez is engaging, generates so much enthusiasm for the subject matter, and is SO intelligent about Asian American studies, specifically Techno–orientalism, which is the main focus of their research. I loved how the class covered different medium, including film, television, food documentaries, music, contemporary media like YouTube, and literature. I liked that Dr. Fernandez paired a piece of "pop culture" with an academic text every class –– kept a good balance. I learned so much, and I'm looking forward to taking more of Dr. Fernandez's classes going forward.
best_gem_comment: Take this class! You will learn so much about the breadth of Asian American topics in pop culture today. Professor is super helpful and open to talk to students outside of class.  You will talk about important Asian American pop culture concepts with a critical and theoretical lens. This is definitely a gem.

course_title: Topics in Latinx Studies: Imagining Latinidad 001
best_comment: This course's readings are super interesting, and the spacing for the amount of readings each week is perfect. You have one discussion post a week based on those readings, and a chance to respond to two others after the first half of the week's class. The content is interesting, and for those just coming into college without having experienced college level reading and humanities/social science classes before, this is the perfect course. For those that have, this is also an amazing course that allows you to learn a lot without having to break your back over readings to do it. The readings vary from academic articles to works of literature,to videos, to music, to podcasts,  and that is one of the things I appreciated most about the course. If you need accommodations through the DAO or otherwise, it is worth noting that this is one of those courses where you do need to communicate extra diligently about getting those met. This class demands that you think about things ahead of time, and that you stay on top of what you need and communicating it with them more than once.
