worse_comment: It’s alright but be prepared to be confused with feedback
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights
course_title_2024: Topics in Latinx Studies: Introduction to Latinx Literature And Visual Arts

best_comment: Expos 10 is an excellent class that you definitely need to take if you do not have a strong writing background.  It's highly recommended if you aim to improve your writing skills. The structured support and feedback it offers are incredibly helpful for both beginners and those looking to enhance their writing abilities.
worse_comment: Take Expos Studio 10 if you don't think you're ready for college writing. I think for many people they don't realize how much improvement they still need, Expos 10 is the way to go if you: want a light course load for the first semester, come from a school that didn't fixate on writing, or don't know how to properly write! Expos 10 is for all students. Fr no cap!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expos 10 is a great course! I have never really enjoyed writing, but the way this course approaches it makes it very enjoyable and I was actually interested in what I was writing. Sections are very energetic, which helped me to participate more. Dr. Deli is an amazing preceptor!
worse_comment: Take this course if you are unsure or not confident in your writing skills
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you want to take expos10 this professor is a good one. However, this class  is unnecessary sometimes
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would recommend going into this course if you genuinely enjoy writing and are willing to spend the time to improve it. At times, Studio 10 may feel a bit tedious because of the abundant amount of assignments to do while you have other classes. I think that if you are a decent writer and plan to follow a STEM path, it may be best to enter into 20 to get this requirement out of the way.
worse_comment: Take this course if you want some extra time to develop your writing skills.  It's relatively slow paced, and you spend a long time diving into each topic/unit, allowing you to understand the full perspective and scope of arguments in the writing you analyze.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you're on the fence about taking studio 10 or expos 20, go with studio. At the very least, this class will build your confidence in writing. I am extremely happy with the decision I made. My preceptor, Dr. Hanes, was amazing. It was clear how much she cared about all of us. She was always available outside of class (mostly through Slack), and her feedback was extremely helpful. The smaller class size allows for you to grow closer with your instructor and fellow classmates.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I'm really glad I took this class. I was able to get a great foundation through this course and feel like I can conquer any essay for the next 3.5 years and forward!If you have any questions, make sure to ask/clarify with Ms. Heath. She won't mind and its better to ask than to do it wrong on the essay.
worse_comment: As someone without a strong writing background, I was worried about taking expos. However, you are provided with a lot of support and feedback, and many assignments are broken down into smaller steps. I enjoyed taking this course with Ms. Heath.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expo 10 is a good class, which allow you to practice your writing skills and learn new strategies. The exercises of the course allow you to practice often and get use to academic writing. I'm an international student, who attended a high school taught in another language and have never written long essays in English.  However, my background  was enough to succeed in this class. I improved throughout the course, consolidated and strengthen my skills. If you are in my situation, I recommend you consider taking expo 20. However, expo 10 allows you to practice more and prepare for expo 20.
worse_comment: Consider expos 20 too. It felt like the recommendations in the pre–college exams were a bit misleading, and the majority of this course does not teach specific essay writing until the final unit.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is great if you are feeling unsure or not too confident about your writing skills as you enter college. However, the course is paced slower, so it is easy to not become too engaged with it until the paper deadlines come up. Make use of office hours with the perceptor as they are very helpful when writing papers. Hannah is great with feedback during one–on–one conferences and does a good job of guiding the class along when it gets too quiet.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Although I was initially worried about having to take Expos Studio 10, I am very happy that I took the course. I never felt alone throughout the semester; I was allowed to explore my writing style while ensuring I learned to meet Harvard–specific writing expectations. Dr. Jehn is a wonderful professor!!! In each class, Dr. Jehn delivers clear passion and excitement. He gives great feedback and genuinely cares for each student.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Goes into detail on each assignment and takes it step by step, which minimizes stress. The slideshows are helpful and the professor is very engaged with students.  Jodi Johnson is very nice and gives good feedback on each draft that is submitted.
worse_comment: Don't take this class unless you genuinely struggle with writing. You will be fine in Expos 20.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I liked this class a lot although I didn't expect to like it as I took it just to fulfil my Expository Writing Requirement and practice my writing skills. The feedback I got in this class from my preceptor is so valuable and helpful. My preceptor was amazing! He required work, effort and participation, but gave even more in return.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: FYRE FGLI CERTIFIED: PICK JONAH JOHNSON AS YOUR PRECEPTOR!! HE IS HONESTLY THE BEST!! He makes students feel comfortable by providing them a safe space to be just be themselves. Students can decompress while also somehow having enough time to do all the taxing expos work. Expos can be exhausting so feel free to get the requirement over with, but I personally enjoyed my time in expos 10 because as someone who came from a rural town, I feel like expos 10 provided some of the foundational writing skills that I'll need to succeed. You will do a lot of writing in college so why not get the proper foundation to avoid trips to the writing center (WHICH IS A VALUABLE RESOURCE THAT YOU SHOULD ALSO USE BUT IT CAN GET CROWDED AROUND FINALS SEASON).
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Taleen is amazing!! She makes the class so interesting and engaging and she gives such good feedback! I really feel like I've learnt so much this semester thanks to her! CHOOSE TALEEN IF IT FITS WITH YOUR SCHEDULE
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I loved this course and I always looked forward to going to my classes. It doesn’t eat that much of your time and it definitely helped me build a strong base for my essays. If you are not confident in your writing, there are many very interesting aspects you’ll learn about here that will certainly improve your writing, analyzing skills and confidence overall. It’s the end of the term and I never once regretted enrolling in this class. Take what I say with a grain of salt though. Everyone’s experience depends a lot on the professor they have. Please please do your research, I know there are some professors out there that make expos 10 look like a non enjoyable class. Taleen is a gem of a professor and person. I recommend her full heartedly and I can say she is genuine in helping all of us have a rewarding experience. The feedback she gives is amazing and helpful, she brings up amazing points in class that left me speechless so many times. I say expos is what you make of it but to me it was one of my favorite classes with one of the best professors out there. 10/10 recommend.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I highly recommend enrolling in this course, especially for those who may feel apprehensive about a lack of writing ability upon admission. While you may not necessarily need it, the boost in confidence and valuable writing experience gained made the extra semester very much worthwhile.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expos 10 is great if you're not confident in your writing skills. It develops them from scratch, going more complex throughout the semester. There are a lot of exercises that helps you start, helps you move on when you feel stuck. Definitely recommend it for international students, independent of desired concentration.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I am very grateful that I took Expos 10 because it gave me the opportunity to significantly improve my writing skills and strengthen my foundation for writing for my future academic career.
worse_comment: Expos 10 is a more chill option to start with the writing requirment, that will allow you a less stressed first semester – especially if there isnt a specific Expos–20 that cauhgt your interst. Having said that, I had higer expectation regarding the depth of the course, I felt like most of the topics we covered were relatively basic and most of the class were familiar with them.I would say that for me the topics of unit 1 and unit 2 were not very engaging and this made me put more time and effort in the papers than I have expected to.TL;DR – if you are looking for a more low–workload course for whatever reason  – take 10 over 20.do keep in mind you will "pay it back" as you must take expos 20 too.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Definitely take this course before taking Expos 20. It helps you be more familiar with what type of essays the college is looking for and you become a better writer, ready to write any written assignments that is given to you. I guarantee you that you will do a lot better in Expos 20 if you take this course first. Also, taking Expos Studio 10 and then Expos 20 fulfills the 1 year of expository writing requirement for premeds.
worse_comment: Do all of the readings– it may be hard to participate in class, especially if you don’t understand (even when you do the readings) but J’d just ask about what you don’t understand to still participate.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you have a good understanding of how to write effectively this course might be easy for you. However, if you want to perfect basic skills this class is perfect.
worse_comment: Take it if you are unsure about your writing skills.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would tell students to take this course 100%, 10/10. This course is easy and growth in the class is very feasible as the feedback is timely, specific, good in substance, and not too nit–picky.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This a great class to take if you are unsure of your writing abilities.  It has a very manageable workload compared to other freshmen courses. If you are a pre–med, keep in mind that you need a full year of English, so I would highly recommend taking this class in the fall and EXPOS 20 in the spring to fulfill the one year of english requirement for med schools. This is the easier route than taking a higher level english course in the future.
worse_comment: Don’t take this class skip straight to expos 20. This will be one of the worst classes. Because expos is bad in general just tey to take expos 20 instead of taking to expos classes.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Great introduction to learn about academic and expository writing. If you are undecided between expos 10 and 20 consider your essay academic background before choosing. Prof. Vilbig is very engaging, always provides feedback. During  class he often presents alternate viewpoints to the course material which are from various fields – literature, phylosphy, etc.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Pat is an amazing professor and you should take expos with her! She is so engaged and positive and makes it fun to write and read, even if you don't typically like to do those things! She is not a harsh grader and really works with you to make you the best writer you can be! She is also very understanding and tries to be as flexible as she can be!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Great class for the mandatory Expos requirement! You learn quite a lot about how to write research papers which is definitely useful for the future, and since you have to take a class like this you might as well take one that gets you out and about for field trips, and also teaches you how to meditate!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: The class is great for fulfilling the expos requirement. It is on an interesting topic, there are several engaging out of classroom classes, and Professor Alqera is great about giving feedback. If you are interested take it!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class with Dr. B, not because it is easy, but because it will make you a better writer and prepare you to do well in other college courses. Dr. B is incredibly intelligent, funny, and kind. You will become a better writer when taking this course. Dr. B always provides tons of feedback on assignments and is always open to working with you to improve your writing or thought process. Dr. B also created a great classroom environment, and it was one of the classes I most looked forward to attending (even though it was at 9:00am). She often brings in food or funny videos of her children. She also allows you a lot of freedom in what you choose to write about; for the research paper, I wrote an analysis of Minecraft through Marx's theory of alienation. The only drawback I would say this class has is sometimes it can be difficult to come up with ideas for the first two papers simply given the nature of the topic being something not often analyzed. Although, Dr. B is always willing to work through these roadblocks with you, so I would not classify it as much of an issue. Bottom line: rank this section high.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: It is a great class. It is very challenging at first if you are an international student who hasn't had so much experience with reading lengthy and difficult articles, book chapters that are specifically related to the field of study. I think people with interest in sociology, history and possibly philosophy would benefit mot from the class, the readings and the focus on writing. However, even as a more science oriented person, this class is extremely useful to grasp the influence of psychology, behavioral sciences and their influence in the questions of causality for example.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Really great class. Class discussions are quite interesting and although there are a lot of readings, the overall workload isn’t bad. Not to mention that Doug Bafford, or “Baffy,” as my class affectionately nicknamed him, is absolutely goated. Doug is genuinely one of the kindest, chillest, most patient, and most understanding professors I’ve ever had. You can tell he’s truly really passionate about the subject material and genuinely wants his students to succeed. I’m so grateful to him for always being so patient and providing so many opportunities for us to receive extra support and feedback if we need it.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is an excellent class. Some may characterize it as an "easier" expos, but arguably it's only easier in the sense that you will spend less time doing readings in this class than in others. There is still a strong analysis and writing component that is likely as difficult as most other Expos. Collier is an amazing instructor and he's very kind and sweet. His feedback on essays is extremely helpful. Make sure you take it seriously. Your thesis is going to play a huge role in the grade you get on your essays, so make sure you put a lot of thought into crafting a strong one. Non essay weeks are relatively light (just a couple of readings), but essay weeks can get very heavy, especially if writing isn't your strong suit. I spent about 15–30 hours on each of the three essays. The topic is also pretty interesting, as you explore the concept of a "wasteland" to its fullest extent, going far beyond what you might characterize as a wasteland. Good class I highly recommend it.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expos is a requirement after all. Although many people said that it actually improved their writing skills I do not feel like my writing has changed a lot throughout the course. However, this section about Orwell's 1984 was amazing (mainly the first half of the course that is more about fictional writing and analysis). Prof Cole is an amazing teacher and really enthusiastic and makes the very best of this mandatory class! Take it!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Professor Cole is great!  He makes section super engaging and works hard to help you learn the writing process.  Furthermore, he's super understanding and always willing to meet outside of class to help with anything course related.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: It is important to know that I will be speaking to the content and nature of this class as I do not like expository writing or writing classes in general. Even with that, this class still made the burden not so bad. There are three units covered over the semester for this class. The first unit was on the Blood Libel from the 15th century. This topic really was quite interesting, but maybe for only a week or two. After that, I was personally over the topic. The second topic was much more modern, we reviewed Graham Hancock and an episode of Ancient Apocalypse from Netflix. I found this topic to be much more interesting throughout the whole unit. It led to some great in–class discussions and some good avenues for paper topics. The third unit is all about researching a conspiracy theory of your own choice and allows for a lot more freedom when it comes to sources, research, and ideas. Throughout the course, the professor gave phenomenal feedback on each response exercise, rough draft, and final paper which really helped improve my writing.Whilst I am not a fan of expos in general, I would recommend this class as a top choice for expos 20.(Please, for your own sake, do not procrastinate the drafts of your papers until 2 nights before they are due like I did.)
worse_comment: This seems like one of the worst expos. Garcia didn't seem particularly interested or knowledgeable on the subject matter. Quick boring and most people did other work on their laptop during class. I would put this very low on the rankings. Would NOT recommend.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: At the very beginning of this semester, I was in another Expos Course " non–combatants" which was a very terrible experience for my first semester and my first class at Harvard. That was when I started questioning my academic writing and my ability to cope in this course with other peers whose first language is English, in contrast to me starting my first international education abroad. But this course was very different from that.  After I swapped in, I started really enjoying the Expos class – at least to the extent a STEM major can enjoy a writing class at all, but it was all in all very enriching in the sense that I became very natural in writing, made a lot of friends in the class, and learned a lot about the college/ research standards. It was still a very challenging class but it never felt like it's unbearable or too stressful. Really recommend it to anyone interested in conspiracy theories and wanting a writing class that actually challenges you and makes you grow.
worse_comment: This class is relatively little work until essay deadlines roll around. Take it if you are interested in conspiracy theories.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: A great expos course! Dr. Given is a great professor that is very personable and engaging. The course content is pretty interesting and I didn't even have any experience/background interest in art history. We learned a lot about repatriation, role of museums, art history and got to make a lot of exciting trips to museums, visits with curators, and a fun capstone project (where you make your own online exhibit) at the end.  This is a truly a well–established and structured course that is fufills the EXPOS requirement. The readings are reasonable and the essay prompts are well crafted. Dr. Given does a good job of pacing out the drafts and final revisions so it helps even if you're worried about taking Expos 20. Dr. Given gives great feedback and made me a better writer!
worse_comment: Great teacher but a boring topic.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class– especially if you have an interest in ethics or art history! Greg was a great teacher, and the material is all very interesting. We went on a ton of field trips both around campus and to other museums in the area, which were also a good introduction to the Harvard campus and Boston area. The readings are not too hard, and there are not too many essays– though you will get some that take up a decent amount of time. Greg gives great feedback, and your writing will improve without a crazy amount of work.
worse_comment: This class isn't very interesting if you don't like the topic.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE! Dr. Gold is an amazing professor who is truly amazing at what she does. While you may go in thinking you understand feminism, once you leave the course you will have a much deeper understanding of what feminism truly is and its layers. Dr. Gold's class does not have a lot of readings and in the essays we have to write she provides a lot of support when needed. She truly is such a kind and amazing person. She is also brilliant. I really am going to miss her!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: THIS CLASS  IS AMAZING! TAKE IT!!!!! Ranking this class as my first choice was the best decision I made this semester. Dr. Gold is the biggest reason why it is so worth it to take this class. She is so amazing, brilliant, and helpful. Through the span of the four months I took this class, I feel my writing has improved so much. Dr. Gold gives SO MUCH helpful feedback (comments on your essays, video feedback where she literally goes through essay and talks about her feedback, and conferences). I also just love the readings she assigns. Very light reading compared to other Expos courses. We do not have readings every class, but when we do, they are so interesting and rewarding to read. Dr. Gold's taste in selecting the reading assignments for this class is superb to say the least. Like I would actually enjoy reading this class's readings just for fun during my free time. And genuinely being interested in this class and the readings made writing so much more fun and easy. For our research paper at the end of the semester, we were able to pick any topic we wanted to research, and getting to write about a topic I was passionate about and invested in made me want to produce my best work possible, not for the grade or the class but for my self and my own fulfillment. You definitely have to put in effort into this class, but as I said, this class makes you WANT to. Since everybody in this class enjoyed it and was passionate about it, we all had so much fun in class together. I probably made the most friends in this class out of all of my classes. Getting to talk to Dr. Gold is also so much fun too and interesting. (These are the type of professor–student relationships you imagine when thinking of Harvard.) Overall, this class is just so perfect; I have no criticisms. If you are looking for a smooth transition to college–level writing from high school–level writing that is both fun and rewarding, THIS CLASS IS FOR YOU. Expos is meant to prepare you for academic writing in your future life in college and beyond, and this class not only achieves that goal successfully but also makes the process so enjoyable and memorable.
best_gem_comment: This Expos class is a gem and make this your top choice!! Dr. Gold is extremely specific and provides a variety of ways to comments and feedback (a draft conference, video, and comments). Her unit curriculum is extremely organized, and you know exactly what you are going to do for the rest of the semester if you're the type of person to plan ahead. The readings are incredibly interesting even if you aren't interested in discussing feminism or any social issues (which was the case for me, and I feel a lot more comfortable discussing these issues). Dr. Gold doesn't cold call on you if you aren't comfortable, and she really tries to understand your learning and writing style and makes the class a comfortable space for discussion. She has a clear rubric that she grades off from and has a lot more assignments and participation to help your grade, so the two major essays don't completely determine your grade. The capstone project is a lot better to do and allows you to flex your creativity and apply the topics you've learned to the real world rather than writing a third essay. She is very quick to respond to any messages on Slack as well and is extremely funny and engaging. Be sure to utilize the Writing Center or any outside opinion or help edit your essays since class mainly talks about the readings and discussing how to write essays better. She gives you lots of time to work on your essays, just don't procrastinate. Overall, an incredibly fun and interesting class, and I don't regret making this my top choice.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this expos class if possible!! Goldberg is a wonderful professor, and you're able to explore anything you want as long as it falls within guidelines. If you're interested in mental illness, sexuality, or race, you'll enjoy this. Note that some of the readings for the second Unit may take you a bit to get through, especially if you aren't used to reading gender or queer theory, but Goldberg does a good job at explaining it and ensuring it makes sense. I like to think I already had a strong background in writing, but this Expos class only strengthened it!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I recommend this course so much, not only because Dr. Ethan's curriculum structure of giving 2 weeks between the 1st draft and final draft (which most Expos don't give) was actually helpful in revising essays into ones that were honest to your ideas, but also because the readings themselves were so interesting and pretty mind blowing at some points. Most expos is mainly focused on the mechanics of writing, but this class taught me so much about theories and introduced me to many short stories that I'd now call one of my favorites. HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS CLASS!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Do the readings well! A large chunk of your essays will be derived from ideas/evidence from the readings so doing them well the first time will be beneficial for you. Dr. Herron is also such a down to earth, approachable professor and will do his best to help you throughout your writing process so don't be shy in reaching out for any questions or help.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I recommend taking this course if you are interested in climate fictions! Eliza creates such a warm and welcoming environment for her students. This environment allows students to feel comfortable sharing their ideas during discussions. For the assignments, there are discussion posts, response papers, and 3 unit papers.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Please take this course! I typically despite writing essays, but Eliza and her assignments made writing not only tolerable but also enjoyable! All 3 major writing assignments offer great freedom in the texts you choose and argument you present; as a result, you feel much more engaged when writing. As for Eliza, she is the greatest strength of this course. Eliza is a passionate, understanding, and encouraging professor. She clearly loves what she does and encourages meaningful consideration and conversation of the course material. Eliza is also incredibly understanding; she knows students (especially those new to college) are only human. Finally, the feedback she gives on assignments is incredibly helpful and has helped me become a much stronger writer.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Dr. Lane is awesome!!! The course is great and teaches you a ton. You become a better writer, learn to look deeper into the meaning of various works, and you learn to analyze various mediums of information. We have a podcast assignment at the end which is really fun. The time commitment for the class is not very high (except when an essay is due), and for the amount of time you put into the class outside of class, you get an awesome return.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Even if the course material isn't 100% your favorite interest (it wasn't for me, at least), I'd still recommend this class. Isabel is a great teacher who's incredibly accommodating and accessible, which makes the course pretty enjoyable and very far from the time–suck that other Expos courses can be. You definitely get out what you put into the course, but honestly it's a pretty nice gem of an Expos course. Pretty easy readings, straightforward essays, a really nice capstone project (I took this course first semester of freshman year, and when you have a ton of finals you're stressed about, having a podcast which takes like 2–3 hours max to do is a nice break from studying), and overall a good environment. Overall a solid pick.
best_gem_comment: Even if the course material isn't 100% your favorite interest (it wasn't for me, at least), I'd still recommend this class. Isabel is a great teacher who's incredibly accommodating and accessible, which makes the course pretty enjoyable and very far from the time–suck that other Expos courses can be. You definitely get out what you put into the course, but honestly it's a pretty nice gem of an Expos course. Pretty easy readings, straightforward essays, a really nice capstone project (I took this course first semester of freshman year, and when you have a ton of finals you're stressed about, having a podcast which takes like 2–3 hours max to do is a nice break from studying), and overall a good environment. Overall a solid pick.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! This has been my favorite class during my first semester. The assignments are fun and are flexible to your interests even though we have specific reading materials to focus on.  The readings in this course were extremely interesting. Each reading assignment was a different court case that we then discussed in class and the discussions were incredibly rich. This class will challenge you and the assignments will take work and effort but the entire process is incredibly rewarding. The comments Ross gives are fantastic. I've used them to guide each of my drafts and final essays. The feedback served as a sounding board for how I was doing, and I internalized those comments. I mentioned at the start of the year that I wanted to know when my essay was quality without the use of a rubric or someone else, and through the comments I've been able to point out issues with my paper on my own now at the end of the semester.The most rewarding to me was our discussion section. The in–class experience was my favorite part of the class. The classroom environment that Ross, my peers, and I created over the semester has been one of my favorite aspects of the Harvard experience so far. I appreciate how supportive and respectful the discussions are and, the student–led aspect of our discussions has led to many personal revelations, closer relationships, and overall understandings across multiple perspectives. On the instructor level, Dr. Ross Martin is genuinely one of the best instructors I've ever had. He is very intentional in what he says and the way he runs his classroom. You can tell that in every action and sentence, he wants the best for his students and the people he interacts with. I needed that in my first semester here. The amount of care and kindness that he has shown to me and the rest of my peers is unmatched. I am so grateful to have been a part of this class and been his student.In terms of preparation, I think it is good to have experience in writing research papers in high school. I think my high school preparation helped me a lot in transitioning to the expos writing experience. However, if you feel confident about your abilities in writing papers generally, I don't think you need experience in constitutional law at all. I had none and this was my favorite class!
worse_comment: Don't get me wrong... this class is difficult. But not because it is badly taught or disorganized. It is difficult because you will be doing the heavy lifting to elevate your writing along with your thinking. For me, it was almost like I was accessing a new part of my brain. Making the class easier would have sacrificed by learning. Keep pushing through, the momentary difficulty you may experience will be 100% worth it in the end.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you are at all interested in pre–law or constitutional law, RANK THIS HIGH!! Probably my favorite class this semester.  The course material isn't necessarily the easiest (you will most definitely struggle on the first paper), but Ross is so incredibly supportive and in–class discussions are very engaging. Be sure to take the initiative and ask for help whenever you need it—Ross always has your back, just communicate!! Would definitely recommend if you have a keen interest in SCOTUS and desire to read actual court cases for class.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Best Expos out there, without a doubt. McKeon is a great teacher, who's patient, kind, engaging, and understanding. The course material is interesting (admittedly I care about both sports and politics), with readings that aren't excessively dense like some of the ones my friends had in ConLaw or other Expos 20 courses. The course Canvas itself is well–organized (unlike way too many other courses at Harvard College), and the weekly email newsletter helps so much. I loved this class as much as one can love an Expos course.My one criticism is that it's predominantly dudes.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class was just a bunch of bullshitting. I wish I picked a more intellectually interesting Expos. The issue isn’t that the topic of sports and politics wasn’t interesting. It is just that Keating is very hand–wavy and speaks in very fluffy terms that don’t mean much. I don’t think I learned anything that made me a much better writer. A lot of the assignments also felt like busy work. I took this class thinking that it would be a very easy A without much work. I’m not sure what my grade is, but I think I probably ended with an A or A–, but the work involved was a little more than I expected. I do think that the time I spent in the class was a waste though, and wished I took a more intellectually stimulating class, or at least a class whose preceptor was more thought–provoking. That way the time I spent on the class wouldn’t feel as wasted.In general, Keating’s feedback is also sometimes pretty vague. For example, he would say “you can try this” or “you can incorporate this,” but wouldn’t necessarily make clear what the problem with the current essay is. However, Keating is a very good person and cares a lot about you as a student. Whenever I had any questions about his feedback I would email him and he would respond with very thorough responses.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!! I came into this semester not really liking writing, but this ended up being my favorite class by far this semester. The units and readings are super interesting, and there isn't a ton of reading which is nice because I felt like I got to focus on the content and on my writing. This course also introduced me to sociology which has been awesome, and our class discussions were really interesting. My writing improved tremendously, and the writing focus of the course really helped me make a lot of the basic components of an essay pop in my writing. If this course looks remotely interesting to you, definitely add it to your Expos rankings. I felt like I learned and grew so much in this course and I cannot recommend it enough.Dr. Meyer has a ton of enthusiasm and interest in the material, and it really shows. She was super engaging, and I always felt welcome in her class. It was really clear that she cares about teaching and about us as students. Her feedback on my essays was super helpful, and she always gave us additional time to talk with her.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: so hear me out –  dr Monaghan is a  pretty strictperson (was/am still afraid of her slightly) but actually i feel I've learned a lot from the class and actually became better writer/thinker due to itin the end of the day she is very supportive and helpful and i would recommend it(however if you're looking for an easy A expos  maybe it's not the best shot)
worse_comment: This was a very interesting class. You will undoubtedly learn a lot. However, I overall do not recommend this to students who are not really interested in wartime history. I thought this class would be mainly about the effects of war on society and the home life. Unfortunately, this was not exactly the case, which was disappointing and made it harder to feel connected to the class/material. In general with Expos, I would suggest only ranking classes which you KNOW you will be interested in. Otherwise, it will be very difficult to write papers on a topic you simply do not connect with.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Again, I would 100% recommend this course. The time commitment is not that bad, the material is interesting, and you learn a lot about your style and how to improve. Dr. Monaghan is so nice and helpful! Hopefully you will get to see her sweet cat during your zoom conferences like I did! Overall, high praise!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I LOVE THIS EXPOS CLASS!!!! Definitely take this one if this is offered because David Nee is AMAZING!!! He gives great advice and buys us food/snacks occassionally!!! I also feel like he really cares about his students, and so, coming to this class and writing essays didn't feel bad at all!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: When reading through the Q Guide before registering for this course, it seemed like Expos as a whole was just a requirement that you have to get out of the way in your first year. The Q reports for this class specifically seemed to be mostly negative, however, I had the complete opposite experience. Dr. Pietras was so helpful all semester, and I found that he gave very intentional and helpful feedback that improved my writing significantly. This course does at first seem like a queer history class, but keeping in mind that it is an Expos course, I feel that it does a fantastic job at building those foundational skills that are necessary for college writing. The course is especially interesting as a queer person, but this has been one of my favorite courses of the semester. If you're looking to become a stronger writer while learning about some very interesting patterns in queer media, this is the Expos for you!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a super interesting expos topic if you are interested in psych. Really awesome professor, and content as well.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you are interested in the topic, I highly suggest taking this course. Dr. Quigley is intelligent and an amazing lecturer. She provides wonderful feedback and is understanding and wants you to succeed. Her comments on my writing helped me learn more about writing in one semester than I did in the entirety of my life prior. She is a bit of a tough grader but I believe the amazing experience I had was worth this. She made me improve. She structures the class in a very productive and helpful way. She is very communicative and great at figuring out how to help you improve. This class seems to attract kind, interesting people. I really enjoyed class discussions. My classmates were very interesting and thoughtful and respectful. I always looked forward to the class and didn't skip a single day. It was amazing and I really do recommend it if you are interested in psychology and intersectionality.The readings can be a bit dense and full of scientific jargon. You definitely need to do them for the class.Do NOT procrastinate writing! It makes the entire process much more difficult.Overall, wonderful experience. I came away knowing much more about writing and research and psychology. Dr. Quigley really dives into the subject matter while still doing a great job of teaching structure and writing. It was a lovely class and I really do recommend it.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would tell future students to not worry about this class! I would say for a freshmen requirement, it is one of if not the most understanding/lenient courses in terms of adjusting to the college's academic environment, and the professors truly want you to succeed and highlight the strengths of your work by giving flexibility. I would highly recommend Dr. Raymer's section, as she was very compassionate and understanding when I needed extensions, and provided helpful feedback on my works! The only graded assignments for me were the final essays, so depending on your work–style that could be to your benefit or deficit.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is such a great expos topic – I loved this course!! The professor is fantastic, and she really creates such an inclusive and welcoming environment in each class. The readings are diverse and interesting, and spark great discussions on issues in science, technology, and medicine. It really forced me to look at ethical issues from a new angle. The structure of this course is really great in how it allows you to adjust to college writing in a safe space, where you get lots of feedback and are able to connect with your professor in a small group setting. Would highly recommend this section of expos – the professor is amazing, kind, and I learned a lot!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS EXPOS. SERIOUSLY. I ranked Animals & Politics as my top choice, and I am so glad that I took this course. The interdisciplinary topic is very interesting, and I learned a lot about animal rights, environmental issues, public health concerns, and policy. I also feel that I really improved my abilities as a writer. But the course is only as good as its instructor. AND DR. SAHA IS AMAZING. This is only my first semester, but she's one of the best instructors I've encountered. She is so passionate about the topic, available to help, and genuinely wants you to succeed. She wants you to succeed in and out of expos, and she truly cares about her students. Also, the feedback she provided was very constructive and helped me learn. Our assignments were also really interesting. Unit 1 was good to get acclimated to college writing. The Capstone Project was an innovative way for us to consider solutions to animal issues, as well as experience a non–traditional writing assignment. And the research paper!!! It was really great to be able to pick a topic of our choice from a broad prompt. This may sound crazy, but I actually worked on my research paper as a way to procrastinate other work – I was just so interested in the topic. And the workload throughout the semester was extremely manageable. I would recommend starting the assignments early, though. Hopefully this review convinced you to rank Animals & Politics as your top expos because you won't regret it.
worse_comment: It can get a bit stressful towards the end of the semester as you have more assignments but still very manageable
best_gem_comment: This was a solid expos course I'd consider a gem. I am very stem–oriented, and this had a good mixture of humanities and sciences as a social science subject. I am also not too strong in my writing skills, however, Saha was very fair and considerate in her grading. She gave her expectations, and if you did your best to meet them (displayed effort to follow her advice to improve) then you would get a good grade. Sometimes it was a bit boring and instructions were unclear about certain parts of essay expectations. Not bad though I would much rather take this over Orwell. There were some readings, however, many people did not do them and you could usually get by just fine. I never really spent any time on this class unless it was like the day before a paper was due. Saha is also just a wonderful person who shows genuine interest and love for her topic!! BEST EXPOS SECTION IMO
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: THIS IS THE BEST EXPOS CLASS OUT THERE! If you have the privilege to have this class available for the term you are assigned to take Expos, look no further. This class is incredibly interesting as it is very interdisciplinary with environmental justice, animal rights, the agriculture industry, and more. Even if you don't have a strong interest in advocating for animal rights or vegetarianism at first, this course will provide you with a great number of perspectives, with your very own helping further this discussion. Furthermore, this course only has two papers versus most other Expos courses having three as there is a capstone project that requires giving a fun pitch on any topic involving animals. MOST IMPORTANTLY, I have never met an educator so passionate about the subject that they teach. The amount of expertise Dr. Saha has on the subject is truly admirable and it makes learning from her so enjoyable. She is the kindest professor I know and I could not recommend this course enough!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you are a prospective concentrator in the humanities, TAKE THIS COURSE. He's a harsh evaluator, I won't lie, but the quality of work he's going to push you to do is really high. I'd rather suffer as a freshman than suffer as an upperclassman unable to properly write a paper. On the other hand, if you are a STEM concentrator who will never take another writing course ever, I would recommend you to just take an easier section that fulfills the Expos requirement. But even if you're a STEM concentrator, the work you do is so rewarding, and since academic writing is a basic skill, I'd highly recommend you take it. Also, here's a nice plus: Unit 1 of this class is like a "crash–course Hum 10." Hear me out: you read a lot of the same texts, but you read tiny excerpts of it that are hell–flavored and interesting. He took out all of the boring/confusing passages. Honestly, the readings in this class are very manageable (I'd say at most 2 hrs per assignment); it's the writing that bumps up the average hours, so just keep that in mind if you are going in with a heavy workload.Adam is awesome and he leaves an essay of comments that are super helpful. His conferences are also very helpful and as long as you take his advice, you'll find that your paper is a lot better.
worse_comment: Take it.  I'm a STEM person at heart, and completing the readings and essays for this class was such a nice change of pace from my other coursework.  I think in general some Expos 20 classes can be constrained into one extremely boring topic, but The Underworld is basically a lens class for writing about almost any issue the world faces in terms of hell (and you'd be surprised to see how many problems relate back to classical works).  The readings are interesting and manageable, and Adam provides an insane amount of support on papers.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is engaging and you'll get as much out of it as you put into it. Ian is a great professor who is always available to talk to you about any issues you have. The classes can be dry sometimes, but class discussions and icebreakers make it a lot of fun, Gradewise, Ian is fair. Like any other expos, the bulk of your grade is dependent on the strength of the three essays you write. My recommendation is to start early! It can get overwhelming if you procrastinate (which is very easy to do). For those who loved movies like Catch Me if You Can, I highly recommend this class – you'll find it enjoyable.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS EXPOS. Or any Expos Ian teaches. He is hands down the best writing teacher I have ever had. He is so funny and fun to have class with. I found the entire class block passing without having thought about the time once, because Ian manages to make topics that are often dry interesting. We watch a lot of movies/video clips, which helps. We also spend the first ~20 minutes of class answering an "attendance question," which is an icebreaker–type question that allowed me to get to know the other people in my class and just have fun sharing anecdotes for the first part of class. My writing has improved so much over the semester, especially because of Ian's feedback, which is both detailed and incredibly helpful. Ian is very clear about his expectations and grades fairly according to them. This was genuinely such a good experience and I would recommend it to anyone.
worse_comment: The subject matter is very interesting but the papers are difficult to write since at least for the first two papers you are looking at portrayals of the con and what they convey rather than the cons themselves.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class! This is likely one of the more challenging Expos 20 classes but is incredibly rewarding if you are willing to put in an extra hour or two a week. Not only will you develop your skills in academic writing, but will get a comprehensive overview of privacy and surveillance. Dr. Sinnott is outstanding and very supportive as well. Unit 1 focuses on privacy theory, Unit 2 focuses on governmental surveillance conducted by the NSA (quite fascinating!), and Unit 3 focuses on surveillance conducted by private entities. All readings are very current ––– discussions and essays are on cutting–edge topics regarding privacy policy. It is quite hard to find a more interesting Expos 20 topic than this, especially if you are mildly interested in government / policy / law.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: While Sci–fi isn't always the most interesting topic, the course load wasn't too bad compared to other expos' and Dr. Spencer is really nice and accommodating
worse_comment: do not take this course. find a more established class with an instructor that has taught this class many times and really knows what to critically provide to students. also, some of the content in this class can be a little disturbing or make you uncomfortable.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I loved my section of EXPOS: Sci–Fi Others. Dr. Spencer is a fantastic professor and the course content is really interesting. If you like sci–fi, this is a great section for you! More broadly, if you stay engaged, participate in class discussions, and do all of your assignments, you will be successful in Expos. You really do get out of it what you put into it. Even if you don't see yourself as a big reader/writer, try to lean in and engage. You can learn many valuable (and widely applicable) things about writing.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: THIS IS THE BEST EXPOS. YOU SHOULD TAKE THIS SECTION! I recommend laughing matters to every single one of my friends because it's simply amazing. I don't think the class is free or easy, as some people have said their EXPOS's are, but my experience with this course is that you really get more than you put in. I didn't have a strong background in paper–writing from HS–– i took AP classes where we had to write essays in an hour or whatever. My writing has improved exponentially and I now feel confident to take Gen–Eds that req. writing. Besides that, it's truly such a fun class to be in. Class discussions every day were such a joy. All the readings were either hilarious or extremely interesting, which is rare for an EXPOS! Also, Elliott is a killer preceptor that will truly help you evolve your thinking and writing. Take this course if you seriously want to improve your writing and logic and laugh a lot.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a great Expos class. I thought the first unit was a little boring (focusing on philosophy of humor), but after that, it got much more interesting. Elliott is a very kind, supportive, and helpful teacher, and I think his lessons and his advice helped me grow a lot as a writer. The first two assignments required every student to turn in a rough draft where we would receive feedback, and Elliott always gave very thorough, constructive, and useful feedback. If you spend time and really work and discuss with Elliott what you need to work on to improve your writing, I think you can definitely get a grade you're satisfied with while also learning a lot about writing.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is great. Professor Zecca is engaging and makes sure that everyone gets the chance to participate in discussions, and section was a blast! The course material is super fun to learn about, but you also learn a lot about using different sources in conversation with one another and how to more effectively structure your essays. The one thing I would say is that in my experience, the feedback on the final essays is a bit sparse –– more just a few broad notes on structure or content rather than in–depth analysis of the essays –– but if you really put work into your drafts and you show up to office hours or just talk to Professor Zecca after class, she's always willing to look over what you have and give you some tips. The workload for homework and readings was definitely manageable too. Overall, loved the class and Professor Zecca! TAKE THIS CLASS!!
worse_comment: This courseload isn't too bad, but when essay deadlines come up, it can be stressful!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you have to take any Expos course, take this!! Mande is the MOST Wonderful teacher I have met in college, and she is so so helpful in every way. She is so understanding and so supportive! Also, all of the readings are so interesting and diverse, giving you new and interesting perspectives on horror. Also, the last essay was a delight to write with all the freedom we had!! Lastly, our class was such a community, with all of us ending as such good friends!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: My favorite class of my first year. I knew not much about AI, but because of the 10 person class dynamic, Jane’s incredibly invested teaching style and wonderful feedback, and a final paper that really made me feel like I was contributing to an ongoing academic conversation, I came out of the class feeling like an expert and a better writer by 10000%. You will gain so much from her class, and also so much passion into being able to write for yourself, and express your own ideas (without ChatGPT!).
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class was so much fun and so helpful! Take this class if you want to study Austen's writing and/or if you want to improve substantially as a writer. The workload is pretty substantial, especially if you actually want to improve as a writer, but I think it's worth it. Dr. Napier is so kind and approachable, and his feedback is incredibly helpful (and very detailed). My favorite part of this class was when we got to watch Clueless and the 2020 film adaptation of Emma and then analyze movie scenes. I considered myself a good writer going into this course, but I feel so much more confident about my writing ability now.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would highly, highly recommend this class! I am a STEM major, but Austen and Us ended up being my favorite class during freshmen fall. Dr. Napier is an outstanding professor and really wants his students to succeed as writers. He gives extensive feedback on student drafts and is always accessible for office hours or writing conferences. Class discussions are engaging and informative, and the content is interesting too. During Unit 1 you read Emma, and during Unit 2 you compare the Emma and Clueless films. During Unit 3, you can write a research paper on any Austen–related topic you want (this can be anything from Bridgerton to Twilight). The community in the class is very tight too, and many students will become friends outside of the course and meet up together for Austen movie nights. This course really got me to grow both as a writer and as a person. I would highly recommend that students take this class, whether they are fans of Austen or not (having prior experience is not at all a requirement).
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Erika was amazing! Incredibly friendly and well versed on the topic of public speaking and performance. Definitely take this class. You also bond with your classmates a lot as you learn so much about them through the various speeches
worse_comment: Seniors: take this class. Take it as a 5th Pass/Fail. Take it and you won't regret it. It's not the best class at Harvard, but it does teach you skills you'll use in any profession.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is hands–down the best class I've taken at Harvard.  I feel like this class has truly changed me for the better – both as a public speaker and how I engage with my fellow classmates at Harvard. I came into the class already a relatively confident speaker,  although I had some areas I wanted to work on. From the very first round of speeches, I was absolutely blown away with how much I was already learning. Throughout the course, I learned how to become an evocative story teller, how to engage directly with the audience, speak on the spot, widen the range in both my vocal tone and body language, utilize the physical space on stage, work with slides and/or props, and weave numerous rhetorical devices into my speeches. At the same time,  each student was given the space to develop their own style, and everybody had at least one outstanding strength that they could share with the rest of the class (from comforting the audience, to projecting their voice, to bringing vulnerability to their speeches, to incorporating humor, and more). Kate and the class always provided helpful feedback that made each one of us a better speaker.  We would do short practice rounds after each speech to incorporate the feedback, and I would often be blown away at how much more impactful people's speeches would become. We also play fun warm up games to start each class (if you've ever done theater/drama, they're similar to those). They might seem silly at first, but they are in fact really helpful, particularly the improv exercises that prepare you for impromptu speaking. Last note on speaking: I really appreciated the space we were given to experiment with each speech. I never felt like I was ever going to be penalized if something fell flat, and making mistakes and figuring out feels most natural were pivotal in my development as an independent speaker and thinker. I was truly taking the class to LEARN, and I loved every moment of it.The class not only taught me about public speaking, but it also reminded me why I wanted to come to Harvard in the first place. Because Expos 40 is an elective, people from all concentrations take the class. I only knew a couple of other classmates coming into the class, and I am so glad to have met such an interesting and kind group of people. I loved listening to everyone's speeches – their various perspectives, passions, hopes, fears, and goals. I learned as much from my peers as I did from the structural parts of the course, and I don't think I could have had that with any other class. Come in with an open mind and intention to be an engaged peer, and you will get so much from this course.1000% recommend! Lottery, and lottery again if you need to! If I could, I would take this class again in a heartbeat!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I cannot stress enough how good this class was, it is one of my favorite classes at Harvard so far!!!! The professor is absolutely incredible (shoutout to Nick!) and always willing to create a nice class atmosphere and help you improve – his feedback is invaluable, and you will also get precious feedback from your classmates. Class is really small (about 15 people) which really allows you to get close to people and just have a lot of fun with the speeches. If you put in the effort, you will truly improve and learn a lot and, regardless of your future plans, the skills you'll learn will be useful for the rest of your life. Assignments are well distributed throughout the semester, and it gets easier to deal with the speeches as the semester goes by. TAKE THIS CLASS!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class! Seriously. You'll leave the course as a more effective public speaker and have a fun time taking the course. I'd start lotterying early for this course because it often takes many shots before people get on. A strong positive of taking this course is getting close with other students taking the class and forming real friendships with the other students while hearing about their interesting life experiences through their speeches. The work load and grading of the course is very kind. For this section in particular, Nick is a legend. He's a very effective teacher and gives excellent feedback. He's also a really cool dude. ***
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Please take this class if you are lucky enough to win the lottery if you are willing to BUY IN (commit to learning and getting better).  Its great. Cannot say enough great things. I learned without realizing. I got to know my classmates so well.  10/10 class. Senior year is the move I think, great way to round out your Harvard experience.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is an excellent class for anyone to take. You’ll be in a low stakes, fun environment and come out a better public speaker. Terry is a great teacher who cares about his students.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class!!!! James is awesome and it is such a great way to build confidence in both public speaking and just generally. The class is so fun and gets you out of your comfort zone in the best way!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Loved this class! James was a wonderful instructor, and I thought my public speaking (and nervousness) actually did improve over the course of the semester. The class is structured around 3 speeches (4 if you count the informal introduction speech) that you give to your classmates. Great feedback on outlines and speeches and great course overall. Would highly recommend, especially if you're taking hard classes like I was and looking to lighten your workload a bit.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Everyone says this, but I wholeheartedly agree –– take expos 40! Public speaking is such a fundamental skill, and this course does a great job of training this skill. The peer feedback aspect of this course is a little awkward to begin with, but ended up being one of my favorite aspects. In other settings, you'll rarely get a chance to get immediate feedback on your speeches from a variety of people. It's also cool to see how other people give speeches and improve over time! I like how tailored this class is to real world applications of public speaking, e.g. interviews, the corporate world, giving toasts, etc. Lee is an amazing preceptor who brings a theater/voice coaching background, which is something I would never had had access to otherwise!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is just as fun and low–stress as they say, but I was pleasantly surprised by how much I learned. I have truly developed in so many ways as a speaker this semester, and got to know some really wonderful people along the way. Zach is so kind, funny, and eccentric– loved having him as my teacher.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Oh man, the first semester that people have had to enroll for next sem without being able to read the QGuide first. This class was incredible, easily, hands down, not even close, my favourite class I've taken. I'm CS through–and–through, took this with 165 and 153 to help balance my load, but this was the highlight of my semester easily. The class community is unmatched in any class I've seen at Harvard – I have a huge amount of respect for everyone else in my section, and also am incredibly glad I got to meet and hear so much from them about their lives, beliefs, values and opinions. Harvard might be the worst rated institution for free speech or whatever we are getting flamed for in the papers, but EXPOS 40 makes a mockery of that. Both in speeches but also just general discussions at starts of classes/around breaks (normally took a lunch break for 10 mins in the middle of 12–2pm class, we were in Lowell screening room so could go get food from dhall as a group which was 10/10), there was an enormous range of topics discussed. Why you should travel, why you should get a credit card, a case for ethical non–monogamy, we should abolish social security, we should get rid of extra time on exams, how to dance Folklorico, how to erg, how to secure the first date, why long distance dating is underrated, an intro to sports betting, intro to meditation and mindfulness, history of the Persian empire (That wasn't quite the title, I apologize we had a lot of great speeches, I loved this one Hayden, you'll just have to give it again :) and so many more. All the speeches of introductions. All the improv sessions, all the warmup dance nonsense and vocal warmups. So many highlights from one class.Now I have to talk about the star of the show. I wouldn't have traded Zach for anyone, any other class, no chance. Zach brought this class to life in a way that I truly didn't think was possible. His energy is infectious, he is a fountain of insane and random knowledge, funny quotes and general good vibes. At the same time, he is an excellent public speaking teacher – I really felt that I have developed a lot as a speaker throughout the class, and it's even more evident in some of my classmates. I was very pleasantly surprised by my improvement, but I was staggered by how much some of the others in the class improved, their first and final speech were night and day, incomparable, it was incredible to see.If this review is ever viewed given the new system, lottery for this class. If you don't get in, put yourself on the waitlists. I got in in the second week of the semester from the waitlist, and I can't express how glad I am that I did. It was the most welcoming and supportive learning community I've been a part of at Harvard, and it was an incredible experience that I would wholeheartedly recommend to anyone here. Oh, and try to get Zach's sections, duh :)
subject: Expository Writing

course_title: Black Holes, String Theory and the Fundamental Laws of Nature 001
best_comment: I absolutely loved this course! It was my favorite class! This class is truly a once in a lifetime opportunity to understand theoretical physics concepts (at some level), and I'm so glad I took it. Please take it. It was incredibly interesting and fun, and refreshingly focused on learning. It was nice to have a course where the only assignments were readings because it was less stressful. That being said, please don't take this class if you don't plan to do the readings because you will get nothing out of the class (the readings were the only reason that I understood the lectures). I hear freshman seminars a hit or miss. This one is definitely a "hit" as long as you are interested in the topics. Cannot recommend enough!
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Black Holes, String Theory and the Fundamental Laws of Nature

course_title: Research at the Harvard Forest—Global Change Ecology: Forests, Ecosystem Function, the Future 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS SEMINAR, MAKE TAKING IT YOUR FIRST PRIORITY FRESHMAN FALL, YOU WON'T REGRET IT. This class was the absolute academic highlight of my freshman fall. Staying two nights at the forest once a month was such a cool and unique experience, and I bonded so much with everyone else in the class. There is a lot being thrown at you on the class days, but is balanced out nicely by how much fun you are having. Dave is an excellent teacher and truly like a father figure to everyone in the class. He makes the experience so special. You also get to have only 3 classes the rest of the month,  since this class doesn't meet regularly, which takes a HUGE load off academically and is a nice way to get adjusted. The homework is minimal. There is reading to do before each weekend. The only submitted work (aside from the final paper) is to submit a short writeup answering a couple questions, due 1 week after each trip. These are very low–stakes, chill assignments that don't take long, and you don't have any submitted homework at all the rest of the month. The final paper was legit but manageable and we had a lot of time to work on it. The forest was absolutely beautiful, the stars were incredible, and it was so cool to get to go around and explore nature – great way to escape the Cambridge bubble and get outside. The accomodations are truly outstanding as well – you live in a huge house with tons of beds, tons of space, nice bathrooms and showers, an active kitchen, and tons and tons of free food and drink that is purchased for you to snack on. You really feel like it is your home and you have total free reign to live in the space. You also learn a lot over the course of this class! Getting off campus 1 weekend per month is really not a huge commitment and is honestly really good for you – I looked forward to those weekends more than anything. It felt like an escape from the stress of Harvard life and into a whole separate world. In conclusion – this is literally, like, the best class ever conceived. It is such a cool, unique, interactive learning experience that you will never get again in your time at Harvard. You only have one semester where you can try to take it – don't miss it for the world!
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Research at the Harvard Forest—Global Change Ecology: Forests, Ecosystem Function, the Future

best_comment: Please take this seminar! Giovanni is an amazing professor. He is great at facilitating discussions, and he is overall just an interesting and fun guy! This seminar is hardly a time commitment outside of class, and it is a great way to ease yourself into college while still taking a worthwhile course. The material is incredibly interesting, and the way it is presented (including the projects we did) lends itself well to thought–provoking and open–ended discussions.
best_gem_comment: If you have any sort of interest in cancer/genetic testing, this course is a gem and the workload is very light.
subject: First Year Seminar

best_comment: This class, in my opinion is one of the greatest ways to start off your Harvard experience, especially if you are really enthusiastic about sailing. Professor Bloxham is one of the kindest and knowledgeable people you will meet at this campus. He will always answer any of your questions on physics topics, and he will always take care of you. The section meeting are enjoyable to be at and food is provided. I can honestly say this is a fantastic course and I'd recommend it to any one with some sailing background and some physics background.
subject: First Year Seminar

course_title: Medicine in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust—Anatomy as Example for Changes in Medical Science 01
best_comment: This seminar is a gem. Sabine is a wonderful professor who is very passionate about her work. Her findings are really interesting and she is very knowledgeable about medicine in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust. She's really nice and considerate. The readings for the class are very manageable, definitely more manageable than most seminars. There is only one final paper (2000 words) and a 5–minute presentation. The class can be boring at times, especially if you're not interested in history and have a short attention span (it's 2 hours), but I think that you'll learn a lot of valuable lessons and it will leave you with a broader worldview for sure. Sabine is a sweetheart. She invited us to her house for a holiday dinner and brought it candy after Halloween. She really cares about her students and the work that she does. I highly recommend taking this class, especially if you're taking 3 demanding STEM classes like me. I found my workload this semester to be pretty manageable and I'm glad I took this seminar. The people in the class came from all sorts of backgrounds, identities, lived–experiences, and interests, and learning from all has also been incredibly valuable. I enjoyed watching the final presentations, especially the one about a student's grandfather who was a Jewish surgeon who operated in Germany during WW2. Easy and interesting class, take it!
worse_comment: Anyone who wants to learn more about the holocaust should sign up for this seminar. The subject matter can be quite difficult at times because it involves the murder and abuse of the most vulnerable, but it also puts a spotlight on the few heroes who risked their careers and sometimes lives to do the right thing.

course_title: Earth Science Goes to the Movies: Math and Physics of Natural (?) Disasters 001
best_comment: This class was easily my favorite class that I took this semester.  The content taught in the course was very interesting to learn about, especially if you like learning about natural disasters.  The movies that are shown, even if they're a bit cheesy, are unironically really good. The Tuesday evening movie night quickly became the highlight of my week. The assignments aren't very difficult. A lot of the class activities are a lot of fun, and do a job of helping us learn content. The atmosphere of the class is very welcoming, and it had a lovely community. I can't recommend this course enough.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Earth Science Goes to the Movies: Math and Physics of Natural (?) Disasters

best_comment: This seminar was amazing. Course load was very easy which is good for a seminar. This allowed to explore only for the love of physics. Professor Doyle is very passionate and knowledgeable in Physics so take the most out of discussions. Final project was very enjoyable.
best_gem_comment: No matter what your background in physics is, this seminar has something to offer for you. Professor Doyle's teaching style takes a little getting used to at first, but you'll definitely come to appreciate his philosophy on education (especially when you realize how nice having no homework in this class is). The final project isn't worth stressing over, and the lab visits at the end of the semester are absolutely the coolest thing ever. Doyle knows so much about physics, and you'll definitely get a lot out of this class if you participate and ask him a lot of questions. For the amount of work this class has (or lack thereof), this class is an absolute gem for a more physics–y seminar and the breadth of topics covered are sure to give you (at the very least) a good pedagogy of what there is to learn in physics beyond mechanics and E&M.

best_comment: 1. Take this class for sure!! It is not a hard class, but if you put even a bit of effort into the material you will come out knowing so much interesting history about medicine that your perspective on surgery will be changed forever. Pre–meds and history buffs, this is an amazing class for you.2. The depth and variety of the readings is awesome. Dr. Millham provides many interesting primary sources and historical analyses for us to read that really were not difficult to get through as long as you set some time aside to do them. Or, if you really are pressed for time, skim to find the main ideas so you aren't just sitting there in silence when he asks a question in class (the goal is to learn, and even knowing a little bit to jumpstart a conversation is better than not knowing anything). I also really appreciated how many different perspectives were provided/considered in the course. 3. The hands–on experiences of this class are not to miss. I absolutely LOVED all the field trips (Countway Library, Etherdome, Anatomy Lab**). I thought they were incredibly insightful and only reinforced my desire to go into medicine in the future. Dr. Millham has established such a good relationship with all the professionals at these locations, and I could really tell they love what they do. Also, who else can say they've held a human heart in their hands!4. Also, Dr. Millham cares greatly about his students. Especially during some of the rougher weeks of the semester, he is an awesome source of kindness and food to his students when he was not required to be. Definitely one of the most conscientious teachers I've ever had.
subject: First Year Seminar

course_title: Microbial Symbioses: From the Deep-Sea to the Human Microbiome 001
best_comment: If you have the opportunity and any interest in biology or organisms, TAKE THIS COURSE!!! I cannot emphasize how much I recommend this seminar as it completely changed how I look at biology but also the world we live in; I learned about microbes, not as harmful enemies but as complex symbiotic entities that are fundamental for life to exist. Professor Cavanaugh makes class extremely interesting, entertaining, and at times, hilarious, making me look forward to class every week. The class is full of amazing FIELD TRIPS and labs while requiring a manageable amount of work that is not burdening. The class book "Multitudes" explains topics in such a fascinating way that makes the material engaging, unlike many dull science textbooks. I will most likely be an AFVS concentrator but this was my favorite class this semester! that's how good it is!!
worse_comment: take it, but beware. you learn literally so much more than any other course you can take freshman year. because of this course, i now run every discovery under the lens of microbial symbiosis to see if it might be at play. life changing course. only problem is that prof really expects a lot out of you and you will inevitably feel like you fail her every single week.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Microbial Symbioses: From the Deep-Sea to the Human Microbiome

course_title: Finding Connections: Perspectives on Psychological Development and Mental Illness 001
best_comment: If you're looking for a quality first–year seminar, I would say take this one. I truly learned so much from the weekly readings and Dr. Rappaport's sharing of her experiences as a  practicing child and adolescent psychiatrist. Although the readings can get a little long some weeks, they are totally worth it if you are interested in psychiatry/psychology. Dr Rappaport is also an amazing mentor with a very kind demeanor; she will put in the effort to make sure you feel welcome in class. I thoroughly enjoyed the assignments each week and Dr Rappaport is generally lenient when it comes to extensions when they are necessary.
