I walk out of this course with a much better understanding of mental illness, so if that's something you're interested in, you should take this class.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Finding Connections: Perspectives on Psychological Development and Mental Illness

best_comment: This class is a good introduction to waves (light, sound, etc.), however it is absolutely not a replacement for Physics 15c. To get the most out of this class, you should be very comfortable with calculus, mechanics, and some linear algebra. Classes sometimes get bogged down by equations and unfamiliar math, however (if you have a solid physics/math background) you will walk away with some intuition of what is going on. Problem sets are very light; all of the members of the class would go to Physics night and work on the problem together with Prof. Georgi there to help us if we had any questions.I would recommend this class to students who have a very comfortable background in the natural sciences and are looking for a laid–back introduction to their time at Harvard. Also––you get to meet Prof. Georgi, a very sweet faculty member :), in a small group setting. If you are a prospective physics/STEM student, though, it may be advisable to not pick a freshman seminar and instead take a more common class (like Phys 15a or Chem 10) as it will probably be more beneficial for you down the road.
worse_comment: This class is very very advanced. You will almosy certainly pass, but you will probably learn nothing and always be confused.

course_title: Transformative Ideas in Brain Science: War, technology, and disease pioneered discovery 01
best_comment: Take it, you'll love it. The content is fascinating and you get to learn about it through engaging readings, fun trips, and the incredibly knowledgeable Dr. Macklis.Honestly, I felt like this course was my "introduction" to Harvard, in that it was exactly what I hoped my experience here would be like.

course_title: Global Health: Comparative Analysis of Healthcare Delivery Systems 001
best_comment: I loved the lectures — I learned a lot and got to know the other students in my class really well, which is why I highly recommend taking a seminar if you can! The readings were super interesting and informative; you don't need to have much prior knowledge, but awesome if you do! Start working on the final paper early and ask for feedback, it's really helpful and in–depth. Also, ask a lot of questions!! Dr. Saini is SO knowledgeable, so take the opportunity to be inquisitive and free–thinking.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Global Health: Comparative Analysis of Healthcare Delivery Systems

course_title: Digging Egypt's Past: Harvard and Egyptian Archaeology 01
best_comment: The professor is really awesome. He's a fun teacher and he really really loves the material. If you're interested in archaeology definitely take the class.
worse_comment: Professor Manuelian is an incredible person and the course has interesting information about Egypt and Harvard. However, sometimes it did feel a little dull and the book was very difficult to read.

best_comment: Definitely take this class– such a good philosophy class, so so interesting and I had my most stimulated and engaging discussions each week here. The class get super close and comfortable discussing and Cheryl is a great conversation leader. One of my favourite classes this semester.
subject: First Year Seminar

best_comment: Take this course if you are interested in philosophy. If not, it's not worth taking this class only because you're somewhat interested in Nietzsche. His writing is difficult to understand and the readings are heavy each week (almost an entire book each week). Phil 3 or GENED 1025 could be better alternatives if you are interested in an intro–level philosophy course. However, Nietzsche (regardless of whether you like/agree with his philosophy or not) is an important figure in the field. So if you want a solid background in his works, this course is great. Also, don't take this course if you're just looking for an easy class since this class won't be nearly as beneficial or fulfilling if you don't do the readings.

This is generally a good class. The one problem I had with it is it is purely discussion based so much of the time it is people debating rather than the professor teaching. If this is your thing though, then you will like it. It also can become repetitive at times, as the whole class is based on skepticism. However, the professor is extremely enthusiastic about it and is extremely knowledgable. If you are passionate about philosophy, this class will be great for you. It is also very little work and the work that is given is very interesting.
worse_comment: If you enjoy philosophy and difficult conversations, I suggest this course. The material will be difficult, and Prof. Elgin will catch you in some single syllable of your argument and prove you wrong, but its fun! The class will not be easy, but you can get through it.
subject: First Year Seminar

course_title: Borges, García Márquez, Bolaño and Other Classics of Modern Latin American Fiction and Poetry 001
best_comment: I'm gonna be honest, I expected this to be my favorite class this semester and it ended up being my least favorite. It wasn't that bad – the work was manageable and Mariano is very nice – but class discussions honestly sucked and our analysis did not really seem to pry at the true substance of the readings. If I could do it over again, I definitely would've taken a different seminar. This class did introduce me to Borges though and I love it! Mariano is obviously super smart (maybe a bit too smart) but sometimes rambles on and his analysis just feels like a reach sometimes. So often it felt like we were arguing over trivialities as opposed to the actual main ideas of a text.

course_title: Complexity in Works of Art: Ulysses and Hamlet 001
best_comment: What a brilliant course, taught by an even more brilliant professor! This course was the highlight of my semester. The books themselves are, of course, quite exceptional. Hamlet and Ulysses are very, very important works of literature that I am very happy to understand now. But I think that the really central experience of the course is Prof. Fisher's way of teaching Ulysses, which honestly surpasses many of the best monographs on the book. Speaking as someone who has dug into the secondary literature on Ulysses in my free time, the words of Prof. Fisher on the text are literal gold for the serious student of Ulysses. I truly wish he'd written a book about the novel or Joyce in general. He is also incredibly kind, and cares about students so deeply (in some ways, he resembles Leopold Bloom in his kindness and care for how others might feel). An honor to have taken this class, seriously.Plus, the weekly papers are actually really good in the long term in making sure you get something out of the course, especially since it is very easy to give up without further incentive for a book like Ulysses. A lot of work for a freshman seminar, but if you are committed to learning from probably the person who knows Ulysses the best at Harvard, this is your chance.
best_gem_comment: Take it if you like literature!! There is more work for this first–year seminar than others, with one single page (~500 word) response paper a week and weekly readings, but if you are willing to put in the work the class is such a gem (in the sense that it teaches you so much)! Genuinely changed the way I think about life and the world around me. Professor Fisher is also such a great professor. He meets you where you are at in discussions + it's so interesting to even just listen to his perspective and analyses.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Complexity in Works of Art: Ulysses and Hamlet

course_title: The Art and Craft of Acting 001
best_comment: This was an incredible course and Remo is an incredible teacher. I believe the class would agree we learned a lot and built so much trust in each other based off of the activities Remo had us do. Everyone in our class bonded so much and we had a blast together. Remo had us go and see plays every week in Boston which really expanded our knowledge and further bonded the class (and allowed us to explore Boston a bit). We sifted through various techniques to help us gain an understanding on acting, from improv games to a final monologue performance. TAKE THIS CLASS!! It's seriously such a great class to begin your Harvard experience with. Again, you bond with the 12 people you're with and have such a great time. You need no previous acting experience, and this is such a supportive space. I cannot stress enough how amazing Remo is as a teacher.
best_gem_comment: I think Remo is a gem, and this is great to take to build a relationship with him. However, if you are very interested in acting, I feel there are probably better classes to take to make you a better actor.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: The Art and Craft of Acting

best_comment: I think this class is great only if you're super interested in translation, comp lit, or poetry. If you're not interested in any, you'll find the class a bit abstract and vague. I personally loved this class and learned so much from it, but I had mixed feelings in that there was a lot of poetry I had to read and I wasn't honestly expecting that. I don't mind poetry, but when I have to read Oberiu absurdist pieces right after doing two problem sets when my brain is already fried, it can get kind of annoying, especially when you're someone who likes to get the right answer and find the ultimate meaning. I think the ultimate point of this class is that you'll never get that singular message from any work of literature, and that's okay (though you may or may not be satisfied with that answer, that deceptively simple message opens up a lot of room for further complexity and a diversity of interpretations). I really loved the creative aspect of this class and I got to use a lot of interesting theories, ideas, and concepts, and apply them to an assortment of things I got to write. I think you definitely get what you put into this class: this class has definitely showed me that I am still interested in literature (though not that much in poetry) and it has even convinced some of my peers to pursue comp lit or translation studies. The readings were a lot more than I expected, and although you could technically get away without doing them, you'll do yourself an injustice. The films, poems, novels that we read/watch are amazing and will introduce some good ideas. The professor is awesome and super passionate. Sometimes this class goes into very abstract concepts (like Benjamin's "messianic language") and it might feel like you're losing touch with reality, but it's kind of a nice break from the problem–solution oriented courses. However for some people it could be very unpleasant and intangible. So it really dependents on your interests and what you want (ideally you would only apply for this seminar if you really wanted to be in it anyways).
subject: First Year Seminar

best_comment: I would highly recommend this class!! Profesor Ofek is wonderful and encourages engaging and interesting conversations every week. The work load is very minimal – you read one case study a week (around 15 pages) and then are expected to come to class ready to participate in a conversation about what you learned/found interesting. On average, I spent one hour a week outside of class for this course. I came into the class with little to no knowledge about marketing. But, I now am even more interested in the topic and I really enjoyed each case study we looked at. This is a great Freshmen Seminar and I would differently recommend it to any student interested in marketing!
subject: First Year Seminar

course_title: Appraising and Reimagining Middle and High School Math Education 001
best_comment: This is an amazing course and one I would recommend to any student. It completely changed the way I think about education and is something I believe I will carry with me for the rest of my life. It was a transformative examination of the US education system and how we can improve it. The course is a great opportunity to think about big questions and ideas, such as inequality, artificial intelligence, and the purposes of education.

course_title: The American Death Penalty: Morality, Law, and Politics 01
best_comment: This freshman seminar is definitely worth taking! It takes some time to do the readings, but you gain a lot from said readings. If you're not into constitutional law or ethical debates, however, your experience with the class might be different.Professor Steiker is a great instructor, that is an expert in the field. She is passionate about teaching and provides her students with many opportunities to learn more about the death penalty and partake in additional events outside of class. Her feedback is really helpful to improve your writing and if you are interested in more niche topics related to the main topic of the course, she will help you find appropriate resources.
worse_comment: Professor Steiker is undoubtedly one of the most accomplished legal scholars in America today, and in this class, you will get an incredibly in–depth education of the philosophy arguments for and against the death penalty in America today. However, this class is more work than average for a First–Year Seminar, with around 100 pages of reading a week. I also would not recommend this class for people that are interested in the mere politics behind the death penalty, as this class largely explores philosophical arguments behind capital sentencing.

best_comment: This class is absolutely life–changing – TAKE IT! This course was hands down one of the best classes I will likely ever take at Harvard. The combination of the passionate, kind professor with the captivating course content and curated students made learning about human rights life–changing in every aspect. Now, while I am considering a career in human rights, I know that I can apply similar principles of meticulously measured empathy and survivor–centered tactics to any work of public service I may pursue. This course will teach you how to think critically about dense legal texts for the first time, which is extremely useful for the remainder of your undergraduate and post–graduate experience (especially if you want to pursue pre–law!). Susan is one of the kindest, most accomplished individuals you will ever meet and it will be a privilege to learn from her each week.  The readings are dense at first, but if you take the time to read them, you will leave the class feeling well–read and accomplished. Please please please apply to this class!
subject: First Year Seminar

course_title: U.S. Climate Change Policy and the Energy Transition 001
best_comment: If you really are passionate about combatting climate change, environmental conservation, and policy analysis + econ in relation to the energy sector, this is the course for you. Hands down. Professor Stock is very dedicated and goes above and beyond to make sure that every student has their specific climate passion represented in the course. Although most people enrolled in this course have already dedicate a large amount of their time to climate advocacy prior to Harvard, there is still a lot of room for growth of knowledge no matter how familiar you are with climate advocacy. I highly recommend.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: U.S. Climate Change Policy and the Energy Transition

course_title: The Economist's View of the World 001
best_comment: This class was one of the most rewarding academic experiences I've ever had.For some background on myself, I'd had no formal economics background and was simply a student interested in politics and current events anticipating a concentration in economics before law school.To offer some context about the class, Professor Mankiw (crazy successful, crazy cracked economist — even though you wouldn't be able to tell by how down–to–earth and approachable he is,) selects 12 students — 6 that lean left economically and 6 that lean right. Each week, students either read, discuss and debate a book on economics (with topics as diverse as two–parent households to immigration to healthcare) or a classmate's oped (each student is tasked with writing one throughout the semester.) The structure of the class itself is such that, at least in my experience, the group of students selected for the seminar are some of the most talented I've encountered on campus — including upperclassmen I've met who've taken this class in years prior! Second, for someone with no formal economics background, I never felt like I was drowning in this class. Rather, if you keep up with the readings you'll feel more than comfortable when it comes to participating in the debates. (Side note — while it can be easy to skim the readings because it's a low stakes class, I promise if you do stay on top of them it's so much more fun.) Personally speaking, this class deepened my interest in the field of economics substantially, and genuinely made me excited to come to class each week.Perhaps most importantly, while Professor Mankiw's views are generally common knowledge, it never feels like he is spotlighting his opinion in class — something many other professors on this campus could quite frankly learn from. He is incredibly good at removing himself from the conversation and serving as more of a hands–off moderator when it comes to the debates, and as far as I was aware, all students felt comfortable sharing their views from all across the political spectrum. Probably some of the best friends that came out of this class were from "opposite" sides of the aisle. Especially for those students that may lean right economically, this is a space on campus you'd feel most safe to express your views without fear of judgement.If you are seriously interested in this class (it's awesome do it!!) be sure to rank it first — because of the number of students that apply, Mankiw only looks at those applications.To sum it all up, the only broad suggestion I had for the class was to have it meet twice a week — really, it was that good.TLDR: TAKE THIS CLASS, IT WAS ONE OF THE BEST DECISIONS I MADE AS A PRE–FROSH!!

course_title: The Economist's View of the World 001

course_title: Measurements of the Mind: The Creation and Critique of the Psychological Test 001
best_comment: I recommend taking this course! Marla creates such a warm and welcoming environment for her students. This environment allows students to feel comfortable sharing their ideas during discussion from the weekly readings. For the assignments, there are a couple of papers and a final project where you create your own psychological test.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Measurements of the Mind: The Creation and Critique of the Psychological Test

course_title: Science in the Age of Artificial Intelligence 01
best_comment: Loved Brendan's teaching style + he conveyed a genuine enthusiasm for the subject. He's an incredible lecturer, always comes prepared to class, and truly enjoys getting to know his students. Would highly recommend taking this freshman seminar!! Final project was very manageable, and readings for each class are super interesting.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Science in the Age of Artificial Intelligence

course_title: Skin, Our Largest, Hottest, and Coolest Organ: From Cancer to Cosmetics 01
best_comment: I would tell them that not only is it incredibly interesting, but that the professor is amazing and incredibly knowledgeable. His passion for his work and for what he teaches makes a world of a difference and made me as a student excited in turn.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Skin, Our Largest, Hottest, and Coolest Organ: From Cancer to Cosmetics

best_comment: PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS! It will unequivocally transform your life in such beautiful, profound ways! If you love and appreciate nature or the world around you, you will not believe the ways in which this class will make you contemplate and embrace the beauty of life. You do not need to have any experience whatsoever, just make sure you do all you can to take this class — I genuinely believe everyone would love and grow spiritually and emotionally from this class. Professor Friedman’s and Daniel are the cherry on top with their childlike–love and fascination with plants and their relationship to humanity. If you are prepared to rethink your approach and perception of life and what it means to be living, take this class!!!!!!

course_title: Quantum Entanglement and the Second Quantum Revolution 01
best_comment: This class was very enjoyable. I think it is a great way to get introductory exposure to quantum mechanics, especially because it is low stress and low stakes. Some topics that we cover in the class are still very confusing, but the opportunity to learn about quantum mechanics in a low–pressure environment is really great, and I recommend to anyone with even a little interest in physics or quantum.

Definitely take this First–Year Seminar if you want something easy yet interesting. I spent about 1 hour per week on work in this class, but still found it to be fulfilling and a good part of my schedule. The homework assignments are super easy, and if you are serious about topology / knot theory, there are more optional components to the homework if you so wish. The only downside to the course is that the weekly 2 hour seminar meetings are not super engaging, but this is more than made up for in the ease of the course overall, chill atmosphere, and interesting content. Professor Kronheimer is super nice and will definitely answer any math or topology related questions you have! If you’re considering this course at all, please do take it!

course_title: Life and Death Lessons from the Fossil Record 01
best_comment: This class is a really good choice for a first–year seminar! Even if you have just a little bit of interest in fossils and paleontology, take it! Javier is a really kind and thoughtful professor. He's also a really cool person! You also might get to go digging for fossils and keep what you find!
worse_comment: As an incoming first–year, I felt a bit overwhelmed with my course load and wanted to find a seminar that filled my intellectual curiousities but was not too much of a burden. This course is for you if you feel the same and have an interest in fossils, climate change, and what they can tell us about the past/future. There were three short presentations (not bad at all), most readings were optional, and no tests, which reduced the stress of force learning. One qualm – this course takes place at 9 AM. Beware if you are not a morning person. Hopefully, they change it because interesting conversations are inevitable in this class, but it depends on whether you can stay awake.

best_comment: Take this class! It's super low commitment/low stakes (I barely spent any time outside of class) and you see lots and lots of really pretty math. The professor is also such a lovely person and I really appreciated getting to know her over the course of the semester, since she really is a role model within the math department.

course_title: Roots & Routes: The Biogeochemistry of Food, From Soil to Plate 01
best_comment: Take Roots & Routes! Going into this class, my attitude was something along the lines of “I’m going to really enjoy this class, and possibly find my calling in it.” Still not sure about the second half, but I was certainly right that I’d enjoy it. I learned a lot about agri science and systems in a setting that I wouldn’t otherwise have had the ability to. I’d had some spark of interest in agriculture and food prior to this class, but it was instrumental in building out that interest to something much more real. Partly because of 52Q, I applied to a food justice internship for the spring–fingers crossed for that!I think that Ann did a great job of broadening its scope beyond hard science; the majority of the readings were very accessible and many addressed indigenous food ethics & practices, cultural significance of food, and narratives about the science we were studying during class. Of course, I learned a ton about plant and food science as well. It's a pretty chill seminar as far as workload goes; roughly 2 hours of reading per week until week 10, with two very short essays during that time as well, plus one 8–ish–hour group final project.And, as a bonus, Ann brings a themed snack every week, which is especially helpful because it’s a 9am (or at least was this year) but you don’t have to eat breakfast before :)
best_gem_comment: GEM!!! As far as first year seminars go, this has got to be up there with the best of them. Ann does a great job at teaching about food, a key topic in today's world, from a scientific lens, in a stress–free way that is understandable. The course really challenges you to think of food holistically and from many schools of thought that value science as the key player.  The assignments are fun and relaxed, and the final group project (building an operational farm) was definitely a highlight of my semester.  The small class also allows you to meet some great people with similar interests. BONUS OF THIS CLASS:  SNACK TIMEEE!
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Roots & Routes: The Biogeochemistry of Food, From Soil to Plate

best_comment: Amazing class. Professor is truly amazing. His dog Hank is very cool. You take weekly excursions out of campus, get to make some new friends, and overall a very relaxing experience. Professor Taylor keeps things interesting as you wander around, and makes it clear that he intends not to put any academic stress on you. Really great fall semester class to lighten your load and enjoy a weekly trip out of the Harvard bubble (which is so hard to get stuck in!).

course_title: Zombies and Spirits, Ghosts and Ghouls: Interactions between the Living and the Dead 001
best_comment: This class was my favorite class and the professor is so considerate and so excited to discuss and speculate, if you take this class treat him good for he is a treasure.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Zombies and Spirits, Ghosts and Ghouls: Interactions between the Living and the Dead

course_title: Back to the Future: The Cities of Tomorrow Throughout History 01
best_comment: This is one of the best seminars you will take, without question. If you are interested in politics, issues of race/class/ethnicity, and the historical development of cities/nations, this class really is for you. Bruno is a great guy and an excellent instructor, and clearly loves what he is doing; he also is deeply philosophical, so if you seek a philosophical take on the history of our cities, this class will be great for you as well. The assignments are not cumbersome at all, and as it is a seminar, this course really is what you put into it. Do try to put in a good amount of effort into this class, though, because you will get a lot out of it.
best_gem_comment: I would recommend taking this course if you are interested in Hist/Lit or Sociology, but do not go into it as an "urbanist" expecting to revel in the boons of bike lanes. You wil find that Bruno is a top tier professor and a true gem of the college, as well as a very interesting person to speak with on issues around Cambridge!

course_title: Buddhist Enlightenment: Visions, Words, and Practice 001
best_comment: Best seminar ever! You will learn so much, not just about Buddhism but also life in general. Workload very manageable, final project super chill –– initial readings may seem long, but doing the readings is worth it. Professor Abe is the most awesome teacher ever! Highly recommend.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Buddhist Enlightenment: Visions, Words, and Practice

course_title: Memory Wars: Cultural Trauma and the Power of Literature 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! This class was my absolute favorite and it genuinely changed my perspective on how I view cultural trauma. There are a lot of readings for this course being a seminar but they are AMAZING. Plus professor Sutterlin leads wonderful discussions and creates an open environment where it is super easy to express your thoughts and reflect on the readings. No one will regret taking this course!
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Memory Wars: Cultural Trauma and the Power of Literature

course_title: Narrative Negotiations: How do Readers and Writers Decide 01
best_comment: This class is fantastic!! It requires a lot of reading and some textual analysis, but overall, the depth of our class discussions was worth the outside work. Professor Bhabha creates a caring classroom atmosphere that discusses societal and racial issues with sensitivity and thoughtfulness. I highly recommend this course for all first–years looking for a meaningful seminar that pairs together iconic literature (novels by Toni Morrison, Virginia Woolf, James Baldwin to name a few) with conversations around facets of identity. This is a gentle and cozy class that hits at heavy topics in a purposeful way, and I cannot stress how grateful I am that I stuck with it!
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Narrative Negotiations: How do Readers and Writers Decide

best_comment: Professor Love is a very enthusiastic teacher. Take if you are considering going into classics or just like the subject material in general. ***
worse_comment: This course is great, but do not sign up if you are not thoroughly interested in the subject or else you will become so disengaged so quickly.

best_comment: TAKE IT!!! I am not exactly sure if this class will be offered next year, but if it will, take it for sure if you get it as your seminar placement. It was such a fun course, and I enjoyed every second of it. It really changed the way I view art, so if you care about (avant–garde) art even the slightest bit, I highly recommend it. Professor Skakov is absolutely amazing. His teaching style is very interesting, and he is clearly so passionate about the material. He personally knows a lot of important artists in the contemporary art scene, so it is very cool to hear more about it whenever he mentions them. Overall, my favorite course here so far by a huge margin!

TAKE THIS CLASS. You grow really close over with other students and Professor Teskey over the the course of the term and you learn a lot about poetry which is super nice as an introductory element in first year especially if you are passionate about it. I loved this class and would take it again anytime

*** TAKE THIS CLASS *** This was such an amazing class and I don't think I'll ever have a similar experience at Harvard – the small classroom setting, the supportiveness and immense knowledge of the Professor, the kindness and humor of everyone in the class, the topics we discussed, it was all incredible. I would consider myself relatively educated on feminism, but the readings we had in this class opened my eyes so much that I essentially realized my understanding of feminism had been reductionist. This class is honestly an amazing way to learn more about the feminist movement, learn about incredible women whose memoirs you'll read, get really close with a bunch of other people who have similar passions as you, learn from an incredible Professor who's not only extremely knowledgeable but also funny and extremely interesting with tons of stories to share! I can't stress this enough, though it doesn't fulfill any requirements, freshman seminars in general are a great way to get close to a bunch of other people and to professors, and I can't think of a way to better fulfill it than this!

course_title: Recent Experimental Architecture: From AutoCAD to Ziggurat 001
best_comment: This was certainly an interesting class, and it made me think about architecture, as well as the physical spaces and materials around me, in a new way. However, a lot of the discussions we had in the seminar were very abstract and theoretical, to the point where most of it would go over my head and I would wonder what the point of the discussion even was. We referenced quite a few interesting pieces of architecture, but I wish we spent more time dissecting the projects. In addition, a lot of the conversations and readings we had on architecture were western–oriented, and so it was disappointing to not see examples and references to non–western cultures. So unfortunately, in this aspect, the seminar didn't live up to my expectations. For the design portion of the course, Rhino definitely has a good amount of a learning curve, and it can often be frustrating to work with. But with each design iteration, it does become easier to work with, and after many hours and lots of sweat, blood, and tears, it's rewarding to see an idea of a house become an actual, created object. Even though the final project was difficult, I really enjoyed the freedom and creativity associated with it. The highlight of the class though was Professor Holder –– he's such an intelligent person and he always has something poetic and deep to say about virtually everything. Every conversation I have had with him has been so intellectually stimulating, and he is also just such a supportive and nice perso
worse_comment: Not the best course. Readings can be tough, and the format of the class is a presentation by a student of the week's reading for the first half of class and then a discussion of the Rhino assignment we did for that week. Instruction on how to use Rhino was minimal, which made assignments tougher to do.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Recent Experimental Architecture: From AutoCAD to Ziggurat

course_title: The Good, the Bad, and the Beautiful: The Ethics of Art 00
best_comment: This is a great class—a true deep dive into the intersection of philosophy, ethics, and art. As someone with no formal philosophy background (and you definitely don't need any coming in), the formal methods of reasoning in the readings and class really stretched me as a student but were extremely rewarding to work on and think about. The readings are definitely not always the easiest to understand but Quinn helped make everything much clearer in class and we had some super cool conversations.The teaching of this class is great—Quinn is one of the most dedicated, knowledgable, and friendly professors out there and is extremely chill and accommodating. At the same time, I felt like he cared a lot about each of our thoughts and was dedicated to helping us improve our understanding of philosophy, from (extremely!) thorough gradings to cool conversations. ESPECIALLY if you are on the more shy side, I encourage you to speak up as much as you can in class (it's ok to get things "wrong"!!) and go to Quinn's office hours! He has really interesting insight and it honestly just feels good to express your beliefs, and the class starts feeling a little lopsided when only a few people dominate the conversation. Start your assignments early so you have time to chat about them with him. If you are thinking about taking this freshman seminar, I 100% encourage it, but definitely make sure to review the syllabus to ensure that you are interested in the readings—I admittedly didn't look too closely and had a different idea of the class than what it actually ended up being so some weeks felt drier to me because of that. This course is a lot less work than a lot of first–year seminars so a great way to get acclimated to Harvard—you get as much out of it as you put in! Lookng back, I wish I had engaged with the course even more because the ideas are all so interesting!

course_title: The Greatest Love Story of All Time? Heloise and Abelard 01
best_comment: The class was interesting and thought provoking. The reading was long at times, but had engaging topics. The class was more focused on religion and God than about the romance between Abelard and Heloise. Though we had many fun discussions about what we thought about their relationship and about the choices they made.
worse_comment: be ready to sit there and have no idea what’s going on and just listen to him talk because that’s what we did the entire semester and i was bored senseless

course_title: The Modern City and its People: South Asia and Beyond 01
best_comment: This seminar is very nice but it requires a good amount of work, roughly 5–6 hours a week if you do the readings. I would want to emphasize that it is a art history and architecture, as said in the course description; if you want to get better introduced into this sphere of work, I would recommend the course. Professor Khandelwal is also very nice and engaged with his students.

course_title: Who Do You Think You Are?: The Ethics of Identity 01
best_comment: This class is very easy and can be interesting! If you're looking to have a rich discussion and learn a lot, I wouldn't recommend it. If you're looking for an easy class with few assignments, take it! It's all what you make it –– if you are genuinely interested and will do the readings each week, you will definitely enjoy it. For me, it just wasn't incredibly fulfilling/worthwhile.

course_title: Reading Buildings. Understanding Our Built Environment 01
best_comment: The site tours are amazing! Super fun and force you to get out of Cambridge. Prof del Real is super kind and helps to build a relaxed classroom environment. Despite this, be warned that on weeks when you're not touring buildings, the 2hr 45min seminars can get extremely boring, as Prof del Real didn't structure them very well/at all.  Still, the class is overall interesting –– I came in with no interest in architecture, and I've left with a newfound appreciation for the field. Assignments are very fair and doable. (4)

100%  TAKE IT!!! Not too demanding but you will get so much out of it. The discussion–based approach to learning facilitates engaging classes, the reading material is really interesting and thought–provoking, and Professor Badaracco is fantastic. No background knowledge is necessary and this is a super class to take as a freshman to gain confidence voicing your opinions and engaging in intellectual conversation in a supportive environment.
subject: First Year Seminar

course_title: Regulating Online Conduct: Speech, Privacy, and the Use and Sharing of Content 01
best_comment: This course was really insightful into various areas of law, and I really appreciated how we dove into not only the legal implications of the topic, but the social implications as well. At the beginning of the term, the two–hour discussions were a little bit challenging to stay engaged in, but as we transitioned more towards technology, and as the readings became more centered on news than legal proceedings, it became increasingly easier to contribute. Moreover, Professor Bavitz was incredible. He was very personable, very accommodating, and did a great job of weaving in his own professional experience, without overwhelming discussions. Additionally, he was really generous with the external opportunities he advertised. Plus, the online discussions were pretty light, and you didn't need to spend a tremendous amount of time reading all the readings very thoroughly. As long as you had a general idea and thought critically, you could get by well enough. Going into it, I wish the topic of "sharing content" was made a little more clear. I was a little surprised by the amount of intellectual property case material we had to read, and in the beginning, it seemed like more of a general IP seminar than an online conduct seminar. However, I think this course is definitely worth taking if you’re interested in the topic.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Regulating Online Conduct: Speech, Privacy, and the Use and Sharing of Content

course_title: Americans at Work in the Age of Robots and Artificial Intelligence 001
best_comment: Friedman is an excellent professor and a kind man. He is brilliant in that he has read nearly any book you can think of and can recall important themes that apply to whatever the discussion is about. He chooses great readings for each seminar class. At the same time, if you want to get nothing out of this class and not be penalized, you can. But that would be a waste of a truly amazing opportunity to work with one of Harvard's great economists. This course is especially good for humanities students or economics students that do not love the more mathy side of the field. If you get the chance and have some free time, ask him further questions about the readings. He can recommend great academic papers on anything you could think of.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Americans at Work in the Age of Robots and Artificial Intelligence

course_title: Economists on Building a Better Society 01
best_comment: It's a good course! You don't necessarily have to do the readings, but I'd recommend doing most of them since they're interesting and make discussing the books (which is what the course is all about) much more fun. I'd also recommend not feeling intimidated to talk with Jason and reach out to set up meetings. It's a great opportunity to get to hear from and talk with an expert in public policy. It's not too much work at all. A book a week can seem like a lot, but they went quick for me and you really don't have to write much at all.

course_title: Rituals and Living the Good Life 001
best_comment: I would 110% recommend anyone interested to take this class. Professor Norton is so kind, funny, and knowledgable, which makes this course so much more enjoyable. I genuinely looked forward to each meet!
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Rituals and Living the Good Life

best_comment: Take this course! It's a really great survey of a lot of different groups throughout modern history, and you'll find that what you learn about can often have applications to today. My one piece of advice is to force yourself to talk in class. Not only is there a participation part of your grade, but if people are engaged in conversation rooted in their actual beliefs with some healthy debate here and there, it makes the course that much more fun.
worse_comment: Whitham is an interesting character – he is kind of uncomfortable to be around. The course itself is very white savior–y and doesn't touch on anything in Latin America or Africa.  This seminar is definitely not what I thought it would be and it would have been better to take a real class. There were sometimes 300 pages to read for one week which was terrible to do. I got away with not doing the readings by just finding a random quote and making a comment on it or asking a question. Another thing about the course that I didn't appreciate was that Whitham changed the readings with one week's notice to reflect the the israel–Palestine conflict. The readings were very insensitive and during the discussions he would shut you down if you tried to speak on the context of the entire situation. Overall, I wouldn't recommend this class unless you are a white history buff.
subject: First Year Seminar

course_title: Corporate Power & Human Rights—Community Resistance and Social Movements 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU'RE INTERESTED IN HUMAN RIGHTS!! Even if you're not, its a great exposure to the field of human rights and really goes in depth on how to advocate for communities in a strategic way. It is by no means surface level in that we really dive into the specific tactics and strategies we can use to fight for change. I found the class to be incredibly inspiring and empowering and feel like I had learned of several tools to employ in the human rights advocacy space in the future. The atmosphere of the class and students was also amazing – super passionate and inspiring students who genuinely care about creating change and are incredibly intelligent. I think this class is great to meet other like–minded people who are passionate about changemaking and see themselves doing so in the future.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: Corporate Power & Human Rights—Community Resistance and Social Movements

course_title: #Adulting: Social Science Perspectives on the Transition to Adulthood 001
best_comment: This class is definitely worth taking, very interesting and not a terribly difficult workload.
subject: First Year Seminar
course_title_2024: #Adulting: Social Science Perspectives on the Transition to Adulthood

course_title: Is Privacy Dead? Privacy, Surveillance, and Freedom in the Digital Age 001
best_comment: Great seminar! It was much more philosophical than I expected (I thought it would be more tech–oriented), but this was a pleasant surprise and I enjoyed doing something new. Professor Pressly is very knowledgeable and does a great job of facilitating discussion. There's readings every week, but they're not that bad. If you're looking for a lighter class where you can meet new people in, this is a great option.
best_gem_comment: Gem!! I loved this course, definitely one of my favorites here. A MUST TAKE!! Minimal work and Prof Lowry is excellent, super easy to talk to, reachable outside of class, and really wants his students to succeed. The assignments are very easy– a journal post on canvas once a week of 50–500 words. The final project is fair as well. The readings were very interesting– somewhat dense at times. I feel that I learned a lot from this class on real–world topics and a lot about technology, too.

best_comment: Be sure to take this class! It is definitely difficult, and sometimes you will feel like you are being treated less like a college freshman and more like a grad student, but you will never regret taking Oil and Empire. Not only is it an amazing class with interesting and engaging course material (be prepared to read (Prof Bsheer recommends skimming) 100–200 pages a week) but Prof Bsheer is an incredibly knowledgeable and approachable teacher who is interested in teaching the class for the right reasons. She will always be ready to change the topic and engage with what the class really wants to talk about, or even just talk about what's going on around school/in students' lives. Even if it can feel a little intimidating, going to Prof Bsheer's office hours is always a pleasure whether you're going to talk about your research paper or just how your life is going.The research paper should be mentioned. At the end of the semester, a 15 page paper is due. However, the way the deadlines work is that most of it will be due in early November, meaning there is not much to do after besides adding the final section and revising. If left to the last day this is still a lot, but even spread out over a few days it is a very manageable amount of work. It definitely wasn't one of the things stressing me out the most during finals week. You will find that, by the end, you'll be doing the paper less because you have to in order to pass, and more because you want to show yourself and Prof Bsheer that you can do it well.Our class this year became very close, which isn't something that I can promise. But I'll say that among all seminars, Prof Bsheer's is uniquely suited to building a community that goes beyond the classroom. If it is proof: when people asked what seminar I was in and I responded "Oil and Empire," they always seemed to know which one I was talking about, and had only ever heard good things!
subject: First Year Seminar

best_comment: This class is incredible and was one of the highlights of my freshman fall! Please take it if you have any interest in race, racism, or the intersection of science and racism. Professor Fuente was an absolutely incredible teacher. From day one, he asked my peers and I questions that were genuinely very difficult to answer despite the answer seeming obvious when he first posed the question. I truly feel as though my conception of race and the history surrounding racism has been challenged thoroughly by this class, and I can confidently say that I think differently about these topics having taken this class. Each class I felt genuinely stumped by some of the questions we were asked to discuss, and it was exciting how discussions didn't just feel like synthesizing information from readings, but as though we were really trying to arrive at some sort of understanding regarding truly complex issues that wasn't yet obvious at the beginning of class. The way I thought about each reading transformed dramatically by the end of our discussions, which made them feel truly worthwhile. In fact, I can confidently say that this course was one of the most academically fulfilling parts of my semester. If you're looking for a class that will truly challenge you and force you to rethink much of how you conceive of concepts like race, this is the class for you. Furthermore, I'd really like to emphasize what a wonderful teacher Professor Fuente is. Each week, we were assigned a brief essay that reflected on the week's readings, and while this assignment wasn't supposed to be anything more than a summary of our thoughts going into the week's discussion, Professor Fuente took the time to leave thoughtful feedback on every single essay we submitted. Whether it was applauding the thinking I had done or pushing me to wrestle with the readings more, I always felt that Professor Fuente truly cared about what I had to say. I felt the same in class, as he truly gave each student the space to speak, even if we were simply posing more questions to the group. He remembered details we shared about ourself on the first day of class and brought them up when relevant throughout the semester, he took interest in our lives outside of school, and, all in all, he made it clear that he cared about our wellbeing which was very comforting being new on campus. As I've already said, he also genuinely challenged us every week, and it made you want to really pay attention to everything he said each discussion. Professor Fuente is also just a really interesting person with some pretty incredible life experiences he shared with us. The two hour seminar period somehow always felt too short!One thing I will say is that if you are simply looking for the easiest freshman seminar option, this class is probably not for you. Readings in this class were long, with full books being assigned for the week's homework sometimes. In addition to that, there was a short essay due reflecting on those readings each week. However, none of those readings ever felt useless. Each class discussion made it very clear WHY we had read a given text or series of texts, and I believe that attempting to cut some of those out would have sacrificed valuable material from the course. Furthermore, the course is structured chronologically, so you really understand the connection between the various texts throughout the semester. Lastly, I cannot express enough what a wonderful experience this class is, and I think that ought to make the greater–than–average freshman seminar workload worth it. It truly is just a great course with a great professor teaching it, and what you take away from Race Science is so worth a couple of reading cram sessions throughout the semester, especially if the rest of your schedule isn't too rough. Please don't avoid this course because of workload if you think you'll be interested in the content. I literally have nothing but good things to say about it. TLDR: Race Science was one of the best parts of my freshman fall, and I am so grateful to have gotten the chance to be Professor Fuente's student. If you are interested at all by the subject matter take the class. It's a great opportunity to have challenging, in–depth discussions in a small–group setting with other students who are similarly passionate about the course content (I loved my classmates in this course!!!!). I'd absolutely recommend giving this course a try, and I'm so happy to have taken it.
subject: First Year Seminar

course_title: The Wedding Complex: Race, Gender, and Sexuality in Love and Marriage 01
best_comment: TAKE. THIS. CLASS!!! I cannot recommend it enough. I learned so much about the intersections of gender, race, class, consumerism, and sexuality in this class. It covers a ton of content and is super insightful. The most difficult part is the readings. If you want to get the most out of this class you need to do the readings and prepare for discussions, and that is time–consuming. Most of the readings are alright, but some of them are very long or dense. Once you do the readings, though, the rest of the class is pretty easy. The discussions are largely student–led and you will learn a ton from your peers.  There are very few assignments; outside of one assignment at the beginning of the semester, the midterm, and the final, it is just discussion boards. You only need to do 8 discussion boards for the class (though you may find yourself voluntarily doing more) and they are short, informal, and open–ended, so there is very little pressure associated with them. Professor Light is incredibly intelligent and sweet, and she also brings food for students every week! You will not regret taking this class, it is so interesting and it has changed the way I think about everything, I regularly find myself analyzing art with tools I gained in this class or bringing up insights from class in discussions with friends because it is just THAT relevant.

Like any seminar, only take it if it's something you're genuinely interested in. There are a decent amount of readings, and you will get so much more out of it if you genuinely pay attention to them. It's helpful to have some understanding of economics and economic theory–– there are two weeks on Marx, and he loves to yap.  Overall, it's a wonderful seminar. Professor Marglin brought us apples every week from his orchard, and has tons of cool stories that he shared with us! He's a great professor and an even better person. Whether you're a capitalist, a socialist, a communist, or have no idea, I urge you to take this seminar!!
subject: First Year Seminar

best_comment: Amazing class! Super interesting if you pay attention... but also you don't have to if you don't want to. Dr. Craycraft is a gem and has so many connections in the field. It felt like she personally knew every author we read. She clearly stated three different tracks at the start of course, essentially outlining what you should do if you want to be super checked in and what to do if you want to do the bare minimum. Loved the transparency of it and learned a lot about myself through the course. The assignments are super chill and easy if you don't wait until the last minute. 10/10 would recommend!
best_gem_comment: Quite the gem, easy assignments and interesting material

best_comment: Amazing class! Super interesting if you pay attention... but also you don't have to if you don't want to. Dr. Craycraft is a gem and has so many connections in the field. It felt like she personally knew every author we read. She clearly stated three different tracks at the start of course, essentially outlining what you should do if you want to be super checked in and what to do if you want to do the bare minimum. best_gem_comment: Quite the gem, easy assignments and interesting material

best_comment: This class is great! There are a lot of readings but since class is weekly you'll have a fair bit of time to do them. The assignments were incredibly flexible and manageable. Professor Lufkin was great to have in class! She would sometimes have treats for us and make us some yummy fresh bread, but she also had good energy during class.
best_gem_comment: This is an amazing class to take and such a gem! Professor Lufkin cares so much about each student and about the subject, and it is genuinely interesting regardless if you know a lot about tattoos already.
subject: Folklore & Mythology

course_title: Stories from the End of the World 001
best_comment: This course is fantastic! I did not anticipate learning so much regarding the philosophical and social implications involved in eschatology coming into the class, but loved a lot of the sections we had that supported more collaborative discussions of these topics. For me, this class was a relatively easy fourth class on top of a difficult course load of three really heavy classes, and I found that to be exactly what I needed. My TF (Andrew Deloucas) was absolutely phenomenal and had a huge impact on my overall experience and engagement in the class –– biggest shoutout to him! While this class exposed me to quite a lot of interesting, thought–provoking media that I would otherwise not have sought out myself, I must say that much of the course readings are quite dry and dense to get through, so much so that a summarizer will become your best friend even after you've perused through ~200 pages of reading per week.
worse_comment: Don’t take this class. Teaching team is abhorrently bad. Based on my final grade, you need AFVS level skills to receive an A on the final and it’s entirely unrelated to your comprehension of course content.
best_gem_comment: Gem GENED that is actually interesting. You should lottery for this class.

best_comment: I really enjoyed this class and think it is a great option to fulfill your GENED requirements. It is low–stress, with no exams and one assignment or project component per week. Lecture and section attendance is graded, but lecture is actually really fun and engaging so it wasn't a problem. Professor Rehding is awesome and really passionate about what he teaches.**
worse_comment: this class is not the easy class you want it to be. Somehow you neither talk about music nor about space very much, but the debate was interesting to watch because people had some crazy takes about colonialism. That was my favorite lecture. Otherwise, this class is a royal waste of time and a waste of the art/aethetics requirement
best_gem_comment: Absolute GEM! Definitely take this class, Prof Reading is the GOAT and is super chill, makes lectures interesting, and grades VERY EASY. There are weekly assignments but they are either not much work or REALLY FUN to do and you get to just be creative which doesn't happen a lot at Harvard. Must take

course_title: Contemporary Developing Countries: Entrepreneurial Solutions to Intractable Problems 001
best_comment: This is not an easy GenEd, but it is not a bad one either. It is just average. I mean, it is not totally boring but not a lot of fun or super engaging. It simply is. Like most GenEds are. It was an okay course in that sense. The grading is very cryptic though (not great feedback, sometimes obvious downgrading) and the expectations are quite high for the project you work on all semester. Most of your grade depends on this work you do as a group, so make sure you find a group that is involved and willing to put in the work. I have the feeling that having a good group made all the difference for me –– we met frequently,  we were all working on the solution we chose to develop, and we had peaceful and friendly interactions. Working with my group was, many times, more engaging than attending lectures (and they are serious about attendance...). I thought lectures were particularly meh sometimes, and I don't know if I learned much from them. Sections were more useless than lectures, but you have attendance for that too. Make sure you are actually interested in problems in developing countries, make sure you want to do group work, read some business cases (readings aren't really mandatory, and you have to pay 50 bucks for them)...be ready for a lot of white savior type of conversations, sometimes eye rolling comments if you are from a non–harvard–traditional background lol. Anyways, this is not a bad course, also not gemmy. This was interesting as far as taking a business–style class is. You also get a different lecturers every 2 weeks or so, which is pretty unique. Since I'll probably not take any HBS classes, this is the closest to it my college experience offers.
worse_comment: This course embodies pretty much every GENED red flag you can think of. Group project work, no pass/fail or auditing, unnecessarily harsh grading with no feedback, mandatory lecture attendance without a good system in place for measuring it, and a considerable amount of work. This is a shame because the course topic and the content is actually very interesting to learn about. I'm afraid that at the moment the bad outweighs the good and therefore I can't recommend this class in its current state.
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: Contemporary Developing Countries: Entrepreneurial Solutions to Intractable Problems

subject: General Education
course_title_2024: Contemporary Developing Countries: Entrepreneurial Solutions to Intractable Problems

best_comment: This class is very interesting, but can be easy to skip lecture sometimes. It is worth going to lecture because they are interesting, well thought out, and give great context for the readings and thus the course assignments. Overall, this was a wonderful course that provides details on the nuance of U.S. occupation, without being at all one sided in favor or against the policies overall. This course is certainly what you make of it, as you may be able to get away without doing the readings on time or without attending all the lectures; however, I would recommend doing the readings and attending lecture because of the valuable knowledge and perspective you will gain from doing so.
worse_comment: Do not take it if you want to just fulfill your gened requirement. Cool concept but a lot of work and prep necessary for section. Also very intimidating for first–years.

best_comment: This class is very interesting, but can be easy to skip lecture sometimes. It is worth going to lecture because they are interesting, well thought out, and give great context for the readings and thus the course assignments. Overall, this was a wonderful course that provides details on the nuance of U.S. occupation, without being at all one sided in favor or against the policies overall. This course is certainly what you make of it, as you may be able to get away without doing the readings on time or without attending all the lectures; however, I would recommend doing the readings and attending lecture because of the valuable knowledge and perspective you will gain from doing so.
worse_comment: Do not take it if you want to just fulfill your gened requirement. Cool concept but a lot of work and prep necessary for section. Also very intimidating for first–years.

course_title: How to Build a Habitable Planet 001
best_comment: Great class that you will actually learn a lot from. This class made me think about things in a different perspective, learning about the big bang all the way to present–day. Learned lots about how food production is a main cause of climate change; this is one example of a topic I never thought about but is truly important. Also teaches you how to defend theories such as the big bang, plate tectonics, and evolution, which was interesting. I love professor Charlie—he has a true passion for the class, likes to make jokes in lecture, and does fun real demonstrations to prove topics. Not too stressful of a class, with the final project, midterm, and final exam being the main stressors. Would highly recommend this class—it's a gened that you will really take a lot from.
worse_comment: Don't take this class. It is deceptively hard for a genEd and requires an unfair amount of background information that most people don't have. People were so stressed about grading that a large amount of the class switched to pass–fail so this class wouldn't tank their GPA. On top of that, Charlie is so antiquated. He regularly says misogynistic and racist things and refuses to listen when students or TFs raise concerns. I found it extremely frustrating to sit in lecture and hear him say outrageously problematic things, only to raise red flags that wouldn't change anything. He very much thinks that, because he is a big name in EPS, his word is final, and has no patience for anyone disagreeing with anything he says. Cut your losses and take an easier gen ed or a gen ed with a better prof.
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: How to Build a Habitable Planet

course_title: The Caribbean Crucible: Colonialism, Capitalism and Post-Colonial Misdevelopment In The Region 001
best_comment: Take it!! This course is very interesting, covering both the history and current state of the Caribbean. Professor Patterson is super knowledgeable about the Caribbean and very passionate about the topic.Section mostly tells you what you need to know for the exams and paper, so definitely attend section because lectures don't discuss the structure of the assignment. Readings are dense, however they are not required, although they will help you engage with the material and do better on exams. The end of the semester is a lot since it is a final paper and a final exam, however it's a fair class since there is not much work throughout the semester outside of the midterm. Overall, this course is great. I'm glad I took it and absolutely recommend it to those looking to complete the History gen ed!!!!!
worse_comment: the class is interesting, but it can be really be really frustrating because there's not a lot of support in completing assignment, and expectations for assignments and tests can be confusing.

best_comment: I really highly recommend that you take this GenEd! It is a great introduction to philosophy and breaks down philosophical concepts and thinkers in a way that is very palatable. The course seems like it was less of a gem than in previous semesters because there are a lot of assignments, but they're all very easy, manageable, and not time consuming. Grading was super flexible as well. The busywork is annoying, but it's very easy to do well in this class. I also liked the Professor. Lectures seem like they would be dry because they're just an hour and 10 minutes straight of pure lecture (no slides, no demonstrations, some Q&A but otherwise not interactive), but I found them to be very well–paced and engaging. Prof. Rinard is a very interesting person who frequently says out of pocket things that certainly keep you interested in lecture! This is a philosophy class about meaning of life, purpose, happiness, and how to live your life well, so if you're not ready to think about those topics then don't take this class. But otherwise, I'd definitely recommend it!
worse_comment: Don't take this class, it is a waste of time. The professor is especially bad and very annoying during lectures because of the many "jokes" she tries to make. Whole class could have been a lot better if the professor stopped coming to "teach" and just posted the lecture notes instead. I would have learned more.
best_gem_comment: I have no regrets about taking this course! After reading Q–guide reviews, I was doubtful, but I took the class and was so pleasantly surprised. I think the Q–guide comments I read were from people who expected the class to require zero effort, which is unrealistic. Don't take it because you need a GEM; take it because you are interested in the material. It is an easy, manageable course if you simply attend the lectures, take notes, and complete the very simple assignments. The readings were most often short (just a few pages), and even if they were a little longer, they were really interesting a lot of the time, so it was great. I felt interested and engaged during lectures, and I laughed a lot too. Professor Rinard is really tuned in to the material, and her anecdotes and funny stories about her own life made the lectures more memorable for me. I found the material very applicable to my own life – not just interesting from a philosophical standpoint. HIGHLY RECOMMEND! :)
subject: General Education

best_comment: I would absolutely recommend this class to any student in any concentration! Though I was unsure at first if the topic would be interesting, I really found it to be a worthwhile and a stress–free learning process. Both Professor Blair and Professor Whittington are wonderful lecturers who make the material engaging and exciting. Additionally, Victoria is amazing TF who grades fairly and makes section a good discussion time. The assignments are all manageable and relevant for completing the capstone proeject. The midterm and final are also reasonable assignments and the teaching staffs give a lot of support in helping you successfully complete them. (Tip: make sure to choose a capstone text one you are actually interested in…because you will be refering to it in many different assignments). Furthermore, the field trips are so much fun and very insightful. Overall, I very strongly advise you to lottery and take the course.
best_gem_comment: GEM GEM GEM!!! Professors are wonderful, TF's are amazing, very little workload, easy grading, and many field trips! Make sure to go to section and lectures though – attendance is taken at both.
subject: General Education
gened: Aesthetics and Culture; Histories, Societies, Individuals

Though I was unsure at first if the topic would be interesting, I really found it to be a worthwhile and a stress–free learning process. Both Professor Blair and Professor Whittington are wonderful lecturers who make the material engaging and exciting. subject: General Education
gened: Aesthetics and Culture; Histories, Societies, Individuals

best_comment: First–Year FGLI:Take this course if you get the chance to!! Professor Yoda is well–articulated, knowledgable, and understanding. I didn't get to interact with her one–on–one a lot when I took the course, but I knew she was very passionate about teaching the course. I will be frank, as a first–year I was intimidated by the amount of knowledge and ideas of discussion being thrown at me, and I never really knew anime had so many layers to it. I think there is a slow start at the beginning of the course, but overall it ramps up as the weeks go by. Analyzing  anime that are outside of the box and even mainstream like Sailor Moon and Gundam was very interesting, and led to very interesting discussions. If you have never taken a film analysis class and want to take on that is somewhat an introduction to it this would be it. If you love anime, or want to learn more about why people are obsessed with anime, take this class. If you need a class to fill your senior schedule, or fulfill your Arts GenEd, this class is perfect!
worse_comment: This class doesn't have a lot of graded work, but the actual graded assignments can sometimes be graded harshly. They kind of expect a background in film analysis which I didn't expect, and a lot of the topics are really confusing. Lots of class time, two weekly lectures, section weekly, and a two hour screening every week. Section didn't really make sense and the topics were random, my classmates and I struggled to contribute to the discussion because it just didn't make sense

course_title: American Dreams Made in Hollywood and Beyond 001
best_comment: I am SO glad that I took this course. I truly had an amazing experience. The workload was present, but manageable (weekly 200–300 responses), the only criticism was the amount of readings for some weeks. Usually they were okay, but especially on weeks where you had to watch two films, we're talking about almost 100 pages of reading which can be quite backbreaking on occasion. The films were so touching, and truly thought out. It made me have an incredibly different outlook on the idea of the American Dream and how American history has shaped this narrative. Furthermore, I feel like I know so much more about films, the canon and the movies that laid the groundwork for what we see now. The lectures were incredibly engaging. Professor Rentschler is very articulate and brought up many film and pop culture connections in his speech, along with audiovisual elements. I loved how it was in a movie theater esque setting instead of your typical desk and chair kind of room. I wish there was more engagement between the professor and the students though. I don't think I have even had a single conversation with him, and his office hours are usually zoom and not in person. The section felt more of like the class than the class itself. Overall, I definitely recommend, especially if you're a film aficionado and are interested in seeing the entertainment that brewed alongside US history.
best_gem_comment: Professor Rentschler is a gem! He's so passionate about the subject matter and about film–– just a really wholesome guy. If you're interested in watching a ton of classic movies and analyzing them in cool ways, take this. Very little work besides watching the movies, a fair midterm, and a pretty open–ended final paper. Solid class.

best_comment: First off, this class is amazing and also a gem. You will have to put in a bit of work (maybe an hour or two) a week outside of class. Take this class if you need the Gen Ed req. out of the way and want a fun interactive course. The class is centered around the final project where you present as another person in your section – forget the acting techniques, how to be Marlon Brando, or method acting stuff. I remember reading the q guide last year about this course and a comment said that "this class was more of a social psych class than anything" which now I could not agree more with. For the first two weeks, you learn various acting methods and watch classic films trying to analyze the methods at play, which I LOVED. After you draw the sticks in section, you then learn theory on social presentation (Plato's allegory of the cave, Aristotle etc) and dive into complex social problems and their intersection with acting (race–based casting etc). At some points, the discussions felt a little forced along the lines of "let's have a meaningful progressive conversation just for the sake of it, to feel good about ourselves, and most importantly to sound modern and smart".  As you can tell, I took this class hoping to be Marlon Brando and did not achieve that (I learned to be someone else though!). However, I am so glad that I took this class. The community you gain from participating in this class  is exceptional. I've met some great friends from section and now we have an amazing bonding experience (learning to act like someone else in section and portray that) that we can continue to talk about for years to come.  I am so glad I took this class!
best_gem_comment: First off, this class is amazing and also a gem. You will have to put in a bit of work (maybe an hour or two) a week outside of class. Take this class if you need the Gen Ed req. out of the way and want a fun interactive course.
