course_title: The Global Heart Disease Epidemic: Stopping What We Started 001
best_comment: I HIGHLY recommend this class. It is the best class I've taken at Harvard––it teaches you about life, healthcare, and politics all at once in digestible ways. You also get to hear from patients of Dr. Lee's who all have such unique stories! My favorite moments in the class were when the patients came in––I could see my parents, my friends, me, as them. I loved hearing their stories, and I also loved hearing Rich's stories. He is so clearly a caring, thoughtful professor who truly cares about both his students and his patients, which definitely comes through in lectures. He also is so passionate about the work he does and the good he believes we can "bring to our little corner of the world" (which will stay with me forever). SO much love for this class. The teaching team was wonderful (shoutout to Nile! SO cool) and Rich was amazing and the course was so informative and life changing. PLEASE TAKE IT!!
worse_comment: the lectures suck, you'll be taught to be more judgmental towards fat people, lack of consideration of mental health when talking about issues of weight loss and addiction
best_gem_comment: One of the best geneds out there!The class is a gem!This gened has the best effort–vs–learning ratio. The assignments are extremely chill. The professor is nice.– You get to learn and be certified in CPR– You finally internalize all the correct advice on nutrition and exercise. This class literally changed my life as I now have a new diet, a different workout routine, and quitting alcohol (best dosage is zero dosage). These are all things that you probably knew, but this course will make you really understand the advice and take them into advice.– After this class you gain, on average, 10 extra years of healthy life to spend with your loved ones. Bonus years if you spread advice around so your loved ones also get those extra years. Maybe even more.Lastly, I think crimson cart shoppers might have subconsciously avoided this class because of the title "heart disease" and people might have the wrong preconception that it is boring since the class is probably full of pre–meds or that the shoppers have the evolutionary instinct to avoid diseases (even its representation as the English word). But that is a mistake. Sure, the class attracts a bunch of pre–meds, but I am not a pre–med and I love this class so much! The content is very accessible and interesting. Everything you learn from this class can be applied in your life. For the second point, good for you if you can overcome the evolutionary instinct to avoid diseases and check this class out and read this qguide comment because you have found one of the great courses of Harvard. Good for you. Now gatekeep this and take it and have fun.
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: The Global Heart Disease Epidemic: Stopping What We Started

best_comment: Great class. Interesting, good material, Professor Henrich is excellent. A good, fair person, too. One of the most interesting thinkers alive. Even if you have no idea what evolutionary biology is (I didn't walking in), it would be worth your time.
worse_comment: This course was not very fun. The lectures could be tedious at times and having the readings and assignments on perusall was not great, especially because it made studying for exams more difficult as you can't easily organise your notes. The quiz system is "generous" – lowest quiz grade is dropped and quizzes are weighted. However this is meaningless as the class is curved regardless. All this generous grading does it make it more difficult to distinguish between students.The subject matter was pretty interesting though
best_gem_comment: I wouldn't call this course a gem, but if evolutionary bio comes naturally to you then it's a pretty stress–free course. Perusall and mandatory attendance are honestly incredibly annoying, but neither require true effort. The best part is that there are absolutely no assignments. There's a bunch of quizzes, which can be difficult if you don't understand the concepts well; however, if you understand bio or neuro or oeb type content then the answers are pretty intuitive regardless of how much effort you have put into the class. And the best part is, the content in the course is actually really interesting!The worst part of the course is that you read about the same content, then watch a video lecture on that content, then learn about that content in person, and the go to section to learn about that content. They treat you like you are an ec10 student (yeah, it's that bad).
subject: General Education

course_title: Moral Inquiry in the Novels of Tolstoy and Dostoevsky 001
best_comment: Take this course if you like literature. You will hear from your peers that this is the only interesting ethics GenEd, and while I cannot confirm this statement because I do not have evidence about the alternatives, I can tell you that if you do not find ethics and civics fascinating (which I do not), you may still love this class. I loved this class. I am no philosophy major, but I am an enjoyer of literature, so you may want to take my opinion with a grain of salt. But I loved this class.In terms of workload: The midterms are hard — you'll have to have either paid attention in every lecture, have a friend who did that, or reread the novels — and it comes out to about 200 pages of reading per week on average. Thus, I wouldn't take it as a third or fourth reading class. I took it with all STEM classes besides so it was a nice change of pace, and I also read quickly, so again you may want to take my opinion with a grain of salt, but the reading is enjoyable and not too dense for the most part so it does go by relatively quickly. All in all though, I'd recommend. Professor Weir is a delight, and the TFs want you to succeed.
worse_comment: Must take class, id rec taking it pass fail because these are need to read books
best_gem_comment: This is a super cool gen ed to take; a lot of reading (which isn't so bad bc I loved Anna K) but the midterms will really test you on the material so you can't get away with not doing all the readings. Kinda hard, esp for a gen ed, but the prof knows the material so well and you will leave this class having learned a lot and read some of the greatest novels ever written. So be aware that this is no gem, but honestly you're at Harvard and you should read these famous texts in a classroom setting.

course_title: African Spirituality and the Challenges of Modern Times 001
best_comment: I really liked the Professor, super intelligent and has a lot of background in the field. In terms of work, most weeks didnt have to do anything aside from attend lecture. Some may say there’s a decent amount of work, but I prefer having a couple chances to perform well and up my score ( group pres, creative interview, midterm papers (short), and a final (10 pages)) rather than one big paper or in person midterm that everything hinges on. Also lots of interesting material, and you can literally choose any aspect of the class to focus your projects on! Super good highly recommend for this requirement
worse_comment: This is up there with the worst classes I've taken at Harvard. Nobody pays attention in class and the lectures are extremely disorganized.  I'm struggling to identify things that I learned outside of the material that I researched for my papers or project. It just felt like a massive waste of time. The class is easy, though, so if you don't care about learning the material, then you should take it.
best_gem_comment: Take this class if you're looking for a GEM, but also make sure you're actually interested in the subject matter. If you're not, it can be pretty easy to lose motivation for the assignments and slack off.
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: African Spirituality and the Challenges of Modern Times

best_comment: tl;dr it's not a hard course but if you don't like ancient greek literature you will not enjoy it. Have fun with the writing assignments and follow the instructions and you will most likely do well. This course has a couple things that really affect your grade: labors (little comprehension quizzes), creative assignments, the midterm essay, the final essay, and section attendance. I think basically all the TFs don't really care if you attend lecture but I did hear about one TF who did roll call with their section during lecture but that was only one I'm fairly sure. Attend section! It's kinda fun but they do have section makeup assignments if you miss a couple. The labors are kind of annoying but you don't have to do very well on them (I usually got 3/5 questions correct), since they're each like 3% of your grade. Make sure to have fun with the creative assignments! The ones where I put my creativity in it I definitely felt happier with than weeks where I just mashed something together, but generally I got about the same score, but do submit them on time because the late day penalty does add up and it's more worth it to submit a worse assignment than a late one. The midterm essay was kind of fun and pretty chill! The final essay was somewhat strangely structured imo but the 75 minutes was enough time for me and you have most of the assignment details before so you can review material before writing. Overall it was a pretty decent class and not too stressful, the TFs are very nice about answering questions (I had Arin and she was great !!),  I didn't find the lectures helpful whatsoever, but the class overall was a decent break from my other coursework since I like Ancient Greek literature but if you don't like it I would be cautious.
worse_comment: Lectures are extremely boring, and I guarantee not one person was paying attention. Take this course if you want to waste one of your class slots and basically do other classwork during lecture, The professor is a sweetheart, but the overall format of this course is terrible. Erin is easy to reach and the head TFs are pretty generous when it comes to extensions.  You can get away without doing the readings, just know a brief summary of the key points for the "labors". The "creative" writing assignments revolve around death, or envisioning yourself dying in 10+ years from now. One of the assignments was a drawing of that. Grading is a lot harsher than it should be, especially for a class on greek mythology, also heavily dependent on your TF. Joao is known as the harshest grader and you're expected to have read the readings and the handouts he emails us, whether it be an hour or a week before section. He also cold calls during section. Used to be a gem, but seems to be getting harder as the years pass, also given that this class will most likely get a different professor in the future. You'll get at least an A– if you put the slightest amount of effort in the assignments, but much more difficult to get an A. There are a lot better Geneds for the aesthetics and culture requirement, and I fully regret taking this course. Do not recommend.
best_gem_comment: This is of course a GEM, but also a really fun class too. The weekly assignments are creative and enjoyable,  the readings are not necessary,  and even the midterm/final are presented in a way that makes them not overly boring or honed in on the specifics of Greek texts. I can't believe I'm saying this but this class actually made learning about ancient Greek literature fun – truly a great class.
subject: General Education

course_title: Disease, Illness, and Health through Literature 001
best_comment: This class is taught like a high school English class. There are so many strict rules that are unlike any college class I've taken. For example, attendance is only counted through reading checks, but if you miss the first 5 minutes of class and the Professor moved on, you can't turn in a reading check even if you showed up for the remaining 1 hour 10 minutes of class. Also, you are forced to write in your journal for like 5–10 minutes every class in silence then discuss what you wrote with your peers, and if you don't do what they ask when they ask, there will be a TF literally standing over you to make sure you're either actively writing or talking to your neighbor. The instructions for each assignment are longer than the assignment itself because they spell out every little detail, which you might think is helpful but they only cover procedures and requirements rather than tips for doing well. Class culture aside, the content is super interesting if this is your first medical humanities class. The readings are awesome and pretty straight forward, and the section in this class was one of my favorite sections in any class. It's engaging, asks interesting questions, and personally interesting to many students, pre–med or otherwise.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS! I don't care what anyone else says –– find another way to fulfill your pre–med English requirement. This course is NOT worth the struggle.The course includes daily quizzes on unnecessarily lengthy readings. I also found it incredibly frustrating that we were required to purchase certain course readings. It seems unreasonable to be quizzed on material that incurs an additional cost, especially when numerous freely available literary works could be used instead (not to mention that this approach limits accessibility to the course for students facing financial challenges).Of all my classes, this one was the least flexible in terms of absences and coursework. Making students write a 500–word response to make up an EXCUSED absence is insane. Throughout the semester, it really seemed as if the staff was working against students. Much of the teaching staff appeared unsupportive, strict, and quite frankly, pretentious. The grading was also very harsh. It felt as if the course was made to be strict and difficult just for the sake of being strict and difficult!!!For a course that takes itself so seriously, it's not even good.  While some readings were interesting, the lectures were incredibly dull and the class discussions felt very forced and unproductive. Our readings would be about serious topics regarding patient health and terminal illnesses, and then we would just talk about...similes and metaphors in class?This is also one of those classes where everyone in section is quiet...even the TF. Assignments were also graded very harshly! This class made me feel miserable.

course_title: Why Is There No Cure for Health? 001
best_comment: I LOVED this class! It's more work than some geneds, but is so worth it. Lectures are engaging and projects, though not insignificant in length, are genuinely interesting. It's a flipped classroom, which I wasn't a fan of at first so give yourself time to get used to the format. Professor Cutler makes it work well –– he's a good lecturer and definitely cares about student learning. Please take this class –– you'll come out with a much better understanding about the U.S. health care industry.
worse_comment: Take this course!!!! Such a special class that reminds you that you are at Harvard. Professor Cutler invited such profound and engaging speakers each week, ranging from ex– senate majority leader to prior head of the CDC to Pfizer execs. There are no stressful exams, everything is project–based or psets and do not require too much time.

course_title: How Music Works: Engineering the Acoustical World 001
best_comment: Absolutely amazing class – take it! Not only are the subject material and projects extremely interesting, but the teaching staff is straight–up GOATED. Professor Rob Wood is truly such a kind, chill person, and you can tell he’s genuinely passionate about what he teaches. (He’s also a very talented electric guitarist!) The TFs are also amazing (shoutout to Ian Griffith!) – legit some of the nicest and most understanding people I’ve met here. The workload is extremely doable, and not having to worry about exams is also a huge blessing. If you’re looking for a chill gened with awesome teaching staff and are interested in the intersection between science and music, take this course! I promise you won’t regret it.
best_gem_comment: Take this class if you enjoy the topics. You get out the exact amount you put in. You don't have to pay attention in lecture, but if you do, the class is so much more enjoyable. I wouldn't classify this as a gem in general, but, for me, it been my favorite class so far.
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: How Music Works: Engineering the Acoustical World

best_comment: The lectures were minimally informative, and contained material that could easily be flagged as highly racist and supporting incompetence. The  section topic was completely unrelated to the course – focusing on whether trans athletes should be allowed to compete in women's sports for all but the last three sections. The content that was relevant was discussed only in the final part of the course (on black maternal mortality), and even then the resources were highly inadequate. I took this course because I wanted to learn more about reproductive health and how that varies across the world, how it intersects with various social and economic issues, and how we can address that. The course description alluded to bringing these topics to justice, however, I have learned absolutely nothing about them. If you actually want a meaningful course,  truly want to learn about the first nine months of pregnancy, and in general want to emerge a more enlightened and well rounded student, stay away from this course. Take your time, effort, and intellect elsewhere.  You have a unique opportunity to study at this university, please do not waste it on a course like this.
worse_comment: THIS CLASS IS A COLOSSAL WASTE OF TIME AND A DISASTER.  DO NOT TAKE IT. “But it’s a gem.” THAT DOESN’T MATTER. YOU WILL LEARN NEXT TO NOTHING, IF NOT NOTHING.Since lectures were optional, maybe 20 out of 130 people attended. And a bunch of people didn't do the readings. There was no homework through which to digest any of the material –– so even if one went to lecture (which, by the way, was often cut off HALF AN HOUR EARLY), it was in one ear and out the other. Consequently, there was a ridiculous amount of dead air in sections; people didn't know anything. We got next to nothing if not nothing done on a given day. (And the TF really tried.) There's a culture where people aren't taking the class to learn (but are just there to knock out a requirement without having to do any work) and drag the people who want to learn down with them. And DAVID HAIG IS THEIR BIGGEST ENABLER.But even without those people, it's practically impossible to learn anything from this class. A given slide has around fifteen words on it if any words at all, so even though Prof. Haig posts them, there's basically nothing to learn from them. And taking notes is a lost cause. One last time: I AM BEGGING YOU NOT TO TAKE THIS CLASS.Or if you’re somehow still considering taking it after reading this, TAKE IT PASS/FAIL because it is very, very hard to try in a class that feels like an especially mind–numbing middle school class.
best_gem_comment: THIS CLASS IS A GEM! I barely did any work for this class and the section discussions were actually interesting. I enjoyed debating about the extent to which transgender women should be allowed to play in women sports. I didn't care for the case study as much, but it was still important to know.

best_comment: I suggest taking this course. You leave as a better informed citizen, and even if you don't plan on concentrating somewhere in the humanities, this class not only fulfills a requirement for you but is manageable and genuinely immersive. Like you actually understand the U.S and all the socioeconomic and political issues that plague it way better after. It's not hard to keep up with either – the course load is very manageable, doing the readings in full is not necessary to have an educational experience (or for your grade tbh lol) and from what I've heard, most sections are hosted well and easy to deal with. My section was amazing, and genuinely my favorite section to attend out of all of my classes (thank you Caleb!). You have interesting conversations, and some of your beliefs may actually be challenged and/or changed. For the most part, the grading is fair, so you can enjoy this class without worrying about leaving with an unsatisfactory grade. Overall, great class, grading is good, sections and content are interesting, and outside work, besides finals week (lol) is minimal.
worse_comment: the information is interesting but sadly the course is very disorganized and the grading is harsher than other geneds. I cant explain the times I asked for clarification for assignments and exams . It was frustrating dealing with interesting information that is not organized for easier comprehension. Every lecture is like an average of 80 slides . I am not really sure why I had to guess how to do my assignments most of the time . It was quite unfortunate as a pre–law that actually cares about the info.
best_gem_comment: It isn’t a standard gem due to the coursework, but it is still very doable to do well and also learn interesting things.

subject: General Education

course_title: Who Lives, Who Dies, Who Cares? Reimagining Global Health 001
best_comment: GENED 1093 was the first GENED I’ve taken during my time at Harvard, and it was definitely one of the best decisions I could’ve made. During Fall, 2023, GENED 1093 took away the midterm and mini–paper requirements, making your grade solely dependent off of 4 quizzes given in section (worth 10% each) and a final paper (+ attendance/participation). The quizzes are EXTREMELY easy and the staff also release a topic bank a week beforehand, which provide a list of 5 sample questions of what may be asked. Then, on the day of, the quizzes often provide a list of 5 questions that very closely mimic the topic bank, often only adding a few more specific details on what you need to address within your response. As a result, this made the quizzes a very easy 20/20, especially if you have a nice TF.In terms of the course itself, the material is definitely very interesting. However, since the majority of the teaching staff are white, the class partially gives white savior complex where it seems like they are focusing on how white people are going to save the world and contribute to the bettering of medicine across the globe. Undoubtedly, the work the team has done, especially some of the Professors, is indeed impressive, but definitely know that it can come off that way on certain topics.Next, during Fall, 2023, the course began to mandate lecture attendance, with them incorporating PollEv into lectures. However, this was done extremely inconsistently, to where there were only around 5–10 polls throughout the entire semester. If there just so happens to be a poll on the day you missed, this can very easily tank your attendance grade, so be careful!Additionally, on the first day, our class was told that the reading assignments were very little for the course, which looking back, was a COMPLETE AND UTTER LIE! The readings are often long, and I did not end up touching a single one throughout the entire semester. PLEASE do not waste your time looking it over, as you can just rely on the Topic Banks and lectures to do well on the quizzes in class.Overall, GENED 1093 is a very enjoyable and chill class. Outside of the few minor criticisms I’ve outlined above, it is definitely an outstanding and well designed course that many of us were able to enjoy. Best of luck to all of those enrolling in the future! ****
worse_comment: Avoid slacking off! Due to the lack of structure in the class, you might feel like not attending class or paying attention, but that makes this class a memorable experience. I didn't focus on completing the readings, and instead tried to focus during lectures which introduced me to some eye–opening cases going on in the world.
best_gem_comment: A solid GEM — super light workload (four quizzes, each of which are completed in class and are composed of two long–answer questions for topics that you receive a week in advance) with the exception of the final few weeks, where you'll definitely have to invest a few hours to complete the research paper, which is 12–15 pages. In complete honesty, the readings are way more interesting and in–depth than the lectures, but given that the lectures present a way more concise and clear version of what's in the (many, many) readings, you really do not need to go through the 90 pages of textbook and paper reading that you will inevitably get assigned. Grading is very generous and most section TFs really want you to get an A: don't stress at all about preparing for the quizzes, because your TF will likely tell you almost exactly what you need to know and do to ace it. Take this GenEd if you're at all interested in global health, social theories, and analyzing case studies!

course_title: Confronting Climate Change: A Foundation in Science, Technology and Policy 001
best_comment: 100% you should take. I came into this course as a gov/Phil person, so I was a little intimidated, but I can 100% say I learned so much. You learn so much in a low stress environment. The midterm was a little hard, but it was good, because it forced everyone to interact with the material. The grade on it did not matter much since most people in the course do pretty well, but the midterm was a good opportunity to actually sit down and learn the stuff. Dan does a good job of breaking climate change down so anyone with any background can learn it. Roxana is AMAZING as a TF to really explain everything you learn in class. Perfect for GENED requirement, but also knowledge I think everyone should have! I can truly say I have learned alot and have knowledge on climate change that will impact my future!
worse_comment: Do not take this class unless you have to. This was one of the worse classes I have taken at Harvard. The curriculum often felt repetitive, the midterm exam had questions that did not truly address the content that we had to learn, and the class had unnecessarily harsh grading.
best_gem_comment: Take notes. If you take notes, you will barely have to study for midterm, and papers will be super easy to write, as they are mostly based on class material rather than outside research.  GEM class, especially for those interested in the environment. Second half of the course is significantly more interesting than the first.
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: Confronting Climate Change: A Foundation in Science, Technology and Policy

course_title: Making Change When Change is Hard: the Law, Politics, and Policy of Social Change 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class if you're interested in developing your understanding of current issues. The class, all in all, is not too demanding because attendance is not mandatory, exams are take–home, there are no reading checks and it's easy to participate in sections even if you haven't really done the reading. But if you don't go to lecture it's really hard to keep up with the content – I say if you don't have any time, just don't do the readings but definitely go to the lecture or have someone who can tell you about it because the exams are hard and the classes are not recorded/slides aren't shared, and depending on your TF, it's not the easiest to get a good grade. The sections were really great, Prof Sunstein has an amazing team of law school students etc. who help him with the course! He himself is also incredibly engaging, smart, and funny. We also had really interesting guest speakers this year and I believe even if it's not the same people, many interesting people (like 2–3 over the course of the semester) with interesting stories come every year. I highly recommend this class for everyone, but especially if you plan to concentrate in the Social Studies (particularly Econ, Psych, Gov) because the content is so extremely relevant and interesting – but definitely keep in mind that the exams are not the easiest and the content can be difficult sometimes.
worse_comment: Look, you may as well shorten the name of this class to just Making Change, because frankly speaking, change is NEVER easy. Let me put it to you this way. So you're a strapping, bright–eyed young lad or lady who just wants to make a change in the world—I don't care what it may be for—but you have a serious problem: you think that making change is light work. You think that your frivolous, insouciant attitude is enough to cut it. HAHAHA NO. That's your optimism bias speaking, the planning fallacy in action!  Are you prepared to combat the Perversity Thesis while fending off sludge from every corner? Have you even stopped to consider that maybe you're the Bootlegger, not the Baptist? Change isn't some docile stream you can bend and dam up at will. It's a gushing waterfall, and right now, you are a mere tree branch getting swept up in all that change.But don't fall victim to Paralyzing Pessimism! Change is fickle thing, but if there's one thing Professor Sunstein has taught me, it's that the FedSoc did it and so can you. Take this class so you can learn about the secrets of policymaking and behavioral science. Personally, taking this class gave me superpowers—the superpower to make change, to be exact. I haven't got a full handle on these powers yet, but I let's just say I was able to make change on my GPA after that Making Change final! Talk about it! Get out there and make change, everyone. But always remember—change is simply never easy.
best_gem_comment: This class is excellent. It is a rare gem where you actually learn something deeply interesting and relevant, as Cass explains various concepts from behavioral science that directly impact various phenomenon we observe (polarization, public opinion changes, revolutions, nudging, etc.).  The class has no busy work–30% midterm, 50% final, 20% participation. Reading is unnecessary, and the exams will not test it—can be helpful to skim once and a while to lock in on a concept, participate in an optional discussion post that boosts your participation score, etc.  There are no recordings of the lectures, so you need to attend class to succeed.  Highly recommend as a low workload yet still productive GENED.
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: Making Change When Change is Hard: the Law, Politics, and Policy of Social Change

course_title: Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to Soft Matter Science 001
best_comment: Proceed with caution! After completing this course, I can come out of it and say that I enjoyed it for the most part, but during the semester, this was not always the case. I developed a very love–hate relationship with this course. I can firmly say that out of all my classes this semester, lectures were actually worth going to and even more, I was excited to go. I loved having guest lectures from different culinary backgrounds and expertise, ranging from chefs from the Galapagos, Michelin star chefs, or owners of local bakeries/restaurants in Cambridge (not to mention the free food we would get every class!!). Lectures were engaging and interesting and the class demos always left me discussing with friends outside of class. However, this class is not the easiest. Though we cook for every lab, this is not a cooking class and definitely is very rooted in chemistry. With minimal previous chemistry knowledge, I was often left confused on concepts as they weren't covered that in depth in class but would make up most of the PSETs. I went to office hours every week and still struggled on the PSETs and did not do well on the exams. If you have never taken chemistry or are a humanities–focused person, you may find this class a little more difficult and more of a time commitment especially for a Gen–Ed, like I did. I still loved the hands–on aspects and cooking aspects of this class, just keep this all in mind while deciding whether it is worth it or not to you to take this class. This class did in fact add stress to my semester where I wish I could've enjoyed it more since there were fun parts, especially the final science fair where they go all out.
worse_comment: You will have a great time in this class, but only if you take it pass fail!
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to Soft Matter Science

best_comment: One of the best geneds I have taken at Harvard! Do look out for the two quizzes that happen every lecture, but don't let that scare you. As long as you skim the readings and attend lecture, you will be able to do well on them easily. I wouldn't say this class is a true gem (again–––two quizzes a week), but it is very well run and I feel like I learned a lot. Really the only assignments are weekly section write–ups (which can be done in 1.5 hours) and then a big Capstone project at the end (but you have a lot of freedom to make the project interesting to you)! Sometimes grading on the section assignments was a little harsh, but overall, a very manageable workload and I really did enjoy. The teaching staff are all so kind and really get you excited for the material. Also, sections are really amazing in this class! You literally get to do pottery :).
worse_comment: Take this course if you have any interest at all in archaeology or anthropology. This course covered topics that were a bit more recent than I would've liked and did not cover as much about learning the more distant past from objects. I would say this is more of an anthropology and archaeological theory course. The reading quizzes are awful but the course staff are convinced that it is a necessary evil.
best_gem_comment: One of the best geneds I have taken at Harvard! Do look out for the two quizzes that happen every lecture, but don't let that scare you. As long as you skim the readings and attend lecture, you will be able to do well on them easily. I wouldn't say this class is a true gem (again–––two quizzes a week), but it is very well run and I feel like I learned a lot. Really the only assignments are weekly section write–ups (which can be done in 1.5 hours) and then a big Capstone project at the end (but you have a lot of freedom to make the project interesting to you)! Sometimes grading on the section assignments was a little harsh, but overall, a very manageable workload and I really did enjoy. The teaching staff are all so kind and really get you excited for the material. Also, sections are really amazing in this class! You literally get to do pottery :).

gened: Histories, Societies, Individuals; Science and Technology in Society

best_comment: This class was amazing, and you should definitely lottery for it if you have the chance. I really enjoyed the forced breaks from my pset classes and the privilege of having a studio space this semester, as well as the experience of making my own canvases. Doing the assignments felt more like fun than work. This class definitely has a large time commitment: one painting is due each week for much of the semester. However, the prompts are definitely really interesting and broad, and the class is much more about improvement and is definitely open to people of all skill levels. I also felt that the TFs and Matt are very understanding and the class is quite flexible. I had Maria, and she was amazing. She was super knowledgeable and I really enjoyed her demos and feedback. You should definitely take this class if you are able to get it.
worse_comment: dont take this course unless youve got an insanely light semester, you make a painting every week and its A LOT of work (unless you dont really care about what you make) i was in the studio sm like ngl it was depressing and pretty bad for my social life. would recommend pass/fail in a light semester, otherwise DONT (also lecture attendance is necessary even though you never need any of the info from it)

best_comment: I would definitely take this class. I had no previous interest in anything medicine related at all, and would even say I had a strong disliking for it. I took this course for a gen ed requirement and LOVED it. The work is extremely manageable, I actually looked forward to working on the assignments (which is something I have never said before), and the readings were so interesting. Some of the readings are definitely on the longer side, but I skimmed those and as long as you get the basic idea, you should be totally fine for the tests, though they are so interesting and would honestly recommend reading them in full if you have time that week. The instruction is so great. The professor is amazing and makes the class so interesting. You can never get bored in this class, and again, this is coming from someone with no interest in medicine.
worse_comment: This class is interesting, but since it is full of premed students I wouldn't take this unless it's pass/fail. The readings are fairly long and the sections not very interactive, but you will probably learn a lot. The essays are on the shorter end for a Ethics and Civics gened, but still painful for a STEM concentrator.
best_gem_comment: TAKE IT IF YOU CAN, especially if you're pre–med you'll love this class. this class is no gem but the content is so fascinating and the weekly readings are so interesting so take your time with them, section will help clarify some of the more difficult philosophical papers, the only flop was that the hour–long midterms gave you an excerpt of the readings and then ask you to name the author, found that very unproductive, otherwise i LOVED this class, dr. jones is an amazing lecturer and is so knowledgable

best_comment: This class is worth taking but only worth taking if done with intention. This is my first GenEd and it wasn't exactly the walk in the park I expected but it was pretty close. If you actually watch the modules and do the readings you're going to be in the top half of the class (and the top half gets an A). That said, a large component of your grade is the policy memos so it's best not just to start those early but to meet with your TF about them so that they know you're putting in the work. Even more importantly with the memos, the grading can feel arbitrary and more based on your TF's personal preferences than the rubric or the sample memos you're given which is why it's so important to talk to your TF. With the reading quizzes, you cannot cannot cannot be late to class because you'll miss them and you don't get any drops for quizzes you don't take. The difficulty on those quizzes varies but they are generally pretty easy—in stark contrast to previous years. This is one of those classes where effort and effort alone makes it pretty simple to succeed. That said, some economics background would probably be helpful. The lectures are the best part of the class, so make sure you attend and learn something from the incredible slate of individuals that take their time to talk to you about economics. Also, since this class double counts for both the Econ concentration requirements and for your Gened requirement (where you can choose which category it fits into) this is a must–take just because of the flexibility it gives you.
worse_comment: This class lacked clear direction. I came in expecting to be given a framework for thinking about globalization, but instead never received the teaching staff's logic for why they structured the course the way they did. Moreover, the asynchronous videos were terribly inconsistent in their depth/there were often imprecise descriptions that muddied my understanding. I was also not a fan of the way the professors held themselves during lecture: there were times when one would talk over the other professor or invited guests very aggressively and times when they would threaten to cold call in an unproductive/belittling way (it is important to note that they did not receive answers from students with encouragement/constructive criticism: students were usually met with blank stares or needlessly harsh corrections). In addition, the reading list was terribly curated (we would not discuss them in section/it was unclear what added value they brought), some of the links would not work because of paywalls (there should have been a much more coordinated attempt at uploading them to Canvas), readings would be added last minute, etc. etc. And, finally, the grading for the midterm was hopelessly opaque & the students only realized AFTER the exam the standards that they would be held to. This is coming from someone who did well on the midterm, so it is not merely bitterness at results coming through. Would not recommend.
best_gem_comment: This class is an excellent gem as far as Geneds go. It has a reputation for being difficult, which I don't understand. Class is only once a week, which saves you time. You also don't need to stay for the entire class, because attendance happens at the start and there are >200 other people there. There are only two assignments, and each is only four pages long (double–spaced). The midterm is straightforward, and the final is take–home. Grading is harsh, but the final curve is not, so it doesn't matter. If you're looking for an easy way to cheese either your Ethics requirement or the HSI one, take this class. If you pass/fail it, the class will genuinely take you under 30 minutes per week on average, and if not, it won't be above 1 hour a week (including time in lecture).

best_comment: I loved this class! From reading the syllabus you can probably tell it involves a bit more work than the average GENED class, but it's 100% worth it in this case! We got to learn about lots of different topics with a really engaged and caring teaching team, the assignments weren't too time consuming and were pretty fun (you get to choose from a selection of books to work with, and get to watch pretty cool movies!), and we were constantly relating the material learned to our current reality. Overall a really great option for a science gened.
worse_comment: This class is incredibly hard if you do not like the deep science needed to understand the topics. The teacher is terrible and goes on tangents, forgetting to teach.

best_comment: INCREDIBLE CLASS. The selected readings and books are excellent; Joan Didion's "Year of Magical Thinking" is a must–read. Professor Coleman is a great lecturer and it is so clear that she is passionate about her students and the powerful topic of grief (be prepared to discuss some very sad but meaningful poems and art!). Section was probably my favorite section from any class I've taken at Harvard, highly focused and great conversations. This class does have multiple weekly assignments and readings that you must stay on top of, but the quizzes are more than fair (ridiculously easy). This class had the most helpful feedback on improving my written work that I've ever received at Harvard. The final paper is highly personal (prompt: write about a loss in your community) and has the potential to be a lifelong memory; it was for me.10/10 class, though not a gem due to multiple weekly assignments. Definitely my favorite GENED I have taken, by far.
worse_comment: This course is very easy, but sometimes the work can seem trivial and the grades given may seem nit–picky. I often found the course more annoying than difficult. The professor can sometimes have a very pretentious air, so avoid this course if that might really bother you.

course_title: Is the U.S. Civil War Still Being Fought? 001
best_comment: This class is pretty well organized and has really interesting and valuable readings, so make sure you do them, especially the shorter ones and Beloved. It's not too hard to get an A in this class, as long as you go to the exam reviews and you do your best on the Pithy Commentaries. I had a good experience in this class. Professor Stauffer is very sweet, and Cleo is an amazing TF :).

Great class. Professors and TF are amazing, and the lectures are engaging. It was a bit more work for a GenEd, but overall it was worth it because I felt like I learned a lot and enjoyed the class. Would definitely recommend!
worse_comment: This class will teach you a lot about China, Chinese culture, and the history of China. However, this is a fair amount of work. You have to watch videos, do little quizzes about them, and read a fairly large volume of material each week. If you skip doing something you will regret it. Also, if you're not a fan of flipped classroom (lectures with the most content are videotaped and watched on your own time) then know that this class has that set–up.
subject: General Education

best_comment: Great class. Professors and TF are amazing, and the lectures are engaging. It was a bit more work for a GenEd, but overall it was worth it because I felt like I learned a lot and enjoyed the class. Would definitely recommend!
worse_comment: This class will teach you a lot about China, Chinese culture, and the history of China. However, this is a fair amount of work. You have to watch videos, do little quizzes about them, and read a fairly large volume of material each week. If you skip doing something you will regret it. Also, if you're not a fan of flipped classroom (lectures with the most content are videotaped and watched on your own time) then know that this class has that set–up.
subject: General Education

best_comment: This class was fun and mostly low–stress! You watch some cool movies, learn some cool things about film techniques and analysis, and discuss Japanese cinema in the context of certain critical lenses. The weekly discussion posts are short and fun, and the video essays are quite a pleasant alternative to writing long tedious essays! Prof Zahlten is super nice and knowledgable and cares about his students, too! The one downside to the class is that it's a 9 am class where attendance is mandatory, which can be painful when the semester ramps up. The mandatory film screenings also take up two hours outside of class time every week, which is something to consider in terms of time commitment. Overall, highly recommended Gen Ed class. It's interesting, fun, and relatively low–stress!
worse_comment: I liked what I learnt –– the staff is very approachable and knowledgeable! But there was quite a bit of work and the class timings were brutal.
subject: General Education

course_title: Moctezuma’s Mexico Then and Now: Ancient Empires, Race Mixture, and Finding LatinX 001
best_comment: Pros: this class is easy. Like, except for the midterm week and the section presentation week, I never did any work for this class. There is an ungodly amount of readings, but that's actually a good thing–––if there's too much to read, nobody will do the readings, which means everybody is equally clueless during section discussions! So... yeah. You don't need to do the readings unless you want to. It's really a "you get out what you put in" sort of class.Cons: It needs a much greater emphasis on the "now" part of Moctezuma's Mexico: Then and Now. It really felt like I was learning history for no good reason beyond Harvard having a deranged philosophy that we all need to take courses irrelevant to our field of study with no importance to daily life. PLEASE teach us about modern–day Mexican culture more than just saying "here is the history, and yes, it is still important today." I felt like what I learned was at best loosely related to Mexican culture and politics today, which is really all I have any incentive to care about. The biggest issue I have is that I found it really really REALLY boring. That said, the easiness makes up for it. Gem in a workload sense, absolutely miserable in a content sense. Obviously, not everyone will feel that way: if you're interested in Mexican history, it will probably be an amazing class for you.
worse_comment: the lecturers have firsthand experience with the discussions. That being said, delivery, intonation, and overall articulation are horrible. They both had soft monotone voices that made you fight against sleep the entire time. It was overall difficult to stay engaged during lectures.
best_gem_comment: Really enjoyed the course material and the teaching team is amazing and super enthusiastic. However, lecture can feel a bit disorganized at times and there are a lot of readings listed, however you do not need to complete them all to participate in section. For the little work put in throughout the semester, the midterm and final are pretty lengthy to make up for it. Overall though, I would still say this class is a gem because it is a fairly light workload but also really interesting material about transculturation, indigeneity, and modern identities.
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: Moctezuma’s Mexico Then and Now: Ancient Empires, Race Mixture, and Finding LatinX
