subject: General Education
course_title_2024: Moctezuma’s Mexico Then and Now: Ancient Empires, Race Mixture, and Finding LatinX

best_comment: Be prepared to read.On good days, you will be assigned around 3–6 comic issues to read, each taking me about 15–20 minutes to read, and perhaps you will send a "Question of the Day," detailing a question you had about your readings to the professor and the TA, proving you did the readings.On bad days, you will be assigned a novel to read in a single weekend, the longest being around 300 pages, and you will have to send a Question of the Day.In this class, you may be asked to do a roleplaying session with a group, in which you act out as a character you design, and hope the person narrating your story is creative enough to keep it interesting. Also, if your group is small, and half your group is absent, it makes it hard to tell the story. Still, I heard great stories being told when we shared these DND–esque stories, and they seem genuinely fun! Attendance was mandatory. Not fun. They will count how many of you are in class, so don't think you can get by by having someone send you the link to the attendance. If you get caught multiple times, you will get talked to by the professor.Essays are not too difficult. Can be up to 1500 words if I recall correctly. Just basic interpretation of comics that we've read.We were given the choice between a final exam that was supposed to be easy, and a final project that required you to read 5 stories of some superhero. I chose the latter, personally because I did not do most of the readings.Lectures are not very substantial in terms of understanding the readings, but can be interesting to watch what happens that day in class. Never a dull moment there.Take the class if you like superheroes (if you don't know anything about them, you'll be totally fine), and if you will be fine with the readings. You will likely end up with an A, A–, or B+, but you better work on those essays to make sure they get As or A–s because you only get 2 and they make up a large percentage of your grade. Risk it if you want.
worse_comment: Don't take this course. The class is extremely disorganized and chaotic. I was really excited about this class because I know nothing about comics and looked forward to the chance to learn more. Unfortunately, I spent much of the course confused and disengaged. The entire course felt haphazard and poorly planned –– and not in a good/gemmy way. Each class felt impromptu –– there were never any slides, and lectures frequently got derailed.  I don't feel like I learned anything. The assignments all felt like busy work, and we were held to a very hard grading standard (Professor Burt said that A level work should be of "publishable quality," which feels like an unfair standard for an entry–level GenEd course).
best_gem_comment: Unless the structure of the class changes substantially, I really recommend you don't take it. The class is advertised as a gem, which is only partially true. There is not a lot of work in the class, but the grading is not particularly generous, so you're definitely not guaranteed an A. Occasionally Professor Burt gave interesting lectures (she is a brilliant, hilarious, well–spoken, and entertaining person). Much of the class, however, involved a role–playing game whereby you pretend to be a superhero and tell a story about adventures your superhero goes on with other people in the class. This may sound appealing, but it is not. It is awkward, tedious, not fun, and incredibly uneducational. There are so many aesthetics and culture geneds at Harvard that can provide you an interesting foray into that world. I suggest you pick one other than this.

course_title: Pluralism: Case Studies in American Diversity 001
best_comment: This course was interesting – no doubt some of the cases were very fascinating and very relevant on an everyday basis with regards to religious pluralism that we see in America but after a while I felt that the case studies got a bit repetitive. Many of the cases played it too safe where there was really only one stance to take because the other one is literally just something that would get you cancelled. Thus many of the points in discussion in class were very repetitive and just everyone agreeing with each other with possibly some additional points from their personal life (which was the part that was definitely nice to listen to). However, I did really enjoy section a lot as it was a very comfortable space to share personal experiences and give more opinionated thoughts – which I guess is what I thought would happen in the class overall but I also realize that it is not as comforting to do the same in such a huge class. Overall though, it is a good Gened to take as it opens your eyes to a lot of things that you may never have talked about with your family or friends like ever so that was really insightful – and the midterm and final are essays that are manageable as long as you space them out well and don't procrastinate – good class to add to your schedule if your schedule is packed with pset classes as my schedule was – just make sure to start essays EARLY!! Ask a TF if you have concerns about your essay topic and get any help throughout the process – it will make your life so much easier.
worse_comment: I learned more about different religions in the American context and the conversations were really enlightening.  I think the Ethics and Civics requirement is notorious for not having good options, and I think this one is a pretty decent option if taken pass/fail. Don't start the final paper at the last minute, doable in 3 days but stressful. Spread it out and talk with the TF about your ideas early.
best_gem_comment: I don't think this Gened is running again, but if it does, I would recommend with reservations. The course content was mildly interesting and Professor Eck is very very nice. There is very little work (just a discussion post and reading) on a weekly basis, but the midterm paper and very long final paper take a while. Taking a class on religion this semester, during the Israel–Palestine conflict, was a bit uncomfortable, especially because no one was willing to talk about it but everyone had an opinion about it. That said, I did learn a lot. The lectures were super boring. Finally, the grading in the class is wildly inconsistent across sections, and sadly, I had a more difficult TF, but I had many friends who had easier TFs. Overall, I wouldn't call this class a gem, but it is definitely doable if you put in some effort.

best_comment: If you're looking for a climate change overview through the lens of multiple different disciplines, this is a great course. Lectures could be a little difficult to follow at times, but big ideas were always clarified in section. The guest speakers were the best part of this class! They were very engaging and connected course content to many different fields. Not too much work and assignments were generally pretty interesting. Readings and other course materials were interesting and definitely enhance the course. The teaching team is very communicative and accessible; they really care about student success!
worse_comment: If you are looking for a class on climate JUSTICE, this course is not for you. This course provides a very in–depth introduction to inter–disciplinary approaches to the climate crisis, from basic scientific concepts that give you the tools to explain what exactly "global warming" or "climate disruption" means. But, this course does not critically question it's narrowly Western perspective and it's evasion of words like climate colonialism are very troublesome and frustrating.
subject: General Education

best_comment: If you're looking for a climate change overview through the lens of multiple different disciplines, this is a great course. Lectures could be a little difficult to follow at times, but big ideas were always clarified in section. The guest speakers were the best part of this class! They were very engaging and connected course content to many different fields. Not too much work and assignments were generally pretty interesting. Readings and other course materials were interesting and definitely enhance the course. The teaching team is very communicative and accessible; they really care about student success!
worse_comment: If you are looking for a class on climate JUSTICE, this course is not for you. This course provides a very in–depth introduction to inter–disciplinary approaches to the climate crisis, from basic scientific concepts that give you the tools to explain what exactly "global warming" or "climate disruption" means. But, this course does not critically question it's narrowly Western perspective and it's evasion of words like climate colonialism are very troublesome and frustrating.
subject: General Education

course_title: What Is the Good China Story? 001
best_comment: I used to try to scrape by in this class without doing the readings. About a month into the semester, I found that I was doing the readings not because it made my time in section easier (it did), but because I wanted to do the readings. This is a literature course, and it may seem overwhelming at times, but engaging with the material made my experience so much better. I learned a lot about China and Chinese literature, which is not even really an area of interest for me. I took this course randomly, because a friend told me to take it with her. I'm so glad I did.
worse_comment: This is a class with not a lot of work. However, the lectures were not very engaging, and I don't think that I learned a lot. Take it to satisfy the GenEd requirement, but don't recommend taking it otherwise.
best_gem_comment: This class is awesome! Definitely a gem. I took it pass/fail and wish I hadn’t, because it’s pretty much impossible not to do well. Lectures are very laid back and they don’t take attendance, so you just have to do a discussion post every week and write three short essays. Overall super low workload and interesting content.

course_title: What Is the Good China Story? 001
best_comment: I used to try to scrape by in this class without doing the readings. About a month into the semester, I found that I was doing the readings not because it made my time in section easier (it did), but because I wanted to do the readings. This is a literature course, and it may seem overwhelming at times, but engaging with the material made my experience so much better. I learned a lot about China and Chinese literature, which is not even really an area of interest for me. I took this course randomly, because a friend told me to take it with her. I'm so glad I did.
worse_comment: This is a class with not a lot of work. However, the lectures were not very engaging, and I don't think that I learned a lot. Take it to satisfy the GenEd requirement, but don't recommend taking it otherwise.
best_gem_comment: This class is awesome! Definitely a gem. I took it pass/fail and wish I hadn’t, because it’s pretty much impossible not to do well. Lectures are very laid back and they don’t take attendance, so you just have to do a discussion post every week and write three short essays. Overall super low workload and interesting content.

best_comment: This was a great class, which I would highly recommend.No matter what you feel about Prof. Sandel's opinions, it is doubtless that he is an incredibly thoughtful thinker and an insanely skilled lecturer. I did not know it was possible to facilitate a discussion among a ~200 person class, but Sandel did it masterfully as if it was nothing. Lecture was very interesting, and he would regularly invite the authors of our readings to come in and speak (including such speakers as the current chief justice of the Indian supreme court, just to give you a sense). By the middle of the course, it felt that readings were a little redundant to lecture (ie the authors would just come in and rehash everything the reading covered), which I found a little unfortunate as it would have been nice to dive deeper into the material, but lectures were still engaging and interesting. I think the intention was for student discussion and engagement with the guests to be what drove the conversation deeper than the readings, which is fair. Some may find this a plus, others a minus, but nonetheless the course was very interesting.In this class, it is very easy to participate in lectures, but hardly necessary. Section was great, very interesting discussions. I will say, in our section students sometimes got too caught up in practical considerations and distracted from the actual political philosophy, despite the TFs best efforts to steer them back towards philosophical thought, which was okay but a bit frustrating. But our TF ran section wonderfully and was very passionate about the material, engaged with us, etc. Essays were interesting topics, and the TF offered very helpful and thoughtful feedback on our first essay. The oral exam was not my favorite idea, but it was not too bad (or at least I don't think it was!)Of all the aspects of the course, the one that was the biggest highlight was Prof Sandel's office hours. These were basically another section, but just run by Sandel. Conversation was always incredibly interesting, and really the most meaningful part of the course to me. Whether you agree or disagree with Prof. Sandel right now, especially if you do disagree with him, you should take this course. The questions that it asks are incredibly interesting, and the conversations that it forces are incredibly enlightening. I have honestly found that the more I've taken the course, the more I've been convinced, and this course has really forced me to look at society in a different way. I think it has just encouraged me to take less for granted, and be more thoughtful in thinking about society. All in all, I would highly recommend this course!
worse_comment: Grading on essays is brutal
best_gem_comment: If you are interested in the idea of meritocracy, definitely take this course! It is the perfect class to explore such an interesting topic– the assignments are primarily readings and the lectures are super interesting. Michael Sandel is the best of the best, and I believe everyone should take at least one class with him.  I felt like I learned so much in this class, and it was such a low time commitment, while still being engaging and fun. The only negative, in my opinion, is that it starts to get a bit repetitive. However, every class is always interesting– Professor Sandel brings in a lot of amazing guest speakers, and you can tell he really cares about this topic and his students! Definitely a gem, you must take this course!

course_title: The Power and Beauty of Being In Between: The Story of Armenia 001
best_comment: READ THIS REVIEW:Professor Maranci is absolutely the best. Super down to earth, really nice, really funny, and really knowledgeable on Armenian art and architecture. I had never taken an art history course, but honestly it was really fun for me to just come to class and hear her present on her material. She is an excellent lecturer, she keeps you engaged live with interesting class discussions (that somehow doesn't seem cheesy and stupid), and she weaves together interesting stories, arguments, and themes in her presentations. She CLEARLY puts a lot of time, effort, and thought into TEACHING which is very refreshing to experience from faculty at Harvard, who more often seem to care much more about their research and less about students. Ultimately, Professor Maranci is incredibly kind and compassionate and just wants you to learn about Armenia, a place and culture and aesthetic tradition she has a lot of love for. If you just show up with a curious and excited mind, you will have a lot of fun, and she will also meet you right there –– that's pretty much all you need to do. That being said, if you think you *Can't Stand* staring at images of art and architecture for an hour and fifteen minutes twice a week, don't take this class, because despite professor Maranci being wonderful and engaging, this class is structured around presentations filled with images of Armenian art and architecture, largely religious in nature (like images of Jesus and churches).Sections weren't great, but hopefully they will be restructured as this was the first year teaching this course.
best_gem_comment: This is a great class to get an introduction to Armenian culture, art, architecture, and history. The class assignments are very fair and the class doesn't require too much work outside of class time and section. I would strongly recommend this course to anyone looking to fulfill their Aesthetics & Cultures GENED! Proper gem!
subject: General Education
course_title_2024: The Power and Beauty of Being In Between: The Story of Armenia

best_comment: This is an awesome class! Completely manageable workload (pretty easy online homeworks 4x per week, a quiz or test every other week, and 3 fairly short writing assignments per semester) and awesome teaching staff. It feels a little fast from the start if you're like me and have absolutely no knowledge of German going in, but you catch on pretty quick.

Take this class, but know what you are getting yourself into. You can expect 1 – 3 hours of homework Monday through Friday (depending on how much time you put in). In addition to having 80 – 100 words to learn each week, you will have a test or a quiz, each of which cover material from the textbook and class. If you turn up,  do the work, and actively participate, you will not only succeed in this class but have the most incredible semester. I LOVED this class. German 10AB at 9am was genuinely my favourite part of every day.  The instructional stuff are fantastic, and the German Department has wonderful events and opportunities to not only practice speaking, but meet new people over great food.
subject: German

best_comment: In the class I made great friends and learned a lot of grammar, vocab, and infos about German culture. Increased my appreciation for the German language and the German dept as a whole. After this class I am now considering a German language citation. Even if you don't have Frau Shire, the class has a great structure and is very fair. You'll love it. Super fun activities that help you learn a lot if you put in some work.
subject: German

best_comment: Take German 20A if you want to improve your speaking and grammar skills! I loved the class so much. Even though I already fulfilled my foreign language requirement with another language, I continued taking German because it was so much fun. The teachers are super educated and qualified. And, the department invests a lot of time and effort into creating a community for German language speakers and learners. One thing I will say is that how fun your specific section is, depends entirely on your preceptor's personality.
worse_comment: It is a language class! You will learn the language as long as you do the work. Don't let yourself get caught in a trap of procrastinating the homework assignments even though they are small; having done them before class time is essential to have familiarity and learn faster.
subject: German

best_comment: Take this class!! You'll learn so much. If Prof. Dymek is teaching it, it will be your favorite class of the semester. It's very flexible and there's never pressure to be perfect. If you're walking the line between intermediate German and fluency, this class will definitely tip you over the edge.
worse_comment: If you come from 20b, do not take this class unless you feel comfortable about your german skills. THIS IS NOT A LANGUAGE LEARNING CLASS. You will get the most from the class if you can do the assignments without having to look up every single word that appears in the reading. I took 20b and felt okay about my german, and i wont say that my reading didn't get better after taking the class. You will be able to read advanced texts and will have the skills to look up words and decipher them. This is genuinely a good skill, but having to read read these texts with little to no guidance turns doing homework into a herculean task. Its dry and time consuming. And that's without the grammar, that you are expected to do by yourself and is barely discussed in class. TLDR: take another german class if you want to learn german, take this class if you wanna get better at reading.
subject: German

best_comment: I would recommend this course if you need to fulfill your concentration or secondary or if you are just extremely excited about German grammar because it is essentially just a grammar course. It was not a walk in the park, but the exams were not heinous. Be prepared to spend a fair amount of time on the homework assignments twice a week. Anne is really lively and makes class exciting.
subject: German

best_comment: Ihr werdet auf jeden Fall diesen Kurs lieben!!! The class is amazing –– Take it if you are interested in German or German comedy!!! Professor Parkes is wonderful, not to mention immensely nice and approachable, and the readings were super fun and interesting. That being said, a few were a little tricky to read so make sure you have a solid background in German; but they were explained clearly in the lecture. In addition, we had a lot of engaging discussions and fun activities throughout the semester and the group really felt like a close–knit community due to the small size. May be my favorite class I have taken on campus to date.

course_title: German Social Thought, Nietzsche to Habermas 1
best_comment: Peter Gordon is the real deal.  He is able to break down the most complicated ideas into the most straightforward language like no professor I've had before, and does so with so much energy and passion that every lecture felt like a master class. I would love to hear him lecture on anything, but the content of the course was also especially well–curated. The course connected philosophical texts seamlessly with German history, with a special emphasis on art (every class began with an excerpt from a different German composer which related to the themes we were about to cover); it was truly interdisciplinary! Furthermore, JP was one of the best section leaders I've ever had. He masterfully guided discussions and made me feel so welcomed and supported. Even though I was nowhere near as qualified to talk about these texts as other students, I felt so comfortable adding my input thanks to his encouragement.  Such a great experience!
worse_comment: I learned how to read before I learned how to talk, so I never really had to say the words "I can't read" until I took a stab at Heidegger. But despite Heidegger's best efforts with Dasein Being–in–the–world vorhanden zuhanden being–towards–death throwness etc. etc., I learned how to read. Now, I can annoy all my friends with a diatribe about how being just a girl in the world is actually a rather Heideggerian concept, then I can use communicative rationality to quash their protests on the battlefield of ideas.

course_title: Angst, Sex, and Dreams: the Psychoanalytic Worlds of Freud, Kafka, and Bachmann 1
best_comment: Dr.William is amazing professor ! But please do not think that because of the name of the course this class is easy lol, it is a literature class and it will test ur writing abilities but honestly the professor makes it worth it, he will meet with you, guide you, provides feedback extensive feedback and his very knowledgeable. The text are also realll interesting

course_title: Intermediate Swedish: Childhood in Swedish Literature and Culture 001
best_comment: Swedish is always my favorite class of each semester. Agnes is the most supportive and reasonable teacher I've ever met. She creates lessons and assigns homework to match our learning pace and makes sure each of us are on the right track. I have never learned so much in such a friendly and warm classroom environment.
subject: Swedish
course_title_2024: Intermediate Swedish: Childhood in Swedish Literature and Culture

course_title: The Quality of Health Care in America 001
best_comment: BEST class at Harvard, no competition. This class made me want to work in healthcare in some capacity after I graduate. Bapu is incredible –– he not only is an amazing professor, but he inspires me to a more giving, happy person outside of the classroom and is an amazing mentor. Raj, the head TF has been the best TF I have ever had as a senior. This was only his first time teaching, and he knocked it out of the park with his communication, support, and intelligence. The guest speakers were all phenomenal and I can say that the class gave me a very solid introduction to the complex healthcare system in the US. Minimal work but maximum knowledge gain –– which is the best of both worlds. Try to get into this class, it is life–changing!
subject: Global Health & Health Policy
course_title_2024: The Quality of Health Care in America

best_comment: FGLI First Year Student:This is the response you want to read. Professor Peterson may seem intimidating but he's a nice dude, and although you might not get to know him personally without going to office hours, or running into him before class he is always a joy regardless. He keeps his politics and opinions out of class, and takes a view of American Government in well, 'a new perspective' like the name of the class. But to get to the point, this class is great if you are: starting your government concentration, unsure on majoring in government, want to take a class that is very entry level to government, and also looking for a class to fill your schedule that doesn't take too much time! There is a one prompt short answer 5 min question at the start of every class, but they are also relatively the course material from the videos so don't worry too much, and it is easy to catch up if you get sick and miss a class.The readings are very inaccessible due to costs, so I recommend finding a way to get them through library reserves or speaking to the Professor or TF, I got one of my books from requesting it from an inter–library loan which is another option. I try not to spend money on books so that is my advice!Summary:– Professor Peterson is a icon, he is funny, well–versed, and knows what he is talking about– Books are expensive, but can be accessed online, through TF's or via library.– Easy if you already took classes like AP Gov, might need extra studying if you don't know anything about American Government– Midterms and Finals were relatively explanatory– Quiz every class lecture, but just the course material– HIGHLY RECOMMENDED COURSE– Also STAN Chris S. Liu!!!!! (dude in the videos!)
worse_comment: THIS CLASS IS A HIDDEN GEM IF YOU WANT TO LEARN MORE OR IN DEPT ABOUT AMERICAN GOVERNMENT. THIS CLASS CAN BE DENSE IN WORK BUT VERY INFORMATIVE AND THE ASSIGNMENTS ARE GRADED FAIRLY BUT I WILL SAY THAT THE QUIZZES FOR EACH CLASS AT THE BEGINNING OF CLASS WERE VERY ANNOYING AND I THINK YOU SHOULD CONSIDER THAT WERE CHOOSING THIS CLASS BECAUSE YOU DONT KNOW WHAT YOU WILL BE QUIZZED ON.
subject: Government

course_title: Data Science for the Social Sciences 001
best_comment: If Blackwell is teaching this class, do not be alarmed by previous bad Q–Guide reports! I was a little worried about taking this class my freshman fall, but it was well taught with so many resources for support outside of class. Blackwell is a great lecturer who does a good job combining coding skills and statistical concepts in his lectures. I will say that having an understanding of some basic statistical concepts may make the class a bit easier to understand. However, it's definitely not necessary.  Similarly, I don't think that you need any knowledge of R to take this class. I came in having never coded in R, and the class definitely takes the time to teach the basics, especially in the first half of the semester. Beyond the class, I genuinely just think there are so many resources to support you with p–sets, projects, and exams that even if you have trouble with the lectures, you should still be alright in the course. Section, office hours, study halls,  and Ed and Slack discussions are all excellent resources. Don't hesitate to go to office hours as much as you need! I went to office hours almost every week to get p–set help, and I'm so glad I did. P–sets were no problem at all for me, and it was because of the incredible help the TFs and CAs provided myself and other students with. The main TFs I went to for help were Ahmet and Pranav, and they were absolutely incredible for the entire semester. Both were excellent section leaders and were very available outside of that. They reliably answered any questions I had about p–sets and my final project. All in all, this class is run very well, and I genuinely believe Blackwell and the course staff want the students to succeed. They certainly did everything they could to make sure we did this semester!
worse_comment: Gov 50 is no longer the horror gov elective that it was once thought to be. Though the coursework isn't easy, the concepts are well–explained and hard to grasp and the problem sets are easy enough to complete in one office hours session. Additionally, the flexibility of the lecture and section makes the workload manageable!
best_gem_comment: INCREDIBLE! I absolutely loved this course. Not so much because of the content (it was a requirement for me) but more so because it was the first class at Harvard other than Ec50 where I felt like the organization and motivation of every single part of the course was intentional and well–crafted. I never felt like it was wasting my time or like it was busy work. Every single thing (except for section) in the course and on the website served a purpose and it did so very well. I can also not say enough nice things about Matt Blackwell. He is a Harvard GEM and we need to protect him at all costs. He cares SO much and it shows so deeply and I am so glad I had him as a professor. I'm worried how the course might change without him next year, but I hope not too much.
subject: Government
course_title_2024: Data Science for the Social Sciences

best_comment: I would recommend that anyone who has completed Gov 1430/1433  take this course. I found it to be an extremely laid–back, fun way to round out the Tech Science curriculum. In this class, you complete a research project of your own choosing.  Meetings are every two weeks for the sole purpose of receiving/providing feedback. The teaching staff is really invested in your success and will help you gain access to any tools that you may need to produce a great project. Since my thesis is tech science–related, I was able to work on a chapter of it for this class, which was amazing.Overall, this class is whatever you want it to be. For me, it was very low–stress and allowed me to pursue a project that I was genuinely interested in. It was also fun to contribute to my classmates' phenomenal projects over the course of the semester. 10/10!
subject: Government

best_comment: I would recommend that anyone who has completed Gov 1430/1433  take this course. I found it to be an extremely laid–back, fun way to round out the Tech Science curriculum. course_title: The Theory and Practice of Civil-Military Relations 001
best_comment: Excellent course, I truly recommend it! The readings are engaging and Avishay is great at moderating debates. The assignment are thought–intensive and not menial work, which is lovely. And Avishay could teach anyone to write an amazing paper, if you just ask. Possibly one of the best government classes for people interested in security and the military.

course_title: The Theory and Practice of Civil-Military Relations 001
best_comment: Excellent course, I truly recommend it! The readings are engaging and Avishay is great at moderating debates. The assignment are thought–intensive and not menial work, which is lovely. And Avishay could teach anyone to write an amazing paper, if you just ask. Possibly one of the best government classes for people interested in security and the military.

This course is great for people who want to learn more about the fields of economics and political science. I came to this course with no previous knowledge/experience in Econ, but I easily made up for that by spending more time on readings/assignments each week. Professor Iversen was also very helpful in this case, always willing to schedule office hours and go through some theories and ideas for the papers. The readings are a bit extensive and very complex, so I would recommend taking this course only if you have the time to apply yourself and actually spend time thinking about the course materials. Overall, a great experience.

course_title: #AbolishPolice: The Politics of Public Safety in the Age of Social Media 001
best_comment: BEST class at Harvard. Halen is a fantastic professor, beyond understanding and flexible. She went out of her way to ensure a strong community was built through outside optional community nights. You also learn so much about yourself and rethink a lot of systems that are in place due to the material learned in class.
worse_comment: I have never taken a class like this before, but I learned a lot about technology and its effect on abolition.

best_comment: A really good course! You will definitely learn a lot about democracy and current examples seen across the world, both now and throughout history. Professor Ziblatt is a really great lecturer and seminar facilitator and would highly recommend to take a course with him at some point during your time at Harvard!

Great class with great readings and incredible in–class discussions. Prof Hiscox is very engaging and a very good seminar leader. He shares a lot of great experiences that he has had from conferences or from past and current research. Definitely take this class. Probably the most interesting class to take to fulfil IR requirement. Also an amazing chill Gov 94 to learn how to do research independently.
subject: Government

best_comment: I cannot recommend this course enough for anyone interested in IR or Comp gov, or for anyone who wants to have a much better understanding of African history, the problems the continent faces today, and some of the solutions and reasons for hope in the face of those issues. Dr. Rhodes was a wonderful professor, and he managed/led discussions masterfully. The semester–long case study project was incredibly manageable and gives you an opportunity to take a deep dive into one country. The content covers basic history of pre–colonial, colonial, and post–independence Africa, with the weight on the latter of the three, and it covers issues from coups to economic development to identity politics, and coming out of this course I feel like I have learned SO MUCH about the continent and especially my specific case study. On paper, the readings may look like a lot, but they are very manageable and if you ever feel that you don't understand one of them, your classmates will be so into the class that it won't be noticeable that you aren't talking for that section of the class. Meanwhile, I never felt like any of the readings being assigned were unnecessary or a waste of time to read, and everything in the course is wonderfully crafted! If you have any interest in this topic PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE!!! I wish there were more like it, and I am incredibly sad that the semester is over
subject: Government

course_title: The Politics and Ethics of Health Care 001
best_comment: GREAT COURSE! The readings were at time long and a little confusing, and it can be easy to get lost in class discussions – but Gabe is an absolutely amazing professor and so supportive.
subject: Government
course_title_2024: The Politics and Ethics of Health Care

best_comment: Prof. Jenn is so, so kind and clearly very knowledgeable about the subject matter. She is always willing to help,  very supportive, and easy to communicate with! She ran section super well, and the class conversation was always informative and enjoyable. Anyone would be lucky to have her as a Prof!

This is one of the BEST courses I have taken at Harvard. Sandel is an amazing professor, and the way he facilitates discussion is unmatched by any other professor. The readings are fun and light– many consist of videos and articles. The discussion component is so interesting because Sandel really finds a way to ignite discussion and get people who have diametrically opposed opinions (based on their discussion posts) to interact with eachother. I looked forward to this course each week and strongly recommend.
subject: Government

course_title: Law and Politics in Multicultural Democracies 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! I CANNOT STRESS THIS ENOUGH! Prof Liviatan is the sweetest, kindest prof at this school, and she is such an amazing, engaging teacher. The readings are actually so interesting, and include a mix of court cases, academic research, and literature. She also stresses the importance of creativity in presenting, and you become much better at presenting over the semester. The class discussions were fire 11/10
subject: Government
course_title_2024: Law and Politics in Multicultural Democracies

best_comment: Please take this class with Dr. Rhodes. You will learn a lot in this course plus Dr. Rhodes is just simply the best and very funny too.
subject: Government

course_title: A Revolt against Globalization? How Political Economies Change 001
best_comment: I would highly recommend taking this class especially if you already have some background in political economy but want to learn more. I learned so so much about political economy in the US and western European nations. The seminar discussions were thought provoking, mini lectures at the start of class were informative, and content itself was really interesting. I do recommend that if you want to contribute to the discussion thoroughly do the readings because the seminar is very lively (its also nice to already have background knowledge in this subject otherwise its easy to get a little lost in the discussion).The main drawback is that since the course is focused on the US and Western European political economies it lacks some diverse perspectives. It would've been nice to at least have more readings from women writers and POC within the US and Western Europe about diverse experiences with the Western political economies, particularly how these political economies have impacted certain groups differently. Overall though, I thoroughly enjoyed the class.

– GREAT CLASS TAEKU IS AWESOME!– this class is really chill, you don't have to do the readings if you don't want to after week 3, but the READINGS ARE SUPER INTERESTING STILL– as a non gov major, this class has made me better understand why someone would want to concentrate in gov, and it has made me understand why an Asian American political collective IS important despite the Asian diaspora being soooo diverse.– Taeku is kind and frequently brings pastries to class, he lets us watch interesting documentaries (like Jeremy Linsanity)– The projects and papers are genuinely interesting because YOU CHOOSE what you want to write about and you can take it somewhere that you actually care about. they feel actionable and purposeful!
If you already have knowledge of or interest in the UN this is a GREAT course, but it is pretty difficult if you do not. The readings can be super dense and there is not much time for background.

course_title: The Politics of Urban Inequality in the United States 001
best_comment: A solid course for those interested in urban studies. I had little knowledge going in – and it seemed like a lot of my peers were a bit more acquainted. But honestly I feel like I caught up pretty fast! I was talking with a friend of mine who majors in Urban Studies at Brown, and it seems like we covered a lot of the most important texts.
subject: Government
course_title_2024: The Politics of Urban Inequality in the United States

best_comment: The Safra workshop is one of the best parts of the fellowship since you get to workshop your thesis/papers with other students who give great feedback and help you come up with even stronger arguments!

The course format or the way that Professor Chen teaches needs to change significantly. Most of the class was lost during lab sections because she moved super quickly, and she was not receptive to that feedback (we tried.) I basically did the labs asynchronously during lab time by following the guides that she created, and my TF Bora was really really great about helping during office hours.I really enjoyed the course material and heard really good things about the class when it was taught by a different professor. It is a fun topic, and has the capacity to be a good class.
subject: Government

best_comment: This is a class that provides a strong, and moderately paced introduction to strategic models/game theory. Every assignment was more than doable, and grading (at least with Juan) was very generous. I felt that I could learn a lot in this class without having to worry about my grade. There is more math than I expected, but it is 100% doable (just basic algebra) so don't let it scare you. Frankly, the class is very interesting if you invest into it. Professor Hummel's slides are clear, and she is a great lecturer – the class also has fun videos/simulations, which were always a delight. Definitely would recommend taking this class, especially if game theory in politics is something that piques your interest.
best_gem_comment: Gem! Absolutely loved this class, definitely one of my favorites. There are only 4 essays and a final paper, around 12–15 days given in between each assignment. The lectures are great, slightly difficult to follow with no background in game theory or any theoretics in Calculus. Professor Hummel is a great professor and is always available and helpful during office hours. No exams/psets which was definitely a course strength.
subject: Government

best_comment: This class is interesting but very reading heavy. Only take it if you love philosophy. As a joint concentrator with philosophy, I enjoyed the material. If you don’t have a passion for ancient philosophy, this class is not for you. However, Dr. Nelson is brilliant and does a fantastic job of drawing out the important parts of the texts.
subject: Government

best_comment: This is a wonderful course. You will learn about how Africa's history (slave trade, colonialism) has shaped its modern politics, how various structural factors (ethnicity, resource wealth) shape incentives to help or hinder development,  the role of the West, and more. If you are interested in the prospects of developing countries generally, you have much to learn from Prof. Raffler, who is very passionate and very approachable. I now have an informed opinion on pathways to African development, and am more interested in careers in development. There are few assignments, all of which are fun and intuitive (although the exam questions were hard due to their breadth). Lecture slides have all you need to know for the exam (along with the readings, of course). You will succeed if you pay attention. Definitely take this one!
worse_comment: I think it you already have a genuine interest in the continent, or maybe you are African and you have family back home there is nothing in this course that you will pick up that you haven't already picked up in life. A lot of this feels like common sense, and I think you will find that you've heard a lot of these things before. You may not learn new content, but you will interact with many academic papers to validate the things you may have picked up before. Whether this is or is not extremely important to you may inform your decision to take this course––it's up to you. I don't think this is an extraordinarily bad class. I don't even think this is a bad class at all. But I do think that is indicative of a larger trend that I see in a lot of GOV department classes and have heard when talking to other concentrators––tedious classes where you may not feel like you're learning anything, a dearth of listings in African politics, and a section that doesn't challenge or provoke thought. This wasn't a *bad* class. But it wasn't particularly good either. And you're not going to feel like you came to Harvard to take classes like this one.

course_title: Politics and Power in Post-Soviet Russia 001
best_comment: I really recommend taking this course!! The topic is extremely interesting and Professor Colton has such an incredible amount of knowledge on the topic. As long as you do the readings and stay engaged in lecture, you will do well.  You will be extremely prepared for both the midterm and final. I had little to no knowledge on the topic coming into this course and am finishing this course having learned more than I have in any other Gov course at Harvard. I highly recommend taking this – the lectures themselves are very interesting and Professor Colton does a great job! The TF was also GREAT.
worse_comment: I learned a lot in this course, but unfortunately it was mostly from the reading and less from the lectures. The readings are broad, varied, and genuinely quite interesting, but Professor Colton's lecture style is not dynamic and was difficult for me to stay engaged with.

best_comment: I enjoyed this course! I think if you have any interest in authoritarian leaders or governments, it's definitely worth trying this class. While the readings can be a bit theoretical, you can definitely see the connection of theory to real–world leaders or history. I was personally pretty excited to see theories from class in real–world politics, something the course highlights nicely with an assignment that asks students to submit news articles/videos/etc about world leaders or events that reflect class themes. I also appreciated the case study aspect of the course where you get to examine a particular authoritarian leader over the course of the semester. I'd recommend avoiding obscure leaders since the assignments related to the case study are very research heavy and often call for quantitative data. Choosing a more obscure leader will make completing these assignments significantly more difficult/time–consuming. Professor Hummel is a great professor. Her lectures are extremely effective, and I'd always prioritize lectures over readings (though I truly recommend doing both! It will make the midterm much easier). She also was available outside of class, and I was able to meet with her for office hours multiple times with very little trouble. Section is good, though it certainly was obvious that many students did not do the readings. However, I think my section leader did a good job of keeping conversation flowing. I'd sincerely recommend meeting with your section leader about each major assignment in the course. As long as I met the expectations I discussed with my section leader during office hours, she was very understanding about grading on all of my essays. Regarding grading, I think the essays were graded fairly. The midterm is open–note, and while there's a tight timeframe given the expectations of the midterm, it's definitely doable with organized notes and a good baseline understanding of the material. I think this course in on the easier side, and it was definitely a good introduction to the Government department in my experience.
worse_comment: Just do the readings and you'll be fine! Though, section wasn't good for me, and it didn't feel helpful at all, almost to the point of me dreading it.
best_gem_comment: The class is fantastic! Professor Hummel's lectures are outstanding, the TF's are great, and the assignments are all manageable given that one finds a strategic case study that can answer many of theories presented in lecture. Readings were relatively moderate in length but chock–full of interesting content. Wouldn't call this class a gem, but it is very interesting and rewarding to take.
subject: Government

best_comment: Highly recommend! Super interesting course that provides you with a broad but insightful overview of american education reform. Class is AMAZING. Everyone is super passionate about the topic at hand and we discuss our readings in depth on Tuesdays. Thursdays are left for amazing guest lecturers that are leaders in education reform. Professor Peterson sometimes says crazy stuff... but take the class! You'll learn so much and actually enjoy yourself.
worse_comment: I would not recommend this class to anyone. The professor called a guest speaker that came to the class "illegal". It is not a comfortable or inclusive space for POC students.
subject: Government

best_comment: TL;DR: fun, super interesting, and relatively easy class – would recommend! Political psychology is such an interesting field, and super relevant in today's political climate. Professor Enos is a fantastic lecturer, very engaging and easy to understand. He has a good pulse on timing, making sure to take breaks for us to discuss with a partner to break up the monotony of lectures. The data exercises help you learn a lot about both the content and data science in general, plus it's cool to get your hands on the data that you've just learned about in lecture. The teaching staff is super helpful, especially with coding, so don't be intimidated if you don't have a ton of experience yet.
best_gem_comment: This class is honestly a gem, especially if you have previous experience working with R. Prof. Enos is a fantastic lecturer, the TFs are great, and the subject matter is interesting week after week. The weekly data exercises are very doable and you learn a lot about the analysis that is done in research in the field by working on them. For my final project, I got to create and conduct my own social science survey with hundreds of actual respondents, which I thought was really cool. If you’re looking for an interesting class in the Gov department, I would definitely recommend this class, especially if you’re a STEM concentrator or also interested in learning about psychology.

course_title: Tech Science: From Democracy to Technocracy and Back 001
best_comment: This is a great class full of awesome content. It can be a little tech doomsday sometimes but think can offer a lot of cool insight to someone who is especially new to the field. Some content requires some technical background to fully grasp on the first go, but all materials are generally easy to digest. This class is overall an awesome way to get introduced to the space. I think Leonie is an amazing lecturer, comments and gives great lectures but can’t help but want more interaction with Latanya Sweeney  as well
subject: Government
course_title_2024: Tech Science: From Democracy to Technocracy and Back

course_title: Tech Science: From Democracy to Technocracy and Back 001
best_comment: This is a great class full of awesome content. It can be a little tech doomsday sometimes but think can offer a lot of cool insight to someone who is especially new to the field. Some content requires some technical background to fully grasp on the first go, but all materials are generally easy to digest. This class is overall an awesome way to get introduced to the space. subject: Government
course_title_2024: Tech Science: From Democracy to Technocracy and Back

best_comment: TAKE IT. OH MY GOD. Changed the way I think. Doesn't matter if you don't want to be a lawyer, all of these things are so relevant and a post–con–law me can now read headlines like a Supreme Court lawyer and not like some political nerd. You don't have to be a political nerd, but you should care about the issues a bit because the course is challenging, but so satisfying if you're engaged. Also, take it whenever, I took it as a first year, fall semester.  Worked out. Fallon is an incredible lecturer, and every class ended in applause. Pretty much every student enrolled was so engaged and cared about the subject, asking fantastic questions that Fallon answered honestly and informatively. The structure of the course was great and I loved every unit. I leaned so, so much historical and political content, and also learned a completely new way of thinking. Sections were so fun, and our TF makes me want to go to law school. The papers were difficult because they were unlike anything I'd written before, but they taught me how to think like a lawyer! Incredible course.
worse_comment: Stay on top of the readings. I did not and it becomes a scary beast at the end when you look back at all the material covered. Take copious notes.
best_gem_comment: Awesome course. Lots of reading, so don’t fall behind, and make sure you go to lecture, but very manageable if you stay on top of your work. Professor Fallon is a gem — funny and incredibly smart. The course grading, not so much. While the content itself is incredibly interesting, and you will come out of the course with a deeper and more thorough understanding of SCOTUS doctrine than you ever imagined, the grading in this course is highly opaque. There are two papers and a final, and it’s very clear that the papers are harshly graded with deflation/grade quota. It’s often very confusing to figure out what the TF wants. However, section–wise, the discussions and debates were my favorite part of the semester. You’ll learn a lot! Just be prepared for whatever they throw at you.

best_comment: This is a great class if you’re looking to broaden your understanding of what it’s actually like to work in the White House and how to become a better person.  Professor Porter and the teaching staff really care about the students and our learning, which is amazing.

If you're interested in international relations, you should definitely take this class. The readings are quite dense, and there's a lot of them, but PLEASE DO THEM! It makes lecture and discussion so much more engaging when you read and understand the theory. It will take some adjusting, but you will find that it becomes easier as time goes on. Christoph and Ruofan are absolutely incredible––––some of the best instructors I've ever had. They are super insightful, caring, dedicated,  kind, organized, and supportive. This class is the perfect amount of challenge. It feels very rewarding at the end of the course. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
worse_comment: Not super in depth about trials

course_title: Science, Technology, and National Security: Japan in Global Perspective 001
best_comment: Prof. Brummer is amazing! Super kind, and he will set up office hours at basically any time to help you out. Every time I went, we ended up speaking for almost an hour. The course is well–structured and the readings are interesting and well–integrated into the lectures. We had a transfer program with master's students from Japan sitting in on the course, which was a really special experience (not sure if this will continue in future years, though). Beyond that, the class is small and the mix of Grads/Undergrads also helps elevate the level of discourse.In terms of work, the class isn't crazy, but you definitely want to put in a good amount of effort to the papers that you do have to write. Luckily, the readings start off pretty heavy but taper off as you get busier working on the midterm/final paper. Grading policy is fair, and feedback on assignments is very helpful. START THE FINAL PAPER EARLY!!!!

This class is amazing! Prof Frieden is that kind of professor you would expect at the world's best university! He is so nice and so wise! The lectures are very freely taught (no slides) but Prof Frieden completely makes up for that with his great ability to explain complex topics and he follows a  very logical and easy–to–follow order. The topic the course teaches is interesting in itself, but Prof Frieden makes this class unforgettable and even more interesting! My best class at Harvard so far!
worse_comment: The material that is learned through this course is incredibly interesting. But it is also very difficult. The 10 page essays are very hard (very few people receive As) and figuring out how to use the three I framework to structure the essay can also be very confusing. But I also can't emphasize enough how rewarding taking this class is in the end (might suggest taking it pass/fail though)

best_comment: This is a great course for anyone interested in neglected regions in international relations discourse or the post–Soviet period outside of Russia. Central Asia features in many of the themes of the times, such as climate change, ethnicity, China–US competition. This course is also a welcome diversion from the usual conflict areas and provides valuable insights on the region. The assignments are very fair and the reading list is reasonable. The readings are much less theoretical than those of courses like Gov 20 and are thus easier to get through.
worse_comment: I think this course is unique in terms of content, and Professor Kassenova has lived experience in the region. However, if you prefer structure in your courses, this class may seem disorganized. Some assignments are unclear, and the grading is not as light as it may appear.
subject: Government

course_title: Central Challenges of American National Security, Strategy, and the Press 001
best_comment: This course might be the most interesting and informative course you take as an undergrad. It is a ton of work, but the lectures are superb –– easily the best that I've had in any lecture course as an undergrad. Assignments are tough and I would recommend going to office hours for additional feedback, but I would highly recommend taking this course if any of the subject matters interest you. Graham, Derek, and David are the best. You will learn a ton.

course_title: Central Challenges of American National Security, Strategy, and the Press 001
best_comment: This course might be the most interesting and informative course you take as an undergrad. It is a ton of work, but the lectures are superb –– easily the best that I've had in any lecture course as an undergrad. Assignments are tough and I would recommend going to office hours for additional feedback, but I would highly recommend taking this course if any of the subject matters interest you. course_title: Central Challenges of American National Security, Strategy, and the Press 001
best_comment: This course might be the most interesting and informative course you take as an undergrad. Assignments are tough and I would recommend going to office hours for additional feedback, but I would highly recommend taking this course if any of the subject matters interest you. Graham, Derek, and David are the best. You will learn a ton.

This class was amazing, I learned so much about Chinese foreign policy as someone who knew nothing about it coming in. The readings are super interesting and important for the monthly discussion responses and the midterm, so definitely do them for that. Lectures are very engaging and only a couple toward the end of the semester were a bit tedious. Section was helpful in explaining more complex concepts, but I really appreciate how understanding the course head and TF were about students that were beginners in IR. This was a really great intro course to IR (even though it's not technically an intro course) and the Professor would explain relevant history while also explaining the most relevant theoretical frameworks for understanding foreign policy. Definitely recommend with enthusiasm!! Small course but super rewarding learning experience!
subject: Government

best_comment: The pace of this class picks up fast. You'll shift from basically probability to inference and regression quickly, so its important to keep up with the lecture notes, review the textbook, and go to section. The PSETs are challenging, so defintely have a strong PSET group to work with. I do think that you walk away from this class with a basic but strong understanding of probability, inference, and regression that lets you learn more on your own. Mathematically, it is quite challenging (especially post–midterm) so in case you thought this was a "Gov" class, don't be fooled. I took this class as an undergraduate Gov major with some moderate mathematical background (Calc BC in HS, and Math 22a) and I certainly found the math challenging but doable. This is a "must–take" for any undergrad interested in doing quantitative research in government, so take it but keep the afformentioned in mind. Grading was relaxed, and getting an A is very doable, conditional on you having a strong PSET group, and being a decent test taker who prepares adequately. I recommend this class, but only for those with a desire to do more math in the context of social sciences!

This is a very challenging class! The 24 hour exam took me 19 straight hours to do. But it's also very rewarding and a very well–resourced course for a class of its size. Kosuke and the teaching staff are all great and patient.I took it as a undergrad with STAT 110 and STAT 111 previously and 139 concurrently (as well as lots of R experience) and was fine for the GOV side of the course, though experience with more advanced regression implementation would certainly be useful. The distinction between the GOV and STAT side can sometimes be blurry, but in general the GOV side is more focused on empirical implementation while STAT focuses on analytical derivations.286/2003 covers a lot of ground. Regardless whether you're STAT or GOV, the course tries to teach both the theoretical underpinnings of various inference methods while teaching you how to implement them, which... is a lot! But it's generally pretty successful in this endeavour.I'd recommend doing all the PSETs and be sure to note that the second half of the course gets much more difficult and has far more content.Also just an aside but the STAT TF Kyla Chasalow is easily the best TF I've ever had. She made the material so clear in her section, even when it could get a bit muddled in lecture. Also she wrote a 130–page note document for the class, effectively serving as a course textbook.
worse_comment: This course is very challenging and you have to invest a lot of time. But your efforts to understand the materials are proportionate to the feeling of acheivement. The course is very demanding and if you have 0 background in statistics, this course will be very difficult.
subject: Government

best_comment: This is tricky but fun, like a puzzle. Put in the time, it's worth it.
subject: Government

best_comment: It is an enjoyable class, but it is definitely what you make it. even if you're the obly one with a certain view point, bring it up as it can spark intellectual debates that others may not have considered.

course_title: The Politics of Health Care in Canada and The U.S. 001
best_comment: This is undoubtedly the best class I have ever taken. This is a true gem of a course and courses like these are what make a Harvard education so worth it. Professor Maioni is just an unparalleled professor. She is both kind and empathetic to her students, and leads the class with brilliance, poise, and a real commitment to helping her students understand healthcare. Additionally, some of the coolest speakers I have seen at this school were guest speakers in this course and Professor Maioni facilitated incredible discussions with each and every one of them. This course does take some time—it is a lot of reading and a paper summary each week in addition to other assignments—but it is worth every hour you put into this course and Professor Maioni provides thoughtful and timely feedback on every assignment you submit in this course. This course made me really grateful to be a student at Harvard where we have access to courses like this and I can only hope that I will have an opportunity to take a course like this again.
best_gem_comment: This is undoubtedly the best class I have ever taken. This is a true gem of a course and courses like these are what make a Harvard education so worth it. Professor Maioni is just an unparalleled professor. She is both kind and empathetic to her students, and leads the class with brilliance, poise, and a real commitment to helping her students understand healthcare. Additionally, some of the coolest speakers I have seen at this school were guest speakers in this course and Professor Maioni facilitated incredible discussions with each and every one of them. This course does take some time—it is a lot of reading and a paper summary each week in addition to other assignments—but it is worth every hour you put into this course and Professor Maioni provides thoughtful and timely feedback on every assignment you submit in this course. This course made me really grateful to be a student at Harvard where we have access to courses like this and I can only hope that I will have an opportunity to take a course like this again.

best_comment: Good introduction to political economics with two great and enthusiastic professors (Pia and Torben).
Good introduction to political economics with two great and enthusiastic professors (Pia and Torben).

Great as a foray into the region! I wouldn't recommend if you're someone who prefers a lot of structure/clarity when it comes to your research and graded assignments, (this class was much more free form) but the tag team of Ekiert and Colton is really enriching for anyone interested in the post–socialist space.

course_title: American Government and Politics: Field Seminar 001
best_comment: The class is perfectly reasonable in its requirements and not difficult at all, and the faculty themselves are excellent, but you likely will not learn much about American politics.
