course_title_2024: American Government and Politics: Field Seminar

best_comment: This course was my favorite course this semester! The sessions were so engaging, and doing data analysis every week and seeing what others in the class did was very helpful to learn to think outside the box, which is very important when doing new research.

As it stands, this class will probably only be really useful to you if you are planning to go into IR. That said, you will probably learn a lot and it won't be a waste of your time because you will be required to engage.
subject: Government

best_comment: As it stands, this class will probably only be really useful to you if you are planning to go into IR. That said, you will probably learn a lot and it won't be a waste of your time because you will be required to engage.
subject: Government

best_comment: It is not easy, but it also is not impossible. The readings will require some time, but if you are committed to learning about IOs from one of the preeminent scholars in the field, then this seminar is just the course for you.

This is one of the best seminars I have taken in my undergraduate and graduate coursework simply because of the dedication and enthusiasm of the instructors, classmates, and speakers. We were an inquisitive bunch that asked questions all throughout each session, and continuing to question the assumptions, positioning, and impact of our research has been an important part of Health Policy Foundations.
subject: Health Policy

course_title: Capitalism, Crime, and Punishment in American History 01
best_comment: 100% take this class if you are interested in 19th/20th century U.S. History and are willing to put in a bit of work. This is probably the best history class I've taken so far (as a junior in the concentration) and I don't say that lightly. I learned so much from the readings –– which are all awesome and very intentionally chosen so definitely spend some time doing them...or at the very least doing part of them since they are like 200 pages a week –– and the discussion is very centered on discussing the readings in depth so it helps you really understand them. There were weeks when I wasn't able to do the reading and it was fine, as Prof. Bekemeyer is so so nice and really just wants to help you (so if no one knew an answer he would help by asking more leading questions lol like he wouldn't leave you out to dry with the discussion). The assignments are a typical scaffolded history assignment structure where you lead up to a final paper on a specific topic you choose based on primary source material – pretty standard here. Prof. Bekemeyer and Sanjay are great – it's the perfect mix of seriousness –– decent amount of reading, discussion cannot be bs'd and the assignments also are taken decently seriously (although I wouldn't say are graded super hard, pretty reasonable). It's a great course for a history concentrator (like me) but it is also a good class for someone who is scared to take their first history seminar/might not have as much of a history background. It's pretty intense on the amount of reading and the final assignment is a 15 page paper creating an original argument based on primary sources (aka you can't just summarize what has been said about your topic before) which can be a bit tough if you haven't written a paper like that before, but if you are willing to push yourself I'd definitely recommend. Prof. Bekemeyer and Sanjay are so supportive and I highly recommend going to their office hours. Overall one of my favorite courses here and I'd recommend it to anyone at all interested (with the caveat that you need to put a good amount of effort/time in lol).
worse_comment: Take this course only if you have preliminary knowledge on capitalism, crime, and punishment. Class discussion is great and you will learn a lot from this course.

course_title: Australian Environmental History: Gondwanda to Global Warming 01
best_comment: This is an amazing course! It was a great way to learn about Australia, but also how environmental history is studied and practiced more generally. Katie is extremely intelligent, kind, and helpful, and truly wants each student to follow their own passions and interests. The readings and assignments were all engaging and useful for the final research paper. The way the assignments are spaced out allows a lot of time for exploration and development of ideas, and results in a research paper that you can really be proud of!

This is a very unique History course, and while it heavily revolves around reading novels, it is quite different from what you might find in the English or Hist/Lit department. You will learn important skills like close reading and textual analysis, but all with a historical lean to it. You will not come away from this class with specific names and dates from Brazilian history, but you will engage with some of my favorite novels in recent memory, with the works by Machado de Assis being a particular highlight for me. Course assignments are manageable, but a good sense of time management and critical reflection are necessary to keep up with the roughly one novel a week cadence. I also have the highest praise for Professor Chalhoub, who consistently delivers some of the most exciting seminar topics in the department in a low–stress, high–energy, extremely positive environment. As a small seminar, you will have plenty of opportunities to make a meaningful contribution and learn from one another, but also get to know Professor Chalhoub, whose availability and flexibility are unmatched. I highly recommend any course he teaches, even if you aren't coming from the strongest background in that subject matter.
This is a FANTASTIC course. This is one of the best classes I have taken in the history department. Great readings, great professor.

course_title: Race, Gender, and the Law Through the Archive 01
best_comment: I rate this class 6/10. Solid history class, but I want to make a huge caveat: You’ll only get one, biased viewpoint on the history of Black lawmaking in this class. The instructor has very left–leaning ideals, and so do the students. The only lawyers that were given case studies were far left–leaning. They were upheld as martyrs. There was no political diversity in this course, which made for a very boring and intellectually dull experience. There was no room for debate. Not all Black lawyers are liberal. I would’ve loved to learn more about conservative Black lawyers and their impacts. Liberals don’t have all the answers. Students self–select into this class, so beware of the class discussions. They’re very left–leaning and left no room for critiques of leftist/liberal ideals. I mentioned representation of conservative Black lawyers in class once and I got shunned. This class has no room for academic freedom. Discussions were long and monotonous and repetitive. It’s the same 11 “future lawyers/activists” and IOP kids spewing their half–baked thoughts on inequality and Black rights—when 80% of the class wasn’t even Black. One day we wasted 45 minutes discussing what pronouns we should use for Pauli Murray. I believe in gender representation/rights, but minuscule details like that are not important for understanding the depth of her impact. No one paid attention in class discussions. Maybe one or two students. Everyone else just did work on their laptops. Given the self–selection into this class, be prepared to meet and be irritated by the obnoxious social justice warriors. One student would never fail to remind us that she’s doing research at Radcliffe and has swipe access to all the buildings. That’s just the nature of people who’d be interested in this class—obnoxious people who think they know the answer to everything. In–class discussions and discussion posts were absolutely useless. Other than that, it’s a solid history course. It’s unique in that you get full access to Schlesinger library. Something that you should take advantage of during your time here — especially if you’re a woman. I enjoyed the research process. Professor Eatmon is a solid professor and accessible with writing/research assistance. She’s not the most organized though. She changed the final assignment halfway into the course, which was incredibly frustrating and unprofessional. We were originally given the option to record a podcast, which attracted a lot of people to the course—including myself. After the add/drop deadline. she changed the final assignment to only having the option of writing a 3,000 word paper….Baiting people into a class with a fun final project—just to change it at the last minute—is not cool. I didn’t appreciate that at all, and future students should beware of this behavior. The archival activities were interesting and unique. Outside of that, I wouldn’t recommend this course. Find another way to engage with the library archives and do research on campus.

course_title: The Origins of the Cold War: The Yalta Conference (1945) 01
best_comment: This class is extremely interesting and worth taking! Based on the course summary, I was not sure I would like the class but needed the credit for my major, but the content was much more engaging and interesting than expected. If you are interested in the history of international diplomacy during World War II or power dynamics between major world leaders, you'll love this class. Professor Plokhii is also one of the best professors I have had at Harvard. He expects a lot from you, but is so encouraging and lighthearted in class.
subject: History
course_title_2024: The Origins of the Cold War: The Yalta Conference (1945)

course_title: Markets and States: The History of Economic Thought Since 1750 01
best_comment: The history of markets and states is a hefty topic to tackle, but the twelve weeks of classes will effectively guide you across a wide range of historical topics and ideas. The readings and discussions were incredible and thought–provoking, and the final paper (if daunting at first) proved a satisfying opportunity for exciting research. Professor Rothschild and Salmaan are amazing, of course, but my classmates brought quite a lot to the table as well: the final few classes are devoted to topics chosen and presented by students, and everyone's discussions of a topic of personal interest (often influenced by personal experience and knowledge) added extra character to a great class. Would highly recommend!

If you're a history concentrator wondering whether to write a thesis, just know that Hist99 is an amazingly well run course that will keep you organized and in community with your peers. History department is a great place to write your thesis because of all the support and structure this class gives.
subject: History

course_title: Immigration Law: A History of the Present 01
best_comment: SUCH A WONDERFUL COURSE! Difficult, definitely, but in all the best ways. Professor H–G is awesome — thoughtful, always looking to improve, and creative in constructing lesson plans. I learned about the complex history of immigration in this country, and how it came to be. I learned important research skills, as well! And I learned about the field of immigration law, from court–watching and from currently–practicing lawyers who came in to speak to the class. My TF was so lovely — she made section such a safe and welcome place, and the classmates I got to know through group projects, assigned "teams" and seats in lecture, and through section, were such great, passionate people. Just beware that class is structured in a slightly unorthodox way — instead of a final exam, there are reading quizzes for each lecture, which are difficult and not open–book. There is a substantial group project, too, and lecture is structured to be more engaging than most others. We do classwork with our "teams," who we sit with, and groupwork is very much valued.
worse_comment: If you are a student who likes structure, relies on assignments, and doesn’t do well with lengthy readings this is NOT the course for you. The professor and TF’s are kind but they were not prepare to teach this course this semester. Quizzes werent graded for weeks on end, the quizzes are extremely difficult even when you do the readings, the group project was supposed to be graded at the start of December and students have yet to get their grades, we didn’t get the rubric for the final assignment until the last few classes in the semester, this course has a lot of potential but is simply way too disorganized.

best_comment: This is maybe my favorite course I've ever taken. If you are interested in history at all, TAKE THIS COURSE!!! The readings are a lot of primary sources, which is amazing, in my opinion! Prof. Penslar is an amazing teacher, and so is Tsiona, the TF. The material is well structured, and I can see through lines throughout history. I feel I have a comprehensive understanding of a lot of the material, learning a lot but still understanding it on more than a surface level. The assignments are engaging and difficult in the best possible way. An amazing course.However, this is definitely an intensive course. It's not that hard to get a pretty good grade, but it is a lot of work. It is a lot of reading, and about 500–700 words ever other week, as well as a written midterm and final. It's a lot of writing, and a course that is best suited for people who already have a passion for history or other social sciences/humanities. If you are uncomfortable doing a bunch of reading and writing, you might find this class incredibly difficult. But, it is 100% worth the challenge, it is a super fun course, and if you put in the work, you get a lot out of it.

This is maybe my favorite course I've ever taken. If you are interested in history at all, TAKE THIS COURSE!!! The readings are a lot of primary sources, which is amazing, in my opinion! Prof. Penslar is an amazing teacher, and so is Tsiona, the TF. The material is well structured, and I can see through lines throughout history. I feel I have a comprehensive understanding of a lot of the material, learning a lot but still understanding it on more than a surface level. The assignments are engaging and difficult in the best possible way. An amazing course.However, this is definitely an intensive course. It's not that hard to get a pretty good grade, but it is a lot of work. It is a lot of reading, and about 500–700 words ever other week, as well as a written midterm and final. It's a lot of writing, and a course that is best suited for people who already have a passion for history or other social sciences/humanities. If you are uncomfortable doing a bunch of reading and writing, you might find this class incredibly difficult. But, it is 100% worth the challenge, it is a super fun course, and if you put in the work, you get a lot out of it.

Take this class!! The material is so interesting and Professor Jasanoff is an amazing lecturer, so you learn so much in every class. It's also fairly easy –– just weekly quizzes and 2 papers over the course of the semester. You can do well without doing all of the readings but they're definitely useful and interesting. Take advantage of Professor Jasanoff's office hours!
worse_comment: I would tell future students to definitively take this course if you want to learn about the history of the British Empire. This course will make you look differently at their impact and how the rest of the world has been affected.
best_gem_comment: Absolutely take this class—without hesitation.  The course material is incredibly rich, engaging, and relevant regardless of your level of overall interest in history.  The course is also extremely inclusive of all concentrations and academic backgrounds.  A great gem.

best_comment: Really good class, both Professor Howell and Hwei–Ru are amazing resources for assignments. The workload really isn't too bad, just a discussion post a week, and the content is presented in an interesting and engaging way.
subject: History

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!! I absolutely loved this class. Professor Martin is amazing and so passionate about the subject. I came into the class knowing nothing about WWI and was unsure how I would like it, but it ended up being my favorite class so far. The lectures are so engaging and so interesting. Professor Martin makes even the more boring topics seem like the most fascinating things ever. Even if you are not super interesting in the war, you learn about so much more than just the battles. Professor Martin discusses a wide array of topics and includes information about all different groups of people. You will learn not just about 1914–1918, but the years before and after, and even more about the war's legacy today. I highly, highly recommend.
worse_comment: 10/10 class. It's a must–take if you're even remotely interested. This is everything a war history class should be. Weekly work load is maneagable, and assignments and final exam are very logical and rewarding. You will learn about battles and some leaders, but war is so much more than that; and this class is too. You also learn about the lived experience of soldiers and civilians, the war economies, the lesser–known stories and fronts, and the legacy of such a pivotal war. Prof Martin is an excellent, engaging, and expert lecturer.  Couldn't recommend it more.

course_title: The New Science of the Human Past: Case Studies at the Cutting Edge 01
best_comment: Congratulations! You just stumbled onto one of Harvard's finest classes. Perhaps you're a freshmen who doesn't know what to take or perhaps you're a STEM kid just trying to satisfy the social sciences requirement. Either way, HIST 1056 should absolutely be on your schedule. There are almost no graded assignments, so it's a great opportunity to learn some genuinely interesting content in a relaxed setting. Furthermore, the only assignments that are graded couldn't be more chill. We also went on multiple field trips, in which we did everything from analyzing ancient coins to making our own pottery to having lunch with notable professors. Finally, if Reed Morgan is your TF, it's a huge bonus; he's absolutely wonderful and was he highlight of the course for me.
worse_comment: Such an amazin class, there is really nothing like it in terms of interdisciplinary classes you could take at Harvard. Its just readings from the past like 2 years on the most recent developments, a book by a forefront leader in the field who you get to meet, and a final project about literally anything you want. You can get out of this class what you put in, and putting in just a little bit of time will change how you view the field of the Science of the Human past.
subject: History
course_title_2024: The New Science of the Human Past: Case Studies at the Cutting Edge

best_comment: This course is an excellent overview of early modern European history, emphasizing breadth over depth. For students on the fence about the History concentration, there is no better place to start than here, as the assignments are structured in a way that will make you feel more comfortable developing a historical argument by the end. The reading load and papers are not overwhelming, and the lack of traditional sit–down exams makes this a good fit for anyone looking to hone their writing skills. Lectures were interesting and engaging, with Professor Herzog doing an excellent job of posing questions and challenging her students to make connections. Noga was also a wonderful TF who was always willing to give feedback on drafts and fostered a very positive section environment.
worse_comment: I found this course very wishy washy given that everything I learned came from Professor Herzog's lectures with no secondary sources to back anything up. The assignments were unrelated to the course material, covering topics like "go to a museum and write an essay about the argument the exhibition is making" or "find an archive and write a paper about how it is organized." Some students might find these simple assignments and lack of secondary source reading as gem–like, but I just found the assignments annoying to do. Even more frustrating, they were graded in a very nit–picky, surprisingly harsh way. I didn't find any assignment gratifying, and the grading was very uncharitable, especially given how vague/simple all the assignments were.  These assignments also didn't really build any of my skills as a history student. The final paper involved three ridiculously vague prompts and only 3 pages to discuss 500 years of European history. No secondary source reading allowed, only lecture notes, and it was so odd and vague. And it just felt a bit silly to not have my work grounded in anything written and to not be able to use any citations. The lectures were fine but there were often big jumps taken. I didn't have a great experience in this course and wouldn't recommend it.

course_title: U.S. Foreign Policy in a Global Age 01
best_comment: Truly one of the best classes I have taken at Harvard so far. Logevall is truly amazing and you also get to learn so much from mid career students. Grade–wise, it will be tough because the final paper accounts for 50 % of your grade.

course_title: The American Century?: A History of the United States since World War II 01
best_comment: 4TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Bekemeyer is an amazing professor and teaches well. The readings some weeks were a bit heavy, ranging from 120–160. However, if you skimmed it good it was okay. This course gives you a good foundation for good courses, (I did not know much about history prior to this course)
subject: History
course_title_2024: The American Century?: A History of the United States since World War II

best_comment: This is by far the best course i've taken at Harvard. I usually never write evaluation's for courses but this course was so incredible that I had to write this response, so here we go. The lectures and readings are intellectually stimulating and Professor Frank Johnson is an incredible orator and teacher.  For how difficult some of the subjects are that this course addresses( Holocaust, and antisemitism), Professor Frank Johnson does an amazing job unpacking these topics in detail while also illustrating larger higher level social patterns within Germany. The classes assignments are rewarding and build upon information from section and lecture, but are not assignments just to give the students busy work. Rather they are assignments that are shorter but have the students thinking critically about themes in this class. Any course with Professor Frank Johnson I would recommend, however this course is so amazing that its worth taking.
worse_comment: Please take this course. It is essential for understanding the state of modern Germany, as well as a stark reminder of exactly how democracies can be undermined, and the nightmare that ensues. Alison and her teaching staff are among the kindest, most understanding team I have yet seen at Harvard. I cannot recommend them or this course highly enough.
subject: History

best_comment: I can't recommend this course strongly enough. The lectures are exceptionally interesting, and the course covers a lot of cool themes relating to Ukraine and the region as a whole. Prof. Plokhy is amazing– extremely knowledgeable, engaging, and friendly. The readings can be quite time–consuming at times, but they are invaluable to understanding the course concepts and getting the most out of the lectures, so it's good to try to stay on top of them. The class emphasizes discussions and they are a lot of fun.
subject: History

best_comment: If this is offered again PLEASE take it! You will learn a ton, and if your experience is like mine you will be in a small class with really dedicated and great fellow students. The readings are great and totally doable if you're good at getting the main ideas. You will really learn what a crazy country this was! There is a final paper and a final exam, which is a bit tough, but it shouldn't dissuade you from what was a great course. If Leora is still TFing, my recommendation is doubled –– she is amazing!

This course is worth taking! With great depth, it covers intellectual history from the ancient period to late antiquity. That being said, the course felt less like an intellectual history course and more like a political philosophy course. Not a big deal, but perhaps something to keep in mind. If you have any interest in philosophies including Epicureanism or Stoicism, here is an opportunity to learn about them in their original context(s). A huge bonus: no random, busy assignments that take time away from engaging completely with all the readings. So long as you do the readings, pay attention in class, and review your notes now and then, you will learn a lot!

course_title: German Social Thought, Nietzsche to Habermas 01
best_comment: Peter Gordon is the real deal.  He is able to break down the most complicated ideas into the most straightforward language like no professor I've had before, and does so with so much energy and passion that every lecture felt like a master class. I would love to hear him lecture on anything, but the content of the course was also especially well–curated. The course connected philosophical texts seamlessly with German history, with a special emphasis on art (every class began with an excerpt from a different German composer which related to the themes we were about to cover); it was truly interdisciplinary! Furthermore, JP was one of the best section leaders I've ever had. He masterfully guided discussions and made me feel so welcomed and supported. Even though I was nowhere near as qualified to talk about these texts as other students, I felt so comfortable adding my input thanks to his encouragement.  Such a great experience!
worse_comment: I learned how to read before I learned how to talk, so I never really had to say the words "I can't read" until I took a stab at Heidegger. But despite Heidegger's best efforts with Dasein Being–in–the–world vorhanden zuhanden being–towards–death throwness etc. etc., I learned how to read. Now, I can annoy all my friends with a diatribe about how being just a girl in the world is actually a rather Heideggerian concept, then I can use communicative rationality to quash their protests on the battlefield of ideas.

best_comment: The lectures are engaging and students get to voice their opinions freely and without any pressure. There is a large amount of reading though, and 100% of your grade is based on an open–book final exam in which you consult all of the semester's readings. Be prepared for a huge time commitment, as the readings are very important to class discussions and the final. You are guaranteed to learn a lot and for undergraduates curious about law school, this will give you a cool experience!
worse_comment: While this class does not have any assignments except for the final, this is not a class that you can coast through without actively engaging and trying to get the most out of the readings that you can. Interesting class but beware the 8 hour take home final with two essays.

best_comment: This is a course about colonial Latin America, but it's more so about how historians work and how to challenge traditional narratives about the period. For instance, you won't learn much about what Columbus did, but you will learn a ton about the epistemological debates about whether Columbus–type figures should even be centered at all. In this sense, I felt I learned a lot about how to think about colonial Latin America but didn't learn a ton of traditional facts about the era (you won't really learn about any kings, big dates/events, etc.). The course is structured thematically instead of chronologically or geographically, and Prof. Herzog brings in a lot of European history as a means to understand the period (which is interesting, since Prof. Herzog is also a scholar of Europe). The assignments are really good because they allow you to go through the historical process and aren't lengthy for the sake of more work. Kevin is one of the best TFs I've ever had and gives a lot of helpful feedback.
worse_comment: good class to take in regard to assignments but not the most interesting material
best_gem_comment: THIS IS A GEM! For any history concentrator or anyone interested in the history of colonial Latin America, this course is excellent. Do not hesitate to take this course because you will not regret it.

best_comment: Such an amazing class. The final capstone project opportunity is so nice and so much better than a final. Students had the chance to work on some amazing, real world projects for class credit. Lectures and reading was very engaging and informative as well.
worse_comment: Unfortunately, this class (with Professor Kamensky) will no longer be offered. It was a great class, and I'm sad future students won't be able to take it.

course_title: A Critical Introduction to the Study of the Middle East 01
best_comment: The professor and TF were great. This was great at guiding us through engaging with historical scholarship. It is a history of the study of the Middle East, not the history of the Middle East. Important to know that.
subject: History
course_title_2024: A Critical Introduction to the Study of the Middle East

course_title: The Ottoman Empire and the World II (1550-1920) 01
best_comment: Professor Kafadar is incredibly knowledgeable and interesting. His lectures are very free–flowing and sometimes hard to grasp. Like any other class, if you do the readings before hand, and even read ahead if you can, then you will get so much more out of the lectures. I would encourage you to read as much as you can before lectures so that you can interact and steer the lecture to things that you found confusing in the readings.

course_title: Nationalism, Political Independence, and Economic Development in Africa 01
best_comment: Professor Akyeampong is a very thoughtful teacher, and I am glad that I took this elective even without a history background (let alone working knowledge on African history). His course provides a thorough and engaging overview of African post–colonial and post–independence development.  You will mostly be grappling with political economy texts which embrace a lot of technical content from both economics and political science, which is a welcome challenge if you are not from these fields (or history). It is certainly a course where you will get more out of it by putting in the work. You should be prepared to dedicate focused time for reading the assigned texts and conducting some light research on your topics of interest. Discussion time with your peers will seem arduous at first, but the insights and learnings you get from each other will be wonderful.  Professor Akyeampong's class is a wonderful opportunity to grapple with the nuances and characters of modern African history especially as an outsider, and the Professor is an excellent guide.

Take this course!! Prof. Jasanoff has intentionally designed this seminar to be extremely engaging and open for experimentation. I've never been in a seminar in which the class time has gone by faster. Each week, you discuss a new theme about the writing process and learn so much via discussion about the interesting readings. Per design, the assignments are low stress and offer opportunity for experimentation. You want to work hard because Prof. Jasanoff gives such interesting and helpful feedback on every assignment that will make you a better writer. You will also learn so much from other people in the seminar. The final paper is a great opportunity for feedback from Prof. Jasanoff and other experienced writers on your creative risks. This course is  beyond a 10/10, and I can't recommend it enough.

If you have an interest in Chinese history, history, and economic history, this is a great class to take! You don't need to know any Chinese (reading and speaking Chinese is not required). The class is structured like a traditional history seminar. Each session is a discussion where groups of students present on readings for that week. The readings can be hard to digest especially since a lot of the theories and ideas are very difficult to understand as an undergraduate, but Professor Ghosh is great at breaking down concepts. Don't get intimidated by the graduate students in the class. They offer so much knowledge, and honestly, you will learn so much!! Although the class was challenging, it was challenging in a good way. You will truly learn how different facades and aspects within Chinese history (and cultural theory) and economics helped China develop into an economic superpower (or attempt to explain how China developed so fast). The readings you will read are very diverse in language (you'll get a few math/quantitative readings), time period, and authors (historians, sociologists, economists). Truly recommend this course!

This is a great course, but be prepared to put in a lot of time. Heavy weekly reading load, and you must do the reading to participate in class discussion. Readings tend to be the type of material I expected to find in a government class rather than history. You'll also be required to facilitate class discussion 2–3 times by submitting reading questions ahead of time. You will get out what you put in. I learned SO MUCH in this class, and Prof. Aumoithe is incredibly passionate and engaging, truly a great professor. He made me feel very comfortable in class and office hours, and encourages out of the box thinking. He is incredibly knowledgeable on this topic.
worse_comment: If you are good at doing independent work then do it. Don't take it if you are not previously interested in American Healthcare or Welfare. Assignments are vague and are able to be taken in a direction that you decide on. Not that much engagement with the teacher.

best_comment: This class was super comprehensive, and Professor Martin is an engaging speaker with a vast body of knowledge. My one reservation is that there were a lot of readings, like ballpark 400 pages per week, so if you're a slower reader I might think about whether you have enough time in your schedule.
worse_comment: Do not leave readings and/or assignments until the last minute. You will run out of time and become stressed. Break down the readings day by day and enroll in this course knowing that the amount of reading expected to be completed is very, very high.

course_title: Early Medieval History, Archaeology and Archaeoscience: Seminar 01
best_comment: Professor McCormick is an amazing guide as you navigate the intricacies of Late Antique and Early Medieval History.  He begins the course with a history of the seminar method, and builds up the class as a community of researchers.  The class really becomes an opportunity to build interdisciplinary skills, apply them to a topic of personal interest, and workshop a publication quality paper over the course of the semester.  You will learn a great deal about the period, acquire new concrete skills in philology and archaeology, and have great fun along the way.  I highly recommend the course to any graduate student with even a tangential interest in the period.

course_title: Histories of Material Objects: Books and Instruments from the Early Modern World: Seminar 01
best_comment: This is a fantastic class! Ann and Hannah are great teachers and lead fascinating class discussions. The class attracted a group from a range of disciplinary backgrounds, and one of the highlights was learning from my fellow students about their projects and research interests. I also really appreciated the scaffolded approach that the class took to the final project: we submitted the essay in stages, and this process led me to produce a final paper that I think reflects some of my best work. All in all, I loved this seminar and I highly recommend it!

course_title: Histories of Material Objects: Books and Instruments from the Early Modern World: Seminar 01
best_comment: This is a fantastic class! Ann and Hannah are great teachers and lead fascinating class discussions. The class attracted a group from a range of disciplinary backgrounds, and one of the highlights was learning from my fellow students about their projects and research interests. I also really appreciated the scaffolded approach that the class took to the final project: we submitted the essay in stages, and this process led me to produce a final paper that I think reflects some of my best work. All in all, I loved this seminar and I highly recommend it!

Two of the best and most knowledgeable professors at Harvard. Really enjoyable to hear them discuss some of the most important questions of political thought, and we learned an impressively broad amount of material.

Two of the best and most knowledgeable professors at Harvard. Really enjoyable to hear them discuss some of the most important questions of political thought, and we learned an impressively broad amount of material.

course_title: Afrodescendant Citizenship in Latin America: Mobilization, Contestation, and Change 01
best_comment: This is an amazing course on a topic that is rarely taught at Harvard. Prepare for A LOT of reading, as a full book and several shorter articles are assigned each week. That said, all of the readings are so carefully chosen and teach you so much about the history of Afrodescendant mobilization in Latin America. The professors are super encouraging and are always available to meet during office hours. I also really appreciated the Sawyer Seminar component of the course because we were able to hear personally from Latin American Afrodescendent activists who are working on these issues on the ground.

course_title: Afrodescendant Citizenship in Latin America: Mobilization, Contestation, and Change 01
best_comment: This is an amazing course on a topic that is rarely taught at Harvard. Prepare for A LOT of reading, as a full book and several shorter articles are assigned each week. That said, all of the readings are so carefully chosen and teach you so much about the history of Afrodescendant mobilization in Latin America. The professors are super encouraging and are always available to meet during office hours. I also really appreciated the Sawyer Seminar component of the course because we were able to hear personally from Latin American Afrodescendent activists who are working on these issues on the ground.

course_title: Readings in Colonial and Revolutionary America: Proseminar 01
best_comment: Historians of science studying modern U.S. topics seeking a course to fulfill your pre–1800 requirement...Prof. Chaplin is a historian of science. This course will be incredibly useful for your work. Take this class!!!!

Graduate class, discussion based, so would recommend if you have background/experience on history of economics/economic thought, and/or the economic history of a region (eg economic history of US/China/UK etc.) – this doesn't really do the canon and moves beyond it to more interesting themes. but as the class crowdsources the readings for most of the weeks, it is highly dependent on your classmates. there is a TON of readings so helpful if you are skilled at reading quickly. it is a graduate class so some of the concepts discussed are pretty high level and abstract. overall recommend but only if you have the background to contribute in discussion

Graduate class, discussion based, so would recommend if you have background/experience on history of economics/economic thought, and/or the economic history of a region (eg economic history of US/China/UK etc.) – this doesn't really do the canon and moves beyond it to more interesting themes. but as the class crowdsources the readings for most of the weeks, it is highly dependent on your classmates. there is a TON of readings so helpful if you are skilled at reading quickly. it is a graduate class so some of the concepts discussed are pretty high level and abstract. overall recommend but only if you have the background to contribute in discussion

I had previously taken an "intro to history" course as a master's degree student. Those instructors should take notes from Professor Bsheer. This course was clearly thought through (more than any course I think I've ever taken), and I walked away from every week feeling like I had gained a new skillset with which I can now approach (or at least think about) as I write history.
subject: History

best_comment: I loved this course and would 100% recommend it to anyone interested in Asian American studies. The syllabus is so interesting and covers a diverse range of the Asian American diaspora. There is an amazing blend of theoretical, academic, and creative works included. Karen is a fantastic instructor – she prompts really interesting discussions and is extremely thoughtful and kind.
subject: History & Literature

best_comment: Please take this class! Angela is a great professor and the films and texts lead to really interesting, engaging class discussions. Highly, highly recommend!

course_title: Human Rights and Humanitarianism in the Modern World 001
best_comment: If history and philosophy are your thing, then this class is perfect for you. If they are not, then you may find the class to be too demanding. There are often multiple long–ish readings a week, and it's best to do them if you want to spend your two hours of class doing anything other than staring absently at your computer screen. I found the class to be difficult but also very engaging: most of the class is spent unpacking the key ideas of human rights and humanitarianism that most of us don't even realize have shaped our worldviews. Everything you hear will feel strange in the most interesting way once you take this class and then just start listening to what is being said online, on TV, in the news, etc. The assignments for this class could be hard, but the first papers are pretty short (only 5–6 page) and there's a lot of freedom for the final. In the end, I found the assignments for this class were the ones I enjoyed doing the most (even if the amount of time I left myself to complete them wasn't always optimal for that enjoyment).

Take this class!!! Vikrant is amazing. You learn so much about the South Asian diaspora, which gave me a chance to connect with my heritage in a really nice way. (Everyone in our class was South Asian but it's definitely open to everyone, and Vikrant does a great job of making sure the conversation isn't solely focused on our identities.) It's definitely very manageable –– the readings are very interesting, and the 2 response papers were a bit stressful but Vikrant guides you through them. As someone with a non–humanities background I was a bit nervous going into the class, but I'm so glad I took it!

course_title: Race and Empire in the Americas 001
best_comment: This is a wonderful course! If you've never taken a Hist and Lit class, this is the perfect introduction to the department. Hannah is one of the best professors I've had at Harvard. The course has a consistent workload: two papers, a public engagement project, weekly response papers, and a final project (broken down into smaller assignments). However, I never felt overwhelmed in the class and the material was so interesting that I didn't mind spending a long time on the assignments. I enjoyed learning about imperialism in its historical context, as well as looking at modern–day iterations of imperialism, such as international aid and adoption. I also appreciated that Hannah gave us multiple options for the public engagement project and the final paper. If you don't want to write a traditional paper for the final, you don't have to!
subject: History & Literature
course_title_2024: Race and Empire in the Americas

course_title: The South: Histories of a U.S. Region 001
best_comment: This is quite literally the only class about The South at Harvard. Dr. Kriby is awesome and I'm so grateful she created this class, at a school that doesn't really have anything like it. Lowkey this made me wish I would have considered Hist–Lit as a concentration lol. Great class! Highly recommend any class with Dr.Kirby she is brilliant!
subject: History & Literature
course_title_2024: The South: Histories of a U.S. Region

best_comment: This course was amazing!! Professor Bloom is an incredible lecturer and his course truly opened my eyes to the history of slavery. He made the classroom environment feel welcoming, comfortable, and engaging. The readings can be long at times but they were interesting, so it wasn't awful. Couldn't recommend this course enough!

PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN EDUCATION!!! Dr. Gowen is amazing and does a great job of selecting significant course materials! You will also be surrounded by amazing students who will improve your experience in the course. Furthermore, the course might change your perspective as it comes to achieving education reform and will inform you on your educational policy ideas
subject: History & Literature

best_comment: One of my most meaningful classes at Harvard. I've had some of my most thoughtful, fun, and engaging discussions through this class. Some fun perks are that there's a trip to Houghton, some movies, and cool sources, but honestly the most memorable days of class were the more seemingly boring ones where we just sat around at the table and had a discussion for the whole time. Readings aren't difficult, there are only two essays and a final paper (and you get to pick which weeks you want to schedule those 2 papers), and meets once a week, so super easy to manage. Beyond that, it's enjoyable and Morgan makes the class very open and exciting. I highly recommend.

course_title: Screen Cultures from Cinema to TikTok 001
best_comment: This is a great course, but I think it was falsely advertised. Whereas the course description focuses on the cultural and political implications of different screen technologies throughout history, the course focused more on the history of how these technologies came to be, focusing on more technical and material aspects (especially towards the end of the semester). This is not to say that the discussions on culture were absent––they were simply not the main focus of the class. As such, this can be a great class if you are interested in History and Science or STS. However, if you are more interested in learning about the politics of representation and/or media studies in general, I would consider other courses. Something to keep in mind is that most course materials were (dry) academic papers and essays, with very few primary sources to engage with. I do think that Emmet is aware of this, and I believe that this will probably change in future iterations of the class. So make sure to take a look at the syllabus!Emmet is fantastic. He was always readily available to meet for office hours to talk about readings and assignments, and provided good feedback.
subject: History & Literature
course_title_2024: Screen Cultures from Cinema to TikTok

course_title: Marx at the Mall: Consumer Culture & Its Critics 001
best_comment: Take this class. You will learn so much, and you will enjoy it too. YOU DON'T NEED TO BE IN H/L TO TAKE IT EITHER!! The readings are accessible and interesting, and the class discussions are great. The topics of the class lend to great critical conversation, and Briana is a fantastic professor that encourages participation and makes learning fun. While it is not super focused on contemporary consumption, Briana found ways to incorporate our interests into the class. The joy she feels in teaching this content is so clearly evident, and her passion rubs off on the rest of the class. She is always accessible and open to helping support you in your work. Briana is a fantastic professor, and any class of hers is one worth enrolling in.
subject: History & Literature
course_title_2024: Marx at the Mall: Consumer Culture & Its Critics

best_comment: Course load heavier than most HL 90s, but really fun! Super interesting material and great discussion opportunities.
subject: History & Literature

best_comment: Take this course!!! The best class I've had at Harvard so far. Adhy is a wonderful instructor. He guides students through difficult, yet thought–provoking questions that matches the importance of the issues in this course. The content was so diverse, we watched documentaries, movies, and read graphic novels as well as essays and short stories, besides the theory that you usually get.

course_title: Contesting Citizenship in the United States 001
best_comment: I LOVED this course!! It was my favorite of the semester! You will gain a very comprehensive and inclusive understanding of citizenship movements. The reading material is mostly history–based, but is all very valuable, with some fun videos towards the end of the semester. Lila is also a great professor and makes herself available for any questions. Take this class!!

Lilly Havstad is a fantastic professor who brings to the classroom an incredible care for her students and enthusiasm for the subject matter. The readings were interesting, and I genuinely enjoyed putting together my final project. Even as a chronically late riser, I looked forward to this 9:45 class every Wednesday!
subject: History & Literature

best_comment: Take this course! Harvard and Native Lands was the best course I was in this semester and it wasn't close. Alan and Mandy are compassionate, brilliant, and thoughtful; the materials and activities we went through in class genuinely reconfigured the ways I thought about a lot of huge topics (land, power, sovereignty, property). The assignments are fun and interesting — you're writing op–eds, physically observing the neighborhood, producing case studies on real moments in Harvard's long history of Native dispossession — and they feel both more practical and more meaningful than the baseline for history classes. Can't recommend enough <3
subject: History & Literature

best_comment: Take this course! Harvard and Native Lands was the best course I was in this semester and it wasn't close. Alan and Mandy are compassionate, brilliant, and thoughtful; the materials and activities we went through in class genuinely reconfigured the ways I thought about a lot of huge topics (land, power, sovereignty, property). Can't recommend enough <3
subject: History & Literature

best_comment: I still think you should take this class despite what I'm about to say, because being able to understand visual art is really important, and this is a pretty comprehensive introduction to what's going on in the art world right now. You encounter a ton of cool art from the last 40 years in class, and some of the pieces I saw in lecture will stick with me for the rest of my life. The workload is never unmanageable, and you can re–do pretty much every assignment with feedback from the TFs, who are great, if you want. This course has the content of an intro class, but Professor Lambert–Beatty does not have the attitude of someone teaching an intro class. As pretty much everybody knows, there's a big debate about what "art" actually is, and it's pretty much impossible to start from zero knowledge about post–modern art and contemporary art without hitting the wall of, "does this still count?" But Professor Lambert–Beatty, maybe because she's been in the art world for so long, and maybe because she's simply sick of the central debate of any person encountering art academically for the first time, sort of refuses to engage with this question. Genuine curiosity from students is met with defensiveness and accusations of thinking the course material is unserious. Sometimes Professor Lambert–Beatty would even acknowledge that some people in the class might be skeptical of certain types of art, but every time somebody took the bait and expressed that opinion, it would turn into a  one–sided debate between a professor and somebody who had only just learned what "contemporary" means a few weeks prior. I'm only expressing this so long–windedly because I hope that in the next iteration of this class, there's a bit more of an assumption of good–faith curiosity rather than an expectation of cynicism. As a humanities student who took this class as a pure elective, my heart sinks when I think of people taking this class for the humanities distribution requirement thinking that this is how we all are. I really do understand the impulse to protect something you love as much as Professor Lambert–Beatty clearly loves art. But I fear that she's just protecting the art from genuine interest. One more thing—as you learn pretty quickly in this class, contemporary art is mostly about and/or related to social justice issues. Professor Lambert–Beatty often comes across as a bit uncomfortable discussing these topics in front of a lecture. Again, this seems to come from a desire to get it right more than anything else, which you have to respect. But it's a bit awkward to sit through the anxious throat–clearing before we can get to the heart of these discussions. Whenever it was something related to my identity being discussed, I felt sort of othered a lot of the time because of her anxiety discussing things that are normal to me. In my opinion, this isn't a reason not to take this class. But something to note. tl;dr take this class but don't raise your hand in lecture unless you want to be argued with
worse_comment: Professor is awful (like really awful at teaching/engaging, i don't believe anyone takes her seriously) but the class is somewhat made up by content, little workload and lack of exams.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

course_title: Art of Monsoon Asia: Interconnected Histories 001
best_comment: Take this class with reservations! I'm sure there will be tons of positive feedback for the class, and it is WELL–deserved. If you are truly enthused about south Asia, or interested in writing a thesis on south asian art, this is the class for you. It is jam–packed with information, but also with resources, which can feel a bit much for someone with a slight interest. I wish I had known that before taking it.There's a lot of graduate students who will take the course too if that gives you an idea about its level of commitment. The professor is really really sweet though and a really wonderful instructor, but I did get the vibe among the undergrads that not all of us were engaged in the class just because it is so intense. (There were also a few of those type of folks who are *too* enthused about the culture that they don't come from, so beware.) I also didn't like that there was an expectation to show up so much, and while I was interested in the class, I wish the staff were more understanding of the other commitments we have. I also felt like we were sorta expected to know what to do with the assignments when the instructions were often vague and it could be difficult to get direction on what to do. It also felt like we were expected to have really great assignments and a final project when there wasn't enough guidance from the staff.
worse_comment: The final project is very tedious, incredibly time consuming, and a large portion of your grade, so start early and check in with the TF / professor about it throughout the process. While lectures aren't the most engaging, the weekly quizzes keep you accountable.

best_comment: Work smarter, not harder. It's really easy to tunnel in on something for your thesis when it could be better to take a step back and see what you gotta do big picture. I didn't feel like the three assignments helped my thesis progress –– I found the desk crits (or just 1 on 1 time with Lisa or Rachel) much more helpful.  Lisa and Rachel were amazing –– whoever the teaching staff is next year, meet with them outside of class! This class is not studio –– it's a lot of research (some historical, some through design/drawing) which took some time getting used to. In studio, you're given the framework for each assignment, whereas now you have to come up with the framework for your thesis.  Don't worry if you don't do as much design work as you would've liked: developing and nailing down your narrative is super important and then you can design!
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: I loved this class. My TF (Roxane) was amazing––– she gave phenomenal feedback  on our weekly writings and did a great job helping lead our weekly class. I really did love this class and there was absolutely zero pressure week to week. Just do the readings (you dont "need" to, but I think all the students agree that it really did help you get more out of the class) and join into the course discussion. I learned alot, met a ton of faculty, and always looked forward to going to class. Roxane, if you see this, thank you. I know the entire class loved having you as the lead :)
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: I really liked this class! We got to read and discuss interesting texts on architecture, apply them to our world and case studies, and use this knowledge to build a research paper with extensive guidance and opportunities to share our developments in class. I learned a lot and enjoyed the experience!
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: This course is incredibly helpful for all HAA seniors who are thesising.  It provides a large set of resources that guide the process, and contains multiple assignments that segment such a large project into manageable chunks. These resources are incredibly useful, especially in the beginning of writing a thesis. I also recommend this course for joint concentrators, as the support provided will likely be more substantial than that of another thesis seminar.The professor and TF are extremely insightful and provide so many great ideas and directions! Kirsten (TF) is the best and has helped with so many theses!
worse_comment: be prepared to have busy work that is not helpful. The course is an unorganized mess as too many people have taught the course and without any clear vision or goal. So follow your own instincts.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: I did not think a whole course could be taught on just a singular building, but I was proven wrong! Each lecture brought in new aspects with content that built on previous lectures. The Hagia Sophia has lasted for centuries and is deserves greater appreciation, so I am happy I took this class to learn more about such a historically, and religiously significant monumental structure.

course_title: Imagining Witchcraft: Women, Satire, and Enmity in Early Modern Visual Culture (from Dürer to Goya) 001
best_comment: Professor Koerner and Professor Pereda are two of the kindest, most caring educators I have met at Harvard. They are so supportive of their students and truly invest in their success. This seminar was a great introduction to witchcraft and promoted interesting discussion centered around the images and readings. I also learned so much about how to write humanities / art history research papers, which was so helpful and inspiring. Take this class if you can!!! I absolutely loved this class and the professors

course_title: Imagining Witchcraft: Women, Satire, and Enmity in Early Modern Visual Culture (from Dürer to Goya) 001
best_comment: Professor Koerner and Professor Pereda are two of the kindest, most caring educators I have met at Harvard. They are so supportive of their students and truly invest in their success. This seminar was a great introduction to witchcraft and promoted interesting discussion centered around the images and readings. I also learned so much about how to write humanities / art history research papers, which was so helpful and inspiring. Take this class if you can!!! I absolutely loved this class and the professors

course_title: Harvard Square: Social-History of Cambridge, MA 001
best_comment: This class leans into history/politics, so if you're interested in that, you'll definitely enjoy it. You don't have to have an art history background to take this class. There's a lot of freedom with the final project so find a topic you're passionate about and run with it! You'll learn a lot.
subject: History of Art & Architecture
course_title_2024: Harvard Square: Social-History of Cambridge, MA

course_title: Architecture and Utopia in the 20th Century  001
best_comment: This course was excellent. The professor is passionate, funny, and engaged. If you want to examine history and theory of architecture in this specific era, I highly encourage you to enroll.
The teacher is very nice and informative however the content is not delivered in an engaging way
pretty interesting, light course load
subject: History of Art & Architecture

course_title: Visual, Material, Architectural Cultures btw East and West (Early Modern Ottoman Empire, 15-17th C) 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class! You will get a broad overview as well as detailed study of specific topics from the transregional interactions in the early modern Mediterranean.

course_title: The Living Image in Premodern Art 001
best_comment: If you are interested in more theoretical art history readings and how to apply those, you will LOVE this class. In general, if you're interested in art history, you will really enjoy this class, and learn a lot. It helped me to think differently when writing papers.

course_title: Threads of Survival: Armenian Liturgical Textiles 001
best_comment: I absolutely loved this course. Christina is an amazing professor. She is super knowledgable it’s insane, and a giant in her field yet so humble, kind, warm and considerate. The course material is super balanced so that most of the semester you are doing readings (which are so reasonable length–wise), a presentation of one of the readings with one other person, a final presentation and the final paper. I recommend start early with the final paper which is what I did and it wasn’t stressful at all. Christina brings cookies and has tea every class which is actually the best. I looked forward to every class and time flies when you’re talking about meaningful Armenian liturgical textiles even if it doesn’t seem that way at first !For context, i am a Neuro major (never had taken a history or art history class before) with a history secondary.
This class was crafted with a great deal of care. From the readings to the object viewings, each moment moment spent on this class was orchestrated to perfection.

course_title: Methods and Theory of Art History 001
best_comment: Be ready to participate actively on class.
subject: History of Art & Architecture
course_title_2024: Methods and Theory of Art History

best_comment: This class is such a great way to explore your research interests and test the limits of your writing. My tips would be: 1)Start early. It feels like the paper deadline is far away but especially because of the way assignments are set up, the draft deadline does sneak up on you, so even in the beginning when it feels like you're working on non–essay things, begin brainstorming on your own if you're someone like me who struggles with picking a topic.2)Don't be afraid to explore the archives. Look things up on the finding aid, talk to librarians, and reach out to people who have resources you're interested in to get the full experience of archival research.3)Take advantage of the meetings your professor offers. Go to as many office hours as you can, and have an open mind towards to constructive feedback you will receive that can only help improve the quality of your paper. and most importantly: HAVE FUN! This class is such an awesome opportunity to dig into your prospectus research question or anything completely different that you'd like to explore. Don't limit yourself and actually put in the time to produce something you're proud of.
subject: History of Science

best_comment: The senior thesis is challenging but extremely fulfilling. If you don't feel like you can handle writing a thesis, then save yourself the trouble and don't do it. But if you feel passionate about a topic (or passionate about research in general), then you won't regret it. It's an incredible experience to work one–on–one with a world–class history scholar and to shape your thesis with your own interests and fascinations.
subject: History of Science

best_comment: writing a thesis has been truly the most intellectually rewarding undertaking i've experienced throughout my time at harvard, and this course has offered instrumental support in making this lengthy and complex process much more digestible and approachable
subject: History of Science

course_title: Knowing the World: An Introduction to the History of Science 001
best_comment: This is a great, chill class. As someone without a strong history background I had a bit of trouble adjusting to the type of info presented but started really enjoying it once I 'got it.' Each lecture has a central argument with relevant examples which I really enjoyed– it was easy to grasp.  Exams and assignments were super fair and chill but you still learn a lot.  The class has really supportive policies– you have a 72 hour bank of extension time and are able to miss one section without explanation (and obviously others when sick.) TFs took attendance as you walked into lecture which I liked because it motivated me to come to lecture and made it more personal since the TFs learned my name super fast. I was always able to just email and watch the lecture recording when I was sick though. Section was relevant and helpful. Section and extra credit opportunities featured a lot of field trips/ site visits which enhanced the course and made it feel more relevant. You're taught kind of the basics to research at Harvard (accessing Houghton/ the archives, analyzing primary and secondary sources, etc.) which is super helpful for future courses. This course struck the perfect balance between being laid back/ flexible and also actually teaching you material. It's probably the most cared about I've ever felt in a lecture course which is hard to achieve.
worse_comment: This class is exactly what it describes itself as – an introduction to the history of science, structured chronologically. I personally enjoyed the second half of the course much more, which covered more recent history and was taught by Prof. Wilson. Nothing in this class is a surprise or a twist, but if you're worried about grades, the teaching staff host office hours and there are many opportunites for extra credit. Sometimes section can be quite dull.
subject: History of Science
course_title_2024: Knowing the World: An Introduction to the History of Science
