course_title_2024: Knowing the World: An Introduction to the History of Science

course_title: Hunger's Long History: Need, Desire, and Science in the Early Modern World 001
best_comment: This is an amazing class!! A great change of pace for a seminar course, and Spencer is the best. So encouraging and positive and really generates excitement around the material.

course_title: Foreign Bodies: On Health and Migration 001
best_comment: Familiarity with theoretical texts would be helpful for the first couple of weeks, otherwise might be tough to participate in class in the first couple of weeks. Other than that small note, this course is fantastic and brings together some of the smartest and most thoughtful people. The "case studies" in class are great, there is some discussion around more current events as well. The class is long but honestly conversation was so great it didn't feel like 3 hours. If you are interested in topics of health and borders, highly recommend. If you are thinking of becoming a doctor, even more highly recommend!

course_title: Sick and Tired of Being Sick and Tired: A History of Health Disparities in America 001
best_comment: This course covers incredibly interesting, pertinent subject matter. As a STEM concentrator taking this class to fulfill a  divisional distribution, I expected to be in over my head. I certainly did not feel as if I was. The class moved fairly slowly, probably because it met only one time a week (I'm not sure if this is helpful, just given the fact that I'm not super familiar with how seminars are supposed to work), and I found that the workload was also pretty insubstantial. That being said, the readings were always intriguing and made me more familiar with parts of history previous courses of mine had overlooked. I wish we could have discussed more in class, but all in all, an interesting class.

The greatest class I've taken at this university –– and I study Computer Science.Prof. Torracinta is a kind–hearted, lovely person who genuinely cares about his material and what students think of it; the class clocks in at about 2:30h (with a 15min break in between!) but it honestly never felt like I was held there for longer than I would've been, it never got boring or mundane at all.The readings were fantastic: the class is titled "Being Human since 1945" but the actual material is about a lot more than that, and it strongly recontextualised assumptions or facts about modern popsci culture, things like gender division (how was it that we decided chromosomes determined gender, even though in 1903 the consensus was that it was a more complex issue?), eugenics, the minimum wage, the philosophy of psychology through Ian Hacking, to end on a high with posthumanism and cyborgs. A smorgasbord of great classes that I've come away feeling very enriched from.Workload is also fair: it's <100 pages of reading per week, 3 thousand–word reading reflections three weeks apart, and a final project (your typical research paper, but you can also choose to write a feature–length article or make a podcast), although participation is strongly required (I mean... it's a seminar class lol).Overall, I would not be surprised if this became one of the crown jewels of the HISTSCI department in a few years, and the class becomes nigh–impossible to actually lottery into. A great, great time!
subject: History of Science

best_comment: this is such a fantastic class. if it’s offered again, please take it. not only are the assignments creative with the prompts, but we’re allowed a lot of freedom to write about what we desire for the papers. there were some weeks where the readings hit so close to home or described a feeling or phenomenon that I had seen/heard/experienced before, but couldn’t put a name to, so it was extremely satisfying & enlightening to read those. the professor and TF were so so kind, and you can tell they both generally cared so much about the material. Even though it’s a long ass, we had smaller group discussions a lot that helped the time pass by a lot faster. this was my first histsci course, and the professor helped in really making me feel welcome & comfortable enough to share my thoughts every class. the grading was nice too and the comments provided helped me improve on my next papers.
best_gem_comment: This class tackles a lot of questions and issues super relevant to our own lives, and each session is simultaneously therapeutic and educational, which I've really appreciated. Professor Lunbeck is a wonderful teacher and shares so many interesting insights into the readings we examine, and Allison is simply a gem!

course_title: Humans in Space: Past, Present, Future 001
best_comment: Love, love, love this class. Assignments are fun and spread out nicely, lecture is incredibly interesting, course materials are great. Prof Hersch is a very engaging lecturer and the class as a whole is extremely well run. Would highly, highly recommend. Fun class all around and I also found a lot of sources through material in this class for other classes
best_gem_comment: I wish all students, regardless of concentration, could take a class with Professor Hersch. He is an incredible lecturer, his enthusiasm for the subjects he teaches is unmatched, and he is incredibly accessible. He is a true Harvard gem. He is typically generous with his grading and gives great feedback on assignments (although it can depend on his graduate student section leader). Take it P/F if you'd like, but if you put in the work and listen to feedback, you should do well. Regardless, please take a class with him. You will not regret it.

course_title: Engineering East Asia: Technology, Society, and the State 001
best_comment: This course is not at all difficult. The professor is great, but the content is very boring. If you need a class to just fill your schedule that requires very little work but you don't mind relatively uninteresting content, this class if for you. Professor Seow is very intelligent and kind and does a great job lecturing, but the content is very boring.

This is a very solid histsci elective and chill class. If you've ever wondered about how scientific knowledge becomes public, why scientific papers are terribly written and locked behind a paywall –– and how law, the internet, misinformation, etc. are shaping all that –– this is the right class. Among many other things, you will come out of it realizing how ridiculously how screwed up scientific publishing is. For a seminar, the readings are relatively short and often super interesting. Sometimes discussion can get a little slow depending on whether people have done the reading, but overall it was still solid. And luckily, Professor Csiszar has great things to say about all the readings. He's also super helpful with research papers (and brought surprisingly good homemade chai tea to class for us a few times!!).

course_title: Burning Books, Fighting Facts: How Individuals & Institutions Resist, Reject, and Destroy Knowledge 001
best_comment: Take this course, but be prepared for discussion! Although this course is listed as a lecture course, it is primarily discussion based. Some weeks there will be a LOT of reading, but the readings are always extremely interesting and/or historically significant, leading to a deep understanding of the history of knowledge and ignorance. The number of readings that you'll do each week can fluctuate pretty drastically, so make sure to look ahead in the syllabus so you aren't left with 300 pages of reading to do in one night. You will probably get cold called, so also make sure to actually do those 300 pages of reading! Overall, an amazing and important course with an amazing professor!
worse_comment: Professor Oreskes is amazing, although kind of intimidating. This material is absolutely relevant for understanding modern relationships to science, climate change denial, misinformation, and whole host of other pressing problems.
best_gem_comment: This class was fantastic. It is by no means a gem– you need to work, and work hard, to really benefit from the course. It is definitely possible to sit in the back and try to disengage (though you may get called on!), but it would only be a disservice to yourself. Overall, it is worth the effort one hundred times over.

course_title: Histories of Material Objects: Books and Instruments from the Early Modern World: Seminar 001
best_comment: This is a fantastic class! Ann and Hannah are great teachers and lead fascinating class discussions. The class attracted a group from a range of disciplinary backgrounds, and one of the highlights was learning from my fellow students about their projects and research interests. I also really appreciated the scaffolded approach that the class took to the final project: we submitted the essay in stages, and this process led me to produce a final paper that I think reflects some of my best work. All in all, I loved this seminar and I highly recommend it!

course_title: Histories of Material Objects: Books and Instruments from the Early Modern World: Seminar 001
best_comment: This is a fantastic class! Ann and Hannah are great teachers and lead fascinating class discussions. The class attracted a group from a range of disciplinary backgrounds, and one of the highlights was learning from my fellow students about their projects and research interests. I also really appreciated the scaffolded approach that the class took to the final project: we submitted the essay in stages, and this process led me to produce a final paper that I think reflects some of my best work. All in all, I loved this seminar and I highly recommend it!

course_title: Scientific Visualization: From Galileo to Black Holes 001
best_comment: I'd highly recommend taking this course if you're interested in the topics! The readings are super fascinating, and Prof. Galison is an amazing teacher. I wish I had taken more time for the readings, because I would've gotten so much more out of the class, so be prepared to spend a lot of time reading.

course_title: The Changing Concept of Race in Science and Medicine in the U.S.: From Jefferson to Genomics 001
best_comment: Hammonds is a giant in her field, which is both an incredible learning opportunity and also intimidating for those who are new to the subject. Class time was not a very valuable part of the course, but the readings are an amazing primer to the field. A lot of times it felt like Hammonds would ask big questions and leave them completely unanswered, which was frequently frustrating. I would recommend this class for those particularly interested in the subject and able to learn on their own outside of class.
subject: History of Science
course_title_2024: The Changing Concept of Race in Science and Medicine in the U.S.: From Jefferson to Genomics

best_comment: Great class, great professor, fun and interesting and great way to delve into a topic related to the course that you may want to use for further research.
subject: History of Science

course_title: Historiography of the History of Science 001
best_comment: It's obviously mandatory for grad students in the department but it definitely wasn't something I just wanted to be over and done with.  In no small part thanks to Victor and Rebecca (and let's be honest Cody), I had a lot of fun and was excited to show up and talk about the readings each week.

course_title: Historiography of the History of Science 001
best_comment: It's obviously mandatory for grad students in the department but it definitely wasn't something I just wanted to be over and done with.  In no small part thanks to Victor and Rebecca (and let's be honest Cody), I had a lot of fun and was excited to show up and talk about the readings each week.
This course offers excellent support and guidance as you begin writing your HEB Honors Thesis.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

best_comment: Strongly recommend you take this course!! It counts for HEB or IB concentrators and it is so chill! The only real work was short weekly responses but the readings are so interesting. The midterm is an essay which is so bless and the final exam took like 30 minutes to do which was so nice. Abigail is so passionate about what she is teaching and is always available and encouraging questions. Love!

course_title: The Human Face: How evolution, growth, and behavior has shaped the way we look 001
best_comment: Take this class if you want a fun way to learn more about human evolution! Julie was super sweet and was happy to construct the class to talk about what we were most interested in. The assignments were always fun and required some creativity, so as long as you are comfortable leaning into that, you will have a good time.
best_gem_comment: A true Gem. The teacher is very reasonable and the course is interesting if you are into HEB or even why the human face is the way it is.

best_comment: It's an amazing course, no question. Rigorous but manageable and ultimately really enjoyable. The professor is really nice. Like all lecture/section courses, the TF is important for one's enjoyment of the class, so hopefully you get an awesome one. Mine was Amar Sakar, who was just the best. The exams aren't too bad since they're open note, and there are almost zero other assignments throughout the semester.

course_title: Wearable sensors: measuring activity, health, and performance 001
best_comment: Take the class! He is a great professor and it is super interesting and engaging. 6 psets and only once a week? A win
worse_comment: If Ali is teaching this course again, TAKE IT. It's HEB but involves other STEM fields too which is cool. Very low stress and does not take much time.

best_comment: Take the class! It's honestly so chill and the papers aren't too bad either. The only thing are the quizzes. The quizzes are worded quite confusingly and the questions can be contradictory to prior knowledge or what you're learning in other classes. But the professor is really interesting, the lectures are pretty fun and chill, and she's pretty helpful and lenient. Take it pass/fail and you'll probably have a good time.

As a brand new course offering, I thought the overall structure and organization of this class were quite good. Dr. Eadaoin Harney did an excellent job putting together the curriculum and assignments on such an innovative topic blending human biology and programming.  I appreciated that the hands–on coding, lab work, and writing assignments directly aligned with and reinforced the overarching learning objectives for human genome research skills.My main critique would be around the clarity and consistency of grading criteria on the practical lab write–ups and coding projects. Moving forward, I would love to see the course develop very detailed grading rubrics and benchmarks for each assignment.  I would have benefitted from additional guidelines to better understand the expectations of my work.Overall, I found this class stimulating as both a programming and genomics challenge! I would highly recommend future students comfortable with self–directed learning take this course to develop an invaluable skill set leveraging code to solve mysteries of the human genome.

If you are a dog lover who needs a science requirement but has no scientific training, this is a great class for you! Erin and Sophie were always very helpful, answered questions clearly, and made themselves available for whatever we needed help with. And you get to play with dogs !!!

course_title: African Climate: Earth's history, humanity's future 001
best_comment: Take this course! It's new (I think) but it is so varied and very different from anything else I've taken before. The assignments are very reasonable and Dr Green is very good with feedback. Discussion was interesting and I liked the structure of the assignments in particular, which meant that you were never under too much pressure at any point during the semester. So glad I took it.

course_title: Professional Writing for Human Evolutionary Biologists 001
best_comment: HEB 1378 is an amazing class!! Definitely take it take it take it!! I believe that if you are in the science field, you should take this class. From popular science writing to policy writing or writing scientific papers/grant proposals, this class teaches you many aspects and areas of scientific writing. This class is one of the classes that you can come back to and use the things you learned as a reference because it covers a wide range of things, and you can decide to pursue some of them if you realize that you are really interested in the field. Dr. Alex is amazing and working with her and learning from her is the one of the best parts of the course. She is very approachable, supportive, and helpful, and works with you on your project. It is a class that make you think about different forms of science communication through lecture discussions and weekly assignments. You choose a project that you will work on throughout the semester and work on that project, and meanwhile learn all these different types of scientific writing. Great course, and I absolutely loved it.

course_title: The Arrogant Ape: Rethinking our Relationships to Others 001
best_comment: This was a really great class, and definitely changed me as a person. The format of the class is a bit unique, as there is no lecture component and is entirely student discussion led (although this means the quality of each class is dependent on a student discussion leader) Two hours of discussion can feel like a lot, so I would say to only take the course if you're really interested in the material and prepared to do the (manageable) readings. There is a great community around the class, and you can tell everyone is very interested in the topic. I was initially worried that the topic might get redundant week to week, but every class was super interesting and offered a look into different aspects of our relationships with animals.  While the weekly work load is relatively low, writing the two papers and planning your week's discussion are pretty involved, and I would say the professor is a bit of a tough grader. I think my only real issue with this class is that the professor does not put grades into Canvas, so it's on students to calculate their own average and keep track of their grades (so hold onto your printed and graded discussion posts!) Overall, this is a really great class, and I think that everyone can take away something valuable from it!

If you have never coded before enter this course with reservations. The lab section is normal bio lab for the first half of the term and then turns into all coding for the second half of the term. You do not need to know how to code to join this class, but I found it very overwhelming and frustrating at times because almost everyone else did know so it wasn't always taught in a super beginner friendly way.  That said, Claire (TF) was super helpful and made the code–learning process so much more manageable and eventually enjoyable (to a degree). I think the class overall is very interesting and worth taking. I think I learned a lot, especially during the final paper. I would just be hesitant if you have never coded or if you aren't super comfortable with dense scientific papers, because the HW is always to read challenging scientific papers and then class is mostly discussing them.

course_title: A Humanities Colloquium: From Homer to Derek Walcott 001
best_comment: TLDR: I wish this class lasted all four years.Two questions: 1) Do you genuinely enjoy reading? 2) Are you excited by many of the books you see on the reading list for the class?If you answered yes to both those questions, I think you should definitely take Hum10. You have to enjoy reading, because that's most of what you're doing for the class: besides a couple of essays per semester (and a very small weekly assignment for your seminar), the only workload is the weekly reading. And you have to be excited by at least many of the books you'll be reading, because again that's just about all you'll be doing.And the reading isn't even that bad – you might be intimidated by the idea of reading one big book per week (I know I was) but it's really fine as long as you pace yourself. Most likely you'll appreciate the break from the essays/psets from other classes, assuming you enjoy reading.I'm a stem concentrator, and Hum10 is my favorite class (there are actually a lot of non–humanities people, and I think they often enjoy it even more than humanities folks). The books are really interesting and well–chosen, the lectures are decent, the seminars are amazing. I'd say the best thing about the class is the culture: you'll probably have a lot of friends in Hum10, and it's super nice to talk to them about the book that week.This is overall an incredible class, and one I know I'll remember fondly for my the rest of my life. I would strongly recommend it to anyone who likes reading books and who has any interest in stuff like literature and philosophy.
worse_comment: read the books. cry. participate. cry. don't write freely follow the expos 20 guidelines. cry.
subject: Humanities
course_title_2024: A Humanities Colloquium: From Homer to Morrison

course_title_2024: A Humanities Colloquium: From Homer to Morrison

course_title: A Colloquium in the Visual Arts 001
best_comment: This class was incredible. It prompts deep thought and visual analysis as well as broader historical and cultural understanding. If anything, this course teaches you how to be an observant and analytical thinker. By the end of the course, you will start recognizing visual patterns and be able to scrutinize every detail in a work and derive meaning from every intentional detail. The readings can be lengthy, but I often skimmed them and felt that it did not hinder my performance in the class dramatically. They will help you write stronger weekly response papers, understand the lectures on a deeper level, and participate more effectively in the section. Lectures are delivered by numerous different professors, with some more engaging and exciting than others. Some lectures are conversational, organized, and engaging while others are not concise at all and feel as if a script were being read for an hour. The looking labs were my favorite part of the class. Once a week, you go with a small group and a TF to the Harvard Art Museum or other locations on campus to view pieces that are similar to the one that you studied that week. This part is very engaging, casual, and fun, and you will realize how much progress you have made in your visual analysis. By the time the section rolled around, I was often a little bit tired of the material, as it does become slightly redundant after readings, lectures, and then the looking labs. However, some sections were fascinating and also fun as you sometimes get to explain your own weekly response papers and hear from others as well. These sections were personally my favorite, as you got to see the work that your classmates put incredible effort into such as designing their own monuments.
worse_comment: Don't take this course. You need years of art history background and significant experience analyzing and writing about artwork BEFORE you enroll. This is not an entry level course. The looking labs are extremely boring. The lectures lose every single student ten minutes in. Only come to this course with significant experience.

best_comment: If you can and are willing to buy in (this is key), take this course! I feel so lucky to have been recommended this course and, ultimately, to have taken it. It's really everything I imagined Harvard would be: extremely interdisciplinary, everyone is extremely bought in and wants to be there, and the professors are highly focused on your growth over everything else. On the note of professors, Robin and Lauren are outstanding professors and likely the best I've had at Harvard. More than in any other class I've taken, the two are invested in your success and will provide detailed feedback to get you there. Also, the assignments are fun, never too stressful, and push you to think a little bit! Overall, I loved this course and am sure you would too.

I absolutely LOVED this course. This is such a great way to fulfill your language requirement and it is so fun. Anbo is an amazing teacher and really engages the classroom, which is impressive for a 9 a.m.. You learn so much in a very short amount of time and I really feel like I walked away with a lot of knowledge of ASL.
This was a great course! I enjoyed the atmosphere of it and learned a lot without having to be super stressed.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: This class is required for thesising concentrators, but it is a low commitment and helpful for staying on track!
subject: Linguistics

course_title: The Science of Language: An Introduction 001
best_comment: VERY HARD on some days, but so so fun. I felt like I got to solve intellectual puzzles on every homework assignment, and I knew that incredible help was just an email away if I ever needed it. Teaching staff was all very understanding and excited to help, but sometimes we moved too quickly to have the necessary time to ask for help if we got lost with the basics. I think I learned a lot and will be well prepared for higher level individual linguistics branch classes, and I'm glad to have taken this. Fair grading is what really sealed the deal, because I got to learn for the fun and be graded for my efforts with difficult topics. Resubmission policy was also very helpful.
worse_comment: I took this for the arts and humanities requirement, since it is a pset course and I generally work though those faster than readings. However, I ended up spending more time on the class than I would have liked, because most of the material is kind of pedantic, and it's kind of annoying to work through the details, but I guess that's just how linguistics is, as a field. I don't love that there was originally no midterm or final and then they were added to the syllabus about two weeks into the course.
subject: Linguistics
course_title_2024: The Science of Language: An Introduction

best_comment: This is the best linguistics course I've taken! It's much more accessible than a lot of the other 100s level courses, and doesn't require anything more than an interest in the subject. Prof Franich is amazing, and the class always went by quickly. The final project allows for a lot of freedom, and since it's something you work on all semester it doesn't feel overwhelming to finish during finals period. I'm so glad the linguistics department finally has a sociolinguistics class and I hope it stays around for many years! Take this class!!!
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: This class is really fun if you like linguistics at all. Professor Bobaljik is really engaging and obviously cares about the material. It is really fun to participate in class as well, and I say that as someone who usually gets very anxious and uncomfortable participating. If you are nervous about the required participation, Professor Bobaljik makes it less scary. He gives positive feedback on your answer even if it's not quite right, and encourages participation for things like examples of English words that have some characteristic, which may feel easier to answer than a question about linguistic theory.I didn't really make friends in this class, but I recommend you do for checking psets over. Even though the psets are easy, some small things are sometimes tricky, like confusing instructions or conflicting approaches. I really loved this class though. It was the highlight of my semester. Lecture was exciting and the readings were interesting. There was never any busywork either– all assignments had a clear purpose and all readings had important information in every paragraph. The process project is extremely fun, so have a blast with it.I didn't give this class all the effort I wish I could have, because of other hard classes and a personally difficult semester, but I still got a lot out of it. In some ways, having this class during such a hard semester in my personal life was amazing because it felt entirely like fun, even though it was something technically productive to work on. It's also a really nice reminder about how cool humans are in general. Language is neat because people are neat. I think if you like linguistics as much as I do, which I am guessing you do if you are a concentrator or taking a secondary in it, this class is the bee's knees. Professor Bobaljik is a really good professor. I recommend taking advantage of office hours to get the most out of the class. If you are confused about topics or particular examples, he will spend a lot of time explaining it and even follow up with more information. Honestly, this class nearly convinced me to become a linguistics concentrator. 10/10 experience.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: Take this class! The class is incredible. Prof. Rau and Aljosa generate a lot of enthusiasm for the material. The psets are great and if you are used to doing psets in STEM classes, these will be way more fun. The psets feel like you are solving little puzzles and they are super fun. Prof. Rau is a great teacher.

This course is well–organized. The instructor is engaging and knowledgeable about course content. If you are interested and really learning some high–level theory in phonology this is actually a great course.
It's wonderful. You will love it even if it is hard.

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 001
best_comment: The 3 psets a week are going to be very tiring and taxing. However, if you can make it do them in office hours so as you have questions, you can ask the TFs. Also on the smaller skills checks and mini exam, still try to aim for a high score so that not everything weighs completely on the larger exams. You will have to put a lot of time and effort in to understand the material if you aren't already naturally really good at this material or have mastered it in high school.

best_comment: This class can get pretty brutal with 3 psets a week, but I honestly think Math MA does a pretty fantastic job in teaching/re–teaching the fundamentals of Calculus to its students, Additionally, while the psets and practice exams can be pretty difficult, the exams themselves are relatively easy. If you study a normal amount in this class, you should do fine.

subject: Mathematics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 011
best_comment: I took Calc BC in high school, and honestly I probably should have taken Math 1a, but honestly I found the class very fun and interesting. If you already have a calculus background, this course will be more interesting than anything, as you already know the rules and theorums but this class really forces you to apply what you already know. But honestly, if I had to take this class with no previous calc knowledge, I feel like it would be pretty difficult because they never ask like normal, straight up questions. They really make you think about the questions. Because I already knew the calculus before this class, I had fun with this style of questions, but for a person who is new to calculus I feel like it would get pretty difficult. I didn't think psets were too bad even though there are 3/week, as they never took as long as I expected. One thing I would absolutely recommend if you want to be successful with the psets is ALWAYS GO TO MQC!!! My routine was I would attempt the entire pset and then I would go to MQC to ask questions about the ones I didn't know and validate my thinking with the TFs.
worse_comment: Do extra practice problems

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 012
best_comment: I loved Math M so much! I never felt confident in my math skills in high school, but Math M allowed me to gain the foundational understanding I was lacking all of these years. I love that Math M is consistently prioritizing actively working on problems, that's the only way you truly learn math!

course_title_2024: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 020
best_comment: It is frustrating, but I've heard that's all of math here. There are required workshops with a CA on Tuesdays, and any exams are taken Thursday evening, so many weeks, you will have math 5 days a week. I spent a few hours in office hours everyday. Go to office hours to do your homework. It is helpful and keeps you accountable. Start Psets early; do not get behind. It's not extremely demanding, so it's in your best interest to stay on top of the content. With that being said, there are 3 psets a week. I found some to be frustrating, but for the most part, it's manageable. With all of this being said, I have taken calculus AB before, but my junior year not senior. Do with that what you will. Request regrades immediately, if you have any suspicion the grading is wrong.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 021
best_comment: Wonderful class if you are looking to strengthen prior calculus knowledge or learn calculus in general.  The teaching team takes an abundant amount of time out of their days to provide proper assistance both physically and through materials that are often provided through canvas.  I originally took MATH 1A and switched to MA/MB in order to enhance my prior calculus and algebraic skills even though I tested into 1A and had already taken AP Calculus AB prior to.  My understanding of both algebra and calculus and being to apply both skills to real world situations have definitely improved greatly (and I would also say that is thanks specifically to my wonderful TF).  I honestly do not regret altering my choice, however, if you are looking to pursue an engineering degree at the university, starting in MA may not be the most ideal for the track but I would speak to an ADUS (also how I decided).  Aside from that, I would say the course is wonderful in the sense that it actually teaches students something new in a way that motivates application and proper understanding. I won't lie and say that there isn't an abundant amount of work (three PSETs  a week that can range from 1–3 hours per PSET).  There are two midterms (for my year) skill checks (two for my year) and a final as well as a few other grading components.  It really just depends on the person and where they feel their calculus knowledge is at.

subject: Mathematics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 022
best_comment: This class can be extremely overwhelming with 3 problem sets each week that are expected to take you on average 4 hours to complete. Aside from the 12 hours per week you spend outside of class on problem sets, you must review content in order to pass exams and gain a full understanding of the material. This class involves attending section 3 days a week, math workshop 1 day a week, and (optional but highly recommended) math coaching 1 day a week and an algebra study group 1 day a week. If you do not have a solid foundation in Algebra and Pre–Calculus, I recommend brushing up on those skills before enrolling. I was unable to complete problem sets without going to office hours and the Math Questions Center nearly everyday. I spent most of my time devoted to Math Ma in comparison to my other 3 classes so I would avoid taking this class alongside other STEM or problem set classes. Although I found this class to be very challenging, the teaching staff and course assistants are the best. My teaching fellow, Matt Demers, was very kind and approachable. He explained concepts clearly during section and was always available to meet one–on–one outside of section to review difficult concepts. The course assistants care that students have a full understanding of material and answer questions thoroughly. If you choose to take this course, please reach out to teaching staff and the ARC (Academic Resource Center) proactively to build relationships and ensure you have the proper resources you need to excel. Don't be afraid to ask for help! The teaching staff wants students to succeed and are more than happy to provide help when needed.
worse_comment: Do not underestimate the course; the psets can be challenging. I also did not do well on a midterm. Do not go over solutions in the practice exams; solve the problems.

course_title_2024: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 023
best_comment: I highly recommend taking this course as it is the perfect introductory course for college calculus. In high school I had taken both pre–calculus and AP Calc AB but was largely unconfident in my abilities, so I was unsure whether to take this course or enroll in Math 1A. Ultimately I believe this course provides the perfect chance to ease into college mathematics, but do not enter the course thinking it will not challenge you. Three problem sets each week, as well as several exams throughout the semester, means this course often can be quite time–consuming, however I believe it ultimately helps ensure you do not fall behind and is beneficial in the long run. My TF Sarah was the best instructor I could've asked for, always happy to help out with any confusion and organizing a great class structure each day, so the TF you are assigned may alter your experience but I truly enjoyed this course.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 030
best_comment: As someone who took AP Calculus AB in high school, I feel that I would have been ready for math 1A. Most of the material covered in class was review for me, which made things easier. If you did well in calculus throughout high school, and feel confident in your skills, I would go straight to 1A. If you are looking to learn/review calculus and some pre–calculus, this class is great.
worse_comment: This course truly challenges you to understand math in a way you have not before. In this way, it's very challenging because you are pushed to put together complex ideas and use your critical thinking but it can also be very fulfilling as you realize that you are transitioning from knowing how to execute steps to a math problem to understanding the interplay of the concepts within a math problem and knowing what skills of yours to use to solve the problem.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 031
best_comment: If you have taken calculus in high school you should be fine. If you didn't take calculus in high school I recommend preparing yourself ahead of time as well as brushing up on your algebra skills. Develop a solid plan to get your 3 sets a week done. I don't recommend waiting until the day before they are due to complete it or to go the MQC for help on Tuesdays, Thursdays, or Sundays because you won't get help.  If you have an actual conceptual question don't go to the MQC to get it answered because the MQC just has CAs who are literally just your peers who have the answer key and more than likely wouldn't be able to help you! Go to office hours! and even then you might not get help because it is so busy! Take this course with caution but if you take it you will be better prepared for math at Harvard and for your goals in general but be prepared to truly put in the work, especially if you care about your grades/gpa!
worse_comment: Math in this school makes no sense and the way it is taught is bullshit. It takes up so many hours of the week.

subject: Mathematics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

best_comment: I took this class as a first–semester junior on the Econ honors track. If you can take this class earlier, absolutely do it. 3 PSets a week is a lot, and the sooner you can get that done, the better. That being said, it is a fantastic class that teaches you the fundamentals of calculus. PSets are a lot, but doable and you get a lot of help from CAs and section leader OH. Exams are also very fair, even easy. If you need to take this class, or you want to learn basic calculus, absolutely go for it. If you're choosing between 1a and 1b, honestly take 1a unless you took BC Calc in high school: math at Harvard is a different beast from HS math, and you may appreciate a lighter introduction –– I sure did!
worse_comment: This class is terrible, if you do not need to take it for a concentration requirement, DONT. I will say the course staff do care, but the format is awful. The "flipped classroom" means you go to the chalkboards in a classroom with a random group to "solve problems" except you haven't been taught anything. There were 3 psets per week and 3 midterms plus a final, which is a hefty workload. RIP math 1a.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Be prepared to work hard and do not be afraid to ask for help. I ended up getting an ARC tutor for the class that helped me hone in on some core skills like drawing derivative graphs, solving different kinds of derivative problems, and ultimately visualizing the math we were doing in class. At the same time, this class is definitely a beast and can be really mentally overwhelming at times for people who haven’t taken calculus before. You just need to constantly motivate yourself and take full advantage of the resources like MQC and office hours to fill in any holes in your learning on your own and you’re bound to be successful.
worse_comment: WHO SHOULD TAKE THE COURSE:– IB Math AA SL prepares you VERY WELL because it already teaches you differentiation and integration. In that aspect, the course will be a little annoying because you are made to understand the concepts of derivatives and integration before you are actually 'allowed' to use things like the power rule and finding antiderivatives to earn credit on homework. However, already knowing differentiation and integration makes the course significantly easier. – If you took IB Math AA HL, probably take 1b instead.– If you've never seen calculus before, that does NOT matter, everything is taught from scratch!HOW TO SUCCEED– Go to Office Hourse (MQC is always packed / always stressful)– Do practice exams for midterms and final but don't take them too seriously because they are much more difficult than the real thing
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is a good class for those that have calc knowledge and need a refresher. The first exam you might not get the best grade but that is super normal because of the adaptation period coming into freshman year and Harvard math. 3 PSETs is a lot and will take up a lot of your time, especially if you want to get a good grade on them. Do not commit the mistake of starting PSETs at MQC, you are not going to learn anything and you're going to be super stressed. Find a PSET group, do them and learn them together then go to MQC to check your answers and leave there early. MQC is waaaay to chaotic and there are not nearly enough CAs for the amount of people there. Overall, solid class but will become one your main priorities.
worse_comment: Absolutely do not take this class, find another way to get a math requirement. This is the worst course I have ever taken at Harvard. First of all, you better know how to teach yourself because teaching is not what they do in this class. They have implemented a "figure it out yourself method"  where you work with your classmates to figure out problems on a topic you have not learned yet, because you have not learned it you spend the majority of the time doing the question wrong instead of learning the fundamental procedures. Secondly, there are 3 problem sets a week and they are not short (average 4 question with multiple sheets per problem set). Unfortunately, there are not enough office hours or MQC time so they are always overcrowded so you spend so much time on these which is not something you can do with 3 other courses. On top of that, they only count for 20% of your total grade!Thirdly, they make you take this "workshop" if you receive below an 80% on the calculus fundamentals test they make you take before the course. The workshop is attended by the majority of the course and attendance is required for grade. Because of this nobody cares about it and as it taught by a Harvard student not faculty, nobody does the work in class – it is a waste of time.Finally, the practice exam materials are not reflective of the real exams at all. They're so much harder than the actual exam (which I guess is a good thing), but you spend so much of your study time trying to navigate the difficulty of the problem instead of focusing on the fundamentals. The exams also have a group component which are 15% of the exam grade and you have to work together after just taking the individual exam to do a whole other exam of problems.I repeat, do not waste your time taking this course. It's a complete waste of your time and education here at Harvard, it has ruined any passion in math I had.
subject: Mathematics

subject: Mathematics

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE(if you are considering taking ma/mb)!!! If you are premed especially and considering taking ma/mb, DON'T!! It will be a very rough spring semester and I am SO glad I just took 1a. Having said that, I had taken precalc before and felt decently prepared for the class, although my calc background was not strong at all. If you struggle with algebraic concepts I would recommend Ma/Mb, but other than that just make sure you know what sin/cos/log/e^x look like and you're good to go. The first few PSETs are scary, but don't let that deter you! The exams will be the same concepts tested in the simplest way and it is easy to do well. Overall, trust yourself! If you start studying for exams at least 3 days prior, pay attention in section, and do the PSETs to actually understand the math, then this class will be easy. I know people are gonna drag this course, but it truly was not bad. The main issue was just that the practice exams were way harder than the actual exams making it hard to get a good idea of what the exams would be like, but this is easily fixable.
worse_comment: This class will be difficult especially if you have never taken calculus in high school. The structure of the class is not very well made. The sections consist of you going to class, being handed a worksheet, and being told to do it. No instruction or material is being taught. In terms of exams, we are not allowed retakes or a chance to fix them. The homework as a result takes a while to complete unless you know people who have previously taken the class before.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Though I took Calculus in senior year of high school, the rigorous, but certainly manageable course has given me a stronger and more comprehensive foundation in math. The psets can be challenging as having 3 a week takes a lot of time. I would strongly recommend going to office hours early and MQC often. Sections are great as they are an intimate space with lots of support, though the learning within them can be improved. Luckily, the psets help increase understanding of material that wasn't as clear in section. The exams were difficult, but the practice tests can be very useful. Overall, Math1a is a great course and I would recommend taking it if you are looking for a better foundation in math.
worse_comment: The TAs and CAs are nice, but the three PSETs a week are indeed brutal, whether you're good at calculus or not imo. If you're not able to make it to MQC despite the very open hours, some PSETs can be hard to complete. The worksheets aren't super straightforward, and unfortunately you are subject to how good your section's TAs and CAs are.

best_comment: If you have taken AP Calc this class is a fairly easy. Definitely go to MQC to make sure you understand the PSETS, but the exams are not bad at all. The practice exams tend to be harder than the actually tests, so if you struggle on those, but can figure them out then you will be fine for the test. I took this class even though I took AP Calc BC, because I hadn't done calc in two years, and I feel like it rlly strengthened my math base. It's a great class and I really enjoyed it. The first PSETs are way harder than any of the later ones, so don't be scared by them, because they get a lot easier. Also the pre–calc skill check is hard and I almost failed it, but it doesn't matter at all for the actual class.
worse_comment: As long as you do the homework thoroughly the tests aren’t bad

best_comment: Math 1a is very well taught, however, the workload is hard with 3 psets a week. It is good to actually spend the time to understand each problem and how to solve it on the pset as it will help you understand the concept better. Outside of the workload the sections are enjoyable.
worse_comment: I would say to struggle on the Psets yourself before collaborating with others and constantly understand your mistakes

best_comment: This is a great course and very doable if you put in the effort. It's a big time commitment, but the resources available make it possible. Go to office hours, build a relationship with the TF of your choice and it is way less miserable doing math with people than alone. Get up and write on the board, encourage others, and make the most of section so you don't waste that time and leave feeling confused for the PSet. Meet Mario if Mario's teaching, he makes math so fun. Math is not my typical favorite area and it's not one I plan to continue, but I genuinely enjoyed many aspects of this class once I figured out that it was on me to make the most of it. I look at the problem–solving process differently now and I believe this is a great class with a really nice progression in the material. Be ready to put in the hours, but know that it is doable if you stay on top of it.

best_comment: Coming into Math 1B, I heard a lot of horror stories. People made this class seem like it was the worst, but I didn't find this to be the case. Granted, I have always been a math person and enjoy the subject material, so that helps. Still, it is definitely a little fast–paced and challenging at times, but I really liked the structure of the class and the way the instructors taught made a lot of sense to me. On that note, all of the TFs and the CAs are amazing!! Use them as resources. This class definitely takes a lot of work if you want to do well, but it is not at all unmanageable. Find friends to study with, go to office hours, and show up to MQC and you will be alright. There are many places where you can get help. If you don't have to take Math 1B for a requirement, don't stress, you will get through it!
worse_comment: Unless you took Calc BC in high school and need this class as a requirement, I would strongly suggest not to take this class. As someone who did not do Calc II in high school, I found this course very difficult and too fast paced. A new topic every section and three psets a week is a lot for someone who doesn't already have some knowledge of the subject. I also found it difficult to learn because this course does not have a lecture component, so there is no way for students to actually learn material before just going right into practice problems.

best_comment: This course is a fantastic introduction to college–level Maths if you completed a regular international highschool degree (British–/German A–levels). Might be very challenging at the beginning as getting adapted to the new teaching style, especially when English is not your first language but it's a great opportunity to make friends and struggle together with others. I didn't enjoy the MQC, so did P–sets in study groups but many really enjoyed the experience there as well.
worse_comment: This class is so much work!!!! Three psets a week and weekly problems that get assigned earlier. The sections only teach you so much and the pset are designed to be hard for you to figure out on your own. This class is kind of a self–study class.

best_comment: Math 1b is hard. It's a lot of work. But I promise you, it is not as bad as people make it out to seem. Before enrolling in math 1b, everyone told me not to take it, but I found it interesting that most people who gave these negative opinions about the class were people who never took it. It's notorious for being really difficult, but I personally believe it's not that difficult. Or I guess I would say it's not too difficult compared to other math classes, 1a and 21a both have 3 psets a week and are the same amount of work. Math 19a and 22a have one pset a week, but their psets are long and hard, so they're probably going to take you just as long to complete as the 3 1b psets. Anyways, if you were placed in 1b, I highly recommend you take it. I was placed in 1b and people told me to skip to 21a, which they thought was "easier", but the 21a people were complaining more than the 1b people this semester. Math 1b truly is not bad at all, as long as you put in the effort. GO TO MQC for pset help. The CAs are SO HELPFUL!!! I personally didn't go TF Office Hours a lot, but the TFs are also there to help you, so go to office hours and see whether they're more helpful for you than MQC. I personally went to MQC every other night. I met some of my closest friends at MQC and had a pset group. MQC was definitely an integral part of my semester. If you took AP Calc AB  and not BC in high school like I did, you'll find yourself learning a lot of new material. You might find it a little difficult to adjust your learning to how math classes work at Harvard, but you will for sure get the hang of it. Some of my friends took BC in high school and they knew the material vaguely but the way the concepts are taught here is very different, so if you're not too confident about your knowledge on BC content and want a refresher before jumping into multivariable calculus then 1b is a good choice. You'll still learn a lot, but it wouldn't be as hard as trying to learn something completely new. Anyways, I highly recommend this course. You should definitely take it if you are placed in it. And I promise you it's not as bad as people say, and it does get a lot better. The first midterm was a little rough for me, but the second midterm was better, and I think I did really well on the final! It's definitely a learning curve, but I feel like I learned a lot and will probably take more application–based math classes next fall.

TAKE THIS CLASS! Although it will be challenging and Problem Sets will be time consuming, you learn so much and take away so much. Math 1B puts a spin on high school calculus and prompts critical thinking and collaboration, which will make math fun (can't believe I'm saying this). I came into Math 1B, simply wanting to get done with a Pre–Health requirement but ended up loving it. Matt (Dr. C) is one of the most kindest, engaging, and passionate instructors I've ever had and I'm glad I took the class. Go to MQC (I've met so many friends through it) and there will be a special emotional bond that comes out of struggling through the course content with your peers. Some of my Math 1B Peers are my best friends and I love that I got to take away a new academic appreciation but made so many new friends.
worse_comment: Whereas my high school math classes taught me how to memorize concepts, math 1b gives you the intuition to solve unfamiliar problems. Switch your focus from solving problems quickly to really internalizing the underlying concepts taught in each problem—this mentality will pay off on the exam! You will get much more out of the course if you embrace the struggle of wrapping your head around slicing, Taylor Polynomials, and differential equations conceptually.

best_comment: It's not as bad as everyone says.
worse_comment: Let me make this simple:1) Take this course if you've taken AP Calculus AB. Don't skip it if you've never done any of the content before, but also don't take the class to review (it's a lot of work)2) Don't be afraid of or scared off by PSET 0. It's ridiculously hard (everyone did terribly on it) but we were all fine after, and the content it's testing you on is barely used.3) Do the practice tests and go to review sessions and you will be fine. Not doing/copying the PSETs might be easy, but it will pay off in the long run to spend 1–2 hours working on them each night.

best_comment: Math 1b is a difficult class. If its a concentration requirement, I'd try to get it over with as soon as possible– ideally in a semester where you're not taking more than 2 additional PSET classes. If its not a requirement, only take it if you're genuinely interested in volume integration, series, and differential equations. The pace of the class is intense and midterms/final feel overwhelming, but ultimately the rigor of the PSETS and practice tests prepare you well. MQC is your new best friend! If you're on the fence about 1a and 1b but your concentration only accepts 1b, I would definitely go straight to 1b (provided you've taken a year of calc in highschool). I didn't take BC nor IB AA HL before 1b and still did fairly well in the midterms and PSETS, but it takes a lot of work. Only case where I would recommend going with 1a and then 1b is if you haven't taken calc at all. Frustration is part of the journey, don't immediately drop the class if you don't understand the PSETs at first. Try to land a section with OLIVER or Wes!
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE UNLESS YOU HAVE TO! If your concentration says math, take anything else unless it is required to be 1b. I did everything in my power to not have to take this course and here I am as a senior in utter confusion. Thanl God it is over, but I do not wish these 3 psets a week, rude course head and unhelpful CAs on anyone.

best_comment: Math 1B is definitely an experience. I would say you really need to be on top of your psets throughout the course and be aware that there are 3 per week. The best thing to do if you take this course is to make use of the support system – office hours and MQCs (so much bonding and friends you can make here) will definitely be super helpful. I personally also enjoyed section, as you get to work with your peers on the worksheet problems and actively apply what you just learned. Also don't be afraid to ask questions – our TFs are amazing and will always be happy to help you!
worse_comment: Just grind, it's worth it, and if you get a bad TF just go to joniers section.

best_comment: Math 1B is a great course. I was initially thinking of skipping it for 21a but I'm glad I took 1b. It provides a strong foundation for my future quantitative studies. Even though 3 psets a week is a lot of time, it is completely worth it and the psets are pretty reasonable (I never actually went to OH or anything and managed to get near perfect scores on most psets). If you need to refresh your math or haven't learned some of the material like series, I would highly recommend you take math 1b!!

best_comment: THE BEST MATH CLASS I'VE EVER TAKEN IN MY ENTIRE LIFE. I took this as a senior after 4 years of not taking a math class since AP calc BC, and it was the best academic risk I've taken at college. Roderic is literally the best math teacher there is, and he is so kind + empathetic that you can trust that everything was assigned for a reason (and not for busy work). I was blown away at how well I learned everything and how enjoyable it was to learn this stuff, especially given how it may feel like a lot of work at times (3 psets a week). This class is a must take if you're on the fence! Even if you don't need to take multivariable calc, take this class because it's so so useful and interesting. I can't say enough how great this class + the instructor is.
worse_comment: You realize Ec10a/Ec1010a teach you a whole lot of nothing. This is a fantastic class and Roderic is the man. Take if you want to actually understand the marginal productivity graphs Ec10 presents instead of an "intuitive" concavity explanation.

course_title: Modeling and Differential Equations for the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: This is an excellent class that I highly recommend you take if you are at all interested in the life sciences/biology/chemistry. Having a solid background in calculus (AP Calc AB is enough imo, but do the first diagnostic pset to figure out your own comfort level) is helpful, along with a high–school level background with biology/chemistry. You'll likely want a basic working knowledge of concepts like rate law, cell cycles, action potentials, etc. You can definitely take this course as a substitute to Math 21A, and possibly 1B. Upsides: 1 problem set a week (5–8 questions, reasonable difficulty and TFs are very helpful), Wes is an amazing lecturer and I highly recommend going to his office hours. Final project instead of a final exam, and the two midterms are honestly fine — and very similar in difficulty/content to the practice midterms. Being a small class, it's really easy to get close with and make friends with your coursemates — make a group to check psets with/study with, and you'll do great. Grading on the psets and exams are fair and Wes really does try to give as many partial points as possible when grading the midterms. Downsides: the course material does speed up in pace somewhat significantly after the first midterm. There are weekly readings (papers) that you should really try to keep on top of,  because otherwise studying for midterms will be a pain (reading–based questions on the midterms make up ~15% of the exam grade). Wes does offer a good amount of meetings/consultations/advice for the final project, but you really need to pick a good initial paper to have a good project — and get started on modelling/simulating in Mathematica well before reading period so you can debug and fix your modifications without getting overwhelmed.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2024: Modeling and Differential Equations for the Life Sciences

best_comment: Be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to class time (three sections + workshop) in addition to three psets per week! That being said if you are interested in math or have to take this for a requirement it's a great option! Super well taught and well organized.
worse_comment: This class is definitely very time consuming with the 3 PSETs a week. Compared to 1B, this isn't as intuitive and was a lot more difficult due to having to visualize things in 3D, and also vectors was pretty difficult. There's only 1 PSET drop with no retakes for the exams except the mini–exam, which isnt really worth much. The first exam felt pretty reasonable content wise but the grading was strict with losing a bunch of points for getting a true/false question wrong so make sure you understand things conceptually. The second exam though was nothing like the practice exams with a lot of the questions not focusing on the main ideas we were focusing on in that unit.

best_comment: This class is essential for STEM majors. If you don't know how to do 21a, you don't know basic skills :/ That being said, even if you're weak in math but you'll be pursuing STEM, you should definitely take this class. It's worth the effort and struggles. I found the difficulty pretty reasonable–– it's mostly difficult at first, when your brain's trying to adjust to thinking in 3D, but once it clicks after Midterm 1, things go by really naturally and quickly (even as the material gets harder). It's a very tedious class but you learn so much and it's kind of fun as you see yourself grow. I think the best part of 21a is the section setting, where you're basically put in a classroom of 20 people and get to discuss the worksheets in groups. There's a bunch of CAs walking around to help you out (so basically 3–4 teachers in the room to help you whenever you're struggling). If you get lost, there's so many office hours and at office hours, you can get a lot of work done with other people who are there (it's arguably better than MQC, which is packed and crowded and you don't get as thorough an understanding). The one reservation I have with 21a is the lack of getting a super duper thorough understanding of material. They do a nice job explaining the concepts and giving you common sense reasoning for why things are a certain way, but if you want to prove the theorems and understand them in and out to the deepest extent possible, I'd recommend the 22 series instead. However, I found that after all the practice I did with computing various things in 21a, I think it's more useful for people who won't be pursuing a concentration in math, where you'll be constantly using math to calculate stuff. Also, as a side note, this course pairs really well with Physics 19 because the teacher will introduce the calculus material before you learn it in 21a, and since you got exposed to it before, you'll have a better time grasping the materials quicker and understanding its relevance. I think the most useful parts of 21a are double/triple integrals, divergence, curl, and optimization. I think those concepts help the most in other concentrations so I'd recommend paying particular attention to those units (but Math 21a inherently builds on itself in a nice way so it's hard not to pay attention to any of those).
worse_comment: It's hard, but not that hard. :)

best_comment: Math 21a seems like the most natural choice for strong (but not genius) students interested in applied math, honors econ, bio, physics, engineering, etc. But I would strongly recommend taking either 22b or 18a instead. The class was very challenging, but not necessarily in the right ways. The tests were full of bizarre and unnecessary computation that had little to do with testing the important stuff. After the second midterm, 3 separate people told me they were dropping their STEM concentration, which is honestly depressing. I could complain, but it would be more helpful to give advice.1. Find a great section. Roderic was wonderful. I'm not sure how the others were. But your experience in this class will depend mainly on your section leader, so make sure you're in a good section. Find an instructor who teaches in a style that works for you.2. Go to MQC. The Psets are often too difficult to do on your own. In high school, I would have been embarrassed to go to something like that because I thought I was too smart for those kind of supports but that was a remarkably stupid perspective. Please try it out or go to office hours or work in a good pset group. 3. DO NOT let this class influence your views on STEM or even math at Harvard. Harvard is an amazing academic environment with a wide variety of classes even within each subfield of study. If you struggle in Math 21a, do not think it is because you should switch to econ or sociology (I love econ and sociology so no offense if you have a genuine interest in those). If you do not enjoy the content in Math 21a, do not think it is because you just lack that passion for STEM that some people have. The reality is it is a strange course with many good components and many weaknesses. Put effort into it obviously, but don't let it influence your views on math in general too much. Also, don't be discouraged if your classmates pick up on the ideas quicker than you or already know the theorems before you learn them in class. They have already taken multi before and wanted an easy class. Simple as that. To people with a multi background already, take math 22 for the proofs or something else. I hate to be so pessimistic because parts of this class were very interesting. But overall, I found it to be quite strange.

Find a great section. Roderic was wonderful. I'm not sure how the others were. But your experience in this class will depend mainly on your section leader, so make sure you're in a good section. Find an instructor who teaches in a style that works for you.2. Go to MQC. The Psets are often too difficult to do on your own. In high school, I would have been embarrassed to go to something like that because I thought I was too smart for those kind of supports but that was a remarkably stupid perspective. Please try it out or go to office hours or work in a good pset group. 3. DO NOT let this class influence your views on STEM or even math at Harvard. Harvard is an amazing academic environment with a wide variety of classes even within each subfield of study. If you struggle in Math 21a, do not think it is because you should switch to econ or sociology (I love econ and sociology so no offense if you have a genuine interest in those). If you do not enjoy the content in Math 21a, do not think it is because you just lack that passion for STEM that some people have. The reality is it is a strange course with many good components and many weaknesses. Put effort into it obviously, but don't let it influence your views on math in general too much. Also, don't be discouraged if your classmates pick up on the ideas quicker than you or already know the theorems before you learn them in class. They have already taken multi before and wanted an easy class. Simple as that. To people with a multi background already, take math 22 for the proofs or something else. I hate to be so pessimistic because parts of this class were very interesting. But overall, I found it to be quite strange.

I took Math 21a as a requirement, but ultimately, it ended up being one of my favorite classes this semester. Since the class is taught in small sections, you build a really good bond with your table, the TF, and the course assistants, and the class environment is very supportive. They really emphasize working through hard problems (and there will be many of them!), which makes the process of learning very rewarding and solidifies your understanding well. I absolutely loved the teaching method of this class and I could not recommend that more. My only reservations with this class are that you should not underestimate the workload of 3 psets/week (the psets are not very short and you will need to check answers or go to MQC for help) and that you have to be prepared to spend time really solidifying these concepts outside of class or before exams. However, if you need to take this class or want to go further in math than Calc I/II, I really really enjoyed this course and would recommend. (P.S. Fanhui is an awesome TF!)
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS! I don't care what anyone says––take anything else. Taking this course has made me realize how manageable and fair of a course Math 1B was. I did well in Math 1B and found this course to be unreasonably difficult. The exams were incredibly unfair –– no amount of studying or practice was ever enough to prepare me for what I was being tested on. It seriously felt as if I was taking an IQ test every time I took an exam.We also met FOUR TIMES a week because we were forced to attend an additional *useless* workshop that no one wanted to be in. Also, for a class that has 3 PSets a week, the PSets were very long and we had practically no extra credit opportunities. I feel like the head of the course was on a mission to make this course as difficult as he could make it.Content–wise, it wasn't even that interesting. Multivariable calculus is quite boring and underwhelming. It's really not worth it.I've heard 21B is also rough, so I would just take 22A instead.

best_comment: Good luck. If you can avoid taking the class, please do. I regret the decision all the time — I could have taken a math I'd already done and enjoyed my life, but I thought I'd challenge myself. I guess I thought that with enough hours studying or doing PSETs at MQC, I'd be able to master the content and do well on the exams. But no matter what I did (practice problems, watch videos, read the textbook, organize study groups, make study guides, etc.) the tests were just so much harder than what the average student in the class would know. When I would do PSETs, I felt confident about the material and also studied an insane amount leading up to every test. Regardless, they went mid. I think the final went better, but who knows? It's an unfortunate situation, especially because I'm pre med so grades matter. So if you're pre med and do not need this class for your concentration, PLEASE take anything else. Something that I realized pretty late was that a lot of people in my section had already taken multivariable calculus to some extent, and so they were able to connect the dots faster than the average student. I wish I had done that with BC, because the mental and emotional toll this class took on me was intense. Of course, challenge yourself and I'm sure you can do anything you put your mind to, but at some point you have to ask yourself: is it worth it? Is your mental heath and happiness worth it? Because that's what I sacrificed this semester and, for me, it was not worth it. Don't let me deter you if you're set on taking this course, but don't gloss over this advice if you're at all uncertain about taking this class. Be your biggest advocate. Best wishes and many thanks for reading.
worse_comment: Unless you were already exposed to this content/have a foundational understanding of the topics, you will be fine. As someone who had neither, I found this course very difficult and got progressively worse.

best_comment: I loved this class! Definitely has a big workload but it can be very rewarding if you stay on top of the psets.  Phil is very engaging and enthusiastic about teaching. I would highly recommend taking this class.
worse_comment: You need to have a strong background in math or have to have seen multivariable before, Unfortunately, your experience in the class is determined by your section leader and how strong of a math background you have. Many students have already had exposure to this material which makes the understanding of the concepts in section be much faster and moving through the material at a very fast pace that leaves people who are new to the material left begins in the understanding. Also, this semester's teaching team did not provide enough support for student who are struggling with the material in the exception of 2 TF's who are dedicated to the students success, (Fanhui & Roderic)  besides that I had very limited contact t and understanding of the concepts with the rest of the team. Office hours and MQC are essential for the understanding of this class and the only way to succeed in the course. I constantly felled behind the course even if I went to MQC, office hours and began the pset the day it was assigned. I constantly put priority in beginning the pset and asking questions in MQC/Office hours in order to grasp the concepts and study outside of class but even with the constant work the exams were extreemely hartd and time consuming which allowed for a lot of room to make mistakes and lower my overall grade in the course. The exams make up a big portion of the grade so this misunderstandings and feeling isolated in the class with your learning and understanding can lead to a low grade and be in the cusp of wither passing the class or having to retake it. Thius class is definately not the best at its teaching sue to the fast–paced that is lead by students who have seen the concepts before and students who this is the first time in seeing the material are elft behind and the gap in knowledge bvegins to build. EVen with the resources of going to office hours and mqc it was still not enough to cover all the concepts needed for exams and psets. This course lacked the extra support that many Harvard classes seem to boast.

best_comment: This class is hard but rewarding. The content's are engaging, but they keep you at your toes with an exam per month. Miniexam was ok, Midterm 1 was harder, Midterm 2 was impossible. Do the practice tests! For the Psets I recommend a good study group, and starting them early.
worse_comment: The experience is very dependent on the TF you get. On the exams they'll sometimes test you on really conceptual things, but if your TF isn't great at teaching you'll miss some of that. It makes the class unfair.

best_comment: This is a pretty standard math class. I felt the class focused more on giving students a conceptual understanding of multivariable calculus concepts, which I liked, instead of having a basic understanding of concepts and then making you spend all your time doing stupidly tedious computations. So a lot more focus on understanding things, setting problems up, and applying knowledge rather than calculus humdrum.Before taking this class, I "took" a multivariable calculus second semester senior year. I think this experienced helped me to some extent, especially with more basic concepts like double/triple integrals and partial derivatives, but I didn't really understand things like Flux or surface integrals or the integral theorems, so 21A was still beneficial and I learned a lotI think 3 P–sets a week is manageable if you manage your time well. Start the day it is assigned if you can or at least look at the problems so you know where you will need help. Work through what you can before going to MQC because I didn't find it very conducive to working. Ultimately, it might seem like a lot but its still less time P–setting per week than some of the other math classesAlso one thing that was super helpful for me was looking back through notes after class everyday or the day after. Just 15–20 mins will help you get a better understanding of the stuff
