I loved this class! Amadeus was easily one of the best math teachers I've ever had, and made classes super engaging and presented the content in a clear and informative way. Another thing that I loved about this course was the amount of collaboration with the other people in the class, because I felt like I got to know and learn from a lot of other people in the class. The 3 psets a week can seem like a lot, but definitely go to MQC, because you'll be able to work with other people and go over problems with the CAs.

I loved this class! Amadeus was easily one of the best math teachers I've ever had, and made classes super engaging and presented the content in a clear and informative way. Another thing that I loved about this course was the amount of collaboration with the other people in the class, because I felt like I got to know and learn from a lot of other people in the class. The 3 psets a week can seem like a lot, but definitely go to MQC, because you'll be able to work with other people and go over problems with the CAs.

This class is engaging and challenging but not at all unmanageable. However, it depends on your math ability which is hard to know before getting here. MQC is incredibly helpful and makes the PSets less stressful. A lot of the class is sketches and visualizations which is fun. There is a fair amount of problem solving too. It's not theoretical, but it's also not algebra–based so if you make a lot of mistakes in algebra like I do that's fine.  Do the practice exams for the midterms and finals. They are the best preparation there is. Also You HAVE to go to MQC regardless of how good you are at the class. Checking PSets is very important.I had a 5 in AP BC Calc and I thought that was good preparation. I was choosing between this course and Math 19A and was glad I took this one because there are a lot of resources and it is much less stressful. The class seems to be structured better and there is always a way to understand a topic you're confused about because there are so many practice problems and office hours.
worse_comment: Very difficult course, challenging exams, material was not explained well and was difficult to grasp.

best_comment: Dear Future Math 21a student,If you received your placement score and it said that you were placed above Math 1B, I strongly recommend you take Math 21a if you have a general understanding of Calculus 1 + 2/AP Calculus AB/BC. I will tell you from experience, this is not an easy course, but it is doable: You just need to put in the work. First, I will talk about the course structure (assignments, exams, etc.) and then I will tell you my personal experience about the class.Lecture – Math 21a is organized into small class sections rather than a big lecture hall like the other STEM classes. You'll have a class of ~20 –25 students. Each class, you'll have to bring your workbook to complete the questions regarding the course concepts. But here's the catch: You actually have to write out WORDS in math. Yes, words... The worksheets are structured so that you won't be able to finish them all on time, but there are few occasions where you will finish. Don't worry though, the solutions to the worksheets are posted on Canvas the same day later in the evening.Problem Sets (psets) – Like Math 1a and 1b, 21a has three psets a week, one due Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. Now, your first instinct would be to take Pset 0 and head to the library to figure it out on your own. That is fine, but, if you're spending 1–2 hours on one question, you are wasting time. My strongest advice is if there are office hours (OH) after class, go to them as soon as you finish class so that the material stays fresh in your mind. The TFs are helpful as they can provide clarification on questions you feel lost on. OH are held on Mondays through Fridays. The other resource that is super helpful is Math Question Center (MQC), which runs from Sundays through Thursdays in the evenings. They are held by course assistants (CAs) who have taken the Math 21a already and can help you knock your pset. My warning is that Sunday nights are usually the most chaotic since so many people are trying to submit their pset before Monday morning; so try to arrive as early as it starts so the CAs give you as much attention as possible. Workshops – The section is honestly not too helpful at times. They are headed by CAs and you are required to attend these sections every Tuesdays, except the Tuesday(s) during the week of your math midterm, and they're meant to show you how multivariable calculus is applied in the real world. While they were interesting at times, I felt like they could have been used more for reviewing topics that build on one another (similar to how discussion sections in science classes are meant to review content). Other than that, you'll have to complete your workshop activities diligently as few of the questions in certain workshops are in your problem sets.Mini–Exam + Revisit – The mini–exam only covered the first 5 topics. It is meant to give you a taste of what a math 21a exam looks like. The good news is that you can retake it for a higher score. The bad news is (1) that if you want to retake it , you would have to take it the same day as midterm 1 (the revisit takes place after the midterm) and (2) it only accounts for 5% of your grade. Then again, every point matters in your grade, so it is up to you.Midterms + FinalYou'll be provided with practice exams with answers and solutions for each test. My biggest advice for this is to do them as early as possible and truly reflect from them. Just as a disclaimer, just because there is a question on the practice test, this doesn't mean it will be on the actual test. The practice exams are to help you identify concepts that you need more clarification on. So make sure that after you finish them, make a tally of all the questions you got wrong, write down which concepts are being tested by them by looking at the solutions, and then bring your questions or concerns to MQC/Office hours. From my experience, I remember that the second midterm surprised us because the wording of a few of the questions was so weird. But regardless, you need to (1) figure out what they want you to solve, (2) discern the possible concepts need, and (3) execute your solution.For my background, I had taken multivariable calculus in high school when I was a senior. However, we did not go as in depth into the topics 21a covers (partly because the class in high school was brand new, so it was a pilot course). Regardless, I still struggled in 21a during the first couple of classes because we needed to think in terms of R3 (the third dimension) and reason with derivatives and integrals in R3. The psets were a pain at the beginning since I made the rookie mistake of trying to figure them out on my own instead of seeking out for help. Luckily, in the second half of the semester, I went to OH regularly after class to knock out a good chunk of pset questions and then went to MQC to verify my answers.Do not be afraid or embarrassed to ask for help in your 21a class. This is not meant to be an easy class nor are you meant to do it alone. Even though most students will have the same/similar math background as you, some may comprehend the math topics quicker than you, and that is okay. It is not indicative of your capabilities or skill set in math, it just means you have more to learn. Definitely, Math 21a helped me grow as a problem–solver at Harvard in terms of recognizing how concepts build on one another, and working collaboratively with others. This class is a journey, and just like any journey, you've got to embrace the process.

I recommend this class. I think having an understanding of math up until the multivariable calculus level (at least) is a good idea for non–math majors, and this class does a pretty good job of teaching that material, in my opinion. I personally had some high school experience with multivariable, but I remembered barely any of it bc my teacher that year was goofy, so my goal was to actually gain a solid understanding of multivariable concepts. This course definitely helped me do that.Three psets a week is a lot, but honestly, I wouldn't want fewer. Each one took me probably 2 hours on average, and I often did them right after class so they didn't drag on. Since the concepts in this class tend to build on each other, it's very important to have a solid grasp of all the material before you move on, and I really think the frequent psets helped me gain that understanding. They forced me to review & practice several times a week, which was definitely a little stressful, but ultimately I don't think I would understand the material as well as I do without them. My goal was to really understand the material, not just to check off a requirement, so this was a plus for me.The material can be really confusing the first time you see it, but honestly, seeing it all start to click into place is so satisfying. This course was very rewarding in that sense. Just be prepared to put in the work of three psets a week and proactive studying for exams. Exams cover a lot of material and ask some types of questions that you won't have seen before, so it really helps to understand the concepts well & intuitively.
worse_comment: If you are an ec concentrator taking this for honors, maybe do 18a instead. Also, this is harder than the earlier calc classes you may have taken and you will have to do more work just to understand the content than you have before. Do not miss any sections. It will be very difficult to catch up. Take the first practice exam as early as you can, two weeks before the actual exam is not too early. Also, this might seem obvious, but the exams can be scary and you might encounter problems that you think you are doing wrong and you probably are. The worst thing you can do in that situation is get discouraged and let it affect your performance on the rest of the exam. Practice triaging problems and not letting it get you down on the practice exams so you are mentally prepared for the real exam. As an ec concentrator, this is probably the hardest class I’ve had to take at Harvard. Spooky. Be prepared to spend A LOT of time on it if you want to do well.

best_comment: To be honest, your experience in this course really depends on your TF for your section. Really appreciate the CAs who help us understand the content. 3 PSETs a week can be a heavy workload for some, so be wary of that before choosing this course. As an econ major, I'd recommend taking this over 18A as there's more teaching support and very similar content.

I have conflicting feelings about this class. On one hand, yes, the allegations are true: this class is very difficult for two main reasons. 1. It is unfamiliar for most people going in. Despite following the A/B naming convention of the intro math courses here at Harvard, 21A and 21B are nothing alike. In the former, it was pretty clear what you were working with vectors and calculus in 3–D space and all of the implications of that followed from the basics. 21B doesn't feel nearly as connected as 21A does; the best way I can describe it is that 21B is a survey of the different (admittedly pretty cool) things you can do with linear algebra, but it doesn't have the same logical progression of 21A, especially towards the latter half of the class. Some will disagree––I know at least one person who hated 21A and loved 21B, so it may just be personal taste. All I can say for certainty is that, if all you've taken for the last few years is calculus, this is a completely different experience.2. The material is hard. Or rather, a more accurate statement would be that reliably seeing the connections between topics is difficult. I don't think that any one topic in 21B is particularly difficult from a conceptual point of view. But, the questions that are asked on exams require a certain "creativity" that requires a level of mastery that's a bit deeper than I think this class set us up for. The class requires you to apply concepts in interesting ways (which is a strength of the class), but it doesn't really teach you how to apply those concepts.Suffice it to say, if you're thinking about adding this as a fourth class to a 30+ hour a week schedule (like I did), don't: you are not him.On the other hand, linear algebra and differential equations are two of the most useful topics in math to learn for STEM students and I equally feel like I learned a ton from this course. But, unlike my other hard classes, I didn't really enjoy the struggle as much. In fact, after the first midterm, I actually started dreading this class because I just didn't feel like things clicked as they were supposed to. Yet, this is a very important class to take for a lot of STEM majors so I do recommend going in with an attitude receptive to learning.So, is this a good class? Maybe, but I for one am glad it is over.
worse_comment: This course was really tough! You spend minimum 3 hours on each pset (gets closer to 4–5 later in the semester), and considering there are 3 psets a week and only 1 drop for the entire semester, you're basically chained to this class every day. Each pset is long and tedious, and you can spend over 45 min on one part of one question just to get to a final answer that's probably wrong because you made some tiny algebraic error. It's also very unfair that the psets are only worth 20% of your final grade; you spend the bulk of your time in 21b working on the psets, yet ultimately it'll come down to how you perform on the midterms/final, which are themselves very difficult. The level of support for this class is also poor. There are very little office hours, and if you can't make it to MQC because of extracurriculars or some other reason, you're pretty much on your own for that pset.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Definitely a harder course than 21a and also very different (i.e. dealing with more algebra and abstract topics as opposed to being able to visualize things), but fulfilling in its own way and a solid introduction to linear algebra, differential equations, and the mathematical reasoning you'll probably need for higher level courses. Jill was a fantastic instructor who very clearly cares about her students, and there are plenty of resources on Canvas and office hours/MCQ to help you with more challenging topics. It starts out okay in the beginning but definitely ramps up in difficulty near the end, so don't be afraid or forget to use the resources they give you! All in all, even though I was struggling quite a bit by the end, it was a super rewarding experience and I'm glad I took the course
worse_comment: Do not take this class unless absolutely necessary. This is the most time consuming and worst class i’ve taken in my entire life. If you have to take it, don’t be too hard on yourself.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: I think Jill is an amazing TF. She really cares about our learning even though she can be hard on us sometimes (mother like). The course can also be challenging if it's your first introduction to linear algebra, but when you get the hang of it, the concepts are pretty interesting. The exams can also be difficult, so make sure to study a lot before hand – DO NOT PROCRASTINATE. Make use of all the OHs and MQC as well, it really is a huge help.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS! Take 22a instead. 3 psets/week is exhausting and unfair. Exams are difficult and not fairly graded. Some TFs and section heads are pretty bad
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is definitely difficult, but I enjoyed that it was a linear algebra course that was purely computational (without the proofs required of 22a).  Three PSET's per week is for sure challenging, but does aid in continuous practice of the material. The class moves fast, so I can see how 3 PSETs per week would be required to ensure that all of the knowledge that we learn is retained. Expect 9 hours per week though. And find a good PSET group! It helps so much oml
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra I 001
best_comment: Cliff is actually SO SWEET and does really care about this class! His Tuesday office hours are gold for getting the psets done and it is really obvious he totally knows his stuff. This is bad in lecture since he does things in his head that would probably be useful to see written out (read: definitely useful to see written out) and he also moved faster than I could keep up with the material, but he shows such a genuine enthusiasm for teaching and for the material that lecture was still worth it for me. Plus, he has a quiet sense of humor and his stories are great! Please give Cliff a chance—I promise you he really cares about students and is a really really sweet professor!!Also—if you're interested in learning about proofs at all, this class is a great intro/boot camp in that if you had a little bit of exposure in high school but not REAL proofs, if you know what I mean. The structure of the problem sets is 10 computational problems plus a few proofs, and that structure is great for easing into the mathematical thinking that goes into proofs. It might unlock a real interest for you! It definitely did for me.
worse_comment: This year's course differs greatly from last year's, with countless flaws. Do not recommend at all.First of all, this course needs a section. There is no real learning done in lecture, because the concepts are so varied and there is a lot to learn quickly. Thus, either the course needs to go slower in lectures or have a section.Second, the course needs a lot more office hours. The problem sets (which often do not cover what is covered in lecture, but rather what's in the book, although I would say that proof problems didn’t even cover that) required me to go to every office hour session, which is not how I think a course should be structured. Unlike other courses, however, these OHs are at extremely inconvenient hours (when all the clubs often meet, so I often had to give up on other meetings). Instead, other classes I took that are approximately the same size (both in class size and teaching staff size) have office hours at every hour of the day, which is much more convenient. This system allows to spread out the number of people at each OH, which was a huge problem this semester for Math 22 –– 1 TF and CA for every OH is not enough if there are 30 people waiting! This often meant not having my questions answered and wasting two hours not figuring anything out. The syllabus says collaboration is allowed, but I found it really hard to find people to work with, mainly because I noticed an unfortunate level of arrogance among everyone who is taking this class toward the less confident in the material. Sections based on confidence in the material would have been much better.Additionally, the teaching staff must be hired more carefully. I found it really hard most of the time to communicate with them, and some of them even shrugged at my question. Based on previous testimony, this is because to be a CA for Math 22 this year there was no selection – just a form to fill out. Needless to say, they were not great educators (except for NS, shoutout to her. She actually made me understand stuff but unfortunately she was only at OH for two hours a week). As someone coming into the course with a lot of calculus experience, this course does not have any of that, which was expected, but I would not consider it an introductory course if it is taught the same way it was taught this year. As a beginner, most of the time, PSets took me a long time (10+ hours). This will probably not apply to the overall average hours spent on the course but that is because half of the class has probably already had some kind of linear algebra experience. But, keep in mind my comments. Although the professor is very good as a human and responds to emails very fast, I don’t think this is a great class to take. Especially if Mathematics is not your concentration.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2024: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra I

course_title: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis I 001
best_comment: This class can be quite aptly described as "locally painful," but "globally rewarding" (Chris).Math 25a is a great class for anyone potentially interested in pure math, and provides a more theoretical approach to linear algebra. Experience with linear algebra and/or proof–writing is by no means a necessary prerequisite for this class, though is definitely helpful (still not necessary, but I do I think some exposure to proofs makes the class much more streamlined.) It is a relatively fast–paced class, though still slow enough to go through every topic in great detail. The course content mainly follows that of Axler and a bit of Artin.Regular attendance is extremely helpful (and also expected), though attendance is not specifically measured (however, you should note that lectures are not recorded, and posted lecture notes tend to be brief; thus, missing class on an objective level is generally not advised). Although this is Chris's first year teaching 25a, he is very knowledgeable and is well–prepared to teach us.  Furthermore, Chris is a great lecturer and very personable, making lectures engaging. There are no sections for this class, as usually only 30 students take it per year, but there are frequent office hours almost everyday of the week, which are really useful–– Chris, our TF Natalie, and the CAs go above and beyond to make sure you understand the material, and are great for pset help (ask them to check over your proofs!). Chris is very responsive to questions and feedback, so don't be scared to ask questions!Chris is a bit more forgiving in terms of class intensity and (overall) grading than what I've heard about Wes (who had taught 25a prior to this year), but you should still expect to spend a lot of time doing math: psets (one per week, due Wednesday at noon) will likely take at least 10 hours and up to 20. Note that psets will be graded more harshly (but midterm (one) and final grading is bit more charitable). Some further notes if you're in–between 22a, 25a, and 55a:22a provides a mainly computational approach to linear algebra, whereas 25a is much more rigorous and is proof–based. I would say that 25a is more of an extension of 22a, where 25a explores much more of the "why" to 22a (you will still need to know how to do computation, however, but is a smaller component of 25a). Meanwhile, 55a is a lot more fast–paced and goes in a bit less depth into linear algebra; you'll spend around two months on linear algebra, and then spend the rest of the time on multilinear algebra (& inner/outer algebras), category theory, and representation theory. I think generally 55a tends to be a little bit more collaborative in nature, but finding peers to work with during OH for 25a is pretty easy; also I think 25a psets are doable by yourself (might take a bit longer though), whereas 55a psets are not so much.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2024: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis I

course_title: Studies in Algebra and Group Theory 001
best_comment: Take this class (if you like math). I have lots to say, but if you don't read all of it, here's my most important point — more than teaching me math and preparing me for future studies (which it did very, very well), this course made me a smarter person. I can't fully describe it, and indeed it's somewhat uncanny — but after a semester of working through Math 55 problem sets, I genuinely notice that my mind is much sharper; I think more intelligently about the world (and I honestly didn't think that was possible) far outside of math. What more could I every ask from a course?Math 55 has a reputation. But no, it doesn't take over your life; you can still take other tough classes, be part of some clubs, and have time for your friends (believe me, I did it, and many others alongside me). Don't be fazed by the "hours per week" — it's much more manageable than you think. And yes, it's hard. But that's the best part. It's more than a class. You make so many close friends and find a wonderful community with your classmates, CAs, and the math department as a whole. Think of it this way: The College claims the First–Year Seminar Program is designed to help you integrate into the Harvard academic community — and that's true, but Math 55 is even better.The hardest part of the course isn't the content. It's the speed and the homework. But Joe Harris is amazing (and I'm sure whoever they assign to teach it in the future will be, too). I truly didn't notice the speed we were moving at — it always feels like he is moving slowly (in a good way), but he manages to cover so much content in a way that every person in the room understands. I have nothing but praise for him. Oh, and his lecture notes are the best. Side note — follow Joe Harris wherever he goes in his post–55 future. You won't regret it.Now for the best part — the homework. Math 55 problem sets are, well, a rite of passage. Yes, they're harder — in fact, I'll admit that they're harder than they need to be for you to learn the content. But solving the problems (whether on your own, or, more often than not, with your soon–to–be best friends) and writing up your proofs engages you with the content in a new way unlike any other assignment in any other course. Believe me, the course is the way it is for a reason — for you to learn, have fun, and make friends. If you like math, take advantage of it while you're here. There is quite literally no better exercise for your brain.You have to live it to know it, but Math 55 is a truly transformational experience unlike any other. In hindsight, I would pick Harvard over any other school just to take this course. There is no better way to start your Harvard journey. And you'll have so, so much fun along the way — from way too many inside jokes to memorable late nights in the math lounge. Enjoy.
worse_comment: This class is way too quick and hard to actually learn anything if this is your first pass going through it, unless you happen to have Olympiad–level intelligence. I spent in excess of 30hrs a week JUST ON THE PROBLEM SETS and had barely enough time to try and fully understand the material. The grading is not too harsh and the course advisors are okay but I highly suggest you take something like 25 where you'll actually learn something. Lecture ranges from barely comprehensible to the class groaning by the end. If you don't work in a group you're probably screwed. In all likelihood you won't be able to finish a problem set by yourself, no matter how hard you try.

best_comment: This class was really fun. Beware, grad students often get carried away and make it too hard. They are inclined to move very quickly.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: The course is not THAT hard for any concerned. It all really depends on your instructor so do research on them to see whether they are good at teaching or have experience in beginner–level teaching. Gammage is a good teacher and he cares deeply for students, though the lectures were lost sometimes, he is amazingly intelligent and it is a spectacle to see!Also, make sure the TF's when you take the course are good! They make or break it. Luke was a TF this year and that man is the GOAT so if he TF's at all take the course! Alot of 55 kids tf this course and while that may sound good, a lot of the time they end up not being the most helpful in actually helping you through beginner content. Do the homework, practice for exams, and ultimately you will be good!
worse_comment: I think the math concepts I learned will end up falling by the wayside, but this course was incredible for me. First, I make connections to the course material in ALL of my other classes. The basic concepts of formal math are so applicable everywhere. Second, learning to write proofs has honed my problem–solving skills, and I am glad I learned it even though I'll never use it again. Finally, learning to read mathematical symbols is, I think, the most important thing I got from this course. In prior math and physics classes I always tend to panic or zone out when I see a ton of symbols getting written on the board. No longer! I am now completely desensitized to notation overload, and I feel confident when a professor starts writing in Greek on a chalkboard.Some specific advice:Don't stress about the tests. There is a CHASM between the difficulty level of the problem sets and the tests. The tests tend to be the most basic possible question based on the material, while the problem sets can be very difficult  at the beginning (office hours are good).This class has very early midterms, which can be difficult but it also means that you won't have to study for this class and a normally–timed midterm at the same time.There are three problem set drops, and problem sets are graded very lightly. The CAs took months to grade our PSETS; we were getting psets from early November back after the final, so bear in mind you may not be getting much feedback until it's too late.Don't read Halmos, if it is assigned again. It is extremely confusing and the same material is covered in the other textbooks.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: I was told that MATH 112 is a course that can vary widely according to the instructor, so take this with a grain of salt, but Salim was a great instructor, and was very receptive to student feedback. Proofs take a while to ideate and write down coherently, so make sure to start p–sets early, and definitely make use of office hours – I would not have made it through the course without office hours.  Most people have good reason to take this class (ex: requirements for grad school) but if this is a part of maths you're interested in and you're comfortable with proofs, take the class!
worse_comment: I will start this by saying my only proof–writing background is Math 101. This class was so difficult and unnecessarily so. It varies a lot by year so please only take it when someone good is teaching it, but this year it was terrible. Starting with lectures, they were basically just Salim reading the textbook out loud and writing it out on the board. A waste of time which just left me more confused a lot of the times. We would just go over theorems in class with no examples on how to apply them. PSETs, therefore, were also impossible. I would spend the entire week in office hours and struggle to finish them. Sometimes, not even the CAs knew how to answer the question and would just end up apologizing. Once, the PSET was so difficult that the entire class got a three day extension so we were able to finish it. Since I the PSETs were so difficult and I had to rely so much on office hours to actually solve them, I feel like I learned nothing; it certainly felt that way when I opened the final and had to stare at a question for 24 hours before knowing how to start. I know this is a required class for Econ PhD's and that it is somewhat encouraged by the math department, but please avoid it if you can (I've heard the MIT version is much better!). It was so difficult and so boring that I feel like it has drained me of my love for math.

best_comment: HT seems like a good, kind person. However, he teaches straight from Rudin/Stein and does not add much to the content besides maybe some proof explanations. So in that sense it's an okay class... but I would MUCH prefer a better teacher for this course that has incredible applications to math, engineering, and physics.The TF, Jarell, was instrumental in me not dropping the class. His section was excellent and he gave great feedback as a TF.
worse_comment: A decent class on measure theory, Lp spaces, and Fourier, but lectures are sometimes hard to follow/important details skimmed over

best_comment: I would question taking this class. While it's not bad, it's not the best structured, and I think there might be other math classes that would be more worth your time. That said though, the content is actually pretty interesting and I definitely learned new things. If you take it, DO WATCH THE LECTURE VIDEOS IF YOU HAVE TIME. THEY WILL AID IN UNDERSTANDING IMMENSELY, TRUST ME.
worse_comment: Don't take this class if Paul is teaching it. If you want to learn functional analysis, you can read Luenberger on your own or wait until after next year (when he's no longer teaching the course). This class is flipped–classroom, and so you end up having a homework, two assigned lectures, plus a three hour class every week. This predictably leads to everyone skipping the recorded lectures. The problems in the class tend to be word problems, making it very different from other math courses, and it can be very hard to think about any applications of the class material. Homework problems can be substituted by asking questions to Bing AI weirdly enough. course_title: Algebra I: Theory of Groups and Vector Spaces 001
best_comment: Good class! Came in with a weak math background (22a, 21a), and was able to do quite well with a considerable amount of effort. Was supposed to be my easiest class this semester (based on prior hours reported on the Q–Guide), but ended up taking the most time by far. However, I came away with a strong understanding of group theory, as well as getting a taste of ring theory, module theory, field theory, and their connections to linear algebra. Elkies' lectures were hard to follow at times, but it was certainly an experience to be taught by a living math legend. He also made a strong effort to get to know everyone in the class. Would certainly recommend to math concentrators and non–math concentrators alike (I'm in the latter, as were many of the other students). Just be willing to dedicate a lot of time (> 10 hours in my case), since the content builds upon itself heavily.
worse_comment: Material was good, but be wary of who is teaching. Elkies rendition of the course is quite time consuming. Problem sets sometimes had mistakes in them, and lectures aren't great. Very small percentage of the class attends lecture since the entire lecture is very difficult to follow and disorganized. This class was supposedly introductory, but Elkies assumed a lot of mathematical maturity by the speed he moved at during lecture.

course_title_2024: Algebra I: Theory of Groups and Vector Spaces

best_comment: This class is pretty good –– definitely delivers on what it promises. The back end of the class definitely was much tougher than the beginning and you'll really need to study to keep up. CAs will make or break the course.
worse_comment: Be extremely careful with this class. I consider myself good at math, but I died (metaphorically) in this class. Take Math 122 first unless you've already taken 55.

best_comment: This was my first upper–level math class, and it was an experience. It was a blast and a struggle rolled up into one. I came in straight from 22A/B, which is definitely possible if you did well in those classes. I also had a little background in real analysis. The first half of the course went rather fine; it sometimes took a while to  fully understand concepts but leading up to the midterm, everything was pretty ok. Second half of the course also went OK — until the last 2/3 weeks–ish. To be fair, the 2nd half is way more interesting and beautiful math, but the last section on Seifert–van Kampen is pretty fast and kind of confusing if you don't already have at least a working knowledge of the intricacies of normal subgroups and quotienting. I feel like I only really understood Seifert–van Kampen after the final, which, needless to say, is too late. In any case, if you're fluent in set theory, knowledgable in rigorous calculus, and conversational in group theory, then take this course. Honestly, I wish I took 122 concurrently with this course. If you're coming from 22A/B, do this if you can and you'll likely be fine in a class with people coming from 25A/B, and even 55A. Even though I didn't, I ended up fine grade–wise ( I think/ hope). As with any math class, go to OH and have p–set buddies. Oh, and by the way, Auroux rocks. He might not teach this class in its next iteration, but he made it a lot better than it would have been under a professor who'd care less. So take note of who is teaching the class.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class teaches you all about integral curves, manifolds, and the start of tensors and their application to manifolds. You’ll gain valuable geometric intuition about manifolds and how to think about notions such as curvature and tangent spaces. The course gave me more confidence in geometry, and is overall a good course to take.The psets were very guided which was helpful in giving you experience and practice with the course material without feeling too lost. I appreciate that the instructor pauses for questions fairly often during the lecture and answer the questions well. It really helped us digest the material better. The recap at the start of the lecture also helped us recall concepts from the previous lecture, which is essential since the material almost always builds upon itself. The accessibility of last year’s lectures notes was really helpful, and I am so grateful for them. The de–emphasis on grades and the plentiful extra credit opportunities made learning more fun. I wish that the motivation behind a lot of the second–half material starting from tensors was more fleshed out, since I could get quite lost in the thick of it; maybe more time spent on the second half would be helpful. Overall, lectures moved quite slowly, maybe a little bit faster would be great. I think future iterations should also provide a latex source for the psets.
worse_comment: Low workload for the first half. No due dates are legit. 4 PSETS. I really liked that this was the lightest workload class because there really isn't any work except for the 4 PSETS, which do take a significant amount of time and need OH. That being said, by the end I was extremely frustrated because I hadn't learned a single thing. So overall I would not recommend.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class was very difficult, at least coming from someone who was not a 55er (like a little more of half of the class was). All in all though, I felt like I liked Colin's lecturing style when I understood it, and he brought a bit of informality to the class in terms of his energy that made the class more intimate (while also getting through a lot of material). To give you some reference on the difficulty of the class, Curt McMullen (who was teaching a graduate complex analysis course in the room the class period before us) asked us if this was a graduate combinatorics class early on in the semester. All in all, the office hours were helpful and the course staff and Colin made sure you knew the material if you asked for help. They were also generous with accepting unpenalized late work which was greatly appreciated by many of us. Next iterations of the course are not guaranteed to be as difficult since the course content and structure changes so much from year to year, so if you are looking for math classes to take try sorting by instructor if Colin isn't teaching this class next fall. Even without having to take exams, I feel like I have a really solid knowledge of algebraic combinatorics in general and other combinatorial objects based on how much I was thinking about them from week to week. Some problem set questions still have me a bit traumatized (the cute kind of trauma though).  I also really liked the topics that involved algorithms and drawing pretty pictures. This is a very visual math course which I love. TLDR:great and interesting class, difficult class, great staff, got something out of it.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Wonderful course!   – Prof. McMullen is really great; he provides excellent intuition for many important concepts discussed (e.g., the Riemann mapping theorem), and also makes many important remarks on subtle points (e.g., the flaw of the Stokes proof of Cauchy–Goursat). Both geometric intuition as well as the algebraic rigor are provided. – The course notes are very well–written. They are rather terse, but give helpful background and intuition, as well as presenting the main ideas of the proofs. – The course is divided into 5 sections: first, basic facts (e.g. material in math 55/113, though also with their relation to harmonic functions and consequently at times physics); then, Riemann surfaces and metrics (e.g., the hyperbolic plane, and the Schwarz Lemma); next, entire/meromorphic functions (main results: Hadamard factorization theorem, gamma function, consequences); fourth, the Riemann mapping theorem (which is a very beautiful theorem! intuition on the importance of the Schwarz Lemma is also provided); and lastly, elliptic functions and curves. The first four are very fundamental in standard complex analysis, and provide many important and general results of Hadamard/Riemann, etc. I also really enjoyed the final section, as a hint towards the consequences of the development done throughout the course on elliptic curves, which of course have many nice relations to algebra and number theory.  – I emphasize also the importance of having both the rigorous introduction as well as intuition and connections. One might think analysis is dry and bashy, but at least 213 shows many intriguing connections between complex analysis and geometry, dynamics, number theory, and so on!
worse_comment: This course is the best math course I have ever taken at Harvard and it is not even close. McMullen teaches with an incredible amount of depth, and due to his visual style of thinking you really get to feel every operation, every function that you learn about in the course. Some tips:1) Be fluent with Math 113 + 131 + group theory material before taking this. The first quarter of this course is 113 review but it is fast and not easy.2) Pay attention to the main ideas underlying all the theorems. Particularly take into account what big ideas like the schwarz lemma actually do qualitatively. I think most of the problems may seem inaccessible if you just think about what theorems look similar, but if you think about what you're actually trying to do qualitatively I feel most of the problems fall out quite readily.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Professor Drozd moves pretty speedily (he's also a bit dry in terms of teaching) in lectures, so definitely have a very strong foundation of MATH 123 before taking this course. Otherwise, the content covered was pretty standard.

This course provided an extensive introduction to algebraic number theory and in particular local class field theory. It covered a lot of very intriguing and foundational material (e.g., the main result of local CFT is very strong and amazing!)  – The course was very difficult. The problem sets in the first half of the course were quite long, though there were many HW problems which were directly related to course material (e.g. prove a fact used in lecture, etc.) The second half of the course consisted of shorter problem sets, which were mostly an application of the course material. The material was covered fairly quickly; for instance, infinite Galois theory (there were several problem sets which helped the material become familiar; it was however covered quickly). – It is helpful to know some mathematics outside of the stated prerequisites. In the first half of the course, 221 (commutative algebra) helps with understanding of, e.g., local rings, Dedekind domains, etc.: familiarity with algebra would make some of the problems easier. At some times, knowledge of cohomology would help (e.g. in Tate cohomology). These are not strictly necessary, but could enhance one's understanding of course material in a broader context.  – Prof. Wood gives very helpful intuition; for instance, in the proof of Hensel's lemma (cf. Newton's method). The course texts are fairly difficult to read: Serre is very terse (and cites Bourbaki frequently); most of the course follows the presentations in Neukirch, which is densely written but with more details; it helps significantly to attend lecture and gain intuition, as well as work through many details on one's own outside of the class.  – There is a review and final exam at the end of the course, which are very useful in regards to summarizing and reflecting on the material learned. Several important connections are made; for instance, Kummer Theory and CFT combine to give the Hilbert symbol.  – The last few lectures are largely a survey over many cool results (e.g. general reciprocity law, absolute galois group of separable closures, etc.) which are beyond the scope of the course. These were an enjoyable outlook onto the relevance and application of material, as well as a look into the progression of the field after the material presented.
worse_comment: This course, along with Math 232a, is probably one of the hardest and most demanding courses in the math department. That being said, it is very worthwhile and the material is very interesting and fundamental. I would highly recommend taking it, especially if Prof. Wood teaches it again, but expect to need to spend lots of time both on the problems and on understanding the course material.

best_comment: Very important material if you want to do geometry (for instance, algebraic geometry or complex geometry). The lectures are very mid / boring, but the TF much more than makes up for it with amazing teaching and exposition / help during OH. Even with subpar lectures (and a subpar textbook), I would recommend the course simply because it is so important.
worse_comment: This course covers a wide range of essential material for any advanced mathematics undergraduate. The assignments and exams for the course are well–designed and manageable, strongly reinforcing the understanding of the course material. I would recommend this course, but be wary if the Taubes textbook is used in the future, as it is difficult to follow.

best_comment: Very important material if you want to do geometry (for instance, algebraic geometry or complex geometry). The lectures are very mid / boring, but the TF much more than makes up for it with amazing teaching and exposition / help during OH. Even with subpar lectures (and a subpar textbook), I would recommend the course simply because it is so important.
worse_comment: This course covers a wide range of essential material for any advanced mathematics undergraduate. The assignments and exams for the course are well–designed and manageable, strongly reinforcing the understanding of the course material. I would recommend this course, but be wary if the Taubes textbook is used in the future, as it is difficult to follow.

best_comment: Math 231A was an interesting and beautiful course. Professor Kong does a wonderful job of explaining concepts during lecture, and TF Lev Kruglyak also deserves a special mention for his clear exposition of alternative perspectives. P–sets for the course were appropriately demanding, albeit some of the problems felt slightly peripheral to what was presented in lecture (maybe this was the intention however as the powerful tools introduced in the course definitely took some playing around with to get used to). The textbook (May) was definitely a strange choice – it did not present the topics in the standard order (which in my opinion was actually a good thing), but it was just way too dry and terse especially for such a beautiful subject. A minor detail, but I personally think a lecture dedicated to explaining the motivation for homology and beginning with more concrete constructions of the abstract concept would have cultivated a better understanding of the idea and a more nuanced appreciation for the beauty of results such as Hurewicz's theorem and Künneth formulae later down the line.To those who enjoyed Math 55 or Math 131 (students from the former would benefit hugely from the careful review of modules and tensor products introduced in 55A, and those from the latter would benefit from self–studying these two concepts reasonably thoroughly), this is a great next step in the world of topology: personally I feel that the key takeaways from this course – namely a greater exposure to and appreciation of category theory, and an experience using tools from various levels of abstraction – will indeed be very beneficial for any future study of maths in general.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is the best version of Math 232 by far (for at least the last five years). Usually it's a number theorist who does abstract scheme theory, leaving everyone with zero geometric intuition or grounding in the matter, but Popa's version really gets into the heart of the geometry. We start with complex analysis in several variables, and then move on to complex manifolds, and then eventually to compact Kahler manifolds. In the process, we develop lots of beautiful geometry, and we also gain an intuition about why we even care about schemes and sheaves and cohomology (i.e. we see why these are very useful things to consider by starting from the geometry, not the algebra). Popa is also the best lecturer I've had throughout Harvard, so if he is teaching this version of the class again, definitely take it!!!!!
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Very interesting! A good 5th class, or a good math class when you're loaded with other ones.  Since the class is pretty self paced, its important to be on top of your work and not leave it all for last minute!!! You get what you put in! The TFs were great, David was so helpful and so kind and supportive!! During the presentation, I got really nervous and would look at him since he had helped me and I felt better!!
worse_comment: This course was barely any work, but I got nearly nothing out of it. The lectures were disorganized and often focused on provocative applications or philosophy more than on the actual mathematics. Since there were no required psets, I never learned how to use/apply the material. This was a fine course to get a requirement done with minimal, work, but I truly got very little out of it.Personally, I was also frustrated by the discussions of how we could use the dynamic models discussed to describe cycles of war or other society–level phenomena. I felt these discussions to be unhelpfully provocative, ridiculously oversimplifying complex problems by declaring that these extremely simple models could relate to them.

course_title: Quantum theory from the geometric viewpoint I 001
best_comment: as an undergrad who (maybe mistakenly) took this class out of curiosity, this class was baffling in many many ways. at face level, this class is extremely challenging even to the most prepared. the level of math that dan just casually mentions as elementary facts that one would have learnt in kindergarten is kinda insane. i am by no means a smart person, but as an undergrad who has taken many math classes and one grad class on differential geometry, it was still really really difficult to follow dan's lectures at many points as he truly goes way and above what one learns in a usual math class. since dan is a geometer at heart, he will go on and on about advanced concepts in geometry, and even though he does not require background in these topics as a hard prereq for the class, be warned that you will become lost approximately 2 lectures in if you have not studied symplectic geometry before. furthermore, as the name of the class might suggest, being a physics student amongst a sea of mathematicians might be the biggest advantage that one might have in this class. i think it is no surprise that even though the class was packed at the start with many graduate students from both math and physics departments, by the end a majority of the physics grad students stayed on, since a strong background in physics (or at least having seen this stuff before in physics) gives you a strong starting point in terms of motivating the material that dan talks about, something that i feel is lacking in those that have no seen quantum field theory before. as a physics student with just a semester of qft under my belt, i was able to appreciate maybe half of the physics that dan talked about. homework was okay at the beginning but as the semester progressed, it got much harder to even know what to write down for problem sets. dan was really not kidding when he said that the problems were open ended and meant to challenge the grad students. it was perhaps a bit too open–ended, to the extent that at many points even the graduate tfs were not sure what the solution to the problem should be, or even how much you were supposed to write down, which was pretty funny and at least gave me some comfort that i wasnt a fool struggling in the class because of my severe lack of mathematical preparation. also, it was a bit pointless when most of the graduate students dont even look at the psets anyways :( i kinda feel bad for this, but towards the last few psets i just wrote down stuff that i thought was sort of correct and handwaved a whole bunch of stuff since i wasnt even sure how much i needed to answer anymoredespite all this, dan is an extremely good lecturer and probably one of the kindest and at the same time most cracked professors i have seen at harvard. i guess the math administration finally did something right for once in their lives by pulling dan over from austin, because his exposition is extremely clear and he is one of the rare few professors that actually knows everything off the top of his head. at the very least, he gives off the impression that he prepares for his classes and does not stumble over his proofs, which is hard to come by in the math department. he is also a kind soul and even reduced the number of problems on homeworks cuz he knew that many of the undergrads were struggling to keep up in the class (this almost moved me to tears). plus he has a sick sense of humour which is all that matters. overall a 10/10 mathematician and a 10000/10 human being. despite how well he taught, i still managed to fall asleep in almost every class, but i feel like thats more of my fault than his. i do have to say though that his voice is extremely calming which definitely contributed a lot to that

Take it, or more generally any class from Hopkins that interests you. Hopkins is a fantastic lecturer and you will definitely get the big ideas from class, but working through the material on your own after the fact and seeing everything come together is very rewarding.
Take anything Stephen is teaching!! He cares so deeply about his students and their experience, and will love to talk to you about anything you're interested in!

course_title: Critical Thinking and Research Proposal Writing 001
best_comment: This course made me think critically about my project and about what the results would be and how I would interpret them. Also getting insight into the F31/grant application process from faculty was especially enlightening. Don't worry if you don't end up doing your project or even presenting it for your PQE –– this is a great exercise for working with project proposals in general
worse_comment: This course only meets four times during the course of the semester. It is not a hands–on research for writing course and will not help you write and revise your PQE, it only makes you to write it.

best_comment: I really enjoyed this course! You get to read lots of interesting papers and engage with very impressive faculty. The presentation format means that you get to really get know the faculty that you present with for your week which is a great opportunity. I'm sure people in the class got by without deeply reading the papers, but it was a lot of fun to engage/discuss if you did.
subject: Biolog Chem & Molecular Pharm

course_title: Principles and Practice of Drug Development 001
best_comment: Minimal commitment (1 lecture a week with minimal work outside of class). Essentially two assignments: a midterm presentation and a final paper + presentation. The latter can be a lot of work and depends a lot on the quality of partners that you get. But with planning ahead its definitely manageable. The guest lectures are fairly engaging for the most part, with some special gems. Some were hard to sit through, including Stan's lectures, but Peter Sorger is a great lecturer. The class tends to focus a lot on the business/economic/regulatory side, and less so on the science/biochemistry side. It is a class designed for people with minimal scientific experience. I can imagine the ideal student for this class would be a business school student looking to go into biotech investment/consulting or something who wants to get a good background of the field.
subject: Biolog Chem & Molecular Pharm
course_title_2024: Principles and Practice of Drug Development

best_comment: This is a class one should take if one has a strong background in CS and/or statistics and wishes to get a better sense of how these topics can be used to ask and answer foundational scientific questions. However, it should not be used as a class to learn these CS/stats techniques–––for that, choose a more technically rigorous class (e.g. Stat 111, CS 25, etc.)

course_title: Teaching 100: The Theory and Science of Teaching 001
best_comment: Great course if you're interested in teaching and an even better course if you want to improve your teaching skills. I took this course because I wanted to become better at teaching, but had no tools to evaluate my teaching ability or identifying areas in which I could improve. This course has given me all of these tools and strategies at succeeding.
subject: Cell Biology
course_title_2024: Teaching 100: The Theory and Science of Teaching

best_comment: To future students: I would highly recommend taking this class if you are looking for a challenge, for a stronger genetics foundation, for an opportunity to get closer to your cohort, and to have an insight in the vibrant and knowledgeable genetics department at Harvard. The people and students involved in this class are amazing.
worse_comment: If you have to take this class, good luck. If you don't, then I would not recommend taking it. This course is taught basically the same as it was in the 90s: chalkboard lectures, no notes provided, very long problem sets, and 24–hour exams. Section is extremely TF–dependent. Everyone ends up getting OK grades, but it causes so much unnecessary stress during an already stressful time. We are trying to figure out who we will work with and what we will do for the next 6 years of our lives—so why are you making us spend full days on exams testing our ability to cross yeast and flies??

We are trying to figure out who we will work with and what we will do for the next 6 years of our lives—so why are you making us spend full days on exams testing our ability to cross yeast and flies??

best_comment: To future students: I would highly recommend taking this class if you are looking for a challenge, for a stronger genetics foundation, for an opportunity to get closer to your cohort, and to have an insight in the vibrant and knowledgeable genetics department at Harvard. The people and students involved in this class are amazing.

course_title: Principles of Human Disease: Physiology and Pathology 001
best_comment: This class, while rewarding, is a lot of work. This class is a flipped classroom, so you will have to watch a 1 hour lecture + quiz before attending a 1.5 hour discussion section twice a week. Some in class discussions were fun and interesting, but they often felt redundant with the assigned homework. Every week, you will also have a tutorial section, in which you either prepare a presentation on a clinical case for a small group to discuss, a 15 min presentation on the background of the disease, or a 10 min presentation on a novel research topic. This is an interesting class, but definitely a marathon. Maybe I'm just out of practice as a graduate student, but this was a ton of work.
subject: Human Bio & Translational Med
course_title_2024: Principles of Human Disease: Physiology and Pathology

best_comment: While the course is challenging for people with not much experience in immunology, I think the faculty lectures and recorded lectures were extremely helpful and more than enough to strengthen my foundations of immunology and added so much more detail to it. Among the details provided, I think it's better to know that since I might not remember the nitty gritty stuff all topics so its more important that I focus on understanding parts of it that I truly enjoy learning about by looking into some review papers about it. I also highly recommend that you read the papers for the TA discussion well as I found the aspect of discussing and analyzing them was really amazing although this does depend more on what TA section you are in.

course_title: Visual Recognition: Computational and biophysical perspective 001
best_comment: This is a super interesting class and great to balance a pset–heavy workload. The assignments are graded somewhat harshly (you have to come to class do to well), but you get free points from the lecture notes comments. The papers you have to read are interesting and the topics connect very nicely. Prof. Kreiman is a fairly good lecturer and his slides/presentations are well done.

Good course. There's a lot of material, but the emphasis is on learning, so the classroom atmosphere feels fairly relaxed. However, it is a lot of class time and there are often multiple assignments a week, so I'd only take this course if you're really interested in learning the subject matter. But if you *are* interested in sound and hearing, this is a great introductory course. Doesn't assume too much background knowledge.
subject: Speech & Hearing Sciences

course_title: Poverty, Wealth, and Religion in the Middle Ages 001
best_comment: This is an awesome class to take if you have even the smallest bit of interest in medieval Europe or religion. It is so fun and engaging and Prof FitzGerald is an incredible and kind guide to the content. Highly highly recommend the course.

I would tell them that if they want to work with Latin manuscripts, taking this class is going to be a much faster and more effective way of learning paleography than trying to teach themselves from a manual.

This is a highly interdisciplinary class that you'll enjoy if you like English, Psychology, Neuroscience, Linguistics, and Philosophy. It's really interesting to see how these come together but I thought the course could do a better job at connecting them a little better. It's both very theoretical and scientific so be ready to learn something new and take a risk to explore! The final project was very fulfilling and interesting to do – Anne is very passionate about the topic and appreciates active participation and discussion; she lets you explore your own interests within the class which is great if you're looking for a personal project to do relating to these topics!
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior

best_comment: The topic of this course is super interesting and unique, and if you're interested in it, I'd recommend taking this class. That being said, the course was very disorganized. The readings on the syllabus didn't match with the readings on Canvas, and Dr. Etcoff never clarified which ones we were supposed to follow. Sometimes I'd show up to class and we'd be discussing a completely different topic from what I was expecting. Thankfully, it doesn't really matter whether or not you did the correct readings (or any readings) – the students led the discussion each week, and nobody knew what was going on, so we just discussed whatever was most interesting to us. I read whichever readings looked interesting and skipped the rest. And despite her lack of organization, Dr. Etcoff is super sweet and happy to let the class unfold naturally, so I was never worried that the disorganization would hurt our grades. TL;DR: if you're interested in the topics and can tolerate a highly disorganized class, take this – the readings are interesting, discussions are engaging, and assignments are easy.
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior

course_title: The Role of Music in Health and Education 1
best_comment: Hands down the best 2 hours of my week this semester—you blink and it's over! I absolutely loved the course material, speakers, readings, and above all, the people. Not only are Dr. Wong and Ayelet two of the most amazing people, I got to meet so many cool classmates from all walks of music from dancers to classical musicians to DJs. Class periods consist of speaker presentations, discussions, and student presentations. If you have even a slight interest in music, I highly recommend taking this class. Also it's really chill and stress–free (stress–relieving honestly) so it would be great to pair with other more demanding courses. One of my highlights from the fall was our end–of–year party and jam session which turned into a student–led concert and Taylor swift karaoke. I hope you'll be able to take this class and have as much of a blast as we did!!!
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior
course_title_2024: The Role of Music in Health and Education

course_title: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Chemistry, Molecular Biology, and Cell Biology 001
best_comment: I LOVED LS1A!!! If you are hesitant about taking this course, I'll say this: I was, too. I had heard scary things about the curve and the difficult exams, etc. and I doubted myself the first few weeks. I think because of that doubt, I didn't do as well on the first PIE as I would have liked (it was literally the EASIEST intro chemistry content but I was so scared of failing that I sabotaged myself – lucky me, we have a drop PIE!)But as the course went on, I realized how absolutely amazing it was. Not only is the content super interesting, but the teaching staff are genuinely the best of the best. From the head professors to the TFs to the CAs, everyone wants to see you succeed and actively supports you. The assessments are so fair. If you've taken AP bio + chem and did well in them in HS, you are chilling as long as you keep up with the material (like do the learning pods on time + read the textbook if that helps you). Go to office hours and student study networks (SSN) for PSET help. Make friends because truly the people in LS1a are so nice and so humble. Even though the grading is in comparison to the other students, generally people still helped one another (of course there were a few exceptions but overwhelmingly the course was collaborative and inclusive). Best of luck, YOU GOT THIS. don't let the doubt get to you, you can and will succeed as long as you engage with the material regularly).Special shoutout to Rachelle, I loved her learning pods and lectures!! She is so knowledgeable and passionate about what she does, you cannot help but also get invested. Thank you!!!!Another shoutout to my bestie and the slayest TF on the planet: José!!! If you get José as your TF you've literally won in life like he is THE best and will teach you, support you, and cheer you on always. I had my section from 6–8:45 pm (which is crazy in the middle of the fall semester when the sun sets at like 4) but José made it so so fun. His jokes and happy personality are so refreshing, I cannot rave enough about him.
worse_comment: Reality: This class is kind of a pain, but you can definitely take steps to make it better/worse. If you want a taste of chem/bio, but don't need a class to fufil pre–med/life science concentration classes,  DON'T take this course. If you get placed into LPSA, take it instead of LS1A (it's better taught).Tips:1. Check your PSET and Lab answers at SSN (PSET) or CPM office hours (Lab). They make up a big portion of your grade and TF's can be harsh graders.2. Your TF will make or break this class. If you don't like your TF, find an extracurricular activity that conflicts with your section and put in a request to move sections. 3. Find 2 TFs you like and go to their office hours every week, even if you feel like you don't need to. Those extra 2 hours of *good* office hours saved me so much time studying/PSETing, but OH with a bad TF literally made me go backwards.4. You can sign up for 1–1 peer tutoring (drop in or with the same person) through the ARC, which is really helpful for studying. I would book 2 hours of peer tutoring during the week before each midterm and they would sit there while I did practice problems until I got stuck (win–win bc then they get paid to do their homework) and then if I was confused they would explain the problem.
subject: Life Sciences
course_title_2024: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Chemistry, Molecular Biology, and Cell Biology

course_title: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Chemistry, Molecular Biology, and Cell Biology 001
best_comment: I LOVED LS1A!!! If you are hesitant about taking this course, I'll say this: I was, too. I had heard scary things about the curve and the difficult exams, etc. and I doubted myself the first few weeks. I think because of that doubt, I didn't do as well on the first PIE as I would have liked (it was literally the EASIEST intro chemistry content but I was so scared of failing that I sabotaged myself – lucky me, we have a drop PIE!)But as the course went on, I realized how absolutely amazing it was. Not only is the content super interesting, but the teaching staff are genuinely the best of the best. From the head professors to the TFs to the CAs, everyone wants to see you succeed and actively supports you. The assessments are so fair. If you've taken AP bio + chem and did well in them in HS, you are chilling as long as you keep up with the material (like do the learning pods on time + read the textbook if that helps you). Go to office hours and student study networks (SSN) for PSET help. Make friends because truly the people in LS1a are so nice and so humble. Even though the grading is in comparison to the other students, generally people still helped one another (of course there were a few exceptions but overwhelmingly the course was collaborative and inclusive). Best of luck, YOU GOT THIS. don't let the doubt get to you, you can and will succeed as long as you engage with the material regularly).Special shoutout to Rachelle, I loved her learning pods and lectures!! She is so knowledgeable and passionate about what she does, you cannot help but also get invested. Thank you!!!!Another shoutout to my bestie and the slayest TF on the planet: José!!! If you get José as your TF you've literally won in life like he is THE best and will teach you, support you, and cheer you on always. I had my section from 6–8:45 pm (which is crazy in the middle of the fall semester when the sun sets at like 4) but José made it so so fun. His jokes and happy personality are so refreshing, I cannot rave enough about him.
worse_comment: Reality: This class is kind of a pain, but you can definitely take steps to make it better/worse. If you want a taste of chem/bio, but don't need a class to fufil pre–med/life science concentration classes,  DON'T take this course. If you get placed into LPSA, take it instead of LS1A (it's better taught).Tips:1. Check your PSET and Lab answers at SSN (PSET) or CPM office hours (Lab). They make up a big portion of your grade and TF's can be harsh graders.2. Your TF will make or break this class. If you don't like your TF, find an extracurricular activity that conflicts with your section and put in a request to move sections. 3. Find 2 TFs you like and go to their office hours every week, even if you feel like you don't need to. Those extra 2 hours of *good* office hours saved me so much time studying/PSETing, but OH with a bad TF literally made me go backwards.4. You can sign up for 1–1 peer tutoring (drop in or with the same person) through the ARC, which is really helpful for studying. I would book 2 hours of peer tutoring during the week before each midterm and they would sit there while I did practice problems until I got stuck (win–win bc then they get paid to do their homework) and then if I was confused they would explain the problem.

subject: Life Sciences
course_title_2024: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Chemistry, Molecular Biology, and Cell Biology

best_comment: I would tell future students that LS50 is a truly transformative experience. It will be one of the hardest classes you have ever taken, but you will also emerge with an amazing group of friends. The best part of LS50 is truly the community––the professors, TFs, and CAs are all very approachable and work hard to create a supportive environment in the class. Special shoutout to Emma Nagy for being the heart of LS50 and to Kara McKinley for her engaging and interactive lectures on Regenerative Biology. Aside from the teaching staff, the students in LS50 are some of the most intelligent and fascinating people you will meet at Harvard. You must seek out LS50 to be a part of it, so your peers will be some of the top STEM students at Harvard––people who will inspire you one moment and then invite you out for a meal the next (just hope you don't get a jalapeño burrito). In terms of content, LS50 is truly INTEGRATED science. This means that you will be learning everything from biology to chemistry to statistical mechanics and coding. This has both pros and cons. On the plus side, you will be exposed to many fascinating scientific specialities you didn't even know existed. However, this also means you will inevitably be exposed to something you don't like (I'm looking at you, stat mech––the bane of my existence). LS50 is also an incredibly difficult course. This is not for the faint of heart. You will be working on psets anywhere from 15–20 hours a week. Psets are impossible to complete on your own unless you are some kind of super–genius (which is entirely possible––like I said, LS50 is full of awesome people). Most psets will require help to complete, which you can find at office hours––hosted every night. Office hours are like the great melting pot of LS50 where much of the bonding takes place. You are bound to form great friendships when you and ten others are stranded at office hours until 11:30, desperately trying to figure out stat mech (which did in fact happen). Midterms are even harder than psets, and a sizable portion of the whole class fails every time. I would also say that part of the difficulty of LS50 comes from the vast discrepancy in scientific backgrounds. Some people in this class have done research all throughout high school, while others (aka me) have never even touched a beaker or pipette before this class. For the most part, the professors do a good job supporting all students, but sometimes prior knowledge of topics is assumed and you have to figure things out yourself. All that said, DON'T take LS50 if you're merely looking for an easy class. LS50 is no GEM; this is life science, not geology, and really intense life science at that. Don't take LS50 unless you're prepared to have it consume your life––you will be attending lecture every day, lab once a week, section once a week, and many additional office hours as well. LS50 takes the place of two classes, and you take it all year; it's literally half of your freshmen schedule, and probably way more than half of your headspace. Don't take LS50 unless you're prepared to reach out and make friends. As I stated above, LS50 has an incredible community, but only if you're willing to be an active member. Friendships don't just sprout up overnight; they are formed out of shared meals, evenings in Cabot pset–ing together, burrito runs in the middle of the night... If you put effort in, you'll get so much in return; if you put nothing in, well...just look to Newton's 1st law. And go take physics instead because we don't actually learn about Newton's 1st law in LS50. DO take LS50 if you truly love science and want to pursue science as a career. DO take LS50 if you want a small class where you can really get to know your professors. DO take LS50 if you want to be around some of the top STEM students a Harvard, and if you see yourself as one of these students ;). DO take LS50 if you want to make deep, meaningful friendships. DO take LS50 if you were able to read this entire crazy, unhinged rant! And finally, DO take LS50 if any of the following experiences sound meaningful to you. After all, science is all about observation, and here's some data culled from my freshmen fall experience: ––Playing spoon Assassins with the whole class ––Eating Thanksgiving with LS50 friends ––Watching a horror movie after the second midterm (what's scarier? Scream or stat mech. Take the class and then decide yourself). ––Staying at office hours until 11:30 (stat mech strikes again) ––Listening to the new TSwift Album with LS50 friends (Cabot party!)––Running to Jefe's at 4 am for pset sustenance ––And so many other memories! There will be no further explanation. Just LS50.
