subject: Life Sciences

course_title: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: Ok, so I would say this is a good way to fulfill your research requirement for Neuro or any other biology concentrators. The workload is lighter than Neuro 91 (only 6 hours compared to 15) and they set you up with a PI who shows you the ropes, so that structure is really nice. We have three presentations during the semester and that’s the only work besides weekly lab work, which you either do during the 3–5pm meeting time or on your own time, depending on the lab you’re in. Also, you have a choice of three labs after they each give an elevator pitch type presentation on the first day of class and I think basically everyone gets their first choice. All groups regardless of which lab you choose work out of the learning lab in Northwest so transportation is not an issue. My only qualm with this class is that I have no idea where I stand grade–wise. There is no syllabus to tell us if participation in lab work contributes to our grade, which is frustrating because half the people in my group never go to lab and collect data. Also, it doesn’t tell us what percentage of our grade the three presentations count for nor did we ever get graded feedback on any of the presentations. Finally, the final paper is a bit daunting because you write a grant proposal that is up to ten pages single spaced, yes I said single spaced. It’s nice that we write a partial draft and get feedback from our PI’s but I guess I wish there was a rubric? Or something that would help me know if I’m on track to get a good grade on it. I also don’t know what percent of our grade this final paper is worth. These are all issues that could easily be fixed and I would love to see them addressed in the next iteration of this course because this really is a great option for people that aren’t ready to take the leap into Neuro 91 :) Would I recommend this course? Yes…as long as I end up with an A.

I have mixed feelings about this class. There are a lot of things I did not like about MCB 60, but in the end, I do appreciate the amount of knowledge I gained. So first, let me talk about the things that need to be fixed: the course structure and assignments. The PSETs and exams were ridiculously difficult for unfair reasons. The PSETs are meant to challenge students to think like researchers, but PSETs should also be an opportunity for students to have a safe–space to learn and actually practice thinking like a researcher. Instead, they are graded somewhat harshly (depending on the specific grader), and the pressure from having to get everything correct down to the last detail takes away from the best learning experience possible. Your homework should be designed so you learn from your mistakes, not for you to be afraid of making them. Unfortunately, these PSETs make up a large portion of your grade, so you just can't make mistakes or else. Also, the answer keys for the PSETs were often confusing and vague as well, so even that wasn't very helpful in the end. The office hours should be places where you can get questions cleared up, but for several of the office hours, the TFs were so focused on not giving away the answer that often they gave very vague guidance that made you walk away even more confused. I do recommend Janice's office hours though if she is still here. Also, the questions written on the PSETs are often written poorly and it can be super confusing on what the question is even talking about. What the question wants is also very vague. For instance, "what does the figure suggest?" Well, often the figure could suggest a lot of things, so you never know what the grader is actually looking for. The amount of time to get feedback is also not that great. By the time you receive feedback, you are already weeks ahead learning way different content. The shortcomings of the exams are very similar to what was described about the PSETs. The exams did get better as we grew over the semester, but the growth process was not the best. The first exam will be atrocious, but they will gradually be ok.  Lastly, you should be aware that the flipped–classroom style also takes away from the learning experience. The weekly pre–lecture videos did not do the best job explaining the background we needed to know for the week. The background would be quickly glazed over and then we immediately dive into problem solving. The textbook did a good job filling in the holes,  but it is still necessary to have detailed explanations on the week's concepts during instruction time just so we can all avoid confusion. However, we don't get that. The textbook reading assignments take up a lot of time and a lot of the content was never ever mentioned or applied again in class. It isn't the best use of time, but skipping it really wasn't a solution either since there are those one or two things you really need to know.  You don't know what is important until later, so you really can't sift through the material efficiently. It will be challenging thinking about the best way to study for this class, but in the end, you will survive. Despite the structure of the course needing some patch–up work, you will learn and grow a lot over the semester. I now have a better understanding of how the cell and body works like a machine. I enjoyed learning how prions are formed, how cell signaling happens, how stem cells work, and how the origins of cancer come to be among lots  of other cool topics. This course covered a lot of great details about how biology works, and it really made me appreciate the fascinating nature of cells. They seem to always have a way around solving problems, and I remember often feeling amazed by the intelligence and adaptability of these building blocks of life. Also, I think MCB 60 did a good job preparing us for lab and research experiences outside of class. Now I have a lot of practice using pipets, knowing how to use centrifuge, doing dilutions, reading gels, counting cells, plating cells, growing colonies, doing Western blot, and also reading research literature.
worse_comment: The lecture style is extremely unengaging. It's one of those flipped–classroom style course where you watch the modules before class and discuss questions with classmates in class, and the course heads manage this teaching style very poorly. You are supposed to think about the questions on the pre–lecture quizzes(which is due every week before Monday lecture), so  I personally felt like I have already done most of my thinking for a question while completing the quiz. Discussion with classmates rarely provided me with much new insight because either the answer was straightforward and warrants little discussion, or my classmates were equally confused. The time given to discussions is PROLONGED(often 5–10 minutes for a single question and altogether account for more than 70% of lecture time), which makes the pace of lecture very slow. At the end of discussion the professor would call on students to give their answers to the questions, but when the students' answers are not toally correct, the professor often fails to explain at the end what the correct answer is. For this reason, the lecture content is often disorganized and I have a difficult time taking notes I can use for exam review. My notes had to rely heavily on the textbook and the pre–recorded modules. The lecture component can be improved if the discussion time is cut down a bit and the professor gives more organized lecturing.  If you have to take this class as concentration requirement, prepare to expect little from the lectures and learn independently.

subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: MCB 63 was a class that I entered with unrealistic expectations due to the Q–Report feedback from the year prior. If you read the Fall, 2022 Q–Report for this course, you will likely notice that many students describe MCB 63 as being a very easy course and a “gem” of a class, with one even saying that it is near impossible to not get an A. However, this is only partially true, with it being highly dependent on your prior experience within the field of Biology, Chemistry, and Biochemistry.At its core, most of the students that are taking MCB 63 have either (1) already taken CHEM 27, another Biochemistry–focused class, or (2) already taken or are in the process of preparing to take the MCAT. As a result, many students enter this course with some form of background on the subject. For students that do not have this background, MCB 63 will be significantly harder, and you will likely feel way behind your peers. In the syllabus, since SGA’s, which are basically reminiscent of PIE’s from LS1a/LS1b are only worth 30% of our course grade, it may seem really easy. However, the SGA’s are very difficult at times, with some not even matching up with the list of objectives we were provided with beforehand. It is very easy to perform poorly on an SGA, as they are graded out of just 30 points (so each mistake costs a lot!) Additionally, with them occurring bi–weekly, it makes it seem like MCB 63 is basically always absorbing your time and causing you stress. It gets especially bad for the final two, which are lined up back to back and cover 6 lectures worth of material at once. Additionally, please know that there are NO GRADE CUTOFFS SET for the course. According to a student from the previous year, they ended with a ~94.5% but still received an A– in the course. For those that are very wary about their GPA’s, please take this into consideration as we are unsure how final grades are decided. At the time of writing this, I still have no clue what I will be ending with in the class.In terms of the class itself, the topics are definitely interesting, but it is very difficult to tell what is important to know/memorize, especially since Professor Viel can get very detailed in his explanations. As a result, it is easy to lose sight of the bigger picture, or to become lost within the minute details of each metabolic pathway. Additionally, he is also relatively soft–spoken, which can make it difficult to understand him sometimes, especially during lecture. However, the content provided is definitely very interesting, as long as you enjoy biology and chemistry! Professor Viel does a good job of tying back what we learn to different aspects of human life, especially in terms of medicine.Overall, if you are reading this, please just know, MCB 63 is GOING to be difficult if you do not have this type of established background or have not had any exposure to the content. Take the other positive reviews with a grain of salt, making sure you understand the background that many students enter the course with. If you decide to enroll, work hard and good luck!
worse_comment: the content is actually kinda interesting on its own but it's presented in the most boring way ever. literally the most boring lectures I've ever been to. cannot express how boring the professor is. so so so so so boring

subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: This course is fantastic. There is a lot of material, but Jeff and Katie teach it incredibly well. I found section to be really helpful in ensuring my understanding as well, and I felt like the material is presented in a really accessible way. I loved having the guest speakers come in each week, and the demonstrations we did during workshops were always great and a lot of fun. As a first–year who took this course because I want to concentrate in neuro, I highly recommend it. My academic advisor cautioned me before taking it as mostly sophomores take it, but it was so worth it and I felt like I was able to be really successful. If you want to take it, definitely take it! Such an interesting course, the PSETs and assignments are so reasonable, and I feel like I learned a lot.
worse_comment: I loved Neuro80!!! I highly recommend it, one of the most interesting classes I've taken at Harvard. Since the first half of the class really focuses on the neuron, it would be helpful to come in with a biology background, but it's absolutely not necessary. I enjoyed the flipped classroom format – I watched all the video lectures then only went in–person for the Thursday workshop, which reviews all the material. If you don't like flipped classroom, you might not like this class, but the Thursday workshop and Katie's  lecture notes are very thorough reviews of the week's material. PSETs are straight–forward, you can work on those in office hours.
best_gem_comment: Take the class!!! It's honestly SUCH a gem. The content is super interesting, the psets aren't too bad (and you can do them at Sunday Problem Set Solving hours with TFs), and the staff are all so supportive.

best_comment: Really consider what you’re doing before you decide to write a thesis, especially if you don’t have to. I thought since I’m already working in a lab it would be silly not to do it, but honestly I probably wouldn’t have done it if I could go back. There’s nothing silly about working in a lab and not having the added pressure of producing enough results to write about, not to mention actually having to write the whole thing. That being said, if research is your passion and you want something to show for it, go for it.

best_comment: It's not an easy class, but going to office hours really helps and Elena is a wonderful professor who is understanding and very willing to help!
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Professor Losick is a nice lecturer, kind person, and great conversationalist. The lectures are interesting and are focused more on following the story of molecular bio than on memorizing content, and you get to meet some incredible guest lecturers whose work was foundational to the field. However, be careful with the assignments–– course staff were very unclear about grading, and set confusing guidelines regarding the importance of the (pretty difficult) homework quizzes and in–class polls. Students were told that our performance in these do not matter, however our grades were still impacted by the scores we got. We also received very little guidance on the final essays, not even a rubric on which we would be graded. We were consistently told not to worry about grading, but you actually do need to worry. Make sure to review your writing directly with the prof if you want to succeed–– other course staff were not the most accessible in the week following up to the deadline. Also, do not expect course staff to be incredibly generous with final grading–– many people had borderline A's, like 91.9%, but were not rounded up. If you care more about learning than you care about your grade, then this is a good class for you. However, for people who need a good GPA for med school, etc., be careful and at least stay in communication with course staff frequently.
best_gem_comment: Take this class!! It is by far one of my favorite classes at Harvard so far. It was interesting to learn about scientists that have shaped the world of Molecular Biology. Professor Loscik is a gem and a wonderful lecturer! He instils in you a passion for the topic and "his story time" moments had me laughing constantly. It is a very well–taught class and I loved taking it.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Two main points:1. This is my favorite class ever.2. This is NOT a gem, but if you do the work you will get a good grade!The course does have its flaws and lectures can be hard to follow at times. There are lots and lots of details and it takes WORK to memorize all of them. I was studying for this class weekly — it was maybe 40% less weekly studying than LS2, for reference. Don't let the "3 psets" fool you into thinking it's an easy class; you have to be disciplined and study because there is just too much information to memorize at the last minute. Don't worry about reading the textbook, just make sure you stay on top of HMX and are paying attention in lecture/studying your lecture notes weekly because if you zone out you miss a lot, and most of the time lecture slides are not at all helpful. So if you miss something you have to ask a friend or go back and rewatch the lecture. However, lectures are really interesting and engaging. Dr. Pillai is a great speaker. Sometimes he goes a bit fast and you will inevitably miss important points. But your section leaders have your back, so pay attention in section too and you'll be fine! I heard there's a giant curve but this is being written before final grades are out so I don't know if that's real.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: This class goes through a very specific subject matter and the course load is definitely manageable. As with upper levels, you read a lot of papers in the field of study, so this class greatly improved my ability to read papers and be able to comprehend literature a lot better than the beginning of the semester. The quizzes are very fair and the assignments are not busy work and a great way to learn!
worse_comment: Participate! It's okay to be wrong, that's how you learn

subject: Music

best_comment: This was a fun class and I definitely learned some music theory, but this is not the class that I had read about on the Q guide from prior semesters. If you have ever played an instrument or read a piece of sheet music, this class will start painstakingly slow for you. We had Monday and Friday sections that were basically just lecture led by a TF, and those were chaotic, a bit unstructured, but covered a lot of material and were generally pretty engaging. Wednesday lectures always felt like a complete waste of time. Assignments were extremely quick and easy. This class was definitely a gem because of how easy it was, but the class certainly left a lot to be desired. I feel like I could have learned a lot more music theory but didn't. It was nice to have this class in my schedule because of how low commitment it was, but I left the class feeling pretty disappointed and wishing for more.

best_comment: This is a really fun class. It really is low pressure and now stressful at all. It allows you to explore all the ideas of what composition is and you get from it what you put into it. Making the final song is a lot of fun and having the Parker Quartet perform it and work with them is a huge privilege. Take this class if you really want the opportunity to compose a song for a quartet, because that is the main point of the class. In terms of learning a lot about music theory and how it supports composition that is not really the emphasis of the course so just have that in mind.

One regret I have is not taking advantage of the TF's willingness to be flexible with part assignments and seating. Communicate with them when it is important to you and be willing to make concessions. If you are a freshman considering HRO, 100% take it. The musicians are incredibly talented and it will inspire you to become a better musician yourself. I love Fed. A little bit scary if you don't show up enough. But I suppose that's a good thing.
worse_comment: Not sure why you're reading the Q–guides for this class. It's HRO: either you're in or you're out.
subject: Music

best_comment: If you're looking for an extremely disciplined, committed choir, this is not necessarily the group for that. However, the community is incredible!! Every single person I've met in Collegium is so interesting, vibrant, and intelligent in a totally different way. And everyone is incredibly kind and supportive to one another, to a greater degree than I've experienced in any other group on campus.
subject: Music

best_comment: I've had such a great time with the Glee Club. You get to make 60 new friends who all share the joy in making music, and you join an organization with such deep history and traditions. Some of my favorite people I've met at Harvard have been from the Glee Club. The music is from a wide variety of styles and time periods, and is neither too easy nor too hard. I came in with quite a bit of choir experience, but I know people for whom this is their first time singing in a group, and it's really accessible. Andy is a great director from whom I've felt I've learned a lot from, and you can see he really loves the music and conducting it. There are plenty of opportunities to take leadership positions and contribute to the Glee Club, which I have found really rewarding. And, if that wasn't enough, you get yearly opportunities to travel and tour around the country/world (I'm sitting here writing this just drooling about our upcoming 3+ week European tour).
subject: Music

best_comment: You should absolutely join RCS! This class has inspired me to pursue music at a high level and to do a joint concentration in music. This is an incredible opportunity to sing exciting, challenging repertoire. If you don't have a ton of experience singing, the faculty and students are very supportive and willing to help you learn! This class also provides an opportunity to travel and to pursue leadership positions. The community is also excellent; I've met some of my closest friends through this RCS. You get to join an incredible network of musicians and support each other, in and outside of music. RCS has been one of my best experiences at Harvard.
subject: Music

course_title: Latino Music in the United States LEC
best_comment: As a Latina myself, taking this class was such a beautiful way of learning more about my culture as well as expanding my horizons on the Latinx music scene all across the US. I truly felt I was able to learn a lot in this class in a very comfortable, stress–free setting. Most of the learning was discussion based and hearing people's unique perspectives about topics and conversations that were both personal and universal was incredibly rewarding. Professor Madrid is also incredibly knowledgeable and facilitated some pretty exciting discussions. What you put into this class is definitely what you get out of it – by doing the readings, participating in conversations, and taking time to appreciate the differences that come together to form the Latin American diaspora within the US, you will not regret taking this class.

TAKE THIS COURSE! If you're at all interested in Black music, this course is for you. The workload was manageable, but always thought–provoking. The materials spanned different genres and eras of Black music. We also went on a few fields that connected our in–class knowledge to primary source materials. Professor B is excellent and has a down–to–earth nature. Excellent class.

This class is fast–paced but very interesting and useful *if you wish to explore the field in greater depth*. Having a background in playing music, or at least being an avid listener, is helpful. Take advantage of sections and the incredible accessibility of the teaching staff!
It’s definitely a good class, but not a lot of feedback so personal motivation and expectation is important. Overall really interesting content!!
worse_comment: Don’t expect to learn anything about producing or writing music in this class. This is a humanities seminar disguised under music because the topic you study is music. But the way you study it is through reading essays, articles, and watching productions through an academic lens
subject: Music

best_comment: If you're in HRO, take Music 107. It's super chill (one reading assignment outside of rehearsal) and you get credit. The readings are interesting, too, and Fed is very lenient about the work. He clearly wants everyone to succeed. 100% a good deal.
worse_comment: There are two sets of readings about the pieces that we played, but other than that, there are no expectations besides showing up to rehearsal!

best_comment: If you are taking jazz band, there's no point in not taking this. The assignments are assigned really late and you are given like three days to do them, but they aren't too difficult. This course is pretty laid back and there's not much to it. Definitely take it if you are already taking jazz band.

This class definitely has a reputation, and you should definitely ask around before you take it. Fed is certainly a unique personality, pedagogically speaking, in the context of Harvard teaching staff –– he can be tough on people, but he's never wrong. For people with a thick skin and a desire to improve, this is a very good thing; for people who want positive feedback or to have a friendly classroom environment, this is not. I was gratified to be personally challenged and fulfilled by the class, but I know that a lot of people have been hurt or bothered in prior years by the course. I do think that everyone with a passing understanding of classical music and a good brain for structure and sound would benefit from the class; no matter your personal idiosyncrasies, there are some practical aspects of how to get certain sounds out of an ensemble that Fed is able to impart. If you want this –– and you can take some very tough personal criticism with a smile –– I'd definitely recommend this class, and I regret that I only was able to take it once.
If you have already taken 51b, you will gain nothing from this course. However, it is an easy way to get theory req out of the way.

This was an awesome class, Andy and Sarah are both fantastic educators and I genuinely believe I learned so much from them. This course is a must–take for anyone who looks to be an educator in the future or just to learn more about disability studies in general. Additionally, the engaged scholarship aspect of the course was phenomenal — taking part in CCV was truly a special experience that I treasured. I had the best time learning to sing and meeting all of the awesome people who we shared the stage with :)

course_title: The Harvard New Music Ensemble STO
best_comment: Take this course to meet Claire Chase in her element. Seriously. This course helped me understand what it means to meet a professor who is a leader in what they do, and who embodies that leadership with a passion that will perfuse the entire ensemble with the desire to find that same spirit. Prof. Chase will never doubt the ability of anyone in the ensemble, and work with them, uplift them, until they feel confident as a performer of New Music. It is rare to take a course with a professor who is so committed to teaching and performance and the same time. Do it to be inspired.

This course was amazing!! I really enjoyed getting to learn about Renaissance performance and culture and learning to play the viola da gamba. Instruction in playing was excellent and made learning a new instrument very accessible and teaching on history and what life was like in the renaissance, particularly in the realm of music was fascinating. This course changed the way I thought about and appreciated music. Both Laura and KvO are the best teachers and their enthusiasm for the viola da gamba made this class so much more fun.
subject: Music

best_comment: Take this course!! This was an amazing, low–stress music class. I had never played contemporary music before (and honestly wasn't even sure if I liked it) and decided to try Music 186 because it seemed interesting to me. I am so, so glad that I took it. It's one of my favorite classes I've ever taken at Harvard. The group classes, workshops, and Throwdowns are incredibly fun and you get to meet awesome music people through them. Throughout the semester, my group spent the time learning one piece and we got to explore it in a way I've never done before. We even had the opportunity to meet the composer of our piece (a perk of contemporary music and also just such an incredible experience)! Jessica and Claire cared deeply about this class and brought an unparalleled enthusiasm for making it the best experience we could have as students. They were receptive to feedback, constructive in their weekly coachings, and so excited to share their love of contemporary music with us. I could not recommend this course more!

Take this course!! This was an amazing, low–stress music class. I had never played contemporary music before (and honestly wasn't even sure if I liked it) and decided to try Music 186 because it seemed interesting to me. I am so, so glad that I took it. It's one of my favorite classes I've ever taken at Harvard. The group classes, workshops, and Throwdowns are incredibly fun and you get to meet awesome music people through them. Throughout the semester, my group spent the time learning one piece and we got to explore it in a way I've never done before. We even had the opportunity to meet the composer of our piece (a perk of contemporary music and also just such an incredible experience)! Jessica and Claire cared deeply about this class and brought an unparalleled enthusiasm for making it the best experience we could have as students. They were receptive to feedback, constructive in their weekly coachings, and so excited to share their love of contemporary music with us. I could not recommend this course more!

course_title: Composer-Performers of the African Diaspora LEC
best_comment: This is a really interesting course. My conception of what music is expanded, and I gained so many insights about genre and other musical topics from our discussions. Professors Terry and Iyer are the best, and you'd be lucky to learn from them.

course_title: Composer-Performers of the African Diaspora LEC
best_comment: This is a really interesting course. My conception of what music is expanded, and I gained so many insights about genre and other musical topics from our discussions. Professors Terry and Iyer are the best, and you'd be lucky to learn from them.

If you're a musician period, JOIN THE CLASS. It's a great opportunity to meet new people and collaborate. Close friendships are often formed through music, and that was definitely the case for me. You get to pick which piece you play for the class and the performance classes are spaced out nicely. Everyone only performs once. IT'S A GREAT CLASS. Highly recommend.
subject: Music

best_comment: If you're a musician period, JOIN THE CLASS. It's a great opportunity to meet new people and collaborate. Close friendships are often formed through music, and that was definitely the case for me. You get to pick which piece you play for the class and the performance classes are spaced out nicely. Everyone only performs once. IT'S A GREAT CLASS. Highly recommend.
subject: Music

best_comment: If you're a musician period, JOIN THE CLASS. It's a great opportunity to meet new people and collaborate. Close friendships are often formed through music, and that was definitely the case for me. You get to pick which piece you play for the class and the performance classes are spaced out nicely. Everyone only performs once. IT'S A GREAT CLASS. Highly recommend.
subject: Music

best_comment: If you're a musician period, JOIN THE CLASS. It's a great opportunity to meet new people and collaborate. Close friendships are often formed through music, and that was definitely the case for me. You get to pick which piece you play for the class and the performance classes are spaced out nicely. Everyone only performs once. IT'S A GREAT CLASS. Highly recommend.
subject: Music

course_title: Topics in Music from 1900 - Present SEM
best_comment: You should absolutely take this class! Professor Shreffler is incredible—she is super available to discuss any questions and she's very supportive of student interests. The course materials were very broad, ranging from the question of whether Fanny Mendelssohn was suppressed by the men in her life to a discussion on the representation of human bodies in Laurie Anderson's "O Superman." You have a chance to learn about a huge variety of composers, styles, and time periods. You also have a lot of flexibility in terms of what you want to do for assignments and what you want to focus on during class discussions.
subject: Music

best_comment: I strongly suggest taking this course! Prof. Abbate is one of the foremost opera scholars in the world and she truly enjoys teaching and getting students involved with the materials.

This is a really excellent class. Prof. Madrid is a phenomenal seminar leader and assigns fascinating, albeit challenging, readings which inevitably lead to stimulating discussions. He approaches the material with a serious but open mind and a strong sense of humour. The result is a class environment in which everybody is encouraged and keen to share, and in which the professor feels as much a participant as the students. If you are interested in histories of the archive, historiographical and phenomenological approaches to music and sound art, or decolonial thinking more broadly, this is an excellent class for you (even if you are not rooted in the Music Department).
subject: Music

course_title: Sonic Mapping and the Black Experience SEM
best_comment: I strongly recommend studying with Professor Jackson!!!! You will be empowered, your mind will be opened, you will be inspired!!!
worse_comment: A unique opportunity to learn and grow by looking within, and breaking down boundaries long imposed on scholarship by racist and racializing structural conditions.

best_comment: I'm delighted this course was offered, and I hope it continues being offered. Like the lands and people from which it sprang, the Albanian language is rich, fascinating, complicated, and a rewarding subject of study. With so few resources existing for English speakers to learn Albanian in a formal setting, this course turbo–charged my self–directed efforts. Through the class discussions and materials, and because I was inspired to delve still deeper in my own explorations, my Albanian is so much better than it was before the semester started, with the greatest improvements wrought in my ability to speak in complete sentences out loud. The dream is that continued speaking opportunities will result in a smoother flow with less buffering time and fewer mistakes.

course_title: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament 1: Pentateuch and Former Prophets 001
best_comment: As an Econ concentrator, I took the class originally to fulfill a requirement for graduation. This class sparked something in me, though. I've always been a social science type of kid, but it made me genuinely find a calling in the humanities. This class combines history, literature, and religion in the most perfect way imaginable. I have a much much more appreciation for the Bible, even as an ardent nonbeliever. My preconceived notions about the infantile nature of scripture were challenged. I had my interpretations and biases, as a result of the context that we live in and I was raised in, challenged. I came to appreciate the truth of nuance. It truly, truly, was a transformative experience. The expectations of the course are very straightforward and set in the syllabus. The exams are quite easy (I ended up with over a 100 in the class), and Professor Teeter provides a study guide that lets you know specifically what to study. The course does a good job of catering to individuals who have no prior experience with the Bible and those for whom the text is familiar literature. You learn a LOT in a very short period.Also, Professor Teeter and Byron are two of the nicest faculty members at Harvard that I have ever met. Professor Teeter exudes this positive energy and contagious excitement about the content. Byron's a grading machine, getting papers and exams back to you sometimes within the same day. His comments were always kind and constructive. Genuinely wonderful people. Get to know them, ask questions, go to office hours, and think about how you can apply the takeaways from class to your own life. I can't wait to take the second half of the course.

Ustadha Dana is one of the most kind and effective instructors I have had this semester. This class will admittedly require a decent amount of work, especially near the middle of the semester when it feels like you are getting 20 new vocabulary words thrown at you every day, but it is pretty worth it. This class will help you grow your Arabic language skills from near–nonexistent to more than you would believe.  If you are interested in Arabic, I'd recommend giving this class a shot.

definitely not the kind of class you can cruise by in, but also not a just keeping you busy for no reason. If you keep up with the work it really does make a difference in your language acquisition and can be pretty entertaining as well. If you can take it at a time with fewer students that is the ideal because you can really engage in class, but regardless, I highly recommend taking advantage of class time to ask questions and practice speaking. Loved the experience and can't wait to take more arabic :)

Take this class if you want an introduction to learning Arabic! It is well structured and easy to follow/not too difficult for first–time language learners. Although the difficulty levels are subject to each person's abilities, there is significant support and structure provided through the class to help you succeed and the professors are pretty flexible and lenient when it comes to grades. The class is really focused on helping you master the language and not merely to get a good grade so I'd highly recommend it!

If you are someone who wants to learn Arabic, this class will teach you so much in such a short amount of time. I am honestly surprised with my learning and ability to understand. That being said, you need to stay on top of your assignments. There are numerous drills per hw to be completed. Sometimes I feel like it can be a bit much, but honestly, if your goal is purely to learn Arabic, you will learn a lot, even if you slack on the daily work. If you are someone who is good with staying on top of daily work, then you will be golden. Section is very fun and you quickly look forward to attending class everyday.

Great class. Not too hard or too easy, all assignments perfectly reflect what you've learned and are prepared to do. Homework every day is a lot but necessary to keep improving. You learn more dialect in this class, which is great, take advantage of this opportunity and don't choose to learn the bare minimum or you'll regret it. Fantastic teacher who really cares about the class and his students.

Dana Malhas is the BEST LANGUAGE TEACHER. I would literally do anything for her. She genuinely cares about her students and holds us to high standards, and her years of experience are well–used to keep us engaged. Huge difference between taking classes with other teachers and taking Arabic from her. ***If you are thinking of studying abroad in Jordan, this class with her is a MUST, it is the only class where you will really gain an understanding of speaking and dialect as you will hear in Jordan. I took just first year Arabic and was able to go to Amman for the summer and feel very comfortable speaking.

This class is still just as challenging as previous years, but the small class size really makes it worth it; it helps to participate better and learn much quicker. Ustaadh Amr Madi is also really kind and encouraging, all the while still pushing everyone to do their best in class. Overall, a good class to take if you want to learn a lot more vocabulary, keep practicing speaking and writing, and learn about more cultural and religious traditions and social movements in the Arab world (although the focus is definitely on Egypt and the Levant).
subject: Arabic

course_title: Advanced Modern Arabic Bridge: Language, Literature, and Culture I 001
best_comment: Arabic 241 is a great course. You will find that you need to be more self driven in certain aspects of your language learning, like vocabulary focus and learning/reviewing new grammar forms, as they are only occasionally tested on homework and there are few if any tests. Definitely take it though, Nader is awesome, I had a great time and learned a ton!

course_title: Introduction to Islamic Philosophy and Theology: The Classical and Medieval period 001
best_comment: This is a great course. I came to it as a junior studying philosophy + religion and got a ton out of it without ever feeling that it caused stress—the course is rigorous and you will be forced to engage (which I think is always a good thing) but you will be able to do so regardless of your ability or familiarity with the discipline or the tradition.  Professor El–Rouayheb is an excellent lecturer and a very kind person.  I'd recommend this course if you're looking to acquire a broad and wide–ranging familiarity with the major issues and trends in classical and medieval Islamic thought, as well as being exposed first–hand to most of the great thinkers that fall under this category.
best_gem_comment: This is a fantastic course, that I could not recommend more highly. If you are interested in philosophy or history, you should take this course. I will note that this is a course on Islamic philosophy, not Islamic law or Islamic history, and so if you are interested in political developments or jurisprudence, then this will not really focus on those topics. Prof. El–Rouayheb is an absolute gem of a person, hilarious and witty and of course extremely intelligent.

best_comment: Take this class! Although it is pretty challenging just by the nature of Hebrew as someone who didn't speak it at all and a native English speaker, Ran made it super approachable and fun! There is a decent amount of homework, but it is understandable in its use––it always related to and reenforced the class material. It is super easy to get feedback and extra help from Ran or the TFs, they really went above and beyond to help. You also get to learn some good music, and the readings in class are great at showing how much we learn very quickly. Overall, this class is great, you learn so much in such a short time!
subject: Modern Hebrew

course_title: The Modern Middle East, Real and Imagined: An Introduction 001
best_comment: This is an amazing course. I am a biology concentrator and had no background in the topic, but learned more than I have in most of my classes here. Professor Zeghal and Conor are amazing at what they do, and the material is very interesting and relevant. There is a decent amount of reading each week but it is not unmanageable by any means, and there is a quiz most weeks, but they are short and straightforward. One of the best parts of this class was how much feedback I got on each quiz and assignment from Conor, who was probably the most helpful TF that I have had at Harvard so far. So, if you need a divisional distribution or want to learn about the subject, I super highly recommend this class.
worse_comment: I took this course because I had to, but I'm not sure I would recommend it if someone is thinking to take it for an elective. The weekly quizzes are an unnecessary stress sometimes and they aren't graded that easily.  The professor and tf are very knowledgeable and accessible, but sometimes the way the information is presented feels not that engaged.

course_title: Shi’a Islam and Politics in the Middle East 001
best_comment: If you are interested in Islam, take this class. Good intro to Shi'a Islam and as someone who is not Muslim, I found it very illuminating to learn more about the origins and current state of Shi'a Islam. Professor Sagha is super knowledgeable and was able to provide a super detailed answer to every question someone asked which was just so cool. Overall, would definitely recommend as I think most people would learn a lot.
subject: Modern Middle East
course_title_2024: Shi’a Islam and Politics in the Middle East

course_title: History of Modern Iran and Turkey 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! I had such a great experience. It’s very in–depth and goes over lots of really cool content from both Iran and Turkey, but it’s also not overly demanding (no in–person exams, lots of support throughout the semester, interactive and engaging lectures, etc). The curriculum covers a really wide range of content that I really enjoyed, and I especially learned about issues in greater depth from the midterm and final writing projects. Wonderful course overall—I ended feeling like I really learned a lot which feels super satisfying!

course_title: The History of the Book: Using Harvard's Greatest Treasures to Study the Material Text 001
best_comment: This class is easily the best class I have taken at Harvard. If you have a chance to take it you absolutely should, regardless of background and prior experience. It has changed my perspective on not just books, but the history and development of modern life. Professor Stern is an incredible professor and puts so much time each week into curating an amazing selection of books, readings, and lectures.Every week you get to spend time in Houghton looking at some of the most pivotal and incredible scrolls/manuscripts/books from throughout history (and you're actually allowed to flip through them and examine as you wish!). The assignments are manageable and well thought through, allowing you to deepen your knowledge and engagement with the material. This year we had weekly readings, weekly short reading responses (completion–based), and two papers at the middle and end points of the semester. The class was held in different locations each week including the Divinity School, the Law School, Dana Palmer, and more. As well as giving you a great opportunity to explore the libraries of Harvard, it means the breadth of material on offer is vast. There are also really cool extra sessions such as the printing workshop where we learnt to use a printing press and a visit the the book restoration building where we learnt how books were bound. Additionally, we were able to speak to so many cool guest speakers and auditors from a whole range of different backgrounds.A nice extra bonus of this class is learning how to navigate and make the most of the Harvard libraries. Whether you are hoping to do some research/thesis or just want to make the most of everything the Harvard collection's have to offer, this course helps you build great relationships with librarians and learn how to make the most out of all the resources on offer. Truly an incredible course

Please take this class! It is definitely super fair in terms of work (definitely moreso than other language classes) and you will definitely actually come out learning something entirely new. You do not need experience to take this course, and it is entirely beginner friendly. Prof. Ebrahimian is also the sweetest and truly cares about each student individually.
subject: Persian

best_comment: A phenomenal course –– gives you the tools to access a beautiful body of literature and introduces you to a new perspective of processing and engaging with the world.
It is a fun and very useful language to learn!
subject: Turkish

best_comment: This course is fantastic. There is a lot of material, but Jeff and Katie teach it incredibly well. I found section to be really helpful in ensuring my understanding as well, and I felt like the material is presented in a really accessible way. I loved having the guest speakers come in each week, and the demonstrations we did during workshops were always great and a lot of fun. As a first–year who took this course because I want to concentrate in neuro, I highly recommend it. My academic advisor cautioned me before taking it as mostly sophomores take it, but it was so worth it and I felt like I was able to be really successful. If you want to take it, definitely take it! Such an interesting course, the PSETs and assignments are so reasonable, and I feel like I learned a lot.
worse_comment: I loved Neuro80!!! I highly recommend it, one of the most interesting classes I've taken at Harvard. Since the first half of the class really focuses on the neuron, it would be helpful to come in with a biology background, but it's absolutely not necessary. I enjoyed the flipped classroom format – I watched all the video lectures then only went in–person for the Thursday workshop, which reviews all the material. If you don't like flipped classroom, you might not like this class, but the Thursday workshop and Katie's  lecture notes are very thorough reviews of the week's material. PSETs are straight–forward, you can work on those in office hours.
best_gem_comment: Take the class!!! It's honestly SUCH a gem. The content is super interesting, the psets aren't too bad (and you can do them at Sunday Problem Set Solving hours with TFs), and the staff are all so supportive.

best_comment: This course is fantastic. There is a lot of material, but Jeff and Katie teach it incredibly well. I found section to be really helpful in ensuring my understanding as well, and I felt like the material is presented in a really accessible way. I loved having the guest speakers come in each week, and the demonstrations we did during workshops were always great and a lot of fun. As a first–year who took this course because I want to concentrate in neuro, I highly recommend it. My academic advisor cautioned me before taking it as mostly sophomores take it, but it was so worth it and I felt like I was able to be really successful. If you want to take it, definitely take it! Such an interesting course, the PSETs and assignments are so reasonable, and I feel like I learned a lot.

Since the first half of the class really focuses on the neuron, it would be helpful to come in with a biology background, but it's absolutely not necessary. I enjoyed the flipped classroom format – I watched all the video lectures then only went in–person for the Thursday workshop, which reviews all the material. If you don't like flipped classroom, you might not like this class, but the Thursday workshop and Katie's  lecture notes are very thorough reviews of the week's material. PSETs are straight–forward, you can work on those in office hours.
best_gem_comment: Take the class!!! It's honestly SUCH a gem. The content is super interesting, the psets aren't too bad (and you can do them at Sunday Problem Set Solving hours with TFs), and the staff are all so supportive.

best_comment: Make sure you have a good relationship with your P.I. and mentor. Otherwise, it's a good litmus test to see if you want to thesis or pursue research post–grad and an overall fun experience!
worse_comment: I learned how to problem–solve and how to run experiments more independently and efficiently. This course just teaches you how to be a scientist and you can apply these skills to a life of science or life in general. However, it should be noted that your experience is heavily dependent on your lab director/principal investigator or mentor. Try to find a mentor/PI BEFORE applying for this course so that you don't get paired with some random PI who might ruin your experience.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: Make sure you have a good relationship with your P.I. and mentor. Otherwise, it's a good litmus test to see if you want to thesis or pursue research post–grad and an overall fun experience!
worse_comment: I learned how to problem–solve and how to run experiments more independently and efficiently. This course just teaches you how to be a scientist and you can apply these skills to a life of science or life in general. However, it should be noted that your experience is heavily dependent on your lab director/principal investigator or mentor. Try to find a mentor/PI BEFORE applying for this course so that you don't get paired with some random PI who might ruin your experience.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

course_title: Sleep Talk: Unraveling the Mystery of Sleep 001
best_comment: Super awesome course. Tony is a chill guy. Every class is fun. You will enjoy yourself I promise

course_title: Sleep Talk: Unraveling the Mystery of Sleep 001
best_comment: Super awesome course. Tony is a chill guy. Every class is fun. You will enjoy yourself I promise

course_title: Sleep Talk: Unraveling the Mystery of Sleep 001
best_comment: Super awesome course. Tony is a chill guy. Every class is fun. You will enjoy yourself I promise

course_title: The Neuroscience of Learning and Memory 001
best_comment: This is a GREAT course and super reasonable in terms of workload. Vincent really cares about all his students' understanding the material and feeling confident with what we are learning. Highly recommend: really interesting material + not a stressful course.

course_title: The Neuroscience of Learning and Memory 001
best_comment: This is a GREAT course and super reasonable in terms of workload. Vincent really cares about all his students' understanding the material and feeling confident with what we are learning. Highly recommend: really interesting material + not a stressful course.

course_title: The Neuroscience of Learning and Memory 001
best_comment: This is a GREAT course and super reasonable in terms of workload. Vincent really cares about all his students' understanding the material and feeling confident with what we are learning. Highly recommend: really interesting material + not a stressful course.

course_title: Neurobiology of Emotion and Mood Disorders 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! It is super fun and maneagable. While the pre–quizzes and post–quizzes seems like a lot, it is super chill! The questions are very straightforward and just ensure that you are grasping some of the big picture ideas. Don't even worry about the final exam – it will be the quickest exam of your life :)The content is super fascinating as you get to learn about the overall neurobio that dictate emotions such as love and depression. The lectures in class are very brief and always left me longing for more exploration! You also learn how to make scientific presentations and how to analyze papers with a critical lens. Not only is Alen such an amazing lecture, but he is also such a remarkable person. It is so inspiring to hear about his lived experiences and how much he loves the work he does (officially and personally). You definitely won't regret taking the class!

course_title: Neurobiology of Emotion and Mood Disorders 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! It is super fun and maneagable. While the pre–quizzes and post–quizzes seems like a lot, it is super chill! The questions are very straightforward and just ensure that you are grasping some of the big picture ideas. Don't even worry about the final exam – it will be the quickest exam of your life :)The content is super fascinating as you get to learn about the overall neurobio that dictate emotions such as love and depression. The lectures in class are very brief and always left me longing for more exploration! You also learn how to make scientific presentations and how to analyze papers with a critical lens. Not only is Alen such an amazing lecture, but he is also such a remarkable person. It is so inspiring to hear about his lived experiences and how much he loves the work he does (officially and personally). You definitely won't regret taking the class!

course_title: Neurobiology of Emotion and Mood Disorders 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! It is super fun and maneagable. While the pre–quizzes and post–quizzes seems like a lot, it is super chill! The questions are very straightforward and just ensure that you are grasping some of the big picture ideas. Don't even worry about the final exam – it will be the quickest exam of your life :)The content is super fascinating as you get to learn about the overall neurobio that dictate emotions such as love and depression. The lectures in class are very brief and always left me longing for more exploration! You also learn how to make scientific presentations and how to analyze papers with a critical lens. Very engaging and rewarding course! I highly recommend. I learned a lot, maybe the most from any of the classes I've taken so far (as a senior) in terms of how to read and understand research.

best_comment: Saad is amazing. I love him. You will also love him. Course content is very interesting and very well–explained. You’ll walk out of this course a better scientist and a better observer of science.

This class is very interesting, and Dr. Beach is great! The discussions are generally pretty conversational and we tend to get into the nitty gritty of not just what the paper is showing, but also how it is showing it (experiments and figures), whether we're convinced, and what we think could be improved. Dr. Beach knows a ton about auditory cognition, and is great at facilitating discussion. Because the class is so low commitment I didn't feel as immersed in the content as I often do for classes, but that's just a tradeoff with the time commitment, and I still learned a lot.

I really enjoyed this course, especially the mix of lecture and discussion that entailed our weekly meetings. I appreciated the opportunity to gain relevant background knowledge on the neuropharmacology of pain and to apply that knowledge to reading and analyzing papers and exploring a topic of interest in the field in the form of a final paper. Definitely recommend taking this class!

course_title: Visual Recognition: Computational and Biophysical Perspective 001
best_comment: Really cool readings and engaging lectures by Prof. Kreiman! Dianna makes the paper discussion portion of the class more fun . The class is relatively chill, so it would pair with a challenging schedule if you have other really heavy courses. I really liked the readings, and highly recommend the class if you're interested in vision especially its computational aspect
worse_comment: Take this class if you want to read some cool papers and bolster your visual system/ML understanding. The class did seem to be a lot of busywork and not as interesting as I'd hoped when I signed up. Not sure I'd recommend since it wasn't super interesting, the grading was a bit arbitrary/unclear sometimes, but still it was overall fairly chill.

best_comment: THIS WAS MY FAVORITE PREMED CLASS, AND YOU SHOULD 100% TAKE THIS FOR 2ND SEMESTER BIO IF YOU'RE PREMED. Here's why:1. The material is the most clinically relevant out of any class I've taken at Harvard. Anatomy and physiology is fascinating, and every lecture in this course is highly relevant to what we'll learn in medical school and in our future jobs as doctors. There's a ton of material, but looking back on it I learned so much in this course and I am really grateful for all of the material. 2. The teaching staff is great. Lieberman and Lauder are gems of lecturers, each of them possessing the rare combination of being extremely knowledgable in their fields and being able to communicate that knowledge in an engaging manner. Labs were a fascinating complement to the lecture material, and I really felt like not a single minute of my time in this class was wasted.3. This course is challenging, but only in the quantity of the material. Each individual lecture is presented in a way that's easy to understand when you study it for a little bit, and lab practicals always feel a little insurmountable when you start studying but as soon as you go over the material a couple of times it's easy to study and master (most people do very very well on them). Exams are difficult, I won't lie, but each individual question is usually a very fair way of assessing your knowledge of the material it's asking about – it's just hard to study alllll of the material that will be on each exam. But there's plenty of support via OH and study questions and whatnot, so if you put in the time that's necessary to study all of it there's no reason you can't get an A in this class.Tl;dr Super rewarding fascinating class that's taught well and you can definitely succeed in it; it's just going to take some time invested but it's totally worth it and I promise it's a better option than any other 2nd semester premed bio class.
worse_comment: TOTALLY take this course if you are invested in learning the material but know that this course will be your most difficult and highest pressure course as there are not many buffers for your exam scores (and you need to be extremely prepared for the exams)
best_gem_comment: This course is so so interesting, I loved the content, but be warned that this is anything but a gem. You learn about almost every system in the body in a single semester in great detail and are tested on all of it. The lab practicals really weren't bad, and were super useful for reinforcing the content. As for the exams, if you think you're prepared, study more. Like one question, I had to draw and label a neuron to dentrite communication. I drew all of it and even added Calcium ion channels for funsies. I got two points off because I didn't draw an arrow in the direction of transmission – it's just very specific and make sure to follow the directions completely.

best_comment: This course was a great overview of biodiversity. The progression of the course was logical, the variety of lecturers kept class engaging, section was hands on and run very efficiently, assignments were often enjoyable and felt low stakes, allowing students to focus mainly on learning the content and enjoying the class, rather than cramming for high stakes exams. Materials provided were excellent for the demands of the course. Assignments were reasonable, left much room for creativity, and encouraged engagement not just with the content of the course but the broader aims of the course. Feedback was usually good and comprehensive. Section was run incredibly efficiently and had a great mix of lab work and content review. This is a great course to take for anyone with an interest in biology at all scales, and doesn't require any extensive background other than the listed recommended courses.
worse_comment: This class is very accessible. The labs are simple and are working to build lab skills and you are given plenty of time to do assignments but go to office hours to complete them. There are NO EXAMS (but may change so check the syllabus). Concentrate in Integrative, if you don't remember that I told you so

best_comment: Content:– I've seen some comments suggesting this class is just like LS1B, but I have to respectfully disagree. This course dives deeper, giving us a richer understanding. We're encouraged to see the bigger picture, not just remember details. This really makes the class stand out.Teaching:– Robin is fantastic! Her enthusiasm and passion for teaching are just infectious. She's also super approachable and always ready to help.– Dan is also great. He's written a lot of the genetics textbooks you might have encountered. Although his teaching style reflects his vast experience/age, sometimes it seems a bit confusingAssignments:– The assignments here are really well–balanced – challenging but not too time–consuming or confusing.– Weekly problem sets are graded on submission, which honestly makes the class more enjoyable. And going to office hours really helps to get them done quickly.– The exams are mostly based on class or problem set problems, keeping the course interesting and engaging. It's nice how everything ties together.
worse_comment: This course has great formatting with appropriate levels of work each week. The problem sets are completion based, which is really appreciated. As it currently exists, I have a difficult time recommending this without reservations. The lectures do not use slides or much visual assistance and are often very difficult to process and understand. Feedback we gave related to this issue was not incorporated, which is a shame. If you do not have a genetics background, I suspect that lecture would be almost impossible to understand (though you could learn outside of class, I suppose). Lectures, particularly with Professor Hartl, were very difficult to understand and *I do* have familiarity with genetics. That being said, I was thankful for the completion based problem sets and take home exams which generally reflected the practice problems.
best_gem_comment: Can be a gem if you put effort in and great takeaway lessons
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: Andrew Berry is just awesome. Even though this is a hard class, he makes every lecture super engaging and entertaining. Because he was so enthusiastic for the subject matter, I became more interested in it and grew to appreciate many of the topics taught within the course. BE PREPARED TO WORKKKKKK FOR THOSE MIDTERMS. 3 midterms...just get ready. After not doing well on the first one, Andrew Berry helped me in understanding what I got wrong and made me feel better about the next 2 exams, and I ended up doing better on those. The 3 psets are mostly chill, and section really helps you in understanding the course material and section readings. Use the term paper to write about something you're really interested in, and you'll have an enjoyable end to the course!! Overall, I'd recommend for anyone considering this class!
worse_comment: Exams are relatively difficult, problem sets not as difficult. Would recommend studying carefully for exams and focus on memorizing if possible as the course goes along

best_comment: My thoughts on OEB 55 are many and complicated. I’ll start by saying I really have learned a lot of ecology in this class. I don’t know if I’d pursue many of the topics we covered further, but it was really helpful in gaining some intuition for how the world around us functions. The field trips were really fun, as was getting to know the TFs and their research. If you’re interested in pursuing ecological field work, it’s a great class to start getting an idea of some quantitative methods and conceptual understanding of ecological processes.Unfortunately, communication was a big weakness. Due dates were frequently adjusted at the last minute, it took a long time for field trip data to be posted (which is fine, but it would be great to know when to expect it if there are delays!) Some of the lectures also felt poorly–paced and weren’t very thorough. I think that in general, a lot of this material requires a very deep conceptual understanding to get an intuition for how it can be applied (on field trip reports, psets, exams, etc) and I didn’t feel like I was getting that understanding from lecture. Office hours were VERY helpful–Evan and Rhemi were both amazing resources.The workload is quite backloaded, especially if you don’t go on the first field trip. This isn’t necessarily a bad thing as long as you plan for it, but definitely made some weekends pretty rough. I put down 4 hours/week in the Q, but that ends up being distributed as a few 1–hour weeks, a few 3–hour weeks, and like two 15–hour weeks. I had almost no out–of–class work for the first half of the semester, but in the second half was juggling two psets, two field reports, and a final (including a pset and a field report due during reading week. I know that’s just how the timing worked out, but still. Uncool.) If you don’t have experience working with data/writing longform scientific reports, expect to spend 10+ hours on the field reports. (Which is to say, don’t be like me and take this before stat/other intro classes. Bad idea.)On the whole, I do wish I’d taken something else, but I’m still not so regretful that I did 55. I learned a lot in this class that doesn’t get taught in other courses, and have already had opportunities to apply it outside of school. Still, if you’re looking to clear the ESPP requirement I would look into OEB 65 instead (I haven’t taken it, but know people like it).
worse_comment: This course was interesting but very disorganized. The professors seem to be operating on a neither transparent nor comprehensible schedule. This results in messy lectures, unclear test expectations, and unnecessarily difficult assignments. A lot of this course does depend on you having a background in statistics and calculus. The actual material itself is sometimes engaging but this is not a fun class by any means. The field trips were also physically tough and disorganized as well, which made the experience less than ideal.
