best_comment: This course is a great survey of many major organ systems from both a morphological and developmental perspective. At times, the content can feel a bit rushed and the exams cover a lot of material, but it's super interesting. There is definitely a vertebrate bias (as there is with most of the scientific literature), but I appreciated that we considered material from both the vertebrate and Drosophila perspective. The first half of the course was very well–organized and taught, with super cool labs, but the organization of lectures and material is a little more muddled in the second half (mostly because you are looking at systems where the line between morphology and development is a lot less clear). I would definitely recommend this class for anyone who is interested in how animals!
worse_comment: If you are pre–med and trying to take a class to fulfill a pre–med requirement, OEB58 might be enticing but I would think twice about whether or not it's the best choice for you just to fulfill the requirement. Overall, I think it is a good class and I definitely learned a lot about animals and organ systems, but I think I would've preferred LS2 instead of this class (but with no hate to OEB58). OEB58 can be extremely challenging if you haven't taken biology in a while, especially if you have no interactions with animal biology. The class has no psets, only weekly lecture, lab, and section, which is nice until the midterm and final come around. There are no practice exams or practice problems to help prepare for the exam, so you really just have to study and memorize everything for the exams. The exams are divided into two parts and are in–class, and they are SO long. Time is of the essence, and it's extremely difficult to keep track of time while also going through each question with enough detail. All in all, OEB58 was, by standard, a good class but difficult. Make sure you know what you're getting into before taking this class.

best_comment: This course is a great survey of many major organ systems from both a morphological and developmental perspective. At times, the content can feel a bit rushed and the exams cover a lot of material, but it's super interesting. There is definitely a vertebrate bias (as there is with most of the scientific literature), but I appreciated that we considered material from both the vertebrate and Drosophila perspective. The first half of the course was very well–organized and taught, with super cool labs, but the organization of lectures and material is a little more muddled in the second half (mostly because you are looking at systems where the line between morphology and development is a lot less clear). I would definitely recommend this class for anyone who is interested in how animals!
worse_comment: If you are pre–med and trying to take a class to fulfill a pre–med requirement, OEB58 might be enticing but I would think twice about whether or not it's the best choice for you just to fulfill the requirement. Overall, I think it is a good class and I definitely learned a lot about animals and organ systems, but I think I would've preferred LS2 instead of this class (but with no hate to OEB58). OEB58 can be extremely challenging if you haven't taken biology in a while, especially if you have no interactions with animal biology. The class has no psets, only weekly lecture, lab, and section, which is nice until the midterm and final come around. There are no practice exams or practice problems to help prepare for the exam, so you really just have to study and memorize everything for the exams. The exams are divided into two parts and are in–class, and they are SO long. Time is of the essence, and it's extremely difficult to keep track of time while also going through each question with enough detail. All in all, OEB58 was, by standard, a good class but difficult. Make sure you know what you're getting into before taking this class.

course_title: The Mouse in Science and Society 001
best_comment: ***TAKE THIS COURSE. Even if you aren't into science, mice are such an important part of our daily lives (as pests, as lab animals, in culture). Was super interesting without being too much work, and the freedom to pick almost any mouse related topic for the final presentation was awesome. Prof PC is so enthusiastic, knowledgeable, a great lecturer, and always made class super fun.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol
course_title_2024: The Mouse in Science and Society

best_comment: I would highly recommend this course, especially if you really enjoyed OEB 52! Dr. Kramer is an amazing professor and cares so deeply about each of her students. The assignments include two exams (one on the first half of material, another on the second half) and a final paper. While the course covers a lot of content and different genetic pathways, the exams are fair and reflective of the core concepts. Definitely take this course if you are interested in plant biology and want a more in–depth understanding of plant development!
worse_comment: Do not take this class unless you are very interested in plant developmental biology. It's a very deep dive into the field and you are expected to memorize a lot of terminology and intricate details about every process. The midterms are not forgiving and the final paper is quite difficult. The professor has a hard time relating to the students in terms of the difficulty of the material. It's also hard to know what is going to be on the exam and what's not.

best_comment: This is a great class to truly learn about how plants respond to climate change and the relationship between plants, light, water, and temperature. Although some of the material is challenging, it is very worth it to understand how climate change will impact plants in the future. Missy is a great instructor, and if you ask for help she will always respond and explain in an engaging way.
worse_comment: I have never taken a more disorganized class at Harvard. The professor prepares inadequate slides, homework grading seems to be completely random, and TFs don't know what's happening overall. 2.45 hour lecture is divided in half, and the second half is useless, boring in class activities. The only good part is that Missy is teaching it and you get to meet her. Otherwise an awful, scary experience in terms of your grades.

best_comment: This class is so interesting and, if you are coming in with some basic evolution and genetics, will change your perspective on genomes and evolution. The course staff are so helpful and willing to answer questions, and the class is usually pretty small so it's a good opportunity to form relationships with your peers. Make sure that you are thorough in your coverage of lecture content when studying for exams – sometimes, concepts that were mentioned briefly will come up.
worse_comment: This course is highly disorganized. Scott is enthusiastic about the subject, but doesn't know how to follow the syllabus and create a realistic timeline for assignments and projects. The TFs have absolutely no idea what they're doing, and half the time they respond to questions with "I have no clue."

course_title: Experimental Design and Statistics for Ecology 001
best_comment: It's a great class and a must–take if you're interested in doing research into ecology/biology. It's super helpful for experimental design, set up, thinking about your questions, hypotheses, etc. Also it's great for learning the statistics. However, the statistics can become quite hard at some point and some familiarity with statistics might be helpful. Furthermore, this class is a LOT of work. Especially around midterms and finals. Ben is also a great teacher. He's very kind, knowledgeable and always happy to help. truly an amazing class.
worse_comment: Take it if you struggle with coding or statistical analysis! If you have data and dont know what to do with it... this is the course for you!

best_comment: I think this class is good if you are looking for an upper–level OEB class that is not super–focused on a certain group of organisms. It is neuro–heavy and pretty broad in scope as far as OEB is concerned. The workload is not too much and the exams were very fair, they did not have anything you haven't seen before but still needed to be studied for.  I really enjoyed this class and I would say unless you really do not like neuro concepts this is a good upper–level OEB class to take.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: I really recommend taking this class if you are interested in entomology!It teaches you basic insect anatomy, and you learn to identify main insect orders and families.  There is no final for the class, and instead you submit an insect collection. The collection does take up a lot of time, but it's really fun and a good break from other academic work. (It forces you to go outside to catch the bugs, and pinning the bugs is fun if you like arts and crafts). The collection is graded mainly based on how diverse it is, and how many insect orders/families you have. I STRONGLY recommend just catching as many insects as possible at the beginning of the semester, when they're still around. If you swipe your net at grass you'll get a lot of small things and there'll be a lot of stuff in there! The beating sheet will also get you a lot of bugs.Also, the class is totally doable as a freshman! And you make friends who also like insects it's really fun :)
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

course_title: Topics in Organismic and Evolutionary Biology 001
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol
course_title_2024: Topics in Organismic and Evolutionary Biology

best_comment: Take this course. It is so rewarding and fun. Professor Nickel is an amazing professor and Justin is an amazing TF. If you like riddles or logic puzzles from when you were younger, this class will be so fun to you and you won't feel like you are doing work for the class but just having fun solving problems. There is so much support from Professor Nickel and Justin and there is so much room for success. It will completely change the way you approach other essay writing and language. Although you will have to put the time into this class to be successful, it is so worth it and doesn't feel like work at all.
worse_comment: The course is difficult, especially if you do not have a math–y background and know how to apply the rules to solve the proofs. I attended many of the study sessions to complete the problem sets, as, otherwise, I could not finish them on my own. I would not recommend taking this course for leisure.
subject: Philosophy

course_title: Introduction to Ancient Greek and Roman Philosophy 001
best_comment: This is an awesome course.  After closely reading classic texts by Aristotle, Plato, Seneca and the like, I have a better sense of my own motivations, desires, and what defines a "good" life. I find myself referring back to these ancient schools of thought in my own everyday life. My philosophical thinking is deeper and much better informed. Professor Noe is lovely; an engaging lecturer, very approachable, and very funny. The essay topics were super interesting (e.g., should our decision making be motivated by pleasure?)––– although I wish the essays themselves were grades less on style and more on ideas. You should most definitely take the class. Trust me, you will enjoy it!
subject: Philosophy
course_title_2024: Introduction to Ancient Greek and Roman Philosophy

course_title: Morality and the Good Life: An Introduction to Ethics 001
best_comment: Though I believe this course was a good introduction to ethics, it was not exactly what I expected going into the course. I had believed there would be a larger applied component where we analyzed real life incidents from a morality perspective, but it was more theoretical than I would've hoped. Going into this course, go to office hours and engage in section because course staff actually want you to succeed. Lectures were slightly monotone, but they do make the abstract ideas in the texts much easier to digest. I would not say this course is the best introduction to philosophy, but it is a very comprehensive overview of ethics.
worse_comment: This is certainly not an easy A, and you will not understand why you get the grades you get.

best_comment: OVERALL:I liked it. Seth is really, really knowledgeable. He clearly knows the readings like the back of his hand and has all sorts of great anecdotes around the history of philosophy. He's so nice and brings a TON of enthusiasm to the lectures. The readings were excessive, but the papers were really cool to write. Most of the class felt like passive learning, though.FOR PEOPLE WHO HAVE TAKEN OR ARE LOOKING AT THE HAPPINESS GENED:If you took Happiness, don't take this; it's pretty redundant. Also, if you're choosing between this class and Happiness, take Happiness, which presents more ways to digest the material and has more engaging lectures. The Happiness readings are better, and there's a decent amount of active learning.
worse_comment: This course was effective in introducing fundamental philosophers but failed to delve deeply into any specific topic and seemed overly quick–paced.

best_comment: Yuan is incredible! Could not recommend taking a class with her more. I came into this course with little experience in epistemology/the moral agency subfield of philosophy but left feeling much more confident, in large part because she guided us to success. For one, tutorial discussions were expertly managed so as to not suppress free–flowing discussion while nonetheless keeping us on track. Moreover, Yuan has this remarkable ability to pick up on useful nuggets in what we say, and it is clear that she herself is very knowledgeable/steeped in this work. (Her office hours are always lively in terms of back–and–forth and incredibly helpful!) Lastly, Yuan supplied us with excellent syllogistic outlines of the readings each week, a small thing that really transformed the way I understand philosophy.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Yuan is incredible! Could not recommend taking a class with her more. I came into this course with little experience in epistemology/the moral agency subfield of philosophy but left feeling much more confident, in large part because she guided us to success. For one, tutorial discussions were expertly managed so as to not suppress free–flowing discussion while nonetheless keeping us on track. Moreover, Yuan has this remarkable ability to pick up on useful nuggets in what we say, and it is clear that she herself is very knowledgeable/steeped in this work. (Her office hours are always lively in terms of back–and–forth and incredibly helpful!) Lastly, Yuan supplied us with excellent syllogistic outlines of the readings each week, a small thing that really transformed the way I understand philosophy.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Take this class! Smriti is a great instructor, she makes the material interesting and easy to understand. The class is incredibly well–structured and the readings are definitely foundational to philosophical thought! I
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Take this class! Smriti is a great instructor, she makes the material interesting and easy to understand. The class is incredibly well–structured and the readings are definitely foundational to philosophical thought! I
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: I LOVE LOVE LOVED this course. For someone who is a STEM concentrator, I found this course to be super accessible and intriguing. I would totally recommend taking this. The workload is not too demanding, the materials is interesting, and the class format lend itself well to learning a lot.

Absolutely take this course. Really excellent course on metaphysics with some history of philosophy on the side. Professor Simmon's runs an excellent discussion, and the readings always have a lot to chew on. I cannot recommend this course enough. Metaphysics and history of philosophy tend to be the areas of the field that I am the least interested in, but I took this course because I had previously taken Phil 8 with Professor Simmons and was very impressed with her. That turned out to be an excellent decision as this was easily one of my favorite classes I have taken during my time at Harvard. Professor Simmons is always available to meet and discuss content (or anything else in philosophy) and I found some of the best discussion happened during office hours. The course itself has a very manageable workload, though reading philosophy closely is always time consuming. There are low–stakes weekly reading responses which you get feedback on, which is helpful. Throughout the semester there are also assignments that serve as preliminary steps in writing a final research paper. At the end of the semester when it came time to sit down and actually write my research paper I realized I was done with all the most tedious parts, and the paper itself was then quite easy to write. I think I produced some of my best writing thanks to this structure, and the feedback on the final paper was extremely helpful. Again, this is a great class and you should take it.
worse_comment: This course is very eclectic––in what other philosophy course do you get to read Aristotle, Descartes, and contemporary work on death & dying in the ICU? And Alison is just wonderful.

best_comment: If you enjoy philosophy and especially the history of philosophy, you should take this course. Shepherd is a very interesting long–neglected philosopher and Professor Simmons and Professor McDonough are awesome teachers. Moreover, the course is very discussion focused so you will learn a lot from your peers and have plenty of opportunities to share your own thoughts. Overall a great course.

If you enjoy philosophy and especially the history of philosophy, you should take this course. Shepherd is a very interesting long–neglected philosopher and Professor Simmons and Professor McDonough are awesome teachers. Moreover, the course is very discussion focused so you will learn a lot from your peers and have plenty of opportunities to share your own thoughts. Overall a great course.

Do not take this course if you do not have a serious background in math. If you want a cool course on model theory with minimal (read: no) philosophical implications, take this. If you are looking for a course on the application of logic to philosophy, look elsewhere. Some tedious proofs, but a lot of cool and clever stuff. If you take it with Woodin, you get the pleasure of learning from one of the greatest minds of our time. It is an honor to learn from him, and I will be telling my kids that I took his class. But it is far from a perfect course. Be wary, esp. if you're just a phil kid and not a math kid.
worse_comment: Really really really bad class, please don't take this. Lectures are boring, problem sets are hard and graded really really harshly with pretty much no feedback, and you won't get any grades back until after reading period.

best_comment: If you've ever been curious about religion and, specifically, different conceptions of self–identity, take this course. Be warned: this course is not a super rigid course, rather loose in structure. If you are someone who needs clear structure in a course, Phil 155 is not for you. But if you are okay being along for the ride, this course is absolute dynamite. Seldom have I taken a course and been so involved with the material, that I found myself questioning the validity of my (fictional) narrative that I've carried all my life. This class pokes holes in the promises you told yourself as a child, the ideas you have for self–gain, and the ways in which you want to live life. I found myself questioning the very nature of my personhood and, as a result, desiring to round out my morals and values through the "greater onward rush of humanity." Besides, Parimal is a S–tier professor. He's the perfect blend of crazy, caring, and genius, and he really cares about meeting with students and walking them along the path of philosophy. I highly recommend this course for those brave souls (if souls even exist) who want to question all they know.

Great class!Material: metaphysics is very weird, but the readings are very interesting when you get down to thinking about them.Readings: hard at first glance. They definitely become easier over time.Assignments: interesting and fair. Youll get tought love on your feedback, but in a very good way.Class discussion: super fun!! Prof. Berkeley is always willing to engage with any ideas and suggestions, and is super good at leading discussions. Strongly recommend going to class every day.TF: Flo is a literal geniusSection: Flo is a literal geniusOverall, strong recommend!!
worse_comment: I would tell future students that this class is time consuming and requires hard work but if you are serious about philosophy as your concentration then I would take the course.

course_title: Philosophy of Technology: From Marx and Heidegger to AI, Genome Editing and Geoengineering (HKS) 001
best_comment: You will cover a lot of material very quickly, but the readings are always interesting and Risse does an impeccable job breaking difficult philosophical positions down into understandable concepts in lecture! Pariroo, the Head TF, is also amazing and section is very helpful if you need further support. The assignments are not too frequent, nor too difficult. You should try to start the papers early, but they aren’t overly challenging! Overall, this has been one of the better courses I have taken at Harvard. The cross–school nature of the class also definitely plays to its strengths. Design students may struggle a bit more with the philosophical readings, but soon will explore concepts more design–related in the third part of the course. Undergrads, do NOT be afraid to take this class !

This class is super interesting! There is so much to learn from the lectures in this class, which will change the way you view the infrastructure and technology around you. Additionally, the discussion component of the course allows you to learn from your peers and hear diverse perspectives on topics like privacy and AI. Finally, the course allows you to explore a topic of interest with a research paper, giving you the time and flexibility to learn a lot about a topic you care about.
worse_comment: This was one of the worst pedagogical experiences I've ever had. The course had no syllabus and no assignments so weekly discussions were often unfounded and hand–wavy. This class only met once a week, and yet at least 3 meetings were canceled and others pushed to Zoom. I honestly felt cheated out of what could've been a cool learning experience.

best_comment: Bernard Williams is a strange thinker; disliking ethical systems and theories, his philosophical project is mostly centered around commentary on various other thinkers' approaches. This makes reading Williams a bit different from reading, say, Kant, but once you are used to him, he asks many important questions. While you may not always like his answers, reading Williams will teach you to be a better thinker and critic of philosophy.Prof. Moran is friendly, approachable, and has a wonderful dry sense of humor. He has a very different approach to philosophy than others I've encountered; he is far less concerned with doing a rigorous reconstruction all of the time and far more interested in getting at and exploring what an argument is really saying. While each approach has its advantages and disadvantages, it is wonderful to experience the latter as someone not previously exposed. His essay prompts reflect that, asking a plethora of questions and opening the assignments up in a variety of directions, giving you a fair deal of freedom to explore interesting strands in Williams' work. I'm thankful to have taken a class with him.

If you are looking for a course with an excellent discussion and an interesting group of people, I would highly recommend this course.  In terms of workload, this will probably be a 4th course for most given that a lot of the course is participation, and the quantity of assessable work is really limited to the two critical papers. On the other hand, if you do want to make it a big commitment, Gina gives excellently Indepth feedback on the papers, and you could push yourself to write excellent papers ––– this is however up to you. If you are not interested in educational justice (i.e. hadn't thought about it much until seeing this course in the directory, I would recommend you look elsewhere ––– the readings may be interesting still, but you may not be able to contribute as well to the atmosphere of the discussion. Overall great course, and the Professor has clearly put in a lot of time and deep thinking as to how to structure the course to maximize the quality of discussions.

This class is pretty openly a view of inequality from a very, VERY left wing lens. I'm pretty moderate politically, so it was definitely an interesting sight to see. Some takeaways:This is less of a philosophy class and more of a sociology/anthropology of why america–bad–capitalism–bad class. You start with the works of Rawls, but pretty much all the rest of the readings are either politically charged ramblings or direct appeals to emotion. This is not to say the readings were bad; Waldron's article on the lack of freedoms for the homeless, in particular, was extremely striking. In general, I'd say the readings are extremely one sided, but at least interesting. Philosophical rigor is rather low.Prof. Stanczyk is every stereotype of a male humanities professor rolled into one. He's pretty nice, and quite funny, which is always good. However, his lectures are just an endless onslought of pure appeals to emotion with very little in the way of actual philosophy. He also very clearly leans extremely far to the left on pretty much every issue, and invited speakers who openly described themselves as socialist. This is neither good nor bad in a vacuum, but definitely something to be aware of when stepping into this class.Both Isaijah and Rachael are absolutely phenomenal, wonderful people and teachers. Spend as much time with them as you can. Grading was extremely impressive and left lots of hints, and they would make sure to make help and office hours available when you needed it. Extensions were available no questions asked on all essays. They're both also super smart, which doesn't hurt.Sections are good. If you have any opinions to the right of Bernie Sanders, you'll often feel a compulsion to bite your tongue. I'm relatively moderate by American political standards, so I had times I was happy to speak up and times I figured it best to shut up and let everyone else cook.Grading is not harsh.Overall, solid class. Very great CAs, cool (albeit very slanted) readings, good vibes.

If you're remotely interested in architecture or design, you should take this course! I had a great experience, and learned a lot. The readings are very interesting, and it's absolutely worth putting in the time to read them thoroughly and think about them. The course has definitely broadened my understanding and enjoyment of architecture. Also, Remei is an amazing professor and cares a lot about this class and her students. I had a great time.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: This class will never be taught again, I've been told, so I'll focus instead on Prof. Moran and Luke. Prof. Moran is really knowledgable and very interesting. He's a great writer, and very interesting to talk to. That being said, his lectures meander and can be dull and unfocused, and often difficult to understand. From what I've heard, he's incredible in a section, but is a lot more difficult to have as a lecturer.Luke is maybe the best TF, definitely the best Philosophy TF, I've ever had. Incredibly kind and knowledgable. He is approachable, and very good at fostering a productive yet challenging section environment. He gives pointed criticism of assignments. Harsh but never unfair, and does a great job grading. He's very meticulous, which is fantastic for a TF. He's also an incredible teacher. Honestly, I want to see this man head a class as soon as possible. He was able to explain complex, difficult philosophical ideas in a way that made sense. I really just want to take a class in which he really focuses on teaching, because he excels at it. He's fantastic, and I really hope I get the pleasure of taking another class with him before I leave Harvard.

course_title: Special Topics in Post-Kantian European Philosophy 001
best_comment: Come ready to dig deeply into a few pages (or even lines) and delight in the ambiguity of language!

While the class is clearly taught by extremely knowledgeable and renowned professors, it felt incohesive and unstructured at times, and the connections to "equality" during some of the sessions were relatively unclear. In this iteration, there were students from all sorts of schools and backgrounds, some with clearly extensive experience in philosophy, and others for whom I assume this was their first philosophy class. This meant that the level of the class was more that of an introductory philosophy class than of a graduate level class. The directions about the 25–page final paper were pretty unclear, and so is the grading of the class. That being said, the class is very light in terms of workload during the semester (1 hour weekly max) but the final paper can take a while.
worse_comment: The profs are famous but lectures were hard to follow.

best_comment: While the class is clearly taught by extremely knowledgeable and renowned professors, it felt incohesive and unstructured at times, and the connections to "equality" during some of the sessions were relatively unclear. In this iteration, there were students from all sorts of schools and backgrounds, some with clearly extensive experience in philosophy, and others for whom I assume this was their first philosophy class. This meant that the level of the class was more that of an introductory philosophy class than of a graduate level class. The directions about the 25–page final paper were pretty unclear, and so is the grading of the class. That being said, the class is very light in terms of workload during the semester (1 hour weekly max) but the final paper can take a while.
worse_comment: The profs are famous but lectures were hard to follow.

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! My praise here will undoubtedly be insufficient. Much can be said about the rich/expertly–crafted reading list, but I owe much more of the experience to Gina's excellent teaching and my classmate's excellent contributions. You are in very competent hands. TRULY: Gina is a gem in this department and you would be doing yourself a disservice if you did not take the chance to engage with her brilliance. There were many times when I would haphazardly present a half–baked idea and she would immediately disassemble it to see the most important elements/build it back up with precise language.

Overall a fantastic course. The professors are unbelievably kind and generous with partial credit (greg and tim u rock), and it's clear that they understand the premed student struggle wrt courseload and support outside of class. PSET material can be confusing, but the most efficient use of your time is to just knock them out at office hours because the TFs and profs are incredibly supportive and helpful. Just stay on top of section videos (they actually teach the content, while lectures mainly focus on practice problems. i personally liked this structure since it allows you to absorb material at your own pace), and make sure to do all the participation credit (there are so many opportunities for participation credit, its awesome) and you're gonna get a good grade in this class. Like A or A–. Course staff are constantly taking the time to adapt to student suggestions, and are overall very open–minded and supportive of a stronger learning environment. If you're ever struggling, reaching out to staff will absolutely benefit you. And labs (albeit not super related to lecture content) can actually be fully completed in the 2–3 hour lab sections, no hand–written/notarized/blessed–by–a–holy–figure prelab notebook required! after a year of the chem 17–27 series, this course was bliss.In the long term: normally PS3 is the traditional follow–up course, and I've heard that it's extremely good at covering MCAT–type questions. In the past there have been some negative reviews of the teaching staff that are no longer teaching that course, so it's very likely that PS3 will also be pretty great when it's your turn to take it. Personally though exams are scary so I will be transferring to AP50B. Peace and love to PS3 staff. I've also heard ok things about the AP50 series, but you just have to be really good at managing your own time and working with groups that might not necessarily want to do their share of the work. Again, regardless of if you do the PS series or AP50 series, if you put in the time each week to knock out the work as you go, you're less likely to get overwhelmed and you'll have a solid grade. Good luck!
worse_comment: If you're a pre–med who needs to take physics then PS2 is fine but if you've never been exposed to physics and are not the best at math then prioritize this class. This class was horrible. The professors are knowledgeable about physics, but it doesn't look like they know how to teach a beginner physics course. They used demonstrations which was cool but honestly did not help me. I went to a help room one night and it was horrible. The room was so tiny and there was just not enough CA's to help the students. The lectures are collaborative–based style and it's honestly pretty bad. There was no midterm review and the final exam review wasn't useful. You get a YouTube video to go over your practice exams but the practice exams are so difficult and do not reflect your actual exams. I'm sure that makes it better so you're more prepared when the exam comes around, but the practice exams were so stressful and it was just bad. This goes onto my list of bad classes I've taken at Harvard.

The professors are unbelievably kind and generous with partial credit (greg and tim u rock), and it's clear that they understand the premed student struggle wrt courseload and support outside of class. Personally though exams are scary so I will be transferring to AP50B. Peace and love to PS3 staff. I've also heard ok things about the AP50 series, but you just have to be really good at managing your own time and working with groups that might not necessarily want to do their share of the work. Again, regardless of if you do the PS series or AP50 series, if you put in the time each week to knock out the work as you go, you're less likely to get overwhelmed and you'll have a solid grade. Good luck!
worse_comment: If you're a pre–med who needs to take physics then PS2 is fine but if you've never been exposed to physics and are not the best at math then prioritize this class. This class was horrible. The professors are knowledgeable about physics, but it doesn't look like they know how to teach a beginner physics course. They used demonstrations which was cool but honestly did not help me. I went to a help room one night and it was horrible. The room was so tiny and there was just not enough CA's to help the students. The lectures are collaborative–based style and it's honestly pretty bad. There was no midterm review and the final exam review wasn't useful. You get a YouTube video to go over your practice exams but the practice exams are so difficult and do not reflect your actual exams. I'm sure that makes it better so you're more prepared when the exam comes around, but the practice exams were so stressful and it was just bad. This goes onto my list of bad classes I've taken at Harvard.

course_title: Electromagnetism from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Lectures give great conceptual foundations, subskill quizzes are a great first step to testing your knowledge (might help to read the textbook first––this isn't widely recommended but I think it definitely helps), the test structure allows reassessments every Friday so it's a low–stress environment but you learn a lot by reviewing concepts each week. Labs are the perfect length and are designed to let you get a key takeaway each week (psst it's more enjoyable if you actually think about what this is!) Additionally, the course staff are super nice and accessible––probably the most so out of any other physics class I've taken. Would definitely recommend, whether you're a physics, engineering, or other science (even premed) concentrator!
worse_comment: I would not recommend this course, avoid it if you can. A TF spends the first few fridays of the semester teaching the basics of python (ie how to write a for loop, defining a function, etc). However, the psets expect you to model magnetic fields, etc and require a significantly higher level of coding skill to complete. The grading on assessments is also very harsh in terms of the fact that you could get most of the question correct and demonstrate knowledge of the topic, but have a calculation error causing you to lose all credit. Psets are also extremely difficult to do on your own, office hours are essential. Overall,  I would take AP50 instead.

best_comment: An incredibly interesting, fun, and informative overview of a bunch of different fabrication techniques.  Professor Melenbrink does an awesome job of introducing all the topics in an approachable and beginner–friendly way, while also going into enough depth that we are able to implement the concepts in a meaningful and deep way.  Lectures and the live demos are very engaging.  The hands–on component of the course is a huge plus––one of the best opportunities at Harvard in my opinion to actually practice and implement engineering techniques (rather than just studying them conceptually on paper).  I started this class not knowing anything about any sort of fabrication, and I learned so much and had so much fun in this class.  I HIGHLY recommend this class for anyone who feels that Harvard's engineering/science courses are too theoretical––this is a great way to learn how to actually build things.  It is quite time consuming, so you need to be prepared to dedicate significant chunks of time to your projects to get the most out of them.  HUGE shoutout to the TFs, they are so helpful and patient.
subject: Physical Sciences

best_comment: This course was my favorite class of the semester, but it definitely did not come with its challenges. It is a very difficult course (although I wouldn't say it is horrible), so I would not recommend someone take it unless they truly enjoy and are interested in physics. For this course, you need a decent background in physics: I would say AP Physics 1 at the ver least, although AP Physics C is probably preferable. This course also does a lot of integration and derivation, so being comfortable with that is beneficial. When I first started the course, I definitely found it to have a big learning curve with the pacing of the lectures and the intensity of the problem sets. Professor Morin is a great, super chill, and very intelligent person, but sometimes the content of the lecture was not super helpful for solving the problem sets. For those, they definitely require a good chunk of time every week, but section is very helpful (Aurelien is a great TF if you have him!), as well as Physics Night, office hours, and the Perusall readings. So there is a good system of support and resources to help you throughout the course.But overall, once you get pat the pain, the class is really rewarding (except for the lab component) and the content is interesting. It definitely teaches you to struggle and think about problem–solving in new ways. The community in the course is also great (one thing that made me consider taking Physics 16 was the community that it fosters, but I don't think that Physics 15a lacks at all in this department), and I've met some of the coolest, most interesting and intelligent people from this course, so I would highly recommend taking the time to collaborate with and meet your peers.
worse_comment: IF YOU'RE LIKE ME...and took AP Physics C: Mechanics in high school and sort of understood what was going on read this carefully. This class is going to be challenging, BUT IT IS DOABLE AND I RECOMMEND YOU TAKE IT JUST READ THIS. There will be times when you feel so confused you might question your self–worth, but read the book and go to office hours. I think almost every lecture I went to I had no clue what was going on, but when doing the problem sets things became much clearer. There are example problems in the book that are INCREDIBLY similar to the homework problems (use that to your advantage by using the example problems as a guide to how to approach the homework problems. There is an explanation for each problem, so read them and understand why certain decisions were made when problem solving). Sometimes, I felt that the book didn't really answer all my questions so you know what I did? I WENT TO OFFICE HOURS AND ASKED THEM SO DO THE SAME! If you're like me, start the problem sets early. If they're assigned on Thursday, start looking through them on Friday and actually getting some stuff down. It's okay if your answers are wrong, but the important part is that you're actually trying to understand the problem while you solve it (that way when you're in office hours asking for help, you can see WHY your answer was wrong, basically learning from your mistakes. If you don't make the mistake, then how will you learn?). Overall, take the class and do not worry if things don't make sense in lecture. The problem sets will be your main learning opportunity, but you have to do your part and try to actually learn from them using the book and office hours. The midterms are alright as long as you study for them. You do that by redoing the homework problems and perusall problems that were assigned –– it's some work, but you'll be prepared.
subject: Physics

subject: Physics

best_comment: 15b is a great introduction to E and M and covers a wide scope of material, so you will definitely learn a lot while taking it! I decided to take it with only an introductory high school physics background (I didn't take AP physics) and found it quite difficult as a result. It's definitely possible to take it with little to no background, but it will be much easier if you've already taken an E&M class. I decided to take it because I wanted a smaller, more physics–concentration centered course than PS3 and I'm glad I did–– the office hours and sections were super helpful and I felt like it was easier to get one–on–one help. Professor Dvorkin is really enthusiastic about the subject and always willing to hear feedback and change the class if people have suggestions. If you go to office hours, you can get the psets done and the CAs are wonderful in helping explain new concepts. One thing to be wary of is that exams counted for 90% of our grade and psets were the other 10%. So my entire grade was basically exams which was somewhat stressful. Other than that, I thought the lab portion of 15b was way more fun (and less confusing) than 15a!
worse_comment: Brush up on your multivariable calculus because you are going to need it. If you do not have a good understanding and are not comfortable setting up integrals over 3D objects and basic differential equations, then you are going to have a hard time with this course. The material is difficult enough to understand, so you do not want to make it worse for yourself by struggling with the math that they already expect you to know.

subject: Physics

best_comment: If you're reading this, you probably have to take 15c (unless you're one of those engineering kids who takes this because it's easier than ES 100–and–whatever, to which I say, bah, humbug). Thus, I'll tell you it how it is. 15c is a pretty standard introductory physics class. It's fine. It's nothing to write home about. You'll learn waves, a couple of differential equations (although they tell you the answers, and if you took 21b you know them already (side note: take 21b before 15c)), and a bit of electromagnetism that if you're like me, you forgot promptly after the 15b final. The problem sets are fine, they're comparable to 15a/b, and the exams are fair. Professor Huth is good, and he's a wonderful character, he'll tell you all about his niche passions that (tangentially) relate to waves. So, aspiring physics major, enjoy. It's not that bad.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE IT. Awful class, material is not well taught or thorough, psets are bad and not useful even, midterm and final are terrible and difficult to study for.

best_comment: Physics 16 is truly an amazing class that manages to be both quite painful and very rewarding.  The Q reports are no exaggeration in terms of time commitment and level of difficulty: I initially thought that there was absolutely no way you could spend more than 15 hours a week on a class, but Physics 16 achieves that for sure. I've probably half–lived in the physics lounge over my fall semester and have almost without exception been in the physics library until around 4–5am minimum on Wednesday nights (Thursday mornings?), and you certainly get thrown in headfirst in the sense that you are forced to learn to collaborate with peers and ask for help from TFs very quickly. I can without compunction say that my first semester revolved around Physics 16, so it's not a class you should take unless you're really passionate and committed to studying physics as a subject.The best thing about 16 (and probably the major thing that brings it from barely bearable to absolutely transformative) is its community. This year's class was about 24 people, and I'm pretty good friends with almost all of them––you really end up psetting in one large group, and I've met some amazing people I would not have otherwise thought to meet (including one of my best friends). Also, community–building often equals free food! Professor Yao (Norm) is wonderful, as are all the TFs and CAs: they are constantly supportive, available, and ready to help when it comes to not just course material but more general topics. As a lecturer, Norm is very engaging, and he takes an approach that really lets you see the line of reasoning that he's using to derive a particular result. The lectures work well with Morin's textbook (Introduction to Classical Mechanics), which is especially useful when it comes to material you don't know very well.Preparation–wise, I definitely recommend at least having AP Physics C under your belt. As someone who took all the AP Physics courses in my junior year of high school, I felt significantly underprepared compared to most of the people in the class who have USAPhO/IPhO/general Olympiad experience. I did, however, have a lot of math and calculus background, which I feel helped somewhat. Regardless, I think almost everyone in the class committed a big chunk of their semester to this class, and if you're okay with spending a lot of your time doing physics, I would fully recommend this class.
worse_comment: It’s great but be ready to make the decision of sleep vs solving a physics problem and getting brain damage from lack of sleep. Do not take as a second priority class. It must be first priority or you will become nocturnal.

As a lecturer, Norm is very engaging, and he takes an approach that really lets you see the line of reasoning that he's using to derive a particular result. The lectures work well with Morin's textbook (Introduction to Classical Mechanics), which is especially useful when it comes to material you don't know very well.Preparation–wise, I definitely recommend at least having AP Physics C under your belt. As someone who took all the AP Physics courses in my junior year of high school, I felt significantly underprepared compared to most of the people in the class who have USAPhO/IPhO/general Olympiad experience. I did, however, have a lot of math and calculus background, which I feel helped somewhat. Regardless, I think almost everyone in the class committed a big chunk of their semester to this class, and if you're okay with spending a lot of your time doing physics, I would fully recommend this class.
worse_comment: It’s great but be ready to make the decision of sleep vs solving a physics problem and getting brain damage from lack of sleep. Do not take as a second priority class. It must be first priority or you will become nocturnal.

best_comment: Physics 16 is truly an amazing class that manages to be both quite painful and very rewarding.  The Q reports are no exaggeration in terms of time commitment and level of difficulty: I initially thought that there was absolutely no way you could spend more than 15 hours a week on a class, but Physics 16 achieves that for sure. I've probably half–lived in the physics lounge over my fall semester and have almost without exception been in the physics library until around 4–5am minimum on Wednesday nights (Thursday mornings?), and you certainly get thrown in headfirst in the sense that you are forced to learn to collaborate with peers and ask for help from TFs very quickly. I can without compunction say that my first semester revolved around Physics 16, so it's not a class you should take unless you're really passionate and committed to studying physics as a subject.The best thing about 16 (and probably the major thing that brings it from barely bearable to absolutely transformative) is its community. This year's class was about 24 people, and I'm pretty good friends with almost all of them––you really end up psetting in one large group, and I've met some amazing people I would not have otherwise thought to meet (including one of my best friends). Also, community–building often equals free food! Professor Yao (Norm) is wonderful, as are all the TFs and CAs: they are constantly supportive, available, and ready to help when it comes to not just course material but more general topics. As a lecturer, Norm is very engaging, and he takes an approach that really lets you see the line of reasoning that he's using to derive a particular result. The lectures work well with Morin's textbook (Introduction to Classical Mechanics), which is especially useful when it comes to material you don't know very well.Preparation–wise, I definitely recommend at least having AP Physics C under your belt. Regardless, I think almost everyone in the class committed a big chunk of their semester to this class, and if you're okay with spending a lot of your time doing physics, I would fully recommend this class.

best_comment: If you are looking for a transformative physics course, this is it. This course is exciting, engaging, and philosophical. Jacob is both an amazing instructor and human being through and through — he is extremely passionate about this course and physics/philosophy in general, incredibly considerate, understanding and kind with a great sense of humour. Lectures can be a bit fast–paced (the course in general covers a LOT of material), but Jacob nails the clear explanations, and if you are still lost, you can refer to his meticulous, textbook–quality lecture notes after class and/or attend office hours. I loved the first–principles approach to teaching/learning; seeing all the mathematical derivations gives you a sense and overall picture of physics that a typical high school course could never achieve.The CAs and TFs were all extremely supportive and kind as well. I would strongly encourage you to attend office hours, even if you have a solid grasp of the homework and lecture material, as Jacob and the teaching staff are extremely welcoming, friendly, open to questions (everything from "basic" questions to ones that go beyond the scope of the course), and knowledgeable. Some people may find the problemsets to be a bit tedious at times, but from someone with very little background in both mathematics and physics (I did not have a solid grasp of Taylor polynomials before starting the course, for example), I thought the problems were extremely insightful, representative of key concepts, and also quite fun to explore.  An interest and/or background in math (e.g. calculus, linear algebra) would be extremely helpful, but it's not necessarily required, provided that you are willing to take initiative / ask questions when you need more help. Note that lectures sometimes go over time, but lectures themselves don't feel like they "drag."While the course can be challenging, grading is fair and (I personally think) quite generous at times. The midterm exams are simpler than the problemsets, and there is no final (in its place a fun project/presentation, where you can choose an interesting physics problem you'd like to explore with a partner or two). The level of understanding you need to develop to "ace" this course (on paper) is not as high as the sheer level of complexity that some of the concepts can reach, but you can (and should!) explore physics more if you are interested (e.g. lecture notes go much more in–depth and often touch upon significantly more advanced ideas/problems).Overall, I am so glad that I took this course, and I think you will be as well!
worse_comment: If you really like physics, then this class is probably great for you. I hated the other intro physics courses, and I had heard that this one was better so I decided to give it a try and was disappointed to find it did not satisfy my expectations. I felt that it covered far too many random topics ranging from all over the discipline, and thus felt extremely chaotic and disconnected. I also found that the class almost always, and I mean very regularly, ran over time, by sometimes upwards of 15 minutes, so if you have a class directly afterwards be wary of that. I truly do think Jacob is a good person and lecturer, I just know this class was not for me. Had it been designed better, and perhaps covered significantly fewer topics, but with slightly greater depth, then perhaps it would have been better.  All I can say, however, is that I found myself dreading anything to do with the class: I hated the psets, hated the somewhat pointless feeling that lab had (especially considering how disconnected it was from our class), and hated taking the exams.

best_comment: This is a great course if you are a physics concentrator. It has a low–time commitment but everything you do is very applicable to other courses and especially to research. I wish I had taken it earlier and I'm happy I took this instead of CS 50.
worse_comment: definitely teaches you computational physics and leaves you  with concrete code to use. not good if you’re  looking for a theory based coding course but good if you need python experience for your research or a starting point to gain some fluency in the language. go to section !!! and make good pset buddies, you’ll need them for the midterm and final.

best_comment: This is a great course if you are a physics concentrator. It has a low–time commitment but everything you do is very applicable to other courses and especially to research. I wish I had taken it earlier and I'm happy I took this instead of CS 50.

best_comment: I took this class in order to figure out whether I was interested in academia and research or not. This class was helpful as a low–workload way to do that. I saw that I find the research interesting, but the structure of academia is not appealing to me, and so if I go to grad school it would be a couple years after graduating college and not immediately. The big assignments are a presentation and a 10–page paper. I found the paper difficult because for some reason I chose a topic I am not terribly interested in, but I see that if you choose a topic you care about it could be a very helpful and enjoyable assignment. The presentation was difficult, however, because they are on topics you probably won't have sufficient background on to explain in depth. Professor Westervelt will help with the presentation, but that also makes it a bit more confusing. For example, he helped me prepare my presentation, and then when I did the example we discussed in front of the class, he said to use a different one and I got rather confused. He also takes over talking for most of the presentation since the point is for everyone to learn about the topic and he will almost surely know more about it than you, so don't be alarmed or worried about your grade if he just starts talking for 10 minutes in the middle of your presentation; the presentation is not formal like that.

Taking this class with Professor Morii is so worth it––I haven't taken many physics classes, but Morii was such an engaging lecturer and clearly cared about the class and student learning. Really well designed lectures, and he was very accessible outside class. He also had us fill out quick questions at the end of class about what we were confused about and actually would send out canvas announcements explaining those concepts in more detail. Genuinely think Morii is one of the best professors I've taken a class with at Harvard so far (and also so nice, he even brought us donuts for the final exam). This class is definitely challenging, but if you put the time into reading Griffiths and review the lecture material it is manageable–– especially because all of the TFs are so helpful during office hours and clearly want you to succeed. Take this class! I did it as an elective (not a physics major) and am very happy I did.
worse_comment: Masahiro is a good lecturer and you get a lot out of the course, but it's also quite difficult. I struggled throughout and only until the end did everything really click for me.
subject: Physics

best_comment: i'll try my best to be honest and write something coherent. i can say that i deeply enjoyed the course and i would recommend it to every physics concentrator. 143a gets a little boring because sure, by the end of it you kinda sorta know what a wave function is, but all you do all day is calculate annoying integrals that tell you something about the energy of an infinite square well or a harmonic oscillator, which like sure fine whatever but it feels so far removed from reality. 143b finally presents you with the real life cool applications of what you learn in 143a. Also, what i meant by "kinda sorta" is that in 143a you feel like you know quantum mechanics and all that, but 143b teaches you that you don't, and then, once you've had this realization, you are now ready to truly learn quantum mechanics. what i want to say is that i truly see no point in taking 143a alone. in my opinion, 143b should be a requirement. plus, the material is extremely interesting, and prof. paban did a great job presenting the material. she is extremely knowledgeable about the subject, her notes were amazing (and to all the haters who say otherwise, they were just too lazy to read her hand–written notes which fine it was annoying that she didn't type them, but her notes are FAR SUPERIOR than a single word david j. griffiths wrote past chapter 7 in his book), and the exams were EXTREMELY FAIR. she is an amazing lecturer with a true understanding of the material and was extremely effective at teaching (except perhaps for scattering because i still don't really understand it but whatever, you get the point).  in short, i loved the class and i would really recommend it. i think that, as a physicist, you should know the material from 143b no matter what so if u are thinking about 143b, just take it.
worse_comment: Some parts seem more confusing than they are, go through them thoroughly.
subject: Physics

best_comment: My second exposure to classical mechanics (having done the equivalent of AP in the UK before uni), Physics 151 was a fun and rewarding experience. Professor Jaffe was great – both at teaching and at using the small class size to its advantage by making it as interactive as possible. TF Serhii Kryhin deserves a special mention for his accessibility, dedication, patience and great explanations. The class community is smaller than that of the typical physics course at Harvard, and as a result usually has a more informal feel to it which gives it the potential to be (and in my experience, was) something special. The material is a really nice breath of fresh air, especially when contrasted with one's typical ubiquitous and frustratingly boring first encounter with classical mechanics, and was both beautiful in itself as well as having many interesting connections with various bits of physics and mathematics such as quantum mechanics, lie algebras, differential geometry and more – definitely gained a totally new appreciation for something I once found so dry and lifeless. The problem sets and exams were a good opportunity to practice working with things that will undoubtedly be seen again and again in modern physics courses such as GR and QFT – sometimes the "bash" felt a bit much but it always resolved to something nice that is consistent with good intuition and felt like a good conceptual takeaway. One critique is that more preparatory material for the exams would be much appreciated – don't think anyone in the class was that clear on exactly what to study, especially before the first midterm. Overall, I find that the course does a great job of balancing beauty and rigour, and I greatly recommend it to all concentrators – especially to those who are interested in the more theoretical side of physics and to those who are looking for a fun and unique course. (Specific groups of people to whom I would recommend this to especially:Ex–Physics–19ers who found the snippets of analytical mechanics interestingAnyone who needs a mechanics requirement but has gotten sick to death of Newtonian mechanics (I belong in this category)Freshmen looking for a lighter course than 16 which teaches similar material (could imagine that this would be especially good to have under your belt before Physics 251 for more maths–forward physics students)
best_gem_comment: This was far and away my favorite class of the semester, and one of my favorite classes of my time at Harvard so far. I had already taken 15a my freshman fall, but I absolutely do not regret going back for a second pass at mechanics. It is a completely different subject when looked at more deeply, and far more beautiful than I gave it credit for before taking this class. The main content of the class revolves around symmetries and conserved quantities in Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics, a subject that (as professor Jaffe stressed over and over) had very deep connections to modern–day quantum theory.Due to the small class size, we all became pretty close by the end of the class. This was in large part fostered by the gem of a TF, Serhii––try and take any class he TF's in the future, not just 151! Professor Jaffe gave incredible lectures for the most part, and would frequently drop incredibly stories about his life and career. He is an incredibly physicist and a really sweet person––the class party at his house at the end of the semester was definitely a highlight!The only downsides I found in the class were the problem sets and tests. Many of the problem sets (biweekly) were short, so the workload was very manageable for the majority of the semester. However, I found the pset questions to be very detached from the material we were learning in class, with much time spent on endless bashing without any noticeable benefit. The exams were stressful, with professor Jaffe not giving any practice exams or practice problems and forbidding cheat sheets (his teaching style is very old school in general). However, the two in–class midterms comprised only 20% of our grade this semester, so it wasn't the worst thing in the world.We had a final project as our final assessment for the class, which was really fun, albeit quite stressful. It is incredibly how deep of a subject classical mechanics is, and I don't think you get to experience its beauty in any other class at Harvard.Overall, I think that Physics 151 is as close to a gem of a class as you're going to get in the Physics department––relatively low stress and low workload, very interesting and relevant content, and an unforgettable experience with incredible people! I would highly recommend incoming freshman take this class over 15a, 16, or 19 to fulfill their mechanics requirement, especially if you have a decent linear algebra background. (Without a solid linear algebra foundation, it's very hard to appreciate a lot of the material we covered.)
subject: Physics

course_title: Thinking Through Writing: Science Themes | 2023: The Time Things Take 001
best_comment: I recommend this course with the highest enthusiasm! This has been my favorite course I have taken at Harvard (I am a senior). I have wanted to take a course about writing about science and this course was everything I hoped it would be, and so much more. Prof. Messud and Prof. Franklin's lectures are incredible; I learned so much from both of them and I appreciated their complementary approaches. I also really enjoyed the guest lectures they arranged for the course: it was so cool to hear from the authors whose work we were reading! I learned a lot from the course readings and appreciated the variety of styles we encountered. The course readings are also really fun and engaging; we read poetry, fiction, essays, science journalism, history of science articles, and much more. I also really appreciated the teaching staff who were very knowledgable, helpful, and dedicated. I regularly attended the professors' office hours as well as the teaching fellows' office hours and I found these sessions to be extremely helpful. I learned so much about how to creatively communicate about science and how to use forms of creative writing to think through scientific ideas and develop my understanding of these. If you are interested in science, creative writing, and/or how these connect take this amazing class!
worse_comment: It's too bad because the concept for this class is so cool, but the execution was just not it. The lectures were very disjointed and disorganized, and the two professors often seemed to be in conflict with each other to the point where it was uncomfortable to be in class. Melissa (the physics professor) also seemed to be disinterested in, or have disdain for, both literature and the students in the class. There was a weird assumption that kept being brought up throughout the course by both professors that English concentrators don't understand anything about physics or vice versa, which I think 1) goes against the purpose of the class and 2) made me a bit annoyed as an English concentrator who hasn't taken a physics class since tenth grade and yet understood the vast majority of the physics concepts that were being introduced in this class. The readings were also heavily white and male, way more than I would have expected from any class taught in 2023? Unless the course improves, I wouldn't recommend it.

best_comment: It is a class like no other. You will work hard, but the rewards are huge. You probably have to take it, but I promise if you have a good attitude and really immerse in the experimentation, you will have a good time and learn A LOT. Take it in the fall if you can.
