subject: Physics

best_comment: This class is an absolute gem, not because it's no work and super easy, but because Prof Mundy has found the perfect balance between challenging coursework and a stress–free learning experience. I have learned so much from this class because of it. The topic is interesting and relevant, and Mundy's lectures make everything accessible and exciting. The problem sets are adequate and the tests are totally doable. As long as you go to class, which is easy because its great, and do the psets, the tests truly feel like an opportunity to demonstrate what you have learned.
worse_comment: I found this course to be very unsatisfying in terms of the physics covered. The pacing is very slow, and the course focuses on applying different models of solid–state interactions while brushing past most of the interesting quantum mechanics behind it all. Lectures were clear but slow–paced and repetitive, making it hard to pay attention at times. Midterms were fair, but it was hard to prepare for them given the lack of practice materials. It's a decent light–workload class if you're not overly concerned with rigor, though.
subject: Physics

best_comment: Take the course if you can commit the time and energy
worse_comment: Don't take this course if you have a heavy workload. It won't work out well and also it won't help you actually learn the material.
subject: Physics

best_comment: Great class taught by Girma. You will learn a LOT in particle physics.  Lectures zoom by in classic Girma fashion, but it will become clear after a while. Problem sets are fair and guide you through. Overall, the class manages to provide an amazing scope of topics with quite a lot of depth, without feeling overwhelming. It is a great class to take before QFT, and will also teach you many topics from 143b very quickly (not saying you should skip it though). The final projects are about researching a famous experiment, which is great for anyone doing research in high–energy experiment. Hao was a fantastic TF, both Hao and Girma are very accessible
subject: Physics

best_comment: Definitely take this class!! I highly recommend. Not only is it probably required, but it's also extremely useful, and I unexpectedly enjoyed every part of it. Eslam and Patrick are wonderful: they do a great job at explaining the material, and they are super receptive to feedback and questions. They are one of the best teaching teams I have ever had. I gained a much deeper intuition behind many more complicated quantum topics, and learned some nice math tricks along the way. It's one of these classes in which you're reminded of the joys of physics. It's great.
subject: Physics

best_comment: tbh, matt's class strongly feels like thanksgiving dinner over at grandma's place. when the feast is laid out in front of you, everything looks so good and you cant wait to dig in. qft was a very exciting subject for me as this was the class that was supposed to really help me understand all the pop science that i had seen before, sort of like general relativity in some regard. the first dozen bites are amazing, and grandma's food tastes as good as always. the first few classes were manageable and i did feel pretty good about the course. however, at some point things start to become fuzzier and fuzzier after around 3–4 weeks, and from then on its all down hill without stopping. back to the analogy, after some point you get full and you want to stop eating, but grandma keeps bringing food out and insisting that you keep eating. you protest and try to tell her that you are full but she is too old and daft to hear anything and keeps piling more grub onto your plate anwyay. after about halfway into feynman's beautiful work that is qed, things actually just stop making sense, and every other class you feel like you go to class but your sleep–deprived half–dazed self cannot keep up with matt's insane lecturing speed, and you end up walking out of class realizing after 5 seconds that you just learnt nothing. in light of this, the problem sets remain unrelenting. this class really and truly made me feel the sentiment behind the saying "the universe does not care about your suffering". just because you don't understand qft doesnt mean that the qft psets are going to do themselves for you. often times, i dont learn that much in class and i end up learning the material by doing the problem sets anyways. the problem sets themselves are chock full of tedious calculations and at many points require certain logical jumps that only a genius could come up with by themselves. asking for help is key in this class, and it is my good fortune that mincheol and xiaoyuan are wonderful teaching staff, always willing to help a struggling student. by the way, an undergrad course assistant and a grad tf is way too little teaching staff for a class of this size. many times, office hours would be full of dying students struggling on psets and poor xiaoyuan/mincheol has to run between different people to answer questions. often times they extend their OH as well, which is often much–appreciated. as for matt, even though he lectures really fast, he teaches well given the time he has and he always makes students feel welcome by never hesitating to answer questions, something which i really appreciate. plus he is really approachable during office hours, which is rare to come byi personally feel that the course consumed my soul this semester, and for good reason. having to relearn the material through the problem sets was extremely inefficient but in fact was actually very helpful to force me to actually realize what i dont understand and then try to tackle them. problem sets took me a good 30+ hours per week, but im more on the slow side when doing calculations so that might not be accurate for everyone. and even though i did all that, i would say i came out of the class having a good idea of how to calculate things, but not really understanding what the material is about. even still, i learnt a lot of physics, which still goes to show how deep the material really is. and even though a lot of people who took qft under other instructors like to think that they are superior, at least i know what a neutrino is, cant really say the same for you guys :)this course truly is like grandma's thanksgiving meal, because even though u kinda suffered at the end and had to drag yourself through the finish line, you still come back every year for more. i suffered in this class but it showed me how challenging this field is and just how brilliant the physicists who took part in contributing to this immaculate theory were. im definitely taking 253b under matt next year
Strongly encourage anyone planning to do research in formal high energy theory to take this course!
subject: Physics

best_comment: To clarify (e.g. for future waiver applications): at least in 2023, the part of the syllabus referring to 'phase transitions and critical points' included the renormalisation group and the epsilon expansion.Vinny is a fantastic lecturer who not only explains course content clearly and engagingly, but who also tends to teach as much of the broader motivation and historical context as possible. You'll come out of the course with a deep understanding of what entropy is (spoiler: it's not disorder) and how to resolve associated apparent paradoxes, and also with an idea as to the diversity of applications of statistical mechanics in current research. I'll prewarn that the final section of the course gets a bit pacy, and from certain conversations, I've heard it's important to choose final projects carefully.
subject: Physics

best_comment: This is a great course! Lots of fun topics, but be prepared for fairly technical and difficult problem sets. Subir is a great lecturer and his notes are excellent if you want to go even further in depth with all of the details. Highly recommended for anyone who is interested in condensed matter theory.

course_title: Modern Atomic and Optical Physics I 001
best_comment: Take it if you have the right background. I enjoyed it and learned a lot, but I also struggled a lot. Perhaps i would have gotten infinitely more had i take some other classes that would have thoroughly presented the material covered in 285b. Prof. Yelin and Abigail were fabulous, and i think lecture were overall engaging and always very interesting. Perhaps some were a little disorganized and hard to follow, but Prof. Yelin is extremely knowledgeable and super friendly/accessible, so you can always reach out to her and ask questions

course_title: Modern Atomic and Optical Physics II 001
best_comment: This class is not really that good. There are much easier ways to learn AMO than taking this class. Sure, you learn a lot of AMO, but at a high cost. The first pset takes 25 hours and is the hardest of the semester, but that is mainly because it has questions that the class covers 2 months into the semester. So you spend a lot of hours just reading other textbooks to figure out what is happening, and you learn a good chunk of the course in that one pset. The final project is not that difficult since you get to work with a group. The course has one hour of office hours every two weeks with the TFs, and then Lukin has weekly office hours, but they are not the most helpful. Maybe it is because this is a grad class, but if you are lost on a problem, the TFs won't tell you how to do it. They will give you hints, but if you are lost and can't understand the hints, all you can do is hope one of your friends knows how to do it. Also, the problems are very hand–wavy, so you can't even really rigorously do the calculations, and you just have to ask the TFs which approximations are allowed and which are not. Furthermore, only pset 1 was graded for me after around a month, and then the remaining 5 psets were graded after the final project. This means I had one piece of feedback the entire course, so I could not tell where I needed to improve before it was too late to do anything. Some grad students are required to take this, but generally the undergraduates cared more about getting things right because of grades. This meant that when undergraduates worked with grad students on the psets, the undergrads would start early, and then the grad students would just work on it a few days before the biweekly pset is due. This means that the undergrads sort of just work on the psets themselves, which also feeds into the unnecessary difficulty of the class. The class has a reputation of being difficult, but it definitely does not have to be. For instance, if the first pset covered more fundamentals like which parts of quantum people should know instead of material later in the course, then students would be better prepared to tackle those questions after the class teaches it.
worse_comment: In this class, you may struggle, you may fail but you will see everything pays off.

course_title: Inference, Information Theory, Learning and Statistical Mechanics 001
best_comment: Given the very broad range of topics that this class covers, it actually does a remarkably good job giving intuition into each topic and connecting them to one another. But definitely don't expect to come out of the class with a rigorous understanding of any one of them –– this is very much a survey–type class. The first 1/3 of the class (information theory) is definitely the best organized and taught part of the  course. The second 1/3 is statistics (a subset of stat 111 covering MLE and Bayesian stat). Idk, maybe it was just me, but after taking a real stat course, their way of doing things looked pretty sloppy and confusing. The last 1/3 is ML, which was interesting and although it had a fair amount of overlap with cs 181, I still learned a lot of new things and gained some intuition.I did take this class after stat 111 and cs 181, which I wouldn't necessarily recommend since it was a bit repetitive. However, Sharad is an excellent lecturerer and the way he motivated everything using information theory and the perspective of a physicist/biologist was still quite new and interesting to me. I think it says something about the class that I still learned from it even coming in with a decent background.The problem sets for this class were decent, but you kind of had no idea what you were going to get. Sometimes they were super easy, sometimes super hard/fancy coding, and sometimes incredibly tedious algebra. MULTIPLE TIMES they would have these problems that were worded in an incredibly confusing way that nobody could figure out (eg has a paragraph of incomprehensible text and then asks about some variables that aren't even defined in the text). Then, when you went to ask the professor or the TFs they seemed to have no idea what the problem was trying to ask either or would give conflicting / self –contradictory explanations of the question. Like ??? The course staff is super chill, so it's ok. It was just a bit weird LOL.
worse_comment: This was one of my favorite, perhaps the favorite class, I've taken at Harvard. Despite being familiar with some of the material, I was excited to go to lecture and see how Sharad thought about it. We spent ~2 weeks in CS 181 on the expectation maximization algorithm, and Sharad presented it more clearly in 45 minutes. He is an incredibly engaging lecturer and it really feels like he has a deep, intuitive understanding of what he is talking about. The course moves quickly over topics sometimes, but I it is intended to be a survey course, and I think it is an excellent survey course. The one downside I'd say is that it was a bit unclear how to complete some of the problem set questions sometimes, but that was more of minor irritant than a major problem with the course.

course_title: Introduction to Quantum Theory of Solids 001
best_comment: This class is extremely good for anyone looking to introduce themselves to solid state physics, while gaining an in–depth understanding.
subject: Physics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Quantum Theory of Solids

best_comment: Excellent lectures, reasonable workload, and interesting topics –– please take it!

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: This course was EXTREMELY helpful for me this semester while I was working on a scientific paper. I found that the structure and content of the course was very applicable to my writing, and I was able to make enormous progress on my writing over the course of the semester. I am very grateful for the feedback and insight Suzanne provided, as well as for the peer–review part of the course. It is most helpful if you are working on some sort of writing over the course of the semester. The coursework was not difficult but since most of the assignments are related to a final deliverable of a paper/statement/proposal it is a situation where you entirely get out what you put it. I think this course would be very helpful for any scientist who wants to communicate effectively or who wants to lessen the intimidation of writing some work up.I even found that the process of writing the paper as laid out in the course was helpful for me to plan future research efforts and streamline my day–to–day work as a graduate student.

course_title: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences I 001
worse_comment: I would tell students not to worry too much about notation. I think I got too stressed in early weeks obsessing over notation rather than understanding the key messages and takeaways.

best_comment: The content was interesting, but definitely an overwhelming amount of terminology. regardless of if you have a psych background, STAY ON TOP OF THE WEEKLY READINGS. just save yourself the pain. the exams are relatively fair but incredibly nit–picky. You have to be able to recall very specific examples and terminology from both the lectures and readings. You are graded almost entirely on your exam performance, but no practice exams are given because there is apparently no point in giving practice questions on content that therefore can't show up on the exam, but you will also be required to know that testing is one of the most efficient ways to remember course content (this was an actual exam question and the prof was confused why so many people got it wrong). On the bright side, sections are pretty easy to prepare for and participate in, so make sure to opt in for those to help your grade. no final essay is a big plus. side note that sections are not therapy sessions! i.e. don't go on a tangent unrelated to the discussion topic that will make you trauma dump and cry in section. yes students have actually done this. peace and love. other course staff are also very kind and helpful. Prof Noll is awesome.
worse_comment: DON'T take the class. If you are a Psyc major, rethink your choices. This class WILL drop your GPA. It is the most poorly structured class at Harvard. I hated taking it and I wish I hadn't. There is only two multiple choice test and determines your entire grade. It is really unfair and I highly do not recommend this.

best_comment: This class isn’t extremely difficult, but there is a lot you will need to remember for the tests (specific brain regions, experiments, etc.). However, the content is interesting and presented in a pretty engaging way, so if you like psych at all you’ll enjoy the class. Just make sure to go to lecture and study with enough anticipation and you’ll be fine!

best_comment: This course is amazing! Fiery is such a great professor! His enthusiasm for social Psy is infectious and really shows through his lectures. Sections are also really fun! The TFs do a really good job of trying to give first hand experience of the concepts that we learn of in class. Final project is really interesting and and assignments and exams are definitely manageable as well. Take this course if you’re interested!
worse_comment: Take this class, but be weary about assignments. Not many, but grading can be odd. Also, be prepared to be lost about how to study for the midterm and final exams. They offer one or two practice questions and nothing else.
best_gem_comment: I wouldn't call this course a gem, as the workload is relatively intense. You have to read a full textbook *and* another book, write two essays, conduct an experiment in the span of a few weeks, complete weekly discussion posts, and take a midterm and a final. Additionally, the lectures are kind of extemporaneous, so it can be hard to know what to take notes on. However, the content is definitely super interesting and the grading is very fair.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses 001
best_comment: If you can, take this class from Annie! She is an incredibly kind, caring and motivating instructor. Throughout this course, she provided excellent feedback and fostered really good class conversations. Overall, content–wise, this class can be quite dry since topics change quickly and it is more of a survey course for the field of psychology. However, since it is thought in very small sections, you usually get to discuss these concepts in depth, and get to know your classmates really well, which was probably one of the best aspects of PSY971! Definitely stay on top of the work because it can pile up really quickly. Thank you to Annie for making this a great experience!

best_comment: Take this course! Dr. Roberts is a great teacher and highly engaged, and the small seminar format provides numerous opportunities for discussion and developing your own thoughts. It's also a great opportunity to read academic papers and research studies in the field of mood disorders (nearly all the readings are published papers, which you are expected to read and submit comments on ahead of class, so be prepared for this!) and to write your own academic paper reviewing some of the existing literature on a topic. This may sound intimidating, but it wasn't nearly as bad as I expected, and can be an enjoyable opportunity to explore the field on your own! I would strongly recommend this class to anyone with sufficient experience – taking PSY1900 or similar is helpful to understand the statistics in papers – and an interest in the topic.

Definitely take this class. You get out of it what you put in, but I think the readings are super interesting and worth doing. Class is more enjoyable if you did the readings and then feel comfortable participating. It is one discussion post a week which is very reasonable and I found the final presentation and paper to be a very enjoyable experience that also allowed me to get closer to a friend and gain a better understanding of their life and how I can be their for them. There is definitely a lot to learn from this class and it was definitely my least stressful class. The work is super super manageable and not hard/stressful, and the professor is very understanding.

best_comment: Great class! Great if you like open–ended seminar classes. The middle of the class readings, “the second module” if you will get a bit dense. It starts to get a lot into the neuro part of ptsd which I’m not really interested in so that part of the semester was a little rough for me because I found the readings kind of dry.  So keep that in mind if you don’t like reading about the neuroscience behind disorders.
worse_comment: Take any class with Travis that you can!!! If you're interested in PTSD or trauma at all, you'll learn a lot in this course. It's very much "you get out what you put in," so it's basically as difficult as you make it.

best_comment: Fantastic class! If you are at least slightly interested in eating disorders, you must take this course. Dr. Shingleton is an incredibly kind and caring instructor, and she is also an expert in the field of EDs, so you will definitely learn a lot from her. This class is especially helpful for breaking some of the taboos around EDs and understanding how these disorders can actually look like in real life. It was also great that there was a lot of flexibility around assignments (i.e., no set deadlines for the response papers), which gave me the opportunity to balance the assignments with my schedule. With that being said, make sure you are not leaving those papers to last week because then it gets really busy around the end of the semester. Overall, phenomenal course — changed my perspective & learned so much, 10/10!
worse_comment: Alright class. Pretty interesting readings. One of the more structured seminar classes I’ve been in. I was stressed about the capstone project but it wasn’t that bad . I would start early if you can to get it over with
subject: Psychology

best_comment: Life–changing class (not exaggerating). IMO, this class is 40% standard lecture–type, research–backed information on the topics in the syllabus and 60% Professor Langer dropping wise anecdotes/insights o positivity from her own long, joyful, well–accomplished life. I've really internalized some of the things Professor Langer has said—her explanations are really informative and provide a unique perspective that I've found really valuable—and that has shaped my whole mindset and outlook for the better. From adopting these thoughts from this class, I've noticed myself becoming more optimistic and experiencing more positive mood/emotion OVER THE COURSE OF THIS VERY SEMESTER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! She has some unique–yet–beneficial positive takes on life overall, and while I haven't found myself completely agreeing with all 100% of them, the perspectives she gives have integrated well into my existing conceptions and shaped them for the better. Also, go to lecture ––  I've gotten the most out of this class from any I've taken at Harvard and I'm a CS major. If you can't take the class, I'd recommend to sit in on it or read some of her other work or something
subject: Psychology

course_title: The Science and Psychology of Music 001
best_comment: Take PSY1018 if you can! Professor Piccolo is a great lecturer and is really enthusiastic about the material we cover in class. He does a great job discussing the association between psychology and music, but also is happy to talk about any concepts we're interested in outside of class. He also tries to make the class as engaging as possible (especially since it's a 9am) by encouraging students to perform and showcase their music skills. He also is super understanding about life events happening, so never feel afraid to reach out for an extension. He is truly there to support and care for his students academically and otherwise! You'll learn a lot from this class about the benefits of music to one's mental, emotional, and even physical health, I fully recommend it!
worse_comment: Do not be afraid to communicate with the professor. He is extremely understanding and will try to accommodate for anything that you are having trouble with.

best_comment: It is a great class. Everything is pretty reasonable, the prof is very nice, and class was as fun as class can get in my opinion. I don't have any feedback for improvement (and I usually have a lot for most classes!). It's not the lowest in terms of workload in the psych department (like there are weekly assignments, 3 short papers, a final project, etc) but it's definitely super manageable and pretty interesting. The professor is super accessible and understanding and does a great job creating engaging slides and "lecturing" us about the material; probably one of the least boring classes I've done
best_gem_comment: this class is a GEM!!! tanya is a wonderful lecturer and person in general––super nice, releases grades quickly, talks fast (I love this but this is just a personal preference)classes are a good split between lecture and discussion, but discussion isn't baseless/useless to fill time like it is in lots of other classes.the weekly topic summaries are super quick and easy, and the papers don't take very long either. the papers were actually really fun to write!overall, a really well structured and interesting class with a wonderful teacher:) if you can, definitely take this class!

best_comment: Great course. It is a bit technical and you will not necessarily look forward to every lecture, BUT Professor Lukas still manages to make every class as interesting and engaging as possible and manages what can be pretty dry material into a funny and lively lecture. Also, while I admittedly would sometimes get bored in class or not be enthused about the process of learning, it is really interesting and important content once you learn it. It is one of the few courses I would talk about outside of classes saying things like "did you know that..." or "I just learned..." I really do feel like I learned a lot. It is definitely one of the more impactful courses I have taken at Harvard. I learned a TON about how drugs actually work in the brain and the true risks and benefits of different kinds of drugs and medications. Professor Lukas is incredibly intentional about the course and has very clear purpose for teaching. Yes, he cares about the content of the course and you need to learn some nitty–gritty material, but he generally cares way more about the more overarching lessons and takeaways than the super specific details. Additionally, he clearly cares a ton about the WHY it's important to know the material and emphasizes content that has real world implications, such as emphasizing the true relevant dangers and uses of each drugs. You can just tell he is a compassionate doctor and researcher that is in this field for one reason only: to help patients and reduce suffering. I feel way more knowledgable in the content of this course, but more than that, I feel like I have a much better grasp of why it matters and can distinguish what is fear–mongering and fleeting anti–drug morality versus what is actually relevant as it pertains to people's suffering, addiction, risks, etc. Additionally, it is quite reasonable in terms of workload and expectations. It is pretty low weekly workload if you attend lecture, but it's not necessarily a gem, you likely will need to study and review concepts and it's definitely not an auto A, but it is very manageable and generally, your grade is reflective of what you deserve. The weekly quizzes can sometimes be a little tricky or asked questions that I didn't realize we were expected to learn, but they are very helpful in understanding what he wants you to know for the big exams.

course_title: Brain Damage as a Window into the Mind: Cognitive Neuropsychology 001
best_comment: Fun course! Honestly not sure how much I took away in the grand scheme of my studies, bUt, the material was super interesting, every lecture was interesting and professor Caramazza is really passionate about the material. Sometimes it was unclear what was important, and I wish I had more direction for studying for the exam/more outside support for consolidating information. Sometimes prof didn't explain things the best (especially when asked to go over something) and outside resources could help with this. Overall though, the course was engaging, you learn really cool case studies and will walk away knowing tons of brain disorders and the various dissociations associated with them. It's a good precursor class to find a niche interest!

course_title: Precision Cognitive Neuroscience: Opportunities Afforded by Deep, Intensive Study Within Individuals 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE. It is an absolute GEM because you get to see Prof. Randy Buckner in his element, breaking down his favorite papers from the psych canon in front of you, and also engage with him in class discussions on topics he's super passionate about. I looked forward to it every Thursday. He really pushes you to think about what it means to produce deep and incisive work, regardless of the methods you will choose to use in the future. Oh, and also make sure to schedule office hours with him––he's super insightful and generous! It's an incredible, educational, and fascinating holistic experience with fascinating ideas to engage with.

I'd highly recommend this course to anyone interested in the imagination or looking for a higher level psychology course with a relatively chill workload. Professor Ullman is a great professor, and he really wants students to learn about topics that they are interested in. The discussions can be super interesting–– definitely one of the classes where you get out of it what you put into it. The final paper is an excellent chance to explore a specific topic as well!

This class was so fun and chill! Each week, there are topics that you read about and discuss in class with interesting and concrete takeaways, from politics, to relationships, to identity. Baumeister is so kind and approachable, and it is amazing to hear him talk about his research as an expert in the field.

course_title: Growing up in a Social World 001
best_comment: take this course if you're interested in learning about children! it's a good class and the professor is really kind! I really got to know everyone in the class and made some close friends! there's not too many assignments (1 assignment every other week) so it's not at all that stressful

This class was interesting and did not have that many assignments. The lectures are interesting depending upon what your personal interests are. Some lectures may seem boring compared to others but I really enjoyed some of them. There is a ton of flexibility with the assignments which I really loved too. The final paper was short which was really nice during finals season! Selva is really passionate about her work and shes really sweet. She is always accessible outside of class and willing to help.
worse_comment: Do not take this class. I regret it so much. Don't take it unless you want busy work, assignments where you just shut off your brain, and to learn maybe a handful of semi–cool things.

course_title: Situational Superpowers: Investigating Interactions between People and Contexts 001
best_comment: AMAZING class, probably my favorite I've taken five semesters into Harvard (as evidenced by the length of this response). I'm a psych minor and thought the class was an absolute GEM –– the readings don't end up being too bad as long as you understand their main points and results/conclusions, and it's really easy to inadvertently hit the (very non–strict) 500–word discussion post guideline while simply explaining your takeaways, so the weekly assignments were really not time–consuming (contrary to my expectations). The "seminar leader" assignment seems like a lot, but it's really just explaining the readings from your chosen week and asking the class to discuss some questions, and Ryan is really helpful with preparing for it. The final paper also ends up being pretty chill because a good chunk of it is regarding your personal takeaways from the literature, which is not hard to write about.Ryan is an awesome professor, really understanding, flexible with assignments, and responsive. At no point in the semester did I ever feel really pressured by this course because most work just followed smoothly from understanding the readings and was evaluated really fairly as long as it was clear you'd thought about the material a bit.  He would frequently go on interesting natural tangents that really helped me 1) mentally connect the course material to other parts of psychology, 2) get insight into parts of psychology I hadn't learned before, and 3) genuinely enjoy and look forward to class each week. If nothing else, I really appreciated a crash course he gave on how to efficiently read a psych paper, which's helped me a LOT with both understanding them and cutting down the time I need to do so, as well as his explanations of some commonly used statistical models in psych papers that I hadn't known about before and served as helpful statistical refreshers. My favorite part of this class was the small seminar discussion feel, since that made it really easy to participate (which was not graded harshly at all) and share/get opinions from Ryan and the class, so oftentimes the class felt like a mutually beneficial dialogue incorporating many different perspectives on why/how something might be the case.I really recommend PSY 1711 as long as you're interested in some of the seminar topics or personality psychology overall. I definitely understand behavioral/personality psychology MUCH better because of this course –– holistically, not solely limited to each week's specific topics –– because of the helpful frameworks/intuition I got throughout the semester. Not much of psychology I've been exposed to before put this much emphasis into how situational factors affect one's personality both short–term and long–term, and I feel much more able think about them both theoretically and with application to better understand my own life now. The course also covers a slew of topics not really touched on in other PSY courses I've taken, from self–concept to social media's impact on personality, and oftentimes really recent research on those subjects. While I was obviously more interested in some topics than others, I thought the class was extremely enlightening overall and definitely had some new takeaways I appreciated from each week. Overall, I thought the breadth this course covered while still keeping a coherent focus on situations' influence on personality psychology was extremely impressive and helpful to learn from, and the class environment/setting made it really easy and enjoyable to do so.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! It is so fun and a very reasonable course load. The lecture may seem scary, but it's not. Ryan is a great instructor too!!

best_comment: This is my FAVORITE class I have taken at Harvard. I would strongly recommend this class to anyone (in any concentration) passionate about these topics, and no background is necessary (perhaps some understanding of philosophical arguments but the readings are very engaging and accessible), but again, would only recommend taking this class with a strong interest in the class description, because every student selected for the class is extremely passionate about the topics, extremely engaged, and ready to form opinions and arguments (with an open mind). Professor Greene is absolutely fantastic and engaging and knows how to encourage discussion while also providing guidance where necessary. He is clearly very knowledgable and a few of the readings we read were written by him. This course is essentially completely discussion based, truly following a "no right answers" motto, but with readings that offer evidence and philosophy allowing for strong arguments to be formulated. This course not only progressed my academic knowledge on these topics but also caused a reevaluation of my morals and beliefs I have and truly feel like I grew as a person in my perception and understanding of myself and the world. The workload is extremely manageable and the assignments provide lots of flexibility in what you write on, which enables you to pursue specific topics you are passionate about. The final paper follows a similar format.

1000% TAKE THIS CLASS! WE don't take about technology and mental health enough and this class completely changed my perspective on social media. I feel like I actually contributed to class discussions and even deleted some social media apps in the process (which led to much better attention span over the semester); Dr. Singh is one of the kindest professors I've had here. She cares about her students, makes class really engaging with frequent discussions and group work. She is extremely knowledgeable in clinical psych, speaks about her own experiences, and is pretty interesting to listen to. The class is super chill, and it never felt like a chore. 2–3 light readings a week and you only have to respond to two in the whole semester, an assignment ~every other week (the longest was a 4–5 page group paper & presentation but we had like 3 weeks for it), and 2 hour lecture once a week flew by (plus she always gave a break halfway through and brought us pizza on presentation day). The weekly appchats (you only do one a smester) were really cool because we got to discuss our own experiences with social media apps, some that I had never even heard of. Getting to design our own app at the end and hear from a principal at a venture capital firm for feedback made me feel like I was at HBS or on Shark Tank. Overall, enjoyed this course so much I'm taking another one with her in the spring so highly highly recommend.
best_gem_comment: Shifali is a true gem. With that said, if you've taken other psychology electives, it can at times feel a bit repetitive. Also, a majority of the class is discussion – we had plenty of engaging discussions, but sometimes the same voices would speak for a majority of the class. I think the class really depends on the students who take it, and the bulk of your learning will be from your peers. Take for Shifali and for the student led discussions, don't take if you are expecting a truly revolutionary class on technology's affect on mental health.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Broken Brains: Mechanisms and Markers of Mental Illness 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this course for anyone who is interested in clinical psychology, neuroscience, or just passionate about learning how to improve mental health. Mayron is such an engaging and kind professor who genuinely cares about his students. In this course, you will be able to learn about the importance of identifying the biological brain basis of different disorders and understanding the role the reward system plays in order to be better able to treat these disorders. We only meet once a week for 2 hours and each week you just have to complete a few short readings and write a 1–2 page reading reaction. The only other assignments are discussion leading once with a partner on the disorder you are interested in presenting on and a final project chapter that makes exam period so much less stressful because you write a section of the chapter with your partner every other week. By the time exams come around, you will already be done writing and will only have to add your infographics and bibliography. This is definitely my favorite psychology class that I have ever taken at Harvard and everyone in my class loved it too!
worse_comment: It is an easy course. There is a reading response every week, a longer project and a presentation. You learn a decent amount but it is not personally my favorite form of learning, because the  course is mostly presentations form other students.

best_comment: Take this class!! I was initially quite nervous about this class but don't let the application tasks scare you. They were honestly not as bad as I was expecting and I came to really enjoy them. We got to explore a stigma of our choice throughout the whole semester and I really appreciated the academic agency that afforded us. Lecture was very interesting and I felt very comfortable with participating. I learned much more about stigma and psychological concepts than I was expecting to. Section was also quite engaging and I loved the discussions. All of the gradings felt fair. The final assignments were pretty manageable, as well as the readings. Speaking of, do the readings! They will be discussed in lecture and you will be expected to comment on them. I felt like Prof H and Sama, my TF, really wanted us to succeed.  While you will have to put in some work, it is worth it and I highly recommend this class!
subject: Psychology

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences 001
best_comment: TAKE THE CLASS!! For those that are looking for an introduction to statistical analysis, this class is it. For those that have taken AP stats/some other type of statistical analysis course, this course will be review for a good part of the semester. You will however get a quick launch into programming in R which in my opinion is extremely useful to know! I personally think the launch into R was a bit quick especially if you do not have any coding experience but the TFs and professor are all amazing and kind so please reach out for help! Hannah was such an amazing TF enroll in her section if you can. She’s so cool I lowkey wish I could be her friend. ***
worse_comment: This class was not fun, however it is a requirement for Psych concentrators so you just gotta get through it. A pset and quiz every week in addition to 2 lectures and an hour and 15 min section was just a lot. Espically when you add in the final project and the three take home exams. Just a lot of work so try to stay on top of it
best_gem_comment: This definitely isn’t as much of a gem as it used to be, but it’s still a pretty solid class. You’ll just have to actually go to lecture, so don’t expect it to as laidback as it has been in previous years. If you’re going into the behavioral sciences in any way, everything you learn here will be super useful for interpreting data and understanding existing research papers.

best_comment: I am not sure how useful machine learning methods will ultimately be for my research (e.g., for more 'data driven' methods, there are still a lot of experimenter degrees of freedom). If you are really pressed for time, it might be worth some pre–preparation on your part to figure out how much your work needs these methods, since the investment you need to put into the class is definitely non–trivial. But, if you have some time to devote to understanding tools leveraged in psychology more broadly – which still might be beneficial to you down the road! – then there is a lot to gain from this class. Learned a ton, even if I do not take it all 'back to the bench' tomorrow.

If interested in learning dev, you will receive a crash–course in the theories in cognitive development. However, do be mindful and cautioned that the reading load may be tough to manage! (that and also the timed 9 hour timed exam in total).

best_comment: It was a great course. I would recommend!

Ashley is amazing and everyone at the lab is nice and helpful. The lab meetings and presentations were really interesting and I loved the feedback people gave. I recommend this lab if you’re interested in psyc research, especially developmental psychology

best_comment: This course can be a great change of pace from a normal class structure. It is interesting to see the behind the scenes of real psychological research. I'd recommend this course to anyone interested in the role of psychology in business, regardless of whether you are specifically looking to go into research. It gives you a new perspective on psychology and provides an opportunity to develop meaningful relationships with researchers at HBS who are doing very interesting work.

This is a pretty unconventional lab. It’s super fun engaging with Ellen in conversation during lab meetings. And testing her hypotheses is fun, but if you want more formal/conventional psych research experience I wouldn’t recommend this lab. I will add that the workload for this lab is super light and is probably a gem for people who need the lab requirement

best_comment: If you've taken a physics undergrad QM course, please take physics251a/b instead of this course. I found this course to no more rigorous––in fact, even easier––than the QM courses I took in undergrad. This course basically covers scattered topics in Griffiths but at a pretty shallow level. It teaches some applications like band structure, rotating wave approximation, quantum info, etc., but I found those to be rather pointless since many people plan to take solid–state, AMO, and QI anyways, which cover those topics more thoroughly. By taking this course instead of a more rigorous grad QM course, I felt underprepared for the other course I took this semester and future physics courses. PSETs and exams are easy but often algebraically tedious, which made them just busywork. The grading also made me feel like I had gone back to high school after graduating undergrad––it's been a hot sec since I've seen points being taken off for not showing enough work even though my answer was correct and I understood what I was doing. But to be fair, the course assignments/sections are very pedagogical and probably useful if you don't have a solid undergrad QM background. And the easier, biweekly PSETs allow for more time spent on research (unlike physics251a where PSETs are weekly).You're required to take this course if you're in QSE, but I would suggest stalling until your later years or until this requirement is relaxed (probably unlikely though).

course_title: Modern Atomic and Optical Physics II 001
best_comment: This class is not really that good. There are much easier ways to learn AMO than taking this class. Sure, you learn a lot of AMO, but at a high cost. The first pset takes 25 hours and is the hardest of the semester, but that is mainly because it has questions that the class covers 2 months into the semester. So you spend a lot of hours just reading other textbooks to figure out what is happening, and you learn a good chunk of the course in that one pset. The final project is not that difficult since you get to work with a group. The course has one hour of office hours every two weeks with the TFs, and then Lukin has weekly office hours, but they are not the most helpful. Maybe it is because this is a grad class, but if you are lost on a problem, the TFs won't tell you how to do it. They will give you hints, but if you are lost and can't understand the hints, all you can do is hope one of your friends knows how to do it. Also, the problems are very hand–wavy, so you can't even really rigorously do the calculations, and you just have to ask the TFs which approximations are allowed and which are not. Furthermore, only pset 1 was graded for me after around a month, and then the remaining 5 psets were graded after the final project. This means I had one piece of feedback the entire course, so I could not tell where I needed to improve before it was too late to do anything. Some grad students are required to take this, but generally the undergraduates cared more about getting things right because of grades. This meant that when undergraduates worked with grad students on the psets, the undergrads would start early, and then the grad students would just work on it a few days before the biweekly pset is due. This means that the undergrads sort of just work on the psets themselves, which also feeds into the unnecessary difficulty of the class. The class has a reputation of being difficult, but it definitely does not have to be. For instance, if the first pset covered more fundamentals like which parts of quantum people should know instead of material later in the course, then students would be better prepared to tackle those questions after the class teaches it.
worse_comment: In this class, you may struggle, you may fail but you will see everything pays off.

best_comment: This course was really one of the highlights of my semester. The course does a great job balancing many things that you might want from an introductory course. In terms of New Testament thought/history, we get fair/detailed treatment of theological/theoretical perspective through the gospels, epistles, and early Patristic theologies. In terms of history, we get a considerable overview from the early Church, heresies, schisms, and the Protestant Reformation into America. Notable too is the time spent on more modern reception ––– Kant, feminism, liberation theology, etc. In terms of methodology/medium, while most of the course is certainly focused on texts, there's considerable exploration beyond philosophy/theology and into art, poetry, personal narrative, etc. Even with the preconceptions of what I thought I wanted from this course (specific interests on aspects of history/theology) and what I thought I already "knew," I learned so much in the variety of new topics as well as in a deepened and changed understanding of areas I thought I knew. The format of the course I think is well–balanced with a variety of readings, a chance for personal reflection with Canvas responses, chance to reflect in class, but also (most appreciated at least in my perspective) a really thoughtful and quite detailed mini–lecture of the concepts introduced in our readings at the beginning of class. This was honestly really helpful in so many ways ––– whether it was explaining certain doctrines of law and sin, the particular context of monastic hierarchies, or just what on earth was being really argued in regards to heresy.  Briefly, too, on some logistics ––– Professor Lamberth is just an amazing person to get to know and makes the classroom experience wonderful. The course never becomes overbearing, either, with grading or workload and just allows you to focus on and enjoy the content of the course.If you're looking for a course that delves really deeply into literary analysis of the Bible or a more theological side to interpreting what is or is not said in the Bible, I think you might be a little let down ––– something like ANE 120A might be more of that exegetical/analytic stuff you're looking for. What this course instead offers, which I think is just as important, is a really informative overview of different ways we can understand the New Testament ––– whether that be identifying some core literary themes of the Scripture and early texts, tracking themes of debate and argumentation within the Church, or studying the changes in modern reception to the New Testament. Even if the course isn't a theological Bible study of the text or a debate–driven course on what the New Testament does or doesn't say about modern ethical issues, this course is wonderful for equipping you with a lot of critique yet respect for the tradition. I walked away realizing how much more complicated and diverse the Christian tradition is, and I think that students find this regardless of whether they are students of religion, people of personal belief in the religion, agnostic or atheistic skeptics of the religion, etc.

If you have the space for this course and even a passing interest in the New Testament, I highly recommend taking this course. Unlike some other "introduction" courses I've taken at Harvard, this is an actual introduction to the New Testament. The readings are fascinating and Professor Dunning is an excellent lecturer. Trust me, you'll have a great time.
subject: Religion

best_comment: Highly recommend! Professor Brekus is incredibly knowledgeable, thoughtful, and kind. As an undergrad this will give you the chance to interact with Divinity school students which is a unique opportunity. I thought this class gave a very fair and balanced treatment of the history of Catholicism, not shying away from the good or the bad parts of the past, while also while encouraging students to share their own perspectives. If you are interested in the history of Catholicism in America... learning about Dorothy Day, the Kennedys, the Jesuits, Fulton Sheen, John Ireland, John Carroll, Maria Monk, nuns, and immigrants... take this class! Even if you think you know a lot, there is still much more to learn.

course_title: Contemporary Conversations in the Study of Religion: Seminar 001
best_comment: This course essentially teaches you how to be a PhD student successfully, and how to prepare for the exams, prospectus, dissertation and job market phases of one's career. Once you've gone through a year of doctoral work already, many (though by no means all) aspects of the course will seem very easy, even redundant, e.g. preparing a conference paper (most of us will have presented more than one of these by this point). If this course were taught in the first semester of the program, it would be more challenging, but also substantially more rewarding. That said, give the assignments your best – they helped me develop ideas that I think will prove really beneficial for exams and prospectus–writing.

The course would be great for anyone interested in thinking more about / getting deeper into decolonial theory. The readings cover key ideas/themes in decolonial thought, and Dr. Rivera leads class discussions through these ideas in thoughtful and intentional ways.  Sometimes I felt like I was barely following class discussions and that I wasn't understanding the cool thoughts from everyone, but I think nevertheless what I learned from the class helped me think in interesting and creative ways & the class was interesting and challenging!

course_title: Beginning French I: Cross-Cultural Encounters in French 001
best_comment: In my opinion French 10 is a good class to take to fulfill your language requirement. It doesn't take that much time at all outside of class as all of the homeworks are due on the day of the quiz. The only work I ended up putting in outside of class was the night before the quizzes when I completed all the homework for the unit and the review packet. I found that this worked well because I ended up learning most of the material just through the fact that we had class 4 times a week. Would definitely not recommend skipping class as that is where most of the learning is done and it is hard to catch up if you miss. I think the TFs are very good, I loved Claire and thought she was a great teacher and very enthusiastic. Overall I enjoyed French 10 and thought it was a relatively easy class to balance the rest of my schedule while also being a great class to learn the language, and I feel like I got a lot out of it.

best_comment: This was a great course to get exposure to the French language and its inner workings and nuances. It's very useful if you want to start learning the French language but don't have the time/capacity to commit to the more intensive immersion courses. But, it really is focused on reading French material, if you're looking at building strong writing and oral communication skills, this may not be the best course for you.

course_title: Intermediate French: Francophone Culture in Local Communities 001
best_comment: Take this course if you must for a requirement or if you are interested in learning languages and want to learn French. If you want to learn French, this is a great course. Be aware that you will not be learning much about French culture, mostly about the culture of French–speaking countries in Africa. Also, be aware that Professor Turman does not actually teach this course and as a student, you will most likely never see her. The course is taught entirely by your section professor. Professor Barfield was great.
subject: French
course_title_2024: Intermediate French: Francophone Culture in Local Communities

course_title: Intermediate French: Francophone Culture in Local Communities 002
best_comment: After taking this class, my speaking abilities did not improve immensely, but my speech comprehension improved thanks to the full immersion into the language every class. This class is not too difficult, but it is usually discomforting in the first couple days because you essentially required to speak, and subsequently, think in French only. I took French 20 based on my placement score and the fact that Dr. Turman said I made a good fit for the class since I already had the fundamentals from my high school french class (verb conjugations, prepositions, etc.) even though it had not taken it since freshman year. However, since this is an "intermediate" class, students are not expected to be super skilled at speaking. Other than that, the class was good. The homework (Dossiers) are graded on completion and give you more insight on various Francophone countries and vocabulary based on various themes (e.g. education, family, etc.). My advice: Work on them as soon as you receive them. As a STEM student, I kept leaving these assignments off to the last minute because I left my psets consume my time. You'll want to study the vocabulary and grammar sooner rather than later as well. What I didn't like about the course, but it was necessary, were the Boomalang conversations. You choose which Francophone speaker you want to have a 15–minute conversation with and review the voice recording and complete a reflection on them. Sometimes I felt uncomfortable with attempting to create new sentences when talking to my speaker, but it pushed me to think more on the spot.The quizzes were okay. The prof provided practice quizzes so that we could sharpen our grammar, and they are generous when it comes to grading them in terms of spelling errors or wrong conjugations. You'll also have to write two 400–500 word compositions based on a theme they assign you. But luckily, they provide a pre–write assignment, which basically has you answering questions that help you make an outline of your composition. Lastly, the Experience Culturelle Project is essentially your final. You have to participate in a French activity and essentially create an in–depth reflection about your experience and then present your findings in presentation in front of your class. Thankfully, the class provides a couple of opportunities for you to complete your project (e.g. Haitian Folkloric and West African dance classes). When I presented I was extremely nervous and I would mispronounce some of the words or spoke too fast. However, know that everyone else in class that has to present is probably feeling the same as you. The culturelle project presentation may be the first time you will have presented in front of others speaking only in French. Oh! And one more thing: Do not be intimidated. What do I mean? There will be students in your French class that will have various strengths compared to you. Some may be better at speaking in French, but have poor writing or grammar skills. The purpose of this class is to help refine and introduce grammar that you'll see more frequently as you continue learning more about the Francophone language. In short, this class is doable, just complete your assignments on time and genuinely practice on sharpening your French vocabulary and practice speaking everyday phrases.
subject: French
course_title_2024: Intermediate French: Francophone Culture in Local Communities

course_title: Intermediate French: Francophone Culture in Local Communities 003
best_comment: I greatly enjoyed this course and I feel like I have made lots of progress in my speaking and listening because of this course. The course is helpful for learning lots of French grammar as well. It pushes you and helps you grow without being so challenging that it is burdensome or "drowning." Professor Reynes specifically was great. I also enjoyed the fact that we focus on French culture outside of the country France, looking at other parts of the world.
subject: French
course_title_2024: Intermediate French: Francophone Culture in Local Communities

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 001
best_comment: It can be a bit rushed. It also feels like the course doesn't know what it wants you to learn besides the grammar, so parts feel very unrelated.
subject: French
course_title_2024: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 002
best_comment: I enjoy learning French, but not too much the structure of this class. It was not my favorite course, but there was NOT a lot of demanding work. It is manageable. The course could be a great choice if you are looking for a light class. I think it is very likely to get a good grade if you submit your assignments. However, I took this course as a requirement for my language citation. Overall, I enjoyed French 20 more. However, the feedback you received is great and helped me a lot to improve my writing skills.
subject: French
course_title_2024: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 003
best_comment: This course taught me a lot about the world of French–speaking media around the world and exposed me to current events in the French–speaking world. We explored many aspects of media. We explored topics like politics, history, economics, entertainment, environment, all of which are important topics in the media. This course has made me more equipped to engage in meaningful conversations in French and I am happy to have taken 30 French courses this semester.
subject: French
course_title_2024: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World

course_title: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema 001
best_comment: Marie was an amazing TF and Madame Brisson was so helpful for this course
subject: French
course_title_2024: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema

course_title: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema 002
best_comment: This class is GREAT!! Not too stressful at all but you still learn a lot and it's valuable. Plus, the final movie project is a great way to meet other students in the class and have fun while learning. Love it!***
subject: French
course_title_2024: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema

course_title: Advanced French II: Justice, Equity, Rights, and Language 001
best_comment: This is a good class! Dr. Turman is very passionate and brings her personal travels into the class. I learned a lot about how to express my views on important issues outside of just the regular Duolingo "this is an apple" lol. The exchange program is great for improving speaking skills, and even though it might feel like a lot of writing work, it really is necessary to help improve your writing.
subject: French
course_title_2024: Advanced French II: Justice, Equity, Rights, and Language

course_title: Advanced French II: Justice, Equity, Rights, and Language 002
best_comment: You should take this, it is a great class!!! There is more homework for the first month or so, but after that it is very manageable. Quizzes are not too difficult, although they are always in different formats, and ample feedback is provided on the writing assignments – they do not have to be perfect to get a good grade. There is a decent amount of homework for every class. Dr. Turman is incredible, and her enthusiasm makes the discussions good. Can be attainable if you are a first–year and have taken French extensively in high school and placed into it (don't be intimidated).
subject: French
course_title_2024: Advanced French II: Justice, Equity, Rights, and Language

course_title: Exploring French Language in North America through Text, Image, and Culture 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Dr. Brisson is amazing and is great to talk to. You will learn a lot about North America and will be able to engage with so many great authors not only by reading their materials, but you will also be able to see them in person and see their unique perspectives live! Dr. Brisson has amazing connections is so passionate about the subject, and truly understands students. Even if you have no strong interest in north America definitely take this course because I am positive you will learn a lot, and develop a strong interest or at least a very well–defined perspective of north American french.
subject: French
course_title_2024: Exploring French Language in North America through Text, Image, and Culture

course_title: Mother Dearest: French and Francophone Writers Confront the Maternal 001
best_comment: you should definitely take this class! Prof. Kim is totally wonderful. Very kind, understanding, and cool. The class is not too stressful, and you will learn a lot. Also the discussions are awesome. This is a class where you will actually want to go to class and you will actually want to do the readings and engage with them. if you do not, you are doing yourself a disservice. It's really enjoyable and you will learn a lot. Also there's no reason to just give up if you get behind because Prof. Kim is often understanding and flexible. like, within reason. And there's not a stressful approach to grading. So you can focus on learning and engaging thoughtfully with the material and actually enjoying yourself. The discussions are really, really good. If you like actually talking and discussing books in great depth and arguing about the material, this is definitely the class for you! If you like slacking off, this is not the course for you!
worse_comment: This is an excellent french class! You will get out what you put in but with Professor Kim it is very low stress.

course_title: The Politics and Aesthetics of Mourning 001
best_comment: This course was amazing! The texts were all varied and approached the topic from a variety of perspectives.  The class was small but very engaged and the assignments were fair in grading and manageable in workload. The one book a week could be tough at times but it was generally spaced out very well. The professor was also very welcoming and if you're not 100% confident in your French, it is a supportive environment to improve too.

* The course was lovely! It made me ask questions I would’ve never thought to ask. * If you get the chance to take a class with Janet, I recommend it!! * The readings were complex but very insightful. * I also really enjoyed the film we watched together. I had an amazing time in this class and I will be carrying it with me for a long time!
worse_comment: Keep on top of reading, little by little, during the week – in order to avoid weekend reading landslides.

best_comment: Take this class. Be ready for some analytical writing, but the content is so interesting and worth it. If you want to improve your French skills (writing, speaking, reading), take this class because you'll be exposed to French every week in a small section where Prof. Rodriguez makes everyone feel comfortable to participate. Also, Prof. Rodriguez is great and has curated a very fun and high–quality syllabus!

course_title: Beginning Italian I - Parliamo Italiano! Pathways to Italy 001
best_comment: TAKE ITALIAN 10 it is incredible and especially if you are with Prof. Tragni (who is a living angel on this planet and the most incredible person). If you are willing to just put in the effort, the payoff is huge. We learned so much so quickly and had a ton of fun along the way. The course is structured very well and the quizzes are entirely reasonable. The final presentation is such a great wrap–up for the semester and the THAs are honestly so fun. Studying a few times a week and just trying to speak with others in the class is the best way to go about doing well in it, just increasing the comfort level and fluidity of speech. You definitely don't need any romance language experience if you just have an open mind and try your best. Prof. Tragni's incredible teaching skills and kindness made this class such a tight–knit community that I was genuinely excited to see every morning. Her passion and love for what she does made this class what it was. This class was a very special experience and I'm so excited to continue learning the language and culture because of my experience in itl10.

course_title: Beginning Italian I - Parliamo Italiano! Pathways to Italy 001

course_title: Beginning Italian I - Parliamo Italiano! Pathways to Italy 002
best_comment: I loved ITAL 10 and highly recommend! It is so cool to see yourself progress in a new language in only just a few months. I had Becky (Rebecca) and she was such a wonderful instructor who created a very supportive, engaging, and fun classroom environment. The nightly online homework assignments can be somewhat tedious at times, but they are very helpful. I would recommend staying on top of the vocab and grammar that you learn throughout the course because everything builds on the previous content that you learned.
worse_comment: Extremely good language class, doesn't focus too much on grammar, but allows you to have simple conversations in no time

course_title: Beginning Italian I - Parliamo Italiano! Pathways to Italy 002
