course_title: Beginning Italian I - Parliamo Italiano! Pathways to Italy 003
best_comment: This is a great class with a few bugs. The online exercises can be problematic, but overall, I had a great experience in the class and would definitely recommend. Try and get a good instructor (like Vincent Leung – he was awesome!) and you should really enjoy the class.

course_title: Beginning Italian I - Parliamo Italiano! Pathways to Italy 003
best_comment: This is a great class with a few bugs. The online exercises can be problematic, but overall, I had a great experience in the class and would definitely recommend. Try and get a good instructor (like Vincent Leung – he was awesome!) and you should really enjoy the class.

course_title: Beginning Italian II - Parliamo Italiano! The Art & Craft of Italy 001
best_comment: This class is a lot of work, but the classroom environment is one of the rarest gems on this campus. You have so many opportunities to speak and practice Italian in supportive and engaged yet with low/no stakes, and I feel like my skills and confidence improved tremendously. Amelia is an incredible teacher and the Italian community is amazing!

course_title: Beginning Italian II - Parliamo Italiano! The Art & Craft of Italy 001
best_comment: This class is a lot of work, but the classroom environment is one of the rarest gems on this campus. You have so many opportunities to speak and practice Italian in supportive and engaged yet with low/no stakes, and I feel like my skills and confidence improved tremendously. Amelia is an incredible teacher and the Italian community is amazing!

course_title: Intermediate Italian: The Colors of Italian Pop Lit 001
best_comment: Please take this class! It's so much fun. The work is much easier than ITAL 11, no VHL, and the assignments are actually fun. The class is smaller so there is more close interaction, which makes it more fun. Katie also made this class so enjoyable, she has an amazing, bright personality and makes going to class everyday a joy. Even if Katie doesn't teach this class, the teachers in this department do their best to make this course fun and enjoyable for everyone, especially since they appreciate students showing continued interest in this department and language.

course_title: Intermediate Italian: The Colors of Italian Pop Lit 001
best_comment: Please take this class! It's so much fun. The work is much easier than ITAL 11, no VHL, and the assignments are actually fun. The class is smaller so there is more close interaction, which makes it more fun. Katie also made this class so enjoyable, she has an amazing, bright personality and makes going to class everyday a joy. Even if Katie doesn't teach this class, the teachers in this department do their best to make this course fun and enjoyable for everyone, especially since they appreciate students showing continued interest in this department and language.

course_title: The Cosmos of the Divine Comedy 001
best_comment: This class is AMAZING. Hands down one of the best I've taken in my entire college career. Professor Pistoja is SO passionate about the text, and so knowledgeable, that class is really a pleasure even if it's two and a half hours long. This is a text I don't think I would ever have understood if I read it by myself, but you get so so much out of it from this class. If you are remotely interested, please take it. The workload is super manageable and Prof. Pistoja and Katie are willing to be super accommodating with everything. Even though this is a lecture, it often felt like a seminar which was great. That being said, I think it lacked a tiny bit of structure.
worse_comment: I have nothing but good things to say about this class–––take it!!
subject: Italian
course_title_2024: The Cosmos of the Divine Comedy

best_comment: This class is difficult because of the volume of reading and complexity of ideas, but the content and the structure of the class ended up being one of the most rewarding courses that I've taken. Since it was taught in Italian this semester, I was very pleased with how much my language capacity improved throughout the semester and was challenged to create my own perspective based on the readings. It was daunting at first, but then I started to connect more with the reading and gained confidence. Prof. Erspamer focused a good portion of the class on our own ideas, which lead to a sort of lecture and then discussion format in the class.

course_title: Beginning Portuguese I: From Cambridge to Copacabana 001
best_comment: Great class, all the Portuguese professors are so nice and welcoming, especially Marcia. Our class was always full of laughter and I looked forward to going to class each day. Super supportive environment to learn a new language in!
best_gem_comment: The Portuguese department and community at Harvard is a hidden gem, truly. You will be introduced to so much more than just the language, and you can go as far as you'd like with it. Marcia is a FANTASTIC professor that is so passionate about Brazilian culture, it makes this class worth its M–Th 9am time slot. BEWARE, however, there is a new professor coming in Spring 2024 that may or may not change your opinion of the course. Although, I've heard that the new prof is using the same course materials Marcia has been using, so it may not be that drastic of a change. If you're even slightly considering the course for your language req, which you probably are since you're reading this, TAKE IT. No regrets. This class has motivated me to go as far as getting my language citation in Portuguese :)
subject: Portuguese
course_title_2024: Beginning Portuguese I: From Cambridge to Copacabana

course_title: Beginning Portuguese for Spanish Speakers I: Português Beyond Portuñol 001
best_comment: Marcia is the BEST professor and educator. She is so empathetic and kind and genuinely cares about her students. Marcia went out of her way to ensure I stayed on top of the class during a major transition point in my life. She helped me learn not just Portuguese but also helped me learn so much about Brazilian culture. I have been in higher education for over 10 years and she is among one of the best educators I have interfaced with. You will not regret taking this course with her!
subject: Portuguese
course_title_2024: Beginning Portuguese for Spanish Speakers I: Português Beyond Portuñol

course_title: Beginning Portuguese for Spanish Speakers I: Português Beyond Portuñol 002
best_comment: TAKE THIS! Jacque is an incredible instructor and the entire Portuguese department is awesome. It is a fun and beautiful language and not as identical to Spanish as some might think. You don't need to have mastery of Spanish to take this course either. This was such a fun and interesting course and not once did I not enjoy a class.
subject: Portuguese
course_title_2024: Beginning Portuguese for Spanish Speakers I: Português Beyond Portuñol

course_title: Intermediate Portuguese I: Justice, Equity and Rights in the Lusophone world 001
best_comment: Marcia is an extremely enthusiastic and friendly instructor who obviously cares deeply about the topics discussed in the class and the learning of the students in the class. The themes discussed in the class are interesting and relevant for people interested in learning about societal issues in Portuguese–speaking nations as well as what communities are doing to try to foster change. There are a variety of different and slightly numerous assignments throughout the course, but the workload is by no means overwhelming.  We also received visits from people working on issues we discussed in class, which was very cool and engaging. I would highly recommend taking this course if you are at all interested! And if you are not, it is an opportunity to learn a lot of new things from a great instructor!
subject: Portuguese
course_title_2024: Intermediate Portuguese I: Justice, Equity and Rights in the Lusophone world

subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: This course is great for people who are very committed to learning Spanish (and are beginners) and people who have a some background in the language but need to fulfill their language requirement. If you do not fall into one of these groups (e.g. you are a complete beginner who is looking for a relaxed introduction to the language or to fulfill your language requirement), you should take another course! This course is very fast–paced and the volume of work is surprisingly high. The grading is also a bit harsher than in other RLL courses. That said, if you want to learn Spanish quickly and are willing to put in the work, this is the perfect opportunity.
worse_comment: Do not take this class if you do not want to spend more time on your language requirement than your actual concentration. There is no structure to the course at all whatsoever and every section is doing something different. The class is not taught very well and you are expected to know how to speak Spanish from the get go even though it is supposed to be an intro to Spanish class.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: I have a MOUTH FULL to say about this course, let me just tell you. Patricia has tried her best, and I try not to blame her, however, the structure of the course is really poor. For an INTRO to Spanish class, there is !A LOT! that is expected from you, and Patricia will spend little to know time reinforcing concepts that we've learned in the past, she just expects that you know them. Once again, for an introductory class, this is unbelievable. You would think there is more built–in support so that students can go over things they have learned again and again so that it solidifies in their brain. The whole idea of learning a language is repetition, repetition, and more repetition. There was little to none of that in this course; we would just breeze through topics week after the next. What's the rush? Just slow the course down.The whole expectation is that YOU make time for office hours and go in and practice with her more... why? Everyone needs more help and practice, why can't you just build it into the class? On top of all of this, the quizzes and exams have been HEINOUS! There are no study–guides, no review, nothing. One time, during class, a student asked Patricia "so, what is the expectation for the exam? What material is good a good idea to review?" And Patricia just said to study everything in the past. Every. Single. Thing? Really? It was insane. The least she could've done is curated a list of verbs that we should know (as they were scattered EVERYWHERE in Canvas rather than in one concise place), and small topics that we should review (for example, telling us that we should know our colors, or we should know how to describe someones appearance, or we should know how to talk about the past). Honestly, this course has been INSANE and one of the worst I've taken in my time here as a student at Harvard. I am just so disappointed and I really hope that the structure takes a huge hit and changes.
worse_comment: This is a good intro, but be careful who you get as a professor. Some grade much harshly in comparison to others which makes it much for difficult if you haven't already taken spanish before.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: It is mildly stressful but fun and productive.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: This is a great course, but is a little challenging if you have never taken Spanish. Jorge is the best teacher ever and is passionate about languages. You really do learn a lot, which is really cool. I think if you've never taken any Spanish before just know that it will definitely move fast, but the workload is fairly light on the day to day bases.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: This was a great course! It was challenging in terms of being a lot of material in a short amount of time but I found the resources and my instructor to be very helpful. I am excited to continue taking Spanish here at Harvard.
worse_comment: don't slack, make sure you know the grammar. I went into this thinking it would be my easy, no work class but it ended up being more demanding than I expected. I still managed an A– but I hated this class
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: It's really not that bad. The only downside is that it is conducted in spanish but you get used to it after 2 weeks. The homework is light and the class is super organized with reading and materials. If you go to class and submit assignments on time you should have no problem getting an A.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: Great organization within the course. You generally will get good support, and learning the language is mostly self–determined. So if you work hard independently, you'll have a good chance. But the classes themselves don't teach you a ton other than basic practice.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: This class is not bad for an intro–level language course. Although they go pretty quickly because there are seven units to cover, it can be manageable. This also holds true for various other language classes here. It would be most helpful to practice Spanish whenever you have the chance if you are learning Spanish for the very first time. It can be easy to fall behind because you are going so fast. I find that if you had a bit of Spanish background from high school, you would have a bit easier of a time.
worse_comment: This class was, while uncomfortable at many times and often a drag to get through when forced to talk to peers, did make me more comfortable with my Spanish speaking than I anticipated.  Many of the explanations for more complex grammar concepts, though, were not nearly explained clearly enough. The practice–oriented model with those concepts often led to confusion, and there are still some concepts that I never truly grasped but did not really need to use on the exams anyways. Overall, the course is effective yet lackluster and rather difficult to sit through at times.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: This class is awesome. Not too difficult and the 4 classes per week seems like a lot but its pretty relaxed and enjoyable so doesn't feel like a chore.
worse_comment: I had quite a bad experience in this class and I think a lot of it had to do with the my TF. At first, Julio can seem nice and funny, but when the course starts to progress he gets blunt with his comments on your assignments and quite rude. Another huge thing I did not appreciate was getting cold called in class all the time and getting corrected after almost every word said (this was not just me it was other students as well). Apparently every other spanish 10 class was given guidance and basically told the questions prior to the quiz and exam, but Julio told us nothing. We would have "mock" quizzes, but he wouldn't grade them in time and the questions were nothing like the actual quizzes. He would suspect so many students of cheating to the point where it felt like he wanted everyone to get in trouble. Don't get me wrong there probably was a lot of use of translators by a lot of students, but he would take out his frustration on everyone within the class. The grading was completely unfair and he would pay so much attention to detail like accents and commas, even though that wasn't the point of the introductory class. If you take this class please choose a different TF, one who motivates you and doesn't try to discourage you.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions.

best_comment: CARLOS IS AN ABSOLUTE GEM I LOVE THEM they were so attentive, so thoughtful, so kind, so intelligent. They made this class so interesting and even though we all came from different backgrounds with different levels of Spanish knowledge, they met us where we were at and expanded upon this and never made us feel lesser than. They are such an incredible professor and human being. We need more people like Carlos in this world. Love love loved Spanish 11. And even if you don't get Carlos for Spanish 11, it's a really great course and you learn a lot!
best_gem_comment: CARLOS IS AN ABSOLUTE GEM I LOVE THEM they were so attentive, so thoughtful, so kind, so intelligent. They made this class so interesting and even though we all came from different backgrounds with different levels of Spanish knowledge, they met us where we were at and expanded upon this and never made us feel lesser than. They are such an incredible professor and human being. We need more people like Carlos in this world. Love love loved Spanish 11. And even if you don't get Carlos for Spanish 11, it's a really great course and you learn a lot!

best_comment: I got a comprehensive Spanish language education in this class in a format that was structured in a very organized, clear way. Every activity or assignment done inside and outside of class contributed to me learning useful language skills and vocabulary. I would recommend taking this class with prior Spanish experience; it goes pretty fast and is taught entirely in Spanish. I would also HIGHLY recommend trying to get Israel as your section teacher. Israel was absolutely amazing. He cared about all of our learning, returned assignments and exams almost instantly and with thorough feedback, and supported us whenever we needed extra help.
This is a wonderful course, Carmen is a fantastic teacher and this is a great way to engage with a new language and meet peers.

You'll be fine. I placed into Spanish 20 and decided to go to 11. It was the best decision. It was definitely a challenging class but totally doable, you'll probably have a ton of friends who are also taking it.
worse_comment: It isn't super difficult to do well as long as you do all of your work and participate in class, but if you don't have a strong background and this is your first college Spanish class, it was quite shocking at first

best_comment: Take this class if you need a relaxed language class to clear a requirement. While there are frequent homework assignments (almost one every class), they are very feasible and only take 20 mins max to complete. If you need help or have any questions the teachers are very accommodating and will do their best to help you.
worse_comment: It’s a moderate level course where there is a lot of busy work sometimes but it is do–able. Study about 1–3 hours for the exam, don’t stress too much about homework or projects they are graded fairly.

best_comment: This is a great language class! It is a very manageable and fair workload. The ends of each unit tend to be a bit more work but other than that it is just three short homework assignments a week. Class is usually engaging and it is a good size for this kind of class.

Solid intro spanish course that (I presume) builds off Spanish 10. I started with just Spanish 11 having taken spanish in high school but been a few years and it was still okay. Your experience will depend VERY MUCH on who your teacher is for section. You will essentially never interact with any other course staff. I highly recommend Maria Jose Guerrero, she is an excellent teacher who helps you stay interested by incorporating currents events history etc into course lessons which is very helpful. Homework 3 days a week but it's relatively light (2–3/5 time & difficulty)

Take this class!!!!!!!!! The hardest part is waking up at 9 am every day, but Xiomara does such a good job at engaging everyone and creating an energetic, positive atmosphere so early in the morning. Learning Spanish through fun activities and interactions with your peers is so much more refreshing and engaging than just taking notes on slides every day in my opinion. Having an exam and presentation/project every other week isn't that easy, but Xiomara isn't strict and they're not that bad if you've tried your best and focused in class! Lastly, Xiomara is such a kind, understanding, patient professor– you won't find someone like her anywhere else. <33

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 001
best_comment: The grading for the written components was quite generous. Also, I went into this course hoping to learn how to speak Spanish better, but the this course did very little to support that. It does help improve your writing ability in Spanish, though.

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 002
best_comment: This class will definitely immerse you into the language! Make sure to keep up with the readings and assignments because test will pop up on you and come very quickly. Come to class prepared with questions  – especially on grammar – because the canvas instructions only give a simple overview.

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 003
best_comment: Response from an FGLI FYRE Student: I am a native speaker but I wanted to take this course to improve my writing skills. The beginning of the course was easy, but it got harder in the middle of the year. I think some of the assignments aren't as clear, so please ask questions whenever you are confused. My preceptor Daisy was a fair grader, but then she left for maternity leave and our work was graded by the head TF Ruy. He is honestly a way better grader and he has a kind soul. For the most part Daisy was a good professor but there were some moments where she kind of made snarky comments. She does honestly want her students to learn Spanish though. She always came to class with a smile on her face asking everyone how they were doing and she encouraged everyone to expose themselves to Spanish by traveling abroad. I recommend this class to improve your Spanish writing and speaking skills but as a native speaker, I sometimes felt that the work was just tedious work.

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 004
best_comment: Carlos was a great instructor! They taught us a lot about how Spanish is used in everyday life, rather than just what would be considered grammatically correct. I do wish the course focused slightly more on practicing and learning grammar rather than on the specific movies or texts that we were assigned for homework since that meant a lot of the learning occured in the homework modules, which are not always the clearest. If you're interested in learning Spanish, this is a useful class that has a very manageable workload.

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 005
best_comment: Grading can be harsh. Assignments are manageable but readings are a lot. There's also quite a bit of homework. It's a great course if you do want to learn the language and about the culture but it seems like a little much for an intermediate level class.
worse_comment: Take Spanish 30 instead. Your experience in this class will heavily vary based on your TF (section leader). I got screwed and got the TF who thought Spanish 20 was our only class. Got assigned work that other sections were not required to do. The daily homework readings are usually chill, they expect you to print it out every time which is fine but can be annoying if you forget.

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 006
best_comment: Overall, HW is pretty chill and so were the compositions.  The exams were a little challenging for time at times, but the content itself was fine.  Your experience in this course can depend on your TF.  Mine was really nice and welcoming, but was insisten on us submitting class work

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 007
best_comment: I would tell them to do your best to get comfortable speaking with all your classmates in spanish and take risks in front of all of them! Also go to your teacher for any support you may need, because they want to help you succeed.

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 008
best_comment: Overall its a good course. If you are looking for a more laid back class this is definitely one of them. I will say, however, that your section leader matters... ALOT. I had a great experience in my section as we were graded fairly (low very nice with grading) and nothing was taken too seriously. However, I will say if you are not someone who goes to class or someone who can deal with last minute assignments, and a discombobulated class this might not be the one for you.
worse_comment: Honestly, this class is fine. My TF was super kind but not a great teacher. The grammar is tricky and not well taught by the textbook.

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 001
best_comment: TAKE IT!! RLL does not disappoint, like all language classes at this school. I absolutely loved all the instructors (met around 4–6 over the course of the semester). They are all so kind, and this will be a part of the week you look forward to even if it does take some sustained attention in a way that other classes sometimes don't.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 002
best_comment: It’s a great class if you’re looking to engage more deeply with Spanish and learn more about the culture in tandem. It really helps with creating a strong foundation in your conversational Spanish, as well as changes the way that you interact with Spanish materials and media.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 003
best_comment: If you're on the fence about Spanish 30, absolutely do take it. If you're not sure what level you're at, reach out to the course head/department staff! It's so important to find the right level for yourself, and this was perfect for me. I took it in my freshman year after AP Spanish in high school and was super comfortable with the class being conducted entirely in Spanish. At least the way my section was taught, it was absolutely the best language class I've ever taken, at any level.
worse_comment: If you are considering it you absolutely should take it. It has a steady stream of work, but nothing insane. Amazing use of time.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 004
best_comment: A great class. Professor Linder is amazing. She can be a little scary at first but truly she breaks you out of your comfort zone which is helpful to encourage one to speak.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 005
best_comment: This class is awesome I highly recommend! It is definitely a good amount of work, but it is very rewarding if you simply put in the time and effort. The material (readings and movies) are all very interesting!
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 001
best_comment: I absolutely loved this class! Please take it! My ability to understand and speak Spanish improved immensely over this course. Coming in I could not have a conversation and now I can. A lot of the coursework is watching movies which was not only fun but also an incredibly useful method of comprehension practice. We also read short stories every week, and we discuss the two in class. The sections themselves are pretty chill as we mostly talk about the readings and movies, but they work to improve your Spanish.I would recommend going to office hours while writing the compositions. The essays are not stressful or graded particularly harshly, but going to office hours will improve both your composition and your writing ability.Coming in I thought the class would be too hard and I was planning to drop to Spanish 30 because although my placement score put my in Spanish 40, I had gotten a 4 on the AP and my AP class was barely a real class.  However, this class pretty much meets you where you are, and I felt that it was the right level for me. It definitely seems the hardest in the first few days, so I recommend just trying out this class even if you're not sure about it. If you make it through the first few classes it will be fine.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Ricardo is a gem of a human being, so so passionate about encouraging students' learning and making them feel comfortable and confident to speak. The movies are a bit of a time suck but most of them are chosen well and interesting to watch.

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 002
best_comment: Excellent course! Natalie was an amazing TF, super fun and helpful. I felt sufficiently prepared for this course by Spanish 30. Work outside of class was manageable. Class time was used effectively and we were prepared well for exams/compositions. I definitely grew a lot in my Spanish speaking skills, and understand different elements of Spanish grammar at a higher level. I enjoyed this course a lot more compared to Spanish 20 and 30.
worse_comment: You may not improve much as a speaker, but you will build a deeper understanding of grammar concepts.

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 003
best_comment: If you're from taking AP Spanish Lit and Lang and you didn't struggle in those classes you'll fit nicely in here**. Our professor was very nice and understanding and the workload is manageable

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 004
best_comment: Amazing class! The movies are well–selected and extremely interesting, and make for enjoyable class discussions. There is not too much homework outside of the movies per week, and the assignments are spaced out. Overall, not an extremely time–demanding class and you will learn/practice important grammar concepts.

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 005
best_comment: *** This class is great, and Ricardo is an amazing TF. All of the movies we watched were amazing, and I think although my Spanish didn't improve that much, I genuinely enjoyed taking the class. You'll definitely be fine taking this after AP Spanish Lang or Lit, and if you wanted to you could probably skip to 50.

AMAZING COURSE! Take it ! Profe Parra is like a second mom she is so awesome – definitely take it with her if you can. The weekly modules are super interesting and the work is really light, but meaningful and introspective. You also meet great people. The environment is super non–judgemental and caring, which is great for practicing language skills.

Take this class! The teaching staff is so supportive, as are the other students. Whether you grew up speaking Spanish or you learned it in school, you'll fit in well. Everyone has something to learn from one another! It's a great opportunity to dig into your latinidad, and be proud and confident :)

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 001
best_comment: LOVED this course. Wilnomy is amazing, so enthusiastic, and encouraging. Our "exams" are all skit performances that we write ourselves, so they were all creative and fun.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 002
best_comment: This class is great for people who want to apply their creativity to Spanish class! There is not too much homework, and granted we don’t have any actual tests, it’s a very casual and comfortable environment where everyone is really there to learn Spanish. I highly recommend if you feel pretty confident in your speaking and comprehension abilities.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 003
best_comment: This class is very fun and very manageable! It is a fun way to learn Spanish and explore important plays and works in the Spanish language. The vocabulary and some other grammatical components may be difficult but the course staff make this class enjoyable. Definitely take for your Spanish citation/language requirement, especially if you enjoy performing before your peers and creative writing.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 004
best_comment: I loved this class!! Probably my favorite course of the semester, it was really fun and chill! Section discussions were great, and you really get out of readings what you put into it. It was a great stress reliever because there are no written exams or anything crazy like that, genuinely fun and a good way to improve in speaking/ reading.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 005
best_comment: This course was the best class I took all semester. I took the course straight out of high school (IB Spanish B HL/AP Spanish Language & Culture) and absolutely loved it. The creative writing is so much fun. You can get away with almost anything in your writing because the prompts are open ended (if you aren't creative, don't worry, there are also very clear instructions). The performance aspect of this class is an amazing replacement for written exams and you are never expected to have memorized all your lines or be able to act. One of my favorite parts of this class is how much we discussed that was both hilarious and politically relevant. You are also more than welcome to define words in class so if your vocabulary has gaps that should not be a concern. The only real prerequisite you need for this class is the confidence to speak freely.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance

best_comment: Such an amazing course! Great material, discussion, and service opportunity. Glenda is the absolute best, most considerate, caring, and enthusiastic professor I've had at Harvard!
subject: Spanish

course_title: The Ethics of Business in Latin America 001
best_comment: I would suggest you to take to course if you want to be better at speaking in Spanish; however, I think you need to be still comfortable enough in speaking to take this class! Adriana Guttierez is the best, she is one of the very engaging and understanding Professors that I had at Harvard. Take this class if you want to learn more about the colonial businesses in Latin America. Also, one good thing about the course is exams are speaking based, which I loved better.
worse_comment: This is a really great class. It is not a gem, but definitely manageable.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: The Ethics of Business in Latin America

course_title: The Ethics of Business in Latin America 002
best_comment: Take it! It is so worth it, Wilnomy is such an amazing teacher. The course itself is incredibly interesting and it is not too terrible courseload–wise. You will gain confidence in speaking Spanish and writing academic essays in Spanish.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: The Ethics of Business in Latin America

course_title: The Ethics of Business in Latin America 003
best_comment: I absolutely love Wilnomy. this is my second class with her after taking SPANSH 50, and I had such an amazing time learning from her again. She makes a genuine effort to engage with the class and encourages each student to participate! Her feedback is really helpful and also incredibly motivating. The readings and discussions from this lecture were also engaging and meaningful. You will leave this class feeling more confident with the Spanish language and more knowledgeable about the world itself. TAKE THIS CLASS!!
subject: Spanish
course_title_2024: The Ethics of Business in Latin America

best_comment: If you really like Spanish and would love to work more deeply with the famous Spanish Golden Age literature that is out there, this class is perfect for you. You will read lots of amazing works by famous authors like Miguel de Cervantes, Garcilaso, and Quevedo. The work is also very doable. For the majority of the semester, you get to enjoy reading for reading. The professor, Luis, will be able to show you so much, and you will learn lots for sure. You will think about the literature in ways you have not considered before. These eye–opening revelations are mindblowing. The rest of the work load is writing 2 essays during the semester plus a final exam with more essay questions. This class is very manageable overall and has a very friendly learning environment.

course_title: Words of Which History is Made: Translation Workshop on Modern Spain 001
best_comment: I truly came away with an appreciate of the subtleties involved in translation. Previously, I had never thought about translation, but there are many different strategies. You can shoot for an exact translation of each word, or you can translate the meaning across languages, or you can do a mix of both, or something else entirely. It's truly an art. I also feel like my Spanish speaking abilities developed, even though that may not be the aim of the course. The professor is fantastic! He's super fun and engaging and really tries to get to know individual students! He really generates participation amongst students.

This is a great Spanish class to take if you are interested in learning more about Spanish cuisine and how its evolved throughout history. The cooking classes are really fun and you get to make some delicious stuff like Spanish hot chocolate and fried eggplant. Homework is very minimal, and the essays are pretty easy to write the night before. If you're looking, however, to significantly improve your Spanish language skills, I would recommend taking a more advanced Spanish class instead.

TAKE THIS COURSE!! ALEJANDRA IS THE BEST! She is so ebullient and energetic, and we had such interesting discussions about gender, race, nationhood, citizenship, consumerism, and so much more. The class is well–structured, and it never lulled or felt like we ran out of things to talk about. The final project may seem daunting, but the course staff really reward creativity and outside–of–the–box thinking, which is a rare opportunity at this school. I came into this course as a non–native but fluent Spanish speaker, and I was super nervous about my ability to keep up. There was definitely a period of adjustment in terms of my language comprehension, but Alejandra was super understanding  and reassuring — it's okay to make language mistakes! After the initial hump, I was perfectly fine and was able to communicate complex ideas about feminism in Spanish by the end of the course. There is far too much reading for you to reasonably finish before each class (about a book per class, which met twice per week), but we always had plenty to discuss, and even in weeks where I had only read the wikipedia page and skimmed the first fifteen pages, I was completely fine. This was an absolutely outstanding way to finish my language citation, and as a Hist Lit concentrator, it honestly felt like one of my concentration classes conducted in Spanish. I recommend this class (and any class with Alejandra) with my whole heart.

course_title: Tobacco and Sugar, Seminar in Caribbean Counterpoints 001
best_comment: This class is heavy. It's worth it—it improved my ability to read in Spanish and got me to read some new books (which I always appreciate)—but the first half of the class is a heavy lift. Highly recommend to anyone interested in engaging with really unique works that deal with issues like race and agriculture, and improving their Spanish in an inviting environment. Professor Sommer is eager to help and excited about the content. My number one suggestion is to talk in class! Raise your own points. You can drive the conversation as you'd like. The class is very much a democracy.

worse_comment: It is important to take this course more seriously than you think— it does prepare you to write the thesis for REECA if you take the steps that it asks of you
subject: Russia, E Europe & Cntrl Asia

best_comment: TAKE IT!! This class brought me so much joy. You learn an amazing amount very quickly. And despite the number of assignments and tests, it never got overwhelming. Russian just became a part of my life – it stopped feeling like a class. You also get close to the other students because you see them every single day for multiple hours. Our class had such good banter and inside jokes that I was genuinely happy to get out of bed at 9am every day. Lastly, I cannot overstate how supportive the teaching staff is. Dima and Nadia are so kind and put it so much work. They were always willing to adapt the course to our needs and pace, while keeping us on track. It was nice to learn Russian for the first time from people who grew up in Russia. Their cultural insights made the language come alive outside of the formal grammar we were learning. They are amazing teachers. The fact that our entire class is continuing with intensive intermediate is a testament to how good the class is.
subject: Russian

best_comment: This course is a lot of time and work, but if you're interested in learning Russian, its definitely worth taking. The course ensures that you're engaged with the language every day, which is really important in the language–learning process.
subject: Russian

best_comment: This course is a lot of time and work, but if you're interested in learning Russian, its definitely worth taking. The course ensures that you're engaged with the language every day, which is really important in the language–learning process.
subject: Russian

best_comment: I never expected to take a language, let alone Russian, past the freshman requirement. However, developing a language proficiency with the unparalleled support of the Russian Language and Slavic staff has been the most rewarding and memorable part of my Harvard experience. Don't be dissuade by the initial difficulty, apply the effort and trust that the incredible staff will support you along the way.

I never expected to take a language, let alone Russian, past the freshman requirement. However, developing a language proficiency with the unparalleled support of the Russian Language and Slavic staff has been the most rewarding and memorable part of my Harvard experience. Don't be dissuade by the initial difficulty, apply the effort and trust that the incredible staff will support you along the way.

This class has a significant amount of work but is well worth it. The focus is less on speaking and vocabulary acquisition and more on fine–tuning your competence with grammar. Liya is an absolutely amazing instructor, she is extremely professional and engaging. Highly recommend taking this course.

This class has a significant amount of work but is well worth it. The focus is less on speaking and vocabulary acquisition and more on fine–tuning your competence with grammar. Liya is an absolutely amazing instructor, she is extremely professional and engaging. Highly recommend taking this course.

course_title: Fourth-Year Russian: Language, Ethnicity, and Diversity in Russia 001
best_comment: You learn a lot of new information about the richness of Russia during this class. You can definitely expect to improve your reading and writing skills, but be prepared to put in a lot of time and effort. Although the assignments are well distributed so that you’re not really doing a lot more work in one week than in other weeks, every week overall has many assignments. Despite this, I would recommend this class to others interested in Russian culture and improving their Russian– language skills. Liya really cares about the students learning and understanding the material. She is always ready to help students catch up on any difficult topics, she’s responsive to questions, and she’s overall an understanding person.

I honestly was not sure what to expect from the class as there were no Q guides but it was honestly fascinating. The works are unique and hard to encounter anywhere else. Professor Skakov is an expert in the field and all of his comments were enlightening. If you have even the faintest interest in modernism/art, Soviet culture, understanding power and control in modern day Russia I would definitely recommend

course_title: Between East and West: A Critical Mapping of Polish Culture 1
best_comment: Professor Kremer is fantastic and I highly highly recommend the class! Each week is a cool discussion on a subject from Polish history and particularly literature/film which reflect specific periods or historical movements. I didn't have much knowledge about Polish history or culture before the class and felt like through the class I've learned so much fascinating material. If you're considering taking the class as long as you find the material on the syllabus interesting, I would definitely recommend the class.
worse_comment: Just take it. Many themes in Polish culture are of course specific to Polish history, but many of the artistic achievements you learn from the class are appealing universally. It's also sad that despite the global eminence of Polish literature, it is not well represented in the United States. I strongly believe that even if you study British, American, or German literature, your knowledge of Polish literature/culture will enrich your understanding of the field.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! It is truly a GEM because of how accessible Dr. Kremer makes all the material. Even if you have no background in Polish history all the readings are understandable and fascinating. You walk away from this class with an immense amount of knowledge on how a country could undergo so many changes in such a short period of time. Class meets only once a week but the discussions that we have are so enriching because you get to see how everyone interprets such dense material through multifaceted perspectives. The assignments are also manageable and fun because they challenge you to write about difficult topics at times. Visit Dr. Kremer's office hours and take her other courses as well!!!!
subject: Slavic
course_title_2024: Between East and West: A Critical Mapping of Polish Culture

best_comment: This class is a lot of fun.  Daria is extremely nice and funny, she knows a massive amount about the era, you probably don't, the films are all fantastic (rare for a film course!) as well as extremely influential and educational (you'll understand far more about movies after taking this course), and the course load is light (other than watching movies, you just have to do a small amount of usually easy reading and do a couple pretty easy projects).Take it as a fifth class if you can.  It's not much work, you'll learn a lot, the professor's great, and it's fun.  What more could you want?

Take this course!! I came into this class taking it as an elective, but ended up changing my major to social studies because I liked it so much :)Social Studies 10 can have a bit of an intimidating reputation, but don't be dissuaded by that – it's not as hard as people make it out to be. The readings are very interesting, and as long as you get through all of them before section, you're pretty much guaranteed to do well in the course.Social Studies 10 is also the quintessential Harvard course – you'll get to hear from all sorts of expert social sciences faculty and read theory that's applicable to pretty much every field of study. The small tutorial size is also great – you'll get a lot of individual attention and be able to build up a close relationship with your tutorial leader. Definitely one of the most unique and worthwhile courses I've ever taken.
worse_comment: I would not recommend this course unless you have to take it for Social Studies. Too much material is squeezed into too little of a time period. Lectures range from good to bad, mostly bad. There's absolutely no reason to have 1 two hour lecture a week, and the class would greatly benefit from having two hour long lectures instead. Section is engaging, but way too long. It is exhausting, and not because it's so rigorous, but because it is too long. There's not enough structure given to Tutorials and they can range wildly in quality. The most important thing, however, is just the sheer amount of material covered. Reading a book a week works when it's Hum10, and you're working with literature. You can understand Frankenstein, mostly, in a week. You cannot understand Hegel in a week. It means that you come out with a very surface level understanding of most thinkers, except for those you choose to write about. Even then, you read so little of their theory that, save three or four thinkers, you feel as though you're not even engaging with them as thinkers. The environment of the course is also incredibly toxic, with just how much pressure they put upon you to concentrate in Social Studies. Every lecture includes 5–10 minutes about why you should concentrate in social studies, and you face actual legitimate pressure to concentrate, which is kind of unacceptable in my opinion. I often legitimately felt ostracized as someone who decided half way through that I wasn't going to concentrate. This course has the opportunity to be an incredible course, but is not there yet.
subject: Social Studies

best_comment: Take this course!! I came into this class taking it as an elective, but ended up changing my major to social studies because I liked it so much :)Social Studies 10 can have a bit of an intimidating reputation, but don't be dissuaded by that – it's not as hard as people make it out to be. The environment of the course is also incredibly toxic, with just how much pressure they put upon you to concentrate in Social Studies. Every lecture includes 5–10 minutes about why you should concentrate in social studies, and you face actual legitimate pressure to concentrate, which is kind of unacceptable in my opinion. I often legitimately felt ostracized as someone who decided half way through that I wasn't going to concentrate. This course has the opportunity to be an incredible course, but is not there yet.
subject: Social Studies

best_comment: Take this course!! I came into this class taking it as an elective, but ended up changing my major to social studies because I liked it so much :)Social Studies 10 can have a bit of an intimidating reputation, but don't be dissuaded by that – it's not as hard as people make it out to be. The readings are very interesting, and as long as you get through all of them before section, you're pretty much guaranteed to do well in the course.Social Studies 10 is also the quintessential Harvard course – you'll get to hear from all sorts of expert social sciences faculty and read theory that's applicable to pretty much every field of study. The small tutorial size is also great – you'll get a lot of individual attention and be able to build up a close relationship with your tutorial leader. Definitely one of the most unique and worthwhile courses I've ever taken.
worse_comment: I would not recommend this course unless you have to take it for Social Studies. Too much material is squeezed into too little of a time period. Lectures range from good to bad, mostly bad. There's absolutely no reason to have 1 two hour lecture a week, and the class would greatly benefit from having two hour long lectures instead. Section is engaging, but way too long. It is exhausting, and not because it's so rigorous, but because it is too long. There's not enough structure given to Tutorials and they can range wildly in quality. The most important thing, however, is just the sheer amount of material covered. Reading a book a week works when it's Hum10, and you're working with literature. You can understand Frankenstein, mostly, in a week. You cannot understand Hegel in a week. It means that you come out with a very surface level understanding of most thinkers, except for those you choose to write about. Even then, you read so little of their theory that, save three or four thinkers, you feel as though you're not even engaging with them as thinkers. The environment of the course is also incredibly toxic, with just how much pressure they put upon you to concentrate in Social Studies. Every lecture includes 5–10 minutes about why you should concentrate in social studies, and you face actual legitimate pressure to concentrate, which is kind of unacceptable in my opinion. I often legitimately felt ostracized as someone who decided half way through that I wasn't going to concentrate. This course has the opportunity to be an incredible course, but is not there yet.

subject: Social Studies

best_comment: If you need to take a methods class, SOC–STD 50 is a great one: you will learn what you need to know about social science research methods and the structure of the course allows you to pay particular attention to the method that interests you most. Matt is also a great teacher. He cares a lot about making the course helpful and enjoyable and about helping everyone develop their research interest. He is very approachable and kind and you will enjoy being in class with him.
subject: Social Studies

course_title: Radical Actors: The Role of Public Education in American Social Change 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this class if you are interested in the issues and looking for an alternative kind of learning experience that isn't typical in most classrooms. While these are really heavy and pressing social issues, the classroom community is really loving and welcoming to diverse perspectives, which Nicole makes a big effort to create. I always felt welcome in that class, I looked forward to hearing the perspectives of my classmates every week, we eat lunch together –– for me, it felt less like a class and more like a group study break with good conversation. Nicole is also someone with a wealth of knowledge about teaching and education, and I picked up a lot of great teaching pedagogy just from observing her teach.

course_title: Art, Political Culture, and Civic Life 001
best_comment: This is a great tutorial! There is a nice balance of theory, history, and current events throughout the course readings. Kiku is also an amazing professor. She does a great job stimulating discussion in class and including everyone in the conversation. She also provides really helpful feedback on drafts and is always happy to engage with students outside of class. Take this class!
subject: Social Studies
course_title_2024: Art, Political Culture, and Civic Life

best_comment: Professor Prevelakis is amazing!! Take his tutorial if you can. He is very knowledgeable and asks great questions to the group, but he also lets the discussion go in a new direction if we so choose. Social Studies junior tutorials help to prepare you for thesis writing and also teach you how to think critically about the world. Do the readings. Ask each other questions. Spend time on your final paper. It’s so worth it. You get out of this class what you put into it.

course_title: Justice and Reconciliation after Mass Violence 001
best_comment: This class is super interesting, and intense. Prof Hansen expects a lot of the students, but in a great way – it's super motivating, and I felt much better about this class than many others because of the engagement level that was required. Prof Hansen is a bit more old school, no nonsense, "not woke," but he's honest and open to feedback – he is out of pocket sometimes but in the most well–meaning way, and he cares deeply about his students. He is always available to chat, whether about class or other academic/life concerns.

course_title: Critical Theory of Knowledge, Technology and Power 001
best_comment: this is a really cool course! you probably won't get to discuss the subject matter in another class,  and the readings are excellent. Bo–Mi is a great instructor who does a great job facilitating conversation and helping you understand topics. some of the weeks' topics were very abstract, especially toward the middle of the course, but I still enjoyed them. it's definitely theory heavy (hence the name) so be prepared for that. I do wish that we discussed politics + tech more (only spent one week on it, felt like it could've been two).

course_title: Empire, Capitalism, and Global Economic Development 001
best_comment: Loved this course! The professor is amazing and very accessible outside of class, I looked forward to discussion every week, and the assignments were all geared toward producing the final paper which made the process very manageable. In addition, you're able to write about anything related to the themes of the class for the final paper, which is helpful for exploring what you may want to write about for your thesis. I really enjoyed the readings, particularly as they were focused on more modern times towards the end. The methodology of this course is historical, which is useful for every social studies thesis and an added benefit of the course in terms of thesis prep. Overall, you leave with a great understanding of the history of economic growth and development & I strongly recommend this course!

Tracey is leaving after this I think :( but if she is teaching anything, TAKE IT. I would follow her to the end of the earth. She is kind, brilliant, silly, and cares so deeply about the subject matter/finding the beautiful and complex things about the world/her students. This course will blow your mind and force you to reevaluate every aspect of your life.

course_title: To Remake the World? Revolutionaries, Regimes, and Paradoxes of Power 001
best_comment: I would certainly recommend this tutorial. Dr Whitham is an excellent teacher, and the class content is so interesting with really well chosen readings. Whitham also provides so much support throughout the research process, which was especially helpful as I had not written a history paper in quite some time, and never one with such a focus on primary source research.  As I changed my topic a million times, he met with me and offered me really helpful guidance and feedback.

course_title: Crime, Punishment, and Policing in an Unequal America 001
best_comment: This was hands down the best course I have ever taken at Harvard. Both Chris and Adaner are extremely kind and passionate about their work and very invested in their students. They don't just want their students to learn information, they are deeply invested in our rhetorical skills and thinking. I've never felt myself pushed so hard in my logic and argumentation, and feel profoundly grateful. This is what I expected a class at Harvard would be: our seminar was filled with incredibly passionate and intelligent students, with everyone tripping over one another to talk, share their experiences, and press a clever point or counterargument. I never felt, though, that anyone was arguing for the sake of arguing, there were not "devil's advocates" (expect sometimes Chris and Adaner). Everyone in the class cared so much about mass incarceration and policing. The readings were really manageable—this is the only class where I felt the professors clearly picked reading that they felt was reasonable to complete, averaging between 50 to 70 pages a week. The result of this was that everyone consistently did all the reading, so our discussions were exceptionally rich—no guessing or staying quiet because you're not sure what's going on. Finally, learning number–premise form has really helped clarify and sharpen my thinking. I have loved the memo assignments, I feel like I'm on top of my game and have produced some of the work I'm proudest of in this class. I could not recommend it more!

To get out of this course everything that it can give you requires a lot of work. There are a lot of readings each week, and one discussion post a week can add up to a lot. However, if you have any interest in examining the origins of sociology, how we came to think about the world in the way that we do today,and the theories that led us to where we are today, this is a great course. All of the learning happens in the section, and Emma and Zehra are fantastic people who genuinely care about teaching and making sure that their students understand the content. If anyone requires any kind of accommodations in the course, it is super important in this course to be proactive about those, but once communicating those needs to course staff, they are fantastic about following up and ensuring that students have what they need. The theories can sometimes be difficult to understand, but if you are willing to put in the time to genuinely understand, the reading guides can be amazing resources. Although the sections are two hours,  if you have taken the time to do the reading,and   with the right TF, , can feel like half an hour, with the time flying by as you break down theories and realize that the readings made more sense than you initially thought they did.
subject: Sociology

course_title: Junior Tutorial: Sociology of Health and Illness 001
best_comment: Take this class! Its a lot of work but very interesting. Prof Daniel is very understanding.
subject: Sociology
course_title_2024: Junior Tutorial: Sociology of Health and Illness

course_title: Junior Tutorial: Morality, Meaning, and Markets 001
best_comment: This class is definitely a good amount of work which requires planning and thinking in advance so you can't really do things last minute. That said, everything we did in class just built up to out final essay which I was so grateful for when finals came around. I found a topic I really wanted to write about which I think was super important for getting through the writing. We also had readings each week which took up time but were manageable. Professor Jijon was absolutely amazing, super supportive, and gave incredible feedback. Overall, definitely work but I loved the class.
worse_comment: Do the readings and participate!! The final paper and your research will be easier to complete if you have done the appropriate amount of reading. Professor Jijon does not just assign reading to make you miserable but to teach valuable lessons about research and the way that people view money and their morals. Because the class is 2 hours long and is discussion based, not reading makes things much worse than is necessary.

best_comment: Take this class. The content was amazing I learned a lot both in terms of sociological content (which has now definitely influenced my way of thinking) and how to do research (Catharina breaks it down really well). The structure felt intentional which was really helpful. But honestly I would take any class that was taught by Catharina. She was really helpful when I asked for help and always was able to find was to give me useful feedback, while being kind and understanding. Plus she made the class really interesting. This class really made me feel better about writing a thesis

TAKE IT!!! Sociology is like everything you want out of gov, philosophy, theology, and psychology but without the fluff. This is a perfect intro course. It's everything you think it will be and more. Mandic is an incredible and dynamic lecturer, the units are concise and well–curated–– I loved the class, religion, state, and nationalism units particularly. It is easy to stay engaged, and I enjoyed writing the final paper because everything connects so well. The quizzes were also super helpful in making sure we kept up with the readings and paid attention in class. It's what you make of it, so if you're cheating on quizzes and not doing reading, cool, but you just won't learn as much as an outcome.
If you're interested in giving sociology a shot, try this course! Can be a bit of beginner content, but it is super rewarding, and the workload is reasonable. Plus professor Cross is just amazing

If you have any interest in the environment, take this class!! You will learn everything about how we interact with the environment and movements surrounding the environment, from the interaction of capitalism and the environment to energy efficiency and its construction. Dr. Ouimette is a great lecturer and really wants us to succeed. She helps a lot with essays and provides really useful feedback.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Ouimette is very disorganized and lectures feel all over the place. She grades paper and exams very harshly and does not offer clear, constructive feedback. I feel like I barely learned anything from this course.

best_comment: This is an amazing class and so worth it! It is a good amount of work as we read essentially a full book each week (though they were all really interesting), and, depending on the project you decide to work on, you could be spending several hours a week going to a field site, taking observations, and writing up notes afterward. That said, I loved this class and the group discussion format. There was a ton of support and feedback from Tom and Jeff and other students on our fieldwork and assignments. I would highly recommend this class!

course_title: Leadership, Social Change, and its Challenges: Boston as a Case Study 001
best_comment: This past semester has been incredibly transformative: it has not only enriched my understanding of leadership but has fundamentally altered the lens through which I perceive community dynamics. The blend of theoretical frameworks with practical applications provided a holistic approach that encouraged active participation and critical thinking in lectures and in section. The discussions in section and during the lecture Q&A sessions were not just academic exercises, rather they were vibrant exchanges that allowed for the exploration of diverse perspectives. One of the standout aspects of the course was the emphasis on experiential learning. Through the midterm shadowing project, I found myself immersed in the challenges and complexities that my leader of choice faced, an opportunity that I never would have had without this class encouraging me to reach out. This hands–on approach not only solidified theoretical concepts that I had learned in class but also equipped me with invaluable skills that transcend the classroom setting. Over this past semester, I found myself not only learning critical skills and applicable leadership theories but also developing a network of like–minded individuals with varied backgrounds and experiences who shared a passion for positive change. The sense of community within the course mirrored the very principles it sought to teach. This course has left an indelible mark on my intellectual and personal growth, shaping the way I perceive leadership and my role within my community. I am grateful for the opportunity to have been a part of this transformative journey, and I am excited to carry the lessons learned into future endeavors, both as a leader and as a member of communities committed to positive change.tldr: This was the best course I have taken at Harvard and has genuinely changed me fundamentally as a person – an absolute must take!
worse_comment: This course is a must for all Harvard students to get to know the place they are living in. The course is ostensibly about leadership, but it also does an incredible job revealing how systems work — how institutions function and are shaped by the individuals leading them or subject to them.  The weekly visits from leaders, field trip to the AME church, and the shadowing assignment are highlights of this class. Ira and Chris do a superb job of framing the course and bringing out themes that will stick with you long after you leave the class (the most striking one for me: how Boston has long been defined by two opposing forces: the progressive, abolitionist pioneers that push for change and the racist, parochial traditionalists that resist it).
