course_title: War, Revolution, and Mafias: in Theory, in Film, and in Reality 001
best_comment: Absolutely take this course! Professor Mandic is super knowledgeable, encourages the whole class to speak up and do our best, and has such great enthusiasm for all the class material. This class will definitley take some time to do the readings and at times the subjects can be hard to read due to emotional responses it may or may not elicit. But, it is a wonderful class that you will learn a lot from and I high recommend you try it out.
worse_comment: I would tell future students that there is a lot of discussion in class, so you should not take it if you are nervous to participate. I would also tell them that the final paper was challenging, for me at least, and there is quite a bit of reading.

best_comment: I highly recommend taking this course!! The weekly workload is not particularly heavy, but you still can learn a ton from readings, class discussions, and working on the final project. Prof Jijon is amazing!!! Super approachable, makes participating in class feel easy & not scary, and also really really smart

This class has potential and I hope it is better for future students. Make sure to take advantage of learning R. The assignments are guided but you want to make sure you understand the language well enough for your final project. Dr. Swindle and David really care about their students and can really help clarify important topics and ideas. Make sure to seek them out if you need help because the final project will be really difficult without it.
worse_comment: My experience wasn't the best. It wasn't hard, but I often felt frustrated because I felt like my time was being wasted. Could just be a fluke year.
best_gem_comment: This is a gem…the coding concepts are simple but useful, we have barely any assignments (5 psets that we get class time to do, 2 tests, a research paper), and David is amazing. However he’s the TF so not sure if he’ll continue.
subject: Sociology

course_title: Pursuing Truth and Justice through Action for Health Equity 001
best_comment: I WOULDN’T RECOMMEND THIS CLASS! At first, I was excited by the idea of a project based course with community engagement. It was awesome to meet organizers who cared so much about niche but super important issues and see why/how their passions manifested through public and justice work. The class has a break about half way through and Flavia even brought pizza a couple of times. BUT the class is just not worth the time and unnecessary stress. There is so little scaffolding for students to know community best practices and have meaningful project ideas that the whole class felt disingenuous. Several groups, mine included, had deliverables that were just connecting their partner organizations to other organizations. However, for the sole purpose of completing the course, it was a long drawn out process of conducting interviews and making things look pretty. Our final presentation thus felt like preaching to the choir. You’re essentially giving a 20 minute lecture to community experts and 20ish students who already probably knew the information because the group projects are pretty similar/have overlap. Towards the end of the semester, everything was just disorganized. The class just became reviews of the professor's research and forced discussions based on questions students had on readings. Among other flaws in the class, some readings are unnecessarily long, we had several challenges being able to see/access materials, and there were several mistakes with assignment descriptions, submission deadlines, etc. on canvas. The feedback is short, vague, and doesn't reflect the grading on assignments/participation. Grades took at least a week to be updated, if at all. I received only 2 grades out of multiple assignments by the time the class ended. The syllabus also gives vague descriptions of the assignment components and it is assumed that you should just know how to complete things to an unrealistic, unspecified standard with no rubric to back anything up. It also doesn't list any concrete information on the expectations in the class on participation, attendance, etc. so if you aren't keen to ask for specifics early, be prepared for a whole rollercoaster of unexpected mess. As a student with both DAO and Title IX accommodations, this class was a nightmare. If you have accommodations, please don’t take this class or do so with extreme caution and keep EVERYTHING in writing. Firstly, the class is in PBHA on the second and third floors with no elevator. When I had mobility issues,  getting zoom access was restricted and an unnecessary deal was made out of moving class to the first floor. Almost every time I asked for help from Flavia or Kamille, but especially Flavia (Kamille often just felt like an enabler/bystander in much of this, which wasn't much more helpful), their condescending tone and poor communication styles made me, and even other DAO/Harvard staff who were witnesses, feel uncomfortable. They were very unaccommodating to physical and mental accessibility needs and quick to shut down conversations on how my accommodations could be met. The irony of the situation was truly unfathomable and traumatic given the supposed intention of the course. Although Flavia preached the importance of listening to people who are experts on their situations and how unethical health practices are harmful–it appears her personal values and teaching style are misaligned. I shared my concerns on several occasions and she was wholly unperturbed. She was incredibly shady in emails and obviously held grudges (even if I owned up to and/or explained something due to disabilities/illnesses). I often DREADED coming to class. The class is small, so everything you do is observed on a microscopic level and that sort of punitive scrutiny can't be productive to anyone's learning experience. Dealing with all these course issues, the staff's poor attitude, and navigating disabilities, was exhausting. I'm worried about repercussions but hoping my honesty will prevent other unassuming students from blindly taking this course. I'm no quitter, so I finished and did my best, but at what cost? For future students, even if you don’t have disabilities or other issues, I would suggest that you take a different course or join a community–based organization and learn through more organic, hands–on experiences. I think Flavia and Kamille are superficially nice, but are deeply flawed and so is the class. Don’t expect the content or name of the course to guarantee that you'll have a good experience or even really learn anything.

course_title: Online Dating and the Transformation of Intimacy 001
best_comment: I enjoyed the subject matter. Professor Narr isn't really available via email and does not generate enthusiasm about the coursework (the enthusiasm comes from students). If you're interested in the coursework, take it, but just be prepared to not rely on Professor Narr whatsoever.
worse_comment: very easy class, but frustrating to communicate with prof. You will often be confused about what you are assigned but you just turn something random in and you will be fine

best_comment: Take this class! Prof Lei and the TF Rachel are some of the best instructors at Harvard by far. The readings are super engaging and we go over them in class. Prof Lei is such an interesting person and makes lectures fun, she is also very understanding and made it clear that college should be about learning rather than grades. My favorite part of the class was section, I had a 9am section and I was excited to go, yeah I know crazy. Rachel is so funny and always makes sections fun and we go over material in an engaging way. If you are interested in the sociology of law or thinking about sociology, this course is awesome no background knowledge is needed!
worse_comment: The professor and teaching fellow for this class are BEYOND phenomenal. There is no downside to this class other than it being at 9 AM. If you're okay with that, you will have zero complaints. Even I am not a morning person and enjoyed coming to class.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: This is such an amazing class that can be emotionally taxing but holds such value. If you are looking for a class that will move you but won't flood you with readings, exams, and assingments this is the course to do it. Elom was an amazing TF who made section interactive, fun, and made you want to be there. Amazing course!

Truly amazing class that gives a detailed overview of many of the systems in the United States that maintain and perpetuate poverty. The lectures are informative and engaging. Tom is an extremely understanding professor and is very passionate about the material, which makes for a positive learning environment. The readings do not take much time per week, which balances out the work of the field reports, which are spaced out well over the course of the semester. Because the field reports require  live engagement, often outside of campus, it makes it hard to wait until the last minute to do an assignment. However, the field reports are very rewarding and truly do help you to engage with the material you are learning in a way that feels and is impactful. There is no experience required to be successful in this class, so anybody interested in understanding poverty in the United States should take it, regardless of concentration.
worse_comment: I would tell students to take the course, but if Wooten is not teaching, I wouldn't be sure and it could be different. But know that you probably won't meet an actually poor person, and that the field assignments are hard because of that.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: This class is excellent for getting a sense of big questions in the field of migration studies. There are lots of readings and the class discussions focus on the readings. Prof. Waters is very flexible and willing to focus on areas of interest of the class. Knowing where to read deeply and where to focus just on key takeaways from readings is important for this class – which Prof. Waters talked about in the class. I really enjoyed class discussions and felt like the class was flexible enough to focus on areas of interest for me while giving a good survey of the field of migration studies.

If you are an applied math major on the sociology track you should 100% take this course. Even if you are another major and you are interested in learning applicable linear regression material opposed to very abstract deep linear regression theory you should take this class. Professor Xiang is amazing at explaining the material at hand and you learn significant and applicable r code. Definitely take this class.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: This is a great course to introduce you to the subfield of social stratification and to learn about how sociologists have thought about inequality.

course_title: Proseminar on Inequality and Social Policy III 001
best_comment: This is a great opportunity to learn from your fellow classmates, who have fascinating research projects.

This class is amazing! Ate Lady is extremely helpful, and does her best to give us all the time to meet with her, or practice in class. Sometimes you might be challenged, but that is what language learning is all about. But this class somewhat felt like a family, and you knew everyone by name, and Ate Lady makes an effort to always have a great time learning as well as her understanding nature. Great class, great professor!
worse_comment: If you have Filipino heritage and have ever had any inclination to learn the language, then take this course! It is worth your time in class, and there is not too much necessary work outside of class in case you are worried about having a busy semester. And if you don't have Filipino heritage, then you should also consider taking this course as it's a fairly intuitive language to pick up and hey, it's the fourth most spoken language in the US so why not!
subject: Filipino Tagalog

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Listen, you have to actually put in the work, but it is amazing. You also need to take it with Richard Ji. He is an amazing teacher, super funny, and every day I would be so excited to go to class because it's always so fun. He will ask you to participate in class but I never once felt pressured or overwhelmed if he would call on me because if I didn't know the answer, he would always help me string the word/sentence along so you never get embarrassed; that's something I really appreciated! DO THE WORKBOOK EVERY NIGHT. Save yourself the stress of studying for the final and also having to cram in workbook assignments the night before it's due. Also for the assignments, if you're Indian, ask someone in your family to go over the answers together. The assignments are really well made so if you actually try to understand them you will benefit a lot. Also 4 days seems like a lot for one week of a class, but it's so worth it and you just learn so much because you're meeting so often. This class really is amazing and was ABSOLUTELY no doubt my favorite class (coming from a STEM major!!!)
subject: Hindi-Urdu

best_comment: I strongly encouraged students to take this course who may need it part of their required language or for any other purposes. Its a great course and you will feel satisfy and feel proud at the end of the semester that you have taken this course.
subject: Sanskrit

best_comment: Love Sanskrit? Love reading Sanskrit? Take Advanced Poetic! You will read extremely interesting texts, and the class will probably be small enough that you will have some say as to which texts you will be reading. This semester, we read the Raghuvamsa and the Abhidhavrittamatrika.

This class was very engaging and filled with many interactive, thought–provoking discussions due to its tight–knit, seminar–styled structure. I really enjoyed the ability to prepare for and lead different week's discussions, as I think such a format helped us to dive deep into our topic of interest, while also being able to hear from our peers and see how they interpreted the readings for that week. In this way, I felt that I gained very valuable insights through our readings and discussions regarding the history and modern–day impact of Ayurveda and other forms of Indian medicine.

This is such a wonderful class! If you are coming from a Tamil background but have never properly studied Tamil, this is a great way to build up a foundation. Jonathan is a fantastic teacher and makes classes really fun. I would highly recommend it!

course_title: Readings in Tibetan Ritual Literature: Rje btsun Grags pa rgyal mtshan’s analysis of the Evocation 001
best_comment: If you want to learn more and educate yourself in Tibetan Buddhism, history in general, and Sakya tradition and Sadhanas in particular, you should join this course.

course_title: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science 001
best_comment: TAKE STAT 100!! This goes out to all the non–STEM girlies who are scrambling to find a QRD class for the requirement: this is one of your best options. QRD sucks in general and STAT 100 is not perfect, but Kelly really wants you to do well, and it is SO doable, I promise. It requires no background knowledge on stats, and although the lectures lowkey don't make sense, the wrap–up sessions are BEYOND helpful (SHOUTOUT JULIE!!) It is important to note that the course recently changed from its usual format, so the exams are no longer take–home (they're all in person), however there are only 2 exams (the midterm and the final) and they are both open note. Also, the PSETS hold way more weight than the exams, and there is an opportunity to do a midterm make–up where you basically just correct your answers and can get some points back on the midterm. Slay!As long as you take good notes, have a PSET group (it could literally just be a couple kids in your section whose numbers you have), you'll be totally fine. I personally am not super interested in stats and probably won't be using R ever again after this class, but still, I can say now that I have baseline knowledge on coding which is kind of cool! Note: be prepared to spend a lot of time on the PSETs. Like a lot. Hahahah.... It'll suck when you're trying to finish it, but you'll honestly be grateful for it in the end because the exams are basically just a shorter version of the PSETS (the PSETS prepare you SO well for the exams). Also, once you get the hang of the PSET grind, it becomes so chill. Still annoying, but if you just lock–in and get it done, you'll be chillin. ALSO!! Shoutout Kelly! She is so understandable and so sweet. Her lectures are a tiny bit boring, but it's okay because she's literally such an amazing human and she is so passionate about what she teaches which makes me really happy! And trust me, she KNOWS a lot of us don't know what we are doing, and she is totally okay with that!! Coding is not the easiest thing in the world, and it takes some getting used to! Kelly and the TF's meet OUR needs, instead of the other way around, which is really cool and such an effective way of teaching. When the profs and the students have mutual respect for one another, it makes for a very safe learning environment that you honestly might not find in a lot of other Harvard STEM courses (from what my STEM friends have told me LOL).So ultimately, TAKE STAT 100!
worse_comment: If you have never coded before, this course will be quite brutal,
best_gem_comment: The best introductory statistics course to take if you aren't already statistically–inclined. The course is definitely heavy, but it is fair and doable. Kelly is a gem and Anais was a great section leader!
subject: Statistics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science

subject: Statistics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for Life Sciences 001
best_comment: This class is awesome! It is definitely difficult if you do not have any experience in R, but the teaching staff is incredibly helpful and supportive. Julie and James are two of the best teachers I have had at Harvard, and they are a big part of why I had such a great experience in this class. If you are interested in biology, I definitely recommend this class for your statistics requirement.

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for Life Sciences 001
best_comment: This class is awesome! It is definitely difficult if you do not have any experience in R, but the teaching staff is incredibly helpful and supportive. Julie and James are two of the best teachers I have had at Harvard, and they are a big part of why I had such a great experience in this class. If you are interested in biology, I definitely recommend this class for your statistics requirement.

course_title: Introduction to Quantitative Methods for Economics 001
best_comment: This class has honestly been one of my favorites at Harvard so far!  I never really thought of myself as a statistics person but this course honestly made me question that a bit.  For context, I took AP Statistics in high school and felt pretty familiar with about 2/3 of the course material going in but no experience coding and generally felt like the load for this course was pretty well manageable.  Kevin is a really great professor and breaks down topics with a lot of examples which is super helpful.  I'd definitely recommend going to the course study breaks, I always got almost all of my p–set and tons of yummy snacks at them!  Matthew is also one of the best TFs in any course I've ever had.  I also went into this course with zero experience with R and feel pretty comfortable with R now.
worse_comment: The Pset questions do not make sense, definitely go to every single office hours. Definitely go to section, it is good for clarifying anything you may have missed. Quite tedious and time intensive. If you have taken AP Stats, you should not have too much trouble, but if not then definitely read the textbook before lecture.
subject: Statistics
course_title_2024: Introduction to Quantitative Methods for Economics

course_title: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science 001
best_comment: lots of work, but very fulfilling. if you have an interest in data science/analytics, this class is really great! it definitely helps if you already know how to code in python, but it's not too hard to learn as you go. lectures: pavlos and kevin are great lecturers imo and the slides are super good. sometimes they'll spend a while answering questions, but lectures are overall efficient and effectiveassignments: psets were mostly biweekly, but super long... be prepared to spend lots of hours finishing the psets. final project: LOVE THAT WE HAD A FINAL PROJECT INSTEAD OF FINAL EXAM! just make sure to work with people you know will get their work done or else you're left with a lott of work to do. milestones are nicely spaced out and definitely help with getting the project done early:)exam: midterm had in–class mcq portion and take–home coding portion. take–home portion was easier than the mcq by far. mcq was open note and internet, but was super hard lol make sure to study
worse_comment: AVOID THIS COURSE AT ALL COST. If you are interested in learning data science methods, I would suggest taking some combination of Stat 139/149 and MIT 6.3900, which will  be much more comprehensive and, more importantly, far less annoying as a course. This course assigned a lot of busywork, and it could feel like the staff did not have much respect for students' time (especially when they assigned a major project milestone to be due on the Monday after Thanksgiving break, and a homework due two days after that). It also often felt like the staff put in much less effort than it asked of students, and held itself to a much lower standard than it did the students. The assignments — and even the exams — were riddled with typos, coding errors, and other mistakes, and they were often very unclear in the way they were written. When asking questions, the teaching staff always led with a condescending tone, and were extremely unwilling to admit they had done something wrong — they would even gang up on students on Ed when one suggested that there was a mistake in an assignment. I and all of the other students I talked to were extremely frustrated with the course by the time December came around. I would not even wish this course on my worst enemy.
best_gem_comment: FGLI FYRE CERTIFIED undegrad RESPONSE: If you are interested data science, environmental science & engineering,  EPS, or any other concentration that requires some sort of research or handling of data, YOU NEED to take this course. I am a cs concentrator and THIS COURSE GOT ME MY FIRST DATA SCIENCE INTERNSHIP. It literally taught me everything i needed to know and i was so surprised at how vocational this course really is. This course is super organized on ed, slides are very pretty, lectures mostly easy to follow (not when kevin lectures im sorry). But i don't think i was ever taught anything that didn't matter you know? It all seemed important and very useful and helped me do really well in data science interviews. Problem sets were super easy for me im not going to lie. If you KNOW how to code this class is kind of breeze most times because you can get away with knowing the main idea behind stuff and the coding parts are very plug and chug and I wouldn't say I did any serious thinking. Final project is a little different because you don't have your hand held, but it was very manageable. Cs50 is DEFINITELY 100% ENOUGH. and if you only took an r course (like stat 100) you are 100 % okay you can do this and you will not regret it. I procrastinated on every pset. THey can take a fat minute to finish which is the hard part, and theres no clever solution or something that will save you time ya know? late days are a blessing too </3. I would say the first psets are difficult the rest was a breeze. I think the hard part comes when you have to interpret things or make decisions about the direction you take your models. THats where the true data science knowledge is applied I would say. ANyway, i took cs107, cs61, and this course at the same time with a gem! Extremely doable ladies trust me you got this.
subject: Statistics
course_title_2024: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science

course_title: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science 001
best_comment: lots of work, but very fulfilling. if you have an interest in data science/analytics, this class is really great! it definitely helps if you already know how to code in python, but it's not too hard to learn as you go. lectures: pavlos and kevin are great lecturers imo and the slides are super good. sometimes they'll spend a while answering questions, but lectures are overall efficient and effectiveassignments: psets were mostly biweekly, but super long... be prepared to spend lots of hours finishing the psets. final project: LOVE THAT WE HAD A FINAL PROJECT INSTEAD OF FINAL EXAM! just make sure to work with people you know will get their work done or else you're left with a lott of work to do. milestones are nicely spaced out and definitely help with getting the project done early:)exam: midterm had in–class mcq portion and take–home coding portion. take–home portion was easier than the mcq by far. mcq was open note and internet, but was super hard lol make sure to study
worse_comment: AVOID THIS COURSE AT ALL COST. If you are interested in learning data science methods, I would suggest taking some combination of Stat 139/149 and MIT 6.3900, which will  be much more comprehensive and, more importantly, far less annoying as a course. This course assigned a lot of busywork, and it could feel like the staff did not have much respect for students' time (especially when they assigned a major project milestone to be due on the Monday after Thanksgiving break, and a homework due two days after that). It also often felt like the staff put in much less effort than it asked of students, and held itself to a much lower standard than it did the students. The assignments — and even the exams — were riddled with typos, coding errors, and other mistakes, and they were often very unclear in the way they were written. When asking questions, the teaching staff always led with a condescending tone, and were extremely unwilling to admit they had done something wrong — they would even gang up on students on Ed when one suggested that there was a mistake in an assignment. I and all of the other students I talked to were extremely frustrated with the course by the time December came around. I would not even wish this course on my worst enemy.
best_gem_comment: FGLI FYRE CERTIFIED undegrad RESPONSE: If you are interested data science, environmental science & engineering,  EPS, or any other concentration that requires some sort of research or handling of data, YOU NEED to take this course. I am a cs concentrator and THIS COURSE GOT ME MY FIRST DATA SCIENCE INTERNSHIP. It literally taught me everything i needed to know and i was so surprised at how vocational this course really is. This course is super organized on ed, slides are very pretty, lectures mostly easy to follow (not when kevin lectures im sorry). But i don't think i was ever taught anything that didn't matter you know? It all seemed important and very useful and helped me do really well in data science interviews. Problem sets were super easy for me im not going to lie. If you KNOW how to code this class is kind of breeze most times because you can get away with knowing the main idea behind stuff and the coding parts are very plug and chug and I wouldn't say I did any serious thinking. Final project is a little different because you don't have your hand held, but it was very manageable. Cs50 is DEFINITELY 100% ENOUGH. and if you only took an r course (like stat 100) you are 100 % okay you can do this and you will not regret it. I procrastinated on every pset. THey can take a fat minute to finish which is the hard part, and theres no clever solution or something that will save you time ya know? late days are a blessing too </3. I would say the first psets are difficult the rest was a breeze. I think the hard part comes when you have to interpret things or make decisions about the direction you take your models. THats where the true data science knowledge is applied I would say. ANyway, i took cs107, cs61, and this course at the same time with a gem! Extremely doable ladies trust me you got this.
subject: Statistics
course_title_2024: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Joe is an amazing lecturer and all the staff for this course are amazing people! Please don't be scared by the reputation of this class; this course really rewards you if you just put in hard work. The course material is also so so interesting. Instead of bashy calculations, Joe tries to make everything work out very nicely (he loves his symmetry arguments), hence less tediousness and more fun! I have learned so much from this class and have enjoyed every minute of it! Just to address some of the common concerns:1. Midterm + Final being too hard: I think if you put in a lot of work (I mean a lot like doing all the practice exams for midterm and final), even if you find the material less intuitive you can still do pretty well on the exams via pattern recognition. This class also has a pretty generous curve to compensate for the difficulty so DON'T BE SCARED! 2. PSETs taking too long + too hard: There are plenty of sections + OH to help guide you through psets. Sections tend to be reviews of the material covered in lectures and techniques for solving problems that are similar to those on the psets. All the TFs are also super patient and willing to help at OH  so don't worry about not having enough support in the class. 3. Statistics boring BOOOOOO: A common misconception (which Joe always addresses at the beginning of STAT110) is that this class is not technically on statistics, rather, it is an introduction to probability (as the name suggests). And, probability is fun. It may be brain scratching at the beginning to think about things such as counting the number of ways to pair people up in a group, but Joe is a great lecturer and tries to help you develop intuition for such problems! All the pset problems are very well written and fun as well! Joe dresses up every year for Halloween too and it was truly one of my highlights of this semester.Some tips on studying for this class:1. Start psets and studying for exams as early as possible: They do take time so please don't introduce unnecessary stress into your life by procrastinating on psets and studying. Some of the problems are really fun to think about as well!2. Study groups: Studying with friends is a great way to motivate each other! It's also great trauma bonding experience to be in the trenches with all your besties.3. Go to section: TFs are AMAZINGGG. Even if you never go to lecture and don't read the textbook, sections will carry you! The TFs put in a lot of work to make times accessible, and since they are all students who have taken the class, they understand what you are going through!4. READ THE TEXTBOOK: Since lectures are only 75 minutes, sometimes Joe cannot go as in depth on certain concepts/proofs/examples. The book goes beyond what's covered in lectures and has so many more examples demonstrating applications of concepts. Reading the textbook definitely helps so much with understanding the material. The book also has neat tricks such as Baye's Billiards that Joe doesn't quite cover in lecture.  TAKE THIS CLASS :)!
worse_comment: Anyone who says that this course teaches a lot or shifted the way they think about life is lying. This course is basically pure pain. You will work hard week after week and still come away barely understanding any of the concepts. Read the textbook. Do practice problems. Make this is your hardest course this semester and make sure everything else will be as non–time–consuming as possible.  Practically all of this class is just pattern–matching and doing practice problems is really the only way to get fluent in it. A much as you think you know what you're signing up for, in practice it will be far worse, more difficult, and more time–consuming. Go to section. Go to office hours. Use every resource provided because they're there for a reason. This class is awful, but you can get through it. Also, to my CS concentrators: do not take this in the same semester as CS61, no matter how tempting it is.
best_gem_comment: This course is undoubtedly a gem when it comes to learning statistics and improving your quantitative reasoning. With that being said, it is a hard course, and in particular the second half covers exponentially more content than the first. Therefore, please study for your finals earlier and don't fall behind on content, or you will be screwed.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: Is it the most inspiring course you’ll take at Harvard? Probably not. But as a concentration requirement, it’s relatively painless (compared to Stat 110/111) and you definitely learn some valuable, fundamental modeling skills. Professor Xenakis is a super nice guy and genuinely seemed to care about students’ concerns. It was his first time teaching this course (or any Harvard course), and so the lectures started off a little dry/rocky. However, they definitely got smoother as the semester went on and I’m sure they’ll continue to improve now that he’ll actually have some time to prepare for future iterations of the course. Like I alluded to, if you’re taking this course, it’s probably because you have to—but all in all, I wouldn’t worry too much about it.
worse_comment: Please utilize all office hours and sections and redo the section stuff that you don't understand. Lecture slides don't really help you learn.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: This is a great stats great, very reasonable expectations! There are weekly problem sets that take around 5–8 hours (sunday afternoon) and a final project at the end, no midterms or finals. Luke is by far one the best professors, he genuinly cares about the students, putting in an abundance of time and effort into the course. of Care and attention Luke brings to the course and students. He also has that rare gift of breaking down complicated concepts making them interpretable.

This course gives a very good overview of popular reinforcement learning algorithms. You get to cover the shiny exciting realm of deep RL, but also some classic algorithms that turn out to be surprisingly useful. Although this class does go over the statistical justifications behind most of the algorithms, I wouldn't let that scare you. The course does a very good job of giving intuitive explanations for each algorithm and why they might do as well as they do, and I found that understanding these explanations could carry me quite far. Problem sets are pretty chill since they're across multiple weeks, so as long as you don't leave them for the last minute they are very doable. They also give you a lot of freedom for your final project, and it turned out to be the least stressful part of my finals period. Overall if you are interested in machine learning and want to see what reinforcement learning is about, I think this class does a great job of showing what is being used in practice today.
subject: Statistics

subject: Statistics

best_comment: This is the best class I took this semester, possibly the best stat class I've taken and I really like 110 and 111. It feels almost like an applied linear algebra class at times, but the psets have a nice real world application element. I would say this class  helps most with statistical and linear algebra intuition, and you really begin to understand what "data" is.  Would recommend 10/10, surveys a lot of cool methods while going deep into PCA, SVD, and NMF. Would say the only thing that might make the class better is decreasing the size of the nonlinear dimension reduction survey a little bit, and maybe expanding the AE or NN unit. I would also say sometimes the clustering unit feels a bit rushed. Overall quite possibly the best class. Shoutout Alex for being an amazing and supportive prof too!

It says you should be good to take this course with stat110/stat111 background, but imo you need more than that. the assumed stat knowledge was challenging, and this course is way more of a lecture–style course than seminar course. Professor Xiao–Li is very passionate about DP so that was wonderful to experience, but I was more interested in the philosophical aspects of the courses and would have preferred to see more of this. I took this course with the intention of being able to use my background in a new way/see things from a different perspective and do believe that this was accomplished, but feel that with more iterations of the course, this can be achieved more
worse_comment: This class was interesting but really disorganized. No one knew how to do the problems on the first HW because we had been taught so much material at once, the outside readings we had been assigned sometimes used different notation/methods than what we did in lecture, and there were no lecture notes or textbook (they published lecture slides, but those were very hard to follow if you weren't actually sitting through the lecture). There were enough bonus points and other assignments that I wasn't super worried about my overall grade, but the homework assignments were way more stressful and difficult than they needed to be. My TFs were nice and trying to be helpful but I think the overall disorganization made that hard as well.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: My first Statistics Course at Harvard, Stat 210 was a good experience. Professor Blitzstein’s lecturing ability was undoubtedly a selling point for the course – even as someone who has done measure theory before I appreciated his exposition of most of the mathematical side of the material. Problem sets were interesting, appropriately challenging and fun to do with other students. Regarding the actual material itself, I will split my review into two halves:1. 'The good stuff'. (Probability and Measure, Representations of Distributions, Expectation and Conditional Expectation, Generating functions, Martingales). I really loved these parts of the course. Learning about these topics answered a lot of unanswered questions I had from 110 in the summer, and simultaneously led me to have very many followup questions (both mathematical and practical) about the material that Prof. Blitzstein and the TFs were great at answering. There are loads of powerful tools here that are really lovelily motivated in lecture and that can be used to approach problems in applied probability much more elegantly than than the approaches one would use in 110. I'm sure this would be mentioned by others as well but I would really like to sing praises especially for Representations and Martingales for helping me build additional dimensions both in my problem solving toolkit and in my appreciation for the beauty of the subject. This might be controversial (especially amongst the maths concentrators), but I personally thought the Measure Theory was done in 210 to an appropriate amount – enough that one understands its role as a "construction tool" for many otherwise not–obviously–well–defined objects that we are working with, but not so much that it got tedious or boring (and believe me when I say that I do not want to read through Royden and Fitzpatrick ever again). The one caveat that I might make is to just briefly expand the conditional expectation topic to a more general one on the construction of conditional probability – didn't understand since 110 why conditioning on an event of zero probability made sense and I feel as though myself and many others would have found the idea of how one might do that enlightening. 2. 'The slump' (Multivariate Normal and Asymptotics). Enough said. These parts of the course were terrible and were possibly the worst parts of any course I have taken at Harvard (to be fair I don't think I've had experience with truly terrible classes here). I feel like whilst thinking about how to teach these topics, Prof. Blitzstein didn't feel the need to motivate these as he feels as though we will see plenty of applications in Stat 111, 212, 230 etc. . I completely understand this viewpoint, and especially as a PhD statistics student I could see why learning about these topics would be enlightening, but for me (and a lot of other undergrads who typically take this class) whose exposure to Stat is limited to Stat 110 and 210, I didn't really get to see why these ideas were important at all. This would have been fine if the material was beautiful, but it wasn't – it was ugly, full of bash and uninteresting. Most importantly I did not feel as though these topics were in line with the theme of the class of looking at 110 material from a more elegant and interesting perspective. It really is a shame that I hated these parts of the class so much as I feel as though Prof. Blitzstein could have made these topics a lot more fun and interesting by recognising that these parts of the course are not the most intrinsically beautiful and adapting by motivating this section of the course a lot more via cool applied scenarios like he does for everything else in 110 and 210 (to be fair, I'm possibly beating on a dead horse here because I feel as though I am in the majority of Harvard maths students in the sense that I hated Real Analysis I for its ugliness was so it is probably safe to say I still wouldn't have loved 'the slump' anywhere near as much as 'the good stuff' but it would have definitely helped it go from terrible to at least meh to see it motivated better).Nevertheless, I'm really glad I took this course and I feel like I enjoyed it overall. I am sure that it is miles more interesting than what Graduate Probability Theory would look like at most other universities. Most importantly, it has generated within me a lot of curiosity about the material and has motivated me to want to answer the remaining questions I still have by taking by taking more Statistics classes.
worse_comment: it starts with measure theory. if you came in with good analysis background but bad probability background, don't get too used to slacking
subject: Statistics

best_comment: This will be the hardest course you take in your harvard life so far. It presents statistics almost like an art form, where problem sets require creativity and not just quantitative thinking. The exams are difficult but you will get through them. The TFs (especially any undergrad ones) are really approachable and you can tell they really love the material and know their stuff inside out. You will love, hate, then love this course again. If you should choose to embark on this journey, I wish your brave soul all the best.
worse_comment: I would say this class is not very good. Exams always had unfairly difficult questions worth a large amount of the exam, various errors and overlooked details in problems, and this is basically unnecessary if you already took Stat 111. It tries to be more rigorous than 111, but it doesn't actually do this, so there isn't much of a point.

course_title: Computational Tools for Statistical Learning: Approximation, Optimization, and Monte Carlo 001
best_comment: Depending on your background, this can be a time consuming class given all the homework questions build off eachother. However it is useful.

Definitely take this course if it's offered! Prof. Kou is a great lecturer and while the course covers truly a lot of material, you will not feel very stressed from week–to–week. Workload is manageable, and the geometric intuitions you get from lecture are very rewarding.

course_title: Sparse Inference, and Network and Text Analysis 001
best_comment: Take this class if you'd like a gem and the opportunity to learn a good variety of interesting topics! However, be prepared to review a lot on your own if you'd really like to retain the material, since there's no homework to keep you accountable to reinforcing concepts. If you don't care too much about retaining the material, then that's a great fit ;)
worse_comment: There is no homework and the only thing is a final course project, which is done in about a month. The topics are appealing and have both theory and applications parts.
best_gem_comment: Take this class if you'd like a gem and the opportunity to learn a good variety of interesting topics! However, be prepared to review a lot on your own if you'd really like to retain the material, since there's no homework to keep you accountable to reinforcing concepts. If you don't care too much about retaining the material, then that's a great fit ;)
subject: Statistics
course_title_2024: Sparse Inference, and Network and Text Analysis

best_comment: This class is challenging but extremely applicable and interesting. In my opinion, you need to be comfortable with statistics above the level of Stat 110/111. My only statistics background was Stat 110 and CS 181, and I struggled to keep up with the theory in lectures (even though Neil is a pretty entertaining and informative lecturer). I think Stat 210 would help, since we referenced results and ideas from that class pretty frequently. You don't need any economics to understand what's going on, but a lot of the application questions Neil gave on psets were macro–related. Assignments had 2 theory questions and 2 applied questions each, which I thought was a pretty good balance. They helped solidify why we use certain models and why certain properties and assumptions matter. There were only five psets, and we were able to drop 2 of them and use extensions on 2 others. There were no midterms, but there was a final that had an applied section that we did at home and a theory section that we took in person during the scheduled final exam time. The final seemed fair to me, even though I didn't do very well (lack of understanding and preparation on my part). If you keep up with homework, attend lecture and office hours, and really understand what assumptions are carried by each time series model, then you should be fine.The class is fair and the content is useful. Take it! It's tough but worth it.
worse_comment: Just read the book and skip lectures (because they are kinda bad and confusing). Also it was very frustrating that half of the final was on a chapter that was taught in the last 2 weeks and we had no practice problems on that topic in particular.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: This is a very challenging class! The 24 hour exam took me 19 straight hours to do. But it's also very rewarding and a very well–resourced course for a class of its size. Kosuke and the teaching staff are all great and patient.I took it as a undergrad with STAT 110 and STAT 111 previously and 139 concurrently (as well as lots of R experience) and was fine for the GOV side of the course, though experience with more advanced regression implementation would certainly be useful. The distinction between the GOV and STAT side can sometimes be blurry, but in general the GOV side is more focused on empirical implementation while STAT focuses on analytical derivations.286/2003 covers a lot of ground. Regardless whether you're STAT or GOV, the course tries to teach both the theoretical underpinnings of various inference methods while teaching you how to implement them, which... is a lot! But it's generally pretty successful in this endeavour.I'd recommend doing all the PSETs and be sure to note that the second half of the course gets much more difficult and has far more content.Also just an aside but the STAT TF Kyla Chasalow is easily the best TF I've ever had. She made the material so clear in her section, even when it could get a bit muddled in lecture. Also she wrote a 130–page note document for the class, effectively serving as a course textbook.
worse_comment: This course is very challenging and you have to invest a lot of time. But your efforts to understand the materials are proportionate to the feeling of acheivement. The course is very demanding and if you have 0 background in statistics, this course will be very difficult.

best_comment: SCRB 10 is by far the best class I have taken at Harvard. The community of this class and the HDRB department as a whole is unparalleled and such a gem. This class is pretty difficult and requires a lot of time but it is so, so rewarding. Bill is one of the best lecturers I have gotten to take a class with, and he makes every class incredibly engaging and the PollEv questions and discussion truly prompt you to think critically about the material at hand. This class teaches experimental design techniques and genetic tools and focuses on the application of these to real–world examples. This class is not a regurgitation of biology facts but will teach you to think critically about how to approach designing experiments for scientific problems, basically reflecting actual real–world basic science research. The teaching team is absolutely phenomenal and is a large reason why this course was so amazing. Every one of the TFs and CAs cares so deeply about the success of the students and they are incredibly supportive of students asking questions and seeking help on assignments/psets/studying for exams, etc. Lauren is also one of the best parts of SCRB 10. She is the sweetest, most caring person ever and is such a gem in the SCRB department. Lauren works so incredibly hard and is so willing to give detailed answers to questions and meet with you one–on–one for anything. The week leading up to each exam, I would email her a ton of questions and she would respond in paragraphs to me and she basically saved me and my understanding of the material if I was ever confused about a topic. I cannot speak more highly of this life–changing course and am so proud to be concentrating in HDRB.
worse_comment: VERY VERY HARD. Harder than ls1a ls1b and chem17. be diligent througout the semester!

best_comment: Amie is the best. She has such a command of this content and is able to teach with a lot of clarity, really pushing you to think further about your experiments (e.g. Why is this design better than another?  When is a positive control unrealistic?)
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

best_comment: Great and very chill course. Jessica is so knowledgeable and enthusiastic, and I honestly just enjoyed listening to her get excited about something new in biology or some really cool concept – she's a very interesting person to learn from. Half of the class is her teaching, and the other half is student presentations/discussions, so everything is very laid back. She really cares about the students and understands that everyone is very busy or applying to medical school, so she's super flexible. Overall, she really just seems to want students to learn and get excited about the material above anything else.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

course_title: From Cells to Tissues, in Sickness and in Health 001
best_comment: the prof is literally the sweetest person ever, absolutely love her, she's so fun, such a star, so approachable + kind, and her mind + expertise go crazy! would 100% recommend just for her. the course material was interesting + fair. exams definitely required understanding of the material, I would review by going back through all the lecture slides, but not unreasonable at all. given little background in upper–level biology courses, I definitely was not as quick on the uptake when analyzing limitations + strengths of experiments in specific papers as others in the class who were actual HDRB concentrators, but I still had a great time + found the course to be very accessible. for me, the papers definitely took time to read, gpt–4 was quite helpful in breaking down some of the jargon as the papers could be a bit dense, especially coming in with little familiarity with cre/cre ER + ablation type approaches. I took this course on a whim + it was one of my favorite courses w one of my favorite professors I've met here! go to OH! she's such an icon + so willing to chat about anything + answer any questions related to course material + beyond.

A wonderful course! Relatively long hours in the lab (6 hours/week), but compensates with very little work outside of lab. The time in lab also flies by. Entirely lab–based course, so if you are looking to learn about basic biology there are probably better courses. But you will come away with a lot of confidence in the lab, and also learn some really cool experiments (expansion microscopy is really cool)! Course staff is absolutely wonderful – Fei is delightful, and he really does care about student learning/success. Also his research is very cool! Overall great way to fulfill a SCRB requirement. I had relatively extensive lab experience before this course and still took a lot away from it.

SCRB177 is a great class if you want to walk with a comprehensive understanding of the immune system and some of its really cool roles in both human health and disease. The teaching staff are very supportive and you can really tell that Dr. Franklin is passionate about the subject. I also really appreciated her willingness to answer questions and give feedback. I think that when it comes to upper level SCRB classes, the professor definitely makes or breaks the classroom experiences and in this case, I definitely felt that I enjoyed the topic of the class way more because I could tell the staff were enthusiastic about the topic. I also think that the work is definitely fair and manageable.

course_title: Understanding Aging: Degeneration, Regeneration, and the Scientific Search for the Fountain of Youth 01
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! I am a senior with a lot of biology under my belt, which is definitely helpful for this class. I am so glad I ended up taking this class this semester— Prof. Wagers is a kind and incredible professor. The topics covered in class give you a great background on an up–and–coming field of biology, and the frequent discussions of how different aging therapeutics are brought to market is very interesting. The class makeup was really fun too— about 50% undergrads and 50% grad students, in an MS/MBA program. Their perspective on biology meshed with business was very valuable for class discussions. The course's assignments are also the perfect balance between meaningful and approachable... I wasn't fighting an uphill battle at any point but I was also not doing meaningless work. The final project is really fun! Prof. Wagers and the TF are super approachable and responded to my emails very quickly. :) Take it!!!
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol
course_title_2024: Understanding Aging: Degeneration, Regeneration, and the Scientific Search for the Fountain of Youth

course_title: The Translational Science of Stem Cells: Present and Future 001
best_comment: The guest lectures were all fantastic. Lee is a great teacher and his content was very interesting. The papers provided are all fascinating. The teaching staff are very helpful and understanding. There are many interesting individuals taking this course that you get to interact with. In this class 75% of your grade is group work that you will almost undoubtedly feel out of your depth completing; this isn't innately a bad thing, and you learn a lot very quickly, but it induces a lot of grade–related stress. I believe taking this course Pass/Fail is not an option, so make sure you have the space in your schedule to really commit to the process of the group project. Feedback could definitely have been more comprehensive and given at more points throughout the semester. A strong biology background is helpful, but everyone seemed to feel equally out of their depth; this course goes somewhat beyond the theory learned in previous classes. There were times I thought taking this course was the biggest mistake of my time at Harvard, there were times I was very glad to have taken it. Not at all an easy class.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol
course_title_2024: The Translational Science of Stem Cells: Present and Future

best_comment: This is a wonderful class, I would HIGHLY recommend.I came into this class without a strong biology background and have really been inspired by this course. It is a wonderful introduction to this entirely new era of medicine. Each lecture, a new guest who has been at the forefront of a revolutionary therapeutic approach joined, offering a slew of perspectives and approaches. This is definitely a survey class, but a really effective one. Mark and Doug were wonderful. Both incredibly smart and thoughtful, they really know their stuff and are so passionate about the material. They make a great duo.Assignments were decent: two critical evaluations, and a few presentations. I liked the emphasis on critically evaluating published work. This really has been a highlight of the semester, and every lecture was a pleasure. I would highly recommend SCRB 197.

The course is definitely useful for anyone interested in developing therapeutics and  biotechnology. It provides a range of insights into different therapeutic areas and modalities, as well as exposure to a number of interesting physicians and scientists in the Harvard ecosystem. The section component of the course is a bit disorganized, with area for improvement. The paper and presentation assignments can feel a bit repetitive, but provide an opportunity for you to dig into specific areas of interest with a decent amount of flexibility.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

best_comment: This class is super helpful in developing writing and speaking skills. I've always been nervous about giving talks, and the progression in giving talks was a good structure to build our confidence in both length and familiarity with the concepts.
subject: Systems Biology

best_comment: This class is super helpful in developing writing and speaking skills. I've always been nervous about giving talks, and the progression in giving talks was a good structure to build our confidence in both length and familiarity with the concepts.
subject: Systems Biology

best_comment: This class is super helpful in developing writing and speaking skills. I've always been nervous about giving talks, and the progression in giving talks was a good structure to build our confidence in both length and familiarity with the concepts.
subject: Systems Biology

course_title: StudioLab on Creativity and Entrepreneurship LEC
best_comment: This course is ALMOST (and emphasis on the almost) a gem.  If you want an easy workload, a class that doesn't demand all of your academic focus, or a last class that will be a stress–free addition to your schedule, by all means take this class because it's not that bad of a workload.  You truly get to learn how to be creative and an entrepreneur, and by every measure the final project in this class was one of, if not, the top highlight of my semester (academically–speaking).  You collaborate to create a unique venture with three others that may allow you (attempt) to be the next Zuckerberg or Gates.  HOWEVER, be warned of the 3–hour lectures, arbitrary grading, and minimal communication from the teaching team that awaits you when you enroll.  It is a very awesome and unique class, and if you have the elective credit to use, by all means, TAKE IT FOR FUN.
worse_comment: This course has an extremely low workload. It could be interesting but you should be aware that almost all work is done in groups which can be annoying to coordinate
subject: Creativity and Entrepreneurshi

best_comment: Take this class. Harvard needs more creative writing workshops. If you're trying to decide which workshop, playwriting is a great balance between creating a real world scenario and putting your own meaning into scenes like poetry. It is a mimicry of human experience and the most fun to write. Sam is an incredibly knowledgeable and talented playwright who is supportive of his students and helps us get better.

This course definitely depends on the instructors so it's hard to know what it'll end up being like but I honestly really loved it!  Morgan and Sam were amazing professors and Sam T and Ryan were super helpful and supportive in rehearsals and classes.  Probably one of my favorite courses from this past semester!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2024: TDM Production Studio: Black Girl Nerd

best_comment: This course definitely depends on the instructors so it's hard to know what it'll end up being like but I honestly really loved it!  Morgan and Sam were amazing professors and Sam T and Ryan were super helpful and supportive in rehearsals and classes.  Probably one of my favorite courses from this past semester!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2024: TDM Production Studio: Black Girl Nerd

best_comment: James is the best! I really loved working with and learning from James. He cares so deeply about the material and is so open to hearing people's thoughts. I did not feel judged or like my opinions were invalid. He also cares so much about us as people which made the class enjoyable.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: The pros: this course is extremely chill, to the point where it basically feels like a non–class and more of a weekly activity. The cons: I don't feel like I really learned anything. I know this was supposed to be a space to explore and generate ideas for my thesis, but I wish  we could've continued to explore different theater artists and theories like we did in the sophomore tutorial to help guide us in this exploration. Instead, most class time was dedicated to structured brainstorming, which felt entirely like something I could do outside of class.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Beginning Acting Through Scene Study and Monologue Work 001
best_comment: Of the 3 hours of class time, I felt like I was only actively engaged for the 20 minutes when I did the monologue and received feedback, and then for the rest of the 2 hours and 30 minutes, I was only sitting in my chair and watching other people.  I wish we did more active and dynamic engagement. For example, acting exercises as a class, scenes as a class or larger groups, or demos from the teachers even. I felt like I would've learned so much more that way. It is a super chill class though.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2024: Beginning Acting Through Scene Study and Monologue Work

best_comment: TAKE THIS! This was my favorite class this semester. Wonderful instructors, great class community without being annoying and forced, fun assignments, reasonable readings, all–around great experience
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: What's so Funny?: Introduction to Improvisational Comedy 001
best_comment: BEST. CLASS. EVER. I seriously don't think there is a better class at Harvard. Remo creates such a welcoming and positive space. All the improv and acting activities are so engaging and interesting. Everyone gets the chance to really learn more about themselves when it comes to generating ideas, team work, etc. I love the community this class built, and I will miss it so much! I look forward to this class every week. Writing the blog posts after each class is a great way to reflect on what we have learned. AMAZING CLASS! PLEASE AUDITION IF YOU CAN!
worse_comment: Amazing, life–changing. Best class at Harvard by far, but you have to be willing to fail and make a fool of yourself!
best_gem_comment: This is a great class if you're looking for an easy 4th GEM. There is literally no homework at all, except a short response at the end of the week where you briefly talk about your time in class that week. However, if you actually want to learn improv, this maybe isn't the best class. Class was pretty inconsistent with how you'd receive feedback during scene work, which was unfair. For example, asking questions during an improv scene is frowned upon. When guys in our class asked questions during scene work, even if it was necessary for the flow of the scene, they were castigated for doing so immediately, and experienced frequent interruptions in their scene work from Remo. However, when certain girls in our class would make the exact same mistakes, they were not critiqued or interrupted as frequently in their scene work. Why was this the case? Not sure. As a girl, I noticed these differences.It doesn't feel like you really learn anything about improv in this class. You simply play games and exercises for 2 hours, and in the lucky chance that you get to do a scene, you get interrupted constantly by Remo, which makes it extremely difficult to actually learn how to improve. Certain people have certain strengths when it comes to acting, and it didn't feel like we catered to those strengths as much as we could have. There's the famous Einstein quote about how judging a fish by its ability to climb a tree is an inaccurate way to gauge the fish's abilities, and this metaphor could not be applied more to this class. For example, judging one's comfort and ability to dance to Taylor Swift songs in front of everyone is not an accurate way to see how comfortable someone is dancing and how good they are at dancing. Why not switch up the music playlist, and see the differences of how people dance? In this regard The class heavily catered to women like myself, and felt inconsistent with how normal classes at Harvard operate.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2024: What's so Funny?: Introduction to Improvisational Comedy

best_comment: Take this class if you are interested in exploring the movement and devising aspect of theater. You don't need to be actually physically good at it, but be mentally prepared and engaged. The time spent in this class is definitely not short, 2h45 min in class then another 75min studio lab. Plus dinner, had to stay from 3–745 at the quad for this class. But you get to really bond with your ensemble in the class, and all contribute to a final piece of performance and get to know yourself better in the process as well, very rewarding! Professor brehm is a great professor in teaching style. She's very enthusiastic, gives you a lot of hands–on experience and is very approachable for support and feedback outside of the classroom.

This course has the potential to be amazing. I don't know if this is the best year to judge how it's going to be in the future since Stevie had an unprecedentedly busy year, so he wasn't present for some weeks of the class. If this course changes in the future to focus more on smaller directing pieces rather than group projects, and you get to direct in real time in class while receiving feedback, this will be a great class. Stevie is a great person to learn from.
worse_comment: Do not take this course. The professor shows up occasionally but not frequently. The lack of structure is very frustrating. Half of our class didn't get the opportunity to direct anything and were just actors in plays that other people directed. Certainly a misleading course title and description. The result was lackluster.

best_comment: READ THIS REVIEW IN FULL – I tell it as it is:This is a phenomenal and really fun course. Ana is an absolutely amazing instructor, and the TF will definitely also be awesome (Cassie was wonderful!), and they are both very kind people. This course is a tremendous amount of fun, and you will be pushed to move in front of others and connect with yourself and others in ways that you have never before. If Gaga, namely moving in bizarre and vulnerable ways in front of others, sounds really scary, or if you know you wouldn't be interested in such a thing, do not take this course because it is "easy". First of all, if you are clearly disengaged because you are "too cool" as you look around and don't commit, this will probably be noticed by others and by the teacher and TF, and *gasp* you might not get an A (I don't know how the teacher grades, just a guess that doesn't seem unreasonable). Second of all, forgetting the grade, your lack of effort can affect and bring down the overall vibe, which is just unfair to your peers who are interested in creating a really special, intimate environment where people are happily moving and connecting with one another in a judgement free zone. ASK YOURSELF: Can you envision yourself moving your hips, spine, arms, legs, neck, and face muscles slowly and in different ways as you make eye contact with a stranger? If this sounds terribly unpleasant or **doesn't sound exciting**, in that you don't aspire to be able to do that, I recommend you really ask yourself why you want to take this course and how you reasonably imagine yourself expressing yourself and exploring in an environment where something like that could and will happen.On another note, the founder of Gaga, Ohad Naharin, has been characterized as moving in a "feminine way", and there is an intimacy and softness of heart that is integral to large parts of Gaga. If you in no universe can see yourself delicately (or sometimes aggressively) moving your body in "weird" or unusual ways, I just don't recommend taking the course. Gaga isn't supposed to turn into a rave (where you move weirdly but in a lost, drunken, out of touch way), but a conscious exploration of our bodies, our movement, and how we connect with these and others around us THAT DOESN'T BREAK DOWN IF EVERYONE STOPS AND STARTS STARING AT YOU (This does happen a few times in groups! Can you dance in the middle of a circle with 30 people? Are you EXCITED to do that and be VULNERABLE in that way!! Reflect –– if you were raving and everyone stopped, you would probably become uncomfortable and lose interest. These are fundamentally different ways of moving with others).I loved this course and encourage others to take it if these things sound interesting. And if one is a bit shy, that's natural of course, and you will get more comfortable throughout the course. But I think the most important question is *Do you want to make yourself deeply vulnerable in front of others?*. If not, don't take this course. If you truly want to make yourself vulnerable and are open to exploring intimacy, take this course. I hope you've found this helpful, and I really encourage you to reflect before signing up.
worse_comment: This course is amazing!!!! I always looked forward to going to class. Even if you have no dancing experience or feel nervous about dancing in front of others, you'll feel at home in the class!

best_comment: LIVE YOUR LIFE AND TAKE IT! It was so much fun! You actually just get to dance for most of class time and Jeffrey was so amazing! I'd never taken a jazz dance dance class but it was nice to learn some basic stuff and gain a deeper appreciation for the art form and how my body moves.

course_title: Embodiment: Contemporary Dance Choreography & Boston Dance Theater 001
best_comment: This class is amazing. You learn some great choreography from some incredible choreographers. This class also challenges you as an artist and a dancer. You definitely need some dance background for this course, and you get out what you put in. Highly recommend putting in a lot of effort to gain the most from this class. Love Jessie and her style of teaching. She is so encouraging and tries to help you be creative.

course_title: Directorial Concepts and Set Design of the 20th and 21st Centuries 001
best_comment: This course is one of the best courses I have taken at Harvard! I would highly recommend it. Julia is so enthusiastic and knowledgable about theater. I quite enjoyed learning about different art movements, set designs, and theater types. A great class overall.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2024: Directorial Concepts and Set Design of the 20th and 21st Centuries

best_comment: This is a fantastic course. The assignments are usually short and fun. Jeff and Amanda are an amazing duo that manage to make 3 hour long lectures very interesting!
best_gem_comment: You will get more out of the class if you put in more effort. If you’re not used to design classes, the course will challenge you in a fun way. This is an underrated gem of a class which offers a new type of learning and feels like a relief from reading/writing–heavy or math/science classes.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! it was so inspiring. it nurtured creativity in whatever way that looks to you, but still challenged the way that you present that creativity—it should be precise and thoughtful.  the class environment was lots of fun and right off the bat had a lot of trust (thank you prof stew). i would always leave class with an urge to write, and i walked away with many more songs and a better understanding of how to make my songwriting stronger while still completely staying true to myself and my stories. oh and the feedback sessions were AWESOME—stew gives excellent feedback and you learn a lot from others' writing. also stew is just super chill and so much fun and passionate and he was very very generous with his time and feedback even outside of class. he really gave a lot of thought to each and every student and their work.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: I LOVED THIS CLASS. My favorite so far at Harvard. It was my first acting class. Tania was a great Professor she taught me a lot and always encouraged me after each performance with great feedback.  The class was so much fun I met amazing friends and got to connect with everybody. It was truly one of the best experiences I've had at Harvard.  Its not like any other class you really get to express yourself and find freedom as you perform. Its an environment where you get to be yourself and improve as an actress.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: Just an amazing course. I took it as an English elective, and I never knew I was interested in theater—I couldn't even really name an "Asian–American play" before this class—but it introduced me to so many great works, and I truly looked forward to class every week. The weekly discussions on Canvas were always so interesting already, and continuing them in person with Ju Yon's lecture to guide us really forced me to think deeply about art and identity. She's an amazing professor, she was always happy to meet and discuss, and she gave such helpful feedback on all the assignments. You get such a great mix of students of different backgrounds, both culturally and artistically speaking. It was so fun to step out of my comfort zone and act and dance alongside such talented people during scene presentations—and you couldn't have caught me dead participating in any sort of performance before this class. Take it!

course_title: Before and Beyond Angels: The AIDS epidemic in live arts, culture, and protest 001
best_comment: This is by far one of the best classes I've ever taken at Harvard. It is a true honor and blessing to learn from and work with Debra. The materials you read, watch, listen to; the people you get to meet; the lives you get to become closer to. It's all so incredible. This is a class that makes you think, "Oh, so this is why I'm at Harvard. To learn about something as moving as this." It is a class taught with such warmth, empathy, closeness, care. You will cry, and it will be awesome.

course_title: Theater and Migration: Building Belonging through Participatory Public Arts 001
best_comment: This course is absolutely amazing! The teaching staff are so compassionate and understanding! They truly see you as a human first, a student second. The course material is super engaging and interesting. One of my favorite courses I have ever taken at Harvard.
The conversations with Tania can be interesting and insightful but would recommend having a project already in mind to develop there.

course_title: The Making of a Musical: The Creative Process 001
best_comment: If you have any interest in pursuing musical theater as a career or are curious about how productions are built from adapting source material to bringing it to the stage, there is no better course at Harvard (or perhaps anywhere). The gem of this class is learning from Ryan and Diane, both of whom are practitioners of theater who have built successful careers bringing shows to the stage. They are inspiring, gracious, and incredibly passionate people who articulate musical development extremely well and foster a passion for the arts (and the many careers it contains) in a way I have not previously experienced at Harvard. This is by far one of the most impactful and inspiring classes I have taken and will help build connections with real, practicing artists in the field. To actually prepare for each class, the readings and viewings of musicals can take several hours each week, so the class is not necessarily the easiest if you're looking for a gem. However, if you do the work and participate, this class will soon become one of your favorites. I looked forward to it every week.
worse_comment: Even if you have no experience at all in musical theater, take it!
best_gem_comment: If you have any interest in pursuing musical theater as a career or are curious about how productions are built from adapting source material to bringing it to the stage, there is no better course at Harvard (or perhaps anywhere).
